column2: Chamber music groups devoted to old music usually wind up with a lot of run-of-the-mill baroque material, but the Gotham Baroque Ensemble has come up with some fresh discoveries.

The job of the nation's strategists would be much simpler if they could confidently accept some of the popular notions about missiles. Two notions, in particular, have confused debate over the composition of the nation's strategic deterrent force.
PARIS -- Despite a disappointing tourist season, France has succeeded in putting her tourist accounts in the black for the first time in years.
BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's hockey team crushed Harvard, 11-1, before 11,880 fans at Boston Garden tonight.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- Increased economic co-operation was a special Scandinavian slogan in 1958.
MADRID -- The Spanish galleon of state, which was pounding a year ago into the teeth of an economic gale, is still being buffeted by ill winds.

When James D. Norris Jr. and his partner, Arthur M. Wirtz, formed the International Boxing Club, Norris was regarded by some persons as the man to clean up what his admirers thought was the questionable side of boxing.
DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP) -The auto industry, planning to build about 600,000 cars this month, is continuing Saturday overtime in many of its factories.
Formation of a new investment company in Santa Barbara, Calif., intended to achieve growth in stock market up-trends and to protect capital in market sell-offs was announced today.

PARIS -- The last few weeks of 1958 were enlivened and confused by a long-delayed clash between the European Common Market and those nations that stayed out of it, led by Britain. A conflict, until then half concealed, came into the open.
LONDON -- Britain moved last year from a tight, anti-inflationary credit squeeze to measures designed to encourage economic expansion.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The stockholder contest at the New York Trust Company has resulted in a proposal for revising the banking laws to make boards of directors more representative of investing interests.
Along Eighth Avenue yesterday, boxers, managers, trainers and promoters returned a split decision on the Supreme Court's ruling against the International Boxing Club.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12--Pravda published today the first purported details of the make-up and flight of the cosmic rocket launched ten days ago. The Communist party organ said that the multi-stage rocket had been launched vertically from somewhere inside the Soviet Union.

The diesel locomotive builders of the United States, their skill and prestige enhanced by their tremendous feat of changing over virtually the entire motive power of American railroads from steam, are now looking overseas.
YEARS ago, all babies wore long dresses and looked like girls. Today, all babies wear long trousers and look like boys.
CARACAS, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Mexico swept to victory in the track and field events of the Central American and Caribbean Games today.
In the last month the Fire, Health and Buildings Departments recorded at least thirty-eight violations against the tenement house at 422 West Fifty-third Street.
CAIRO, Jan. 12 British and Egyptian delegations formally began today negotiations that are expected to result in settlement of financial claims arising from the Suez war of 1956.

TOKYO -- Japan's economy is moving out of the recession that followed the 1957 slump in the United States and elsewhere. It caught Japanese industry in a period of over-expansion. After falling back sharply from the peak of prosperity reached in 1956, Japan appears to be set firmly once again on the highroad to well-being in all aspects of her economic life.
The forty-three-story building at 444 Madison Avenue, one of the avenue's tallest, is to be named the Newsweek Building when Newsweek magazine takes occupancy of five floors in the structure May 1.

There is nothing surprising but much that is gratifying in the news that the United States and Turkey are writing out a new mutual security pact. It is expected to guarantee United States assistance in the event that Turkey is the victim of Communist aggression. This is simply putting into concrete terms the so-called "Eisenhower Doctrine" that was designed for the protection of threatened states in the Middle East.
A retired policeman received a suspended sentence yesterday after he had admitted fatally stabbing his common-law wife in a suicide pact.

Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald said yesterday that 850 of the 1,323 pupils suspended between February and June of last year were still under the direct supervision of the Board of Education.
CONAKRY, Guinea -- The West African territory of Guinea won political independence from France last September and found herself face to face with economic reality.
The independent International Longshoremen's Association has filed a formal application for re-admission into the merged labor movement.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 12 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer described the Soviet draft peace treaty for Germany today as "brutal." He warned his critics that there was a danger of weakening Allied support if they did not completely back his rejection of it.
Generally United States companies engaged in foreign trade have viewed the emergence of the new European Common Market with increasing uneasiness.
A four-alarm fire early this morning heavily damaged an auxiliary roundhouse in the Morris Park Yard of the Long Island Rail Road at Richmond Hill, Queens.

HONG KONG -- External pressure to restrict low-priced exports hit this colony hard for the first time last year. Mainly because of strong objections from British textile groups, colony producers were forced to agree reluctantly last November to a voluntary export quota.

AUCKLAND, N. Z. -- New Zealand is taking her first steps to establish an iron and steel industry. The modest start may be the forerunner of a vast development and an important export in trade with Pacific countries.

ROME -- The Italian economy did not do as well last year as in previous ones. The feverish increase of industrial activity that characterized 1956 and most of 1957 was slowed. Agriculture stepped into the breach however, increasing the Italian gross national product 3.5 per cent compared with that of 1957.
It appeared yesterday that the Wednesday and Friday TV fights would continue on much the same basis for the present, despite the Supreme Court de cision against the International Boxing Club.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- (UPI) -Henry Cooper, a London plasterer, became a challenger for the world heavyweight crown tonight by winning the British and Empire titles. Cooper out-pointed Brian London in a fifteen-round fight at Earls Court Arena.
CHRIST CHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Robert Wollard, 18 years old, of the United States, won the international men's free-skating championship at the world rollerskating tournament today.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia -- Optimism is the watchword of commerce and industry in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasland for 1959.

Recommendations by investment services and brokers weighed heavily on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. There were strong gains scattered through the list, but the net change at the close was small.

Extensive increases in school salaries were urged yesterday by Mrs. Rose Russell, legislative representative of the New York Teachers Union. She made the request at a meeting with Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.
The story of the New York City Ballet and a sampling of ballet art are in a display opening today at the New York Public Library.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Legislation to restrict billboards along major state highways was proposed tonight by Senator Harry Kraf, Democrat of the Bronx.

The Port of New York lost overseas general cargo trade during the first six months of last year, but it did so at a slower rate than the nation as a whole. Consequently, during the period, the port's share of that type of foreign commerce rose appreciably.
Eric Johnston warned last night that the United States must undertake coordinated, long-range and expensive economic, political and social programs to meet the threat of Soviet competition.
An increase in trans-Atlantic air fares starting April 1 has been tentatively voted by the scheduled airlines.
" Making Europe."

IN The Mistress Cook (Oxford University Press, 1956) Peter Gray notes that the making of puff paste, the most intricate of doughs, can be as effortless as playing tennis or bridge. Like those diversions, he adds, it is not a game to be learned from a printed page, no matter how lucid the author.

Efforts are being made by the Legal Aid Society to free Joseph J. Hogan, a 52-year-old widower and father of five children, who was recently arrested for escaping from a Federal prison thirty-two years ago.
Seventy-three donors contributed a total of $832.60 yesterday to the fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases.
BUFFALO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Starting tomorrow, Blue Shield of Western New York will allow individual enrollment of persons over 65 in an experimental program.
A new production of Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" will be presented in the early part of next season at the Metropolitan Opera.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The forecast that the President had decided to engage in house-to-house fighting against the rising cycle of inflation began as a "reliable report" in the press, is now semi-official and may become official when the President speaks Wednesday to the National Press Club.
THOSE leaving for warmer, sunnier places might be interested in packing a coordinated wardrobe that is as pretty as it is practical.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 12 -- The Pakistan Government has rejected a Soviet note protesting the proposed bilateral defense agreement being negotiated with the United States.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Firing squads reportedly sent seventy-five bodies sprawling into one grave near Santiago de Cuba today.
Commuters were delayed up to more than two hours yesterday as a result of Saturday's New Haven Railroad wreck at Stamford, Conn.
ALGIERS -- Last year was an eventful one for Algeria's economy

With a dearth of patrons for the tickets it sells in passenger stations, the New York Central Railroad in the last two years has searched for buyers for the stations themselves. It has sold 100 stations but seeks to sell another 300.

PHILOCTETES, for one performance only. Curtain: 2:30 P. M. At the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street. Two versions, by Sophocles and Andre Gide, with Ellis Rabb acting title role in each. Both staged by Stephen Porter for the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy.

Edward R. Murrow will serve as narrator for two separate documentaries on racial integration to be broadcast simultaneously next week. On one program he will be heard discussing integration problems in the North and on the other similar problems in the South.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -United States diplomats hope to sign new economic and defense agreements with Turkey, Iran and Pakistan before the next Baghdad Pact meeting on Jan. 26.

Abe Stark, the City Council President, has taken a constructive public position in recognizing and warning of the damage that may be done the city by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's intemperate hostility toward school construction. He foresees the creation of an unsympathetic reaction in the Legislature at Albany, affecting state aid and also endangering second approval of the $500,000,000 bond issue debt exemption for school construction which must later go to the people in referendum.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Completely integrated metropolitan transportation is an impractical dream, Robert Moses asserted today.

In your issue of Nov. 25 a friendly Canadian, R. M. Fowler, prompted by his distress over the intensity and vehemence of anti-American feelings in Europe, has taken the trouble to point out as a source of irritation to foreign visitors the discourtesy and delay they are subjected to in passing through our customs.

TUNIS -- Tunisia last year appeared to have had a favorable trade balance for the first time in a non-war period. Economists, however, were quick to explain that this did not result from basic improvement in the country's economy.

Irving Sherman, erstwhile friend of former Mayor William O'Dwyer and Frank Costello, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson to thirty days in prison and fined $1,000 for failing to register as an alien.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Two years ago Harold Macmillan became Prime Minister of a discredited Government and a shaken country. Today the Conservatives can scarcely find enough superlatives to praise "Supermac."
The heightened activity in marketing last year was reflected in the number of applications made for trademarks.
The Glaessel Shipping Corporation has announced the opening in April of a new trans-Atlantic passenger service between Italian ports and Montreal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the conviction of a Los Angeles book dealer for possession of an allegedly obscene book entitled "Sweeter Than Life."

If horses could bet on people, they would find past performance more consistent in the grandstand than on the track. Horseplayers in this state accounted last year for attendance and betting figures so similar to those for 1957 that a photo-finish camera would be needed to separate them.

The New York State Bankers Association said yesterday that it would oppose a proposed amendment to the State Insurance Law permitting life insurance companies to act as trustees for pension and retirement funds.

LAGOS, Nigeria -- Expanding trade and a building boom are evidence that Nigeria is developing rapidly. An area the size of Texas and New Mexico combined with a population of 35,000,000, this largest of Britain's remaining colonies will gain its independence on Oct. 1, 1960.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Delegates to the Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization began today what promised to be long consultations on the Western response to the new Soviet bid for an early peace conference on Germany.
With little fanfare but solid results, Belgium continued last year to be one of the focal points of United States industrial investment in Western Europe.
MOSCOW -- Economically speaking, 1958 was almost lost in the shuffle and excitement in the Soviet Union.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company today announced a "ready money" plan that extends to individuals a revolving line of credit.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The four Democrats who will chart party legislative policy held their first strategy conference today. Former Governor Harriman was absent.
The question of sharing our atomic secrets with - France, while very important in itself, is not a problem which can be considered on narrow grounds.

In general, Fidel Castro's victory in Cuba has been hailed as another advance of liberalism and democracy over dictatorship and totalitarianism. Perhaps it is all of that. However, it gives me somehow an uneasy feeling reading in the newspapers that the victorious rebels are placing hundreds of persons -- men and women -- before firing squads after drumhead trials lasting a few minutes.
TAIPEI, Taiwan -- Total output and per capita production of this island rose steadily last year. Under more normal circumstances, Taiwan undoubtedly would be headed for better things.

United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold is just back from one of those journeys which usually result in at least a temporary improvement in the troubled areas he visits. This time he went to the Middle East, spending Christmas in Gaza with the U. N. troops, but visiting also Beirut, Khartoum, Addis Ababa, Jerusalem, Amman, Cairo and Benghazi.
SINGAPORE -- Last year marked a turning point in Singapore's economic history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Treasury bill rate rose this week on both ninety-one-day and 182-day bills, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The rate on $1,600,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills rose substantially from 2,678 per cent last week to 2.808 per cent and that on $400,000,000 of 182-day bills from 2.959 per cent to 3.034 per cent.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Tube Investments, Ltd., a British concern, and the Reynolds Metals Company, of the United States, own about 87 per cent of the outstanding common shares of the British Aluminium Company.

Three members of the crew of the British balloon Small World arrived at New York International Airport yesterday morning from Barbados, B.W.I., where they had landed after crossing the Atlantic from the Canary Islands.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley disclaimed responsibility yesterday for inventing one-way streets. He said that Julius Caesar first used them in ancient Rome.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- A largescale reorganization of the Republican State Committee is in prospect before the end of the month. It is being undertaken at the direct request of Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -President Eisenhower will appear before the National Press Club Wednesday to explain his legislative program and clarify the objectives of his next two years in the White House.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Tenth United States Circuit Court of Appeals at Denver has reversed itself and affirmed that a Federal District Court has no jurisdiction in a union financial accounting case.

In 1956, for the first time in the history of the old school on Gun Hill Road in the Bronx, Evander Childs' senior class dedicated its year book to a teacher -- William Gay. Bill Gay has received many honors in the fifteen years he has been teaching and coaching swimming at Evander.

BONN, Germany -- The 1958 news from West Germany's labor front was good. Labor peace was preserved, employment figures soared to a post-war high, and wages for almost two thirds of this country's 19,300,000 labor force were improved.

DETROIT, June 12 (UPI) -Jim Miller, the defensive line coach at Purdue was named today as the head football coach at the University of Detroit. Miller, who was a co-captain at Purdue in 1941, succeeds Wally Fromhart.
ATHENS -- The new year promises moderately well for Greece, a country with a low standard of living and a perennial unemployment problem that no government has been able to solve.
THE violinist Joseph Fuchs offered a distinguished recital before a capacity audience at Carnegie Hall last night.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 12 -The leader of the People's Republican party appealed to all opposition forces today to "join hands" to restore "political security" in Turkey. He said political insecurity was at the root of the country's economic troubles.

The election of Edmund F. Wagner as chairman of the Seamen's Bank for Savings here was announced yesterday. He will succeed on Feb. 1 John D. Butt, who will retire Jan. 31. Mr. Butt will continue as a trustee of the bank.

LISBON, Portugal -- An industrial movement has begun in Portugal, where adverse weather, a dwindling market and receding prices have eclipsed the country's traditional staples and made mechanization a necessity.
Mayor Wagner apparently narrowed the field yesterday from which he is expected to choose the city's "one big new tax" for 1959-60.
ACCRA, Ghana -- This new nation, born March 6, 1957, out of the former British Gold Coast colony, is having severe economic growing pains.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Jan. 12 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan topped Jerry Lewis, the comedian, in an exchange of Hollywood fun at the Paramount studios today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee will commission nine non-government experts to recommend an overhauling of the Taft-Hartley law.

Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission, said yesterday that the "nation that wins the next war will be the one best prepared to withstand the effects of a nuclear attack."
MOSCOW -- The Soviet Union with its vast system of collective and state-owned farms and with millions of acres of newly plowed "virgin lands" produced more grain last year than ever before.

On Saturday President Eisenhower and his aides are to meet with Soviet Deputy Premier Mikoyan in a "little summit conference" to discuss the East-West conflict which for the present is focused on Berlin and Germany, though the larger stakes are the whole of Europe and peace itself.

CLAYTON, Ala., Jan. 12 -State Circuit Judge George C. Wallace today defied a Federal court order that he throw open the voter registration records of Barbour and Bullock Counties to the Civil Rights Commission.
JAKARTA, Indonesia -- Goodby, 1958, and good riddance.

GENEVA, Jan. 12 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union approached agreement today on the wording of a fifth article for their proposed treaty banning nuclear tests without coming to grips with the key issues.

The New York Central Railroad, which last week had second thoughts on its proposal to marry the Pennsylvania Railroad, denied yesterday that it had left the bride at the church. However, Central's president, Alfred E. Perlman, indicated that the groom was looking around for a better match.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, Jan. 12 (Reuters) -- A star-studded company, including Dame Edith Evans, Sir Laurence Olivier, Charles Laughton and Paul Robeson, has been assembled for this year's 100th season of the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre, it was announced here today.

RABAT, Morocco -- Like other underdeveloped countries, Morocco is in dire need of capital for the development of her resources. French investments began to decline after 1952 and reached a low with Morocco's independence in 1956, when about 100,000,000,000 francs ($238,000,000) fled the country.

The Export-Import Bank of Washington (Eximbank), overseas lending arm of the Treasury, announced yesterday the issuance of a credit of $12,500,000 to a Brazilian iron mining concern to permit it to double its production.

NEW DELHI, India -- This is the year of make or break for India's Second Five-Year-Plan. The task for 1959 is to move ahead decisively toward the attainment of the plan's reduced goals by a prodigious voluntary effort on the part of all.

LITTLE ROCK, Jan. 12 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked Federal District Court today to nullify the Arkansas law under which Gov. Orval E. Faubus closed Little Rock's four public high schools.
BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- East German commentators gave three cheers today for Premier Otto Grotewohl's diplomatic achievements in Arab lands and speculated on his chances of making good in India, too.
A bank in Jamaica, Queens, was robbed of $2,000 yesterday by a man who passed a note to a teller in which he threatened to explode a gasoline bomb. The thief escaped.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan -- In an hour's flight from the Ethiopian border to Khartoum, the principal factor of the Sudan's economy unrolls like a green carpet under the wings of the big airliner.

SAIGON, Vietnam -- Last year was a period of recession and diminished economic growth for the countries of Southeast Asia. As the year closed, however, prospects appeared brighter, for most countries in the area looked forward to improved economic expansion in 1959.

AMSTERDAM -- The Dutch economy reached the bottom of the recession in the second half of the last year and it is generally the opinion that, barring worsening of the international political situation, the economy will improve this year.

DUBLIN -- Ireland closed her account for 1958 with a deficit in her balance of payments, but not of a size to cause concern. Despite a bad harvest there are many encouraging signs that the republic is hard at work creating a healthy economy.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark -An increase in foreign exchange holdings was a prime factor in the favorable economy of Denmark last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Secretary of Welfare Arthur S. Flemming appointed a new advisory council on public assistance today.
The nation's steel scrap industry must stabilize both the quality of its output and the market demand if it is to survive, the president of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel said yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Belgium -- Last year had a sobering effect on Belgium's economy.

DUBLIN Jan. 12 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera refused today pleas for the release of members of the illegal Irish Republican Army detained in Ireland and asserted that its activities were "worse than futile."
Soviet Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan will lunch with Wall Street bankers here tomorrow at his request. It was said yesterday that the get-together will be entirely social, not financial.
Houston, Tex., has designated Jan. 28 for the sale of $20,245,000 of general obligations to finance public improvements. Dated March 1, 1959, the bonds will come due serially from 1960 to 1984.
NOW comes the plain proposal, publicly advanced, that fishermen and hunters report and help prosecute vandals and hoodlums among them who are driving landowners to post their property.

Although the tip that led to the return of the kidnapped Chionchio infant came from an anonymous telephone caller, the police search for her was one of the most intensive in the recent history of the department.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Senator J. Allen Frear introduced legislation today that could save du Pont Company stockholders an estimated $700,000,000 in taxes.

We'll concede it's not clubby to take a poke at your own kind, but there's just no dodging the issue. The baseball writers certainly did not overly distinguish themselves with the manner in which they handled, or manhandled, their recent rookie-of-the-year selections for both the American and National Leagues.
BEIRUT -- Lebanon is making a remarkably rapid recovery from the ravages of civil fighting, sabotage and political strikes that harassed the country from May 9 to Oct. 15.
Hearings have begun here on charges that six leading makers of antibiotics engaged in price-fixing and other improper practices.

TARGUIST, Morocco, Jan. 12 -- Using artillery, tanks and rocket-carrying planes, the Moroccan Army has won an important first battle in its effort to subdue a threatening tribal rebellion in the Rif Mountains of northern Morocco.
OKINAWA -- The American-administered Ryukyu Islands, including the huge United States military base of Okinawa, were converted to a complete United States dollar economy last Sept. 16.

MELBOURNE, Australia -Business generally was steady in Australia last year. However, there was some feeling of frustration over the pace of expansion because of reduced wool and metal prices and a deterioration in the balance of overseas payments.
HONG KONG -- In all fields, 1958 was a year of great economic expansion and drastic social change in Communist China.
KARACHI, Pakistan -- The big change of 1958 was Pakistan's new determination to live within her means and as soon as possible to pay her own way.

Manhattan's avenues and cross streets began taking on a seafaring look yesterday, particularly in the Fifty-ninth Street sector, where the New York Coliseum made ready for the forty-ninth National Motor Boat Show, which will open Friday night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Democratic House leaders moved today to gain firm control over the Committee on Education and Labor.
BEIRUT -- The Middle East countries enter the new year with the hope that it will be better than the last.

WHEN Nat Fleischer was 12 years old, a kindly neighbor on the lower East Side took the shiny-eyed youngster to Tuckahoe to see Terrible Terry McGovern knock out Pedlar Palmer for a world championship. That's when Nat was bitten by the fight bug. His condition has improved not a whit over the intervening sixty years.
Mayor Wagner asserted yesterday that Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy had a "blank check" on all matters of police discipline.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The Massey-Ferguson Company, Canadian farm machinery manufacturer, is negotiating for the tractor interests of Britain's Standard Motor Company.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -Anastas I. Wikoyan said today that the Soviet Union had abandoned the kind of pure communes recently set up in Communist China because it was found that they would not work without an incentive system.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Administration was urged today to undertake "a vigorous development program" to achieve economic nuclear power in the United States within ten years.

CAIRO, Jan. 12 -- The Arab financial institution for economic development came into being today when Libya subscribed to its charter and raised the level of stock subscriptions to more than 75 per cent of the projected total.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 12 -- Belgian authorities in the Congo arrested two African mayors and banned a political party today on the eve of a declaration on self-rule for the territory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -A sweeping antitrust decree against the country's top professional boxing promoters was affirmed today by the Supreme Court.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller announced tonight that he was considering asking the Legislature for increases in the state income tax and the levy on cigarettes.
TEHERAN, Iran -- Iranian manufacturing made heavy gains in 1958 with a Governmentsponsored shift from public to private ownership chalking up corresponding headway.

THE Bell Telephone Hour, for so many years one of the more civilized fixtures of radio, re-emerged last night on television in the first of four monthly presentations over Channel 4. The program was a varied delight offered with impeccable taste.
ANKARA, Turkey -- Most Turks are remembering 1958 as the year that brought hope and promise to their country's vexed economy.
A stout blonde widow who had borne eight children was held yesterday for the kidnapping on Jan. 2 of a newly born baby from St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn.

There is unrest in the Belgian Congo, where riots have caused the lives of more than thirty persons. The trouble was evoked by the 50,000 unemployed Congolese -- a paradox in a country that is basically and potentially prosperous.
South Africa had a generally favorable economic year in 1958. Major sectors showed increased activity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -A sweeping antitrust decree against the country's top professional boxing promoters was affirmed today by the Supreme Court.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller announced tonight that he was considering asking the Legislature for increases in the state income tax and the levy on cigarettes.

THE Bell Telephone Hour, for so many years one of the more civilized fixtures of radio, re-emerged last night on television in the first of four monthly presentations over Channel 4. The program was a varied delight offered with impeccable taste.
Events today: Gordon Jones, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, 12:30 P. M.; "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Boston Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The State Conference of Mayors opposed today any court reorganization plan that would eliminate city and village courts or take judicial budgeting out of local hands.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- This country is in the midst of a deep depression. Coffee, the principal export item, suffered from a drop of more than 25 per cent in price and a greatly reduced crop. Political strikes and revolutions have damaged the tourist income.
TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called on the Legislature today to find without delay an acceptable solution to the critical problem of rapid transit for commuters.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company Inc., will raise the wholesale price of heating oils, Diesel fuel oil and kerosene by four-tenths to a half cent a gallon along the Eastern seaboard today. In New York City, the heating oil price will advance to 11.5 cents a gallon from 11 cents.

The first annual report of the Public Review Board of the United Automobile Workers Union will be a historical document in the annals of labor union democracy. Composed of a leader in each of the three religious faiths, a university president, two judges and a professor of economics, the board is, in effect, the Supreme Court of the 1.3-million-member U.A.W. -- the first of its kind among the biggest American unions.
American Airlines, Inc., may be in the market sooon with a new equity type offering, according to William J. Hogan, executive vice president-finance.
SANTIAGO, Chile -- The state oil monopoly, Empresa Nacional del Petroleo, plans to expand installations this year.
PEIPING, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- Communists in the vast region of Sinkiang in northwestern China were reported today to have been told to struggle against "chauvinism and localism" in that area.
OTTAWA -- An accelerated program of road and highway construction is being planned for the next ten years.
VANCOUVER, B. C. -- An industrialist, making the best prediction he could for the economy of British Columbia, said: "Some decisions will be made in 1959 that will be bright for the future."

The Massachusetts Port Authority announced today plans to issue about $72,000,000 of revenue bonds on or about Feb. 3. The operation is designed to finance assumption of control and management of bridge, airport and dock facilities now under the supervision of other agencies of the state.

HALIFAX, N. S. -- Canada's Atlantic provinces must soon pick a new way of economic life. New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland can no longer depend for their prosperity upon fishing, lumber cutting, farming and mining.
Changes in the top management of the H. J. Heinz Company, international food processing concern, were approved yesterday by the directors.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -Gains in the grain futures markets on the Board of Trade here today were scarce but fairly substantial. Most setbacks were held to small fractions of a cent.
GEORGE BURNS appears to have worked out his television problems very nicely.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Coast Guard rescued eighteen men from a grounded tanker in ice-choked Chesapeake Bay early today. The ice-breaker Chinook took the crew off the small tanker Samuel H. Herron after the vessel went aground in seven feet of water about one mile off Tolchester Beach, in the Upper Bay.
TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Wesley L. Lance, president of the State Senate, called today for the creation of a new state department whose primary aim would be to keep commuter railroad lines in business.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam -Engineering surveys have begun for the $150,000,000 hydroelectric power project that the Aluminum Company of America and the Surinam Government will build in the Brokopondo area, eighty miles north of this Surinam River port.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 13 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus proposed in his third-term inaugural speech today that Arkansas allow students to collect tuition payments rather than attend public schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Secretary Arthur S. Flemming announced encouraging results today in preliminary tests of a new pain-killing drug, NIH 7519. He called the drug "ten times as effective as morphine, fifty times as effective as codeine."

ATLANTA, Jan. 13 (AP) -The defense said today that it expected to prove George Bright innocent of the Oct. 12 bombing of the Atlanta Jewish Temple. It named one of the state's key witnesses as the actual dynamiter.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -The voters elected Uruguay's first conservative Government of this century as last year drew to a close in the midst of economic unrest and growing trade dependence on Communist markets.
OTTAWA (Canadian Press) -- Lower shipments of nickel and crude petroleum contributed to a reduction in Canada's exports during November, the Bureau of Statistics has reported.
Jamaica, British West Indies, the best place to go for a planter's punch, reports growing success in enticing industry to her sun-washed shores.

An early dinner, a fashion show with an international flavor and dancing are on the agenda for the fete being planned to benefit the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Inc. It will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Feb. 10.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 (AP) -Aides put in two hours of fancy footwork before the State's new athletic commissioner was sworn in today.

" Stephen A. Douglas: Defender of the Union," a biography by Gerald M. Capers, will be published by Little, Brown on Feb. 9. Although the focus is on Douglas' life, the author also gives an analysis of the events that led to the Civil War and the role Douglas played in them.
Last year Bermuda had its most prosperous year since the British colony was founded in 1609. The Atlantic island wound up 1958 with a surplus of 194372, equal to $544,241.
TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Following are excerpts from Gov. Robert B. Meyner's annual message delivered today before the New Jersey Legislature:
ASUNCION, Paraguay -- The guarani held firm last year as one of the world's soundest currencies despite adverse trade terms, a loss of exchange reserves and labor agitation.
Actors Equity Association announced yesterday that it had suspended Errol Flynn on charges of "conduct unbecoming a member" of the union.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Governor Rockefeller named today as assistant press secretary the man who wrote many speeches attacking him in last fall's campaign.

Production of raw steel in this country rose to 8,713,000 net tons last month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. That compared with 8,569,318 the previous month and was the second-largest monthly output of the year, exceeded only by the 8,839,778 tons poured in October.

Two months ago the results of the 1958 Congressional elections were interpreted everywhere as a sweeping victory for liberalism, particularly in the Senate. Down to defeat went Mr. Bricker and other "stalwarts" on the Republican side. Into the Senate came new Democrats from the North and West, younger men with a lively interest in such matters as the cause of civil liberties.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Missile workers seeking representation by the Teamsters Union tried to hold an organizational meeting today out were ordered off Government property by the Air Force.

TORONTO, Ont. -- James W. Kerr, who last month took over the reins of Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., is the youngest president in the comparatively short and stormy history of the company that built and now operates the world's longest natural gas pipeline.

SAN SALVADOR -- El Salvador is again pushing construction of the Littoral Highway, which skirts the nation's entire Pacific coast from the Guatemalan border to a point near the port of La Union on the Gulf of Fonseca.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -Britain's trade deficit, the excess of imports over exports, was the lowest last year since 1950, the Board of Trade announced today.
The new forty-nine star American flag -- which does not become official until July 4 -- was unfurled yesterday at the Seagram Building.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Rudy LaRousso tossed in 27 points and Walt Sosnowski contributed 18 tonight as Dartmouth swept to its fourth straight Ivy League basketball victory by defeating Harvard, 74 -- 56.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- A ban on cash prizes in all raffles and a 400 per cent increase in the maximum retail value of raffle awards were recommended today by the State Legalized Games of Chance control Commission.
Canada snapped out of the recession ahead of the United States, according to spokesmen for the Committee of Canadian Investment Companies.

Anastas I. Mikoyan arrived in the city last night under tight police security arrangements to see that no outbreaks marred his visit. The Soviet official, a First Deputy Premier, landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 7:54 P. M. His flight from Los Angeles, on a United Airlines plane was half an hour late.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -The Honduran economic program for 1959 "includes all of the developmental activity possible within the framework of a balanced budget," according to Jorge Bueso Arias, chairman of the National Economic Council.

Three apartment houses occupying a plot 125 by 100 feet at 335 to 343 East. Fifty-fifth Street, between First and Second Avenues, have been purchased by Harry Horwitz, realty operator. The buyer was born in a private dwelling at 339 East Fifty-fifth Street before construction of the present buildings on the site.
LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Bolivia's economic stabilization program survived last year a sharp loss of income from tin exports and a wave of internal political and labor conflicts.

Seymour M. Wilson, the former chief accountant of the city's Real Estate Bureau, received a suspended sentence yesterday on his plea of guilty to a grand larceny charge. He stole between $38,000 and $40,000 from the city and has made restitution in the amount of $13,600.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Following is the text of the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:
OTTAWA (Canadian Press) -- Twenty-two Canadian uranium producers have urged the Federal Government to take steps designed to assure markets after the expiration of present contracts in 1962 and 1963.
The "Hallmark Hall of Fame" series has completed casting of lead roles for "Berkeley Square" by the selection of Jeannie Carson and Edna Best to star with John Kerr, who was announced earlier.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Two young Americans studying agriculture in Israel were seized by Syrians today near the border on the northern tip of Lake Galilee, an Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman said.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 10 -The latest unemployment figures from Istanbul and other industrial centers are causing some alarm among Turkish officials and other observers.
TORONTO -- The Toronto Stock Exchange began 1958 on a gloomy note. That carried over from the latter part of 1957. But the atmosphere was broken by a steady rise in industrial offerings.
Prices of cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points up to 2 points off yesterday. Prices moved in a narrow range. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
Concern last year over economic conditions in Latin America was reflected in an extensive compilation of comparative data on the area by the United States Department of Commerce.

TORONTO -- Dr. Hans T. F. Lundberg, pioneer in prospecting from the air and one of the world's top stamp collectors, estimates he has found ore worth $5,000,000,000 in twentyeight countries. After a discovery, he has rarely lingered long enough to profit by its exploitation.
OTTAWA -- For Canada 1958 was a year of economic contradictions and paradoxes. At its end the recession seemed to have passed. The outlook was neither bright nor dark but merely gray.
CARACAS, Jan. 13 (AP) -Mexican swimmers continued their mastery in the Central American and Caribbean Games today.

The nation's merchants were urged yesterday to save downtown business districts lest entire cities decay. They were warned, too, that action was necessary at once to stop the losses of downtown shopping areas throughout the country.
A record outlay of $422,152,414 for the operation of the city's schools in the fiscal year starting July 1 was urged yesterday by the Board of Education's finance committee.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The British Government strongly endorses the tough position taken by the United States Administration in exchanges with Anastas I. Mikoyan on Germany, including Berlin, authoritative sources said today.
The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago borrowed $20,000,000 yesterday on fifty-year debentures at a net interest cost of 4.592 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The same $34,500 a year Manhattan judicial plum that strained relations between former Gov. Averell Harriman and Carmine G. De Sapio appeared today to be responsible for a mild but quickly healed rift between Governor Rockefeller and the New York County Republican organization.

Tourism is now Mexico's third largest industry and earner of precious American dollars. It is exceeded only by coffee and cocoa. It brings in almost $600,000,000 a year. The number of visitors runs to about 612,000.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 13 -The Norfolk City Council voted 6 to 1 today to halt all public schooling above the sixth grade, effective with the start of the new semester on Feb. 2.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua -- This country has an economy based on two main agricultural products -- cotton and coffee. Since the prices of both commodities fell throughout the world in 1958 the year was a disappointing one. The outlook for 1959 is not favorable, since there is no indication of a price upturn in either cotton or coffee.
A resolution calling on the state to legalize and to tax off-track betting on horse races was introduced yesterday in the City Council. It was referred to the General Welfare Committee.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13 -- A foretaste of commercial jet air travel to South America was provided by a United States Air Force KC-135 that streaked here today from Tampa, Fla., in 10 hours and 10 minutes.

At stockholder meetings of industrial and other companies in which its trust accounts own shares, the First National City Bank of New York occasionally votes these shares against management. This was reported yesterday by the chairman of the bank's trust affiliate.
QUEBEC -- Year-round navigation to Quebec, long a dream, is becoming a reality at this St. Lawrence River port.

Now that we finally have the information booth at Forty-third Street and Broadway, but on the wrong corner, I want to thank the Convention and Visitor's Bureau and civic group officials who made this important tourist necessity possible.

May I be allowed to add to Harrison Salisbury's comments in your issue of Jan. 11? Mr. Salisbury states that "the seeming discourtesy of the State Department, the constant harassment by Hungarian pickets * * * have produced a barrage of negative publicity for the United States in Europe."

Mr. Mikoyan is mistaken if he thinks that only the Hungarians are outraged by his American campaign tour for international communism and that he can dismiss these demonstrators as "an unimportant group that does not express the true body of the American people." The Hungarian demonstrators represent, in very truth, the troubled conscience of the American people.

Alfred C. Thompson put in a busy day yesterday. Mr. Thompson, a former boxer who heads a department store, arose early to attend sessions of the National Retail Merchants Association convention at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

MONTREAL -- The question, which came first, the chicken or the egg, is being posed here in connection with the mushrooming of industrial and residential developments in the Montreal area, and the radical changes in the bridge, street and highway network.

Changes in the organization of the Socony Mobil Oil Company were announced yesterday by Albert L. Nickerson, president and chief executive officer. They involved the formation of two new operating divisions and a reasssignment of responsibilities for corporate affairs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Secretary of State Dulles said today he was "feeling good."

News had a gloomy cast yesterday and stocks on the New York Stock Exchange lost about $1,400,000,000 of their aggregate market value. Most of the declines were unimportant but occasional issues made pronounced moves.
Overwhelming support to give the Metropolitan Regional Council permanent legal status developed yesterday at a public hearing at City Hall.

All was uncertainty among members of the International Boxing Club and of the Madison Square Garden Corporation yesterday, a full day after the United States Supreme Court had ordered the dissolution of the boxing unit.

BUFFALO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A court order was sought by the Federal Government today to require a paving company official to say whether he had used $41,900 in company funds to pay off city official for paving contracts.

CALGARY, Alberta -- Natural gas export projects to serve the El Paso system in the Western United States, and also the California area, with Alberta gas were still being developed in Alberta at the end of 1958.

TORONTO -- The Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario put into operation late last year an electronic computing center, which, among other distinctions, boasts the greatest number of input points ever hooked to a data-processing system.
HAVANA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Fidel Castro gave Cuba's United States-backed multi-million dollar gambling industry a go-ahead tonight, but with tight strings attached.
MADRID, Jan. 13 -- The United States and Spain signed a new economic aid agreement today.
Canada executed a daring stroke in debt management last year -- one likely to be remembered with gratification if inflation should present a serious threat again.

Nine Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen in the Springfield Gardens area of Queens joined yesterday in an appeal to real estate agents to end high-pressure tactics aimed at inducing white homeowners to sell their properties to Negroes.

Early yesterday morning Edwin G. Zabriskie passed quietly away in one of the institutions he had served so well for more than fifty years. A third-generation physician, graduate of Erasmus Academy, Columbia College and Long Island College Hospital, he did graduate work in Berlin and Paris. Returning to this city, he entered and remained in the new and still most frustrating of medical disciplines, neurology and psychiatry.
A pledge of "enthusiastic support" for plans to improve Fourth Avenue was given yesterday by Borough President Hulan E. Jack to a group of business men.

CUMBERLAND, MD., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Bishop James E. Walsh of the Roman Catholic Church, who has been missing in Communist China, was reported today to have been "arrested for infringement of Chinese law."

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -The president of the Pennsylvania Railroad said here today the possibility no longer existed that his company would consider a merger with the New York Central Railroad. He added that he saw no real advantage to coordinating the facilities of the two lines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Pentagon has told Congress that the extension of the draft is "absolutely imperative to the security of the nation at this time and for the foreseeable future."
Four persons were injured last night when a man wielding an axe broke into a midtown hotel room and assertedly attacked its three occupants.

Hal Roach Studios has absorbed the dozen film-distribution outlets of Distributors Corporation of America. The announcement was made yesterday by Hal Roach Jr., president of the producing company, and Fred J. Schwartz, president of D. C. A. The latter is an importer of foreign films as well as a producing organization.
HAVANA, Jan. 13 (AP) -Cuba's sugar-production quota for 1959 was set today at 5,800,000 tons -- 200,000 tons more than last year.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 13 -- A silence here that scarcely concealed official shock greeted Secretary of State Dulles' statement today that free elections were not the only method of bringing about the reunification of Germany.

The menu for lunch that the First National City Bank will serve today for Anastas I. Mikoyan, First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, has not been announced. Probably no attempt will be made by the hosts to slip in as a dessert "sleeper" the $39,000,000 claim that the bank has been nursing against Russia since the bank's branch offices in Russia were taken over by the Soviets during the 1918 Revolution.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was still digging out from under yesterday, but managed to cut down delays caused by the freight wreck at Stamford Saturday.

KENILWORTH, N. J., Jan. 13 -- For the first time in its sixty-one years, the Rahway Valley Railroad faces a strike threat. One-quarter of its employes are threatening to walk out on Jan. 21 unless their demand for a pay increase is met.
George Meany, president of the merged labor movement, said yesterday that he had not yet received a formal application for membership from the independent International Longshoremen's Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A group of Eastern Republicans announced today that they were ready to introduce strong civil rights legislation that would test the effectiveness of the Senate's new filibuster curb.
HAVANA, Jan. 13 -- Fidel Castro declared today that the revolutionary courts would function "until all criminals of the Batista regime are tried."
PANAMA -- The output of Panama's two top industries, bananas and shrimp, fell during 1958, but agriculture and light industry for the most part continued to expand.
The giant United Automobile Workers is still beset by financial headaches. It has just ordered a new cut of $425,000 a year in its operating budget to get itself out of the red.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- At year's end, no steps had been taken to implement President Mario Echandi's earlier statement that he intended to buy out the United States-owned Power and Light Company here, to nationalize it. Informed sources were of the opinion that no further moves in the matter were likely soon.
Youth Squad policemen are being pressured into making more arrests through a point system that gives them credit for arrests, a citizens' committee report charged here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- If too many political "executions" follow the Republican leadership revolution, no Republican party will be left, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. warned today.

American Foreign Power Company, Inc., is backing its faith in Latin America to the tune of about $100,000,000 a year for at least the next four years. This is the same amount the big holding company spent last year in the eleven nations where its operating subsidiaries are situated.
The fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases received sixty-seven gifts yesterday totaling $1,812.57.
TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- The man who gaveled the opening session of the New Jersey State Senate to order today might have been as comfortable if he had used a baseball bat.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Mayor Wagner offered a program today to save and improve commuter railroad service in the New York metropolitan area.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -Ford Motor Company late today confirmed reports that it planned to enter the new-car financing field.

HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A Negro woman who campaigned on a platform calling for peaceful integration of schools took office last night as a board member of the South's largest segregated school district.
Albert Ehlers, Inc., will switch its coffee account at the end of the month from Dowd, Redfield Johnstone, Inc., to the Co-Ordinated Advertising Corporation.

THE influence of the North American Indian today is not confined to the reservation. This is evidenced by the growing popularity of Indian designs in home furnishings. And tomorrow, this interest will be furthered with the opening of modernized galleries at the Museum of the American Indian.

The recent arbitrary criticism of the Mayor's excellent practice of appointing committees to analyze municipal problems and recommend action prompts this letter, as well as the report in The Times of Dec. 8.
CAIRO, Jan. 13 -- A difference arose today in negotiations between Britain and the United Arab Republic for a settlement of financial problems that developed from the Suez war two years ago.
GENEVA, Jan. 13 -- The United States and Britain assured the Soviet Union today they did not want a czar running the proposed organization for controlling a nuclear test ban.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -The Navy disclosed today that it had armed the planes of two aircraft carriers of the Seventh Fleet with the Sparrow III guided missile. The Seventh Fleet is in the Western Pacific area.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- France decreed tonight the widest measures of clemency taken for Algerian rebels since they began fighting more than four years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Big national Republican campaign groups spent about $1,000,000 more than their Democratic counterparts, final reports showed today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -The freshman class of the Eighty-sixth Congress turned out forty-seven strong to go to school today.
BUFFALO, Jan. 13 (UPI) -Ray Bluth of St. Louis clung to a twenty-two-pin lead over Lou Campi of Dumont, N. J., tonight in the fourth day of the eighteenth annual All-Star bowling tournament.

CLAYTON, Ala., Jan. 13 -- The grand juries of Barbour and Bullock Counties invited the Civil Rights Commission today to examine voter registration records turned over to them by State Circuit Judge George C. Wallace.
MONTREAL -- The biggest news made by the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges during 1958 was the official announcement that a merger with the Toronto Stock Exchange was being studied.
ATLANTA, Jan. 13 -- Gov. Samuel Ernest Vandiver pledged in his inaugural address today to uphold the state's racial segregation traditions.

BUENOS AIRES -- The stormy course followed by Argentina during 1958 brought the country at year end face-toface with a decision: whether to tighten its belt to end the continuing cycle of inflation and political strife.
SANTIAGO, Chile -- The new Administration headed by President Jorge Alessandri plans drastic measures to correct the country's faltering economy.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Nearly 13,000,000 bags of unsold surplus coffee -- worth close to $650,000,000 at current average prices -- filled the warehouses of the Brazilian Government at the end of last year. And new shipments of the beans that could find no foreign markets, despite lower prices, continued to cascade into overflowing storage bins.

Moscow's ways grow ever more mysterious. Yesterday's events provide a case in point. Pravda appeared with still another denunciation of the so-called "anti-party group" of which Mr. Molotov has been a leading member. Yet diplomatic reports from The Hague and Moscow told more insistently that the Soviet Union had proposed the name of Mr. Molotov as Soviet Ambassador to the Netherlands.

QUITO, Ecuador -- Important steps were taken by Ecuador last year in the field of basic development. Meanwhile the nation's economy showed notable stability in comparison with the situation in most of South America.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- The Government announcement followed two days of riots last week in the Belgian Congo capital of Leopoldville.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Dr. Hans A. Bethe, a member of the President's Science Advisory Committee, said today it was still possible to develop an effective atomic test inspection system despite newly discovered difficulties in detecting underground explosions.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- A Chrysler engineer predicted today that the car of the future would not be bigger and that it could not become much lower.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. -- There are few frontiers left for men to challenge in North America, without plunging into the Arctic, but Newfoundland is one. Formerly the oldest colony of Britain, it is now Canada's tenth province.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association charged Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday with "slanderous and unwarranted accusations" against its officials.
Anastas I. Mikoyan brought his one-man Soviet goodwill mission into New York City last night after a week's gruelling transcontinental campaign.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Last year was a period of political transition. The economy was subjected to all the uncertainties and hesitancies attendant on an election year. Despite that, trade, both internal and international, continued to improve, the foreign-exchange balance was strong at year's end, and the cost of living index had risen only its normal annual few points.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Administration was reported today to have decided on Philip W. Bonsal, a career diplomat, as the new United States Ambassador to Cuba.

Top management changes were announced yesterday by the Tri-Continental Corporation and its subsidiary, TriContinental Financial Corporation, and the Broad Street Group of mutual funds -- Broad Street Investing Corporation, National Investors Corporation and Whitehall Fund, Inc. J. W. Seligman Co. is sponsor of the investment companies.

A contract for the purchase of the six-story apartment building at 47-50 Forty-first Street, Sunnyside, Queens, has been resold by Jacob Gruber to an investing client of Albert Fribourg, attorney. The property, 170 by 100 feet, contains sixty apartments.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Roadblocks were cleared today for an early merger of the New York City central bodies of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Representative Leslie C. Arends of Illinois, a leader in the unsuccessful fight to retain Joseph W. Martin Jr. as House minority leader, was recommended unanimously today to remain as the Republican whip.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- plan to transfer the 1960 Navy-Notre Dame football game from Baltimore to Philadelphia was symied tonight by the Baltimore Park Board.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Members of the United Auto Workers in the United States and Canada will vote later this week on a proposed three-year contract with Electric AutoLite Corporation.

MEXICO CITY -- For the Republic of Mexico the year 1958 was one of bustling industrialization, great economic activity, large-scale road building, all of it dominated by a Presidential campaign and a change in administrations.
The country's only merchant ship ever to operate as a seagoing "roll-on, roll-off" cargo carrier is about to be turned over to the Navy for military use.

ELLIOT LAKE, Ont. -- This community of about 17,000 people is a town with a very brief history and an uncertain future. Only four years ago there was nothing here but wilderness. Now there is a planned community with all the amenities to be found in much larger and older cities.
TOKYO, Jan. 13 -- The education of an Empress began today for Miss Michiko Shoda, the commoner who will marry Crown Prince Akihito of Japan in April.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 11 -- The Yugoslavs are keeping a wary eye on the beginnings of the European common market and the accompanying financial changes in the member nations. So far the Yugoslavs have not been able to decide whether the market will hurt them more than it helps.
REGINA, Sask. -- The starting of work on the $182,000,000 South Saskatchewan river irrigation and hydroelectric project was the most important single event in the province last year.
Harriman Ripley Co., Inc. and Wood, Gundy Co., Inc. are offering today $75,000,000 of Province of Ontario 4 3/4 per cent debentures, due in 1984, at 98.50, to yield about 4.85 per cent.
BROOKLYNITES can put away their passports and leave their decorators behind when they go shopping for Danish modern furnishings. For Abraham Straus has brought the style to the borough in abundance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Election to the Senate has cost Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and an associate $41,666.67 in a canceled law contract with the Republic of Guatemala. Senator Dodd gave it up voluntarily.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- A United States Embassy spokesman protested formally against the "invasion" by two Korean policemen seeking a United States Information Agency cameraman. The cameraman took pictures of a clash between the police and antigovernment demonstrators today, reliable sources reported.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Despite the world-wide slump in coffee prices in 1958, exporters and producers here do not seem to be alarmed. Costa Rica produces mostly high grade types of coffee that are sought for blending and then command premium prices. The motto here seems to be: "We can always sell our coffee."
North American production of newsprint turned downward last year for the first time in five years. There were prospects of better times in 1959, however.

WARSAW, Jan. 10 -- The liveliest debate in Warsaw today had to do with cutting the suit to fit the cloth. The debaters -and they are getting pretty excited about it -- were not tailors but architects.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- The Compania de Acero del Pacifico, Chile's steel enterprise, is bent on making progress in 1959 through substantial new investments. And it is doing so notwithstanding the fact that net profit for the year ended June 30, 1958, was down to $1,663,373.32 from $5,446,923.69 in the preceding period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Secretary of State Dulles said today the United States and its allies were trying to find new proposals for solving the problem of Germany and meeting the Soviet challenge on that issue.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 13 -- Textron, Inc., disclosed today that its West Coast subsidiary, Hawaiian Textron, Inc., was discontinuing its shipping operations.

SAN SALVADOR -- How to meet the situation resulting from the drop in world coffee prices is the chief problem confronting El Salvador as 1959 starts. The Government is seeking means of insuring the continued prosperity of this tiny Central American republic, which normally depends on coffee for 85 per cent of its export income.
The Air Force is accelerating the development of a new category of strategic weapon -- the air-launched ballistic missile.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The United States moved today to avert a bitter dispute at the first assembly of the United Nations Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization over membership on the agency's Maritime Safety Committee.

LECH-AM-ARLBERG, Austria, Jan. 13 -- A new political generation is rising to prominence in Europe and as it approaches power it brings with it changed ideas. This is especially true in France, West Germany and Italy, traditional bellwethers of the Continent west of Russia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- State Department officials said today there were indications that the Soviet authorities soon would release a United States flier held by the East German Communists since he parachuted behind the Iron Curtain Dec. 3.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Albert M. Cole as Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
A rift on the Board of Education came into the open yesterday after the board voted to appeal a dismissal of charges against two Negro mothers who had been boycotting Harlem public schools.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 13 -- The state of siege imposed Dec. 3 was lifted in most of Colombia last night.

ANOTHER winter, another ice show. The one that arrived last night at Madison Square Garden is the twentythird edition of the "Ice Follies,'' the pride and product of the Messrs. Oscar Johnson and the Shipstad brothers, Eddie and Roy.
The woman accused of kidnapping the Chionchio baby was held in $50,000 bail yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- President Alberto Lleras Camargo said in a recent interview he was "not very pessimistic" about Colombia's economic future. Economists and business men here believe he probably meant the nation's short-range -- until next June -- economic and financial picture looked excellent but the long-term view did not.

EDMONTON, Alberta -- Early in December the Air Transport Board of Canada reserved judgment on the application of Canadian Pacific Air Lines to compete with Trans-Canada Air Lines in transcontinental service.
THE skin divers are making a strong bid for a say in any legislation to restrict the taking of striped bass, and they have as much right to be heard as anybody else.
LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 13 -- Brazil has instructed her Ambassador in Lisbon to begin negotiations with the Portuguese Government for the safe conduct to Brazil of Gen. Humberto Delgado.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Senator Berry Goldwater Republican of Arizona, said today he had agreed to sponsor President Eisenhower's labor program in the Senate.

FROM the moment that twelve men and four women file onto the stage of the Heckscher Theatre and take their seats on a bleachertype of bench before a blue cyclorama, the concert version of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra" throbs with excitement.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Camden County moved today to assure the building of an adequate stadium as part of its bid to get the Philadelphia Phillies to transfer their National League baseball club to South Jersey. Bob Carpenter, owner of the club, is considering moving the franchise from the Pennsylvania metropolis to this state.
OTTAWA -- Canadian authorities planning the communities of the future in the Arctic are breaking away from conventional thinking and experimenting with some startling new construction forms.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- British Columbia had the biggest run of sockeye salmon in history last year. The run to the Adams River spawning grounds was estimated at 18,000,000 fish. Fifteen million of them were caught on the way by commercial fishermen.

WIINIPEG, Man. -- The 71year-old Winnipeg Grain Exchange no longer dominates the cash grain market of the world. Nor does it expect to attain that prominence again. But that does not prevent the 400member exchange from carrying on a battle against the adpancement of government in the field of grain marketing.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- The Chrysler Corporation announced today that a shortage of automotive glass would force the company to suspend final car assembly operations after Friday.
A man who attended the gangland meeting at Apalachin, N. Y., testified yesterday before the State Commission of Investigation under compulsion.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island -- The potato crop, the economic backbone of Prince Edward Island, was down 250,000 hundredweight this year from the 1957 crop. The price was high in February and the spring but it tapered off later. Potatoes account for about a third of the island's $25,000,000 income.

NEWARK, Jan. 13 -The New Jersey Public Utility Commission has granted four railroads increases of 5 per cent in coach fares and 15 per cent in parlor fares between points within the state. The order permits the carriers to put the new rates into effect Jan. 25.
MEXICO CITY -- Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), Mexico's nationalized oil industry, is due for a structural and financial overhauling.
The Soviet exhibition to be held at the Coliseum from June 28 to July 27 was described yesterday as a Russian attempt to ease tension between the Soviet Union and the United States.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 13 Earl H. (Red) Blaik resigned today as Director of Athletics and head football coach at the United States Military Academy, effective Feb. 15, his sixtysecond birthday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Leaders of the American Farm Bureau Federation told President Eisenhower today that the organization would do all it could to help the drive for a balanced budget.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Football Rules Committee indicated today a strong stand against any return to the two-platoon system.

" IN the past fourteen years Mrs. Seymour had grown as fond of Emily as it was in her nature to be of one who was in no way essential to her comfort. That is to say, she was pleased to see Emily arrive, not sorry to see her go; frequently found herself admiring Emily's looks and behavior when she was present, and seldom thought about her at all when she was absent."
The use of voting machines in primary elections here cannot begin earlier than 1960.

LIMA, Peru -- Although Peru was plagued in 1958 by continued trade and budget deficits, intensified by the drop in world prices of her principal exports, there was substantial progress and development that augured well for the economic future of the country.
MEXICO CITY -- Agriculture, always a decisive factor in the Mexican economy, produced record crops in 1958 as the result of above-normal rains in most regions.
REGINA, Sask. -- The year 1958 was a banner one for Saskatchewan.

Latin-American sugar producers realized higher than normal prices in sales in the world market last year. Despite threats of damage to Cuba's sugar crop and of interference with distribution by rebel activity on the island, Cuba supplied her normal share to the world market and ended with a light carry-over.
MEXICO CITY -- In the first eleven months of 1958 Mexico exported 979,930 long tons (of 2,240 pounds) of sulphur to the world markets, the Mexican Institute of Sulphur has announced.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13 -- The first Soviet census in twenty years, to be taken this week, is expected to provide clues to several riddles.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department o! Agriculture follows:

MONTREAL -- This area's natural gas industry, established just over one and one-half years ago, has reached a point where its economic benefits to the community run into millions of dollars in taxes, purchases and payrolls.
GUATEMALA -- The predicted downturn for the Guatemalan economy in 1958 took place and its adjustment to a lower key of activity is expected to continue in 1959.

The Long Island Rail Road will put into service today a new nine-car train from Freeport to New York. The train will leave Freeport week days at 9:27 A. M. and arrive in Pennsylvania Station at 10:12 A. M., after stops at Baldwin, Rockville Centre, Lynbrook and St. Albans.

The sort of violence and irresponsible carryings-on displayed by the irate demonstrators wherever Mr. Mikoyan shows up in this country is indeed regrettable. However, a useful lesson may be learned from their recklessness. That is the selfdefeating and futile aspect of protest by mob violence.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Unemployment climbed back to more than 4,000,000 last month, largely because "unusually severe weather" cut outdoor work, the Government reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -(UPI) -- The New York Central Railroad today notified the Interstate Commerce Commission that it plans to halt operation of five passenger trains operating daily between Weehawken, N. J., and West Haverstraw, N. Y., on Feb. 12.

UNDER the title, "Four American Expressionists," the Whitney Museum is opening today four miniature retrospective exhibitions of paintings by Karl Knaths and Abraham Rattner and sculpture by Doris Caesar and Chaim Gross. All four are highly individual artists and even to group them in so loose a category as expressionism is something of a feat.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has repealed an amendment to its by-laws that barred. "Oscar" recognition to any person who admitted membership in the Communist party or who declined to refute charges of such membership.
A DARK, brown-shingled Dutch cottage broods in a little hollow hemmed by winter-blackened trees, bushes and tall weeds at Clarendon Road and East Fifty-ninth Street in Brooklyn's Flatlands district.

The automobile racing world suffered a jolt yesterday when Reuters reported from London that Tony Vandervell, builder and owner of Britain's most successful racing car, the Vanwall, was quitting racing because of poor health.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 13 -- The Board of Education was charged last night with "absolute negligence" by Mayor Irving C. Freese. He asserted that several school buildings had deteriorated because of lack of proper maintenance.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- A little end-of-account profit - taking caused the main sections of the stock market to turn irregular today. However, the undertone remained firm and gains outnumbered losses among the industrials.

FREDERICTON, N. B. -- New Brunswick is a province of nearly 18,000,000 acres, of which 79 per cent is in forest. This vast natural wealth in timber was gravely threatened several years ago by the bud worm.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Bananas have long been second only to coffee as a main export crop and source of Government revenue here. Since virtually all the banana crop is grown for or by the United Fruit Company of Boston through its subsidiary, the Compania Bananera de Costa Rica and shipped by them, the fruit company is the biggest employer of labor.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 13 -- Vieno Johannes Sukselainen, speaker of the Finnish Parliament, formed an Agrarian minority Cabinet tonight and thus ended a forty-day Government crisis.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 13 -- The Belgian Government announced today measures aimed at organizing in the Congo "a democracy capable of exercising sovereignty and making decisions about its independence."

YELLOWKNIFE, N. W. T. -Last summer work was done on the road to connect this NorthWest Territories town with the northern end of the Mackenzie Highway. Survey parties were studying the route that will link the northern arm of Great Slave Lake with the eastern part of Great Bear Lake.

Clarion Concerts' third program of the season last night at Town Hall was one of its most successful to date. And admirers of the organization could take pleasure in the fact that its three soloists all stepped up from the ranks.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 Democratic lawmakers are likely to line up solidly in opposition to the 2cent a gallon gasoline tax increase proposed by Governor Rockefeller, Senator Joseph Zaretzki disclosed tonight.

Once Governor Rockefeller determined, to his own satisfaction, that fiscal "disaster" lay ahead unless "hard decisions" were made, he plunged into the taxation problem with disdain for political consequences. There are reliable signs that he is determined, as quickly as possible, to return to a pay-as-you-go policy, especially on highway construction.
Roy Hamey, who was the general manager of the lastplace 1958 Phillies, was hired yesterday as the assistant general manager of the world champion New York Yankees.
BERLIN, Jan. 13 -- Communes may be all right for China but they are not the way to build socialism anywhere else, according to the East German Communist party.
FISH chowder in a chafing dish is a delectable expedient that every busy cook should include in her plans for informal entertaining during the winter.
Heavy supplies of green coffee continued to depress prices last year, despite further efforts of Latin-American countries to bolster the market through an export quota agreement.
Detroit, Mich., borrowed yesterday $17,695,000 on issues of tax-secured and revenue obligations to finance water and public parking installations and other public improvements.

The High School Teachers Association rejected yesterday a salary-increase proposal made by the Board of Education. Instead, the group asked that all high school teachers get $1,000 more than elementary and junior high teachers.

Secretary of the Army Wilber M. Brucker and Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, yesterday expressed regret over Earl (Red) Blaik's decision to step down as Army's head football coach, The Associated Press reported.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- State Senator Jack E. Bronson, a Queens Democrat, introduced in the Legislature today a bill to set up a legislative committee to study the possibility of creating a regional agency og government for Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad -For Trinidad, 1958 was the most significant year since its discovery by Columbus in 1498. Trinidad last year became the capital of the new West Indies Federation and thus dislodged Jamaica as the center of West Indian affairs.
AN abstract painter of long standing, George McNeil, shows characteristic blunt vigor in his new work at the Poindexter Gallery, 21 West Fifty-sixth Street.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- A meeting between Premier Michel Debre and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, presumably to try to iron out acute French-British differences on trade problems, was foreshadowed today.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 13 -The National Assembly seemed today to be disposed to grant special powers to Premier Phouy Sananikone and to approve moves to revise the Constitution.
