BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- New laws providing for legal exile of up to two years for certain offenses have been quietly enacted by the Yugoslav Government.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Although Venezuela went through a major revolution and readjustment in 1958, the country maintained a fairly high level of economic activity. The Government's income totaled about $1,300,000,000 for the year and oil production held at the high rate of 2,000,000,000 barrels a day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Republican leaders of Congress agreed after a White House conference today that the heavily Democratic majority would decide whether the Government ended the new fiscal year with a surplus or a deficit.

Commodity futures prices closed mostly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges in featureless trading. Copper, rubber, lead, hides, cottonseed oil, and wool advanced; cocoa, potatoes, and zinc declined, and price movements for coffee and sugar were mixed.

Bizarre and mysterious traffic continued around Columbus Circle yesterday and last night in preparation for the big event at the New York Coliseum starting Friday night. This, of course, will be the National Motor Boat Show, here every January.

Louis A. Green, who became a director of Loew's, Inc., last February, resigned yesterday from the motion picture company's board. Joseph Tomlinson, another director who had opposed Loew's management, resigned last week.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Fred Rice has resigned as head football coach at Colgate University to become a defensive coaching assistant under Lisle Blackbourn at Marquette. The Marquette athletic director, Larry (Moon) Mullins, made the announcement today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A Pan American Airways official estimated today that the two airlines operating between the Pacific Northwest and Hawaii would carry 45,000 passengers this year.
IT was an amusing stunt that the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy hit on for its performance yesterday in its experimental matinee series at the Theatre de Lys.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- An 11 per cent decline in freshman enrollments in college engineering courses, after seven consecutive years of increase, was announced today by Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

There are seasonal reminders on store shelves that the potbellied stove of yesteryear still is with us. Aside from the variety of miniatures available for gifts, the old-fashioned stove has taken on added meaning as the weather continues cold.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's National Railways system obtained a friendly ear in Washington early last year, at a time when United States railroad presidents were testifying in that nation's capital on the financial plight of their systems before Senate and House investigators.

HAVANA -- Cuba is looking forward to a year of prosperity as the result of the victory of Fidel Castro's two-year revolution, which ended with the flight on New Year's Eve of the former President, Fulgencio Batista.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 -- The erstwhile Brooklyn Dodgers won one of their most important victories today, far from a ball park.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- Diplomatic quarters here reported today that the Dutch Government had notified the Soviet Union of its acceptance of Vyacheslav M. Molotov as Soviet Ambassador at The Hague.

CALGARY, Alberta -- Oil companies operating in Canada have been trying to plan their 1959 operations in a mist of uncertainty. This was caused in part by political considerations and in part by international oil conditions.
AT the age of 75, Dr. William Carlos Williams is the avantest of the gardes.
Otto Preminger will produce and direct four pictures within the next two years with a total budget of more than $12,000,000.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The twin problems of maintaining solvency in a deepening economic crisis and still finding means to support vital longrange development programs dramatically overshadowed most of Latin America last year.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey criticized the Eisenhower Administration last night for lack of leadership in meeting the world-wide economic competition of the Soviet Union.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Jan. 13 (AP) -- A mix-up over a game law technicality cost Gens. Carl A. Spaatz and Ira C. Eaker and two other generals $25 fines in the city court of Thomas County.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- A top educator in this state voiced strong disapproval today of the widely held thesis that the more hours spent in the classroom and the more homework meted out the better the school.
Anastas I. Mikoyan called last night for an end to "nyet, nyet, nyet" (no, no, no) in Soviet American relations and the introduction of "da, da, da", (yes, yes, yes).

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The International Harvester Company and the United Automobile Workers reached an agreement today on a three-year contract. It presaged the end of a two-month strike that has made 37,500 workers idle.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Seventeen housewives were reported yesterday to be holding mixed emotions toward the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- From now on it will be more difficult to pass the examination for admission to the bar in New York State.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan 14 -- The National Assembly voted today to give special powers to the Government of this little Buddhist kingdom of 2,500,000 people.

Thirteen thousand BMT subway riders were delayed up to thirty minutes in yesterday morning's rush-hour when a Brighton Beach express train broke down in the Sixtieth Street tunnel under the East River.

The lawyers of New York State, who have been widely criticized for having dragged their feet on thoroughgoing court reform, are now rallying to its support. This is good news indeed. Lawyers certainly know the courts, and the need to modernize them, better than anyone else -- except the judges themselves -- and can greatly increase the pressure for effective change.
LONDON, Jan. 14. (AP) -- The Russians looked ahead today to the twenty-first century and saw:

THE stout crutch called coincidence supported considerable weight last night in "Dangerous Interlude," a drama on the Channel 2 "United States Steel Hour." The script was by Robert Van Scoyk from a play by F. Wyndham Mallock.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Western diplomats said today that study of the text of the news conference remarks by Secretary of State Dulles did not support early reports that he had modified his basic position on the German problem.

Snakes are as reluctant as overweight women to let the public know their weight. This became apparent yesterday at the Bronx Zoo when Dr James A. Oliver, the zoo's director and curator of reptiles, tried to weigh and measure his heavy pythons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The State Department announced today that Secretary of State Dulles would not attend the semi-annual meeting of the Baghdad Pact Council in Karachi, Pakistan, Jan. 26.
The National Retail Merchants Association will encourage European manufacturers to visit this country to study the American market and what the consumer here wants to buy.
BERLIN, Jan. 14 -- Lieut. Richard Mackin, United States Army flier, began his seventh week under East German detention today, apparently without prospect of early release.
MADRID, Jan. 14 -- Fernando Maria Castiella, Spanish Foreign Minister, left by plane today for an eight-day official visit to the United Arab Republic.
Staff changes in the New York Customs District have been announced by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs.

JEAN SCHLUMBERGER, who won the Coty award last year for imaginative jewelry design, has created for Tiffany's a collection that incorporates magnificence of design and unexpected use of colored stones.
The Fire Department shut down the "notoriously neglected" tenement house at 422 West Fifty-third Street yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- Peter May and Colin Cowdrey batted England into a good position to salvage a draw at the close of the fifth day's play today in the third cricket test match against Australia.
GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- The Soviet Union expressed doubt today about the sincerity of the United States desire to end testing of nuclear weapons.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- A Federal judge today ordered the Alexandria School Board to stop using race as a factor in assigning students.
An increasing number of the nation's companies are making places for marketing departments, a study made by the American Management Association has disclosed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, following the lead of Warner Brothers and Twentieth Century-Fox, has placed all the studio television film production under the personal supervision of its over-all production chief, Sol C. Siegel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, said today that he had high hopes Congress would repeal the 10 per cent tax on plane, train and bus tickets during the current session.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Earl H. (Red) Blaik sat in his office at the military academy today and looked back on an eighteen-year career as Army's athletic director and football coach. That career, he announced yesterday, would end on Feb. 15, his sixty-second birthday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Two members of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy proposed today that internationally supervised tests be conducted to determine the feasibility of detecting underground nuclear explosions.

THE London clubman in his native habitat and on seasonal migratory flights is the hero and villain of our books for today. He appears in two imaginative studies. One is "My Uncle Harry,"* a wildly probable memoir of a dauntless Edwardian by Geoffrey Willans. The other is "Esprit de Corps," a sheaf of mannered diplomatic sketches by Lawrence Durrell.
Two new committees have been formed to work for the success of the ninth annual Animal Kingdom Ball to be held in the Pierre next Thursday evening.

F. H. McGraw Co., a major engineering and heavy construction concern, has bought 200,000 shares of its own common stock from the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corpora tion for $800,000. The corporate affiliation of the two companies has been terminated.

Governors, Mayors, county executives, state legislators and members of Congress attest the urgency of metropolitan problems that defy solution by local government. Nowhere is the situation more acute than in the tri-state New York region.

The Kings County District Attorney's office will seek a kidnapping indictment today against Mrs. Jean Iavarone. She is accused of having abducted Lisa Rose Chionchio from St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn.

Trading in most commodity futures was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices closed irregularly higher. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, rubber, hides and lead rose; the world sugar months, potatoes and copper declined, and price movements for coffee the domestic sugar contract, wool and zinc were mixed.
MONTREAL, Jan. 14 -- Twelve ocean-going freighters, eleven flying foreign flags, steamed down the St. Lawrence River today approximately five weeks after they had been trapped by early winter ice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- George Meany said tonight that a mounting lack of education facilities in America was a far worse and enduring threat than a deficit in the Federal budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Eisenhower praised Earl H. (Red) Blaik today as "a very great man" whose retirement as head football coach at West Point would have happened long ago, had Blaik been thinking only of himself.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Administration made it clear today that it had no new proposal for solution of the German problem to put before Anastas I. Mikoyan this weekend.
THE only controversy stemming from Press Week is why the Waldorf-Astoria's Jade Room has catsup-colored draperies.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (UPI)--Bob Keegan, a Chicago White Sox right-handed pitcher, was released outright today to Indianapolis of the American Association.
A planning meeting for the annual benefit luncheon and fashion show of the Trifles and Treasures Thrift Shop of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center will be held today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Airlines and unions argued today before the Civil Aeronautics Board over the airlines' mutual antistrike aid pact.

PARIS, Thursday, Jan. 15 -- The Council of Ministers of the six common market countries proposed early today that bilateral talks, chiefly between France and Britain, should seek to dispose of a British complaint of trade discrimination.

SKI SKETCH: Walter Stugger, who gave up his Austrian citizenship last October to become an American citizen, has retained his Alpine style of skiing as director of Bousquet's Ski School in Pittsfield, Mass. Although he has been in this country only since 1953, Stugger has fared extremely well.

BEN HECHT, the mellow doyen of premeditated controversy, surrendered to the impulse last night. On his program over Channel 7 he turned actor in a play from his own pen. Both Actors Equity and the Dramatists Guild now have more in common than they have had for years: a surplus member.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The United Mine Workers and the Pennsylvania anthracite operators signed a new agreement today raising wages $1 a day. The work day is seven hours.
RIDGEFIELD, N. J., Thursday, Jan. 15 -- A large part of eastern Bergen County and two Hudson County communities were blacked out for more than an hour last night and early today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Air Force has ordered an extra firing stage that could permit the use of the Atlas missile for shots to the vicinity of Mars and Venus.

Raymond T. O'Keefe, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Thomas P. Coogan, president of Housing Securities Inc., will speak at a dinner meeting of the Peter Minuit Post of the American Legion tonight at the Biltmore Hotel.

An unpretentious, expertly played and thoroughly absorbing program was given last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The participants were the American Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Robert Scholz, and the soloist was the soprano Saramae Endich.
Just after the turn of the century a small boy in Lincoln, Neb., used to climb on his bicycle after school to deliver packages for his father's dry goods store.
The Great Dane Club of America, which has strong views on the proper colors for the dogs in its breed, is taking an official stand on the matter this week.
TORONTO, Jan. 14 -- At practice yesterday, Coach Phil Watson gave scoring quotas to his Rangers for the remainder of the season.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics romped to their eighth straight victory and their twenty-fifth in the last twenty-nine starts by defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 123 -- 112, tonight at the Boston Garden.

The nation's gasoline inventories rose 3,542,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supplies aggregated 190,~ 024,000 barrels, compared with 186,482,000 a week earlier and 198,738,000 a year ago.

Heretofore, David Susskind has shied away from producing spectacles. But with "The Hunt of the Sun," which deals with the conquest of Peru in the sixteenth century, he intends to branch out into the spectacular field. The leading role requires an actor of Rex Harrison's stature.

These menus, which appeal each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 14 -- After eight years of Republican rule, J. Millard Tawes, Democrat, was inaugurated today as the fifty-ninth elected Governor of Maryland. He succeeds Theodore R. McKeldin and enters the state's chief office with the backing of a solidly Democratic General Assembly.
The highly controversial proposal to widen Fulton Street from Broadway to Water Street was approved unanimously by the City Planning Commission yesterday.

The New York Red Cross Chapter, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue (MUrray Hill 9-1000), appealed yesterday for volunteers to work with bloodmobiles and donor centers. The greatest need is for volunteers who can serve one weekday in Manhattan and the Bronx.

Disappointing figures on employment and unemployment for December have been made public by the Departments of Commerce and Labor. The number of jobless recrossed the 4 million mark last month in the biggest numerical rise since that of last June, when the number of unemployed, at 5.4 million, reached its highest level since the recession began in mid-1957.

THE New York City Ballet presented last night the final new work of its current season at the City Center, in the form of George Balanchine's "Native Dancers," set to the Fifth Symphony of Vittorio Rieti.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Lee Shaffer sank a lay-up in the last twenty-two seconds of an overtime period to break a 68-68 tie and third-rated North Carolina went on to gain a 72-68 victory over top-ranked North Carolina State in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game tonight.
The McLouth Steel Corporation cleared a little more last year than it did in 1957 despite a smaller volume of business, according to the preliminary annual report issued yesterday.
Archbishop Makarios expressed belief yesterday that the British would allow him "to go back to Cyprus in the very near future."

BONN, Germany, Jan. 14 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has informed West Germany that the United Arab Republic's establishment of trade missions with East Germany did not imply diplomatic recognition of "the so-called German Democratic Republic," a spokesman for the West German Government said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Administration officials were said today to be "very much interested" in the creation of a Government Trading Corporation to help this country fight Russia's economic offensive on equal terms.
Your issue of Jan. 7 reported a warning issued by the Port Authority to cab drivers who refuse short-haul fares at the airports.

NOT many years ago, spring chicken was the mainstay of Lydian feasts. Available in limited quantities from late winter to early summer, the tender, young fowl was a luxury item generally reserved for Sunday and holiday meals.
The Federal Trade Commission is not likely to be persuaded to change its mind that the granting of inequitable advertising allowances by dress manufacturers is a violation of the Robinson-Patman Act.

HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- The first courts-martial of Batista adherents in the Havana area will begin this week end. The announcement was made today by Lieut. Arnaldo Rivero, secretary of a commission investigating the alleged crimes of 600 prisoners at La Cavana Fortress, across the bay from Havana, where the trials will be held.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Oklahoma University's football team doesn't want to "have to go" to the Orange Bowl game. And the Board of Regents today agreed to request the Big Eight Conference to amend the contract requiring the champion to play in the game.

Events tonight: "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic, Sir John Barbirolli conducting, Berl Senofsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Beatrice Krebs, mezzo-soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 14 (AP) -- An emergency operation that kept a Democrat in the hospital allowed Republicans today to take full control of House of Representatives.
After two seasons of ups and downs, there is no question as to where a belt belongs this spring.

The resumption of dividends on the common stock of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., was announced yesterday by S. W. Cantor, president. The company operates forty-nine units in the East, South and Middle West.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer called in the United States Ambassador today to express West Germany's concern over remarks by Secretary of State Dulles on the reunification of Germany.

Irving H. Ludwig has been elected president and general sales manager of the Buena Vista Film Distribution Company, a subsidiary of Walt Disney Studios. His election fills a vacancy created last week by the resignation of Leo F. Samuels.

The babel of official double-talk, mingled with some honest thoughtfulness, about how to solve the commuter railroad problem in the New York metropolitan area has risen to a new high in decibel count. But whether in Trenton, Chicago, New York City, Westchester County or up in the suburban areas of Connecticut it almost invariably has one common denominator: Let George do it.
UNION SPRINGS, Ala., Jan. 14 -- The Civil Rights Commission reluctantly accepted an invitation today to examine voter registration records here under terms laid down by the Bullock County grand jury.
A judge upheld yesterday the right of The New York Times to use a new type of stereotype mat designed to save printing time and cost.

The four-story building at the northwest corner Broadway and Sixty-first Street, formerly occupied as general offices and an automobile showroom by the Studebaker - Packard Corporation, has been sold by John A. Dilliard.
Manhattan College's strong track squad retained its team championship in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

ATLANTA, Jan. 14 (AP)--Jacob Rothschild, rabbi of The Temple, which was bombed Oct. 12, testified today that George Bright had questioned him about the world's Jewish population several months before the bombing.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Lord Altrincham urged Queen Elizabeth II today to live in other Commonwealth countries where the royal children might grow up and marry members of other races to cement Commonwealth ties.

TOKYO, Jan. 14 -- Sacred protocols observed for centuries in the Japanese imperial family were shattered today in the ceremonies making formal the engagement of Crown Prince Akihito to Miss Michiko Shoda.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 14 -- This town was plunged into debate today over attempts to change what was termed the "honky-tonk" appearance of its business section.

This year's production by the Blue Hill Troupe will benefit the New York chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. The amateur Savoyards will perform Gilbert and Sullivan's "Princess Ida" at the Hunter College Auditorium April 1 through April 4.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Major rice exporting countries, including the United States, may be facing competition in 1959 from Communist China, the Food and Agriculture Organization said in its December Bulletin of Agricultural Statistics.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 14 -- Marie Torre, New York radio and television columnist, walked out of the Hudson County Jail here today after serving a ten-day term for refusing to divulge the source of a news item.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The stock market was without a decided trend here today. Price movements among the industrials generally were small and irregular.

SEVERAL years ago Milton Goldring set out from the precincts of everyday experience for the illimitable spaces of a dream world. That world, more simply and assuredly expressed than before, continues to hold his attention in his current exhibition at the Grand Central Moderns Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue.
Bolshevism's leading salesman met some of this country's No. 1 merchants, industrialists and bankers yesterday. By day's end the impact that each had made on the other was notable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Senate voted today to expand its major committees by eighteen seats to accommodate the top-heavy Democratic majority elected last November.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Senate rackets inquiry culled its year-old "sick list" of witnesses today and directed six of them, reported to be well now, to appear next week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Walter C. Dowling, United States Ambassador to South Korea, has been summoned home for consultation, the State Department said today.

The Schools Motion Picture iCommittee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14 -- The Argentine Congress ended a special session today, leaving the nation under a state of siege, without a budget and without prospects of elections soon in the federally administered provinces.
BUFFALO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Ray Bluth won the qualifying trophy of the All-Star bowling tournament tonight with the highest thirty-six-game total in the 18-year history of the competition.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 14 -- The Cabinet approved today an amendment to the West German criminal code making imprisonment of not less than three months mandatory of conviction of charges of anti-Semitism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--President Eisenhower held out the prospect today of lower income taxes "eventually" if a balanced Federal budget resulted in holding the line on prices and other costs. But he said tax reforms to increase incentives must come first.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Politicians and diplomats in Whitehall have reached the conclusion that the West should make an early attempt to probe the Soviet Union's position on Germany.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 14 -- Gimbels told Macy's today that it would become its competitor at the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center here.

New Yorkers have always considered Staten Island different from the rest of the city, an attitude often shared and rejoiced in by Staten Islanders themselves. For people with children, it's the terminus of a ferry ride where you immediately re-embark for New York without leaving the ferry house.

Premier Khrushchev has proposed that West Berlin be made a free city without foreign troops. May I suggest that in dealing with this development American spokesmen refrain from returning the eternal negative and advance some constructive, positive ideas of their own?

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller signed his first bill as Governor today. It was a deficiency budget measure adding $28,100,000 to the appropriations for the current fiscal year ending next March 31.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 14 -- Mrs. Indira Gandhi, daughter of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, emerged today as a leading candidate for the presidency of the Indian National Congress.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The State Council of Churches charged today the proposals to legalize off-track betting on horse races constitute a "surrender to the gambling interests."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A new phase of policy is starting in Washington with the usual results. General statements on complex matters, often extemporaneous and imprecise, are leading to divergent interpretations of what the new policies, if any, actually are.

WHERE do conductors look for novelties? Why did Robert Kurka's Symphony have to wait until last night for its first New York performance at Carnegie Hall by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Robert Shaw?

The Mergenthaler Linotype Company cleared $419,000 in the quarter ended Dec. 21 as a result of a $644,000 dividend declared by its English subsidiary, Linotype and Machinery, Ltd. Gordon W. Wattles, chairman. disclosed this result to stocholders at the annual meeting in Brooklyn yesterday.
A varied list of industrial, railroad and utility securities worth more than $51,000,000 are being offered to investors today. The offerings are:
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The state's lawyers and accountants agreed today to try to keep from trespassing on each other's professions.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Dale Hall, the hard-hitting halfback whose blocks sprang Glenn Davis loose for many of "Mr. Outside's" famous long runs, was solidly on the "inside" track today to become coach of the great Army team left behind by Earl Blaik.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 14 -- Plans for a $50,000,000 oil pipeline development in southeastern Kalimantan (Indonesian Borneo) were announced here today by the Shell Oil Company of Indonesia.

In the course of a sound and statesmanlike exposition of the German problem, in which he rejected the Soviet proposals as "brutal" and "stupid," Secretary Dulles injected at his latest press conference some remarks which appear to lift the Western position into the diplomatic stratosphere, with nothing to hang onto except confusion.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 6 to 19 points yesterday, with new crop months strongest. The advance equaled from 30 cents to 95 cents a bale.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday lost its last hope for favorable action by the city on its plea for impartial grievance machinery in the Police Department.
An attempt to rob a bank by proxy came to grief yesterday afternoon at the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company branch at 40 East Forty-second Street.

Strength in the final hour rescued a wavering stock market yesterday and brought not only a higher close for the general list but the highest mark for The New York Times rail average since May 14, 1956.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Right Rev. Arthur C. Lichtenberger was installed here today as the twenty-first Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Eisenhower nominated Norman P. Mason today as Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- The Soviet press reported today Secretary of State Dulles' remark that free elections were not the only way to unite Germany.

When opportunity knocks at the Metropolitan Opera, it is usually at short notice. Late yesterday afternoon tenor Barry Morell was informed that his colleague Carlo Bergonzi was indisposed and would not sing Rodolfo in "La Boheme." Could Mr. Morell take over?
It is a long trail for many New Yorkers to the Museum of the American Indian. But, having reached Broadway and 155th Street, the traveler finds a fascinating collection that touches all the Americas.

The City Housing Authority, heeding the protests of East Bronx property owners against an influx of low-income families, has set the highest rent schedule for subsidized public housing at Castle Hill Houses.

THERE may be some hope in New York State for the bobwhite quail, long gone from here except for some areas of Long Island. Charles P. Brown, a game research investigator, says so cautiously in an article in the December-January issue of the New York State Conservationist.

BETHPAGE, L. I., Jan. 14 -- The culture of Japan was demonstrated by Japanese artists and representatives of the Consulate General in New York in a closed-circuit television program at the Plainedge High School here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A screening committee today recommended Joe Cronin's election as president of the American League effective Feb. 1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The president of the International Boxing Club said today he could not act on a court ruling to break up the organization until he found out from a Federal judge when the corporation must be dissolved.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 14 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia was welcomed in New Delhi today as an old and cherished friend.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A native of upstate New York with the characteristics of a New England Yankee will be the Government's new housing chief. He is Norman Peirce Mason, a 62-year-old former lumber dealer. For the last four years he has headed the Federal Housing Admin -isLration,
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Delaware State Board of Education submitted a seven-point school integration plan today intended to start in the first grade next September.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Eisenhower talked today like a man who looked forward to retirement -- at least temporarily.
Albert Ackalitis, a widely feared waterfront hoodlum who had been "missing" since last Friday, walked into the offices of the Waterfront Commission yesterday in response to a five-day-old subpoena.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 4 -- A jury in the State Supreme Court here could not agree today whether Mayor Joseph P. Vaccarella of Mount Vernon, a former boxer and ring referee, had punched a visitor at City Hall. But it dismissed false arrest and malicious prosecution charges against the Mayor, four detectives and the city of Mount Vernon.
Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference yesterday at the National Press Club in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

ROME, Jan. 14 -- On the eve of the opening of the thirty-third congress of the Italian Socialist party, the Communists are showing apprehension that it may mark the end of their alliance with the Socialists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Jan. 7:
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- Seventy-one Africans were killed in anti-European rioting in the Congo capital earlier this month, it was officially announced here tonight.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Prof. George Wald of Harvard tonight was named winner of the 1959 Rumford Premium by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

THE Orient is being stripped of its mysteries this season. For New Yorkers, the first major evidence of this strong trend in home furnishings appears in the furniture galleries opening today at Stern's.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's budget chief has warned Federal officials against going over the President's head and asking Congress for more military funds than the new budget provides.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 14 -- Strict limitations have been placed on activities of the so-called People's Militia by Maj. Gen. Abdul Karim el-Kassem, Iraqs Premier. In the future the militiamen and the Iraqi Students Union will perform any policing or military duties only under direct orders of the army or of the military Governor General.

THE general was appalled. In his first public appearance as Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, Maj. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger sat in the stands at Franklin Field on a bleak November afternoon in 1940 and watched Army suffer the worst defeat in the history of West Point football. Puissant Penn clobbered the inept cadets, 48 to 0.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company accused the Michigan Supreme Court today of having usurped a legislative function in its decision awarding state jobless benefits to Ford workers made idle here by an Ohio strike in 1953.
A germ that made its first known appearance in the United States in a cow in Brooklyn in 1843 may be associated with human diseases, including crippling arthritis, it was reported here yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that Oren Root, a New York city lawyer, would be named as a Deputy State Commerce Commissioner as soon as there is a Commerce Commissioner to appoint him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The 1958 rush for home mortgage insurance gave the Federal Housing Administration the biggest year in its twenty-five-year history.
ONE of the most significant developments in the art of cooking, the electronic range, is still shunned by many homemakers.
Columbia University's Society of Older Graduates presented its Great Teacher Awards last night to Dr. Polykarp Kusch, Professor of Physics, and Carl F. Kayan, Professor of Mechanical Engineering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The contention that the Senate repudiated the democratic principle of majority rule when it defeated the Douglas resolution runs headlong into the fact that very many more Senators than one-half of their number plus one opposed the proposal.

Sleet and rain with a sudden drop to freezing temperatures made roads in the metropolitan area extremely slippery last night. One person was killed in a traffic accident in Queens and at least seven persons were injured in accidents that occurred in Rockland County.
Another teachers organization yesterday rejected the salary plan now under consideration by the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan 14 -- The Justice Department pressed the Federal Communications Commission today to disqualify "automatically" and "absolutely" any television channel applicant who attempted to use improper influence.
The Ford Motor Company's announcement on Tuesday that it planned to form its own financing affiliate continued to depress the stocks of the major commercial finance companies yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association Rules Committee today widened the goal posts by 4 feet, 10 inches to invite more field goal attempts. The committee also relaxed the substitution restrictions to speed up football on the college level.
Show me a thrifty people (the Finns, for example), and I'll show you a people high up the scale of respect for law.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 14 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders introduced its 1959 budget of $16,649,666 today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The House Republican Conference voted unanimously today to take "an unqualified position in opposition" to a resolution designed to abolish the Committee on Un-American Activities. Members are not usually "bound" by conference resolutions, as they are at caucuses.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 14 -- The First San Juan Drama Festival opened last night before a sellout audience that saw Fay Bainter and Albert Dekker in the 1958 Pulitzer Prize drama, "Look Homeward, Angel." The play, adapted by Ketti Frings from Thomas Wolfe's novel, was presented at the Teatro Tapia in the initial effort to bring Broadway shows to Puerto Ricans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--President Eisenhower said today that it would be "a little stupid" to deny that the Russians were somewhat ahead of the United States in certain phases of missile development.
The Mexican Ambassador to the United Nations presented a citation yesterday to the leader of a group of Jewish organizations for his efforts on behalf of human rights.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The grain and soybean futures market appeared to have started off toward a good rally today but a late flurry of selling wiped out most gains on the Board of Trade.

Contract talks between three networks and the Radio and Television Directors Guild were broken off late last night. Union members were alerted for a possible strike call this morning or at any time afterward.

The Diamond Alkali Company cleared $6,475,000, or $2.32 a share, on 2,796,421 common shares outstanding last year, Raymond F. Evans, chairman and president, reported yesterday in a preliminary, unaudited statement.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- A jury of seven men and five women was selected today to hear the Federal conspiracy trial of Representative William J. Green, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and six co-defendants.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Japan's new Antarctic expedition reported today that two of fifteen Husky dogs left behind at an abandoned Antarctic bas last February had been found alive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, called today for an investigation of possible favoritism in the Defense Department's twenty-billion-dollar-a-year procurement programs.

Owing to the persistent propaganda of a high school pressure group, the public has been misled into believing that high school teachers are better prepared and work harder than their elementary school counterparts. This is patently untrue.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Members of the United Nations Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization split with considerable bitterness today in a dispute over "flags of convenience."
The Army's Chief of Research and Development interrupted a prepared speech yesterday to deliver a scathing attack on Anastas I. Mikoyan's goodwill tour here.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Estate and home owners in the center of the town of Bedford, near quaint Bedford Village, took another step today in a fight to block the state from building an adjacent broad highway for mixed traffic.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered further proceedings today on charges that the Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa., had violated antimonopoly laws.
An intensive hunt for fire hazards in hospitals and other structures here was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- The automobile industry says it has developed techniques for treating engine exhaust fumes to reduce hydrocarbon emissions from cars by 60 to 90 per cent.
New Jersey announced yesterday plans for borrowing $25,000,000 on water bonds on Feb. 16. The borrowing will be the first under authorization by the voters at a referendum last November.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Rockefeller Administration, it developed today, is weighing two alternate methods of putting the state income tax on a withholding basis.
Plans to convert congested Whitestone Parkway from a four- to an eight-lane artery were initiated Yesterday.
Frank D. O'Connor, District Attorney of Queens County, announced yesterday that he would present charges against James J. Crisona to the grand jury "at the earliest possible moment."

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Ilsa Konrads, Australia's 14-year-old swimming marvel, set a world record of 19 minutes 25.7 seconds for the women's 1,650-yard free-style tonight. This clocking also bettered the world 1,500-meter record.
A man who attended the gangland meeting at Apalachin, N. Y., fourteen months ago yesterday refused ninety times to answer questions put to him by the State Commission of Investigation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- More than a quarter of a century of continuous research lies behind yesterday's announcement of the discovery of NIH 7519.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Representative William L. Dawson, Democrat of Illinois, one of the nation's four Negro Congressmen, charged today that President Eisenhower had followed a "passive, do-as-little-as-possible policy" toward racial discrimination.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Senator Prescott Bush said today that Congress might have to face "the unpleasant necessity" of raising taxes to hold the line against inflation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Michigan Bank of Detroit contended in a court action yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board lacked authority to require a member bank to raise additional capital in the form of common stock rather than preferred stock.

Stockholders in the New York Trust Company defeated yesterday the efforts of a dissident group to add five directors to the bank's nineteen-man board. The vote at the an nual meeting was 810,000 shares to 256,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Eisenhower recalled today that he had had more "quite warm arguments" with Winston Churchill, in World War II than with any other person in the Allied Forces.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Perry Moss, who helped coach Miami to three consecutive football victories over the University of Florida, starting in 1954, today was named head coach at Florida State.

Two lawyers -- more versed in Blackstone's law than Bowditch's navigation -- debated yesterday the likelihood of a Staten Island ferryboat's straying far into the East or Hudson Rivers. One never has.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- It was the conviction of observers in Paris today that the French Government was making a new attempt at a cease-fire in Algeria.
ATLANTA, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- The defense tried today to discredit witnesses who had testified that George Bright, charged with bombing' The Temple here last Oct. 12, was a fanatic anti-semite.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Administration will soon propose legislation to permit the sale of Government-seized shares of the General Aniline and Film Corporation. At torney General William P. Rogers disclosed the plan today.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Goals by Johnny Bucyk, Don McKenney and Jim Morrison carried the Boston Bruins to a 3-0 triumph over Detroit and into a fourth-place tie with the Red Wings in a National Hockey League encounter tonight.
The Century Boat Company's new twenty-two-foot Raven hardtop is designed as an all-around boat for the family. The plastic top extends more than halfway to the stern and can be used as a sun deck.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 15 -- A new pay scale permitting public school teachers here to receive up to $10,200 a year was proposed today by Dr. Carroll F. Johnson, Superintendent of Schools.

Another year of the United States Power Squadron, will find Dr. Lester C. Lowe, Los Angeles physician and yachtsman, at the helm. He has been renominated to serve his second year as chief commander, and the election will be part of the annual meeting at the Hotel Astor tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Adlai E. Stevenson have agreed to serve on a committee set up to wipe out their party's $750.000 debt.
PINEHURST, N. C., Jan. 15 (UPI) -- George C. Marshall, retired general of the Army and World War II Chief of Staff, suffered a stroke today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn, in effect, scuttled a proposal today to abolish the House Committee on Un-American Activities and transfer its work to the Judiciary Committee.

THE appreciation of wines can be an intellectual as well as a gustative experience. When wines are savored on both levels, the enjoyment is doubled. This is the opinion of H. Gregory Thomas, president of Chanel, Inc., and grand master of the Commanderie de Bordeaux, a recently formed wine society that staged its winter dinner last night at the Carlton House.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- A Navy vehicle collided with a truck loaded with frozen orange juice yesterday. Six young enlisted men were killed. Three were injured.
The Sea Minx, a 26-foot-cabin cruiser, is being offered for the first time this year by the Coast Yacht Works of Red Bank, N. J. It heads a line of five models.

PARIS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- An agreement giving the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) a half-interest in any oil found in some 12,500 square miles of desolate Sahara sand dunes probably will be reached next week, informed sources said today.

The Wagner administration's calculations for the 1959-60 expense budget have firmed up to show a need of $145,000,000 in "new" revenue in the fiscal year starting July 1. This new revenue must come from new taxes, or from greater state aid. It cannot come from a normal increase in yield from real estate or other present taxes.

Since the 1959 indoor track season will get into full swing tomorrow with the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus meet in Boston, it's time to take stock of the spiked-shoe situation at the local colleges.

The second of the season's New Music Concerts under the direction of Eric Simon, last night in Carl Fischer Concert Hall, presented several works new to this city, including Olivier Messiaen's "Quatuor pour la fin du temps."
BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Stanley (Bucky) Harris, who has devoted most of his sixty-one years to baseball, today was named successor to Joe Cronin as general manager of the Boston Red Sox.

THE virtually omniscient pundits of the Football Rules Committee certainly came up with a dilly in their most recent cerebral outing. These devious thinkers wasted no brain waves on the one sensible way of solving their goal-post problem -- restoring the uprights to the goal line where they belong.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Threats and intimidation by New York City gangsters were charged here today with preventing the election of a Boston dock leader as a vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association.
Old Budapest, the fifth annual charity ball of the Hungarian Catholic League of America, will take place tomorrow in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Events today: New York Philharmonic, Sir John Barbirolli, conductor, Berl Senofsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:40.

The Soviet Union's victorious hockey team, loaded down with souvenirs, left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday after expressing gratitude for the "unconditional hospitality" accorded during three weeks of play in the United States.

The man who prefers sail will find a great deal to interest him at the Motor Boat Show. Whether he wants to skim over a lake in a sailing surfboard or put out to sea in a substantial cruising yacht, the medium is there. So are a lot of boats in between.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Samuel R. Pierce, a 36-year-old Negro lawyer and former Cornell football star, was given a temporary appointment by Governor Rockefeller today as a General Sessions judge in New York County.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- An Atlas rocket was launched here tonight in an attempt to span the intercontinental range of 6,000 miles.
The Soviet economic report adds to the available evidence that 1958 was the most successful production year of the Soviet economy.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of Solomon E. Senior of Flushing, Queens, to the Workmen's Compensation Board. He said he would be designated chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -Modern American capitalism is in grave need of dedicated "evangelists" capable of expounding its strengths and virtues, it was said today at a conference on the moral foundations of economic growth.

Kastor, Hilton, Chesley, Clifford Atherton, Inc., an advertising agency, leased two floors in the building at 575 Lexington Avenue at Fifty-first Street from Sam Minskoff, Inc., the builder and owner. The agency was formed through the recent merger of Kastor, Hilton, Chesley Clifford, Inc., and Atherton Currier, Inc. Vincent J. Peters and Peter Korn of Cushman Wakefield Inc., agent for the building, arranged the ease.

After much fanfare, radio, tele- vision and press build-up, Senator Hubert Humphrey finally lets us into his confidence regarding his interview with Soviet Premier Khru- shchev. I wish to comment on the following part of Senator Hum- phrey's exclusive public report:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -The market demand forecast for domestic crude oil during February was set today by the Bureau of Mines at the highest level for any month since the forecast for April 1957.
HAVANA, Jan. 15 -- Cuba wants good relations with the United States, Fidel Castro, rebel leader told the Rotary Club here today.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses.

After seven and a half months of one-man rule France returned to a normal political regime yesterday when President de Gaulle opened the first Parliament of the Fifth Republic for its first working session. He did this with an austere message in which he reminded the Deputies of his new constitutional powers which, as he said in his inaugural address, enable him to "impose" his will.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- The Town of Harrison may Collect more than $100,000 annually from the County of Westchester in taxes on that part of the $11,000,000 Westchester County Airport that lies within the town, a legal opinion held today.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- England held Australia to a draw today in the third match of the five-match cricket test series.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A twenty-year separation of father and son may end shortly with the issuance of an immigrant visa to Hary Philip Levenstein, 30-year-old son of Sam Levenstein of Hillside, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- New efforts were under way in Congress today to head off legal attacks on professional baseball, football, basketball and hockey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Two Democratic law-makers said today that both labor and business should account to the public for price or wage increases that threaten to feed inflation.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- A special state commission today had some potentially explosive things to say about two prized status symbols of the American motorist -- the new car and the low-numbered license plate.
Columbia University scientists told yesterday how specimens of a tiny shellfish brought up recently from a deep Pacific Ocean trench were helping to forge new links with the past.
OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- The Canadian Government reaffirmed today its full support of the Western position in the "cold war."

The forty-second annual dinner dance of the American Horse Shows Association will take place this evening in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event is in honor of the horse show exhibitors and high-score award winners.

The National Boxing Association's executive committee yesterday accepted assurances from Ray Robinson and Floyd Patterson that they planned world title defenses. Then the boxing chieftains warned Algeria's Alphonse Halimi to defend his world bantamweight championship by April 15 or face loss of his crown.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- The directors of Inland Steel Company today named Joseph L. Block to be chairman. Mr. Block had been president since 1933.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -The Philco Corporation today unveiled a production line that it expects will help the transistor to eliminate the vacuum tube.

The American edition of a new biography by Elizabeth Jenkins, "Elizabeth the Great," will be published by Coward-McCann on Feb. 26. The author sheds new light on many facets of "the strong and mysterious personality" of Queen Elizabeth I of England.
ALEXANDRIA, La., Jan. 15 -- Louisiana segregation leaders told registrars of voters from seven Louisiana parishes today how they want registration laws enforced in Louisiana in the future.
Anastas I. Mikoyan told a group of the American Jewish Committee yesterday that reports of an intended large-scale movement of Russian Jews to Birobidzhan in Siberia were untrue.

Self-regulation of advertising and merchandising practices by merchants was urged last night by Charles H. Kellstadt, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., before the Government steps in to enact legislation.

When a boat show comes to New York, throngs of out-of-towners also arrive, frequently with their families and various pleasure-boating gear and impedimenta. Visitors come from Europe, Canada, Latin American countries and the Caribbean islands.
MOZART'S "Don Giovanni," aristocrat of operas, has become a popular hit at the Metropolitan Opera. Happy, happy days!
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 -- A Croatian accused of responsibility for mass executions in World War II won his fight today against extradition to Yugoslavia.

RYE, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- One of the newest railroad stations in the country is receiving attention here because of its picture windows and modern decor. It also is causing specula tion on its cost and why it is not used after apparently having been finished three weeks ago.
Murray Westreich, who had been serving as secretary, has been installed as commodore of the Colonial Yacht Club of Mamaroneck, which is entering its fifty-seventh year. He succeeds Mack G. Klosty.

The comprehensive news cover- age, the editorial and publication by The Times of the text of the report on the Metropolitan Regional Coun- cil comprise an important contribu- tion to public enlightenment on this all-important ubject.
A steam pile-driver drove a pipe thirty-six inches in diameter into the silt off Fort Lafayette Island yesterday to mark the start of construction for the $320,000,000 Narrows Bridge.
Retailers were urged last night by one of their leaders to take active parts in politics in order to have voices in the decisions "that are reshaping the cities in which we live and do business."

SYRACUSE, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Although they scored only one basket in the final eight minutes, the Philadelphia Warriors registered a 95-91 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
Two men who attended the gangland meeting at Apalachin, N. Y., must explain today why they should not be jailed for contempt for refusing to answer questions about the meeting.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15 -President Juscelino Kubitschek apparently was misled by questionable Soviet statistics when he outlined his Operation Pan-America program for economic development. This was the opinion of anti-Communist officials today after a study of the report.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Margaret Varner of Wilmington, Del., reached the final of the Women's Connecticut squash racquets championship at the Greenwich Country Club today. Miss Varner defeated Mrs. Walter B. Mahoney, Chappaqua, N. Y., 15 -- 9, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 9.
The stock market made a new historic high yesterday as measured by The New York Times average of fifty stocks. The rail average also advanced to its best mark since May 10, 1956.

The principle involved in the Senate struggle to amend Rule XXII is completely stated in your editorial of Jan. 9: "Fhere is no good argument in a democracy for perpetuating the positive or the negative rule of a minority."
BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- An attractive brunette blinked and grimaced. A platinum blonde beauty tilted her head and ground her teeth. A pretty red head attempted to appear nonchalant.

The backlog of new market borrowings by local governments was swelled substantially yesterday. Announcements of sales dates for new issues totaling more than $53,000,000 were made by Louisiana, Puerto Rico, Texas Colleges, and Harris County, Tex.
ATHENS, Jan. 15 -- Archbishop Makarios said on arrival at Athens Airport tonight that the truce in Cyprus "could become permanent if the British rulers showed a spirit of goodwill."
WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 15 -- Worcester City Council has cast 280 ballots in an unsuccessful attempt to elect a Mayor. There is no indication when the stalemate will be resolved.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The annual statistical report on the Soviet economy said tonight that the Soviet Union outstripped the United States in production of milk in 1958.
BAYONNE, N. J., Jan. 15 -No criticism was raised today at a public hearng on a proposed two-mile-long industrial highway, planned for this city's eastern shore along New York Bay.

The recent Chicago fire that killed ninety chil- dren and three nuns, and the loft building blaze on Mercer Street last winter that resulted in twenty-four deaths, spurred Fire Commissioner Cavanagh to order an intensive search for viola- tions of the law and other hazards in this city's factories and schools, as had been done in tene- ments -- with temporary closings to remove spe- cial dangers that could be gotten rid of quickly.

Deputy Premier Mikoyan's press conference at United Nations headquarters yesterday revealed little not already familiar to persons accustomed to following the activities and arguments of the Russian delegation in that same set of buildings. The famous personality, the outer aspect of good- will, the glow that followed Mr. Mikoyan's elec- tioneering tour of the American hinterland -- these were new.

Trading on the American Stock Exchange has been booming lately. Yesterday 2,532,945 shares changed hands on the A. S. E. This was the largest volume since May 6, 1930, when 2,540,000 shares were traded.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan appealed tonight to the nation for a "vote of confidence" in the Conservative Government when Britain holds her general election.
The City A. C. and the Columbia University Club maintained the lead in respective divisions of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C competition yesterday.

BUFFALO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Bob Hitt of Livonia, Mich., took over first place after three rounds in the All-Star bowling tournament tonight. However, his ascent was obscured by the fine performance of the man in tenth place, Lou Campi.
What was apparently a juvenile attempt at sabotage temporarily set the New Haven Railroad back yesterday in its struggle to recover from the effects of last week-end's train wreck.

A MAN named W. O. Nagel is kicking the outdoor sports statisticians around, and he ought not to do it. Outdoor sports statisticians are serious individuals and they revere the dollar sign as much as anybody on earth.
BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- Mayor Willy Brandt called upon West Berliners today to remain calm and steadfast during a crisis that he said had not yet reached its climax.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- There was much speculation today as to the practical effects of a trade proposal made earlier in the day by the Council of Ministers of the six common market countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- From various sources supposed to know whereof they speak the word came last week-end that the President intends to make, direct to the people, an intensive campaign against infla- tion, with homely illustrations from the steadily rising prices in the painful experience of every house- holder.

Most New York commodities declined yesterday, reflecting weakness in metal futures. Copper, lead, zinc, platinum and rubber declined; cocoa and the domestic sugar months rose, and price movements for potatoes, world sugar positions, cotton-seed oil, coffee, hides and wool were mixed.
The nation's public high schools have been found to be basically capable of meeting educational needs by Dr. James B. Conant, president emeritus of Harvard University.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Garrison Davidson, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, today denied reports that Dale Hall, Vince Lombardi "or anyone" was the leading candidate to succeed Earl H. (Red) Blaik as West Point's football coach.

TORONTO, Jan. 15 -- Muzz Patrick, general manager of the New York Rangers, today said plans virtually had been completed for the foreign tour that would take the Rangers and the Boston Bruins to eight countries upon the completion of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs.
