Two of its eleven inboard cruiser models are being exhibited at the boat show by Colonial Boat Works, Inc., of Millville, N.J. The line ranges from a 24-foot utility to a 53-foot custom motor yacht that sleeps ten persons.
State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo has been elected chairman of the executive committee of the City Title Insurance Company, it was announced by Irving M. Ives, board chairman.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Fulgencio Batista denounced Fidel Castro today for causing a "river of blood" to flow in Cuba.
A four-alarm Queens fire that lasted five and a half hours wrecked six stores and a beauticians' school yesterday at 165th Street in Jamaica.
ROME, Jan. 15 -- The lobby of one of Rome's great and glorious hotels, the Excelsior, looked like a church bazaar this morning as the Italian spring and summer fashion showings got under way.
Marie Torre, a television columnist for The New York Herald Tribune, was left dangling yesterday as to whether she would be asked again to identify a news source in court.
PEDAGOGUES have provided stepping stones for Samuel Riley Pierce Jr. 36 years old, in his progress toward General Sessions, New York County's highest criminal court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson indicated today that he might lower the export price for Government cotton. He also suggested that he might review the export price periodically in the effort to move more surplus cotton.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 550,090 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

THE committee arranging the fifteenth annual National Antiques Show for the first week in March in Madison Square Garden is borrowing New York mementoes for the exhibition from museums and New York families.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 15 -- Judge George C. Wallace was ordered today to show why he should not be held in criminal contempt for refusing the Federal Civil Rights Commission access to voter registration records.

MADRID, Jan. 15 -- The Spanish Government faces an inevitable currency devaluation within the next few months, according to all available signs. Generalissimo Francisco Franco's hand is being forced by economic events outside Spain.

"ON THE TOWN," the cheerfully unpretentious musical with which the talents of Leonard Bernstein, Jerome Robbins, Betty Comden and Adolph Green exploded on Broadway fourteen years ago, was very pleasanttly revived at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse last evening.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The State Department is speeding the appointment of an ambassador to Cuba to convey United States concern over wide-scale executions there.

The naming of dec- The ades, like the naming Roaring of babies, is at best Twenties an arbitrary business. Was American life from 1890 to 1900 really one long lark, as we are led to believe by the expression "Gay Nineties"? Prob- ably not.
THE Diners' Club announced yesterday the addition of a new service.
The 1958 Catholic Youth Organization award for "outstanding service and inspiration to youth" was presented last night to Mrs. Charles H. Ridder.
Golfers in the New York district will honor their own metropolitan champions as well as national and international stars at she Metropolitan Golf Writers Association's awards dinner on Jan. 27.
Three brothers, along with seven other winners in the annual art contest of the Police Athletic League, received awards yesterday from Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- A surprise move by union negotiators today cast doubt that the nine-week-old strike of 37,500 International Harvester Workers would be settled quickly.
GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- A new move by the West is expected tomorrow at the three-power conference on banning nuclear tests.

The American Power Boat Association has named the following committee appointments for 1959: Executive Committee; William Edgar John, chairman, Rye, N. Y.; Donald L. Guerin, Webster, N. Y.; William A Smith, Staten Island; George J. Trimper, Buffalo; Jim Wilson, Quincy, Mass.; measurer and Chief Inspector, Charles D. Strang, Oshkosh, Wis.; Al Hart, assistant, Tahoe City, Calif., chief surveyor, Bob Schelling, Howey-In-The-Hills, Fla.; chief counsel.
Gian-Carlo Menotti's "Maria Golovin" will be the first opera to be taped by the N.B.C. Opera Theatre for television network production. Previous presentations were live.
The Ladies Auxiliary of the New York Foundling Hospital will give its ninth annual bridge luncheon on Jan. 29 in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane.

One domestic crisis has been settled at the Bronz Zoo but another is poised, as ominous as an elephant with a trunk of water. The first problem involved a female gibbon and two offspring. The second concerns a parrot and its vocabulary.
The Fire Department succeeded yesterday in serving a subpoena on the alleged agent of a tenement it ordered vacated Wednesday because of numerous fire hazards.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -O. Gordon Delk resigned today as Deputy Commissioner of Internal Revenue.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 15 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee rejected today a request by Vice President John M. Chang to discuss ways of easing South Korea's acute political tension.
The Federal Government's crackdown on organized crime is currently directed against the Mafia and its trafficking in narcotics.
Anastas I. Mikoyan expressed confidence yesterday that a great-power summit conference would be held eventually. But he refused to predict when.
A bright red sport shirt touched off a lively student debate over proper attire at the Columbia Grammar School yesterday.

The Boxing Writers Association held its thirty-third annual dinner, named the Bill Corum Memorial for the Journal-American columnist, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. More than 400 ring followers were in attendance.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- New Star, a Florida-bred, rallied with a burst of speed in the stretch today and won the Sophomore Handicap, the closing-day feature before 9,728 fans at Tropical Park.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, Jan, 15 -- Premier Michel Debre confirmed today more bluntly than ever before the strongly nationalist trend of French foreign policy under a Gaullist regime.

In the last six years Beatrice Krebs has been winning an enviable reputation for herself as an oratorio soloist and as a singer of character parts in opera. Last night at Carnegie Recital Hall she made a big plunge into a new field. She gave the first of three programs devoted entirely to lieder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today blocked the sale of two million dollars worth of stock by Hamilton Oil Gas Corporation, which lists Dan Thornton, former Governor of Colorado, and Frank Leahy, former football coach at Notre Dame, among its officers.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 15 -Official reassurances from Washington have failed to dispel the growing conviction here that a basic reappraisal of United States policy on Germany has begun.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has purchased the six-story mercantile building at 115-19 Worth Street, northwest corner of Lafayette Street. It is opposite the site of the proposed Federal Government office building.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Coast and Geodetic Survey published four small experimental charts of the Potomac River today.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Julius Bores and Billy Maxwell unleashed birdie barrages late today and tied for the opening-day lead with fiveunder par 67's in Bing Crosby's $50,000 golf tournament.
Tile first presentation of George Balanchine's "Concerto Barocco," set to the double violin concerto of Bach, opened the bill of the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the resignation of William R. Peer, his executive secretary in charge of press relation since Jan. 1, 1954.

PORTLAND, Conn., Jan. 15 -- A four-engine Air Force transport plane crashed and burned today in a heavily wooded area near here. Two men in the crew were killed. A third, who was thrown clear of the wreck, suffered serious injuries.

Two redesigned engines, available in true pairs, and an economy 8-horsepower singlecylinder engine are being displayed for the first time at the boat show by the Palmer Engine Company of Cos Cob, Conn. The complete exhibit includes engines ranging from 70 to 250 h.p.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Henry J. Friendly, a New York lawyer, is now the leading candidate for a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- A French offer of safe conduct for Algerian rebel leaders to come to France to discuss a ceasefire was renewed today before the National Assembly.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Kathy Cornelius of Lake Worth, Fla., and Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., carded 1-under-par 72's today to share the first-round lead in the Tampa women's open golf tournament.
The parents of Lisa Rose Chionchio, the infant kidnapped from a hospital nursery hours after her birth Jan. 2, were among the ten witnesses testifying yesterday before a Brooklyn grand jury.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 15 -- The Italian Left-wing Socialists, allies of the Communists, opened their thirty-third party congress today. The main question the congress is to decide is whether the party shall continue cooperating with the Communists as it has done since the end of World War II.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Scientists of the Bureau of Mines have made a major technological advance in the efforts to develop high-temperature metals for the missile-space age.

VALPARAISO, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The first Bomarc ground-to-air interceptor missile launched from a new multi-million-dollar test center here hit a jet drone eighty-five miles over the Gulf of Mexico.

A reliable Hollywood authority insists that Warner Brothers is purchasing the screen rights to "Tall Story" the impending Howard Lmdsay-Russel Crouse comedy, stemming from Howard Nemerov's novel, "The Home-coming Game."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Pancho Gonzales, the world professional tennis champion from Los Angeles, lost the victor's purse and his temper tonight when he bowed to Australia's Frank Sedgman in the final of the Victorian tournament, 6 -- 4, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 4.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Army announced today that Jane Marie Mullady of 64-39B 186th Lane, Fresh Meadows, Queens, was killed when she walked into the moving propeller of a light Army plane.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- About three-fourths of the total spending on defense contracts went to 100 prime contractors and organizations during the twelve months end-ng last June 30, the Pentagon reported today.
An investigation by the Bronx District Attorney's office into charges that a borough church had not paid two women their share of a $1,000 bingo prize was dropped yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Loyal sons of Yale need not fear that their alma mater has been tampering with the official calendar.
Refuse will be collected five instead of six days a week in five sections of the city starting Monday, Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane announced yesterday.

At 6 o'clock tonight (pleasure boat skippers like to call it 4 bells), winter will come to a ten-day halt. Landlubbers may feel frigid air, even think there is rain or snow falling the next few days, but pleasure boatmen won't believe it.
The city's annual observance of Printing Week was brought to a climax last night with the dedication of the seven-story building housing the thirty- three-year-old New York School of Printing.

TUNIS, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- President Habib Bourguiba bitterly attacked today France's action in devaluating the Franc. He announced that the French-Tunisian customs union had "practically ceased to exist."
EACH exhibition of the graphic work of Kaethe Kollwitz adds to the impact of her profoundly moving human statements.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 15 -- President Arturo Frondizi has prepared a list of topics for discussion with United States officials during his forthcoming visit. They include military cooperation, industrial development and an exchange of nuclear materials.
Patterson Brothers, Inc., a 110-year-old New York hardware store, will close the doors of its Park Row and Madison Avenue outlets tonight for the last time.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner, announced today the names of seventy additional winners of Regents college teaching fellowships. Each fellowship is good for two years and carries a stipend of $2,500 a year.

Malcolm Roberts, unseeded, upset the defender, Calvin MacCracken, in the New York State singles squash racquets championship yesterday. Roberts, from the Lone Star Club, won by 16 -- 18, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 7 at the Downtown A. C., to gain the semi-finals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -Representative Thomas L. Ashley of Ohio rejected today appointment as an assistant Democratic whip of the House. He said that Speaker Sam Rayburn had refused to give Northern Democrats a voice in shaping party policy.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Nations eager to haul down "flags of convenience" scored a substantial victory at today's assembly session of the United Nations Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz asked the Legislature today for stronger restrictions on fly-by-night charity organizations that prey on the public.

Anthony Anastasia, vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, was a pleasant and courteous host yesterday to three reporters he escorted through his nearly completed $750,000 union hall in Brooklyn.
Just being 100 years old yesterday was joy enough for Mrs. John H. Rand. So, stacks of birthday mail were laid aside temporarily, and a family celebration was put off until later.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The Rockefeller administration's search for $230,000,000 in additional taxes was complicated today by a demand for a $140,000,000 rise in state aid to education.
TO a woman accustomed to planning her home for her husband's comfort, widowhood poses many problems.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- French books, including some contemporary novels, will become the first Western books sold here in many years under the terms of a new cultural and technical agreement negotiated between France and the Soviet Union today.
A SMALL, dark, owl-eyed man who resembles Napoleon is, indeed, emperor of the hat designers.
ATLANTA, Jan. 15 -- Gov. Ernest Vandiver, in his first message to the Georgia Legislature, proposed today six new measures aimed at preserving racial segregation in the state's public schools.

Businesses trimmed their borrowings from the larger New York City banks $52,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a reduction of $84,000,000 in the similar week a year earlier.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Texas Railroad Commission ordered an increase of 31,971 barrels a day in the February Texas oil allowable today, fixing the permissive flow at 3,194,826 a day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Post Office announced today that it would postpone indefinitely collections of the penalty charge for delivering mail with insufficient postage.

A married couple described as "accident prone" by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan were among nineteen persons indicted yesterday for grand larceny in fraudulently obtaining welfare payments. A twentieth was cited for obtaining welfare under false pretenses, a misdemeanor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Dr. Herbert Dittman, special representative of Chancellor Adenauer, is satisfied that the United States will not soon nor easily abandon the policy of German unification by free elections.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- Jerry Lewis will star in a Broadway stage musical comedy next fall provided he can arrange his heavy schedule of movie commitments to take at least six months away from Hollywood.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- An omnibus housing bill backed by the Democratic leadership was introduced in the House today. It set the stage for the first major battle in the new Congress.
Personnel at Mitchel Air Force Base, Hempstead, L. I., will give blood to the Red Cross today.

MIAMI, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Nineteen top sprinters were named today for the Royal Poinciana Handicap, so Hialeah had to split the race into two divisions for tomorrow's season opening. The meeting will run forty days.
Religious, political and social-action student organizations at City College will no longer receive student funds.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner was sworn in yesterday as the first member of the women's reserve of the Boy Scouts of America. She received a membership card and pin from Dr. Phiny H. Powers, deputy chief scout executive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The year 1958 finished with a surge in housing starts, a continued upward movement in industrial production and a slight dip in personal income, Government reports revealed today.
Captain's Club, a service organization of the pleasure-boat waterways, will begin accepting its first memberships this week in Florida. Eventually its service zones will take in the entire country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Diplomatic immunity is no bar to testifying in Federal court, the United States Court of Appeals ruled today.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Formation of a "United Germany" in which nuclear weapons would be prohibited was proposed tonight by Harold E. Stassen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Senator Prescott Bush introduced legislation today authorizing the Government to reimburse states for toll and free roads incorporated in the 41,000-mile interstate system.
TRENTON, Jan. 15 - Gov. Robert B. Meyner plans to appoint a state Coordinator of Commuter Rapid Transit within a week.
Fuel has been added to the flaming argument about the race for space by last week's publication of the final report of the House Committee on Astronautics and Space Exploration.

LOWER BANK, N. J., Jan. 15 -- For nine generations the Leek family has built boats on the banks of the Mullica River. Once these were bay scows that hauled salt hay from the marshes, oyster boats and small, sturdy schooners for the coastwise trade.

TRENTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The New Jersey Racing Commission, in a sharp departure from usual practice, today held closed meetings on applications for 1959 racing dates. Chairman Thomas J. Brogan said the meetings could not be termed "hearings."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -Five Democrats believed agreeable to the House liberal wing were reported today to have been chosen to fill vacancies on the House Education and Labor Committee.

Lazare Saminsky has had a ong and active life as a conductor and a composer. For many years he has been musical director of Temple Emanu-EI, and an organizer and conductor of music festivals. Last fall, he retired from his post at the temple and last night at the Hunter College Playhouse, a concert of his music marked his fortieth year in the United States.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The British Government struck out today against the sale and publication of intimate views of the royal family by its servants.

The Kingdom of Denmark is planning to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a proposed public offering of $15,000,000 of external dollar loan bonds to be sold in the United States market under the direction of Kuhn, Loeb Co., Smith. Barney Co., Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The grain futures market appeared today to have exhausted again all its recent bullish influences. Although there were several rises in the list on the Board of Trade not one exceeded a fourth of a cent a bushel while a few setbacks ran to a cent or more.
The fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases continued to climb yesterday toward a possible new record.

Atkinson, Here From Florida, Doesn't Want to Wind Up Career 'Going Downhill' Ted Atkinson, one of America's great jockeys, returned to New York from Miami yesterday facing the possibility that his riding career may be ended because of a back ailment.
Boats and motors made in nine foreign countries are on display at the National Motor Boat Shbow at the Coliseum.
The threat of a strike by the Radio and Television Directors Guild against three networks receded as both sides agreed to resume contract talks at 10:30 A. M. today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem has made an overt move to control the Communist movement in Iraq.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 15 -- President Francois Duvalier of Haiti declared today that he would allow dictatorial powers by which he has ruled by decree for six months to expire on schedule Jan. 30. The country will return to democratic rule, he said.
A new store selling spare parts for jets opened yesterday at New York International Airport and served two customers -- American Airlines and Pan American World Airways.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 15 -- Tribal unrest in the mountain areas during recent weeks has impelled Morocco into perhaps the gravest crisis in her three years as an independent state.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A test of the national Civil Defense warning system was held today. A signal for a simulated or hypothetical air raid warning was put into the system this afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Stock market prices advanced on a broad front today, although buying remained fairly selective and on a small scale.

TODAY and tomorrow the concluding performances will be given of a remarkable religious play that opened at the Union Theological Seminary last evening. It is Henri Gheon's "The Mystery of the Finding of the Cross," in an English translation by Frank de Jonge, and staged by E. Martin Browne and Henzie Raeburn.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The public, to whom the British Museum was opened 200 years ago to the day, took no more note of the anniversary today than did "Ginger Jim."

The $10,000,000 loss in potential retail business said to have resulted from New York's nineteen-day newspaper shutdown was termed "highly conservative" yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, Inc.
Plans were announced yesterday for a study of the school problems confronting city children who move to the suburbs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers called today for a "concerted effort" by the Negroes of the South to register and vote.

WASHNGTON, Jan. 15 -- Roger W. Jones, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau and a long-time career civil servant, is slated for nomination to the chairmanship of the Civil Service Commission, according to authoritative reports.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- There is a growing belief here that the American people, much more than the Kremlin, can press for changes in the Eisenhower-Dulles foreign policies.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 15 -- The leaders of Yugoslavia and India surveyed the world around them today and decided that it would be a happier place if the great powers could agree "at an early date" to end nuclear tests.
Just when ski operators in the north country were becoming fearful that the annual January thaw would present itself and ruin the snow picture, along came a heartening weather forecast last night.
Deere Co. achieved record sales and increased earnings in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, Wililam A. Hewitt, president, reported yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- France granted formal diplomatic recognition today to the new republic of Guinea, four months after that former French West African colony became independent.

Columbia's varsity basketball team, which won its opening game on Dec. 3, then lost its next eleven, extended favored Princeton considerably last night at University Hall before succumbing to the Tigers' overall superiority, 75 -- 66.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Air Force has failed in its latest effort to shoot the mighty Atlas over its full intercontinental range. The missile sputtered out last night after having gone about 200 miles.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization agreed today to ask the International Court of Justice for an advisory opinion on the knotty legal questions that have disturbed its deliberations this week.
George Abbott and John Allen have taken great strides toward completing the musical they are tailoring for Genevieve, French singer.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 16 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's special assistant has asked to be relieved of his post in order to defend himself against charges of impropriety published in the Communist press here.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 16 -- Elgin Baylor, rookie star of the professional Minneapolis Lakers, refused to play tonight in a National Basketball Association game against Cincinnati in protest against segregation policies at a hotel here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Administration made public today scientific data supporting its new conclusion that underground nuclear explosions were more difficult to detect than had been estimated previously.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Art Wall of Pocono Manor, Pa., took the second-day lead in the $50,000 Bing Crosby national pro-amateur golf tournament today, but Jimmy Demaret took the spotlight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Taxpayers may be allowed next year to use the simple punch card form, 1040A, on incomes up to $15,000, the Internal Revenue Commissioner said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., ousted Republican leader, ended up better off today than all the Congressional leaders at least in one respect: He had the newest chauffeurdriven Cadillac limousine.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan made two Government changes today affecting the political direction of foreign affairs.
Little-known germs called PPLO (for pleuropneumonia-like organisms) may be the cause of some baffling common human infections, it was reported here yesterday.

TO illustrate the outlook of American artists who were influenced by the Impressionist movement in Europe in the last quarter of the nineteenth century and the early part of the twentieth, the American Academy of Arts and Letters is opening today in its gallery on Audubon Terrace, Broadway and 155th Street, a notable loan exhibition of more than eighty paintings by thirty-three American artists.
MADRID, Jan. 16 -- Spain and Britain have renewed their controversy over the 255-year-old issue of Gibraltar.

The building at 154 Market Street, Newark, N. J., has been purchased for investment by Realty Equities, Inc., for cash over mortgages amounting to $516,000. It contains 22,000 square feet of space and is occupied under a long-term net lease by Crawford Clothes.
LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 16 -Henrique Galvao, a political prisoner since 1953, escaped from the Santa Maria Hospital here last night.
BERGDORF GOODMAN is now offering a professional decorating service, an unusual feature for a women's specialty store. The decorating division is set up within the antiques shop on the fourth floor.

LONDON, Saturday, July 17 -- The resumption of trading relations with Egypt is being cautiously considered by British business men following the initialing of the financial agreement. It is not yet certain whether many British concerns will choose to re-enter the Egyptian market until the situation, politically as well as economically, is clearer.

BANGALORE, India, Jan. 16 (Reuters) -- Batting on a perfect pitch, the West Indies touring cricket side scored 373 for seven wickets on the opening day of the three-day match against a South Zone team today.

Two calls have been sounded within recent days to pause and take a leisurely look at what is basic to the improved future of New York City. In the onward rush of having to deal with immediate, pressing governmental housekeeping problems it is hard to find time to take inventory, examine the whole, study distant destinations.

Deputy Premier Mikoyan's American tour reaches its climax today at a meeting with President Eisenhower at the White House. There has been speculation that Mr. Mikoyan has sought this meeting to submit new proposals, perhaps a bid for another summit meeting.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Plans for the construction of the largest hotel to be built here in thirty years have been announced by Mayor Richard J. Daley and Wayne A. Johnston, president of the Illinois Central Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Treasury reported today it had received subscriptions totaling $1,800,000,000 for its $750,000,000 issue of 4 per cent Treasury bonds of 1980.
Medical science has made a discovery that will enable a partly paralyzed housewife to wash her dishes and perchance to make a pie.

Events today: "Manon Les-I caut," 2 P. M., and "Un Ballo in Maschera," 8, Metropolitan Opera; Boston Symphony Orchestra, conductor, Robert Shaw; Concert Artists Guild, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 3;I Margot Rebeil, soprano, Town Hall, 5:30; Herbert Stessin, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic conductor, Sir John Barbirolli Berl Senofsky, violinist, 8:30.

A group of seventy-eight residents in the area of Riverside Drive and West Ninety-eighth Street charged yesterday that their neighborhood was becoming "increasingly unhabitable" because of inadequate police protection.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The proposed contract called for a 6-cent-an-hour or 2 1/2 per cent wage increase, whichever is larger. Pay under the old contract averaged $2.55 an hour.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 16 -A Foreign Ministry official said today that Ellis O. Briggs, the United States Ambassador, had delivered an informal paper contradicting an often-cited Brazilian economic study predicting that the Soviet Union would become the world's leading economic power by 1980.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Average wholesale prices in the primary market rose 0.1 per cent to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday advanced 2 to 12 points (10 to 60 cents a bale), except the new July which fell 40 points ($2 a bale). July is an inactive month so far.
The Democratic League of Haiti called upon Haiti's President Francois Duvalier today to guarantee a free Presidential election under the auspices of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -C. Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, told a religious gathering here today that this country's foreign aid program was a moral obligation to underdeveloped nations, whether or not the threat of communism existed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Active short-covering raised soybean futures contracts rather substantially all along the line on the Board of Trade today as dealers considered two possible bullish influences.

A daily feature of The New York Times is a column called "Man in the News." It gives a sketch of a person prominent in the news of the day, combining information about the individual's career and an insight into his personality.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Democratic nations are accustomed to the fact that democracy, as practiced by different Governments, is practiced in various forms. We see democratic monarchies and democratic republics. We accept as equally democratic societies in which the legislature dominates and societies in which the Executive overshadows Parliament.

WELL known in his native land, the contemporary Danish painter, Kay Christensen has waited until this year for his work to be shown in this country, at the Meltzer Gallery, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street.
An Alaskan who finds the winters in New York pretty rugged has nonetheless come to town as an economic missionary.
The financial affairs of the C.I.O. Buffalo Council were found yesterday to be in a satisfactory condition after a daylong hearing here.
The bust of James Kent (1763-1847) was stolen from the Hall of Fame Thursday night.
KANSAS CITY, Jan 16 (AP) -- A wage offer by a key oil industry employer today ended threats of a week-end strike by 105,000 refinery workers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee picked Senator Stuart Symington as its target today for a broadside signaling an early start on the 1960 campaign.

ZABAGLIONE gelato is the chilled version of a fluffy, custard-like Italian dessert that is subtly flavored with marsala. A Long Island reader has requested a recipe for the dessert, which is popular in many Italian restaurants here.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Japan's Sadao Yaoita, a 4-1 short-ender, tonight defeated the world flyweight champion, Pascual Perez of Argentina. It was the first defeat of Perez' pro career. The 23-year-old Japanese won a unanimous decision in the non-title ten-round bout.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -The United States rejected today the Soviet Union's request for an immediate resumption of talks on measures to reduce the danger of surprise attack.

Volunteer Service Photographers will gain from a theatre party at next Thursday's performance of "Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre. A few tickets still remain and may be obtained at the group's office at 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.
A spectator in a West Fortysecond Street movie house, escaped serious injury yesterday when he was thrown twenty feet from the balcony to the orchestra floor in a fight with another patron.
One of the delegates to the gangland meeting at Apalachin, N. Y., fourteen months ago was ordered to jail yesterday for his refusal to answer questions by the State Commission of Investigation.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 16 -George S. Craft was elected this week as president and a director of the Trust Company of Georgia. He succeeds Charles E. Thwaite Jr., who was elevated to chairman.

Thousands of buyers from all parts of the country have completed here the high point in their inspection and ordering of merchandise for the spring and summer retail selling seasons.
The United Whelan Corporation, which operates a retail drug chain, is further diversifying its activities through acquisition of Crawford Clothes, Inc., men's apparel chain.

It seemed probable yesterday that the city would have to seek power to increase its sales tax to 4 per cent to close most of the $145,000,000 gap between available revenues and the 1959-60 expense budget.
PARENTS anxious to have their children think for themselves outside the home were advised recently to respect the right of youngsters to challenge some parental opinions and decisions.
Steels, rubbers and meat packers were firm yesterday in a session of the New York Stock Exchange that swung vigorously in both directions and ended with little net change in the averages.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Paulie Armstead, Los Angeles lightweight, scored a controversial split decision over favored Len Matthews of Philadelphia in a furious tenround fight tonight.
The nation's major chain and mail order companies wound up 1958 with a sales increase of 5.1 per cent over those of 1957, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

N. Y. City Housing Authority The New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $20,300,000 of serial bonds on Jan. 27. The issue will come due on Jan. 1 from 1960 to 2006. Money from the sale will be used for the permanent financing of Linden Houses, a city subsidized development in Brooklyn.

CAIRO, Saturday, Jan. 17 -Egypt and Britain ended two years of bitter estrangement early today when their representatives initialed an agreement on the financial problems that arose from nationalization of the Universal Suez Canal Company in July, 1956, and the ensuing British-French attack on Egypt.
THE impulse to go South moves people as much as it does birds. According to American Express, millions of Americans will migrate between now and the end of March, when the resort season ends.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 16 (UPI) -- The trainer, Frank Childs, was seriously injured today at Santa Anita during the early-morning workout period when his saddle pony reared and fell on him.

The American Jewish Committee released yesterday a detailed memorandum that it is forwarding to Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet Deputy Premier, listing suppression of every phase of Jewish activity in the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- A nonprofit corporation established last year to provide financial aid for college students has guaranteed loans to 3,584 students so far this year.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Jan. 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower wished Gen. George C. Marshall a speedy and complete recovery today from the slight stroke the retired soldier-statesman suffered earlier this week.
JOHN SOLUM, flutist, made his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
Hawaiian sugar growers are trying out a new machine to extract juice from sugar cane, using a method that went out of style more than fifty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -The Democrats projected today quick hearings and early Congressional action on a bill for a $1,000,000,000 airport construction program.

The Knickerbockers, who have been faring poorly on the road, will seek their fourth straight National Basketball Association home victory this afternoon when they meet the Cincinnati Royals at the 69th Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Wheat, sorghum grains and soybeans from the bumper farm production of 1958 are being stored under Government price supports at a record rate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -Anastas I. Mikoyan and Secretary of State Dulles conferred at length today on United States-Soviet differences in preparation for a meeting with President Eisenhower tomorrow morning.
Four Chinese orphans, the children of refugees from Communist China, were met by their new parents yesterday as they arrived here by air.

THE odd jacket, fashioned in the manner of Chanel, is one beautiful way to stretch a resort wardrobe. Worn over linen dresses or with shorts and shirts, the jacket fashion is prettiest in strong, vibrant colors.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- The new weather information service of the New York State Thruway Authority kept employes busy today changing the posted warnings for motorists.

In an opulent setting of blue, silver and crystal in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, the program of the Viennese Opera Ball opened last night with a minuet danced by a group wearing elaborate costumes of Old Vienna.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission asked the United States Court of Appeals today to extend to Feb. 2 the time for filing its findings concerning Tuscarora Indian land sought for the Niagara Power project near Niagara Falls, N. Y.
Pablo Casals, who was 82 years old on Dec. 29, will perform in eight of the twelve concerts of Puerto Rico's third annual Casals Festival.
NEWARK, Jan. 16 -- The New Jersey State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners today granted the Public Service Electric and Gas Company a temporary increase of $3,500,000 in gas rates.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Gordon Chalmers today was named athletic director at Iowa State College.

ROME, Jan. 16 -- Someone must have spread the word all over Rome that the newest "look" in fashion was the wide one that American designers endorsed in their spring collections a month ago. Six Italian houses have just shown their spring models and, to a designer, they prefer wide shoulders, wideopen necklines, wide belts and hippy, wideat-the-side skirts.
2Vfany New Yorkers of southern birth attended the seventythird annual Dixie Dinner of the New York Southern Society last night in the Grand Ballf room of the Plaza.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The congress of the Italian Socialist party gave a threeand-a-half-minute ovation today to an appeal that it renounce party leader Pietro Nenni's road to political isolationism and return to its old alliance with the Communists.

Britain's trade deficit -- that is, the excess of imports over exports -- fell last year to the lowest level since 1950, according to the final figures of the Board of Trade. It totaled $1,192,800,000, or $523,600,000 less than the year before.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Eastern Air Lines collected close to half a million dollars in benefits last month from the other airlines under their mutual assistance agreement in event of strikes.
Local 153, of the Office Employes International Union, scored a victory yesterday in its initial invasion of the freight-forwarding industry.
BOB HOPE'S Christmas invasion of United States military bases overseas turned into pleasant television on Channel 4 last night.

The development of a workable device to generate electricity from radioactive isotopes was hailed yesterday as an important achievement, even though the fuel presently used to generate five watts is valued at about $30,000,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- With both clubs in top condition, the action should be first-rate when the New York Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks collide tomorrow afternoon in a Nationally televised National Hockey League game in the Chicago Stadium.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 -- A donor who requested anonymity gave Harvard College $2,000,000 for scholarships today.
THE world's most adventurous and expensive fashion show was held 30,000 feet in the air Thursday night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee listened skeptically today to what one of its members called a "mildly optimistic" Administration report on national defense.
HAVANA, Jan. 16 -- United States and Cuban business men and industrialists in Cuba are paying taxes in advance in an effort to help the revolutionary Government.

A no-raiding decision by the merged labor federation may have the ironic effect of sending 800 Pan American World Airways stock clerks into the outcast International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Included in the group are 325 clerks employed at the Air Force guided-missile center at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The United States, represented by an Air Force All-Star team, defeated Argentina tonight, 87 -- 73, at Concepcion in a first-round game in the world amateur basketball championship.

The little kingdom of Laos is the most recent of several young independent states to discard, at least formally, some of the forms of constitutional democracy and adopt a firmer executive rule. The reason given there is not unlike that in some neighboring nations. The democratic structures, it was held, were too feeble to cope with the instant threat of subversion from within and aggression from without.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- An atomic generator smaller than a man's hat was displayed today by the Atomic Energy Commission. It has no moving parts and is capable of doing the work of 1,450 pounds of the best electric batteries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower chose Dr. Wernher von Braun and four others today to receive the highest honor the nation confers on career civil servants.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 16 -- South Korean plainclothes policemen have seized a Korean who had entered the United States Embassy building in the central part of Seoul and held him for five hours. An embassy officer said today the embassy lodged a strong protest with the South Korean Foreign Office and received a full apology.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 16 -- Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, called off, a scheduled news conference here today and left New Delhi empty-handed.
BUFFALO, Jan, 16 (AP) -- Billy Welu of St. Louis led the field midway in the finals of the All-Star bowling tournament tonight.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A high East German Communist said today that his regime intended to take control of the air corridors to isolated West Berlin. He declared it would be suicidal for the Western planes to try to go through the air lanes without permission.
Activity in the new capital market will be at a fairly high level next week with five major debt offerings scheduled for competitive bidding.

Artur Rubinstein turned to his favorite composer -- or, at least, the composer with whom his name has been most closely allied -- last night in Carnegie Hall, where he gave the first of three Chopin programs. The hall was sold out, and all available space on the stage was filled with eager listeners.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Chris Crawford of Piedmont, Calif., gained the third ground of the Australian national tennis tournament today by beating Barry Phillips Moore of Australia, 15 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- There was no shortage in the quantity of movies available last year to theatres in Los Angeles, at least. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced today that a total of 396 feature pictures had been set aside for nomination as best-picture "Oscar" award contenders.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt, who tried for two years to obtain a bill for a state school financing authority, renewed his request today. He urged that the bill be brought up for a public hearing to "prevent the backroom maneuvering" that blocked it in 1957 and 1958.
Three hold-up men used psychology instead of their pistols last night to get $14,000 from the safe of an upper East Side supermarket.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- About 8,000 requests have been received for graduate fellowships under the new Defense Education Act, but Congress thus far has voted funds for only 160.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 16 --The United States, Britain and France will probably extend for one year the order to Alfried Krupp to sell his vast coal and steel holdings.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- The United Auto Workers Harvester Council voted acceptance tonight by a narrow margin of a three-year contract with the International Harvester Company.

CAMILLA, Ga., Jan. 16 -- It is a brutal act to shoot one of a man's wild gobblers within a few feet of him while he is strolling along without a gun, convinced that the turkey hunting is over for the day.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The French National Assembly gave overwhelming approval today to Premier Michel Debre and his Government for a program emphasizing unshakable French sovereignty over Algeria.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A simmering controversy in the Legislature over public relief probably will come to a boil at the Capitol on Feb. 18.
BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- Three Boston longshoremen were ordered today to appear before a grand jury next Monday in New York. The jury is investigating labor conditions on the New York waterfront.

ALGIERS, Jan. 16 -- The first of the French Government's clemency measures affecting Algerian Moslems have gone into effect. At the same time protests from European conservatives to local authorities and newspapers diminished today.
IN his long, arduous and often troubled life, Dr. Syngman Rhee has been called many things -- a patriot, a tyrant, a stubborn old man.
Joseph J. Hogan was freed from prison yesterday and reunited with his five motherless children through the efforts of Bernard Moldow, Legal Aid Society lawyer.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold expressed guarded optimism today regarding developments in the Middle East.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 16 -President Arturo Frondizi has approved decrees restoring to the former owners the Bemberg properties valued at more than $100,000,000. These properties were seized in the celebrated Peronist expropriation.

MIAMI, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Kentucky Pride blistered the racing strip today in winning the second division of the Royal Poinciana Handicap at Hialeah. The Hasty House Farm's Solution turned in a surprise victory in the first section of the stakes at the opening of the forty-day meeting.

Julius F. Mercandino, 48 years old, is a lucky man, and he is the first to admit it. A week ago yesterday morning he jotted down on a pad "Smith Barney 100 (X) 97 1/2 Benton. That meant that he, as a new member of the New York Stock Exchange, had bought 100 shares of United States Steel for Smith Barney Co., from Benton Co.
One of the nation's smallest, trimmest and most earnest athletes decided yesterday to end the career that has brought him esteem and affluence.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., shot a par 73 in a cold, strong wind today to take a five-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the Tampa women's open golf tournament.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, pledged today the full cooperation of his organization in the form of technical advice and service to the new Arab Development Bank formed by the Arab League.
One of Brooklyn's dreariest slum areas, between the Williamsburg Bridge Plaza and the Navy Yard, is in a ferment of efforts to rebuild and a controversy over the kind of new housing it should have.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) -The Soviet Union's cosmic rocket has reached the closest point it will go to the sun, the Moscow radio said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In extensive experiments at the University of California, scientists have combined the disposal of city wastes with the production of animal fodder. They have been using sewage treatment ponds to grow algae, tiny plants that thrive on sunlight and supply a nourishing diet of protein, fats and carbohydrates.
The National Horse Show will be held in Madison Square Garden this year Nov. 3 to 10, according to a listing issued yesterday by the American Horse Shows Association.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 15 -- A social experiment here to improve the conditions of the lowest-paid unskilled workers has attracted wide attention among students of labor legislation in the Americas and Europe.

Ramex Associates, Inc., which recently contracted to buy the Raleigh Hotel at 121 West Seventy-second Street, has sold its contract to an investing client of the Herbert W. Tuttle Company, broker. Governor Rockefeller declared last night that his chief interest in the city's need for more revenue was to get a tax increase that would be the least detrimental to the people and to business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -Fifty freshmen members of the House of Representatives won assignments to major committees today. This unusual kindness to first-termers was brought on by the resounding Democratic victories in November.
The National Broadcasting Company is moving its "Ellery Queen" mystery series from Hollywood to New York, where it will have a new producer and star.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Dalton Trumbo, blacklisted by the movie industry as one of the "unfriendly ten" witnesses after hearings of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, tonight said he had written "The Brave One" -an Academy Award winning script for 1956.
SHANNON, Ireland, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- A trans-Atlantic airliner carrying a Soviet amateur hockey team made an emergency landing today after a dash across the ocean to the Irish coast.
BELVIDERE, N. J., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Elmer Mayberry, game warden, was jailed tonight after pleading innocent to a charge of murder in the death of a deer poacher yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) -Ward's Automotive Reports said today that auto manufacturers probably would build 100,000 more cars this month than in January, 1958, when 489,357 were built.
DALLAS, Jan. 16 (AP) -Mickey Mantle indicated today he had laid plans for a long battle to get the 1959 contract he thought he deserved from the New York Yankees.

Frederick Ashton's "Illuminations" was restored to the repertory of the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, with Nicholas Magallanes, Melissa Hayden and Diana Adams once more in the chief roles, and Ellen Faull again singing the beautiful song cycle of Benjamin Britten that comprises the score.

SAN JUAN, P. R. Jan. 16 -In his state of the commonwealth message delivered to the Legislature just before he left for Washington today, Gov. Luis Munos Marin said the time has come for the United States and Puerto Rico to "consider jointly certain clarifications and modifications of the compact existing between the two Governments."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Government business came close to a standstill for a few minutes at the White House today. Kim Novak and Perry Como showed up.
LITTLE ROCK, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A state legislative committee declared today that Arkansas' racial unrest had been deliberately engineered by the Communist party.

KOCHI, Japan, Jan. 8 -- Raiden, a gigantic brown dog with a strain of English mastiff in his ancestry, is the reigning sports idol in this city of 180,000. As many as 2,000 paying spectators witness Raiden's competitive appearances in this remote prefecture on the eastern side of Shikoku, the smallest of Japan's four main islands.

The to-do over the goodwill tour of Anastas I. Mikoyan, First Deputy Premier of Russia, seems hardly to have penetrated the market limbo where Russia's defaulted dollar bonds have been languishing since they were delisted by the American Stock Exchange in 1956.

The Tri-Continental Corporation reported yesterday record year-end investment assets of $392,054,570, equal to $48.38 a share. This compared with $303,413,142, or $36.42 each on fewer shares on Dec. 31, 1957.
The International Business Machines Corporation achieved new records in sales and earnings last year, according to preliminary figures issued yesterday by Thomas J. Watson Jr., president.

NORWALK, Jan. 16 -- The City Trust Company at its annual stockholders meeting this week elected Robert H. Whitney as president. He succeeds Charles W. Bitzer, who was elected chairman. New directors are William A. Haist Jr. and A. Fuller Leeds, senior vice president and trust officer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A new battle has broken out in the war over Government purchases of heavy machinery from foreign manufacturers.
MOSCOW, Jan. 16 (UPI) -The Soviet Union warned Iran in a formal note today not to sign a military agreement with the United States. The Russians offered to "exchange views" with Iran on the issue.
The New Haven Railroad reported yesterday that a dragging piece of broken equipment had caused the freight train wreck in Stamford last Saturday.

Maximum fines were imposed yesterday on two officials of the realty firm that operates an apartment house at 380 Riverside Drive. The building is the one in which a youth was recently killed in an elevator accident.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 16 -- Western observers here were optimistic today over the outlook for Laos. They believe there is a good chance the Communist influence can be overcome and a new phase of progress and development can be begun in this little Buddhist kingdom on the Mekong River.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 16 -Federal and state officials offered support today to a drive intended to ease employment problems on Long Island caused by recent cut-backs in defense production.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Industrial shares went higher today on buying stimulated by yesterday's rise of Wall Street and by some favorable company statements.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. WYANDOT off New Zealand, Jan. 16 -- Warm weather, a couple of sunsets and a seagoing symposium on the Antarctic have ben the highlights of a seven-day, 2,200-mile voyage from the bottom of the world to New Zealand.

In keeping with the growing demand for smaller, more compact inboard power plants, the new marine Diesel engines featured at the boat show are lighter in weight and have lower silhouettes. Many models suitable for use in sailing auxiliaries and small work boats are on view.

VANDENBURG A.F.B., Calif. Atop a sandy hill overlooking the blue Pacific, a Thor intermediate-range missile stands at this base, waiting to be launched. During the next days or weeks a scientist will turn a key in the adjacent blockhouse and Thor will hurtle skyward -- it is hoped -- carrying aloft the first Discoverer satellite.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 -- A source within the Democratic group indicated tonight that Philadelphia had emerged as one of the strongest candidates.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17--State subsidies are being withdrawn from a number of theatres in Moscow, Leningrad and other cities, the newspaper Sovietskaya Kultura reported today.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, received a pledge of full support yesterday from the State Commissioner of Education for efforts to increase teacher salaries.
The recreational boating industry's first national convention will be staged in October, 1960, under the auspices of the Outboard Boating Club of America.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- This island city, situated at the farthest point south in the United States and long known for its Spanish atmosphere and the siesta-like attitude that goes with it, is beginning to wake up and compete more aggressively for a share of the tourist trade.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 17 -- Wallace (Bud) Werner of the United States cracked his jinx by winning the men's downhill event in the twentieth Hahnekamm ski races today. He led a record run down the famous Streif course.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Jan. 17 -- In St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral here this morning Miss Mary Therese Vincent of Centerport, daughter of the Rev. Bernard J. Vincent of Port Chester, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Vincent, was married to Richard Herbert Schuster.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 17 --This capital, an equatorial cauldron where dreams of a better Indonesia are frequently trampled by party politicking, seems to have a fondness for living on the brink of big decisions--and this was a big week of brink living.

The forty-ninth National Motor Boat Show had its first full day in the New York Coliseum yesterday. The attendance was heavy. It always is.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 17 -- Bowie race track today offered Ted Atkinson a job as an official, starting with the 1959 meeting which begins Feb. 7 and continues through March 31.
Beagles continued to lead the popularity parade in 1958 among the breeds recognized by the American Kennel Club. Chihuauhuas remained in second place.

ALMOST any subject, approached from the vantage points of separate disciplines, may yield insights not discernible otherwise. Here we have two books on Latin America, written by exponents of two disciplines, that of the historian and that of the missionary priest, both concerned with the development, spiritual and material of that vast area south of the Rio Bravo.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- In the plaza at Main Street and Broadway, the tall evergreen tree stands cheerfull y girdled with red-blue-green lights. Passing motorists, sportsmen and visitors recognize it as an invitation to attend Saranac's annual gala winter carnival.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho -- Added attention to facilities for tyro skiers, plus a new spotlight on Tyrolean decor, mark the new season at this winter sports resort in the lee of Idaho's Sawtooth Range.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Much has been written about the impact of the visit of Anastas I. Mikoyan upon the United States. But rather less attention has been paid to the impact of the United States upon the Soviet's First Deputy Premier.
A 19-year-old junior at City College has been awarded the college's only foreign study award, the Aaron Naumberg Scholarship.

SCHOOLS and individual instructors have announced courses in amateur photography to start this month and next.

The second of three specially designed bauxite carriers that the Ormet Corporation will place in operation this year will be named Revere, in honor of the famous patriot. This was announced by James M. Kennedy, chairman of the board of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Some 371 Princeton University undergraduates have decided that the present United States Constitution does not fully meet requirements of the space age.
BELLEAYRE, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- A ski team representing New Jersey defeated a squad of New Yorkers by 33.5 seconds today to win the eighth annual giant slalom.
An all-Handel evening of arias, covering a half-century of the composer's work, will be held at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

ROME, Jan. 17 -- The Pope called for special prayers in the diocese of Rome Jan. 25 for the Roman Catholics of China. He said they were threatened with a "fatal schism." He will participate in the prayers that day in the Basilica of St. Paul outside the walls of the western outskirts of Rome.
WASHINGTON -- In less than two years, the National Association of Marine Dealers has established itself as a potent factor in America's fastest growing sport.

BY the tourist calendar, if not by the wanderings of the sun and earth, we are midway through the winter season, and what a strange season it has been so far. Long-awaited developments went by unnoticed, some lost in the blackout of the New York City newspaper strike, others postponed and delayed by airline strikes and revolutions.

LET me assure Professor Tumin that I did read his book and that my criticisms that he has not taken the pains to refute, still stand. The momentum of 1958's advancing stock market was undiminished last week. There was no spectacular rise, but prices rose to record highs in fits and starts. Apparently, inflation is of concern to the business community.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 17 -- John Motley Morehead, 88 years old, philanthropist of Rye, N. Y. has added six private preparatory schools to the "eligibility list" for $5,000 Morehead scholarships at the University of North Carolina, his alma mater.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 (AP) -- W. Hal Bishop's Pete's Folly today strengthened his claim as the top horse at the Fair Grounds with a neck victory in the $10,000 Marriage Handicap.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. -- More than half a century after the first international automobile race was held on the hard-packed sands here where automobile racing history has since been made, this area will celebrate the opening of a new speedway.

The United States Coast Guard unites in one organization facilities and personnel for the performance of many functions designed to improve the safety of the growing numbers of those who operate water craft for pleasure or profit.
A pioneer in the building of aluminum craft, Grumman Boats, Inc., of Marathon, N. Y., is exhibiting seven outboard models and twelve canoes at the motor boat show.

To the Screen Editor: The recent selections by The New York Film Critics of 1958's best work in films is quite sur prising, to say the least. I sincerely feel that a great many other equally deserving candidates have been overlooked.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- Speculations about a possible softening of the Soviet line on Berlin and Germany certainly has not reached the reading and listening citizenry of Moscow.

FEW house plants are better suited for the narrow window shelf than the marica. Often called apostle plant, it has twelve flat, fanlike leaves that curve gracefully at the top. A member of the iris family, the marica is sometimes known as walking iris because of the way it produces young plants from the drooping peduncles (flower stalks).

An annual dinner dance was held last night in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane for .the benefit of Colony House. The organization is a settlement house at 297 Dearie Street, Brooklyn, that provides child care for children 3 years of age and older. It also operates clubs and recreational programs for adults.

The Moenchsberg Mountains in Salzburg, Austria, will be poorer next year by 2,000,000 cubic feet of rock, and riche by a new theatre. It will be named the Salzburg Festival Theatre, will cost $8,000,000 and will back into the mountain.

The scene was a building in Santiago de Cuba. A revolutionary military tribunal composed of Fidel Castro's bearded guerrilla fighters sat in judgment of a former aide of deposed dictator General Fulgencio Batista. Spectators crowded the makeshift courtroom.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Yale's hockey team smothered an inept Cornell squad, 11 -- 0, tonight. Seven Yale players scored.

CHOPIN: Les Sylphides; IBERT: Divertissement; Paris Conservatory Orchestra, Roger Desormiere, conductor (Richmond). A re-issue on London's new low-priced label of two works formerly in the company's regular catalogue.
WASHINGTON, Jam 17 -- The heads of twenty-three railroad unions announced today that they would make a full-scale fight against "unjustified" abandonments of passenger service.
Two New Jersey men have been questioned by New York City detectives about the 1952 Brooklyn killing of Arnold Schuster, a 24-year-old clothing salesman.

" Encouraging results" in preliminary tests of a new pain-killing drug were announced in Washington last week by Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. The new synthetic substance, named NIH 7519, the Secretary said, has been found in the tests on monkeys and humans to be "ten times as effective as morphine and fifty times as effective as codeine."

TRENTON -- The waterways of New Jersey constitute one of the greatest recreational assets along the Atlantic seaboard and the use of streams for increased boating provides a tremendous economic uplift to the business of the bordering communities. In addition to our tidal waters, there are about 800 lakes and ponds in New Jersey.

A 17-footer built to handle the biggest outboard motors on the market is being introduced at the boat show by the Lyman Boat Works of Sandusky, Ohio. It is part of a display of four outboard and three inboard craft.

MANY girls go through a phase when they feel sure that they have been adopted, but this delusion, in Patricia Castle's case, took an extreme form. Her friend Alberta, both of whose parents were psychiatrists, exposed Patricia to such a flood of garbled Freudianism that Patricia was convinced that, not only had she been adopted, but that she was an Indian.
The Port of New York last year took in $475,472,748 in customs from imports. Collections, spurred by a higher volume of imports, surpassed those of 1957 by 5.3 per cent.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Despite a few setbacks such as airline strikes and an unprecedented early season snowstorm in desert resort areas, Arizona appears headed for another record-breaking winter tourist season. The chief contributing factors are improved facilities and roads, more attractions and a greater influx of visitors from East Coast states.

ONLY venturesome New Yorkers will have the good fortune to see this winter's major old master exhibition, that of paintings by Nicholas Poussin (1594-1665). On view during this month at the Toledo Museum of Art and from February 11 through March 10 at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the seventeen pictures on loan from American and Canadian public collections Justly represent the genius of the great French classicist.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- Despite an expected economic recovery in the last half of 1959, the living standard of the average Japanese is not likely to see a marked rise this year, Japanese economists say.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 14 -- The 3,000 business enterprises and industrial plants in the Dominican Republic have been directed by the Government to establish employe restaurants by April 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Dr. Alan T. Waterman, director of the National Science Foundation, asserted today the American people were making only an apathetic response to a determined Soviet bid to achieve world scientific supremacy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- It's a pretty safe bet that the New York Rangers would have been happier if they had continued their tour to Detroit instead of stopping here. The Black Hawks put a crimp in the Rangers' play-off plans by scoring a 7-1 victory at the Chicago Stadium today in a nationally televised game.
The Coast Guard here is about to reissue 40,000 port security cards that will expire this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Moscow weather marked the visit of Anastas I. Mikoyan to the White House today. The thermometer stood at 14 degrees, the sun sparkled on the snowy lawns and policemen stamped their feet to keep warm.
An angler's article of faith -- that outboard motors disturb fish -- appears to have developed a flaw.

The electronics industry is opening new frontiers in the conquest of disease and is rolling up sales of more than $200,000,000 a year in doing so. This is 100 per cent more than the volume of five years ago. At that time sales of electronic instruments and devices used in medicine totaled $100,000,000 a year.

HAVANA, Jan. 17 -- The hunted young man who for three hours whispered his passionate hopes and ideals into my ear in the gloomy jungle depths of the Sierra Maestra at dawn on Feb. 17, 1957, is now the chief power in Cuba.

The United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union is investing $300,000 in a "rescue operation" that will make it the majority stockholder in a big hat company and save the jobs of 325 idle union members.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- This is a town that watches a political fight with all the cruel and dispassionate intensity of a circling wolfpack.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 17 -- William Danforth and Dr. Paul Steele of Pittsburgh, who head the draw, led the way into the semi-finals of the annual Greenwich invitation doubles squash racquets championship today.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 17 -- Displaying strength in all departments, Manhattan's track team easily defeated Dartmouth, 74 1/3 to 34 2/3, today.
Two 1959 championship crew regattas were awarded to the Detroit area in meetings yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

The "queen" of the boat show, a 46-foot motor yacht, is being exhibited by the Richardson Boat Company of North Tonawanda, N. Y. The company is celebrating is fiftieth year as a boat-builder.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- The establishment of a county-wide school building agency to pool resources and reduce costs in anticipation of a predicted Westchester population increase of 330,000 by 1975 was proposed today.

New measurements made last year at the Mt. Wilson and Mt. Palomar observatories indicate that the universe is much greater than earlier estimates suggest. The latest measurements indicate, it is reported in the current Year Book of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, that the distance of the Virgo cluster and of all more remote galaxies must be increased by a factor of between 5 and 10 over the values obtained in the Nineteen Thirties.

It is the current almost unanimous opinion of New England bankers and business executivesI that the improvement thatI characterized the second half of 1958 will continue for at least another six months and possibly much longer. NEWARK, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Patrolman Eddie Dixon was ordered today to appear at a departmental hearing Jan. 30 as a result of his recent middle-weight bout with Gene (Ace) Armstrong.

LOS ANGELES Jan. 17 -- Launching facilities for the Titan intercontinental ballistic missile are under development at both Vandenberg Air Force Base in California and Lowry Air Force Base at Denver.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- This has been a busy winter so far for innkeepers and ski operators in this Berkshire mountain country and the buzz of activity has borne out the prophecies of those farsighted ski pioneers of more than two decades ago: that, given its fair share of snow, this area has all that is needed to be a major winter sports center.

Herbert Stessin, in his piano recital yesterday at the late afternoon hour in Carnegie Recital Hall, reinforced the good impression he had made in his previous appearances. He is a very sound pianist, a first-class technician, and his musical ideas are intelligent.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- France presents today a strange spectacle of the liberal Left -- the traditional defender of popular government -- looking to the holder of personal power for protection from the elected Parliament.

JUST as the 1959 world-championship bridge match is coming up (in New York, beginning Feb. 7), The Bridge World magazine has concluded an analysis of the 1958 match between Italy and the United States, which was played a year ago at Como, Italy, and resulted in victory for the Italians.

HONOLULU -- This is the time of the year when Hawaii is at its liveliest, for the annual Narcissus Festival, celebrating the Chinese New Year, is under way until Feb. 13. New Year's Day falls on Feb. 7, and on this day and all through the celebrations there will be special events.

A concert of piano duets by the husband-and-wife team of Helenand Karl Ulrich Schnabel will benefit Parents Without Partners. Mr. and Mrs. Schnabel are donating their services to the Jan. 31 concert, which will take place at the New York Center for Better Living, 227 West Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--President Eisenhower and Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, conferred today for an hour and forty-five minutes on outstanding East-West differences, but they reached no decisions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated Roger W. Jones of Hartford to the Civil Service Commission today. He would succeed Harris Ellsworth, the present chairman.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 17 -- Sweden has decided to postpone the development of her own uranium resources for her first atomic power plant.
Shoe production set a record of slightly more than 598,000,000 pairs last year. The figure compares with 588,000,000 in 1958 and the previous high of 597,600,000 pairs in 1957.

MOST Americans "saw" the Civil War in their own time through the eyes of the sketch artists in the field with the armies. Art exhibitions opening this week in New York museums and galleries include paintings, sculpture, prints and drawings by a number of well-known European and American artists. Nearly fifty group and one-man shows are announced.

Bob Turley, 28-year-old, Yankee pitcher, has been chosen to receive one of the major awards given annually by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

As Coach Joe Lapchick's precocious, once-beaten lads sped to their eighth straight and eleventh victory of the season, one wondered why they were ranked only ninth nationally.

MADE of heavy-gauge aluminum with a vinyl insert, here is a combination weatherstripping for doors which also replaces the doorstop molding. PARIS, Jan. 17 -- France's new regime received its first thorough workout this week.

THE civilization in the New World before the landing of Columbus -- an anthropological curiosity less than thirty years ago -- is today the subject not only of a number of popular books but also of exhibitions in museums devoted exclusively to the fine arts.

In three of the last four years, Congress has voted down Administration proposals for Federal aid to build schools.
