BUFFALO, Jan. 18 -- Billy Welu, the 6-foot 4-inch St. Louis bowling star, notched his first major individual title by winning the eighteenth annual national all-star bowling championship tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- The Alec Coppel stage companymystery, "The Gazebo," presented on Broadway last month by the Playwrights Company and Frederick Brisson, has been bought for filming by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
BELGIAN CONGO, Jan. 18 -Leopoldville now is outwardly quiet, but beneath the surface there is much activity.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- Chairman Mae Tse-tung of the Chinese Communist Party is expected to lead his country's delegation to the Twenty-First Congress of the Soviet Communist Party, which starts at the end of this month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended Jan. 17:
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The trend of stock market prices last week was generally upward. The strength of Wall Street helped and a number of good company profits reports aided the movement.
The international battle over ships that fly the so-called "flags of convenience" took a new and bitter turn over the week-end.
A computing device that operates at the point of sale as an integral part of a cash register has been developed by Matronics, Inc., of this city.
Senora Marta Fernandez do Batista, wife of the ousted dictator of Cuba, arrived in New York by plane yesterday to pick up her two young sons. She will take them "very shortly" to Daytona Beach, Fla.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 -Walter Ulbricht, chief of the East German Communist party, has pledged that his regime will not blockade West Berlin if the Western powers pay proper respect to his sovereign republic.

City Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday that he had been authorized by Mayor Wagner to set up six special units of case workers to handle problems of "difficult" families on the relief rolls.

THE human side of Congress was observed during a telecast yesterday on Channel 4. The half-hour program, called "The 86th Congress: the Personalities," included statements from newly-elected Senators and Representatives and leaders of both houses.
The construction companies that put up the United Nations headquarters will build the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

MAY is the usual month for the Interracial Fellowship Chorus' annual Haydn Mass. But this season, because of the 150th anniversary of the composer's death, the chorus is singing two of his Masses -- one in the winter and one in the spring.

Burton Lane, composer of "Finian's Rainbow" and other shows, is planning to become a producer. With that objective, Mr. Lane has acquired the rights to Edna Ferber's novel, "Giant," for which he will provide the melodies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -Anastas I. Mikoyan introduced himself to the American way of life today. Judging from his reactions on visits to two ordinary Washington households, he liked what he saw of it.

The Wolverine Tube division of Calumet Hecla, Inc., announced yesterday that it had started commercial production of columbium metal extrusions. Columbium, which also is called niobium, holds special interest as a construction material for rocket and missile components and atomic power plants, because of its high strength at elevated temperatures and its nuclear properties.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Before a crowd of 31,100, the largest ever to watch a ski jump here, Einar Dohlen, University of New Hampshire senior, captured the Norsemen Ski Club's Class A event today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower sends his $77,000,000,000 balanced budget to Congress tomorrow amid indications that it will run into prompt attack from Democrats critical of its defense and missile outlays.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Gil McDougald, infield star of the New York Yankees, today was named winner of the fourth Lou Gehrig Award. The minor leagues' president, George M. Trautman, who is chairman of the selection committee, made the announcement.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 -- Los Angeles was chosen today as the site for the 1960 Democratic National Convention.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The resignation of Alger B. Chapman as treasurer of the Republican State Committee was announced today by L. Judson Morhouse, committee chairman.
ROME, Jan. 18 -- The Roman collections swirled to an exhilarating finish tonight. And as usual the best came at the very last.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 -The Democratic party's choice of Los Angeles for its 1960 national convention has more than the usual political implications.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Supreme Court has just received from the executive branch the equivalent of a 5-to-4 decision.
The Adenauer Government still has an opportunity to oust the Nazis who have infiltrated industry and the army, Heinz Galinski said here yesterday.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- More than 900 competitors, including a handful of Americans, tonight roared off through snow, ice and fog on the Monte Carlo motor rally. They rode in some 300 cars.

Fire Commissioner Cavanagh's report on the results of his department's inspection in depth of all the city schools is, on the whole, reassuring. It will be especially so to the parents of children now in school -- and to the children too -- who have been alarmed by the fact that ninety pupils should have been killed in a single school fire in a great city like Chicago.

The Sun Oil Company has decided to appeal the decision of the Federal Trade Commission that the company violated the antitrust laws in giving assistance to one of its Jacksonville, Fla., dealers in 1955. Willard W. Wright, vice president for marketing, said the decision would be appealed to a Circuit Court of Appeals.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- A nineweek strike of 37,500 International Harvester Company workers ended tonight and the company prepared to resume production tomorrow.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 -- Recovering smartly after yesterday's walloping at the hands of the Chicago Black Hawks, the New York Rangers completed a successful tour of enemy rinks tonight by stopping the Red Wings, 4 to 2, at the Olympia Stadium.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The National Union of Manufacturers said today that British industry was watching "with the keenest interest" Anastas I. Mikoyan's conversations in the United States.
Following is transcript, provided by the National Broadcasting Company, of the "Meet the Press" television program last night on which Anastas I. Mikoyan was guest:

The facts of the continuing war against infantile paralysis are well known to the public. Annual widespread support of the March of Dimes has financed aid for thousands of polio patients in desperate need of care and treatment. More than that, the contributions have made the Salk vaccine a reality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the Soviet Union had created an "iron, forceful and formidable" way of life that was making great advances in competition with the "sluggish" pace of the United States and other Western democracies.
MANILA, Monday, Jan. 19 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen has been called back to Washington for consultations, the United States Embassy announced today. He will leave Tuesday evening.

Robert Moses will recommend today the construction of a slum-clearance housing development adjoining Battery Park that is expected to cost $21,147,477. The proposal will be submitted today to Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate.
The Fire Department will retain intensified school inspections like the one it recently completed.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 540 persons who passed the examination for admission to the New York State Bar held last Nov. 6 and 7. A total of 1,063 applicants took the test.

A plan for putting families that qualify for public housing into one of every five private apartment units built with state aid has been offered to Governor Rockefeller. The rent difference would be subsidized by the local housing authority.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Jan. 15 -- Alaskans are preparing to savor the first fruits of statehood. With their minds on the cost of living, taxation, new capital and resource development, they are awaiting eagerly but with some uneasiness the opening session of the forty-ninth state's first Legislature.

The visit of Anastas I. Mikoyan, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, on the special hour-long edition of "Meet the Press" was most interesting viewing throughout, a fine coup for the National Broadcasting Company.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- If nothing else, Mikoyan's visit to the United States appears to have defused the Berlin time bomb. After a period of genuine alarm the Soviet traveling salesman has conveyed the impression that there will be no war next spring.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 18 (UPI) -- The Navy unveiled today a rocket engine and control system "with the flexibility and control needed for manned interplantetary flights and landings on the moon."
MUONG SING, Laos, Jan. 18 -- This quiet green valley is rapidly filling up with refugees from Communist China.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The United States completed its sweep through the preliminary round of the world basketball championship tonight with a 103-58 decision over the United Arab Republics. But in a major upset the Soviet Union lost to Canada, 63 -- 54.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- Pope John XXIII warned students for the priesthood today against worldliness and ambition. Ecclesiastics should place the care of souls above anything else and not seek preferment, the Pontiff declared.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Soviet and United States academies of sciences are about to conclude an agreement for a broad exchange of scientists between the two nations.
A new national union of postal clerks has been formed by groups that quit the National Federation of Post Office Clerks in protest against "undemocratic" policies.

FOUR of S. J. Perelman's stories on life in Hollywood were distilled yesterday afternoon into a delightfully humorous hour called "Malice in Wonderland." The program, one of the funniest in some time, was seen on "Omnibus" over Channel 4.

Alan Hovhaness' Prelude and Quadruple Fugue, Op. 28, received its first New York performance Saturday night by the Brooklyn Philharmonia, conducted by Siegfried Landau at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Joseph N. Welch, who has categorically denied that he is an actor, has signed to appear in his first acting role. The Boston lawyer will play the featured role of a judge in a major motion picture, "Anatomy of a Murder."
A 17-year-old printer's helper admitted yesterday that he had stolen about a hundred cars in the last three months because he did not feel like walking.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 -If anyone on the political scene at the moment can stick a feather in his cap and label it "victory", it is a tall, genial, owlish-looking local lawyer named Paul Ziffren.

" My Fair Lady" opened off Broadway last evening for a limited run -- one performance to be exact. It was produced in a Bronx auditorium without scenery but with great spirit. All of the roles were played by members of the Broadway cast and admission was free.

" Paradise in Trust," a new book by Robert Trumbull, is planned for February publication by William Sloane Associates. It is a report on the American administration of the Pacific islands of Micronesia -the Marshalls, the Carolines and the northern Marianas.

VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Dom Mintoff, Labor party leader, in announcing a program against "British dictatorship," called today for a general strike and "national day of mourning" to mark suspension of the island's Constitution.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 18 -- The congress of the Italian Socialist party in this city tonight took a cautious step away from the Communists by approving a motion calling for the "autonomy" of the party, which had been closely linked with the Communists in the past.

School Superintendent John J. Theobald offered two suggestions last night for easing the teacher shortage in the city's schools: an extra hour's work for an extra hour's pay and early hiring of graduates from the city's colleges.
Mayor Wagner gave the city's taxpayers a conditional promise yesterday of freedom from new or heavier special levies in the five or six fiscal years after 1959-60.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 18 -- By announcing a 4 1/2 per cent 400,000,000 guilder loan at 95 per cent, the Government has made an effort to start covering an estimated 800,000,000 Treasury deficit for 1959.
The American Museum of Natural History is trying very hard to seem like a tropical rain forest. It wants to keep its giant beetle as the only living one in the United States.
The directors of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany allocated $10,100,785 yesterday to Jewish communities, organizations and institutions in thirty countries.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 18 -- Opponents of President Syngman Rhee's Government are planning a court test of the new law enabling the Administration to appoint municipal and village officials. At present these functionaries are elected.
Two youths were killed and four others were injured early yesterday when their car smashed into a pillar of the elevated West Side Highway at West and Franklin Streets.

There were three first performances of contemporary works last night at a chamber music concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. They included a Piano Sonata by Henry Onderdonk, a String Trio by Joseph Kantor and a Quartet for Five Instruments by Ralph Hollander.
FOR a leisurely brunch or supper, consider a light, fluffy omelet as a pleasant contrast to heartier foods.
Governor Rockefeller in his message to the State Legislature advocated the construction of more housing for middle-income families; he urged the use of more private funds to accomplish this.
Samuel Rudin, builder, who plans a forty-story office building at 80 Pine Street, has announced the letting of six major contracts amounting to more than $10,000.000.
Milwaukee County, Wis., is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $14,029,000 on Feb. 2. Dated Feb. 1, 1959, the bonds will come due serially on Feb. 1 from 1960 to 1974.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 -- The Arab states are being urged to form a united front in demanding a greatly increased share of the proceeds from Middle Eastern oil.
" Child of Our Time," the recently published novel by Michel del Castillo, will be televised on the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Playhouse 90" series on Feb. 5.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 18 -- President Arturo Frondizi departed today for a twelve-day visit to the United States, leaving behind a nation torn by strikes and virtually under military rule.

The square block of vacant land bounded by Irving Avenue, Halsey and Eldert Streets and the Long Island Rail Road tracks in the Ridgewood section of Queens has been purchased by Dworman Associates, realty investor and builder.

With an appropriate guest, Mayor Wagner, before the cameras the television interview program "Searchlight" celebrated yesterday its 250th broadcast. Begun five years ago as a collaboration in the public interest between N. B. C.'s WRCA Channel 4 and the Citizens Union, the program has been informative and newsworthy in its presentation of public officials facing the questions of reporters and a spokesman for the civic agency, with Ben Grauer as moderator.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- The State Senate approved today a referendum on a $66,800,000 bond issue to expand Rutgers University and seven other state institutions of higher education.

The nation-wide average state tax on gasoline is 5.9 cents. Ten states have a 7-cent tax, five 6.5 cents. Twenty-one states charge a 6-cent tax. Ten states lay a 5-cent tax and one 5.5 cents. One state has a 4-cent tax, and only Missouri goes as low as a 3-cent tax.

A group of high school students has demonstrated such exceptional ability in handling college-level science that professors at Columbia University's School of Engineering are using superlatives to describe them.
Recently you printed an editorial supporting the proposed James Peter Warbasse Houses.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 19 -- Indonesia's National Council has offered a proposal that might give President Sukarno immense power in the choice of half the members of a new type of Parliament. The Parliament would be within the framework of the President's "guided democracy" formula.
The Gulf States Utilities Company raised $10,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year, first mortgage bonds at a net interest cost of about 4.65 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A Caribbean "good neighbor" of the United States and Cuba urged Americans today to show "the greatest possible forbearance'' toward the revolutionary movement led by Fidel Castro.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 -- The American Motors Corporation, maker of the Rambler and other small cars, reported today that the company earned $21,052,168 or $3.56 a share, in the three-month period ended on last Dec. 31. This compared with $4,948,736, or 89 cents a share, a year before.
Benny (Kid) Paret fought Victor Zalazar for the first time at the St. Nicholas Arena on Dec. 15 and won a unanimous decision. The bout was the last of 1958 at America's oldest fight club.

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, announced last night that two anonymous gifts of $50,000 each had been received to expand mission work in this area.

THE history of pre-Columbian art is gradually unfolding in New York, revealing a little suspected wealth of imagery and a remarkable range of invention. The Aaron Furman Gallery, 46 East Eightieth Street, makes an important contribution in documenting the relatively unfamiliar cultures of North Peru in a current exhibition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The Government announced today the formation of a special group to see that the nuclear plants and space rockets of the future were safe and livable.

" SOLITARY LIFE,"* by Richard Katz, is an exuberantly gregarious memoir in praise of living alone and liking it. This is in the great tradition of hermitage. The hermit turns out to have been a man who has been everywhere and seen everything. Now he has decided to get away from it all, cultivate his garden -- and tell multitudes about the fair rewards of solitude.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The long-raging dispute and rivalry between the Army and Air Force over the merits of their respective 1,500-mile intermediate range ballistic missiles appears to have been decided through the Pentagon's reluctance to make a decision.
SAN NICOLAS, Argentina, Jan. 19 -- The skyline of Argentina's first steel town is rising slowly out of the pampas.

Who was James Kent? The question is inevitable when we read of the forcible removal of his bust from the Hall of Fame. Speculation on the fleeting nature of fame often comes when that American Pantheon of heroes on the Bronx campus of New York University moves into public focus.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 19 -- A Federal court held today that the closing of selected public schools to avoid racial integration violated the United States Constitution.
OTTAWA, Jan. 19 -- Two trunks containing priceless Polish treasures left for New York by train last night on the way to Poland.
A new and better universe has been ordered by the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium.
Zbigniew Orywal, who captured the American 1000-yard title last winter, arrived from Poland yesterday with ambitious plans for the indoor track season.
TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Government brought out at Dave Beck's income-tax trial today that he received double payment for expenses in 1950 for attending concurent conferences in Miami, Fla.
Employees of downtown securities concerns will give blood today at 15 Pine Street to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Continued reliance on long-range nuclear weapons for defense was affirmed in President Eisenhower's budget proposals to Congress today. One of ...
The Board of Education's proposed 1959-60 expense budget request received a little praise and a lot of criticism at a public hearing yesterday.

The Manufacturers Trust Company here experienced a rise of $60,545,000, or 15 per cent, in savings deposits last year, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday. The rise compared with one of $65,000,000 in 1957, when the savings interest rate was increased from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent.

A new move to organize a second major professional football league is under way. The officers of the new group, the International Football League, say that their association will match the National Football League in size, salaries and ability.

Prostitution has become such a standard cost item for big business concerns in this country, a radio program contended last night, that some companies now keep call girls on their payrolls to please customers.
Intensive security measures will be taken by the Police Department to see Anastas I. Mikoyan off to the Soviet Union this afternoon.

President Nasser of the United Arab Republic has completed a settlement of the rival financial claims resulting from his seizure of the Suez Canal and the consequent Anglo-French invasion. The settlement leaves him in undisputed control of this vital waterway at bargain prices.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 19 -- The treason trial of thirty persons resumed here today after two adjournments.
A leading United States astronomical magazine describes as "incontrovertible" the evidence submitted to it by a Soviet scientist to back his report of having seen a volcanic eruption on the moon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Government spending of $5,484,000,000 is in prospect for the coming fiscal year to support scientific exploration of the universe and to develop new weapons of war and instruments of peace.
The Twenty-first annual Maple Leaf dinner dance will be given by the Canadian Women's Club of New York on Jan. 30 in the Savoy Hilton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Treasury went out of its way today to tell the world that introduction of bills in Congress aimed at raising the price of gold did not mean that such a thing would actually happen.

TORONTO, Jan. 19 -- The Terminal Tower Building in Cleveland -- the tallest in the United States outside New York City -- has been purchased for $13,000,000 by a group of United States and Canadian investors.
Prices of cotton futures moved moved 5 points off to 15 points up yesterday. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale).
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Administration's first official estimate on the recovery from the recession today put the pace slower than the last time.
Moderate increases in foreign trade and services by the United States during 1959 were forecast yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

CAMILLA, Ga., Jan. 19 -- It is possible to report tonight that Charley Dickey's fires have been damped if not quenched, and that the man at last can be re-admitted to the society of humans and turkey hunters.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- The Soviet Union has offered the recession-threatened Hamburg shipbuilding industry a $65,000,000 order for passenger ship construction.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Dandy Blitzen made the favorite players happy by registering a half-length victory in the $6,000 Poinsettia Purse before 17,393 today at Hialeah.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- George M. Bright's attorney took an automobile door into court today to bolster his contention that an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and state's witness had bombed the Jewish temple, not his client.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 19 -- New York City bid for the 1960 Republican National Convention today, but it was seeking an "economic shot in the arm" rather than a political advantage, according to L. Judson Morhouse, the state's party chairman.
DETROIT, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The nation's auto plants have built 297,458 passenger cars so far this year. The total compares with 283,252 in the 1958 period.

The International League Baseball Players' Association yesterday ordered its 160 members not to sign their 1959 contracts or to report for spring training unless the league granted them a pension plan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, visiting Soviet First Deputy Premier, asked the United States today to reduce barriers to Soviet United States trade.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 19 -- Virginia's "massive resistance" laws against racial integration in the public schools were struck down today by the state's own highest tribunal.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- An investigation of flagrant rent-control violations in New York City rooming houses has been scheduled by the Rockefeller administration.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A board of inquiry said today severe thunderstorm turbulence was the "most probable immediate cause" of the crash of a Maritime Central Airways CD4 in which seventy-nine persons died Aug. 11, 1957.

THE LITTLE Orchestra Society, which is about to embark for a tour of the Far East, concluded its local season at Carnegie Hall last night with an eighteenth-century classic, Gluck's "Iphigenie en Tauride."
Harrison Rosdahl of Ridgefield Park, N. J., won the open shot-put event of the St. Francis Prep track and field games at the High School of Fashion Industries yesterday.

The New York 1890 Ball, to be held in the Ballroom of the Sheraton-East on Feb. 26, Will benefit the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults, Inc., and mark the opening of the national 1959 Easter Seal campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Following is a glossary of the main financial terms used in the budget:

The One William Street Fund, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of 25.1 per cent in net assets for the first seven months of operations. The giant mutual fund ended 1958 with net assets of $276,747,000. It started its operations with assets of $221,221,000, on May 29, 1958.
Investment yields on United States Government bonds rose to above 4 per cent on a wide front yesterday as the market for Treasury securities suffered its most severe setback in many weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming said today that New York State had been lagging in the vocational rehabilitation of the disabled but would improve under Governor Rockefeller.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 19 -- President Frondizi said today that leaders of illegal strike actions in Argentina would suffer the "consequences of the law," but asserted he did not fear for the stability of his Government.
Airline, aircrafts, rubbers and electronics issues held their own on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, but the rest of the list was soggy.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Most shares declined in heavy trading on the stock exchange here today. The predominance of selling pressure was laid to the latest public opinion polls which indicate a sharp reduction in the Conservative party's chances of victory over the Labor party in the next election.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is in big business to stay.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower made a personal appeal to the country by radio and television today for support against money appropriations not requested in his budget estimates.

The Seiberling Rubber Company is offering its common stockholders the right to subscribe, at $14 a share, to 106,841 shares at the rate of one share for each four held on Jan. 19. The offer will expire Feb. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower proposed today the sale to private industry of the Navy's oil reserves, including the Teapot Dome field in Wyoming that figured in a sensational scandal in the Nineteen Twenties.

THE man of the year was also the lion of the hour at the recent eating and oratorical contest staged by the Boxing Writers Association. That would have to be Archie Moore, a beguiling rascal of regal mien. The king of the light-heavyweights was enthroned in the seat of honor, the picture of elegance and savoir faire.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan brought his Washington visit to a close tonight to the strains of an impromptu concert by Van Cliburn.

TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today named Superior Court Judges C. Thomas Schettino and Frederick W. Hall as State Supreme Court justices. He also reappointed Justice Nathan L. Jacobs to the seven-man tribunal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of Norman P. Mason as Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- New aviation fuel taxes were recommended in President Eisenhower's 1960 budget today.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A heat wave that has sent the thermometer well past the 100-degree mark posed a threat today to the third-round singles matches in the Australian national tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The constitutional crisis over state as opposed to Federal powers in public education faded into history last November when the Supreme Court defined a broad area of state authority in this field.

" Count Five and Die," an account of the Allies D-Day deception, by Barry Wynne, will be published by Ballantine Books in a paper-back edition next Monday. The Allies' plan to deceive the Germans as to where they would land was to make them believed it would be in the Netherlands.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The International Transport Workers Federation met here today to consider its next moves in its campaign against so-called flags of convenience.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The grain trade gave a slightly bullish construction today to most of the Department of Agriculture's report on stocks of grains held in Government loan, issued last Friday.

Tickets for the Fifth Avenue Openings are still available. These are the two giant fashion shows to be given this week by the Fifth Avenue Association. The presentations will serve as a showcase for 100 spring costumes culled from American designers and manufacturers.
The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling opposed yesterday a recommendation by a world order study conference that Communist China be recognized by the United States and admitted into the United Nations.
Six union officers will serve in the new nine-man board of directors of a Massachusetts hat factory saved from liquidation by a union decision to purchase a majority stock interest.
One hundred and fifty models will appear tomorrow and Thursday in an all-American fashion show here designed to show that the best clothing designs do not have to come from abroad.
MORE value than money is one of New York's specialties. There are lots of distinctive bargains to be had, all showing taste and imagination and costing very little.
COLUMBIA BROADCASTING SYSTEM'S radio network last night broadcast an hour-long documentary on a subject traditionally sidestepped: the use of prostitutes in the world of business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower submitted to Congress today a "hold the line" budget estimating Federal spending in the fiscal year 1960 at $77,030,000,000, with spending and receipts precariously in balance.

As a Palestine Arab refugee, and as one who speaks for the refugees every year before the United Nations Special Political Committee, I was interested in the recent letter of the Right Rev. Bishop James A. Pike, Bishop of California, relating to Israel's offer of compensation to the Palestine Arab refugees.

A "thorough and impartial" survey of how local housing authorities throughout New York are managing their state-subsidized public housing was promised yesterday by State Housing Commissioner James William Gaynor.
Roy Campanella, who was partly paralyzed in an automobile accident a year ago, was shaken up in another auto mishap yesterday.

The budget submitted to Congress yesterday by the President shows that the Administration foresees for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1, 1959, and ends June 30, 1960, expenditures of $77.0 billion and receipts of $77.1 billion, leaving a surplus (at least on paper) of $0.1 billion.

" The Magic Flute" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last night, with Jerome Hines making his first appearance of the season as Sarastro, and Lucine Amara singing her first Pamina of the season.
A 36-year-old gardener from Newark took a dual oath yesterday, He vowed he would never again take advice from a mailman and would never return to New York City.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Francis Schremp, chief officer of the American freighter John Lykes, was swept off the deck of his ship by a fifty-foot wave. Less than a minute later, another gigantic wave swept him on board again.

An inspector of the City Department of Buildings was accused of neglect of duty yesterday for certifying a dilapidated tenement as "structurally sound." The Fire Department had ordered the building vacated last week.

Steel production rose last week to the highest level since the week that began Sept. 30, 1957, and was scheduled to increase further this week reflecting a growing accumulation of steel orders as manufacturers sought to build inventories.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- A Polaris missile was launched today on an 800-mile test flight that Navy officials described as "fully successful."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to help state authorities get together for better supervision of juveniles.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -A leading West German Protestant churchman has condemned Prof. Karl Barth's views on the church's role in the struggle against communism as the worst kind of neutralism.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 19 (AP) -- John Patterson was sworn in as Governor of Alabama today. He said he would preserve segregation even if it meant closing the schools.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The drawing for the championship round of the world amateur basketball tournament tonight was postponed because of a political snarl.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower appointed Don K. Price Jr., a Harvard university dean, to his advisory committee on government organization today.

Futures prices closed generally lower yesterday in dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, the domestic sugar contract, copper, lead, zinc and hides declined; coffee, the world sugar months and rubber rose, and price movements for potatoes, cottonseed oil and wool were mixed.

Stockholders of the Commercial Bank of North America voted at yesterday's annual meeting to approve an increase in the authorized capital shares from 480,000 to 505,000. According to Jacob Leichtman, president, the new stock will be paid out in the form of two semiannual 2 1/2 per cent stock dividends this year.
HAVANA, Jan. 19 -- A series of courts-martial of about 1,000 "war criminals" will start within forty-eight hours, the judge advocate of the Cuban armed forces announced today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- "Total Selling," a new program for newspapers was previewed here today accompanied by speeches, singing and dancing. The singing and dancing were novel.

OFF to Puka Puka! After a brief stopover in Hawaii to exchange greetings with hula dancer, Whisky Johnnie Frisbie, Lowell Thomas headed for this tiny South Sea atoll with an International Geophysical Year expedition to study a solar eclipse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy was reported ready today to beat the Administration by introducing a moderate labor reform bill tomorrow.
Anastas I. Mikoyan produced no new ideas in the realm of foreign policy, Henry Cabot Lodge, head of the United States delegation to the United Nations, asserted yesterday.
Two judicial decisions, one Federal, the other by the Virginia Supreme Bench, struck hard yesterday at segregation in the schools.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Republican leader of the Assembly expressed some doubt today whether there would be enough time in the 1959 legislative session to resolve the issue of authorizing more branches for savings banks.
They say he's the outstanding high school basketball player in the city; that in about five years he'll be hailed as the new Bob Cousy of the professional game.

A strongly worded suggestion that the textile industry put an end to "running our businesses like our fathers did before us" was advanced last night by James E. Robison, president of Indian Head Mills, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senate Republicans remained deadlocked today over committee assignments for the Eighty-sixth Congress despite offers by several senior members to give up choice posts to maintain harmony.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Edgar Eisenhower, observing his seventieth birthday today, said that his brother, the President, was doing the best he could for the American taxpayer.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- If the nationwide urban renewal program is to continue cities must be able to count on a minimum of $6,000,000,000 in Federal aid over the next ten years, a real estate executive said today.

The forty-seventh annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases has achieved the highest financial return in the fund's history. However, the number of donors is still considerably below that of previous years.

Another scene in the Great Heavyweight Mystery was played yesterday. Cus D'Amato, the self-appointed guardian of the crown, enchanted the audience at D'Amato's Little Theatre in the dual role of hero and villain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Democrats accused President Eisenhower today of playing politics with the budget.
A vaccine effective against the common cold in most cases may be on the market this year.
A will left by Oscar C. Cintas, former Cuban Ambassador to Washington, and involving $8,000,000 to $10,000,000, was challenged in an action filed in New York County Surrogate's Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that collective bargaining staked out by the Taft-Hartley Labor Act superseded state antitrust laws.
HONG KONG probably has more tailors a square block than any city its size. Here, one can get a Chinese tailor to make a dress for as little as $5 if the purchaser provides the material.

President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina, who arrived in the United States yesterday on a twelve-day visit, has inadvertently picked a dramatic moment in his country. Whether the Peronists and Communists deliberately chose a period when they knew the President was going to the United States to cause trouble, or whether the course of events rose to a natural climax is hard to say.
Judson B. Shafer upset his Yale clubmate, J. Lenox Porter, in the opening round of the Yale Club's Bulldog squash tennis handicap tournament yesterday.
A steady stream of conversation from a Bronx bank teller exasperated a gunman into abandoning a hold-up attempt last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Republican legislative leaders decided today to bring the bill raising gasoline taxes 2 cents a gallon and Diesel fuel 3 cents to a vote tomorrow in the Senate and Assembly. The gasoline tax is now 4 cents and the Diesel fuel tax is 6 cents a gallon.
Jane Powell has been chosen to star in a special two-hour television version of "Meet Me in St. Louis" April 26.

A contemporary American quartet and one by a mid-nineteenth-century German composer turned out to have striking similarities last night at the Beaux-Arts String Quartet's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.
BERLIN, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- A Soviet scientist said today transplants of human hearts now were theoretically and practically possible.
When a man "swallows the anchor" it means he packs his gear and retires from the sea.

Although Jerry Leider, the young producer of "The Ages of Man," says he is "proceeding cautiously," he nevertheless has taken the first step toward doing for Tennesse Williams what he already has done for Shakespeare.

GENEVA, Jan. 19 -- The United States and Britain made a major concession to the Soviet Union today in an attempt to end the stalemate in the three-power conference for ending tests of nuclear weapons.
Dallas, Tex., received bids yesterday on issues of bonds totaling $17,600,000 to finance water, sewerage and other public improvements.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 19 -- Buford Ellington was sworn in today as Tennessee's forty-second Governor and promised his four-year term would be an "era of readjustment in the light of our existing tax sources."
RICOTTA is a fresh, moist, unsalted cheese that most Americans know as an important ingredient in lasagna. But the Italians, who invented it, make many delicious uses of the cheese as a dessert.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its Dec. 8 decision that natural gas pipeline companies could raise their rates without prior approval by the Federal Power Commission.

Cecil Smith of the Oak Brook Polo Club in Hinsdale, Ill., and Bob Skene of San Mateo, Calif., retained their ten-goal handicaps according to the 1959 ratings of the United States Polo Association released yesterday.
PARENTS have a right, in fact a responsibility, to coach their children for intelligence tests.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- The Screen Extras Guild today protested that "certain" major motion picture studios and "some" television producers have become lax in payment of salaries to performers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Max Lehrer is known to some of his colleagues as a human computer. At the Pentagon, where he helped prepare the $40,945,000,000 defense budget, he also has a reputation of being a man who never wastes time.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- There are unmistakable signs that the Conservative party's prestige with the voter and its position as favorite to win the coming general election are crumbling
The Brooklyn woman whose baby was recently kidnapped and recovered, lent her services yesterday to the campaign against the city's increased rate of poliomyelitis.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 19 -- Following are excerpts from a Federal Court ruling here today striking down Virginia's school closing law:
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Two days of meetings here between the Foreign Ministers of Greece and Turkey has produced an atmosphere of optimism over the chances of a compromise solution of the Cyprus problem.
WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Blessing his accusers, the Rev. Marian Pirozynski entered court today to answer charges of black marketing and corrupting public officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Representative William J. Green, Jr. said today that the Army had notified him it would award a turbine contract to the Baldwin Lima Hamilton Corporation, Philadelphia, although a British concern had submitted a lower bid.

WACO, Tex., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Baylor University today hired 37-year-old John Bridgers, the defensive line coach of the National Football League champion Baltimore Colts, as head football coach and athletic director at the Southwest Conference school.
Mayor Wagner signed a new local law yesterday designed to prevent landlords from benefiting both from tax abatement and increased rents.

" Aparajito" ("The Unvanquished"), the second feature in the Indian-made trilogy about an Indian family, directed by Satyajit Ray, has been booked into the Fifth Avenue Cinema, where it will open Feb. 16. "Pather Panchali" is the first.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 19 -- A strange sequence of events will be described to a Westchester County grand jury tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A foreign aid program emphasizing more economic and less military assistance was offered to Congress today.

The New York Central Railroad, which has put almost all of its passenger station facilities up for sale, has signed a six-month option agreement with Station Development Enterprises, Inc., for the lease or purchase of the road's terminals at Cleveland, Ohio, Buffalo, Syracuse and Rochester, New York. The consideration paid to the railroad for the option was not disclosed.

Many prominent persons will entertain tomorrow at the gala cocktail party preview of the fifth annual winter antiques show at the 107th Infantry (old Seventh Regiment) Armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. The show will be open to the public from Thursday through Jan. 27.
Heavy trading on the American Stock Exchange caused its tickers to fall behind floor transactions all during the first two hours of trading yesterday.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- All but eight of 322 cars were still in the running tonight as winter-wary drivers headed this way in the Monte Carlo auto rally.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Treasury Department urged Congress today to close loopholes in the taxation of cooperatives that had been opened by court decisions.

There is one sentence in Prof. W. Friedmann's admirable letter printed Jan. 16 which sticks in the mind: "Continuous refusal to acknowledge a political reality, without attempting to alter it, will increasingly embarrass the West."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs climbed again this week.

TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- The State Senate adopted today a bill that would permit Camden County to build a huge stadium as part of its bid to induct the Philadelphia Phillies to move the National League baseball club to New Jersey.

ALGIERS, Jan. 19 -- A local rebel commander, in his personal aswer to French cease-fire offers and clemency measures, has declared that the Government in Paris has done nothing to bring Algeria closer to peace. He accused the French Army of "persisting in its tortures and systematic massacres of innocent Algerians."

BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, Jan. 20 -- The Government mobilized municipal transport workers early today in a general strike that had been supported by about 75 per cent of Argentina's organized labor. Hundreds of Peronist and Communist leaders of the strike have been arrested.

The Fire Department closed a small printing shop in Greenwich Village and one department of a metal-etching plant in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday. A new team, making unannounced inspections, found hazardous conditions requiring immediate correction.
Alvin (Doggy) Julian, the Dartmouth basketball coach, predicted yesterday that "in the near future you will have 18,000 fans in Madison Square Garden again" to see college basketball double-headers.
Carnegie Hall will have a normal season in 1959-60.
Three men and four youths were arrested last night as members of a $100,000-a-year truck-hijacking ring in the Seventh Avenue garment district.
Builders have been advised by a leading mortgage broker not to delay their projects in expectation of a more favorable turn in the mortgage money market.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- New Jersey's six largest cities decided today to conduct a joint investigation of relief and welfare costs, which have increased sharply in the last year.

American Jews were urged yesterday to give "full philanthropic priority" to a special $100,000,000 fund sought by the United Jewish Appeal. The sum will be used to resettle 100,000 East European immigrants expected in Israel this year.

Although bowling doesn't rank among the leading spectator sports, the fans who pay their way into an arena to watch it are a devoted lot. The 2,500 persons who sat in on the final night's competition in the National All-Star tournament in Buffalo, Sunday, certainly were enthusiastic.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 19 -- A significant step was taken today to reduce tensions between Jordan and the United Arab Republic.

An overflow attendance reportedly placed substantial orders at the opening here yesterday of the winter wholesale home furnishings market. Exhibitors in the New York Furniture Exchange, focal point of the furniture market, described buying from "fair to good." Most said it was good. Those who assessed it as fair added that they had "no complaints."
The Transit Authority is opposed to all subsidies -- whether from the city to freeze the present 15-cent fare by law, or from the authority to provide reduced-fare transportation to school children.

VIENNA, Jan. 19 -- Interior Minister Oskar Helmer said last night that espionage activities of foreign powers in Austria had "become unbearable in recent times."

PICASSO'S reservoir of vitality is so well stocked that he has been able to overflow into nearly every known medium. At the newly opened Landry Gallery, 712 Fifth Avenue, drawings, lithographs, etchings, ceramics and sculpture give a sketchy but stimulating idea of Picasso's creative expansion.

AT 10 o'clock one morning this week, Julius Samuels arrived for lunch at Sloppy Louie's restaurant, 92 South Street. Not many New Yorkers lunch so early and certainly very few arrive, as Mr. Samuels did, swinging a ten-pound red snapper in one hand.

THEY called the new series that began on Channel 7 last night, "Alcoa Presents." It purports to be a dramatization of investigated case histories involving the occult. The first installment was a flimsy fraud.
ROME, Jan. 20 -- Socialist and Roman Catholic doctrine are incompatible, the Vatican warned today.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Jan. 20 -- The Security National Bank of Long Island charged off losses of $999,805 in 1958, Herman Maas, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here today. He said, however, that there were prospects of significant recovery.
MANILA, Jan. 20 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen left the Philippines tonight for Washington with a bag full of problems.
Approval of the merger of two large steel companies in Germany by "the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community" is cause for alarm.
HAVANA, Jan. 20 -- A mass demonstration will be held here tomorrow in support of the revolutionary Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Lincoln White, State Department press officer, said today that there was "no crisis" in United States-Philippine relations.
A residential hotel and a seven-story apartment building that had been marked for demolition in the Riverside-Amsterdam redevelopment plan were spared yesterday by the Committee on Slum Clearance.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation has started preparing a major iron ore mine for production by April of next year.
A new mortality table, the first in eighteen years, will come up for legislative approval this year in many states. It comes to the same conclusion as the previous one: Americans are living longer.
Trading in commodity futures was unusually light yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices moved in narrow ranges in featureless trading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)--Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, charged today that the Studebaker-Packard Corporation was trying to take advantage of a tax situation to deprive the Treasury of $70,000,000.
FOR more than forty years the gentlemen of the Amateur Comedy Club, Inc., have rehearsed their shows in two century-old brick stables in Sniffen Court, off East Thirty-sixth Street.

ATLANTA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A defense witness in the trial of George Bright testified today that he had eavesdropped on telephone calls made by an undercover Federal informer in the case. Bright is accused of setting off an explosion Oct. 12 at The Temple here, a Jewish house of worship.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Willie Mays today agreed to his 1959 contract with the San Francisco Giants for a salary estimated at $80,000.

Drastic steps to increase the dwindling number of touring stage attractions were recommended at yesterday's first session of a three-day industry-wide conference. One hundred persons attended the luncheon meeting held at the Top of the Six s Restaurant, 666 Fifth Avenue.

The airliner carrying Anastas I. Mikoyan to Copenhagen on his return to Moscow made an emergency landing in Argentia, Nfld., last night after one engine failed over the Atlantic and a second engine caught fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Democrats increased the vigor of their attacks on President Eisenhower's $77,030,000,000 balanced budget today. In turn, they came under fire from Republicans who sought to blame them in advance for any spending above the President's figures.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Pilkington Bros., Ltd., British flat glass manufacturers, announced today a new method of making high quality glass that its chairman, Sir Harry Pilkington, said was the most important glass-making advance of the century.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The projected Administration proposal for a deferred-payment school construction bill was put before Republican Congressional leaders at the White House today.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 20 -- Statements by Col. Fadhil Abbas el-Mahdawi, president of the special high military court, indicate that Col. Abdel Salam Arif, former Deputy Premier, and Rashid Ali el-Gailani, former Premier who led the 1941 pro-Axis revolt, have been tried by the court on charges of treason.
President Eisenhower's budget message received a cold reception yesterday in American shipping and shipbuilding circles.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- A week after the resignation of Earl Blaik as head football coach and director of athletics, the United States Military Academy showed little signs today of having decided on a successor.

The Museum of Modern Art has gone to court to prevent Huntington Hartford, grocery chain heir and art patron, from using the name Gallery of Modern Art for the $2,000,000 art museum he is planning to build at 2 Columbus Circle.
Ground will be broken and construction started in the spring on Fordham University's midtown center, which will cost $25,500,000.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association completed last night preparations for a court fight to compel Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to give the police force a grievance system like that in other city departments.
The Police Commissioner called upon the public yesterday to turn in any information that might help the police track down charges that big business concerns hire call girls to please their customers.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- The Temple University School of Theology has lost its accreditation in the American Association of Theological Schools.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The first serious accidents of the Monte Carlo automobile rally occurred today at the villages of Die and Fourmerette as drivers headed into the mountainous areas of France.
Robert R. Battipaglia, Queens County Democratic leader, gave the word that set his fellow Democrats a-feudin' and a-fussin' again last night with a declaration of war on James A. Roe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The President's Award for Distinguished Federal Civilian Service was presented by President Eisenhower to five prominent Government employes today.

The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company has announced the election of Paul T. Rotter and Robert C. McQueen as vice presidents. The formation of a new division to be known as the insurance services division also was announced.
NEWARK, Jan. 20 -- A housing official expressed optimism today on the fate of urban renewal and housing legislation.

LONDON, Jan. 20--Stock market prices again receded today, although a small rally toward the end reduced losses in many sections. Net declines were generally less than a shilling (14 cents). Only a very few industrials went against the trend.

Henry Cooper and Brian London may go on thumping each other again and Archie Moore may go on offering upper-bracket sums in furtherance of the cause of bellicosity, but it seems that the next fight for the heavyweight championship of the world will involve two other fellows.

If rain mixed with sleet beats on the north windows, if the mercury shrinks in its tube, this is the day to find a comfortable chair, light a pipe or good cigar, and sit down with the 1959 spring seed catalog.

A mixture of snow, rain and heavy fog yesterday caused hazardous driving conditions throughout the metropolitan area. There were two deaths in traffic accidents, one in New York and another in New Jersey.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo, America's Davis Cup hero, gained the quarter-finals today at the Australian tennis championships, but faces withdrawal from the tournament because a pulled stomach muscle has failed to heal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization did a quick turnaround last week in an international controversy over a contract for two hydraulic turbines.

Today's new film is "The Perfect Furlough," a Universal-International military comedy starring Tony Curtis, Janet Leigh, Keenan Wynn and Linda Cristal, at the Roxy, Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street. The wide-screen film was produced in color by Robert Arthur. Blake Edwards directed from a screen play by Stanley Shapiro.

"Music for Young America,' the five-week series of free concerts given annually by the National Symphony Orchestra for high school students visiting Washington, D. C., during their spring vacations, will open this year on April 15.

One central fact stands out, now that Anastas I. Mikoyan's visit to this country is ended: both the extreme hopes and the extreme fears which were generated a month ago by the prospect of his visit have been disappointed. Those who thought he was coming here with a major concession which would end the Berlin crisis have found that he came empty-handed.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The Rockefeller Administration's patronage mill began grinding today, but in the eyes of some Republican county chairmen it was still grinding exceedingly fine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower's Economic Report gave formal recognition today to an element in the recent inflation that has received increasing attention among experts. This is the "cost push" effect of higher depreciation charges and research and development expenditures in industry.

The Clarkstown and Orangetown, N. Y., Union Free School District 8 borrowed $2,135,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of serial bonds. The issue was sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
