"At the risk of hurting some people's feelings, I can't take it seriously."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, chairman of the Senate Disarmament subcommittee, said today that new ways to detect underground nuclear explosions had been found.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- In this birthplace of Cuba's revolution, citizens nod with satisfaction at the sound of the firing squads.
The Transit Authority approved a $6,000,000 plan yesterday for modernization and relocation of the Brooklyn Bridge station of the IRT East Side subway line.
TRENTON, Jan. 20 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Governor Rockefeller and Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut will meet Feb. 10 to discuss problems affecting all three states.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan.20 -- Carl Sandburg showed up ten years late tonight to receive an honorary degree from Upsala College here. He then entertained an audience of 2,700 with ballads strummed on his guitar.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- The Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council unanimously passed a resolution today to support a proposed Congressional investigation of so-called "runaway" film productions in foreign countries by American interests.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 20 (AP) -- William Jones, secretary general of the International Basketball Federation (F. I. B. A.) said today that the Soviet Union and Bulgaria would be subject to severe penalties, possibly expulsion from the Association, if they persisted in their refusal to meet Nationalist China in the final round-robin of the world basketball championship.

The letter of H. B. Cantor published on Jan. 14 erred in ascribing credit for the Times Square Information Center maintained by the New York City Department of Commerce and Public Events. The Information Center arose from a request made by former Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams to Commissioner Richard C. Patterson Jr. in September, 1954.
A radio disk-jockey yesterday morning started an attempt to set a record for staying awake.

Commissioner Cavanagh's report of the Fire Department inspection of the city's 2,004 public and private schools, following the Chicago tragedy, contains a striking series of "recommendations" for the reduction of fire hazards. But his report does not show how far existing laws, ordinances and department regulations make obedience to those standards a matter of compulsion.

Directors of Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock and also to raise the quarterly dividend rate in the June quarter, subject to business conditions.

Mrs. Edward Gropper entertained at tea in her home at 193 Park Avenue yesterday for members of the program committee for the sixth annual May Festival Dinner Dance. The fete on May 11 will aid Just One Break, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Administration offered two methods today to reimburse states for 10,850 miles of roads they had contributed to the 41,000-mile Interstate Highway System.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 20 -- A Westchester grand jury began to hear evidence today to determine whether there was attempted fraud against the First National Bank in Yonkers. Three witnesses testified.
American Airlines will start its first coast-to-coast jet service on Sunday. Using Boeing 707 planes, the company will run daily flights between New York and Los Angeles.

The eighth annual Mardi Gras Ball of the Junior League of New York will have many prominent persons among its patrons and patronesses. Their names have been announced by Mrs. John C. Carrington, ball committee chairman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following is the text of a policy statement issued today by the Democratic Advisory Council on the budget President Eisenhower sent to Congress yesterday:
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (AP) -- How many referees will admit they can't see the ball?
Uncle Sam himself may get into pleasure boating now that it has soared into enormous popularity as a participation sport.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 20 -- The Finnish Government announced tonight that President Urho K. Kekkonen would leave tomorrow for a brief visit to the Soviet Union.

The Composers Group of New York City presented a program of new music at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. All works heard were first performances except a song cycle by Tom J. Flannagan Jr. and Johan Franco's "Toccata" and "Nocturne," the last two having their first New York performances.
A California film director joined the Screen Directors International Guild here yesterday. His action was hailed by the union as a step toward reciprocity with West Coast directors.
The Buildings Department opened a new drive yesterday against tenement house owners who have not installed central heating.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- An all-out attempt to increase newspaper advertising will be made this year through four special promotions calling for the participation of 1,750 daily publications.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- Bulgaria will reorganize her administrative set-up because the present form of economic management has not kept pace with means of production, the Sofia radio announced tonight.
George A. Brenner, a former Surrogate and county judge in Westchester, was indicted here yesterday for forgery and the theft of $318,000. This figure, it was said, may go "much higher."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower stressed today the "particular critical role" of union leaders in keeping prices stable.
The George Junior Republic is starting a four-year campaign to obtain $1,970,000 to increase its activities.
Under circumstances described as "amicable," Alan Schneider has withdrawn as director for the forthcoming Sigmund Miller play, "Lovely Star, Good Night."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Officials here are convinced that the passage of the new South Korean National Security Act has cost President Syngman Rhee and his Liberal party much popular support.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Doyle Langdon Northrup lost his cloak-and-dagger anonymity today as one of the nation's leading scientific spies.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Andy Bathgate, the new glamour boy of the National Hockey League, held a 31-point lead today in the mid-season voting for hockey's highest honor -- the most-valuable-player award, which carries with it the Hart Trophy.
Fear of being labeled "space cadets" is inhibiting many reputable scientists from working on space research, Dr. Lloyd V. Berkner said last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senate Republicans completed their committee assignments for the Eighty-sixth Congress today after a week of intra-party bickering.
Anastas I. Mikoyan sipped a Martini-on-the-rocks yesterday in a Pennsylvania Railroad dining car and reminisced about vodka drinking in the Kremlin.
The American-Marietta Company had a record net income of $17,581,005 in the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, against $17,182,701 in the preceding fiscal year.

HODDING CARTER, editor of The Delta Democrat and Times of Greenville, Miss., is one of the ablest newspaper men in the South and the author of numerous superior books. As one who considers Mr. Carter's "Where Main Street Meets the River" one of the best books yet written about the South, I find it painful to report that Mr. Carter's new book, "The Angry Scar: The Story of Reconstruction,"* is sadly disappointing.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller, complying with the state code of ethics, has listed ten businesses under New York State jurisdiction in which he has invested $10,000 or more.

The Fire Department's city-wide inspection team put a Manhattan loft and a Bronx toy factory on ten-day notice yesterday to correct hazardous conditions. A visit to a second Manhattan loft showed the serious violations of last spring had been corrected.

A portrait of the forty-ninth state is given by Ben Adams in text and pictures entitled "Alaska: The Big Land." To be published early in March by Hill Wang, it presents an assessment of the importance of statehood for Alaskans and the rest of the American people. The author has based his book on information gathered last summer during a trip through the major parts of Alaska.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A special analysis in the Economic Report today attributed the 1958 decline in exports and the big outflow of gold to factors other than inflation in the United States.

With the delivery this month of six self-propelled rail-diesel (RDC) passenger coaches to the Federal Railways of Brazil, the Budd Company of Philadelphia has worked itself out of orders for any type of rail equipment.

Joel Ryce, an American pianist who was trained at the Curtis Institute and recently has been playing in Europe, made his debut last night in Town Hall. His program, a rather interesting and unconventional one, consisted of Bach's Fourth Partita, Aaron Copland's Piano Sonata, Chopin's G minor Ballade, Debussy's "Pour le piano" and Liszt's Twelfth Rhapsody.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The Democratic party's leading spokesman on housing legislation told the home building industry today that he was against a proposed billion-dollar extension of Federal "special assistance" funds for home financing.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- The Rev. Daniel J. Linehan, chairman of the department of geophysics at Boston College, received the Navy Distinguished Public Service Award today, the highest civilian award the service can bestow.

The Historical Automobile Cavalcade, run at Sebring, Fla., last year as a preliminary to the world championship twelve-hour sports car race, caught the fancy of the crowds and of old-car owners everywhere. So this year, with W. A. (Tim) Howkins of New York in command, the cavalcade will be twice as long and many times more interesting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower speeded Anastas I. Mikoyan on his way to Moscow today with a message of hope for peace and for United States-Soviet friendship.
In a half-hour signing ceremony at the Chase Manhattan Bank here yesterday, twenty-one United States banks granted a two-year stand-by credit of $200,000,000 to France to help stabilize the franc.
The Board of Education was warned yesterday that it must act immediately if it wished to head off the threatened mass resignations of evening high school teachers on Feb. 2.
Sales and earnings of the General Foods Corporation reached new records for the three and nine months ended Dec. 31, Charles G. Mortimer, president, reported yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 20 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. said tonight that Virginia remained rigidly opposed to any school integration anywhere in the state despite adverse rulings yesterday by the Federal and state courts.
Cultural interchange and friendship between the peoples of Brazil and the United States will be advanced as the result of the Carnival in Brazil at the Pierre on Jan. 30.
Anastas I. Mikoyan left for Moscow yesterday, confident that his visit had improved prospects for peace and that there would be no war in the near future.
ATLANTA, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The Georgia Senate voted quick approval today of four new segregation bills asked by Gov. Ernest Vandiver. They were sent to the House, which had passed another measure.
PARIS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The French Ministry of Finance posted new measures today making it easier for non-residents of the franc zone to repatriate capital investments in France.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Methodist Church is experiencing a resurgence in Communist Poland and remains active in other European Iron Curtain countries, it was declared here today.
SOME of this century's most important chair designs owe their existence to a Danish craftsman's fling at sculpture.
ALBANY, Jan. 20--The Legislature voted unanimously but joylessly today to bare its innermost bookkeeping and job-awarding practices to public inspection.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Dr. Arturo Frondizi, President of Argentina, arrived today for a state visit. He was warmly greeted at National Airport by President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- An attempt to block television distribution by Columbia Pictures of some 300 theatrical movies was denied today by Superior Court Judge Kurtz Kauffman in Los Angeles.

A new Governor took office at Albany Jan. 1. A new Legislature began its session Jan. 7 and yesterday, just thirteen days later, it responded responsibly to a Rockefeller call for political courage and increased the gasoline and Diesel fuel tax, effective March 1. The Governor promptly signed the measure. This is no small achievement.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 20 -- The chief of a new mission sent by the United States to train Haiti's army arrived today. Both governments call the program "a further demonstration of the close bonds of friendship."

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- A French anthropologist of noted courage and integrity, Mme. Germaine Tillion, wrote recently that "one can regard only with the deepest suspicion any sort of definition of the phrase used by politicians who do not want to commit themselves to recognizing Algerian autonomy: 'the personality of Algeria.'"
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower was saluted by Senators of both parties today on the sixth anniversary of his first inauguration as President.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan promised the House of Common today that Britain would accept a conference with the Soviet Union on Germany's future alone rather than on the whole problem of European security.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon will send special messages to the Republican National Committee meeting here this week. Republican leaders said they would be "fighting" messages and would begin an effort to remake the party for the 1960 Presidential campaign.

Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel yesterday committed Mrs. Jean Iavarone to Kings County Hospital for medical and psychiatric examination after she had been indicted on kidnapping and assault charges.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 20 -- The mood of officials in the Foreign Ministry was one of gay good cheer today in contrast to the gloom and uncertainty that prevailed a week ago.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 8 to 19 points (40 to 95 cents a bale) off on old crop months to 4 to 6 points (20 to 30 cents a bale) up on new crop months.
Stuffed owls were sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History as part of a nature exhibition for children who are patients at the hospital.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 20 -- The second installment of the Italian spring fashion showings is now in full swing at the imposing and chilly Pitti Palace here. This incredibly beautiful city is enveloped in a cold fog that would do justice to San Francisco, but this has not deterred the foreign buyers and press. They have arrived in droves to inspect the collections.

THE struggle of the serfs to cast aside the yoke is always a touching one. The plight of the underprivileged nags at man's conscience and stirs his sympathy. But the strike threat of players in the International League contrives to hit with about as much impact as a blob of butter landing on the floor.
Appointments affecting the Board of Standards and Appeals were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
Senator Jacob K. Javits urged last night that the United States reject any proposal for a summit conference with the Soviet Union that did not include the West's principal allies.

David Niven will be the host for a new filmed drama series that will make its debut April 7 over the National Broadcasting Company television network. The actor will also appear occasionally in a drama role.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator John F. Kennedy offered Congress today a labor-management reform bill that he said would either reform or drive out racketeers. In addressing the Senate, Mr. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat, specifically named James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, "and his ilk."
Steels, motors, rubbers, aircrafts, oils and drugs were firm yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the averages closed a little lower.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 20 -- Mayor Irving C. Freese, pursuing his investigation of Norwalk's commuter parking problem, took a ten-minute ride on the 7:03 New York-bound train this morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The World Jewish Congress reported today that the provincial government of Tripolitania had by decree taken control of the Jewish community there.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- For the first time, Britain is becoming a net importer of merchant shipping.

Rutgers has bobbed up with a new athletic hero. The current toast at New Brunswick is a young man named Karol Strelecki. This sophomore from Bethlehem, Pa., shows every promise of attaining the eminence in basketball that Bill Austin did in football.

With a new management team at the top, Schick, Inc., of Lancaster, Pa., announced yesterday a new pricing policy designed to stabilize retail prices and discourage discount selling at retail. It also said the policy would result in immediate reduction of the suggested list price of its electric shavers. The price of the Power shave model was cut from $31.50 to $22.50.

More new businesses blossomed forth in December than in any other month on record, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. That credit reporting concern said that incorporations of new companies rose about 36 per cent to 16,446 last month, from November's figure of 12,090. The December formations were 20 per cent above the previous record of 13,633 set in October, 1958.

Last night's program of the New York City Ballet at the City Center contained the season's first presentation of Francisco Moncion's little ballet, "Pastorale." Treating with excellent taste the delicate subject of blindness, it manages to be tender and touching.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 20 -- United States oil companies were placed under military control her tonight as the Government extended its mobilization of key industries to combat the general strike.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 20 -- Samuel Goldwyn declared tonight that management executives as well as the creators of films must share responsibility for the high costs that have put the motion-picture industry in its present depressed economic state.
OTTAWA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Great Lakes shipowners and operators today urged "preservation of historic toll-free areas" in connection with the St. Lawrence Seaway.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A tentative agreement to fix the first Tuesday in June as the permanent date for primary elections has been reached in conferences between party leaders here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas committed his power and influence today to the passage of a four-part civil rights bill in the present Congress.
United States Government bonds closed irregulary lower yesterday after an erratic trading session in which long-term issues touched low levels.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Nine State Senators opened New York's Year of History today with a brief re-enactment of the first Senate meeting in its original colonial setting.

In Richard Witkin's article on a possible "missile gap" between ourselves and the Soviets in coming years I was shocked by some of the opinions he quoted -- opinions of our military and political leaders. However, they advocate the policy of our having a military force which is second-best; a force able to destroy a large segment of the enemy's territory, but still an inferior force.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The only significent commercial influence on the Board of Trade today centered on near-by wheat contracts. It was bullish and listed both those deliveries by a cent a bushel or more.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to enact new laws to overcome recent Supreme Court decisions dealing with Communist subversion, criminal confessions and income taxes of gamblers.

MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP) -- H. H. Polk's Mlle. Dianne defeated Castle Rock Farm's Miss J. G. by a nose after a thrilling stretch duel before 15,022 race-goers today at Hialeah. Mlle. Dianne paid $5.50 for $2. Sandys Joy, owned by Merrick Stable, was two lengths behind the embattled pair and finished third.

A sharp drop of 692,277 shares in the short interest position in the month ended last Thursday was reported by the New York Stock Exchange after the close of the market yesterday. The aggregate short interest as of Jan. 15 was 4,381,079 shares, down from 5,073,356 as of Dec. 15, 1958. This was the lowest since Feb. 14, 1958, when it was 3,921,260 shares.

Jack Barry and Dan Enright, producers of the television quiz show called "Twenty-One" -- which went off the air after allegations of fixing -- declined yesterday to sign waivers of immunity before a New York County grand jury.

EAST NORWICH, L. I., Jan. 20 -- A revolt against the Republican leadership in the Town of Oyster Bay was quelled here today with the election of Thomas R. Pynchon as chairman and leader of the town Republican Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following are the letter of transmittal and excerpts from President Eisenhower's Economic Report, sent to Congress today:
The first shipload of aluminum ore from the Dominican Republic has arrived at the Point Comfort, Tex., refining plant of the Aluminum Company of America.
Joseph J. Lordi has been elected president of the New York Athletic Club. His election was announced at a special meeting last night.
PARIS, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- Agreement has been reached between Russia and the International Tin Council on global exports for 1959. An official announcement is expected in the next few days.
Northbound local service on the West Side IRT subway was interrupted yesterday for almost two hours, between Chambers Street and Thirty-third Street, by a power failure.

Loew's Theatres, which expects the final plan of separation from its parent company, Loew's, Inc., in the next forty-five days, is exploring an offer to purchase stock in the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Dave Beck, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was described at his tax trial today as a free spender who sometimes provided liquor for entertainment but "never touched a drop."
The city took an initial step yesterday toward abolishing the recently scandal-scarred Bureau of Real Estate and replacing it with a full-fledged Department of Real Estate.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 20 -- David Leo Lawrence took the oath of office as Pennsylvania's 102d Governor today with a call for bipartisan cooperation to solve the commonwealth's "very difficult fiscal problem."

The International Boxing Club and James D. Norris and Arthur M. Wirtz, majority stockholders in Madison Square Garden, intend to comply fully with the provisions of an anti-trust decree, Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan was told yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The Government won an uncontested victory today over the man who had begun to relate in a Sunday tabloid newspaper some of his recollections of the royal family's domestic life at Windsor Castle.
SEATTLE, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Alaska's first elected Governor, William A. Egan, remained in critical condition here today after a two-hour emergency operation for an intestinal ailment.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, left London Airport in a driving rain today for New Delhi on a 36,000-mile, three-and-one-half-month air and sea journey around the world. He will visit India, Pakistan and British territories in Southeast Asia and the Pacific.

Walter Piston and Douglas Moore have won the 1958 awards of the Music Critics Circle of New York. Mr. Piston's Viola Concerto was voted the outstanding orchestral work of the year, and Mr. Moore's "The Ballad of Baby Doe" the best opera.

THE irony of this will not be lost on Sir Thomas Beecham, who has always taken a realistic view of the world and its foibles. His appearance as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night was marked by a rapturous acclaim that exceeded anything he had received here in the past. He was now not only a musician but also a television celebrity.
GENEVA, Jan. 20 -- The Big Three settled down today to discussing the details of a control system for enforcing a ban on the testing of nuclear weapons.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Colonial Secretary Alan Lennox-Boyd told the House of Commons today that anti-terrorist operations in Cyprus would continue despite the truce maintained by E. O. K. A., the outlawed nationalist underground organization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The White House arranged some unusual entertainment for a dinner tonight honoring President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina: A simulated television show.
Representatives of all parts of the shipping industry, with the exception of labor, discussed the controversial cargo-container problem here yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 -- The easiest way to start a political conversation in Central Europe these days is to drop the name Mikoyan.
CAMILLA, Ga., Jan. 20 -- There are a few details to running a 5,000-acre shooting preserve on which about 10,000 quail and a few pheasants and Chukar partridges are shot in a season.

A membership meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night unanimously adopted a committee report endorsing the Judicial Conference's plan to reorganize the state's court system.
THE major distinction enjoyed by Anna Cora Mowatt's "Fashion" was not seriously impaired by its outing last night in the Royal Theatre, just off Second Avenue.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The Treasury announced today that it had approved the acquisition of the British Aluminium Company by Tube Investments. Ltd., a British company, and the Reynolds Metals Company of the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The Legislature voted today to raise gasoline taxes 2 cents a gallon and Diesel fuel taxes 3 cents a gallon, effective March 1. The gasoline tax is now 4 cents a gallon and the Diesel fuel tax 6 cents.

ST, LOUIS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals, led by Jack Twyman's 30 points, broke open a tight game with a run of 7 straight points in the last three minutes and upset the New York Knickerbockers, 114 -- 108, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

Argentina is traversing a rocky road, but at least one can say that it is going in the right direction. Obviously, if any one man is to be credited, he is President Arturo Frondizi, who is now in Washington. At the same time, most Argentines would say that Dr. Frondizi brought some of the present troubles upon himself. For the most part he inherited them.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20. -- The Soviet Academy of Sciences quickly followed up today the Communist party's instructions to change the editorial board of one of its magazines and to order all biologists to devote greater efforts to solving problems encountered in Soviet agriculture.
A 1959-60 basic tax rate of $4.26 for each $100 of assessed valuation of real property was forecast yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.
NEWARK, Jan. 20 -- The Erie Railroad reported today that its net deficit for 1958 would be about $4,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Senate Democrats strongly defended today Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, against a Republican charge that, as first Secretary of the Air Force, he allowed United States air power to deteriorate.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Alfred R. Loos of Blauvelt was reappointed as a member of the State Board of Parole today by Governor Rockefeller. The nomination was sent to the Senate for confirmation.
A physician was fatally stabbed in his Bronx office last night and his 17-year-old receptionist wounded by a man who posed as a patient.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Gen. Nathan Farragut Twining, like the famous admiral whose name he bears, was cast in a difficult role today.

Former President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba said yesterday that he gave up office and left Cuba New Year's eve to save bloodshed and because certain of his military chieftains defected to Fidel Castro's rebels.

The missing secretary of George A. Brenner surrendered yesterday for questioning about the alleged loan frauds of the former Westchester surrogate. She had been sought by New York and Westchester authorities for a week.
PLAINSBORO, N. J., Jan. 21 -- What is said to be the world's largest privately owned and operated nuclear research reactor went into operation here yesterday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Harold E. Churchill, president of Studebaker-Packard Corporation, defended today company plans to acquire other concerns in order to take advantage of tax laws. He said Studebaker-Packard was making money with the Lark auto.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 21 -- British royalty and British science sent the same smiling ambassador of goodwill to New Delhi today in the person of Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh.

BROWNLEE, Ore., Jan. 21 -- A footnote will be added to the Hells Canyon controversy tomorrow when the Idaho Power Company brings the Brownlee Dam to its capacity of 360,000 kilowatts by putting into operation a fourth generating unit of 90,000 kilowatts. Three others went into action last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Government auditors told Congress today that $46,000,000 worth of generators bought by the Tennessee Valley Authority from Westinghouse Electric Corporation did not work properly.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21 -- Only hard-core Peronist and Communist unions had held out in the fourth day of the strike protesting President Frondizi's Economic Stabilization Plan.
Trading in commodity futures continued dull yesterday on the New York exchanges. Activity was featureless in most markets.
Your timely editorial on Jan. 18 should help to promote constructive discussion of changes in the Taft-Hartley Act.

A Brooklyn grand jury investigating crime in the borough's public schools called upon the State Legislature yesterday to pass and Governor Rockefeller to sign a bill permitting corporal punishment for unruly pupils.
The Board of Estimate yesterday set Feb. 20 for a public hearing on the proposed sale of the city's rapid transit power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company.
Different points of view about United States policy toward Communist China were expressed yesterday at a luncheon forum of Freedom House at the Roosevelt Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Philip Forman, Chief Judge of the Federal District Court for New Jersey, is slated for promotion to the Federal Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

ALL things are relative. And, relatively speaking, the tart red cherry comes off exceptionally well in the canning process. When the winter wind doth blow, it is a frugal and imaginative homemaker who makes the most of this pantry item from a former harvest.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Following is the text of a statement issued by Governor Rockefeller's office today on state finance with an appendix prepared by State Budget Director T. Norman Hurd:
Commercial paper rates were raised yesterday 1/8 to 1/4 of 1 per cent on unsecured promissory notes sold directly to investors.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy asserted yesterday that almost all cases of relief fraud now being prosecuted had been submitted by his department to the District Attorneys.

The city Labor Commissioner intervened yesterday in the teacher salary dispute that is threatening to close the evening high schools on Feb. 2. About 30,000 students would be affected by the shutdown.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, signaled a major change today in the Government's program to achieve economic nuclear power in the next decade.

ADELAIDE, Australia. Jan 21 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo withdrew from men's doubles in the Australian national tennis championships today because of a strained stomach muscle, but then yielded to official pressure to reconsider his decision.

FIFTH AVENUE, fashion's "Great White Way," staged a spectacular last night. Until curtain time at 8 o'clock, the Fifth Avenue Openings had been the most controversial off-Broadway production of the year.

THE French chef's knife, a broad-bladed, heavy implement, performs culinary miracles when used with a light, quick hand. Professional cooks prize it for its versatility. Most chefs own one or more. Talented, budding Escoffiers and home cooks can learn to use it with dexterity and professional elan.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Rapidly growing Rockland County will begin a $92,800 country-wide planning program next Tuesday.

AT about the same time last night, Edward R. Murrow appeared on a radio program dealing with the racial issue. On the Columbia Broadcasting System's series "The Hidden Revolution," he was the narrator for a thirtyminute presentation about relations between Negro and white residents in a local community.

Electric power production last week was 13,324,000,000 kilowatt hours, down from the record 13,554,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable 1958 week it was 12,400,000,000.
A 60-year-old professional Santa Claus spent nearly two hours on a Municipal Court witness stand yesterday trying to make a jury believe in him.
Deputy Mayor Paul O'Keefe told an integration-minded audience yesterday that he did not regard it as a responsibility of government to "achieve patterns of population."
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 21 -- It takes more than fifty-fivemile-an-hour winds and plummeting temperatures to cool off local pride in the city's huge new waterfront terminal.
Despite record sales of $1,209,920,000 in the fiscal year ended on last Nov. 30, earnings of the Douglas Aircraft Company declined, directors were told yesterday at a meeting in Santa Monica, Calif.

The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation and its subsidiaries showed declines in sales and earnings last year, according to a preliminary report released yesterday by John E. Bierwirth, chairman, and Roy F. Coppedge Jr., president.
The suspicion is growing among pleasure-boat people that the New York Coliseum, with its four exhibition floors covering seven acres, is not large enough for the National Motor Boat Show.
Mickey Mantle refused to say in Dallas yesterday whether his contract from the Yankees called for a salary cut. But Whitey Ford showed no such reticence here about his own contract.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The British Ambassador protested formally to John Foster Dulles today over the Army Corps of Engineers' rejection of a British company's low bid on a contract for two hydraulic turbines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- The Navy today downgraded officially the results of a Polaris missile test at Cape Canaveral, described originally as "fully successful."
Conrad L. Wirth, director of the National Park Service since 1951, was honored yesterday by the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society.

The Rudder Club, a maritime industry organization, installed new officers last night at a dinner meeting in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn. Heading the list is Thomas F. Anderson, vice president of the AndersonLinton Lumber Company of Brooklyn as commodore.

Cold weather continues to cut light fuel oil stocks, used mostly in heating homes. Inventories of this product dropped 9,451,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
KENILWORTH, N. J., Jan. 21 -- The first strike in the Rahway Valley Railroad's sixty-one years was called today. It didn't seem to make much difference.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -Cecil B. De Mille died of a heart ailment today in his home on De Mille Drive here. He was 77 years old.
Chief and company officers of the Fire Department received notice yesterday that they must give up all outside employment by June 1.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The Eisenhower Administration was attacked today for its chilly attitude toward new housing legislation proposed by the Democrats.
PANAMA, Jan. 21 -- Panama rejected today protests by the United States, France and Japan over the recent law extending her territorial waters to twelve miles.
Senator John F. Kennedy's measure is the first of many forthcoming labor bills to reach the floor of the Senate.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 3 points (15 cents a bale) lower on old March and 2 to 7 points (10 to 35 cents a bale) higher on other months.
The United Hospital Fund said yesterday that Mayor Wagner had promised to increase the city's payments for the care of city patients in voluntary hospitals starting July 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Following is the text of speech by President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina before a joint session of Congress today, as translated by the Argentine Embassy:
NYACK, N. Y., Jan. 21 -Two Rockland County fires today took three lives. Two persons were listed as missing.
Three Boston officials of the International Longshoremen's Association testified yesterday before a New York County grand jury.

MIAMI, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Levelix won the $26,425 Jasmine Stakes at Hialeah as expected today, outrunning thirteen other 3-year-old fillies in the midweek feature. She won by a length and three quarters.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- A joint State Senate and Assembly Committee agreed today on bills to solve the state's assessment problem. The measures will be introduced Feb. 2 in both houses of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -Doubts about the wisdom of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson's proposal for a Federal conciliation service on racial matters were expressed today by President Eisenhower.

Directors of the Missouri Portland Cement Company yesterday raised the quarterly dividend with the declaration of 75 cents a share, payable to common stockholders on Feb. 13. The company had paid 50 cents in previous quarters plus extras of 25 cents in August and November.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Jan. 21 -- Forty-eight hours of torrential rainfall plus today's intermittent showers have temporarily removed the threat to Israel's water supplies.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The stock market recovered part of its setback of yesterday as selling dried up and bargain hunters came in at the lower levels. Yesterday's gains on Wall St. also encouraged buying.
Oregon sold yesterday an issue of $20,000,000 of war veteran's welfare bonds due in 1964 and 1965 at an interest cost of 2.77501 per cent.

Today's new film is "Some Came Running," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer version of the novel by James Jones starring Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Shirley MacLaine, at the Music Hall. The Sol C. Siegel production was directed by Vincente Minnelli, from a screen adaptation by John Patrick and Arthur Sheekman.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 21 -- The Little Rock school board asked Federal District Court today to allow it to reopen the city's four closed high schools Monday on a racially segregated basis.
HAVANA, Jan. 21 -- Fidel Castro said today the Cuban revolutionary Government had no reason to "offer explanations to the United States" for the execution of those it called war criminals.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Union leaders are pressing Senate Democrats to seize party control of the rackets committee.
The development of a cathode vacuum tube with an indefinite life span was announced yesterday by the Army Signal Corps and Tung-Sol Electric, Inc., of Bloomfield, N. J.
A city agency set up to do research on juvenile delinquency recommended yesterday that less emphasis be placed on correctional institutions and that more be given to probation.
The Manufacturers Trust Company and the Bankers Trust Company, New York City's third and sixth largest banks, are weighing a merger.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 21 -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, put a high price tag today on his program to make the Republican party a "continuing and sustaining political action" force.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- The National Cancer Institute today rejected Japan's antibiotic, Mitomycin C, as a potential cure for cancer.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller estimated today that state expenditures in the next fiscal year would be $235,000,000 greater than in the current year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The offer by the Department of Agriculture to extend loans on soybeans stored on farms provided the major, if not only, incentive for future dealers to do business today on the Board of Trade.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 21 (UPI) -- An Army publicist testified today that Representative William J. Green, Democrat of Pennsylvania, had to be kept informed of any jobs opened for bids at the Tobyhanna Signal Corps depot.
ALGIERS, Jan. 21 -- Contrary to official statements French clemency measures in Algeria have not been completed, responsible French officers said today.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad reported yesterday preliminary earnings for 1958 of $16,073,000 after taxes, fixed charges and contingent interest. This compared with $24,131,000 earned in 1957.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A committee of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany will set to work soon on a re-examination of policy on Germany in preparation for an expected conference with the Soviet Union this spring.

The American Smelting and Refiring Company (Asarco) reported yesterday that it had sold its entire remaining holdings in the common stock of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation. This amounted to 225,973 shares.
Unperturbed by a sharp drop in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, stocks pushed ahead yesterday to a historic high. Aggregate market values rose about $1,500,000,000.

QUEBEC, Jan. 21 (AP) -The British freighter Appledore sailed down the ice-dotted St. Lawrence River today. She was the last of thirteen foreign ships delayed since early December by ice in Montreal harbor and the adjoining Lachine Canal.
OTTAWA, Jan. 21 -- Canadian Pacific Airlines will get a franchise to operate a limited transcontinental service in competition with the Government-owned Trans-Canada Air Lines.

Masters, Inc., which operates a chain of eight discount department stores, plans its first entry into Queens by acquiring the inventory of Abramson's Department Store, in Flushing, which is owned by the Hecht Company of Baltimore Md.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Carl Switzer, freckle-faced Alfalfa of the "Our Gang" comedy series, was shot and killed tonight by a friend in an apparent argument over money, the police said.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The French Communist party was reduced today to official anonymity in the National Assembly by the adoption of new working rules.
Private interests supporting the proposed $1,000,000,000 redevelopment of lower Manhattan received assurance yesterday that the city would cooperate with their plans.

M. Lowell Harman, owner of a printing company here and a heavy buyer recently of shares in the Madison Square Garden Corporation, is biding for the controlling interest, it was learned yesterday. The controlling shares are owned by James D. Norris and Arthur M. Wirtz.

The 991st Field Artillery Battalion, New, York National Guard, will give blood today to the New York Real Cross Blood Program in the Kingsbridge Armory, 29 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx. Residents of Elmont, L. I., will gire blood in Stanforth Junior High School there.
The First National City Bank of New York issued a formal statement yesterday about the luncheon it gave on Jan. 12 for Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier.

Opposition arose in colleges yesterday to an anti-subversion provision of the National Defense Education Act of 1958. The provision requires students seeking loans to disclaim by affidavit belief in or support of groups advocating overthrow of the Government by force.
Every citizen of the United States must be educated to the limit of his capacity if this nation is to survive as a democracy in the nuclear age, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins said last night.

Harry J. Carman, student, teacher, scholar and cheerful philosopher, celebrates his seventy-fifth birthday today. They "retired" him in 1950 as Dean of Columbia College, for statutory reasons of age, and made him Emeritus. But as one of his friends, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, said on another "retirement" occasion, "No one can retire Carman."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina sought to assure the United States today of a political and economic climate favorable to foreign investment in his country.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 21 -- A stalemate has developed in the dispute between Laos and Communist North Vietnam over a block of territory on the border between the two countries.

What a pity that we did not seize the opportunity afforded by Mr. Mikoyan's visit to come up with a set of imaginative and workable proposals for the unification of Germany and the reduction of tensions in Central Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Administration sent to Congress today its proposals for the first two major legislative issues of the new session -- housing and airport construction aid. Both plans were less generous than the Democratic bills already submitted.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21 -- An undercurrent of comment and gossip against the United States here is accompanying news of Dr. Frondizi's trip.

The "Bal DiaBALLique" will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on April 17. The event, which is being sponsored by the Knickerbocker Ball Foundation, Inc., will benefit the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation and the Universal International Symphony Orchestra and Music Institute (UNISOMI).

The New York State Racing Commission yesterday authorized programs of nine races a day starting with the coming thoroughbred season. The move, in keeping with a trend that has seen the lengthening of racing programs in various parts of the nation, is expected to add between $4,000,000 and $5,000,000 to the great sums that have been realized by the state through pari-mutuel wagering.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The United States, Britain and France are discussing the arrangement of a conference with the Soviet Union timed to prevent the transfer of occupation authority in Berlin by the Russians to the East Germans May 27.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 21 -- The Italian fashion shows are continuing to unfold relentlessly onward in the Pitti Palace here. Emilio Schuberth showed his collection last night and Guidi Veneziani this afternoon. While pleasant enough, their offerings added nothing startlingly new or different to the general Italian couture silhouette of widening shoulders, narrowing waistlines and spreading hips.
BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Jan. 21 -- The chief hope for spreading Methodism in the cities lies in ministering to the Negro, a national mission of the denomination declared here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- A former United States Commissioner of Social Security said here today he had been impressed by the progress made by Soviet social security and pension programs.

ATLANTA, Jan. 21 (UPI) -The Defense sought to show today that officers investigating the bombing of Atlanta's Jewish temple arrested George Bright and charged him with the bombing because of a $25,000 reward in the case.

The fight for control of the Wilson-Jones Company, a Chicago manufacturer of stationery and office supplies, has produced a new wrinkle in proxy contest technique. Yesterday Swingline, Inc., a Long Island City stapling machine concern that is trying to take over Wilson-Jones, offered to buy a block of stock for cash and an eight-month call option.

In the good old days of vaudeville it was not unusual, when an acrobat was approaching the climax of a dangerous balancing act, to hold a large placard aloft that everyone in the audience could see. The placard carried an injunction to this general effect: "Kindly withhold your applause until this act is over!"

A Gutenberg Bible valued at more than $500,000 left New York yesterday on a return trip to Poland. It had been removed from a museum in Poland to Canada nineteen years ago for safekeeping from wartime destruction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Twentieth Century-Fox intends to invest $66,000,000 in the production of thirty-four pictures this year. The announcement was made today by Spyros P. Skouras, president, and Buddy Adler, studio production chief, at the end of conferences here attended by all of the company's top New York executives.

DUKE SNIDER had it coming to him. He was an ornery varmint who deserved to be gunned down without mercy. He'd tormented the good guy in his bullying way, riding into town with four other killers just to pick a fight. They were a nasty bunch, outlaws all. They were such contemptible critters that they didn't even show respect to the Flower of the West, a woman.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- The Saar, long a source of dispute between France and Germany, was without a government today on the eve of negotiations to bring about full ties with West Germany.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Most television programs would have to obtain a license from the Board of Regents under a bill introduced in the Legislature today. The cost to the TV stations would be $50 for each half hour or less.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- The final stage of the Monte Carlo Rally began tonight when 168 cars -- including two with American crews -- began the gruelling, 267-mile mountain regularity test that will determine the distribution of $11,000 in prize money.

Dr. Harry James Carman, Dean Emeritus of Columbia College and Moore Collegiate Professor Emeritus of History, is 75 years old today. He will brighten the day by doing two of the things he loves best: teaching and pondering how to serve mankind.

CAMILLA, Ga., Jan. 21 -- There are only a few quail hunters left who can make the jack-pine shot. This shot is made when a quail dodges around a dense little pine that grows branches down to the ground. The hunter shoots through the pine at the unseen bird and drops him.

A ninth participant in the Apalachin gangland convention was ordered to jail yesterday for refusing to answer questions by the State Commission of Investigation. The order was handed down by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter.

EDWARD R. MURROW and Fred W. Friendly joined forces again last night over Channel 2 but not under the name of "See It Now." Together they presented a characteristically provocative and touching documentary on the school integration problem in Norfolk, Va., where this week Federal and state courts wiped out the "massive resistance" laws.

Fog closed down on the city yesterday, delaying planes and forcing midday motorists in some sections-to use their headlights. The billowing gray curtain delighted photographers but proved a hazard for travelers. About thirty flights were held up at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens; some incoming planes were delayed up to two hours.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -President Eisenhower said today that critics of his $77,030,000,000 budget were suffering from "budgetary schizophrenia."

Eight physicians, including five former presidents of the American Heart Association, issued a statement yesterday designed to help Americans avoid heart attacks and strokes, the leading cause of death in the nation.
