IN his latest original drama, "The Velvet Alley," which was seen last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2, Rod Serling dealt with a familiar theme -- how success in Hollywood can spoil a decent, sensitive individual.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The Soviet Government declared tonight the outcome of the Geneva conference on banning nuclear tests depended entirely on the United States and British Governments.
IN one fell swoop, Macy's decorating staff has banished into oblivion the white-walled, neutral-upholstered, carpeted, ceilinged room.
AN old-fashioned beef stew has great appeal on a winter's day.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Chile moved out in front of the field of seven nations tonight in the world amateur basketball championships with an 83-71 victory over Puerto Rico. It was Chile's second triumph in as many starts.

Consumption of newsprint in December dropped sharply from the year-ago level, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. Production in Canada and the United States, however, rose 8.2 per cent above that of the 1957 month.
Following are the texts of a joint statement issued by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Herbert H. Lehman and Thomas K. Finletter and a reply by Carmine G. De Sapio:
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- Two new atomic power plants are under construction in the Soviet Union and two others are being prepared for chosen sites, a Soviet official disclosed today.
Dr. Chien-shiung Wu, a woman scientist who helped disprove one of the cornerstones of modern physics, received the twenty-third annual Research Corporation Award last night.

GENEVA, Jan. 22 -- The West called today for fast-moving international teams to help police a ban on nuclear-weapon testing, which the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union are attempting to negotiate here.

MARSHALL CASSIDY, the Dean of Men at the Jockey Club College, will soon welcome a new pupil. He will be a comparatively elderly schoolboy named Ted Atkinson. Although fellow jocks regard the Atkinson erudition with such awe that they call him The Professor, the newest scholar will humbly seat himself in the last row of Dean Cassidy's equine kindergarten.

Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens accepted yesterday the declaration of "war" issued Tuesday by Robert T. Battipaglia, Democratic leader of Queens. He dismissed Mr. Battipaglia summarily from his $11,000-a-year position as Superintendent of Highways.

The current campaign by our city to raise more money through new taxes leads one to consider an obvious inequity. What dollar amount might be realized by removing the exemption from real estate taxes given to real estate entrepreneurs who happen to be eleemosynary or educational organizations?
THE Winter Antiques Show, which opened here yesterday, is not only a collecting point for the valuable, the rare and the desirable, but also a rich deposit of decorators' inventions.

Directors of Delta Air Lines, Inc., voted yesterday to resume payment of dividends on the common stock with the declaration of 30 cents a share for distribution on March 2. The most recent payment was a similar amount, distributed March 3, 1958, prior to which 30 cents a quarter was distributed in 1957.
Two hospital buildings -- one seventy-one years old, the other almost new -- got a high mark in fire safety yesterday from Fire Department inspectors.
THE American wife does not mind if her husband wears the pants, but she wants to help buy them.
ROME, Jan. 22 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani's Government gained a new lease on life tonight when the Chamber of Deputies in a secret vote upheld it by a majority of one. The vote was 279 to 278.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 22 -- Dr. Mason W. Gross, president and provost of Rutgers University, announced today that plans had been completed for a new $1,000,000 library at Douglass College, the university's women's division.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Soviet statement on the conference in Geneva on suspension of nuclear tests as made public in English by the Soviet press agency Tass:
Recovery from the 1957 recession has been stronger than expected, according to a consensus of business and industrial leaders who spoke at a meeting here yesterday.
Everybody interested in baseball knows that Willie Mays possesses superlative skills as an athlete. So his admirers may be shocked to learn that Willie can't swim.

Net income of A M. Byers Company for the quarter ended Dec. 31, the first of its fiscal year, rose to $275,200 or 77 cents a common share on sales of $5,461,229, Buckley M. Byers, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday.

On page 15 of his Budget Message President Eisenhower called upon Congress, as part of the program for aid to the under-developed nations, "to enact legislation to expand the mutual security guarantee program."

A one-night cruise of the Liberte -- said to be the first such booking for a luxury liner -- will be a benefit for the New York City Cancer Committee. The group planning the "Captain's Gala" had its first meeting last week aboard the French ship.

Rear Admiral Henry C. Perkins, commandant of the Third Coast Guard District with headquarters in New York, had an intriguing thought yesterday at one of the important meetings generated by the National Motor Boat Show.
The British Travel Association served haggis, Scotch whisky and cigars yesterday to some American Scots and their sympathizers at its office in Canada House, 680 Fifth Avenue.
The police last night were investigating the disappearance of a 23-day-old baby boy from an apartment in West Eighty-fourth Street. They listed the case as a possible kidnapping.

The Belmont Stakes will share status in added money this year with the Kentucky Derby, John W. Hanes, president of the New York Racing Association, yesterday announced the increase in value of the Belmont event to $125,000, the same amount that is put up by Churchill Downs for the Kentucky Derby.
CHICAGO. Jan. 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WHEN Clement Grangier accepted his present position as executive chef of Luchow's Restaurant a few weeks ago, there was mild astonishment on the land and on the sea. Reaction came not only from fellow French chefs in New York, but from M. Grangier's brother, who is head chef of the French Line's Flandre.

Commodity futures trading, out of the ken of most investors, is a big business. In its annual report the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, Inc., reported that the 3,871,985 contracts traded on the sixteen active commodity exchanges represented commodities valued at $37,000,000,000.

THE adventurous collector in search of works of art that a modest purse can afford is enthusiastically advised to visit the Davis Gallery, 231 East Sixtieth Street, and its current show, "Functional Sculpture through the Ages."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Representative Richard Murray Simpson's strident call today from the prairie for the White House to start talking Republican was not a surprising outburst of impatience. Mr. Simpson, whose Republicanism is the unreconstructed, non-liberal, unmodern variety, has been bridling for months about what he feels is the absence of any readily identifiable Republican standard over the White House.

CAMILLA, Ga., Jan. 22. -- Wind is about as bad for crow shooting as it is for quail hunting, and the wind won't stop blowing around here. But a few crows paid the bitter price of brigandage today, just the same.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that he was disappointed with the failure of Edward R. Murrow and officials of the Columbia Broadcasting System to cooperate with the police in their investigation of vice in the city.
NEWARK, Jan. 22 -- A 1959 Essex County budget of $34,734,423 was approved today by the Board of Chosen Freeholders. That is $2,177,783 higher than last year's budget.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee unanimously approved today a resolution to permit a subcommittee to continue inquiries such as the one into the Adams-Goldfine case.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- The Soviet Union called on Norway and the Netherlands today to withdraw their threat to quit the International Whaling Convention.
The broad $1,000,000,000 redevelopment plan for lower Manhattan was approved in principle by the city yesterday.

Stockholders of Servel Inc., Evansville, Ind., will be asked at a special meeting Feb. 26 to approve certain changes in the charter. These would increase the authorized common shares from 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 and raise the company's debt limit to $15,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation was charged today with giving some retailers an illegal price advantage over their competitors in the electrical appliance field.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Labor leaders assailed President Eisenhower's Economic Report today as a blueprint for stagnation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A bill to reduce the tax depletion allowance for oil and gas producers from 27 1/2 to 15 per cent was introduced in the House of Representatives today.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- The board of governors of the National Basketball Association today announced a policy designed to protect Negro players against embarrassment stemming from segregated housing and dining facilities in some areas.

Of the $603,600,000 of new credits and allocations made abroad by the Export-Import [EXIM] Bank in the first six months of fiscal 1959, some $162,000,000 was extended by United States commercial banks, private investors and companies, Samuel C. Waugh, president of the bank said yesterday.

DES MOINES, Jan. 22 -- Following are the texts of messages sent to the Republican National Committee by President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon and excerpts from an address by Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman:

The nation's largest aluminum producer, the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) plans to acquire a leading wire and cable maufacturer, the Rome Cable Corporation, in exchange for 355,226 shares of Alcoa common stock.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Commissioner Bert Bell, who previously had said that pensions for National Football League players were not feasible, reversed his field today.
A contract for the purchase of the blockfront on Central Park West from 103d to 104th Streets has been signed by Max Abramchik Son, realty investors.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Jim Ferree of Winston-Salem, N. C., and Paul Harney, Auburn, Mass., took the first-day lead in the $15,000 Thunderbird invitation golf tournament today with 5-under-par 66's.
AT the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue, ten gallery regulars are exhibiting one work each in a spacious installation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Carl F. Hansen, superintendent of schools here, today denounced the attack on District of Columbia integrated schools made Tuesday night by the Governor of Virginia.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 22 -- King Hussein and Gamal Abdel Nasser, President of the United Arab Republic, seem well on the way to patching up their quarrel for the time being.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Jan. 22 -- Attending meetings of the Joint Military Armistice Commission in Korea has become a popular social pastime for American women and others in Seoul.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller named Republicans today to replace Harriman appointees as heads of three state labor agencies. He appointed:

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 -- The general strike against President Arturo Frondizi's economic stabilization program collapsed today on back-to-work orders from Peronist strike leaders fearing military reprisals.

DES MOINES, Jan. 22 -- President Eisenhower called today for "unremitting" Republican activity from now until the 1960 election. A Republican Representative immediately challenged him to live up to his own advice.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The world welterweight champion, Don Jordan, scored a third-round knockout over Mexico's Alvaro Gutierrez tonight in a non-title bout.

Mckesson Robbins, Inc., achieved record sales and earnings in the quarter ended Dec. 31. Sales for the nine months ended with December also were the highest for any similar period, according to the company's report.
The Glen Alden Corporation has sold its Ward LaFrance Truck Corporation division to a group of investors led by Harris J. Klein. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.
The members of a Municipal Court jury were saved yesterday from having to say whether they believed in Santa Claus.

Guests trekked through a simulated jungle inhabited by toy animals to the main ballroom of the Pierre and adjacent rooms last night to attend the ninth annual Animal Kingdom Ball. The dinner dance was a benefit for the adoption service of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Sales finance companies added $34,000,000 to their borrowings from the larger New York City banks in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This contrasted with a reduction of $42,000,000 in the like week a year earlier.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- A United Nations official called on American home builders today to help clear slums throughout the world.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- While weary drivers tried to catch up on much-needed sleep tonight, officials continued their complicated calculations to determine the winners of the $11,000 Monte Carlo sports car rally.

WHITE PLAINS, JAN. 22 -- Westchester County's parkways will get some signs that can be seen, and new center barriers on the parkways will consist of corrugated steel slabs on steel posts, similar to those recently used.
The super-secret code by which Army transmitted instructions to its "lonely end" last fall was revealed last night by the author of football's most intriguing formation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Democratic attack on the Administration's package of housing proposals began today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- House Democratic leaders agreed with President Eisenhower today that the two-term limit on Presidents should be repealed.
Elgar's "Dream of Gerontius" may have been the last piece of music that Pope Pius XII ever heard, according to Sir John Barbirolli.

" The Pulse of Radar" the autobiography of Sir Robert Watson-Watt, will be published by Dial Press on. Feb. 17. The carpenter's son from Scotland, who conceived the idea of radar and developed it, tells how he convinced soldiers and politicians that they should use it and as a result "revolutionized the whole of modern war." He also tells the story of individual radar devices and of the battles they affected.
Governor Rockefeller stressed the extent of state contributions to local school costs in appealing last night for support for his forthcoming budget.
Would we not be able to appraise the current concern about inflation a little more judiciously if we set recent events against the background of price movements over the last sixty years?
American Electric Power Company set records in virtually all of its 1958 operations, according to the preliminary annual report released yesterday.
The Sylvania Television Awards for 1958 were presented at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel last night.
PITTSTON, Pa., Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The Susquehanna River flooded today and gouged a huge hole in a coal mine tunnel, spilling tons of water that trapped twelve. Forty-four miners were rescued.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- Smith Kline French Laboratories today reported that consolidated net sales of $124,062,955 resulted in net earnings of $20,963,145 last year. These figures compare with $115,489,065 and $20,552,936, respectively, for the previous year.

A dismissed investigator for the Welfare Department was accused yesterday of exacting kickbacks from six relief recipients while he was employed by the department. He was indicted for falsification of accounts and for grand and petit larceny.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Democratic and labor union leaders were mobilizing today for an attack on Governor Rockefeller's tax proposals. They said the plans constituted a "soak the poor" program.
ATLANTA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A Negro leader said today that Negroes who had filed a school desegregation suit had been offered money to withdraw from the case.

A builder's proposal to take over a Brooklyn housing venture initiated by the United Housing Foundation was referred by the Board of Estimate yesterday to the City Planning Commission and six other agencies. They will make a study and report.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Two farmer organizations announced today pioneering efforts to find new markets abroad for this country's surplus agricultural commodities. They are the American Farm Bureau Federation and the Great Plains Wheat Marketing Development Association. Both will work out of Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Administration today attacked as "outmoded" and "too high in cost" a Democratic bill to authorize $575,000,000 for the Federal airport program over the next five years.

There should no longer be any doubt whether it is possible to have too many people in for cocktails. It is, and a scientist has proved it mathematically. According to his calculations, it is possible to tell when there are too many guests -- even one too many -- by judging whether the party is a "loud" one.

IS Wagner turning the corner at the Metropolitan Opera again? The past few seasons have been winters of discontent for his works. They have not been performed often and have not drawn as they used to in the late Thirties.
Albert Ackalitis, ex-convict and notorious waterfront hoodlum, failed to heed a court order directing him to appear and testify before the Waterfront Commission yesterday afternoon.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 22 -- Italy has just about had her say on the word fashion for this season.

Advocates of the early curtain time for Wednesday and Thursday matinees will have their wish fulfilled early in March. The step was confirmed yesterday by Louis Lotito, president of the League of New York Theatres.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The National Football League today ruled that its players could not play in pre-season or post-season games unless sanctioned by the N. F. L.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 22 -- The Rev. Albert Fay Hill, pastor of the 295-year-old First Presbyterian Church here, believes it is too easy to join a church.

The Bureau of Salesmen's National Associations has asked the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to review a ruling made in 1958, under which many non profit organizations conducting trade shows have been held subject to income tax at corporate rates. The bureau represents twenty-four traveling salesmen's organizations. The bureau considers these groups non profit organizations, the tax-exempt status of which has been questioned or revoked because they conduct trade shows.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Twelve oil producer associations are urging the Eisenhower Administration to adopt promptly a mandatory program for cutting imports of crude oil and oil products.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, wool, cottonseed oil, potatoes and hides rose; copper, lead, zinc and rubber declined, and price movements for coffee and sugar were mixed.

Floods, sleet and snowstorms swept the Eastern and Midwest areas of the nation yesterday. Locally, the fog and rain that hampered the metropolitan area Wednesday cleared away. The thermometer readings, which had been in the unseasonable upper forties and fifties for the last three days, dropped below freezing during last night.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 22 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen of Finland and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union conferred in Leningrad today on means of restoring to normal the long strained relations between their countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan 22 -- A suggestion designed to mediate the old question whether the social worker learns more in the text book or the tenement was offered here today by a curriculum study committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- New "cash" type savings fell a little in the third quarter of last year. But these savings in the first nine months of the year were larger than those in any full year since the end of World War II.
Steel users are gradually increasing their steel inventories, but so far the increases have been made to support improved business rather than to prepare for a possible steel strike this summer.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Illness of a key defense attorney today forced an early week-end postponement of the conspiracy trial of Representative William J. Green, Jr., Philadelphia Democrat, and six other men in Federal District Court.

The establishment of a nation-wide severance pay fund covering all unionized employes in the women's garment industry was predicted yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
A three-day convention of New York and out-of-town theatre operators ended here yesterday with the adoption of a series of resolutions aimed at helping business on the road.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Members of Congress from New York tonight explored ways of getting a bigger share of Government defense contracts for the state's industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The State Department said today the European Atomic Energy Community might impose a tariff on United States-built nuclear reactors partly financed by the United States Government.

Now that the annual January thaw -- 1959 vintage -- has come and apparently gone, ski operators yesterday were trying to repair the damage done by the recent high temperatures and the twenty-four-hour rainfall.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- An international federation of seafarers' and dock workers' unions decided here today to make ship-owners hire crews under contracts with unions of the ship-owners' nationality.

PITTSTON, Pa., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Hope dimmed today for the lives of twelve coal miners still trapped in a complex tunnel flooded by the Susquehanna River. Rescue operations -- their cost already exceeding $2,000,000 -- continued.
Allan A. Buckhantz and Mitchell May have combined under the firm name of B M Theatre Productions to produce a new musical next season.

Events today: New York Philharmonic Young People's Concert, conductor Leonard Bernstein, noon; "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 2 P. M.; "Otello," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; New York Philharmonic, conductor, Sir John Barbirolli, 8:30.
Moscow, Jan. 20 -- Moved by patriotism and stung by a challenge to practice what he has preached, Dmitri Shostakovich has written an operetta.
Only the oils showed any sense of direction yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Most of the other major groups were mixed. The market as a whole managed a tiny advance on the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Senator Stuart Symington charged in the Senate today that the Administration might be adjusting intelligence estimates of Soviet missile strength to meet economies in the budget.

A meeting between jazz and what is usually considered one of its basic sources might have been anticipated at a program called "Afra Ghan Jazz" at Town Hall last night. It joined the primitive dances of the Asadata Dafora Dancers and a representative of contemporary jazz, Les Jazz Modes Quintet.

The white elephant was a lady this year. In the person of Mrs. Emmett Whitlock, a committee member, she popped up out of a huge birthday cake to greet guests at the twentieth annual White Elephant Party last night. Mrs. Henry J. Taylor was honorary chairman.
ATLANTA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- George Bright, a 35-year-old industrial engineer was acquitted tonight of a charge of dynamiting the Atlanta Jewish temple on Oct. 12, 1958.
Albert Ackalitis, hoodlum and ex-convict, refused to answer questions by the Waterfront Commission yesterday after he finally appeared in response to its subpoena.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 23 -- The Soviet Union will start its long-delayed trade negotiations with Finland as soon as possible, it was announced tonight from Leningrad.

A Queens man who allegedly advertised 50-cent filters as "converters" that turned black and white television pictures into "living true colors" was arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions Court. He was accused in a three-count criminal information of using untrue and misleading advertising.
A happy anniversary was celebrated yesterday in Caracas, Venezuela. Exactly a year previously the hated dictatorship of General Perez Jimenez was overthrown.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- To help him assure "the regular functioning of the public powers as well as the continuity of the state," President Charles de Gaulle has assembled the biggest staff of experts in recent French history.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 23 -- Mass education, a favored instrument of all Communist parties on coming to power, is beginning to show results in Rumania.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Paul Coltelloni and Pierre Alexandre, of France today captured the over-all trophy in the twenty-eighth Monte Carlo auto rally.
Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney yesterday ordered an employe of a renting agency to be held in jail for a week while the court decided what sentence to give him for a Sanitary Code violation.

Among the many persons who entertained at cocktails in advance of last night's dinner dance of the Yorkville Community Association at the Plaza, was the fete chairman, Mrs. Charles W. Lewis. She and Mr. Lewis had guests at their home at 1158 Fifth Avenue.

Although only one new corporate security offering next week will be sold by competitive bidding, a number of negotiated sales and several subscription offerings will bring the total to a sizable figure.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 -- A program of events for 1959 that surpases any in the history of the group was revealed today by Harry Cushing of New York, national activities chairman of the Sports Car Club of America.
John T. Clancy, Queens Borough President, announced yesterday he had invited city officials to discuss with him the possibility of parking automobiles in unused parts of the subway in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers said today that a pupil-placement plan in public schools would seem to be constitutional if it were not used to discriminate against Negroes. Mr. Rogers also said he did not believe that the need would arise again for the kind of direct action that the Federal Government took at Little Rock, Ark., in 1957.
Dimitri Mitropoulos, a conductor of the Metropolitan Opera and former musical director of the New York Philharmonic, suffered a heart attack yesterday and was admitted to the New York Hospital.

Investor interest in the Monthly Investment Plan (MIP), a five-year-old child of the New York Stock Exchange, reached a new peak in 1958. The plan was started on Jan. 25, 1954, to permit investors to buy stocks on a pay-as-you-go basis. The number of subscribers and their holdings of shares in listed companies are now at the highest level ever.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan stepped out of the limelight and into a hulking black ZIL limousine without comment today as he returned to Moscow from his none-too-restful eighteen-day "vacation" in the United States.

A twelve-hour exposition today from 11 A. M. to 11 P. M. and a six-hour display tomorrow from 1 to 7 P. M. are all that separate New Yorkers and many visitors from a return to winter drudgery. Their exciting annual January interlude, the National Motor Boat Show, is drawing to a close at the Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Senator Mike Mansfield, Democratic Whip, warned fellow Democrats today not to overreach themselves on civil rights legislation because of their hope of winning the White House in 1960.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 23 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Henry A. Byroade breached the South African Government's strict social code by inviting an American Negro to a party in his honor, it was learned today.

A golden copy of a ship's wheel mounted on a surging sea was presented yesterday to seven newspapers, two of them weeklies, for leadership in boat advertising linage and in the promotion of recreational boating and allied water sports.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 23 -- Fidel Castro received a hero's welcome in Venezuela today. Arriving at Maiquetia airport at 1:30 P. M., he was cheered by 50,000 people. The crowd broke through police lines in a effort to get near the Cuban rebel leader.

Robert T. Battipaglia, Queens Democratic leader, charged yesterday that Borough President John T. Clancy had not acted on his own initiative when he summarily dismissed him as Superintendent of Highways.
JANUARY brings colds, cross spirits and chilling weather. The best antidote, other than a trip South, is a leisurely shopping stint.

DETROIT, Jan. 23 -- A Federal grand jury indicted the Detroit Chevrolet Dealers Association, Inc., and twenty-two Chevrolet dealers in the metropolitan area today on charges of violating the Sherman anti-trust law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- From the fields of labor and industry Congress received pleas today to discard President Eisenhower's economy geared housing and airport aid proposals in favor of more ambitious programs.

AS the opening event of the 1959 Philadelphia Arts Festival the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts held a preview of its 154th annual exhibition in its galleries last evening. Awards and citations were announced. The exhibition will open to the public tomorrow and will continue through March 1.
About 40,000 Manhattan-bound subway riders from the Bronx and Queens were delayed yesterday morning from five to twenty minutes by mechanical trouble on the IND and IRT lines.

DES MOINES, Jan. 23 -- The Republican National Chairman pleaded for unity today after another G. O. P. Congressman had called on President Eisenhower to do more for the party. While he emphasized that he had no particular individuals in mind, Meade Alcorn, the chairman, told the Republican National Committee that "some leaders seem in the public eye to appear to be blocking their own teammates."

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Anne Heggtweit of Canada triumphed in the women's slalom race of the international white ribbon ski tournament today. She beat the world champion, Inger Bjoernbakken of Norway, by 1.7 seconds.

ROME, Jan. 23 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani was partly successful today in efforts to halt a threatened walkout from his cabinet. Of two ministers who earlier this week sent letters of resignation to Signor Fanfani, one withdrew his and the other appeared likely to do so.
MIAMI, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Bill Hartack drew a ten-day suspension today for rough riding in Thursday's seventh race at Hialeah. The suspension starts Sunday and will last through Feb. 3.
An old Liberty ship fitted out with the most modern scientific equipment left Baltimore yesterday bound for South Atlantic waters far off the regular trade lanes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--Bankers must pursue resourceful policies and use imagination if they are to meet the challenge of increasing competition from other financial institutions, a leading banker warned here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Governor Rockefeller sent to the Senate today the names of ten appointees for confirmation. Among them were the reappointments of Joseph A. Martino of Manhasset, L. I., as a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority and of Morris Iushewitz of Mount Vernon as a member of the board of trustees of the State University.
PRESIDENT Urho Kaleva Kekkonen of Finland, who is in Leningrad to negotiate better relations with the Soviet Union, is a practical statesman with a pliable policy.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos announced tonight that Mexico had broken off relations with neighboring Guatemala.

Hank Bauer, the 36-year-old outfielder, and Gil McDougald, an infielder six years younger, were in the Yankee offices yesterday. Bauer signed his 1959 contract, making him No. 1 on that list, but McDougald left his unsigned.

In The New York Times of Jan. 18 your Belgrade correspondent reported that the United States may give to Tito's Government an additional $20,000,000 aid. Thus the total amount of aid in this year would reach $150,000,000.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 23 -- The scene of tribal disorders has shifted from the Rif Mountains in northern Morocco southward to the Middle Atlas mountains near Fez.
A convicted forger who is managing director of the Shelton Towers Hotel was arraigned yesterday as a material witness in the alleged loan frauds of George A. Brenner.
PHILADELPHIA Jan. 23 -- Russian rockets may have sent imaginations soaring, but they have brought American education down to earth, a scientist said here tonight.

Achievement awards will be presented by New York University to four alumni of its College of Engineering and University College of Arts and Science at the annual University Heights Deans' Day, to be held this afternoon at the N. Y. U. Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.
The Metropolitan Opera is interested in producing Gian-Carlo Menotti's newest opera, "The Last Superman."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The Air Force general who was responsible for spending $87,000,000,000 of the Government's money in his thirty-year career will retire on Feb. 28, the Air Force announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--The American Council for Judaism declared here today that the integration of American Jews into every phase of the nation's life was being hampered by what it termed the "growing centralization" of Jewish organizations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The House Rules Committee moved again today to control foreign junketing by members of Congress.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- Mrs. Irene Ellis Murphy of Birmingham, Mich., has spent the last five years building her own version of an economic bridge for Filipino handicraft workers whose skills she helped to foster.
Teachers in the city's high schools went directly to the source yesterday for the latest information to pass on to their students.

The little Asian kingdom of Laos has done the right and wise thing in bringing to the United Nations a complaint of Chinese Communist encroachment on its frontier. Laos has asked for an observer or an observer group. This request is reasonable. It should be granted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Bills designed to enforce ethical conduct by Federal personnel in both the Executive and legislative branches were introduced in the Senate today by Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York.

In The Times of Jan. 19 Harry D. Comer complains that the New York State income tax does not permit deduction of Federal income taxes. He says: "Obviously New York is collecting a tax on a tax. Can that procedure possibly be constitutional?"
President Eisenhower declared sections of the flood-stricken states of Ohio and Pennsylvania disaster areas last night.

YOUNGSTERS need a "balanced diet" of activity as surely as they need carefully planned meals. In some cases, parents may have to limit the variety of children's after-school pursuits just as they would between-meal snacks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Controller General Joseph Campbell said today that the Navy had used the wrong cost figures in placing a $76,518,000 price tag on a contract for F3H Demon planes.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo, hero of the United States' Davis Cup victory, rallied to down Barry MacKay in their all-American semi-final of the Australian national tennis championships today.

The city-wide program of the Play Schools Association will be aided by proceeds from the association's annual Valentine bridge, canasta party and fashion show on Feb. 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 -- Red combines wheeled through the fields of yellow grain in the southern pampas this week, reaping the biggest money harvest Argentine farmers have known in years.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -- West Germany put a tariff of nearly $5 a ton on imported coal today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The utility meter reader will join the family iceman in retirement if an invention patented this week is adopted generally. It takes readings automatically by telephone and feeds them to a billing machine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Eisenhower said today that the $3,600,000 to be spent on the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer was "about the best investment of money this Government has made in a long time."

DENVER, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Regents of the University of Colorado today dropped Head Coach Dallas Ward. His eleven-year football record at the Big Eight Conference school was sixty-two won, forty-one lost and six tied.
HAVANA, Jan. 23 -- Maj. Jesus Sosa Blanco was condemned today to death before a firing squad in the first summary court-martial of "war criminals" held by the revo lutionary regime in Havana.
Peter Close, St. John's brilliant runner, added a distinguished performance to his record last night.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The Linen Thread Company announced today the sale of its United States subsidiary to the Indian Head Mills of New York City, subject to Government approval. The transaction involves about $12,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina said today that his country would not welcome a visit by Anastas I. Mikoyan, Soviet First Deputy Premier.
A plan to offer business executives a short course in the humanities, "to broaden their perspective and judgment," was announced yesterday by the American Foundation for Continuing Education.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The State Health Department said today that it was checking radioactivity of the lower Hudson Valley so that any "abnormal" increase could be gauged.

IN England, Elgar's oratorio "The Dream of Gerontius" has rarely been out of the reportory of the choral societies and festivals since its first performance in 1900. In this country it has rarely been in.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The United States, trailing by seven points at the half, rallied to top Puerto Rico, 54 -- 53, tonight in the final round robin of the world amateur basketball championships.
The annual presentation of the New York Film Critics' awards for film "bests" of 1958 will take place tonight at a private reception at 11 o'clock at Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West Forty-fourth Street.

HOW much salt is "salt to taste ?" The amount of salt required in a dish depends upon many things, including personal preference, the natural salt in the food and the quantity of food cooked. For a perfectly seasoned dish, it is necessary to taste the food as it is prepared. The following general rules will provide a helpful starting point.
A homeless and unemployed dishwasher who, according to the police, passed a threatening note to a teller to obtain $6,000 was quickly captured in a Brooklyn bank yesterday afternoon.

Two floors in the new office building at 360 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fortieth Street, have been leased by Senville Realty and Construction Inc., owner, to Outdoor Advertising Inc., national sales and promotion organization. Tom Brown, vice president of Cushman Wakefield Inc., was the broker.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 23 -- The Board of Missions of the Methodist Church appropriated $21,341,488 today for evangelical and social work in this country and overseas in the coming year.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The Western world's major maritime unions agreed here today to draw up jurisdictional lines for a global battle against shipowners using flags of convenience.

Five stories of a seven-story factory building at 41-43 Division Street on the lower East Side were ordered evacuated and closed by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday. The move was made during an unannounced visit by the department's new mobile inspection team.

A TRENTON reader, Mrs. Neal W. Chilton, has submitted several questions about cakes. First, she asks about the difference in flours. Secondly, she comments on a sweet chocolate cake, the recipe for which was listed in this newspaper on Jan. 4.
GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- The United States and Britain rejected today the Soviet Government's charge that they were seeking to torpedo the three-power conference for banning tests of nuclear weapons.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 23 -- The Charter Revision Commission last night recommended an end to the fee system in the town clerk's office and the increase of Councilmen's salaries from $600 to $1,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The United States Consumer Price Index dropped in December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. At the same time, factory workers' earning rose materially.
Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson called on Congress yesterday to complete without delay the Eisenhower Administration's proposed revisions of farm programs.
PHIL SILVERS' immortal Sergeant Bilko expanded his Friday bridgehead on Channel 2 to a full hour last night; the situation was happily well out of hand.
Prices of commodity futures moved generally off yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

A group of midtown tenants have filed an appeal against a recent court ruling that authorizes their landlord to collect higher rents retroactively from the time he first applied for them in May, 1957.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Louis (Scarfare) Lieberman denied today that he had come here to organize the trucking business in the Los Angeles garment industry.

Two fine soloists who have never before played together joined forces last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art They were Erica Morini, violinist, and Rudolf Firkusny, pianist.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent to 119.6 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- Britain's National Gallery has paid 125,000 ($325,000) for a "St. George and the Dragon" by Paolo di Dono Uccello, Italian fifteenth century painter.
A broken-hearted father made an eloquent appeal yesterday for the return of his missing twenty-four-day-old son.

The distribution of racist and hate literature reached a new post-war high last year, it was reported yesterday by Ralph E. Samuel, chairman of the national executive board of the America Jewish Committee.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 -- All civil aviation within Mexico and international traffic on Mexican-flag lines was brought to a standstill today by a work stoppage of nearly 500 pilots.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- JoAnne Goodwin of Haverhill, Mass., who won the Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament in 1956, gained the semi-finals of the same event today with a 3-and-2 victory over Betty Kerby of Akron, Ohio.

S. George Zauderer of George Zauderer Sons has purchased for investment the eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at 136 East Thirty-sixth Street, southeast corner of Lexington Avenue. Paterno Estates Inc., Carlo M. Paterno, president, was the seller and had owned the property since 1935.

Fourth-quarter earnings of the Budd Company more than doubled those of the 1957 final quarter. They enabled Budd to report a profit for the year 1958 after operating in the red for the first nine months.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP)--Ted Williams renewed baseball's richest player contract today by signing with the Red Sox for more than $125,000 for the 1959 season.
The newest weapon in the city's fight against cancer will be in operation in about a month, the Mount Sinai Hospital said yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 23 -- A Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that four Negro children must be admitted to Stratford Junior High School, Arlington, Va., on Feb. 2, the start of the next school semester.
Frank Fain made a plea for individuality in dress at the Columbia Grammar School yesterday. He was told by his peers to straighten his tie and get back in line.

DETROIT, Jan. 23 -- Inside, outside and underneath both boards, the West was superior to the East in the ninth annual All-Star game of the National Basketball Association at the Olympia tonight. It was, therefore, with plenty to spare that the squad coached by Easy Ed Macauley turned back Red Auerbach's group, 124 -- 108, before 10,541 fans.

The new regime in Cuba has made a well-intentioned but terrible mistake in the method it chose to try the men accused of being war criminals. A spectacle such as was seen in Havana on Thursday, in a sports stadium, with a mob howling for blood was bound to cause a revulsion here and everywhere in the world.

A symposium by the generals and scientists in charge of the United States space program will be published Wednesday by Praeger under the title "Space Weapons: A Handbook of Military Astronautics." Compiled by the editors of Air Force magazine, the volume presents a comprehensive survey of this country's status in the race to space.
Ingemar Johansson was four hours late arriving from Sweden yesterday, but he didn't lose (a) his appetite, (b) his composure or (c) his confidence.
New York State will be leading, not lagging, in economic growth within a few years, in the opinion of Dr. William J. Ronan, Governor Rockefeller's secretary.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 23 -- In a switch from setting a code of behavior for children, the school superintendents of Bergen County have adopted a set of rules for themselves. The goal is to prevent the raiding of other schools' faculties to get good teachers.
Jerome Jennings, New York financier and business executive, said yesterday that he was the leader of "a group of investors" that were negotiating to buy working control of Howard Stores Corporation.

Within three days after the United States and Britain made a major and potentially hazardous concession at the Geneva conference on nuclear weapons tests the Soviets have issued another statement obviously designed to wring more concessions from them.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Once again the Cyprus problem is on the verge of settlement. Diplomatic negotiations, between Greece and Turkey, which broke off last November, have neared agreement. If they succeed in ending their savage intra-NATO dispute, the entire strategic picture in the eastern Mediterranean will improve. But if they fail on the brink, a situation that is already bad will become immeasurably worse.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The state's highest court ordered today that a 5-year-old girl be taken from foster parents who sought to adopt her.
The 175-acre Jamaica Race Track, twice scratched as a housing site, is back in the race against the city's housing shortage.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for 1958 and for the final quarter of the year.
A psychiatrist yesterday scored the apathy of the public toward suicide despite statistics showing that it is twelve and a half times more prevalent than murder.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- Soviet nuclear scientists announced today that they had put the world's largest atom smasher into capacity operation.

KFAR VITKIN, Israel, Jan. 17 -- Visitors from seventeen African and Asian countries are searching here for new social and economic patterns to meet the peculiar needs of newly emancipated or awakening nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Defense attorneys contended today that a news article had violated the secrecy of the grand jury that indicted Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside in the award of a Miami television permit.
The call by the liberal wing of the Democratic party for a grass-roots movement to revitalize the party has given encouragement to insurgent groups seeking to oust Tammany district leaders.
HICKSVILLE, L. I., Jan. 23 -- Business leaders here today called for early action on a $10,000,000 project for the elimination of seven Long Island Rail Road crossings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Delivery of mail by guided missiles is the newest gleam in the eye of Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.
UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 22 -- The production of crude steel in Europe declined slightly in the first three quarters of 1958 compared to the same period in 1957.
Government reports show that the year 1958 ended with a surge in housing starts, a slight dip in personal income and a further slight rise in industrial production.
ALGIERS, Jan. 23 -- Nationalist rebel forces blew up a train carrying oil from Touggourt in the Sahara to the Mediterranean coast tonight, the French Army announced.
A Brooklyn judge opened the way to freedom yesterday for a 70-year-old man who has spent forty-three years in prison.
Coach Eddie Erdelatz of Navy got a new Cadillac convertible and a big surprise on Thursday night.
VIENTIANE Laos, Jan. 23 -- An American walked up to a desk in the Laovieng Bank here today, presented 32,000 kip and asked for 400 United States dollars in travelers' checks.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Directors of the Texas Company yesterday raised the dividend on the common stock with the declaration of 60 cents quarterly, payable March 10. This action places the stock on an annual basis of $2.40 a share. In previous quarters shareholders received 50 cents a share.
The overthrow of Fulgencio Batista in Cuba apparently will not alter the plan to erect a Central Park monument his Government helped to finance.
A barber of Italian descent who cuts orphans' hair for nothing and once had considerable success selling Israel Bonds, will be honored next week by the Boro Park Lodge of the B'nai B'rith.
A campaign for increased state aid to the city colleges was opened yesterday by the coordinating committee of the Public Education Association.
The cornerstone of the first unit of a new cathedral and headquarters for the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America will be blessed and dedicated at 1 P. M. today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP)--The player pension issue was put off until April and the player draft reduced from thirty to twenty rounds today as National Football League owners wound up their annual winter meeting.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved up to 13 to 17 points (65 to 85 cents) on old crop months yesterday, but 4 to 7 points (20 to 35 cents) off on new crop months. The volume was fairly heavy, especially in the afternoon trading.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz proposed today the automatic suspension of physicians, dentists, nurses and other professional people licensed by the state who were treated for mental illness.
NO need to take to the highlands for a tweed suit. A brisk, blue-eyed Scotsman, Peter Saunders, will mail one to you.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that there may have been political considerations in the award of a Government contract for two turbines to a Philadelphia company this week. A British company had submitted a lower bid.
The Educational Television and Radio Center will move its headquarters from Ann Arbor, Mich., to New York this spring.
CAMILLA, Ga., Jan. 23 -- Dogs are one of the great problems of a shooting preserve in South Georgia.
MONROE, La., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- A derailed tank car of liquid gas exploded tonight killing at least four persons and injuring 52 spectators and workers.

The New York Central Railroad's decision earlier this month to halt joint merger studies with the Pennsylvania Railroad broke up "exploratory" discussions of seven other Eastern carriers on what steps they should take as a defense. It hasn't however, dimmed the interest in a merger of five New England railroads.

Divided support by the insurance industry and solid opposition by banks was given yesterday at a hearing on a proposal to amend New York's insurance law to permit insurance companies to act as trustees of pension and retirement plans.

A new year brings another reminder that this continuing city pays tribute to progress in each generation by destroying what, in the generation before, was generally admired and pointed out to the visitor in our midst as giving our home town just right to pride.

KENILWORTH, N. J., Jan. 23 -- A New Jersey union official charged today that the state safety laws were being violated as a result of the walkout Wednesday of three track maintenance men of the Rahway Valley Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Eisenhower created by Executive Order today a special Cabinet Committee on Activities Affecting Prices and Costs. The aim of the new group will be to guard against inflationary practices in the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Government agencies are reviewing United States policy toward trade with the Soviet Union.

GEOFFREY HOUSEHOLD'S autobiography, "Against the Wind,"* is a splendidly unusual story of a wildly picaresque life. It is gay where, according to the usual rules, it should be moody, and moody where it should be gay. The gods of the copybook maxims don't seem to have guided the man who wrote that chill thriller, "Rogue Male," at all.
Encampment for Citizenship, a summer educational project for young Americans, will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the April 9 performance of Tennessee Williams' play "Sweet Bird of Youth."

TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi, who was re-elected today as president of the ruling Liberal-Democratic party, stressed the need for cementing the party's unity by reshuffling Cabinet and party posts.

Dr. James B. Conant, president emeritus of Harvard University, is making the high school principal's job easier. That is the vigorous reaction of some leaders in secondary education to Dr. Conant's reports on his study of the American high school.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 23 -- Norfolk school officials denied today a statement by Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. that make-shift private tutoring classes had proved an adequate substitute for public schools closed to avoid integration.
IT was through Victoria's music that I found my way to the incredible sixteenth century. It happened at Geneva in the early Nineteen Twenties, a year or two after I had concluded my formal studies.

LAST year, for the first time in history, the state opening of Parliament was televised, and it was thought necessary to warn the viewers that the "Queen's Speech" was not really hers, that the words were those of her Prime Minister and that her faithful subjects were not to interpret her delivery of the speech as approval for what was said in it.

The fact that few women go into fields involving science and mathematics is a major loss of talent to the nation, educators have warned. Some surveys have indicated that only 4 per cent of college physics majors and less than one-fifth of all science and mathematics majors are women.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 24 -- An Eskimo carpenter is favored to become president of the Alaska Senate when the first Legislature of the forty-ninth state convenes here Monday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 24 -- Premier Phoui Sananikone organized a Laotian Government today that gives strong representation to new young political leaders. He also brought army officers into the Cabinet for the first time.

Civilian jobs abroad with attratcions such as traveling and housing besides the pay checks are reaching out again for qualified young women. Tomorrow the Army Special Services begins its annual interviewing in New York City.
CALL it a momentary illusion but our town occasionally takes on the guise of a Hollywood-on-the-Hudson. Last week, it was learned that another major production would be filmed here in its entirety.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -Tennessee Agricultural and Industrial State University scored an easy victory tonight in the women's national Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 -- The Democrats' choice of Los Angeles for their 1960 national convention is already paying off in potential votes.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 24 -- An internal political crisis of perhaps unprecedented severity in this country has damaged the position of the Republic of Korea in relation to the ever-present threat from Communist North Korea.

Steel production in the Cleveland-Lorain district totaled about 3,800,000 tons last year, or only two-thirds of the 1957 output. After reaching an ebb in the second quarter, production in the October-December quarter showed a 16 per cent rise from the level of the preceding year and was only 9 per cent short of the high established in early 1956.
Reluctant to see the National Motor Boat Show get ready to up anchor and leave the New York Coliseum for another year, enormous crowds yesterday thronged the gay dry-land anchorage.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey said last night that his state should never again build a large mental hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has recommended to the White House that any agreement with the Soviet Union on a suspension of tests of nuclear weapons should be limited to tests in the atmosphere. The agency would exclude underground tests from the ban.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 24 -- West Germany's partners in the European Coal and Steel Community are questioning whether a new tariff announced in Bonn yesterday is in accord with the spirit of the six-nation agreement.

FIFTY white flowering dogwood -- a gift of the Garden Club of New Jersey -- will be shipped by air to Niigata, Japan, in time for spring planting. The dogwood will replace the city's famous willows which were destroyed by fire in 1955.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 24 -- Two brothers, elderly farmers who continue to work a small tract despite a fortune gained through the sale of land, were beaten and robbed by a band of men who broke into their home here last night.
BOSTON, Jan. 24 -- The Massachusetts Milk Control Commission, up to its neck in controversy, was supported this week by the State Supreme Judicial Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A renewal of the battle for labor reform is at hand. Senator John F. Kennedy, Massachusetts Democrat, has reintroduced the old, political war-scarred Kennedy-Ives bill with a few material changes, and the Administration's 1958 bill, with a few changes, will go to Congress in a couple of days.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 -- Charges of waste, inefficiency and labor corruption against Mexico's nationalized oil industry have drawn a bitter reaction from a union leader.

PERHAPS Hollywood's constructive influence on humorous fiction is not a fit subject as yet for a doctorate thesis, but in the case of Richard Powell's amusing second novel, some acknowledgment on the grade-school or "Drive-In" theatre level seems in order.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -Three thousand music lovers joined tonight in celebrating the 102d anniversary of the Academy of Music.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24 -- One of the few "name" show dogs entered in the Maryland Kennel Club's forty-sixth event that began today was the Afghan, Ch. Shirkhan of Grandeur. The 4 1/2-year-old silver blue dog won handsomely in the breed for the owners. Sunny Shay and Dorothy Chenade of Hicksville, L. I. He was distinguished because he had taken best in show at Westminster the winter before last.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- A Soviet woman astronomer who has been touring the United States said today that she was going home with information that American husbands helped their wives with the dishes.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 -- Sports Car Club of America delegates to the national convention here got down to business today. New and liberal rules, relaxing the old restrictions were submitted by the Contest Board and a expanded schedules for racing and rallying were approved.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24 -- Military repression of labor's general strike this week puts President Arturo Frondizi and the unions face to face with the failure of a policy to create labor peace in Argentina.

SINCE Ed Lacy won the Mystery Writers of America's Edgar award for Best Novel of 1957 with his exciting "Room to Swing" (now available in a Pyramid reprint, 35 cents), he has published only one minor novel hardly meriting his byline.

SOMERSET MAUGHAM is 85, and he has decided that at last it is time to go out of business as a writer. "I am a free man and a member of the unemployed," he told Aneurin Bevan, the British Socialist leader, on television not long ago. "You ought to be sympathetic to me." "Yes," said Mr. Bevan, "the well-upholstered unemployed."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- The shift in treatment of the mentally ill and retarded has created a great demand for more social workers, it was said here today.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians today traded Earl Averill Jr., 28-year-old rookie third baseman, to the Chicago Cubs for an outfielder, Jim Bolger, and a right-handed pitcher, Johnny Briggs.
Two auction sales this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries will bring to market antiquities, Gothic and Renaissance art and English period furniture and decorations.

The cornerstone for the first unit of a $2,500,000 cathedral and headquarters center for the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America was blessed and dedicated yesterday by Archbishop Sion Manougian. He is the newly elected Primate of the Diocese.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 24 -- Abdel Salam Arif, No. 2 man in the revolt that overthrew the pro-Western Iraqi monarchy last July, has been tried and convicted of treason, it was announced today.
Lenox Hill Hospital will benefit from the proceeds of the second annual "Neighborhood Dinner Dance," to be held Feb. 5 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

TOLEDO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A United States swimming team captured thirty-seven of fifty events today to defeat a Canadian squad at the Glass City Auditorium in the sixth annual Canadian - American all - star meet.

Industrial activity is recovering vigorously. So far in 1959 predictions that there would be a steady rise appear to have been borne out. The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity at the end of the third week in the New Year has reached a record level with a combined index of 216.7 indicating a strong renewal of the upward progress recorded before the year-end holidays.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The two favorites Alex Olmedo of Los Angeles and Neale Fraser of Australia, will meet Monday for the Australian national tennis championship. The big question is whether Olmedo can hold out for one more day.

Using a light, deft stroke, Henri Salaun gained the semifinals of the Harry Cowles squash racquets tourney yesterday. Before a capacity gallery at the Harvard Club, the game's national champion moved through two matches with ease.

A blanket of snow and zero temperatures kept shoppers away from the stores last week. Sales still showed a small gain over the 1958 period, which also had severe weather conditions. THE Ware Collection of glass flowers at Harvard University's Botanical Museum in Cambridge, Mass., attracts more than a third of a million visitors a year. To gardeners and botany students the life-sized glass flowers are not only beautiful, but an excellent teaching device.

Nonagricultural employment in Illinois at the end of 1958 was 147,200 lower than at the end of 1957, the State Employment Service reported. Employment in December totaled 3,354,800 in 1958 compared with 3,502,000 the year before.
Trustees of Cornell University authorized yesterday the construction of a library of modern design on the campus at Ithaca, N. Y.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has informed a meeting of electric utility executives that it is prepared to develop, design and manufacture the equipment for a giant nuclear power plant of 330,000 kilowatts. The plant would be of an advanced pressurized water reactor design -- the type that has been carried to the most advanced state of development in the nation's civilian atomic power program.

MY wife and I have just returned from a grand-tour "free" trip by air. I had won two tickets from New York to Rio de Janeiro and back in a television puzzle program. Casting up accounts on our return, I noted something that has caused me to put quotation marks around that adjective in front of the word "free" in the first sentence.

TOWARD the end of May there will be a free concert in an unusual section of Central Park. It will be around the Bethesda Fountain. If Robert Moses can be cajoled into giving permission, there will be fireworks exploding over the lake at 72nd Street.
The police concentrated in three areas of the city yesterday their search for an infant kidnapped when he was twenty-three days old.
