BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 -- C. Ross Hamilton Jr., of Reading, Pa., took a second look at the Afghan, Ch. Shirkhan of Grandeur, tonight and decided he was a better dog than he was the first time.

ON June 5, 1916, Horatio Herbert Kitchener drowned in the North Sea when the cruiser that was taking him to Russia struck a German mine. The victor of Omdurman and avenger of Gordon was not quite 66 years old, the idol of the British people for whom he symbolized military distinction and selfless patriotism.

A FORMER network president, a critic and a producer examined the present state of television last night. Their discussion, on "Open End" over Channel 13, was authoritative and intelligent, although its appeal often was limited to representatives of the broadcasting industry, sponsors and advertising agencies rather than to the average viewer.
The announcement of Pope John's intention to call a council for church unity was welcomed yesterday by Protestant and Christian Orthodox leaders. But there was a note of caution in their comments.
MADRID, Jan. 25 -- Alberto Ullastres, Minister of Commerce, declared here tonight that there would be no devaluation of the Spanish peseta.

MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., beat Sweden's Birger Folke today for the Coral Gables-University of Miami men's singles tennis title. The scores were 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.
Activity held up last week in the steamship charter market, but rates again slid slightly, forcing another drop in the freight rate index.
Jet passenger service across the nation began yesterday with a record flight from Los Angeles to New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina appealed to United States investors today for help in developing his country's basic industries, especially hydroelectric power and steel and iron.
The action of Schenley Industries, Inc., in setting up its own subsidiary to handle outdoor and transit advertising has caused considerable interest and concern in the advertising industry.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 25 -- As foreshadowed a week ago, the Netherlands Bank reduced the bank rate by 1/4 to 2 3/4 per cent, compared with 5 per cent early last year.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- A rookie, Les Colwill, scored twice with his team short-handed tonight and paced the New York Rangers to an 8-3 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at the Garden.

MADRAS, India, Jan. 25 (Reuters) -- India, 398 runs behind with seven second-innings wickets left, faces an apparently hopeless struggle against the West Indies on the final day of the fourth test match Monday. Even a draw would clinch the series for the West Indies.

The New York Times published on Jan. 16 an announcement from the State Education Commissioner, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., that seventy additional Regents college teaching fellowships had been awarded in New York State. It is to be noted that thirty-eight of these awards were won by graduates of the municipal colleges.
The American Jewish Committee charged yesterday that widespread discrimination against minority groups in New York's middle-income housing was depriving the city of much-needed tax revenue.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- The tempo of steel ordering was faster last week. More of the same is expected this week. Demand has increased among auto makers and miscellaneous users. The latter, however, are not ordering as far ahead as are auto makers.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Fifteen-year-old Chris von Saltza broke three more of her American women's short-course swimming records at an exhibition in the San Jose State College pool tonight. The program had been approved by the Amateur Athletic Union.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The bicentenary of the birth of Robert Burns, the Scots poet, was celebrated here today with the laying of wreaths at the Poet's Corner in Westminster Abbey and at the Burns statue at Victoria Embankment Gardens.

Americans were described here yesterday as persons whose "thinking has bogged down," whose schools "have become hot-dog stands at which students play an academic hoopla game," and who derive serenity from "tranquilizers, books by various swamis and counting sheep."

CAIRO, Jan. 25 -- The Egyptian Foreign Ministry gave its answer today to the British request to diplomatic status for the mission that will put into effect here the financial agreement initialed Jan. 16. Egypt is reported to have acceded in part to the British request.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 25 -- The police recovered fifty bodies today from the wreckage of a motion-picture theatre in Kucuk Yali that collapsed last night.

Until statistics are available proving otherwise, it would seem that the current winter is a rather poor one for colds. A casual sampling of data about the neighborhood appears to show a subnormal number of sneezes, less denunciation of doctors for their inability to do something about it.
The 12,000-deadweight-ton Muneshima Maru, latest addition to the fleet of the Iino Line (Iino Kaiun Kaisha, Ltd.), will start the return leg of her maiden voyage from Japan on Feb. 6.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 25 -- Calls for national unity and for support of the Government of President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes were made today by independent newspapers and political parties in the crisis arising from Mexico's breaking off of diplomatic relations with Guatemala Friday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 25-- Representatives of the Baghdad Pact powers assembled here today for the sixth session of the alliance's Ministerial Council, opening tomorrow.

THERE was rejoicing by his legion of friends recently when Bucky Harris was named the general manager of the Boston Red Sox. Bucky's wanderings seem over because he's now anchored in one of baseball's most attractive spots, backed by the wealth, generosity and understanding of the club's owner, Tom Yawkey.
OTTO LAUREN NELSON Jr. is a busy man. His activities are so varied that when he is asked to number them, he smiles and says, "I don't know, offhand."
Oldsmobile will discontinue the Patti Page show on the American Broadcasting Company TV network in March and become the sponsor of a new series to be televised by the National Broadcasting Company.
BOSTON, Jan. 25 -- The public does not have "the right to know everything about everybody," Richard Cardinal Cushing told a group of newspaper men today.

ONE of Marion Stevenson Patmore's favorite pastimes is curling up with a good book. A good cookbook, to be exact. She reads volumes on food with the same relish and enthusiasm that most people reserve for mystery stories.
Swollen waters overflowing the ice-choked Ohio River and its tributaries threatened more areas of five states where thousands already have seen left homeless, The Associated Press reported.
A late-comer in the small jet-engine field, the Pratt Whitney JT-12, has been ordered as the power plant for the first production models of the ten-passenger Lockheed JetStar.
Scheduled to be shown on the screen of Williston Academy's luxurious new auditorium later this semester is the motion picture, "The Bridge on the River Kwai."
PALM SPRINGS, Cal., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., fired a 9-underpar 62 to capture the $15,000 Thunderbird invitation golf tournament today.
One-year returns on mutual funds do not give a true picture of their value as an investment medium.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Chicago Black Hawks tonight for the first time this season. The 4-1 game was marked by the splendid play of Ed Chadwick, the Leaf's goalie.
An improved West Side IRT subway line -- modernized in the last two years under a $100,000,000 rebuilding program -- will go into operation Feb. 6.

SAUSALITO, Calif., Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Sterling Hayden said in a letter made public today he was taking his four children on a voyage to Tahiti in defiance of a court order so he could give up his old life of making "trashy" movies and still be the "guiding force" in their lives.
In its first venture into home decorating, Saks Fifth Avenue is aiming for the largest potential in clientele -- babies.

A MONTH or so ago, a downtown waterfront beachcomber saw a large white tomcat foraging on an old pier. When he caught the cat he found, hidden in his neckfur, a broken identification tag. There had been a ship's name on it, but not enough was left for clue.
The Pope's declared intention to convoke an ecumenical, or general, council of the Roman Catholic Church may mark a major milestone in the modern history of Christendom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Development of improved yttrium metal that may be the answer to difficult problems in the design of atomic reactors and missiles was announced today by the Department of Interior.
Auburn, the nation's only undefeated major college basketball team, is playing just for the record.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Congress appeared likely today to be preoccupied next week with military matters. They will include the start of a full-scale review Of the nation's missile program.
Henri Salaun of Boston owns one of the keenest touches in squash racquets. His skill with the racquet has provided a continued source of admiration for followers of the sport.
The fate of 15,000,000 refugees over the world is an American problem whether they come to our shores or not, according to the chairman of the newly organized United States Committee for Refugees.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- Communist leaders from various parts of the world are gathering in Moscow for the second time in fourteen months to assess the Communist movement's international standing and to hail Soviet successes and plans for the future.
Max Pollikoff's "Music in Our Time" concert Saturday night at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association was a judicious combination of new works and repeats.
The International General Electric Company (India), Ltd., has received orders from India's biggest steel producers for seventy-five diesel-electric industrial haulage locomotives.
Lack of money is the "only objection" the Port of New York Authority has to taking over control of commuter rail transportation in the metropolitan area, Austin J. Tobin said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Nearly all trade considerations in the grain futures market favored the bullish side last week, and price gains were the broadest and most uniform in more than two months.
The proportion of the country's population holding down jobs today is the same as it was in 1890.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 25 -- Fidel Castro said in an interview here today that the United States would have to change its attitude toward Cuba before better understanding could be reached between the two countries.
ROME, Jan. 25 -- Many of the best-informed Western diplomatic sources on Africa are startled, confused and uneasy over the rate at which nationalism is transforming the heart of the continent.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- A thirteen-member "task force" to stimulate private investment in middle-income housing was announced today by Governor Rockefeller.
The need of Roman Catholics for spiritual reading was stressed yesterday in the sermon at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 25 -- Francis Neilson, author and a former member of the British Parliament, spent a quiet afternoon with friends in a reflective birthday celebration here today. He will be 92 years old tomorrow.
" Fifth morning" rail service for coast-to-coast freight shipments has been instituted by forwarding companies, Morris Forgash, president of the United States Freight Company, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- An indication of the inquiring mind of Alexander Hamilton, first Secretary of the Treasury, is revealed in a just-discovered letter in his own fine handwriting.
A 14-year-old boy proudly displayed a jewel box yesterday that he had made for the ninth annual handicraft exhibition of the Catholic Youth Organization of New York.

The United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union has taken a step that confounds commonly accepted ideas about labor's place in the economic scheme of things. The union has bought a controlling interest in the Merrimac Hat Corporation of Amesbury, Mass., whose employes are all union members, and has appointed its own officers to six of the nine places on the company's board of directors.
Tens of thousands of complaints about building-code violations have not been followed up because of inadequate enforcement machinery, the New York Times Youth Forum was told yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet Government emphasized today that the withdrawal of Western troops from West Berlin was an essential element in East-West negotiations on a settlement of the crisis over that city.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- The 1959 convention of the Sports Car Club of America ended here today on a note of harmony.

Roy Campanella, the former catcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers, received the Citizen of the Year award from the Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith at the group's eighth annual awards dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt last night.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 25 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen said tonight the Soviet Union had not demanded anything of Finland that would endanger her relations with the West.

Howard Stores Corporation, a seventy-two unit men's and boys' clothing store chain, announced over the week-end the election of five directors. Two head a group who have "agreed in principle" on the terms for acquisition of a substantial number of shares of Howard stock.
A rocket fired eighty-six miles into the sky over the Atlantic Ocean has produced a photograph that constitutes a new type of weather map of that region.

A program proposing greatly increased Federal aid to housing was made public by Mayor Wagner yesterday. It will be presented to the Banking and Currency Committee of the Senate at a public hearing in Washington today.
PARIS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Jamin, the 11-10 favorite, put on a strong stretch drive and won the $40,500 Prix d'Amerique trot today at Vincennes race track. Two American entries finished out of the money.
The Metropolitan Regional Council -- a voluntary body for analyzing the problems and planning the growth of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut -- was urged yesterday to seek official status now.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- One of the leaders among the state chief justices who criticized the United States Supreme Court last year for overriding precedents has just been overruled by the judges of his own court on the question of precedents.
Verdi's "Macbeth" will be presented for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera Thursday evening, Feb. 5, in a benefit performance sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild for the Production Fund.
Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division here declared yesterday that if the Legislature failed to approve court reform this year he thought it "lost for this generation."
" How to be in the world, but not of it or from it," was the question raised yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Leslie E. Cooke at Riverside Church. The title of the sermon was "No Static Faith."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit won the Helen Lee Doherty amateur golf tournament, 2 up, today after staying off a rally by Joanne Goodwin, the 1956 winner.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves today hired John McHale, the general manager of the Detroit Tigers for the past three years, as general manager and vice president of the Braves.
In one of his many philosophical moments Ralph Waldo Emerson described an institution as being the lengthened shadow of one man.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Advocates of economy in Government are resorting once again to the analogy between the Federal budget and the family budget.

An abridgement, of Sir Winston Churchill's six-volume "The Second World War" will be issued Feb. 19 by Houghton Mifflin. Now called "Memoirs of the Second World War," the volume contains an epilogue by the' author on the postwar years.

When General Ayub took over sweeping powers in Pakistan last October, assumed the Presidency and set aside the previous constitutional structures for the time being, it was remarked here that his action would ultimately have to be judged by the use to which he put those powers. He has now set into operation one of the sweeping reforms that he promised, a drastic revision of the land tenure system.
The New York Foundation has granted $250,000 more to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the center announced yesterday.
The backlog of pending local government borrowing was swelled by $129,585,000 by announcements of fourteen new bond issues over the weekend.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- The American Council for Judaism called on American Jews today to re-examine their affiliation with those Jewish groups that tend to "limit the individual status of the American Jew and the voluntary character of his identification with his religion."

Cotton futures prices showed mixed tendencies last week, but closed with all deliveries in higher ground. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange finished with gains of 50 cents to $2.60 a bale.
Protestant and Eastern Orthodox leaders emphasized yesterday that any effort to reunite the Christian churches must be a cooperative venture.

THE craze for things oriental, which has swept through fashions and furniture recently, has left its mark on the nation's cuisine. Within the last year, no less than a dozen restaurants that specialize in Chinese or other Far Eastern cuisine have opened here.
Delivery was made yesterday of the first issue of New York State local government bonds to carry a warranty by lawyers about the constitutionality of the borrowing.
HOOFBEATS and six-shooters were silenced for one hour last night on Channel 4 as two Western shows were canceled to make way for a scientific program.
CAIRO, Jan. 26 -- The Ministry of Education closed three Roman Catholic schools today.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) last year had consolidated net profits of $564,000,000, or $2.73 a share based on the average number outstanding during the year, Eugene Holman. chairman, estimated yesterday. Consolidated earnings for 1957 were $805,000.000. or $4.08 a share.

THE bearded bard of Ayot Saint Lawrence, draped on the hand of a puppeteer and bobbing a wooden head with gleaming eyes, made a splenetic appearance last night on the stage of Theatre East, where he found himself in mixed company.

It may not really be the "Baghdad" Pact any more, since Iraq is not represented at the Ministerial Council meetings that have opened in Karachi. Iraq has not made a formal withdrawal from the alliance but is, to say the least, an unusually silent partner. In the beginning it was felt that Iraq's defection would spell the end of the "northern tier" alliance as an active instrument of policy.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The Assembly, by a 139-to-2 vote, passed a bill tonight that would provide five more racing days for horseplayers and make an extra $1,100,000 for the State.

With respect to the views of Alfred Baker Lewis published Jan. 10 favoring racially unsegregated education, the educational problem in the South and elsewhere may be largely and more beneficially disposed of by simply resorting to segregation by sex instead of color.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 26 -- Justice Minister Hong Chin Ki said today that blood might flow in the streets of Seoul if President Syngman Rhee's Government permitted mass outdoor rallies against the controversial National Security Law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A special analysis in President Eisenhower's economic report last Tuesday revealed that prices with the exception of those for machinery and other "producers' durable" goods, had risen less in the United States in the last five years than in the industrial nations of Europe.

THE height of refinement in the Japanese woodcut was reached when artists discovered the beauty of embossed paper free of ink. Now, Josef Albers, whose geometric color sorcery is well known, takes the embossing, or "gauffrage," technique one step further.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur observed his seventy-ninth birthday yesterday. He was the guest of honor at a birthday party at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and received telegraphed greetings there from President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for an examination of charges that a National Broadcasting Company television station had unfairly promoted the products of N. B. C.'s parent company, the Radio Corporation of America.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (Tuesday) (AP) -- The International Tin Council said today Russia had agreed to limit tin exports outside the Iron Curtain to 13,500 tons in 1959.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Four heads of Britain's East African territories conferred with Colonial Office chiefs here over the week-end on the nationalist agitation that is sweeping Africa.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- A complete forgiveness of state taxes due April 15 on 1958 incomes was reported to have been proposed seriously today at a top-level Republican conference with Governor Rockefeller.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 26 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. was reported preparing today a two-point plan to propose to the school-crisis session of the legislature.
The National Association of Manufacturers chided Edward R. Murrow yesterday for implying that big business employed prostitutes as a matter of policy.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The shooting of Carl Switzer, a film actor, during a fight over $50 was justifiable homicide, a coroner's jury ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that a union could use "harassing tactics" during contract negotiations as a means of forcing an employer to yield to its demands.

TRENTON, Jan. 26 -- The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill that will permit Camden County to erect a massive stadium in its bid to induce the Phillies to cross the Delaware.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen began today intensive consultations on the deterioration of United States-Philippine relations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The populous Delaware River area had $57,000,000,000 in personal income in 1957, or 17 per cent of the national total, the Commerce Department reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Piittsburgh Steel Company and Sharon Steel Corporation are considering a merger. Pittsburgh Steel made the announcement today, declaring: "The officers of Pittsburgh Steel Company and Sharon Steel Corporation have been studying the possibility of a merger.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced plans yesterday to build the world's first plant to produce the Firestone-developed synthetic rubbers, Diene and Coral.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Almost all share groups continued to decline in the stock market today. Prices proved sensitive to further profit-taking in the absence of demand.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 26 -- Federal Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. freed former state Judge George C. Wallace today of charges of criminal contempt of court in a civil rights case.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev said tonight that there was a possibility of a "thaw" in East-West relations.
The Transit Authority is exploring the possibility of operating trains without motormen or conductors throughout the rapid transit system.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 -- The State Senate approved today the creation of a state agency to keep rapid-transit facilities operating until a long-term solution to the commuter problem can be found.

The Society of Stage Directors is being formed to guard the welfare of directors as well as choreographers. Such protection is considered necessary for the hitherto unorganized groups despite the fact that skilled members in each division are able to command their own fees.
Trying desperately to avoid an increase in the 15-cent fare, the New York City Transit Authority is re-examining its revenue and cost structure and has found some inequities long embedded in custom.
SPECIAL fashion dash for winter wardrobes can be in a bright pullover, an open-faced jacket or anything colorful and gay that enlivens a costume.

There is a rumor around high school locker rooms that the surest way to receive basketball scholarships to college is to play fast and hard when Bill Sachs is watching. Sachs doesn't deny this, but he says that any 7-footer can get a scholarship without his help.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26--A jury of eight men and four women was chosen today to hear evidence in the Powell sedition trial. The often-postponed case had its origin in the Korean war.

History sometimes acts like a tide, with the same irresistible sweep, and those who try to stop it are like King Canute. The wave of demands for independence in Africa has that same implacable impetus. One has the impression that nothing will stop it.

On the upbeat for the last six months or so, the common shares of American Motors Corporation have made music for their owners -- the jingling of profits in their pockets. Last year the shares showed the sharpest rise of any on the Big Board.
New Yorkers will be asked to give $6.000.000 to the Greater New York Red Cross drive, opening March 1.
Mayor Wagner appointed a thirty-member citizens committee yesterday to interpret the West Side renewal program to the community.

Charlotte, N.C., revised yesterday the terms of a proposed market borrowing to finance municipal improvements. It is now planned to take bids March 3 on issues totaling $5,785,000. The proposed borrowing was $4,250,000 when first announced.

Three networks currently negotiating new contracts with the American Federation of Musicians are seeking a cutback in the number of musicians they are now required to maintain on staff in various cities.

Three Amherst student editors sent 1,000 copies of their college newspaper to the University of Moscow yesterday in an effort to create better understanding between the United States and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Operators of the major United States airports told Congress today that the nation's air transportation system could bog down unless more Federal funds were provided for airport facilities.

"The Art of Animation." Walt Disney's retrospective exhibition tracing drawing and animation from the Stone Age through current Disney film-cartoon techniques, will start a month's stand tomorrow at Stern's forty-second Street department store.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- An implied warning that may endanger the passage of a comprehensive court reform law this year was sounded in the Senate tonight.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 26 -- The West German Government is making a painstaking study of the Soviet proposal for a confederation of the two German states to see whether some elements of the plan might be brought to serve the objective of a free united Germany.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, made a sharp recovery in the final quarter of 1958 but earnings for the year were almost $20,000,000 below those of 1957.
MADRAS, India, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -- The West Indies clinched the five-match cricket test series, beating India by 295 runs in the fourth match today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- Adlai E. Stevenson demanded today the restoration of stress on teaching teachers the solid content of educational subjects instead of the techniques of teaching.

It is unfortunate that Pearl Buck, who is a good Christian and who has devoted so much of her life to the Orient and its peoples, would make such unfounded statements about the Korean orphans and President Syngman Rhee's attitude toward them as were reported in the Jan. 7 issue of The Times.
An effort will be made this afternoon to head off a possible work stoppage of harbor tug-boat workers at midnight Saturday.
A record crowd of 21,240 was on hand for the wrestling show of the year at Madison Square Garden last night. An estimated 10,000 fans were turned away at the box office.

The Fire Department announced yesterday that its inspectors who are checking all hospitals in the city found 351 fire violations Thursday and Friday. In addition 261 violations of rules of other city departments were uncovered.
A mobile hospital contained in 135 packing cases was assembled in one hour yesterday during a civil defense training exercise at Teachers College, Columbia University.
Snow flecked Manhattan and made some suburban roads slippery. The snowfall began about 9 P. M. and by 2 A. M. totaled more than a half inch at the Battery. The temperature at 2 A. M. was 28 degrees.
VERSAILLES, Ky., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A private plane crashed in flames in isolated country near here tonight, killing four men.
The twenty-eight annual Loyola luncheon, bridge party and fashion show will be given for the benefit of the Loyola School and Jesuit Seminary Fund on March 5 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Charles Lassueuer, Swiss pianist, made his appearance in a recital at Town Hall last night. A native of Lausanne, Mr. Lassueuer was trained at the Conservatory there and studied in Paris with Isidor Philipp. Since then he has combined teaching at the Lausanne Conservatory with an active career as soloist.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Jan. 26 -- The constitutionality of the morning prayer in the public schools will be tested in the State Supreme Court in Mineola next month.
An enormous rocket engine capable of putting a five-ton television relay station in orbit will probably ready for flights before 1962.
The assistant manager of Birdland, a basement night club at 1678 Broadway, was stabbed fatally in the chest early yesterday morning.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UPI) -Robert Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, said today the United States was ready to guarantee the Soviet Union against attack from a reunited Germany.

A formula for moon-shot trajectories so accurate that the moon theoretically might be hit within one mile of the exact destination of missiles has been worked out by scientists of the Republic Aviation Corporation.

The Anaconda Company announced yesterday the appointment of John B. Knaebel as president and managing director of Anaconda Iron Ore (Ontario), Ltd. That concern is a subsidiary of the Anaconda Company (Canada), Ltd., which in turn is a subsidiary of the Anaconda Company.

Floods in the Midwest reduced the nation's steel production last week. but output this week was scheduled at the highest level since the week that began on June 10, 1957, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, reported yesterday that its net income for 1958 had dropped to $61,921,680, equal to $3.96 a common share, from $85,014,422, or $5.45 a share, in 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas protested today the Supreme Court was not giving citizens the protection due them against unlawful search and seizure by the police.
The role of kitchen gadgets -- both traditional and improvised -- in helping a paralyzed housewife run her home from a wheel chair was shown here yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The State Education Commissioner announced today the appointment of a twelve-member advisory council on adult education.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 26 -- The Baghdad Pact Council met here today in search of a program that would re-establish confidence and security in the troubled Middle East.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Some patients once considered in the last stages of cancer still are alive, three years after receiving serum from horses inoculated with their type of malignancy, a Canadian doctor said today.
Measures being taken to avoid the entrapment of a community under a radioactive smog were described yesterday to the American Meteorological Society.
Three more Buildings Department inspectors were accused yesterday of failing to report structural defects in a West Side tenement shut by Fire Department inspectors Jan. 14 as a "menace to life."
BRIGANTINE, N. J., Jan. 26 (AP)--This community's beached whale died tonight in the pounding surf. Five minutes later a truck from the New York Aquarium arrived.
ADELAIDE, Jan. 26 (AP) -Alex Olmedo stood on the threshold of tennis greatness today, a tired and aching champion looking for no new worlds to conquer. All he wants is peace and rest.
The Soviet Union's leading Communist novelist has published a denunciation of Soviet officials' preoccupation with setting world sports records.
LEMONT, Ill., Jan. 26 -- Dr. John H. Roberson, manager of the Dayton area office of the Atomic Energy Commission, was named executive director of Associated Midwest Universities today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Two House members said today that they would press for an investigation of Congress's own watch-dog on Government spending -- Controller General Joseph Campbell.

One of the things that can happen only once took place yesterday at Juneau, Alaska. This was the opening of the first State Legislature of our newest commonwealth. It was fitting that the President of the first Alaska Senate should be an Eskimo, William E. Beltz. Alaska has many Eskimos in the north and northwest, Aleuts in the Aleutian Islands and elsewhere and Indians mostly in the southeast.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Rick Ferrell, one of baseball's great catchers, today was named temporary general manager of the Detroit Tigers.
The proposal of City Council Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey for local referendums to decide on legalizing off-track betting on horse races was, in eff rejected yesterday by Ma Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Arts Club of Washington appealed today for the return of four bronze gongs taken from the Indonesian Embassy's Gamelan Orchestra at a dress ball Jan, 16.

"PIONEER, GO HOME!"* by Richard Powell is one of the most affable tales of liberty without license that has appeared since "You Can't Take It With You." It is rich in familiar comic situations seasoned with a certain measure of invention. And it preaches the doctrine, most soothing when considered vicariously, that the best things in life are free.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 26 -- One of the most enthusiastic receptions ever given to an Australian performance was accorded by Saturday night's audience at the opening here of "My Fair Lady."
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- A French military spokesman in Algiers announced tonight casualty figures for operations last week that indicated some of the heaviest fighting of the Algerian war.
ROME, Jan. 26 -- The first response abroad to the decision by Pope John XXIII to call an ecumenical council in quest of Christian unity was "encouraging," Roman Catholic chmen here said today.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 26 -- A plan for "re-evaluating Westchester's thinking" about its parkways was submitted to the Board of Supervisors today. The board would assemble facts to justify the retention of the parkways as local toll roads under county control.

JOHN QUINN signed a five-year contract not long ago as vice president and general manager of the Phillies. Such signings are considered routine these days and yet this one had a certain historic significance. For the better part of a half century big league baseball has had a Quinn in a top executive position.

A plan for the development of Suffolk County, including mono-rail transportation and a jet plane terminal at MacArthur Airport, was outlined yesterday at Pratt Institute's School of Architecture in Brooklyn.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 -- The Buick division of the General Motors Corporation announced in Flint today that it would lay off about 2,000 workers this week to gear output to sales.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Defense Department told Congress today the draft law must be extended to prevent a dangerous drop in enlistments.

Directors of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company recommended a two-for-one split of the Class B common stock yesterday. The move is subject to approval by shareholders at the annual meeting in Jersey City on April 8. One of the "Big Three" tobacco manufacturers, the company's Camel cigarette is reportedly the largest seller in the field.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TORONTO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- International Nickel Company (Inco) of Canada today stepped up production of nickel-copper ores.
The threat of a strike against a large segment of the city's baking industry was disclosed yesterday by Louis Yagoda, district director of the State Mediation Board.

GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- The United States and Britain offered the Soviet Union today strong guarantees for impartial international control of a ban on tests of nuclear weapons. David Ormsby-Gore of Britain presented the Western plan for staffing the control posts of an international inspection system.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Yugoslavia's agricultural and other economic policies were attacked by Pravda today as having "isolated" that country from the "commonwealth of Socialist countries."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower invited a number of Republican Senators and Representatives today to a series of White House breakfast meetings to enlist their support of his legislative program.
The nation's electric utilities reported yesterday new highs in most phases of power production, but the highs generally ran slightly below predictions made last October.
If Stefan Redl had his way, he would fight only at the St. Nicholas Arena. He has yet to be defeated there.
ROME, Jan. 26 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani and his Cabinet resigned today, giving rise to a Government crisis whose solution appears to be difficult.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- By mid-1961 the Defense Department expects to use satellites to relay messages around the world, thus ushering in a new era in global communications.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The State Department believes the negotiations in Geneva have reached "a critical point," with the outcome dependent on the Soviet attitude toward international inspection.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 26 -- An Israeli soldier who wandered near the edge of No Man's Land in the center of Jerusalem was shot dead this afternoon by Jordanian legionnaires.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 26 -- Foreign Minister Joseph M. A. Luns is scheduled to discuss the "Molotov mystery" at a closed session of a committee of Parliament here Wednesday.

An investment group, sponsored by the United Investors Syndicate, Inc., has purchased the five-acre Windsor Park shopping center, in Bayside, Queens, according to Harry Seeve, president of United Investors.
Thomas Fitzpatrick, the New Jersey steamfitter with the propensity for landing planes in New York City streets, landed in jail for six months yesterday.
Twelve years ago collegiate bowlers in the metropolitan area took steps to place the sport on a level with other varsity sports.

A defense of Madision Avenue, its men and mores, has been written by Fred B. Manchee entitled "The Huckster's Revenge." It will be published by Thomas Nelson on Feb. 6, the beginning of National Advertising Week.
The city has about 2,000 negligence claims and court actions pending against it, a record in the city's history.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller was an interested spectator tonight as the Senate confirmed forty-four of his nominations for state offices.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 26 -- His friends call it determination and his enemies stubbornness, but all agree that "the fighting little judge" of Barbour County is a competitor who seldom gives up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Treasury bill rate fell a little for ninety-one-day bills and rose a little for 182-day bills this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,400,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 2.975 per cent, compared with 3.035 per cent last week, and that for $400,000,000 of 182-day bills was 3.337 per cent compared with 3.233 per cent.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 -- Tribal chieftains from remote northeastern frontier areas came to town today to celebrate the ninth anniversary of India's independence and they appeared to be having the time of their lives.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The Democratic State Chairman furnished today a description of his party's 1960 Presidential nominee that would eliminate Adlai E. Stevenson and Averell Harriman as contenders.

Home buying is a better defense against inflation than playing the stock market, a real estate analyst said yesterday. "The purchase of a single-family residence is the best inflation hedge that the average family can make," said Roy Wenzlick of St. Louis.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 26 -- President Francois Duvalier cut salaries of Government employes today for eight months starting Feb. 1. The cut had been expected because of the economic crisis here.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A move by William E. Bufalino, president of Teamsters Local 985, to transfer a five-million-dollar slander and libel suit against the counsel of the Senate Racket Committee was denied today in United States District Court.
IGNACE STRASFOGEL, who got his big chance last night at the Metropolitan opera, is a conductor who has waited in the wings a long time.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, said today that the new program of aid to under-developed countries would be used mainly to attract capital investments from other sources.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- F. Alden Gray, the racing director of Roosevelt Raceway, is here lining up the champion trotters of Europe for an international race planned by the Westbury (L. I.) track for opening day next Aug. 1.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Fifty-seven members of the House of Commons, about 9 per cent of the total, will retire from politics when Parliament is dissolved for the coming general election.

Impelled by the realization that modern economy demands larger units than the European national states, four Scandinavian countries have given new impetus to a long-standing project for a customs union and a common market of their own.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday said it was investigating a sudden sharp rise in the price of Borne Chemical Company common stock.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Texas Attorney General Will Wilson said today a temporary restraining order had been issued to stop Sinclair Oil Corporation and Texas Pacific Coal and Oil Company from merging.

The New York Central System reported yesterday earnings of $4,050,995 for 1958. This was less than half of the $8,423,078 cleared in 1957 and the smallest amount since 1946, when the company sustained a deficit of $10,449.000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Arthur S. Flemming, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the chief surprise he had encountered in putting the National Defense Education Act into operation was the large sum the colleges had requested in funds for students loans.
The speeches at the Communist party Congress opening in Moscow today may help influence the results of policy debates now going on in the United States, not least the discussion of the new budget.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The auto industry probably will build 550,000 cars this month, missing its original 590,000 goal because of curtailed output by Chrysler. A shortage of plate glass, cause by labor trouble at its supplier, has hampered Chrysler production.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Paris seems all set to give us two ways to look for spring. The spring and summer fashion collections got under way today with the showings of Pierre Cardin, Jean Patou and Jacques Heim, and two road signs to follow were clearly there.
Renato Bonacini, violinist, and Robert Conant, harpsichordist, gave the first of two joint recitals last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)--Wheat and soybean futures were steady to firm again today in fairly active dealings on The Board of Trade. Most demand shifted from the distant to the near-by contracts.
Mayor Wagner started a new kind of campaign yesterday. His object was to win for New York a June heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson, the champion, and Ingemar Johansson of Sweden.

Police and Federal Bureau of Investigations agents yesterday continued their search for 23-day-old John Tavarez. The baby was kidnapped last Thursday from the Tavarez home at 158 West Eighty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Chief of Naval Operations told Congress today that the Navy needed more fighting ships, aircraft carriers, planes and missiles if it were to meet the threat posed by Russia's 450 submarines and growing naval strength.
FURNISHING a two-room apartment for the first time does not necessarily mean mortgaging the future or resorting to a hodgepodge of miscellany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave tentative approval today to a profit-sharing plan adopted by six major airlines to cut losses during strikes.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 26 -- The new State of Alaska opened its first legislative session today with hour-long ceremonies in the old territorial capitol overlooking the Gastineau Channel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Walter Slezak will follow in his famous father's footsteps at the Metropolitan Opera next season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today he felt that he had done the right thing in warning against relying on Visan food supplement therapeutic "in the treatment of serious diseases such as cancer, cerebral palsy, diabetes, and heart trouble for which it was being recommended."
A United States council on foreign, economic and social policy to set goals for this country's effort in the "cold war" was proposed last night by Senator Jacob K. Javits.
HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- The court-martial of Capt. Pedro Morejon, the second of the officers of the former Batista army to be tried in Havana, began tonight at Camp Columbia, military headquarters.
THE curtain rises today on,. the nation's most famous fashion show.
MASSENA, N. Y., Jan. 26 (UPI) -- About 300 Mohawks demonstrated today against paying state income taxes.
A one-year collective bargaining agreement was signed yesterday by Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority with a union representing 600 bridge and tunnel employes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today that the Navy would start a school with Federal funds on the Norfolk, Va., base next month if public schools in Norfolk were not opened shortly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -Prompt Congressional approval of Hawaii as the fiftieth state was urged by the Administration today through Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior.
The machine tool industry, which makes the machines that make machines, finished the year with a powerful upward thrust.
A Valentine's Day Ball at the Brooklyn Museum will be a fund-raising event aimed at helping to wipe out the museum's deficit.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, laid down today a six-point banking law reform program that he said he would try to have passed in the new Congress.
ABOARD THE TOWBOAT A. D. HAYNES II ON THE MISSISSIPPI, Jan 26 -- Electronic depth-sounding machines have replaced the leadsmen who used to chant the marks for riverboats.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26 -- A possible key to a national peace formula in the internal war that has threatened to split the merged labor federation brought cheer to leaders of powerful craft unions in the building trades.

The Erie Railroad yesterday has found a buyer for its freight-forwarding subsidiary, the National Carloading Corporation. The purchaser is the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway, which acquired the business through its wholly-owned Chanslor-Western Oil and Development Company subsidiary.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- The Communists, who have operated as an underground party since 1952, are flexing their muscles in the democratic atmosphere of Cuba. They are attempting to gain control of labor and participate as a dominant force in the revolutionary government.
Newspaper advertising linage last year, hurt by the recession and the strike in December by deliverers in New York City, was 5.1 per cent lower than it was in 1957.
MANILA, Jan. 26 -- President Carlos P. Garcia addressed Congress today with a state of the nation message that minimized current differences with the United States.

The bottom of the East River was cluttered yesterday with seven railroad cars carrying wheat and coal. An unbalanced carfloat of the Lackawanna Railroad strewed half its load on the Manhattan side of the river between Grand Street and Fifteenth Street.
THE anatomy of a flop is not something to be written about; it can only be lived.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Universal-International has obtained motion-picture rights to "The Ugly American," a best-seller novel by William J. Lederer and Eugene Burdick.

Your excellent reviews of 1958 and prognostications concerning 1959 have fortunately been able to point out evidence of the return of this country's interest in Latin America. After ten long, lean years in Pan-American relations, the insults heaped on Mr. Nixon during his official visit to South America caused the Vice President as well as President Eisenhower and the country at large to give new attention to this subject.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The United States and Russia scored easy victories tonight and stayed unbeaten in the round-robin finals of the world amateur basketball championship.

The past few days have seen a great deal of speculation about what the Twenty-first Communist Party Congress opening in Moscow today will bring. The one real fact we know, however, is that the meeting has been called to adopt a final version of the Seven-Year Plan for 1959-65.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Orlando Cepeda, the National League's rookie of the year last season with the San Francisco Giants, was charged with assault and released in $500 bond today, then was fined $200 by the Puerto Rican League president as a result of a riot in yesterday's play-off game.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The Government strongly denied today that it was turning over control of Sahara oil riches to foreign concerns. The office of Jacques Soustelle, Minister delegate, issued a statement to Premier Michel Debre in response to rumblings of discontent in the French press and other circles over last week's deal between Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and two French concerns to exploit a new area in the Sahara in southeastern Algeria.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Sir John Cockcroft, one of Britain's most distinguished scientists, has been named the first head of Churchill College.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Colleges and universities appealed to Congress today for help in financing new building.

AT THIS time of year, honey is one of our most attractive and plentiful commodities. Most of that marketed in the United States is extracted or liquid honey; that is, honey that has been separated from the comb. As a rule, the lightest colored honey, such as s weet clover and alfalfa, is the mildest. Orange blossom honey has a delicate, distinctive flavor that makes it a general favorite.
Reuben Vargas is a gentle philosopher in a business that thrives on blood and violence. He tries to equate the economics of pummeling another human being with the admonition of the golden rule.
A blind news dealer who had a street-corner stand in downtown Brooklyn for twenty-nine years got a new stand yesterday in the warm corridor of Brooklyn's new Supreme Court Building.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Bob Turley, the fireballing pitching star of the world champion New York Yankees, today was named the winner of the ninth annual S. Rae Hickok "professional athlete of the year" award for 1958.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation has reported a profit after being in the red five years. In the last quarter of 1958 the automobile maker achieved a net of $3,700,000, the first profit since the final quarter of 1953. In the last quarter of 1957 the company had a deficit of $1,515,000.

Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was light in most markets. Copper, zinc, tin, hides and rubber rose; cocoa, potatoes and cottonseed oil declined, and price movements for sugar, coffee, wool and lead were mixed.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 26--The Rumanian Government is facilitating the emigration of Jews to Israel on an increased scale.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- As Western Europe faces the risks of its new regime of greater currency freedom, it watches closely the inflation in the United States. For this inflation may reduce the risks Europe assumed in moving toward convertibility of its monies in December.
Stuart Constable, executive officer of the Park Department, confessed yesterday to being a former vandal.

The nation's money managers should be spending less time protecting the value of the dollar and more time promoting economic growth, Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said here yesterday.
The 4,000 persons who work at United Nations Headquarters on Manhattan's East Side were without telephone connections to the outside world yesterday morning.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 26 -- A northeaster has just blown itself out and the anglers are sitting around the Pelican Hotel this evening grinding their teeth about what they are going to do to the sailfish and other species tomorrow.
A new type of airliner seat, designed for added safety in a crash, has been adopted by Sabena, Belgian World Airlines, for its Boeing 707 jets.
In a session dominated by motors, steels and oils, aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange declined about $1,100,000,000 yesterday.
The demand for physicists is booming again.

G. Russell Clark, executive manager of the American Bankers Association, will be named New York State Superintendent of Banks by Governor Rockefeller, it was learned yesterday. He was chief administrative officer in charge of operations and personnel of the banking association, which he joined in October, 1957.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Western reply to the latest Soviet note on Germany will propose a foreign ministers' conference in late April or early May but will adhere to established Allied policy, diplomatic sources preditced today.

Soviet scientific equipment to be used in the teaching of physics in the United States will go on display here today. The exhibit will be held in conjunction with meetings of the American Physical Society and the American Association of Physics Teachers at the New Yorker Hotel.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Stock market prices again retreated here today, influenced by yesterday's Wall Street weakness and some profit-taking at the end of the bookkeeping account.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Perry Jones, the 70-year-old captain of America's victorious Davis Cup team who has been chosen to handle the job again this year, indicated tonight he might not accept the assignment.
Anyone who has seen a Grand Prix race abroad, or the 500-mile race at Indianapolis, will tell you that these are the most exciting automobile events in the world.

One window, made of some 9,000 pieces of stained glass and longer than a football field, will color the front of American Airlines' new terminal at New York International Airport, at Idlewild, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate rackets committee heard today that a lieutenant of James R. Hoffa had made more money from trucking than the Teamsters Union had paid him to look after the drivers' interests.
DETROIT, Jan, 27 (UPI) -- Henry Ford 2d, president of Ford Motor Company, said today his company hoped to build a $15,000,000 assembly plant in Argentina for the manufacture of trucks and tractors.
Japanese two-man life rafts, shoe brushes from Britain, snakebite kits, or a fully automatic solar furnace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the Government's "Buy American" decision on a contract for two turbines was justified on its merits."

IF the women of New York City and its environs have felt a strange ringing in their ears the last day or two their difficulty is easily explained. On Monday night and yesterday morning, their powers, problems, pettinesses and perfections were talked about, turned inside out, taken apart and reassembled by five lively observers of the current scene.

Stocks opened weak yesterday as if they meant to continue the sell-off that closed Monday's session. Shortly before noon, however, confidence returned. Prices rose with hardly an interruption for the rest of the day and ended at about their highs.
Pierre Monteux, Jean Morel and Paul Paray will conduct the New York Philharmonic during the four-week period originally scheduled for Dimitri Mitropoulos.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that he thought the Soviet Union wanted to win the "cold war," not end it.
Gold, which has long captured men's minds, now may capture more of their dollars. Trading in small gold bars will start Feb. 3 on the Toronto Stock Exchange and they can be bought on margin.

Directors of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday subject to stockholders approval at the annual meeting May 12. If shareholders ratify the plan, directors indicated they would declare a quarterly dividend of 37 1/2 cents payable June 10 on the new shares.

Public health authorities yesterday thwarted the reunion of a Rye, N. Y., couple minutes after the husband arrived at the International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, with the 18-month-old German girl they will adopt.
Peter Ustinov's chances of portraying the role of Dr. Samuel Johnson in James Lee's version of his television play, "The Life of Samuel Johnson," appear more positive.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Marquess of Lansdowne today, rebuffed criticism of reporting by British diplomats abroad.
The Lord's Day Alliance of the United States praised business and labor yesterday for their interest in its program of keeping Sunday as a day of worship and rest.

The question of whether the port will have a full-fledged tugboat strike will not be answered until Sunday afternoon. At that time tugboat workers will vote on the "best and final wage offer" made by employers yesterday afternoon.
Net earnings of the John-Manville Corporation last year increased 23.3 per cent over those of 1957, despite a sales dip of 1.3 per cent, A. R. Fisher, chairman and president, announced yesterday.
The Administration's defense budget, now starting on its rocky road through Congress, provides for fewer numbers but more power.
February 26 has been chosen as the date of sale of $103,495,000 of serial public housing bonds by local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Adminisration.
A resolution in support of legalizing and taxing off-track betting on horse races was introduced into the City Council yesterday by Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey.

To save the 15-cent subway fare, the Transit Authority is considering ending or changing its cut-rate program for school children. The agency would prefer to have the Board of Education assume the burden of paying the $12,000,000 a year it costs to transport pupils at bargain fares.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev larded his lengthy report to the Soviet Communist party congress today with frequent wisecracks and quips.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the Chinese Nationalists were planning to withdraw some troops from Quemoy as the fire power of the island garrison was increased.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 28 -- Virtually the entire farm population of North Korea has been impressed into a system of huge "agricultural cooperatives" by the country's Communist rulers, a defector said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A group of Southern Senators proposed today a constitutional amendment that would give states exclusive power to decide whether their school systems should be integrated.
With the introduction of "Gounod Symphony" into its repertory, the New York City Ballet has completed its schedule of novelties and revivals for the season at the City Center.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A crippling telephone strike began today on top of a walkout by pilots that had paralyzed all major domestic and international service by Mexican lines since Friday.

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, declined yesterday to testify before a grand jury investigating the Brenner loan case, unless the panel granted him immunity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The improvement in employment during the May-December period of last year, often described as slow, was about the same as in the recovery from the recession in 1953 and 1954, the Department of Commerce said today.
Driving competition in the "American way of life" may be related to heart and artery diseases that are the major cause of death in the United States, it was suggested here yesterday.
The National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday its selection of Arthur Miller for the Gold Medal for Drama and of George Grosz for the Gold Medal for Graphic Art.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 27 -- Arthur T. Roth, president of the Franklin National Bank of Long Island, told stockholders today that the bank had spent about $60,000 in the last two years on his campaign for tax equality among financial institions.

The chances are slim that the projected coast-to-coast "jet" football conference of major independents will be formalized soon, if ever. This group would have Army, Navy, Pittsburgh, Penn State, Syracuse and Notre Dame as Eastern members.
The basketball game that just couldn't be lost was lost by the New York Knickerbockers last night at Madison Square Garden.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev proclaimed today that the Soviet successes in space rocketry had shifted the balance of world power to the Socialist camp and that economic successes would soon have a similar result.

ELMER ANDERSON CARTER's appointment as first Negro chairman of the state's anti-discrimination commission is not likely to be applauded either by hot-eyed integrationists or by stand-pat conservatives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Departments of Defense and State gave their approval today to the admission of Hawaii to the union.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 -- The Soviet Union's foreign economic policies are geared to its main goal of world domination, C. Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today.

Today's new film is "The Trap," a Paramount melodrama with Richard Widmark, Lee J. Cobb, Tina Louise and Earl Holliman, at the Capitol Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street. Norman Panama and Melvin Frank co-produced. Mr. Panama also directed and collaborated with Richard Alan Simmons on the scenario.

A PARISIAN painter, Dubuis makes a quietly effective debut at the Ruth White Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, with a group of oils, collages and pastels. His paintings are abstractions -- works in which form, color and surface are equally honored.
New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $183,000,000 will be offered to investors today.
ROME, Jan. 27 -- President Giovanni Gronchi moved today to solve the Cabinet crisis precipitated by the resignation yesterday of Premier Amintore Fanfani and his coalition Cabinet.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Ock Willoweit, a 55-year-old golf equipment salesman from Dayton, Ohio, shot a two-under-par 70 to lead the field in the first round of the Professional Golfers Association national senior championship today.
IN "Rashomon," which opened at the Music Box last evening, the materials of the theatre have been molded into strange and fascinating shapes.

Bill Rosensohn yesterday minimized the threat of a lawsuit that would prevent him from carrying out his plan to promote a heavyweight title bout this spring. It is Rosensohn's intention to pit Ingemar Johansson, the European champion, against Floyd Patterson, the world champion. He expects to sign the pair tomorrow.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 27 -- The Baghdad Pact Council wound up the main business of its sixth session today with a frank appraisal of the dangers to peace in the Middle East.

Joseph Profaci, a reputed Mafia leader, admitted yesterday that he attended the gangland meeting fourteen months ago at Apalachin, N. Y. But it was just by accident that he happened to be there, he said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Air Force officials told Congress today that the main threat to United States security was the Soviet Union's "formidable" intercontinental-range nuclear-armed missiles and aircraft.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Eisenhower will ask Congress tomorrow to legislate major reforms in the labor-management field.
TUNIS, Jan. 27 -- The Algerian Provisional Government declared "regretfully" today that it saw "no prospect for peace in Algeria" at present.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 27 -The leader of Moroccan Leftists announced tonight the formation of a "party of the masses" called the Democratic Istiqlal (Independence) party.

YONKERS, Jan. 27 -- A state plan for four broad new traffic corridors through this traffic-choked city received unanimous support tonight from the City Council. It has been tentatively approved by Westchester County officials.

The Monsanto Chemical Company had the best fourth quarter in its history, but earnings for all 1958 lagged behind those of 1957, according to a preliminary report yesterday of Charles Allen Thomas, president.
The rescue of two men who had been adrift eight days in a small dinghy was reported yesterday by the Dutch aircraft carrier Karel Doorman north-east of Bermuda.

Most of the controversial shipping flying "flags of convenience" match the highest construction standards in the world, Walter L. Green, chairman of the American Bureau of Shipping, declared yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- There is still a political Left and Right in France, at least in the National Assembly.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 27 (AP) -- A Navy seaplane, returning on one of its two engines from an exercise 200 miles at sea, plunged into Willoughby Bay early today. Four of the ten crew members lost their lives.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- High French financial officials said today they were fairly well pleased so far by the results of the "enormous gamble" taken in December. They alluded to the decision to devalue the franc and make it partly convertible.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 27 -- Princeton's controversial "bicker," the ten-day period in which upper-class eating clubs select sophomores for membership, will get under way tomorrow.

THE exhibition of late nineteenth and early twentieth-century French painting and sculpture owned by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pearlman, opening today at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, brilliantly illustrates one of the great creative periods in European art.
