SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Union gained undisputed possession of first place in the world basketball tournament tonight by trouncing Chile, 75 -- 49.
Robert R. Battipaglia, Queens Democratic leader, called on Borough President John T. (Pat) Clancy yesterday to "end the reign of terror at Borough Hall."
KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 27 -- A throne covered with leopard and hyena skins still symbolizes a particular problem of Uganda in the scheme of British East Africa.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan 27 -- Riots occurred in Florence today during a general strike proclaimed to protest against the eviction by the police of 400 sitdown strikers from the Galileo precision optical instruments factory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican of Manhattan, raised some eyebrows but won a round of applause in the House today by breaking an unwritten rule. The rule is that freshmen do not publicly challenge the statements of senior colleagues, particularly members of their own party.

Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers, former Deputy Commissioner of Buildings, testified yesterday for more than two hours before the New York County grand Jury investigating charges of graft and corruption in the department.

Reiko Hatsumi, a recipient of a Samuel Goldwyn literary award, whose prose has appeared in The New Yorker and Holiday, has written an account of her childhood in Japan. Called "Rain and the Feast of the Stark," it will be published Feb. 20 by Houghton Mifflin.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 27 (AP) -- A Federal judge removed today what appeared to be the last barrier to the operation of racially integrated public schools in Norfolk, Virginia's largest city.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon said last night that First Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan of the Soviet Union found the United States "overwhelmingly united" behind the Administration's foreign policy.

A new nonprofit fund announced yesterday that it would offer fellowships to high school teachers to attend summer college courses in journalism as part of a plan to rekindle job interest in the field.
The Guild and the Parents Guild of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest are sponsoring a benefit dance to be held in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East on April 3.
Charles E. Browers in his letter published Jan. 17 demands who are the Hungarians to complain about dictatorships when they did not lift a finger against their own under Admiral Horthy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Mervyn LeRoy, a leading director and producer of motion pictures, said today he was contemplating becoming active in the production of filmed series shows for television.
Noxzema Skin Lotion, a new product, will be distributed nationally with the account to be handled by Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles, Inc.

A new method of managing a department store was outlined yesterday by the Retail Research Institute of the National Merchants Association. In effect, it separates the buying and selling functions and introduces the "staff and line" plan used in a manufacturing organization to a retail business.
The Waterfront Commission will make another attempt this morning to question Albert Ackalatis -- if he shows up.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Solid Fleet won the feature, a $10,000 grass race, at Santa Anita today and returned $86.90 for $2.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 27 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan proposed today a state budget for 1959-60 that would be $47,000,000 greater than present spending.

The new Federal space agency has selected 110 candidates for possible assignment as the test pilot of the nation's first space capsule. The agency expects to narrow the list to twelve volunteers by late March.

HOBOKEEN, N. J., Jan. 27 -- Faculty members of Stevens Institute of Technology here were offered a plan today to help them finance the purchase of new homes. The program was worked out by the Institute and the Prudential Insurance Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -The defense at the Powell sedition trial offered today to "prove" that the United States used biological warfare in Korea. Proof was promised if the defense were permitted to bring witnesses from Communist China.
A message from President Eisenhower was among the greetings received last night at the national awards dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Two Negro lawmakers called on the Legislature today to investigate what they called "de facto segregation'' in the New York City school system.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Elmer A. Carter of New York City, a Negro and one of the original members of the State Commission Against Discrimination, was named chairman of the agency today by Governor Rockefeller.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions as reported to the State Commerce Department today:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Senator Rolando Masferrer and other members of his party who fled Cuba Jan. 1 have been granted temporary parole in this country.
ROME, Jan. 27 -- Pope John XXIII appears confident that unity talks between Roman Catholics and some Eastern Orthodox leaders will be held.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 27 (AP) -- An agreement on a new contract with the Wisconsin Telephone Company covering 6,300 workers in Wisconsin was announced today by Edward V. Peil of Milwaukee, state director for the Communications Workers of America.
The majority of Americans evidently have recoiled in horror from the mass executions in Cuba. And many have wondered why there was not immediate official denunciation of such barbaric retribution.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A legislative investigation of engineering and architectural design contracts awarded during the Administration of former Gov. Averell Harriman was urged today by Republican lawmakers from Syracuse.

THERE are those who love Maria Meneghini Callas, as she is well aware. Because of the exigencies of a recent hot operatic war, she is not appearing at the Metropolitan this season, but she refused to let her admirers down.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- A threatened proxy fight at the Crane Company apparently was averted today when the management announced its intention to add four new directors to the seven man board.
Several specialists in the study of atomic bomb fall-out agreed yesterday that it was impossible at present to predict drift of fall-out clouds more than a few hours in advance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Cardinal Spellman will testify next week at a Federal Civil Rights Commission hearing in New York on discrimination in housing.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- David W. Peck of New York, a strong advocate of court reform, was reported slated today to head a reorganized state constitutional revision commission.

Ever since, and even during, the catastrophe of the second World War, the Western powers have sought to restore to the world a just and lasting peace. To that end they have made innumerable proposals, beginning with the Atlantic Charter, continuing through the war and post-war conferences of Teheran, Yalta, Potsdam, Moscow, London, Paris, New York, Geneva and elsewhere and culminating in the Charter of the United Nations.

John J. McCloy, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said yesterday that the activity of other financial institutions was increasing competition for commercial banks. He said these included insurance companies, savings and loan associations, savings banks and "the great proliferation of Government agencies lending money in many different ways.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Air Force blasted its nineteenth Atlas skyward tonight on what was reported to be another ocean spanning, 4,000-mile flight into space.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev warned unidentified "officials" of the United Arab Republic today not to persecute Communists. He said the Communists were the most steadfast supporters of the Arabs against "imperialism."

Net income of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, dropped 28 per cent last year as a result of the recession. But steel orders have increased substantially in recent weeks. And Roger M. Blough, chairman, said yesterday he expected continued improvement throughout this quarter and the next.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- New racial disorders shook the capital of this West African colony today. They were the first since riots erupted here three weeks ago.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- The professional educators hit back at their critics today.
It seems easy to break into newsprint these days by some shouting against landlords or slum-lords. Never have so many condemned so few and with such steady repetition.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 27 -- Building unions made plans today to crack down on wasteful labor practices that were causing giant oil and chemical plants to be built with non-union workers.

Arthur R. Guastella, associate editor of The Bond Buyer, was elected president of the New York Financial Writers' Association at the annual meeting last night. He succeeds Robert G. Shortal, assistant financial editor of United Press International.
Lack of funds now threatens the Health Department's ability to guard the city's well-being the department's commissioner said yesterday.
OTTAWA, Jan. 27 -- Canadian Broadcasting Company producers and their sympathizers staged a colorful and noisy protest today outside the Parliament Building.
Manhattan College's basketball team scored its seventh victory in eleven starts this season by defeating City College, 83 -- 56, on the Jaspers' court last night.

Casey Stengel, manager of the world champion Yankees, held his annual midwinter news conference in the Bombers' offices yesterday. As usual, he covered more ground than in the days he played the outfield for John McGraw's Giants nearly forty years ago.

The common shares of Borne Chemical Company, Inc., dropped 27 points on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as a wild and sudden boom came to an end. The Exchange had announced that it Was investigating recent trading in the issue.

The Regan Building, a thirteen-story office structure at 140 West Forty-second Street, has been acquired on a long-term net lease by Milton Sloame from the Sova Management Company, the owner for the last few years. Alfred Kohn Co. was the broker.
A good housing year in 1959 was forecast yesterday by the nation's new housing chief.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 27, (UPI) -- A German crew won the Swiss four-man bobsled championship today. The United States entries finished fifth, ninth and eleventh in the tune-up for the world championships.
Rain or sunshine can be ordered at will in a new environmental test chamber installed at the United States Army's Frankford Arsenal in Philadelphia.

FROZEN puff pastry, welcomed here earlier this month in a major bakery's fruit turnovers, appears again in plain and filled pastry shells. Vendome, 15 East Forty-eighth Street, has the frozen pastries under its own label.
GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- The Soviet Union held out today for 100 per cent national staffing of control posts for policing the proposed ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
Argentina's economic difficulties were viewed yesterday as a welcome opportunity for a fresh start on more effective development of resources and industries.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 27 -- The Planning and Zoning Commision has abandoned a controversial proposal to rezone land near the Westchester County Airport for executive offices and research laboratories.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -- California's crew coach, Ky Ebright, whose rowers have won six national championships and three Olympic titles, will retire at the end of next season.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi, in an administrative policy speech before the Diet (parliament) today, strongly denounced advocates of neutrality and emphasized closer ties with the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to recommend confirmation for nine major State Department nominations.
GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- The World Council of Churches attaches "special significance" to the convening by the Pope of an assembly on Christian unity, a spokesman said here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -The United States is sending a scientific mission to sub-Sahara Africa to gather basic knowledge on which future long-term aid programs may be built.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller told legislative leaders of both parties today that his budget would call for tax increases amounting to $275,000,000.

Ashley T. Cole, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, said yesterday, "There is no reason why there cannot be racing at both New York and Saratoga at the same time." However, he pointed out that legislation would be necessary because of the law that Saratoga must have twenty-four exclusive days a year.

HIS political foes and his warmest friends have called Charles Abrams a zealot. Mr. Abrams says this is not 100 per cent accurate. He describes himself as "a practical planner who becomes a propagandist when it's necessary."
A three-truck collision and fire on the Long Island City approach to the Queensboro Bridge jammed traffic on the Manhattan and Queens ends of the bridge yesterday afternoon.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced yesterday that their plan to merge had been called off.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower ended their abbreviated five-party White House winter social season tonight with a dinner honoring House Speaker Sam Rayburn.
HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- The drastic reforms being introduced by the new revolutionary Government of President Manuel Urrutia Lleo threaten to shake the Cuban way of life.

In recognition of the devoted efforts of hundreds of volunteers serving as Big Brothers with our three organizations, Times Square was renamed Big Brother Plaza during the recent National Big Brother Week.

Blood will be given today at the New York Telephone Company, 45 South Sixth Avenue, Mount Vernon, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. A bloodmobile will also call at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, 32 Avenue of the Americas.
New York's second kidnapping hunt in recent weeks ended yesterday when 28-day-old John Tavarez was found unharmed.
HAVANA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Exiled Haitian Senator Louis Dejoie is conferring with Cuban revolutionary leaders on "plans for the liberation of Haiti," the newspaper El Crisol said today.
HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- Former Capt. Pedro Moreon Valdes, an officer of the former Batista army, was condemned today to death before a firing squad.

GIUSEPPE VERDI'S "Macbeth," composed around 1847, was cast in darksome shade. The Shakespeare narrative -- the action and the plot -- seem secondary. The Verdi "Macbeth" puts the accent on Macbeth's psychological buffeting.
A light snowfall, enough to caution motorists and tantalize youngsters, covered the metropolitan area yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's statement today that the Soviet Union was producing intercontinental ballistic missiles in series -- that is, presumably on assembly lines -- was received here with apparent indifference.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The 1932 Packard used by Franklin D. Roosevelt when he was Governor has stood in a dark corner of the state garage for most of the last sixteen years because nobody in Albany can decide what to do with it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Justice Charles E. Whittaker of the Supreme Court refused today to stay the trial of seven persons scheduled this week in Denver. They are charged with a conspiracy for the violent overthrow of the Government.
TRENTON, Jan. 27 - The largest association of scavenger concerns in New Jersey granted favors to a Teamsters Union official to "keep on his good side," a State Senate committee was told today.

CAIRO, Jan. 27 -- Three Jesuit primary and secondary schools closed yesterday by the Education Ministry will be reopened as soon as offending textbooks can be replaced and faculties questioned, a ministry official indicated today.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Spiritual and lay leaders of many religions have often talked of the desirability of joining all faiths in some kind of informal alliance to block communism's spread. When Cardinal Pacelli, before he became Pope Pius XII, visited New York in 1936 he discussed this with Myron Taylor, later our special Presidential envoy to the Holy See.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- A New York educator suggested today that the maximum use of educational television could make it possible to get a university degree without attending a school.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Sleepy Hollow Restorations, the Rockefeller-financed "little Williamsburg of the North," announced today that it would raze the two-story grist mill and undershoot water wheel at Philipsburg Manor, formerly Philipse Castle.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 27 (AP) -- An Agriculture Department official said today that almost $6,000 in Federal assistance payments had been made since 1953 to the operator of President Eisenhower's farm.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A late rally raised new-crop wheat futures and left distant soybean deliveries with small gains today on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The nation needs 140,000 new schoolrooms, the Office of Education reported today. Last year the need was estimated at 142,300.

BONN, Germany, Jan 27 -- The West German Defense Ministry angrily called upon the German Evangelical Church today to repudiate the Rev. Martin Niemoeller for calling military training "a high school for professional criminals."
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- The man whose memory dominated the last Soviet party Congress received a formal but only passing mention today as Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev celebrated a new Communist order.

Canadian Javelin Ltd., holder of mining concessions in Canada and South America, has leased a floor in Canada House at 680 Fifth Avenue, corner of Fifty-fourth Street. The concern soon will become an American corporation under the name of the Javelin Corporation and will move its headquarters from St. Johns, Nfld., at the end of February.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A $379,500,000 progam of laons and grants for redeveloping chronically depressed areas was put before Congress today with the backing of Democratic leaders.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 28 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion foresaw today the possibility of mass immigration of Jews from the Soviet Union.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has resold the property he bought recently at 335 to 343 East Fifty-fifth Street, adjoining the northwest corner of First Avenue. The buyer was Frank Grasso, who owns several parcels near by on Fifty-fifth Street.
FREEPORT, L. I., Jan. 28 -- A model of the Acropolis in Athens, complete with its Parthenon, temples and statuary, has been constructed by an 11-year-old boy here.
Westport, Conn., Jan. 29 -- Fifty wooden reproductions of Army rifles, which have been gathering dust in a storage shed here for years, may go into service again.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Department of Defense will attempt to launch fifteen satellites this year in a program to develop space vehicles for reconnaissance, meteorology and communications.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Fifty-four requests were received today for the 1932 Packard used by Franklin D. Roosevelt when he was Governor of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Hearings on legislation to admit Hawaii as the fiftieth state drew only one avowed opponent today.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today gave the Greyhound Corporation permission to raise its fares 6 per cent on travel within the state, effective Sunday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (UPI) -Representative Barratt O'Hara left here today without clearing up the confusion surrounding his sponsorship of a Negro boy as a page in the House of Representatives.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 11 points (55 cents a bale) up to 10 points (50 cents a bale) off yesterday. The volume of business was moderate.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28 -- Yugoslavia's Communists felt today a little like the sailor who had correctly forecast a typhoon -- pleased at the accuracy but unhappy about the weather.
The story that appeared in the Jan. 14 edition of The Times stating that the use of voting machines in primaries cannot begin earlier than 1960 deserves rather special attention.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower called the foreign aid program today the most economically effective means of blunting and turning back . . . blandishments of the Communists."

ALEXANDRIA, Va. Jan. 28 -- A last-minute effort to block the admission of four Negro children to a white junior high school in Arlington next Monday was rejected today by Federal District Judge Albert V. Bryan.
The earth is not quite a flattened sphere but is slightly pear-shaped -- stem end at the North Pole -- it was reported here yesterday at the opening of the American Physical Society's annual meeting.

George Charles de Hevesy, a 73-year-old chemist and Nobel prize winner, who pioneered in the use of radioactive isotopes, yesterday said enthusiam, perseverance and an ability to distinguish what was important were the attributes of "a great scientist."

Textile manufacturers who have taken the trouble to copyright their designs now have an excellent chance to halt the activity of plagiarists, Arthur M. Klurfeld, executive director of the Textile Fabrics Association, Inc., declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Eisenhower brushed aside criticism of his leadership from within the Republican party today as no more than could be expected by anyone taking a middle-of-the-road position in politics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev predicted yesterday that economic growth in the Soviet Union over the next seven years would come to about 8.6 per cent a year. Judging from recent performance, he may not be far wrong. Mr. Khrushchev said this compared with an annual rate of growth in the United States of 2 per cent.
HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- The Supreme War Tribunal's inaction in the appeal of Maj. Jesus Sosa Blanco, condemned last Week to death as a war criminal, has disturbed the people of Havana.

President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina arrived in New York yesterday and continued his campaign to assure business men that his country offered a safe climate for investment. During the day he was greeted by Governor Rockefeller, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and city officials.
OTTAWA, Jan. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Canada exported $4,928,500,000 of goods in 1958, just below the record high of $4,934,400,000 in 1957.
STUART, Fla., Jan. 28 -Florida fishermen divide into about as many species as there are game fish, and their attributes vary as widely. But they are not nearly so hard to identify.

Premier Khrushchev was in a confident mood when he delivered his opening speech at the twenty-first Communist party Congress in Moscow. His claims and promises were many: the Soviet rocket successes had shifted the world balance of power in Moscow's favor; soon there will be a similar shift in the world balance of economic power; the Soviet Union itself is beginning to move toward the Communist utopia.

Bankers Trust Company started the recent merger talks with Manufacturers Trust Company, Horace C. Flanigan, chairman of the latter, told stockholders yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting. Neither he nor William C. Moore, chairman of Bankers Trust, would say, however, in answer to stockholders questions, which bank would become the surviving institution if the deal should go through. Mr. Moore presided at his own annual meeting two hours before the meeting of Manufacturers Trust.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent Congress a report today saying that disposal of surplus farm commodities was likely to remain a costly problem so long as the price support program guarantees profits.
GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- The West stressed today at the three-power conference on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons that permanent mobile teams would be needed to investigate suspicious events.

The Italian Cabinet crisis will have the customary upsetting effects on internal politics and, to a certain extent, on the general conduct of affairs in the country. Foreign policy was not at issue and there is no reason to believe it will be affected in the slightest. This means that Americans can look on with a certain detachment and friendly interest.

DAN FERRIS didn't mean to sound like an auctioneer but the honorary secretary of the Amateur Athletic Union found himself accepting bids. It was at a gathering of the various directors of the indoor track and field meets that plans were unfolded for the current board floor season. Dapper Dan was the coordinator and it was through his office that invitations would go forth to outstanding foreign stars.
An experimental project that has shown success in discovering and developing abilities of pupils in deprived areas will be extended next week to sixteen New York City schools in three areas.

JAMES M. BARRIE'S comedy, "What Every Woman Knows," was revived last night on the "Du Pont Show of the Month" over Channel 2. With Siobhan McKenna and James Donald in the leading roles, the work still rang true in both warmth and laughter.

Regardless of the current booking congestion, room can be made -- as if by magic -- for anything resembling a potential hit. Apparently, this situation applies to "A Raisin in the Sun," with Sidney Poitier, Claudia McNeil and Ruby Dee in the cast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The eight Southern Senators who sponsored the submission of Senator Talmadge's proposed amendment to the Constitution to legalize public school racial segregation would be joined by others in both branches of Congress if their motion should reach the voting stage.
The New York Board of Rabbis voiced opposition yesterday to any sectarian religious practices in the public schools.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 28 -- The Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America today approved $750,000 in loans to forty congregations to be used to buy parsonages, church sites, or church construction on projects totaling $2,000,000.
El Davie Fulton, Canadian Minister of Justice and Attorney General, last night criticized undue and unacceptable interference with Canadian sovereignty by United States antitrust laws.
The retiring chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of being "overly cautious" on civil rights.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron Steuer reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the city to dismiss the claims of twenty-one present and former Municipal Court justices for pay cuts taken during the depression.
Governor Rockefeller pressed last night for quick action by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to meet the commuter crisis in the metropolitan New York region.

George F. Leggett, 21-year-old Nazi imitator of Forest Hills, Queens, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate period in the Elmira, N. Y., Reception Center. He was convicted last Dec. 3 on four counts of burglary and three of petit larceny.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The Soviet Communist party's congress became a show of unity by the leading Communist countries today as the Chinese and Poles hailed Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's formula for permissible diversity within the Communist camp.

John Humcke Jr. received three of the twenty-one awards for national amateur championships presented at the New York Athletic Club's annual all-sports dinner last night. The former Linden (N. J.) High School star was recognized for his 1958 triumphs while wearing the red and white of the Winged Foot track team.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Two new approaches to court reform, less drastic than most pending plans, were introduced in the legislature today.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The advertising industry's answer to outright prohibition of billboards along major state highways was presented today to the Legislature.
The Transport Workers Union warned the Transit Authority yesterday that automated operation of subway trains would endanger the safety of passengers.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 28 -- Prospects for a settlement of the border dispute between Thailand and Cambodia appeared today to have improved.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The question of cultural interchanges with Communist China was raised at today's first plenary session of the Third National Conference on Exchange of Persons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- A leader in the field of educational broadcasting said today that the Government must support use of television for that purpose if this country is to stay abreast of the Soviet Union in schooling.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Stock market prices tended to advance slightly here today under the lead of Government securities.
Mark Van Doren, his wife Dorothy and their son Charles each have a book scheduled for publication next month.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust has reported net assets of $1,432,816,211. This was equal to $13.35 each on the 107,295,924 shares held by 199,449 shareholders on Dec. 31, 1958. These were the highest year-end figures in the thirty-four year history of the large mutual fund.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Adele L. Rand's Clem, who whipped Round Table three times last year, opened his 1959 campaign today by beating nine other good horses in the $25,375 Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declined today to endorse a bipartisan legislative proposal for new statewide assessment laws.
The Waterfront Commission moved with haste yesterday to punish Albert Ackalitis, ex-convict and waterfront hoodlum, for his steadfast refusal to answer questions -- but it was not quite fast enough.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York proposed yesterday that the Federal Civil Rights Commission recommend a large increase in public housing and changes in Federal laws to keep this housing from becoming segregated.
Postponement of sinking fund payments due Jan. 25 and July 25 on the issue of $26,000,000 of 5 3/4 per cent bonds of Stanrock Uranium Mines, Ltd., has been authorized by most of the bondholders.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 28 -- The Baghdad Pact Council ended its work here today with a warning that the threat of aggression against the Middle East was not diminishing.

A leading political adviser to former Gov. Averell Harriman gave his support last night a movement aimed at reducing the power of Carmine G. De Sapio, the leader of Tammany Hall and a national committeeman.
YONKERS, Jan. 28 -- The Lincoln Commuters Club, which operates chartered buses from Lincoln Park and Bryn Mawr here to mid-Manhattan, is in trouble with the New York police.
Net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation last year increased 2.9 per cent above that for 1957 despite a 5.6 per cent drop in sales.
PARIS, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- President Charles de Gaulle announced promotions tonight for three generals who were key figures in the Algerian uprising last May that brought him to power.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- Western diplomats found no basic changes today in Soviet policies as outlined by Premier Khrushchev yesterday.

HOMEMAKERS have just become used to dealing with hi-fi, and along comes "stereo." Having once rearranged the decor and perhaps even torn out walls to accommodate hi-fi, what can the housewife expect if the audio bug in the family decides he must have a stereophonic sound system ?
The imposition of tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway was defended here yesterday by James W. Danahy, chairman of the New York-New Jersey Committee for a Self-Supporting Seaway.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- King Phumiphol Aduldet proclaimed an interim Constitution tonight to replace the one dissolved after Field Marshal Sarit Thanarat's anti-Communist coup last October.

QUITE credibly announc,d as the nost comprehensive exhibition of the work of N,-inslow Homer, the showing that opens at the lNIetropolitan Iuseum today includes 2tt examples of the artist's varied output in oils. watercolors, drawings, prints and even ceramic tiles.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Wellington Fund has reported that 1958 operations produced the largest annual increase in net assets in the thirty-year-history of the large, open end investment company.

A. M. Sonnabend, chairman and president of Botany Mills, Inc., a diversified company, said yesterday that discussions were under way to explore the "possible advantages" of a merger with the F. L. Jacobs Company, Detroit maker of auto parts and phonograph equipment.
Almost $3,000,000,000 was lopped from the aggregate market value of New York Stock Exchange stocks yesterday in a busy session. The ticker ran as much as eleven minutes behind action on the floor.

The Public Health Committee of the New York State Bar Association is to be commended for its proposal that the Public Health Law be amended to permit physicians to treat confirmed narcotics addicts, as reported in The New York Times of Jan. 23.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 28 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. told an emergency session of the Virginia Legislature today that he was helpless to prevent the imminent desegregation of public schools in Norfolk, Arlington and Charlottesville.
The city has begun site studies for a third slum-clearance project in lower Manhattan's billion-dollar redevelopment area.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The grain futures on the Board of Trade worked slowly back today from a fairly broad early slide but closed steady to slightly lower.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Americans ought to be proud of this country's missiles progress and not have a "hangdog attitude of humilitation," President Eisenhower said today.

The New York Central Railroad's action in canceling a possible merger with the Pennsylvania Railroad will deprive the two carriers of savings of $100,000,000 a year, James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania, said yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller's office said today that the cost of the proposed income tax changes would be "less than $1 a month" for two-thirds of the state's 4,300,000 taxpayers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, January 21:
ROME, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President Giovanni Gronchi conferred with six former Premiers today in his search for a man to head a new government.

M. L. Mandeville has been appointed vice president and director of sales, international division, of U. S. Industries, Inc., here. He had been an assistant general manager of sales for the overseas division of Continental Can Company.
Peter Tripp 32-year-old radio disk jockey for WMGM, completed a 200-hour stay-awake ordeal at 7:14 o'clock last night. He set what attending doctors believe is a record.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Colonial authorities called out troops today to disperse Negro demonstrators who roamed through this capital looting buildings and stoning European - owned cars.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon and former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey talked together privately here yesterday for an hour and twenty minutes.
Comdr. Malcolm C. Ross, a Navy balloonist, said yesterday that on two flights high in the stratosphere last year strange black clouds had been visible for a few minutes, then vanished.

A committee of New York alumni of St. Mark's School in Southboro, Mass., has chosen the Feb. 17 performance of "Tall Story"as a benefit. Brantwood Camp in Peterborough, N. H., which is maintained by the school, will gain by the event.
The nation's inventories of light fuel oil dropped 8,693,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The United States has protested to West Germany against the imposition of a new tariff on imports of coal from the United States.

TENAFLY, N. J., Jan. 28 -- Using a crane with a large steel ball to break up rocks weighing as much as 140 tons, workmen started today on the two-week task of removing 3,300 tons of trap rock that slid off the face of the Palisades here Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, was pictured today as being involved in a scheme that cut sickness and hospital insurance benefits to union members while raising premiums.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was defeated today when he attempted to obtain a subcommittee chairmanship for himself in the House Education and Labor Committee.
MORAVIA, N. Y., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A 15-year-old boy shot to death four members of his family late today near here, the state police reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States was willing to engage in new talks with the Soviet Union if they gave promise of bearing fruit.
The city's prisons were pictured yesterday as seriously overcrowded in a situation "fraught with danger."
John W. Hanes, president of the New York Racing Association, expressed concern last night over proposed legislation that would permit simultaneous race meets in Saratoga and New York.

Directors of the Freeport Sulphur Company yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 90 cents from 75 cents a share and recommended a three-for-one split of the common stock. The dividend is payable March 2 to holders of record of Feb. 16.

Futures prices closed generally lower in more active trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Wool, world sugar positions, cottonseed oil, copper, lead, zinc and rubber declined; hides rose, and price movements for coffee, the domestic sugar contract, cocoa and potatoes were mixed.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 -Delegates to the fourteenth Mississippi Valley World Trade Conference were told yesterday that the United States could be squeezed out of world trade by mounting competition from the Soviet Union, Latin America and Europe.

The American Stock Exchange has been plagued recently by activity in some stocks whose prices bounded upwards after rumors. Edward T. McCormick, president, said yesterday: "Ways and means must be developed to curb the effect on the securities markets of the wide dissemination of unconfirmed rumors."

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday that discrimination in housing was "the most persistent and unyielding expression of prejudice facing American Jews today, and probably the most damaging."

The Salvation Army, whose executive headquarters are at 120 West Fourteenth Street, enjoys a unique position in the respect and affection of New Yorkers. It has earned this position over the years by a record of selfless devotion to everyone in need or trouble, whatever his race or creed. The Army's institutions and services in the city are managed in a businesslike manner that always has appealed to contributors.
Vince Lombardi, the offensive coach of the New York Football Giants since 1954, was named yesterday as the head coach and general manager of the Green Bay Packers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Managing Director of the United Nations Special Fund, said today the new program of aid to under-developed countries would succeed because it was "just plain good business."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Director of the Budget said today that the nation would have to face up to the question of higher taxes if Congressional actions were to produce a significant deficit in the budget.

Fordham University's basketball team scored its tenth victory of the campaign against three defeats by romping to a 93-67 triumph over Wagner College at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, last night. The loss was Wagner's tenth in fourteen games.

New York City has borrowed $25,000,000 on tax anticipation notes at an interest rate of 2 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. Of the total issue, $15,000,000 will be dated Jan. 29 and the $10,000,000 balance Feb. 4.
PREMIER CHOU EN-LAI has long been one of the triumvirate in China's Communist party under its leader, Mao Tse-tung, ranking with Liu Shao-chi and Marshal Chu Teh.
The Yankees, who never waste time doing what has to be done, yesterday brought about the first crack in their so-called wholesale salary dispute with their players.
City agencies laid plans yesterday to meet a possible fuel shortage posed by port tugboat workers who may strike Saturday night over a wage dispute.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers and basic steel companies will open their 1959 contract negotiations in New York in mid-May, The Associated Press was told today.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Despite Labor party criticisms, the House of Commons approved today Britain's recent move toward greater convertibility of the pound sterling.

The New York Rangers offered the 15.138 customers excellent hockey for the first period last night at Madison Square Garden. Thereafter, most of the excellence was on the side of the Chicago Black Hawks. The result was a 3-1 defeat for the Rangers in a National Hockey League game.

ALTHOUGH Charles Darwin was born on the same day as Lincoln, Feb. 12, 1809, a comparison of their careers must give place this morning to autobiographical material about Darwin. This is contained in the first complete edition of "The Autobiography of Charles Darwin,"* edited by his granddaughter, Nora Barlow.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 -- Representatives of 3,000,000 building unionists and their employers took the first step today toward setting up permanent joint machinery for solving the problems of the construction industry "in the best interests of the industry and the general public."
About twenty of Madison Avenue's top agencies have made presentations downtown at the New York Stock Exchange. They may end up with nothing more than expense account entries for cab fares.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The bowler-hatted gentleman and his stylish wife in The News Chronicle's front-page cartoon today were applying for emigration to "tax-free Russia."
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Hopes that rose briefly last fall for a speedy settlement of the Algerian war have all but vanished following a rebel statement yesterday that "no perspective of peace" was visible.

There are many specific points of danger in international relations today, such as Berlin is at this moment, but the greatest danger is the existence of the generalized condition known as the cold war. It might be defined as a feud among nations, a state of mind which makes difficult or impossible the peaceful adjustment of relations. The longer it continues, the greater is the likelihood of armed conflict.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Post Office Department said today, with dignity, that it now understood all about the new conversion rate for the French franc.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday the withdrawal of its offer to acquire the assets of the Texas Pacific Coal and Oil Company through an exchange of stock. The offer was made last November and provided for the exchange of one share of Sinclair for each 1.55 shares of Texas Pacific.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Alfons Landa, president of the Penn-Texas Corporation, was named chairman and chief executive officer of Fairbanks, Morse Co. today, following a meeting of the Fairbanks, Morse board here.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana's Prime Minister, hit back today at critics of his regime and defended the actions of his government against "enemies of African freedom."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 Another story conflict between Hollywood motion-picture and television film interests appeared to be developing today. Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country last month amounted to $2,281,881,000, an increase of 15 per cent over the volume of $1,982,342,000 for the comparable month a year ago.
Two magistrates were pro-rooted to the Court of Special Sessions yesterday by Mayor Wagner. At the same time the Mayor appointed two new magistrates.

A record net income of $43,116,942 was achieved by the Procter and Gamble Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended Dec. 31, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 28 -Russia defeated the United States at basketball tonight for the first time in international competition. The score of 62 to 37 in favor of the Soviet team was a faithful reflection of the difference between the two teams.

Dr. Edward Teller yesterday revised his statement that thermonuclear power would not be achieved in this century to say that it might be brought about in "this century, perhaps." He spoke at the American Physical Society's annual meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower bid for party unity in Congress today at a White House breakfast with key Republican Senators.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The House of Commons approved today, 235 to 88, a second reading for a bill to rid London's streets of prostitutes.

A cocktail dansant to be held in the Carnaval and Crystal Rooms of the Sherry-Netherland on March 1 will benefit the Disabled Veterans Association of the Leib Cossacks Regiment and its military museum in Courbevoie, near Paris.
NEWARK, Jan. 29 -- The Jersey City Board of Education has agreed to discontinue its annual religious census of public school pupils.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- A demand that the accused foes of Nikita S. Khrushchev's policies be arraigned before communism's supreme authority was made today at the twenty-first Soviet party congress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A coalition of Senate liberals introduced a civil rights bill today that would expand Federal power to enforce school integration.
Stocks rallied mildly yesterday from the decline on Wednesday but lost much of their momentum before the close. The result was a moderate gain on considerably reduced volume.

OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 29 -Reduction and simplification of the complicated governmental units in Westchester would improve the "business climate" of the county, leaders of business, government and education agreed today.

Residential construction rose sharply in this state last year when 84,987 units were started or authorized at a cost of $1,675,897,000. This was an increase of 18 per cent over the, 72,136 units costing $1,652,585,000 in 1957, according to a report submitted to Governor J Rockefeller by James-William Gaynor, the new State Housing Commissioner.

Last spring, a Socialist program was adopted at the congress of the League of Yugoslav Communists at Ljubljana, Yugoslavia. The program was denounced by the Soviet Union and Communist China as "revisionism." An authorized version of it has been translated from the Serbo-Croatian by Stoyan Pribichevich, American author, war correspondent and magazine editor.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Jan. 29 -- The North Country Exchange, Inc., of Oyster Bay, a resale shop conducted for the benefit of the Community Hospital at Glen Cove, is marking its tenth anniversary under the chairmanship of Mrs. Gordon W. Burnham Jr. of Glen Cove.

Two wool-processing groups accused the Treasury Department yesterday of "unseemly haste" in its move to end anti-subsidy duties imposed on Uruguayan wool tops since June, 1953. The term "tops" means wool that has been scoured, carded and combed preparatory to spinning.

Residents of Nassau County. L. I., are paying higher interest on loans, getting lower interest on their savings and are being deprived of the full banking services enjoyed by their New York City neighbors, a group of university economists asserted yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 29 -- France may have enough plutonium by the end of next summer for an atomic bomb and may be in a position next year to explode it.
DENVER, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Zora Folley of Chandler, Ariz., stabbing with his left jab, punched out a unanimous decision over Alex Miteff of Argentina in a ten-round bout tonight.

I wish to commend The New York Times on its excellent editorial of Jan. 28 "Soviet Challenge and Western Response," which I called to the attention of my Senate colleagues and inserted in the Congressional Record.
Directors of American Machine and Metals, Inc., yesterday voted to split the common stock on a two-for-one basis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -Godfrey p. Schmidt, a court-appointed monitor of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, suggested today that pending labor bills should deal with a "home-grow fascism," which he said had enveloped the union headed by James R. Hoffa.

Most of Niven Miller's publicity material shows him dressed in kilts. Thus, when the Scottish baritone strode on the stage of Town Hall for his debut last night, the audience was audibly disappointed to see a pleasant-looking young man dressed in orthodox tails.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Early passage of Hawaiian statehood legislation had the formal support today of both Democratic and Republican floor leaders in the House of Representatives.

INGEMAR JOHANSSON of Sweden looks as Irish as an outsize leprechaun. He was beaming with a happy, Celtic grin yesterday as he signed a contract to fight Floyd Patterson for the world heavyweight championship. But Patterson didn't seem amused. He just appeared bored, an act which places a rather high price on boredom because his signature guaranteed the champion a mere $300,000.
More fuel is being added to the marketing fire in the tobacco industry -- small cigars.

The Union Pacific Railroad yesterday reported earnings for 1958 of $77,782,444. That was 15465,332 less than the 19571 pr6fit of $78,247,776. The year'sl net was equivalent to $3.29 a common share, against $3.34 in 1957.

The State of Connecticut will offer for sale on Feb. 10 an issue of $50,500,000 of rental housing notes. The money will be used to finance loans to municipal housing authorities for the development costs of moderate-rental projects.
HAVANA, Jan. 29 -- Fidel Castro will leave Monday for the Sierra Maestra to start the distribution of land that he promised the countrymen there during his two-year rebellion.
A new variety of flight vehicle, higher-flying than an airplane but something less than a true space craft, is under serious study.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Providence (R. I.) Journal said today that Senator Theodore Francis Green should step down as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee because of his age.
CECIL BEATON, a man whose tastes and talents have ininspired a myth, is never in danger of not living up to it.
The telephone bill which I received the other day had a new notation -- "U. S. Tax." I pondered the questions, why, when and for what was the tax imposed?
HONG KONG, Jan. 29 -- Seven Chinese fishermen who escaped with 906 others from the mainland in recent months said today they had fled because of intolerable conditions in the communes.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 29 -- Prince Rainier suspended the Constitution and disbanded the Legislature today to show that he alone was ruler of Monaco's 370 acres.

The program at tonight's opening of "Requiem for a Nun" will list William Faulkner as the author of the drama, co-starring Ruth Ford and her husband, Zachary Scott. Today the script is to be issued in book form by Random House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today President Eisenhower had asked Congress to surrender its authority over the strength of the various services.
The co-leaders of this country's unionized seamen demanded yesterday the resignation of Clarence G. Morse as chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and Maritime Administrator.

GOWRAN PARK, Ireland, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The American steeplechase champion, Neji, conceded many pounds to a dozen rivals today and finished a out of the money in the race for the Thyestes Cup. The Irish-trained Slippery Serpent won as Neji making his first European start, finished fifth.
The Navy's share of the Administration's defense budget for the fiscal year 1960 will maintain a fleet of approximately the present size.
Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, declared last night that the "corrupting influence of complacency" was the most serious problem facing this nation.

Today's new film is "The Last Blitzkrieg." a Columbia military melodrama starring Van Johnson, at the Mayfair. Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. The Clover Production was produced by Sam Katzman and directed by Arthur Dfeifuss on location in the Netherlands, Lou Morheim wrote the script.
The International Petroleum Company, Ltd., experienced a decline of $24,000,000 in earnings last year, the preliminary annual statement disclosed yesterday.
GENEVA, Jan. 29 -- Britain proposed today a joint meeting of experts at the three-power conference for ending nuclear weapon tests in an attempt to make a new approach to stalled political issues.
BELGRADE, Yugoslav, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- Yugoslav trade with the Soviet Union will be reduced by $16,000,000 this year, reversing a three-year policy of increased trade, it was announced here today.
CAIRO, Jan. 29 -- An influential Egyptian told Nikita S. Khrushchev today to mind his own business.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- The House Veterans Committee approved a bill today permitting the Government to raise the interest rate on G.I. housing mortgages from 4 3/4 to 5 1/4 per cent.

If doing good is the only certainly happy action of a man's life, John D. Rockefeller Jr. in reaching the age of 85 must look back through the years with much satisfaction. He would, in his modesty, utterly disclaim greatness. But there is a greatness that springs from goodness and this, it seems to us, is what has given his life meaning and character.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey told the National Conference on Exchange of Persons today that the Soviet Lend-Lease debt should be used to finance an exchange of family visits with the Communist countries.
City authorities stepped up their search yesterday for the true owners of a dilapidated tenement that was shut down by the Fire Department on Jan. 14 as a "menace to life."
Ellis Island is slowly sinking -- in price, that is.

The rift in the honeymoon between the Soviet and Egyptian dictatorships disclosed by President Nasser's arrests of local Communists has now developed into an exchange of verbal potshots between Moscow and Cairo.
HOWARD LINDSAY and Russel Crouse are honest playwrights who like to have their principles and their jokes at the same time.

Stockholders of the May Department Stores Company and the Hecht Company approved yesterday at special meetings a merger of the two concerns. The result will be a department store chain with sales of more than $600,000,000 a year.

Now it's official. Ingemar Johansson of Sweden is going to fight Floyd Patterson, the champion, for the world heavyweight boxing title. The champion and the Swedish challenger signed contracts for the bout yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 28 -- A local high school boy who set to music Lincoln's Gettysburg Address when he was 13 years old will have his work performed during Lincoln Day celebrations in Washington.
A tale involving a "divine" mushroom, used ritually for centuries by Mexican Indians and now experimentally by psychiatrists, is being unfolded at the American Museum of Natural History.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Sputnik III, the ton and a half Soviet satellite launched last May 15, is orbiting back into sight.
MOLLY will be at her own Round Table in the New York University Faculty Club dining room at 22 Washington Square North at luncheon today, but not in her black-and-white waitress' rig.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 29 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that the Soviet Union's policy on Germany was aimed ultimately at "mastery of the whole world."
An attempt is being made by the Board of Education and a group of Negro parents to resolve the Harlem school controversy.
The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company has formed a hydraulic turbine division with the facilities of the S. Morgan, Smith Company, recently acquired by Allis-Chalmers.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 29 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. warned a group of diehard segregationists from the General Assembly today that he would veto a package of bills they had hastily introduced to frustrate school integration next Monday.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- More than 14,000 holders of state scholarships and fellowships stand to lose a part of their awards under the revised state income-tax program proposed by the Rockefeller Administration.

Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. of Virginia took a step on Wednesday that might be a reminder to some other Southern Governors, including the Governors of Arkansas, Georgia and Alabama, that state laws are not valid when they run counter to the Constitution of the United States.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- A court reform plan on which Republican leaders are relying as a framework for a feasible program was laid before the Legislature today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 -- Following is the text of the opinion by Chief Judge Simon E. Sobeloff of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit accompanying his stay of a lower court order requiring immediate admission of twelve Negro children to white schools in Charlottesville, Va.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 553,845 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today,
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower plans another visit to the Maine Chance health and beauty resort in Arizona next month.
Senator Herman E. Talmadge appealed here last night for a Constitutional amendment to let citizens decide locally how and when to comply with court orders to end racial segregation in public schools.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 29 -- Three infants, one of them two weeks old, died in a fire that destroyed their parents' shanty home here this morning.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Two top-ranked yachts, the United States' Argyll and Argentina's Cangrejo, arrived eight hours apart today as the first two finishers in the 1,200-mile race from Buenos Aires. The ocean race started on Jan. 18.

Antonietta Stella, who sang most of the Cio-Cio-Sans last season in the Metropolitan Opera's Japanese-conceived production of "Madama Butterfly," returned to the part last night when the Puccini opera was given its eighth performance of 1958-59.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- A dispute that may prove acrimonious seems to be brewing between the United States and Britain over the adoption of a standard international short-range radio-navigation aid.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above the level of a year ago.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Leonard Rose, 'cellist, John Corigliano, violinist, Laszlo Vargo, 'cellist, Harold Gomberg, oboist, Manuel Zegler, bassoonist, at Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Vanessa," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Arda Mandikian, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Eisenhower announced today the names of fifteen trustees from the public for the National Cultural Center.
IN APPOINTING Robert William Purcell as his special consultant on railroad commuter problems, Governor Rockefeller has tapped his own family's business adviser, a railroad man's railroad man.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The American Guild of Variety Artists has served notice it will resist plans to have the Moscow Circus tour the United States under a cultural exchange agreement.

Ginger Rogers and Louis Jourdan will star in a special musical variety show to be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Saturday, Feb. 28, from 9 to 10 P. M. It will be produced by Roncom Productions, Perry Como's company, and sponsored by Pontiac.
Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, in a book published today, urges a more rigorous public school system. He also suggests changes in industry and government to give more freedom to the creative worker.

The recent conference of municipal Mayors and railroad representatives in Chicago did a great deal to bring to the attention of the American people the critical plight of our railroad transportation system and, more particularly, the acute commuter problem.

Although its steel-making rate last year was the lowest in twenty years, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation covered its usual dividends by a comfortable margin. And its profits in the final 1958 quarter were the second highest for any quarter in the company's history.

Child development and the building of good parent-child relationships will be the topics of two spring courses to be given at the Queens College School of General Studies, Flushing. The informal classes will be led by Z'ev Spanier, a member of the Educational Clinic of the college.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Andrei A. Gromyko warned today that if the Western powers spurned the Soviet proposal on Germany the Communist world would "seek other ways" of solving the problem. The Soviet Foreign Minister's warning came in a major foreign policy speech at the third day's session of the twenty-first congress of the Soviet Communist party.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 29 -Craft unions in the building and metal trades formed a united front today in an effort to outstrip mass production unions in organizing workers in atomic energy, chemical, oil and other expanding industries.
MANILA, Jan. 29 -- There are signs here that the Philippine Government is disposed toward reforms that could ease the strain on Philippine-United States relations.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Ronna Goldblatt, a tiny 13-year-old eighth grader from Newton Center, Mass., today won the school figures half of the novice ladies class in the national figure skating championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- State Department and foreign embassy officials today interpreted the release of tens of thousands of Rumanian Jews for emigration to Israel as a Soviet move to stir trouble in the Middle East.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 29 -- President Syngman Rhee's principal legislative aide called upon the ruling Liberal party today to end a boycott that has brought the National Assembly to a standstill for the last fifteen days.

Futures prices moved mostly up yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Commodities showing increases were wool, lead, tin, copper, hides, rubber and cocoa. A decline was recorded by world sugar. Commodities with mixed price moves were potatoes, domestic sugar, coffee and burlap.
Milton C. Mumford has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Lever Brothers Company, a leading producer of soaps, detergents, toilet articles and margarine.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 29 -- Six Norfolk secondary schools will reopen Monday on a racially integrated basis, the Norfolk School Board decided here today.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 28 -- The Monetary Board has ordered a substantial increase in the funds made available by the central bank to all banks for productive purposes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to scrap the Government's costly system of rewarding farmers for planting less. He urged that the United States and its allies join in harnessing their surplus food production for the cause of universal peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Judge Burnita S. Matthews refused today to dismiss an indictment accusing Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside of conspiring to influence the award of a Miami television permit.
The Benrus Watch Company, upset over present pricing of watches at retail, is dropping its line of some 400 and replacing it with fifty or so on which prices will be maintained.

PAINTINGS and sculpture by twenty-four contemporary artists of sixteen countries make up the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. This showing presents examples acquired by the museum within the last year.
CHICAGO. Jan. 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A water-main break at 12:50 A. M. today at Broadway and Fortieth Street disrupted northbound subway service on the Broadway BMT line. The police closed Broadway to traffic between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets.
Anyone who attempted to rob the Chemical Corn Exchange bank would most likely have a movie made of his crime.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Moderate short selling and liquidation of some long positions were the major pacemakers today in a slow and weak grain futures market on the Board of Trade here.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The worst fog for many winters, the kind Charles Dickens called "a London particular," paralyzed London and most of England and Wales tonight.

About two decades ago the world was astounded when some of the oldest and most important Bolsheviks, former comrades of Lenin, rose in public court and "confessed" to terrible crimes against the state they had helped create and build. BERLIN, Jan. 30 (AP) -- East Germany said tonight that it was ready to release a United States Army pilot, First Lieut. Richard Mackin, through an arrangement with the Red Cross.
An Arctic passenger-cargo ship struck an iceberg off Greenland on her maiden voyage yesterday and reported that she was sinking. Ninety-five to 130 persons were reported aboard the Danish vessel.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Hostility toward neighboring Guatemala mounted in Mexico today, fired by a report that Guatemalan demonstrators had destroyed a border bridge and Guatemalan planes had flown over a city in southern Mexico.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The world champion, David Jenkins, today assumed a commanding lead in his bid for a third straight national senior figure skating title.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- More bad news came to the Secretary of State today. This time it came from the Capitol with the announcement that the chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee would pass to Senator James William Fulbright, whose antipathy to Secretary John Foster Dulles is one of Washington's open secrets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- To make any concession to the processes of aging, no matter how small, is to Senator Theodore Francis Green an act of treason to one's self.

Alexander P. Hirsch, chairman of the Welbilt Corporation, announced yesterday agreement on terms for a merger with a large furniture manufacturing company with sales of more than $20,000,000 a year. He declined to name the other company but said that Welbilt would be the surviving company if the transaction were completed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The Voice of America estimates that 7,000,000 persons behind the Iron Curtain listen to its daily broadcasts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Senate Rackets Committee heard testimony today that a high official of the Carpenters Union had drawn four concurrent salaries. At the same time, witnesses said, he used his union influence to sell over-priced oil and gasoline to builders.

The Chain Belt Company has declared a 60-cent quarterly dividend on the present common stock, payable Feb. 25. In previous quarters 50 cents was paid and an extra $1 was distributed last October. Directors also formally declared the three-for-two split to be paid Feb. 25 as approved by stockholders on Wednesday.

A new television picture tube said to give bigger and clearer pictures than the present twenty-one-inch type, although it is about the same size, was announced yesterday. The manufacturer is the Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30 -- The Soviet Union tonight forfeited its chances of winning the third world basketball championship. For political reasons the Soviet team failed to show up for its scheduled game against Nationalist China.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- The Western powers have been taking their own good time about defining their views on Berlin. This is wise because the problem is extremely serious. Any misjudgment of Soviet intentions or aspirations could have disastrous consequences just as any failure by Moscow to comprehend our own intentions and aspirations would be equally grave.

The Public Service Commission's report on the financial problems of New York State railroads was damned with faint praise yesterday by the New York Central Railroad. A divergent view came from the Long Island Rail Road.
Many persons of social prominence entertained at cocktail parties before the Golden Anniversary Ball last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Eisenhower warned Congress today that any cutback in foreign aid would mean far greater spending for defense.
The lawyer for the renting agent of a tenement closed on Jan. 14 as a "menace to life" was sentenced to thirty days in jail yesterday for contempt of court.

SHOPPERS can save several pennies by buying dried, shelled chestnuts instead of those sold fresh in the shell. This tip comes from Mrs. Leonie M. Holland of Brooklyn. She reports that dried chestnuts are now available in the open-air markets along Ninth Avenue, below Forty-second Street.

The assessed valuations of real estate and special franchises in New York City for 1959-60 have been set tentatively at $23,796,918,227. This is a record and represents an increase of $1,346,633,280, or about 6 per cent, over last year. The final valuations for 1958-59 were $22,450,284,947.

Frederick H. Ide has been elected president of the Kent Company, Inc., manufacturer of industrial vacuum cleaners and floor machines in Rome, N. Y. He succeeds Gordon E. Kent, who has been elected chairman of the board.
Trading of shares on the New York Stock Exchange this month produced much activity but little price movement.

I must take exception to the editorial which appeared in The Times of Jan. 15 concerning Mayor Wagner's plan for dealing with the interstate transit crisis. The title, tone and substance of the editorial showed that the whole point of Mayor Wagner's presentation had been missed.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- The General Motors Corporation asked Westchester County today to sell Kingsland Point Park on the Hudson River here so that the adjacent Fisher body and Chevrolet factories could be expanded.
"For Love or Money," an audience-participation television show, was dropped yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System because it was not "free from control."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- A small boy who was burned by steam as a baby while his mother was bathing him in an apartment house kitchen sink was awarded $350,000 damages in State Supreme Court today.

Harold Vincent Roelse, vice president and economic adviser of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, retired yesterday after thirty-five years of servive with the bank. At the same time, he stepped down as associate economist of the Federal Open Market Committee.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Unheralded Brazil burst into championship contention in the world amateur basketball tournament tonight by whipping the United States, 81 -- 67.
A decline in bond issues and a sharp increase in stock flotations from a year ago, marked the new securities offered publicly here in January.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Farmers' living costs and production costs rose to a record during the last month while prices they received for crops and livestock remained unchanged.

The Jewish Daily Forward announced yesterday that agreements had been reached with employes assuring continuation of publication. The Yiddish-language daily earlier had said it would have to suspend on Feb. 8 unless labor costs were reduced.
Preliminary work on the construction of a $10,600,000 four-berth steamship terminal in the Gowanus Bay area of Brooklyn will get under way immediately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Federal Power Commission today denied an application for permission to transport natural gas to the Consolidated Edison power plant near the United Nations Building in New York City.

MANILA, Jan. 30 (AP) -- President Carlos P. Garcia barred James Bell, Time magazine correspondent, from the Philippines today because of an article in the magazine suggesting President Garcia was a luxury loving unpopular President who had failed to correct his nation's economic ills. Mr. Bell is in Hong Kong.

When the Titanic collided with an iceberg in 1912, the world learned to fear icebergs as never before. Out of the Titanic disaster was created The International Ice Patrol, operated by the United States Coast Guard but financed by fourteen nations.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The assailant of the Hialeah Race Course security chief meant to shoot the officer's brother, the police revealed today.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The British-Egyptian financial settlement initialed in Cairo two weeks ago has been stalled by a dispute over which British assets in Egypt were seized permanently and which were seized merely for the duration of the Suez crisis.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- France has informed other members of the Western alliance that she is unsympathetic to holding a foreign ministers' conference before the end of May, the deadline set in the Soviet proposals on Berlin.

The verbal battle between Soviet and Yugoslav Communists has flared up again this week. Premier Khrushchev began the latest skirmish in his major speech on Tuesday when he lashed out at the Yugoslav "revisionists," accusing them in effect of betraying the working class and charging that Yugoslavia is improving its economic position more slowly than is the case in countries allied with Moscow.
