MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- A ranking union leader asserted today that the Senate rackets investigation had "outlived its usefulness."

A series of radio messages yesterday painted in terse phrases the agony of the sinking Hans Hedtoft in the North Atlantic. All were relayed by the Coast Guard cutter Campbell as she steamed at a reported speed of nineteen knots for the Hedtoft.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A discreet "beep" sounded inside the coat of a court aide. He walked out of the courtroom, picked up a phone, listened, then left the building.
GLEN ELLYN, Ill., Jan. 30 -- Eight elderly persons, many of them bedridden, died today in a fire that swept a nineteen-room frame-and-stucco private nursing home.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Israel complained to the Security Council today that "constant" attacks were being made on her territory from Syria, in the United Arab Republic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Average wholesale primary market prices fell 0.1 per cent to 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Requisitions for new capital are slated to reach the market at an active rate next week, with total volume below recent aggregates and with the accent falling on corporate equity financing and local government borrowing.

Heavy selling depressed cotton futures in late trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The selling developed after publication of the mid-January cotton parity price. The parity price was sharply below that a month earlier.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 30 -- The Belgian plan for gradual introduction of government in the Congo by Congolese is winning the approval of native leaders there, in the judgment of Maurice van Hemelryck, Minister for the territory.

Two six-story apartment houses at 248-50 West 154th Street have been sold by the Delta Investors Corporation, David H. Solove, president. The buyer was an investing client of Patterson Michaels, attorneys.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today that Great Lakes ports be put on an equal footing with ports on the Eastern Seaboard and the Gulf of Mexico in the free time allowed for unloading railroad export freight at shipside.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Speedier action by governments in adjustment of price support measures has been recommended by the Food and Agriculture Organization for Western European countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The House Armed Services Committee gave swift approval today to President Eisenhower's request for a four-year extension of the draft.
VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 30 -- Dom Mintoff, former Prime Minister and leader of Malta's Labor party, has called for a "stay-in strike" by the people of this British colony for Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- High-ranking East German intelligence officers have been arrested as a result of the defection to the West of the intelligence departments Deputy Chief, political quarters in Bonn that have sources in East Germany said today.

I am writing to protest the current indignation from commentators and public opinion against the Castro regime in Cuba. Such vociferous shrinking from the horror of executions impels me to wonder why similar interest was not aroused when Batista's forces were receiving arms and equipment from America and England, though money and arms on their way to rebel forces were confiscated and their purveyors detained in Texas or Florida jails.
HAVANA, Jan. 30 -- The Cuban Cabinet suspended four articles of the Constitution today for ninety days to speed up the trials of "war criminals."

NEWARK, Jan. 30 -- Eddie Dixon counted himself out of the boxing profession today. The 25-year-old middleweight told Police Director Joseph F. Weldon that he had reached his decision -- to remain a member of Newark's Police Department.
TUNIS, Jan. 30 -- The Tunisian Government, at a major turning point in its foreign economic policy, has proclaimed the battle for economic independence from France.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senator Theodore Francis Green resigned today as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Spectacularly successful in reforming France, President de Gaulle has, unfortunately, been less successful in solving France's biggest problem -- Algeria. Early hopes for a speedy settlement are fading, and both sides are resigning themselves to a continuation of the more than four-year-old guerrilla war.

HAVANA, Jan. 30 -- The harvest of the Cuban sugar crop is progessing well, according to Alberto Fernandez Echevarria, Government delegate now heading the Sugar Stabilization Institute. About fifty mills of the 161 in the island have started grinding, Senor Fernandez said.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Tango, an Argentine yacht, glided into Rio on a light wind today with an excellent chance of winning the fifth annual 1,200-mile ocean sailing race from Buenos Aires. Argyll of the United States and Argentina's Cangrejo also were expected to be high in the final standings.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- Wendell B. Barnes, administrator of the Small Business Administration, said here today that investment companies licensed by the Administration would receive "a wide range of freedom" under the Investment Act of 1958.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30 -- Chile's new Government is preparing to call on Washington for credits that are described here as the last financial props Chile will seek abroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address to the National Conference on Exchange of Persons today:
Control of Madison Square Garden, an institution to generations of sports fans, was sold yesterday for about $4,000,000 to the Graham-Paige Corporation, a New York investment company.

RETURNING to the New York Philharmonic podium after a month's absence, Leonard Bernstein resumed his traversal of way stations along America's musical journey. For the next few weeks he will concern himself with compositions written between the late Nineteen Twenties and middle Forties.
TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 30 (AP) -- A Seattle investment counselor testified today that salaries paid to members of Dave Beck's family as officers in the K L liquor companies were excessive.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz called yesterday for more vigilance in the allotment of welfare funds. Eighteen more defendants had pleaded not guilty to charges of receiving relief money illegally.

ONE of the distinguishing features of American abstraction is that its major exponents never relinquished a fundamental respect for subject. Nearly all the noted abstract expressionists began as figurative artists.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- A mistrial was declared this afternoon in the Powell sedition case.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30 AP) -- The Air Force volunteers were not good enough.
BONN, Germany, Jan, 30 -- The Government brushed aside a last-minute request of the United States for a sixty-day delay and the Bundestag approved a 10 per cent tariff today on foreign coal imports.
HELENA, Ark., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Eight men were killed and two persons were injured today when the boiler of a Mississippi River log-loading boat exploded twenty miles downstream from here.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 30 -- Class work and community service complement each other at West Orange High School.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 30 -- Marek Hiasko, restless young Polish novelist who obtained asylum in the West last October, explained today why he had decided to return to Communist Poland.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- A dozen pink carnations were laid on the grave of Franklin D. Roosevelt today in the annual ceremony marking his birthday. It was the seventy-seventh anniversary of the late President's birth.

The longest losing streak in Columbia basketball history became longer last night when the Lions lost to Navy, 67 -- 54, before 1,000 spectators at University Hall. Columbia, which downed City College in the season opener on Dec. 3, has not won since, dropping thirteen in a row.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- A public hearing on residential rent control, traditionally the noise highlight of the legislative session, will be held Feb. 19 in the Assembly chamber in the Capitol.
Capt. Joshua L. Goldberg, district chaplain of the Third Naval District, declared yesterday that spiritual freedom is the basic strength of America.
Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from the Mayor of Jersey City regarding a recent editorial on Mayor Wagner and the interstate transit crisis.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- The West German Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, today approved legislation for maintenance of the joint French-German military research institute at St. Louis, Alsace.
WASHINGTON, JAN. 30 -- The House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee voted today in favor of giving to Hawaii one Representative in Congress instead of two when it attains statehood.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 28 -- In the eyes of Alaskans, gold has lost its glitter. The metal that lured thousands from the shops and farms of America at the turn of the century is decreasing in importance in Alaska's economy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- A United Nations mission to West Africa has reported that the 760,000 people in northern British Cameroons want the territory to join Nigeria, which becomes independent in 1960. The mission said that popular sentiment was so clear that it saw no need for a plebiscite.

The problem of making the busy family physician a more effective participant in cancer control activities was discussed here yesterday at an area medical meeting sponsored by the American Cancer Society.
Bernard H. Gordon, realty operator, has resold the four-story building at 1056-58 Flatbush Avenue, northwest corner of Beverly Road, Brooklyn, to a client of Henry Brinsley, broker in the deal.

The holder of Japan's national high jump championship is not, as one might expect, a Nipponese. He is a native American -- John C. Thomas, a Boston University freshman who holds the world indoor record of 6 feet 11 3/4 inches.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore and Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., were eliminated today from the women's international four-ball golf tournament.
Cocoa futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange in the heaviest trading since Nov. 19.
In The Times of Jan. 28 I noted the perplexing problem of the disposition of Franklin D. Roosevelt's 1932 Packard which faces the powers that be in Albany.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- Thick fog blanketed four European countries today, playing havoc with road, rail, air and sea traffic.

Evander won its tenth Public Schools Athletic League indoor swimming championship in the last fourteen years at New York University's Quigley Memorial pool last night. Coach Bill Gay's swimmers tallied 29 points, fifteen more than Brooklyn Tech, the defender.
I was delighted with your editorial of Jan. 23 concerning public assistance and the Department of Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Manufacturers' sales and new orders increased in December. Factory inventories held steady for the third straight month.

GENERAL liveliness and an affectionate interest in subject matter are the most conspicuous merits of Lena Gurr's cityscapes and Cape Cod scenes at the ACA Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street. She more or less abstracts what she sees into small, flat planes, which have a nodding acquaintance with cubism.

A SPLENDID physical specimen named Dixie Qualset bounced into New York this week and, for many women suffering from low spirits, sniffles and a general feeling of midwinter flabbiness, she was an inspiring sight.

While the Danish passenger ship Hans Hedtoft was sinking off the southern tip of Greenland yesterday, rescue operations were coordinated by the United States Coast Guard from a building on the southern tip of Manhattan.

The late Ruth Benedict's approach to anthropology was that culture is inherited through custom and not biologically. This theory is developed through selections from Mrs. Benedict's articles, journals and correspondence by Dr. Margaret Mead in "An Anthropologist at Work: Writings of Ruth Benedict."
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 30 -- Two young hoodlums who shot two patrolmen last night have evaded a search by 400 policemen in the wooded Palisades and near-by homes.
A strike of 5,000 bread and cake bakers at midnight tonight is a "very definite and serious threat," a mediator said yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- A record fleet of thirty-five yachts, including three former winners and a "dream boat," will set off at 10 A. M. tomorrow in the twenty-sixth annual Lipton Cup race.

Net earnings of the Standard Oil Company of California (Calso) were about $258,000,000, or $4.08 a share, last year, R. G. Follis, chairman, said yesterday. This was 11 per cent below the net income of $288,230,000, or $4.56 a share, reported for 1957.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30 -- An investigation of alleged health code violations in seven low-cost housing developments here was ordered today by Mayor Charles S. Witkowski.

The President's plea for the discontinuance of our present farm policy in this week's special message to Congress is to be commended. His critical appraisal of the existing policy, which has been a chronic festering sore on the economy since it was adopted as an emergency measure at the outbreak of World War II, is completely unarguable.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- The theatre season here was enlivened last night by the entry of two important names in world literature -- Feodor Dostoevski, the great nineteenth-century Russian novelist, and Albert Camus, contemporary Nobel Prize-winning French writer.
GENEVA, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Swiss men have to decide again this week-end on the perennia issue of whether to allow woman to vote.

A Queens County grand jury cleared Supreme Court Justice James J. Crisona yesterday of political bribery charges. He had been accused of offering inducements to a Democratic leader in return for the latter's support in the borough presidency race in 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A long-distance communication system patented this week for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation will bounce short waves off man-made reflectors in the sky.

The Cincinnati Redlegs and the Pittsburgh Pirates completed a seven-man player deal last night. The Redlegs obtained Frank Thomas, John Powers, Jim Pendleton and Whammy Douglas in exchange for Smoky Burgess, Don Hoak and Harvey Haddix.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- The Yugoslav Communist party today accused Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union of interfering in Yugoslavia's internal affairs.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Road-building plans that will disrupt traffic for 40,000 motorists a day on the Bronx River Parkway here were unfolded today by engineers.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 30 -- Auto traffic increased last year on the New Jersey Turnpike, but toll revenues did not rise comparably.
The New York State Bar Association adopted two resolutions yesterday favoring state legislation to prevent law-enforcement agents from using illegally obtained evidence in court.
EVEN if William Faulkner's name did not appear on the program of "Requiem for a Nun," which opened at the John Golden last evening, his signature would be visible on every scene.
Deputy Attorney General Lawrence E. Walsh called on lawyers yesterday to help insure Congressional action for civil rights that would be "not just something glibly called civil rights legislation."

MAKE-UP and the machine age have joined forces. A new electrical appliance called Makeur removes and applies make-up with better results in less time. Only the mouth, eyes and eyebrows need the human touch.

"Riders of the Purple Sage" (1925), starring Tom Mix, will be today's children's film at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets. Performances begin at 11 A. M. and 1:15 P. M.
A full-scale test of a double-bottom operation -- two semi-trailers hauled by a single tractor -- is scheduled to begin this week on the New York State Thruway.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 30 -- A 23,000,000-crown (a crown is worth about 19 cents) fur auction ended here today with mink prices about 7 per cent higher than last month but slightly below the peak of a year ago.

A policeman and a hold-up man were killed in a gunfight early this morning in an East Side tenement. More than sixteen shots were exchanged between two policemen and three hold-up men as seven gamblers looked on.

Motors, oils and drugs held back yesterday but almost every other major group of stocks pushed forward to end the week on a strong note. Steels, chemicals and aircrafts showed many more gains than losses.
Many descendants of the city's original Dutch colonists attended the tenth annual dinner and ball of the St. Nicholas Society last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
BELGRADE, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The article in Borba said the Soviet Communist party was trying to blacken President Tito's regime for two reasons:
Protestants and Roman Catholics will soon be asked to make their annual contributions to support the work of their churches among the hungry and the homeless overseas.
The Nassau County Clearing House Association said yesterday that banking services in the county "may well serve as a model for any area of the United States."

The American League, in business as a major circuit since 1901, today will elect the fourth man to hold the office of president. The distinction will fall to Joe Cronin, one-time shortstop and manager for both the Washington Senators and Boston Red Sox and more recently the general manager of the Bosox.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- With the end of the Paris showings almost in sight, two individual couturiers, Alix Gres and Madeleine De Rauch, brought their spring collections out from under wraps today. Both were in good form, showing the kinds of clothes that have made them well known.
Things were humming yesterday for the off-Broadway impresarios. Production plans, including opening dates and casting notes, were announced for several incoming attractions.

Argentina intends to take the initiative in seeking to organize a common market in its area of South America. This was disclosed yesterday by President Arturo Frondizi as the Argentine statesman, with his wife, said farewell to New York at the end of a three-day visit.

Shirt-sleeved physicists sat cross-legged in the aisles of the crowded New Yorker Hotel grand ballroom yesterday afternoon to hear two reports that appear to be of classic significance. In the first paper, Prof. Paul A. M. Dirac of Cambridge University proved mathematically that gravitational waves existed and that they could carry energy.
The high jump and the two-mile run will command the chief attention of 15,000 spectators tonight at the fifty-second annual games of the Millrose Athletic Association.

THE Equity Community Theatre of the Bronx, whose home base is the De Witt Clinton Adult Center at 100 West Mosholu Parkway, began its tenth season last night with a presentation of Christopher Fry's poetic romance, "The Lady's Not for Burning."

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 30 -- The loudest noise disturbing the balmy air of crisis-seized Monaco tonight was the popping of champagne corks at a benefit gala for the British-American hospital of the Riviera.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Government space experts testified today that they believed the Soviet Union could now pinpoint a city in the United States with a ballistic missile fired more than 5,000 miles away.
With a minimum of fanfare, the Soviet Union is sending a squad of thirteen athletes to the North American ski championships and invitation speed skating races at Squaw Valley, Calif., next month.

OKECHOBEE CITY, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Anybody can catch fish in the right place at the right time, but there are a few fishermen left in this world who can get there too late, leave too early and still do business. It would be a pleasure to meet them.
Four thousand unionized captains and crew members on 400 harbor craft here will stop work at midnight tonight over a wage dispute.

THIS is the peak season for Belgian endive, the versatile imported vegetable that is excellent hot or cold, raw or cooked. Shipments, which began last September, are expected to continue in good supply through April.

WALT DISNEY has been financially successful in using his television program over Channel 7 as an instrument of promotion for his full-length films to be shown in theatres. Last night he once again turned sixty minutes of video into a trailer, this time in behalf of "The Sleeping Beauty."

A distinguished-looking man tried his hand as a waiter at a luncheon yesterday in the Faculty Club of New York University. He was new at the trade, having worked for years in other aspects of university administration.
Governor Rockefeller's defense of his new tax proposals is scheduled to get state-wide television and radio coverage Monday night.

MONTREAL, Jan. 30 -- This year appears to hold good prospects for the Canadian pulp and paper industry, Robert M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, said today. He warned, however, that the industry must improve its merchandising methods, particularly in export markets.
Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, yesterday was called "the key to effective labor legislation" in Congress this year.
Arda Mandikan sang music spanning a period of nearly twenty-two centuries at her impressive United States debut last night at Town Hall.

Events today: "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Zinaida Alvers, contralto. Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Leonard Rose, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Armen Guirag, tenor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A debate over the relative merits of manned bombers and the big ballistic missiles of the foreseeable future continued all around the capital today. But at the Pentagon, officials said that the argument was over for the time being.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson said today the United States should strive to fly its first nuclear-powered airplane by 1962 and to achieve economic atomic electricity by 1969.

In your Jan. 10 edition you print a letter from H. LeRoy Whitney concerning the Tennessee Valley Authority. To disparage the rate of economic progress in the area Mr. Whitney uses a form of statistical "analysis" which should not go unchallenged in your newspaper.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 29 -- Recent reports of a plot by Thailand against the Cambodian Government have proved advantageous to the Communists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The United States brushed aside today an implied threat by Hungary to sever diplomatic relations unless the United States agreed on talks to "eliminate obstacles impeding relations between the two countries."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The New York Central Railroad appealed to the Federal Government today for permission to discontinue all passenger train service on its St. Lawrence division in upstate New York.

Eighth Avenue boulevardiers who thought they had seen everything witnessed something new last night when a fighter and his manager picketed Madison Square Garden. The pickets, Joe Lissy, a middleweight, and Willie Grunes, were protesting the refusal of Jack Barrett, the Garden matchmaker, to use Lissy in a ten-round bout.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Attorneys for the Arlington County, Va., school board asked Chief Justice Earl Warren today to stay a lower court order requiring admission of four Negro children to a white junior high school on Monday.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 30 -- Segregationists in Virginia's General Assembly stalled action today on the program of Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. for passive acceptance of token public school integration. The delay provided assurrance that the emergency session of the Assembly would continue through next Monday, when desegregation comes to six schools in Norfolk and one in Arlington County.
Ignace Strasfogel made a second successful appearance at the Metropolitan Opera last night, conducting Samuel Barber's "Vanessa."

For the best results when frying frozen swordfish steak, the Fishery Council suggests using a heavy skillet, preferably iron. An excellent utensil for frying, sauteing and pan broiling fish, this type of pan has the required thickness to prevent the fish from drying out and keeps the juices intact, thus maintaining the flavor.
Premier Kishi and Foreign Minister Fujiyama have again rejected both neutrality and "neutralism" for their country and have pledged it to close cooperation with the United States and the free world.
Almost 800 evening high school teachers -- virtually the entire staff -- voted last night to resign en masse on Monday to point up their demands for higher salaries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today a head-on collision of two Erie passenger trains near Sloatsburg, N. Y., Aug. 11 was caused by a failure of one train to receive a special operating order for that day.
GENEVA, Jan. 30 -- The United States formally requested today that carefully controlled nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes be exempted from the proposed ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The Army announced today it had successfully tested an underground shelter designed to protect troops against the effects of atomic weapons.
Rueben Vargas, of Richmond, Calif., virtually unknown to Eastern fight fans, upset Tony Anthony of New York in the star ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
NEW YORK can be an obliging city. There are a number of accommodating services that various stores offer at a reasonable price.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Britain reiterated today her belief in the need for, and possibility of establishing, a European free-trade area.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 -- A local Teamsters Union squabble involving the rule of James R. Hoffa seems about to reverberate across the country.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Some scattered buying shored up wheat and rye futures moderately in rather listless activity today on the Board of Trade. Other grains and soybeans continued weak.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 30 -- Prosperity at any price and the love of soft living were cited by Admiral Arthur W. Radford tonight as things that could destroy the United States.

MIAMI, Jan. 30 -- A grass race, the first big test of its kind of the current meeting, will be the main event at Hialeah Race Course tomorrow. The $25,000 added Bougainvillea Turf Handicap will have its fourteenth running and, only as a coincidence, it has attracted a field of fourteen.

PAUL B. BRINE is one actor who sets his own stage. He has transformed a meager railroad flat on East Fifty-fifth Street into an airy, functional backdrop for his paintings and antiques and for himself and his friends.
Lee Schlessinger, a 42-year-old former convict, and his wife, Terry, 35, were booked last night on homicide charges in the slaying of the assistant manager of Birdland, a Broadway jazz center.
HONG KONG, Jan. 30 -- Economic dislocations in Communist China have resulted from "poor planning and frantic haste" in setting up communes, informed local sources said here today.
TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- Production of the first general issue of New Jersey license plates since 1952 has been halted by a strike of 300 convicts at the State Prison here.
Government securities men joined in happily yesterday with Wall Street's expanding T. G. I. F. (Thank Goodness It's Friday) Club.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Hillsdale gets the biggest test of his career tomorrow when he faces eight challengers in the $177,150 Maturity at Santa Anita.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The American Bankers Association supported the Admiinstration today in opposition to Democratic proposals for more Federal spending for housing and slum clearance.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 30 -- The Port of New York Authority was invited tonight to take over the freight as well as the commuter train service in the New Jersey-New York area.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Jan. 30 -- Part of a headline above a story in yesterday's New York Times on the new Treasury financing inaccurately conveyed the impression that the Treasury expected an unduly large attrition -- demand for cash -- in the exchange.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A panel of economists told the Joint Congressional Economic Committee today that taxes should be raised right away or Congress should be prepared to do so soon.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- President Charles de Gaulle renewed tonight his offer of "honorable conditions" to the Algerian rebels for a cease-fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Administration put forward this week its first positive program for easing the farm problem. Heretofore, the Administration leaned heavily on eliminating from farm law those programs or devices it believed had created trouble in the agricultural economy.

SPANISH-SPEAKING Caimanera is an island paradise in the Caribbean -- a paradise filled with, for the most part, hungry, proud, and grumbling Caimaneros. Its fervidly religious people, with that clarity of vision often given to the helpless poor, see everything external as either black or white.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Loyola of Chicago, weathering a whirlwind 38-point splurge by Al Seiden of St. John's, upset the seventh-ranked New Yorkers, 95 -- 85, in a double overtime basketball game tonight.

BEPPU, Janpan, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Abandoning his diplomatic approach to the incident, Nikolai T. Fedorenko, Soviet Ambassador to Japan, charged today that a drunken Japanese stevedore had deliberately challenged him to a fight.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 31 -- A demonstration by about 15,000 unemployed was broken up here today by National Guard and police units. Many of the demonstrators were carrying improvised weapons.

One of the principal post-war controversies in education has been the issue of content versus method in the training of teachers. On the "method" side are professor of education. Their most vocal critics on the "content" side have been liberal arts teachers.

Baseball's two major leagues voted yesterday to give to the winter leagues operating in the Caribbean countries a free hand in playing their native players regardless of the number of years of service they have had in the major leagues.
TUNIS, Jan. 31 -- High Tunisian officials expressed fear today that the Algerian revolt would spread into other countries if there was no political negotiation between the French and the rebels.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of James H. Smith Jr. as director of the International Cooperation Administration.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- A Cuban Communist told the Soviet party congress today that the Red underground forces were "in the first rank" of the rebellion that overthrew the regime of Fulgencio Batista.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Army now is assembling space vehicles that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has ordered it to use in satellite and deep space soundings this year.

President Eisenhower took advantage of his address to the National Conference on Exchange of Persons to dramatize the immediate importance of our mutual security program in terms of the preservation of peace. He put the program in the light of an investment in security when he said:

Another heavy week of the art season brings into museums and galleries a wide variety of painting, sculpture and graphic art by both European and American artists, past and present, traditional and modern.

RUDY PILOUS, the coach of the Chicago Black Hawks, a team currently enjoying an unforeseen resurgence in the National Hockey League, is a large, informally arranged man with a toastmaster's relish for such clubby aphorisms as "What you win on peaches, you lose on bananas" and "The water's always shallowest where it bubbles."

EVERY now and then, the art world, a world never too stably poised on its axis, gets shaken by one minor earthquake or another. The most recent rumbling concerns a suit instituted by the Museum of Modem Art against Huntington Hartford, which seeks to restrain the latter from calling his projected two million dollar museum on Columbus Circle "Gallery of Modem Art."

CAIRO, Jan. 31 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq first welcomed and then rejected an invitation from President Gamal Abdel Nasser for a meeting on the Syrian-Iraqi frontier a few weeks ago, the Cairo daily Al Ahram said today.

COLLECTORS of foreign stamps are currently centering their interest on southwestern Africa, where there is a new star in the philatelic firmament -- Togo, an independent republic within the orbit of France.
Guidance is expected to become an increasingly important part of the educational process in the next few years, as Federal funds extend its use and stimulate its development.

The 1,400 members of the New York City Buildings Department carry heavier workloads than those of most other municipal agencies. The 733 inspectors among them are exposed to greater temptation and opportunity for graft than any other group of city employes with the possible exception of the police.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 31 -- The first Alaska State Legislature was asked yesterday to form the executive branch of the state government around a framework of fifteen departments.

Police were needed to stop a free-for-all in the Fordham Gymnasium yesterday during the annual basketball game between the Rams and Seton Hall. The fighting, as Fordham won, 93 -- 69, was closer and more exciting than the basketball.

The origins of the first great rift in Christendom date to as early as 331, when Constantine I moved the capital of the Roman Empire to Constantinople (now Istanbul). With the later division of the empire into East (the Byzantine Empire) and West, Constantinople's importance over-shadowed that of Rome -- a situation soon reflected in church affairs.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 31 -- The recent overtures of Pope John XXIII for union among Christians has captured the imaginations of many leaders in Eastern Orthodox churches. But the basic, centuries-old cleavages in belief make almost all of them wonder how unity in any organized sense can be brought about.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- William Z. Foster recently wrote China's Mao Tse-tung that he was trying to get a passport to visit Communist countries. The honorary chairman of the United States Communist party wrote that he hoped "to get better medical treatment than I can possibly get here in the United States."
A new series of Saturday morning astronomy lectures for youngsters of the space age will begin this week at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West at Eighty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that it was considering relaxation of the strict secrecy that has surrounded atomic weapons for the last fourteen years.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- California taxpayers, switching to a Democratic administration, found themselves this week in much the same tax plight as New York taxpayers.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla. -- The tourist volume in this central Florida area has been steadily increasing during recent years. Almost 1,500,000 visitors a year flock to one of the principal private attractions near by a good indication of the preference of many tourists for lakes, rolling hills, boating, freshwater fishing and motoring through miles of orange groves as against sandy beaches or night-club entertainment.

Some hopeful observers say that they have seen a quickening in the willows, an amber look of liveliness that was not there a few weeks ago. And they say wistfully that the red osier dogwood stems will be blushing before long. This could be true, but more likely they have seen the willow wythes and osier stems from a new angle of sunlight and warmly damp with midday melt.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 31 -- An ex-convict, released just one week ago from the Bordentown Reformatory, was arrested today in the shooting Thursday night of two Englewood policemen. Both of the policemen are recovering from the wounds.
A jumper and a vaulter pushed the foot racers into the background last night in New York's first big indoor track and field meet of the 1959 indoor season.

THE twenty-third annual exhibition of The New York Press Photographers Association will open tomorrow with a showing of about 400 photographs, including the top 1958 prize winners, in the Chrysler Automobile Salon, Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue.
Discovery of a new synthetic anti-hookworm compound, found in clinical trials to be the most effective of its kind, was announced last week by the British Information Service.
The state of the cold war was reflected last week in contrasting moods in the contending centers of power -- Moscow and Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Attorney General, William P. Rogers, has urged a Federal judge to threaten the School Board of Little Rock, Ark., with contempt action unless it quickly proposes steps to reopen its high schools on an integrated basis.

The Maritime Administration on Jan. 1 had in effect a total of $244,800,000 in Government mortgage insurance coverage and in commitments to insure mortgages involving thirty-two ships, according to Walter C. Ford, acting Maritime Administrator.
CATALOGUE pictures and descriptions of flowering plants are always alluring. Unfortunately they do not always tell the whole story.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 31 -- This port marked the return of a German luxury ship to Caribbean waters today for the first time in twenty years.

DUE north of Manhattan there is a county called Westchester. It is not to be confused with Hecate or Yoknapatawpha, though it has a certain fame. Its population in 1957 was 766,000; its size for some time has been 448 square miles It is credited with two "firsts," the cocktail (1779) and golf in the United States (1888).

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Army Athletic teams had a field day against New York opponents today. The cadet basketball team toppled Columbia, 101 -- 80; the track team defeated St. John's, 68 -- 41, and Army swimmers won nine of ten events in trouncing the Lions, 60 -- 26.

Since reading a letter in your Mailbag last week from Dale Robbins I have been wondering how anyone in the audience at "J. B." and I could come to such contradictory conclusions about Archibald MacLeish's play.
The President's budget for the fiscal year 1960, beginning July 1, appears to propose greater total expenditures by the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare than in any previous year.

AMONG the attractions that some of the warmer tourist spots have in common at this season are carnivals. The most famous in this country is New Orleans' annual Mardi Gras which begins on Friday and for five days fills the city with parade music and general gaiety.
Initial plans have been made for the annual spring theatre party for the benefit of the Berkshire Industrial Farm at Canaan, N. Y., a national treatment center for boys with behavior problems.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 31 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev struck a sensitive nerve when he criticized the suppression of Arab Communists this week, and the main body of Arab nationalism is still tingling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The chairman of the Senate rackets committee announced today that he had obtained evidence of questionable recent activities involving the Teamsters Union and would conduct hearings on them next week.
CARLSTADT, N. J., Jan. 31 -- A program of land use for the Hackensack Meadows that would ignore political boundaries was outlined this week to the Meadowlands Regional Planning Board.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 31 -- Issues to be faced in South Korea's next national elections scheduled for the middle of 1960, seem to be taking significant shape in the unsettling atmosphere of the current severe political disturbance here.
An experiment in teacher-training that has lured degree-holding housewives, salesmen, craftsmen and others into the teaching profession has completed its first year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 31 -- A group of property owners of the North Stamford area is protesting plans of the Stamford Jewish Center to establish a nonsectarian children's summer day camp in the neighborhood.

Of recent days telephones have been ringing constantly in the city-grayed, Georgian-style Caen-stone house at 130 East Eightieth Street. HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- The tide of revolt in the Caribbean is being ridden by the Haitian opponents of President Francois Duvelier. A Haitian revolutionary front has been set up in Havana and is endeavoring to establish liaison with the new revolutionary Government of Fidel Castro and President Manuel Urrutia.
BOSTON -- The battle road along which the Minute Men sniped at British Redcoats at the opening of the Revolutionary War in 1775 is being considered for a national historical park.

BOSTON, aJn. 31 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins scored four times in the final period and maintained their perfect television record with a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game today.

HIGH peaks of nineteenth and twentieth century French art are scaled in the Henry Pearlman collection, now being shown at Knoedler's for the benefit of Greenwich House. Cezanne dominates the show, much as the Montagne Sainte-Victoire dominates the Provencal countryside in the magnificent late landscape here.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31 -- He is becoming known in Westchester as Boss Michaelian. And there were no indications today that he would soon relinquish his rule of the county government and the dominant Republican organization.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 31 -- An investigation into a deal involving shipments of military cargo made by the Department of Defense with a Philadelphia stevedoring company has been asked of New Jersey Representatives in Congress.

Richard C. Cole has been elected president of Vitro Uranium Company, Salt Lake City, Utah, a division of the Vitro Corporation of America. He had been a vice president.
Great Lakes shipping and port interests last week made a joint plea for participation by Great Lakes ports in the export of agricultural products under Federal assistance programs.

ATLANTA -- Like many another American city, Atlanta has been caught with its flaps, down by the zooming growth of the nation's modern air transportation system. The city's airport, fashioned from an automobile race track in the Nineteen Thirties, has become the air hub of the South and one of the world's busiest interchange points.

" THE UNFORGIVEN," an outsize production that John Huston, director, describes simply as "an adult Western," is developing before the cameras on windswept plains about twenty miles from this historic old mining city.

A $50-a-month minor league shortstop of 34 years ago yesterday became the $60,000-a-year president of the American League. His name is Joseph Edward Cronin, born 52 years ago on Oct. 21 in San Francisco.
A nine-man squad that included four college golfers was named yesterday as the 1959 United States Walker Cup team.

REGULAR readers of this column know that I esteem Ed McBain's novels of the Eighty-seventh Precinct as the best of today's procedural school of police stories -- lively, inventive convincing, suspenseful and wholly satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The rise of Senator Fulbright of Arkansas to the chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee can be an event of considerable significance, depending on how the Senator and Secretary of State Dulles approach one another from now on.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Mrs. Frank McMahon, chairman of the Palm Beach Heart Ball, which will be held at the Bath and Tennis Club on Feb. 19, has announced that Mrs. H. Loy Anderson will be chairman of the Feb. 15 brunch in the Celebrity Room of the Royal Poinciana Playhouse and of the annual Concours d'Elegance.

CHARLES DILLON STENGEL holds all the records as a non-stop conversationalist. But he delivered the shortest speech of his career during the first inning of the second world series game last October.

IN the supercharged atmosphere of East Germany during the popular uprising of June 17, 1953, people were not above producing rhyming slogans. One that still echoes the length of the truncated strip known as the German Democratic Republic is "Spitzbart, Bauch und Brille sind nicht Volkes Wille" -- or, in a free translation that preserves the spirit, "Goatee, paunch and spectacles the people find rejectables."

THE only adjective that adequately describes the career of George Perkins Marsh is the generally trite one -- but in his case accurate -- of "fabulous." Happily, David Lowenthal, Research Associate at the American Geographical Society, though he has clearly been living with Marsh for a long period of exhaustive research, is still so bemused by his subject that he has composed a biography while still convinced that he is telling a fable.

THE slim, long shape of Nike rises above the sagebrush and mesquite of West Texas, and missiles soar over the vast arid ranges where the drumming hoofbeats of the horse cavalry once stirred the desert dust. At Fort Bliss, where the lean, tough "yellowlegs" tamed the West's wild frontier, the Army of today is reaching into the frontier of the sky to develop the tactics of tomorrow. . . .

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- A proposed $11,455,000 long-term plan for flood prevention, water-supply and recreation in the Brandywine Creek Basin would provide for the historic area's water needs until the year 2010.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A study of American seamen's earnings showed today that subsidized shipping companies were keeping tight reins on their payrolls.
The United Nations is now making a fresh start in its ten-year-old effort to assist the economic development of the underdeveloped countries.

New York apparel manufacturers who played host to visiting buyers last month are adding up their orders for spring and summer goods. The consensus is that buying at the wholesale level is moderately better than a year ago.
A collection of valentins is on display in the Children's Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Nearly 300 public officials and private and public social workers joined yesterday in a conference to propose new legislation on juvenile delinquency.
Five thousand bread and pastry bakers struck against six wholesale and retail bakery employer associations last night as negotiators broke off talks on a new contract.

Twenty-seven newspaper advertising executives will attend a two-week seminar beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute, Columbia University.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- An issue as old as British political history will play an important role in the coming general election. The issue is the extent to which The Establishment controls the workings of the British Government, industry and finance.

THE Fund for the Republic issued last week a preliminary sampling of its forthcoming study of the relationship between television critics and the TV industry. ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A strong tendency by Governor Rockefeller to avoid political partisanship is becoming a source of growing annoyance to Republican political leaders and legislators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The proposed enlargement of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund has been tentatively approved by enough of their member countries to assure accomplishment if all of them follow through with the necessary action.

For a President who cannot succeed himself and whose party has just taken a bad beating in the Congressional elections the reasons are historically obvious.

No trace was found yesterday of the Arctic passenger-cargo ship Hans Hedtoft, which struck an iceberg off Greenland Friday and reported that she was sinking. Ninety-five persons were believed lost on the Danish vessel, which was on her maiden voyage.

Senator Theodore Francis Green of Rhode Island likes to walk the two miles from where he lives to where he works. Jo Ede's Nino Padovano, a black standard poodle owned by Mrs. Charles W. Phinney of Cambridge, Mass., was the leading point-winning dog at the seventh annual show of the Poodle Obedience Training Club of Greater New York yesterday.
THERE is no end to anniversaries. Are you impressed by round numbers like centennials, sesquicentennials, bicentennials? The music world can always find several to signalize with pious observances.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Lexington-Concord Road, scene of opening events of the American Revolution, has been recommended for inclusion in a National Historical Park.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31 -- Florida's Gold Coast is getting back on the gold standard -- but the Croesus touch is much less universal than it was in pre-recession days.
Laura Neuberger, the 5-year-old girl whose foster parents fought a long and losing battle to adopt her, is now living with her natural mother, the Jewish Child Care Association of New York reports.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew, allegedly washed up after nearly three decades of competition, outwitted a horde of youthful Olympic hopefuls today and captured the lead in the national outdoor speed-skating championships.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 31 -- The Hungarian Government said today that it was compelled to limit the activities of the United States Legation in Budapest. It said the legation activities constituted a danger to the Hungarian state.

I would like to express my heartiest endorsement of Mr. Taubman's re-evaluation of "Vanessa" and, more especially, to compliment him on his eminently fair-minded refutation of the savage criticism which was leveled at the opera last summer by the German and Austrian critics.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 31 -- Frostbite skippers of the host Indian Harbor Yacht Club defeated winter sailors from the Riverside Yacht Club, five races to three, in their annual team series staged in brisk northwest winds today.
Fire drove 200 persons, including sixty children, from their homes in the six-story Old-Law telement at 66 Rutgers Slip, at Cherry Street, yesterday at 6 A. M.

The Misses Diana B. Farr, Harriet Ferris Brown and Doris Ward, debutantes of the season, were honored jointly last night by their parents at a dinner dance at the River Club. They are the daughters of Mr. and Mrs. F. Shelton Farr of Lawrence, L. I., Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gascoigne Brown of Cedarhurst, L. I., and Mr. and Mrs. George A. Ward, also of Cedarhurst.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 31 (UPI) -- The University of Florida baseball coach, Danny Litwhiler, a former philadelphia Phillies' power hitter, slammed a 400-foot homer today as the National League posted a 1-0 victory in the fourth annual March of Dimes old-timers game.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 31 -- The bleak customs sheds at Israel's port of Haifa were filled again this week with long lines of immigrants, freshly arrived from Eastern Europe.
Two youths were charged with homicide last night in the hold-up slaying of a policeman earlier in the day. They will be arraigned this morning in Week-end Felony Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Secretary of State Dulles will fly to Europe next week to discuss the German situation with Western leaders.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The Home Office will publish early next week a White Paper on penal and prison reform that will represent another Government effort to modernize Britain's social legislation.

RECENTLY awarded the Kate Greenaway Medal for the best English picture book of 1957, "Mrs. Easter and the Storks" is at least as distinguished for its freewheeling fantasy as for its impressionistic, occasionally cluttered but generally amusing, illustrations.

WHAT good is a blind cow dog on a small ranch where every animal has to pay its way? That was what Krissy would have to prove to her practical, hard-pressed father when he discovered, as he inevitably would, that Skip, the beloved collie, had gone blind.

The opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway as a deep-draft waterway is just a few months off. Yet it is still uncertain whether there will be United States-flag participation in the general cargo commerce on the Great Lakes when traffic opens up in mid-April.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren turned down today the Arlington County School Board's request for a delay in racial integration.

THE problems of the world -- today, our problems -- will tomorrow be our children's problems. Are we equipping the younger generation to deal effectively with them? This is the central question in education -- a perennial question, which every adult generation must, in a sense, answer anew, taking into account the changes that may have occurred in the nature of the world's problems.
A New York rabbi asserted yesterday that both a reaffirmation of the Ten Commandments and legal action were needed to counteract the recent spread of hate literature.
TROY, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's hockey team beat Princeton for the second time this season, 6 -- 4, in rough contest at the R. P. I. fieldhouse tonight.

WILMINGTON, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Gordon Eaton of Middlebury College won the New York State downhill ski championship at the Whiteface Mountain Ski Center today. He finished the mile-and-a-quarter course in 1 minutes 33.4 seconds.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Janet Morgan and Mrs. Sheila MacIntosh, first and second seeded foreign entries from England, today advanced to the final of the Massachusetts women's squash racquets championship at the Union Boat Club.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Beverley Bainbridge, an 18 - year - old Australian swimming star, set a world record of 2 minutes 43.8 seconds today in the 220-yard butterfly at the 55 - yard Enfield fresh - water pool.
Demonology was elevated to a place beside far more concrete topics yesterday in a report to the American Physical Society.

TIKAL, Guatemala -- Heretofore almost unnoticed, the magnificent remains of the vanished Mayan empire are now overtaking the well-trodden Chichicastenango-Lake Atitlan-Antigua highland circuit as Guatemala's top tourist attraction.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- Many authors of books, plays and poems are being unjustly denied the right to a Government pension simply because they do not belong to the Union of Writers, according to a group of prominent Soviet literary figures.

MT. HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- The St. George Rink from Montreal, skipped by W. E. (Ted) Thompson, tonight reached the final of the Ardsley Medal competition, main event in the Cuthbertson bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club curling rink.
James E. Robison is a young man in a old-fashioned industry. In a quiet, almost diffident way he is introducing some young-minded ideas that are setting the textile industry on its ear.

A SOLID 16 per cent more Americans were issued passports or had them renewed for foreign travel in the calendar year 1958 than in 1957. This would seem dizzying, except that such increases have been going on a long time. By the record, Americans are more and more prone to travel.
Back in the summer and early fall of 1921, immigrant-carrying ships of all kinds raced across the Atlantic trying to beat confused quota deadlines imposed by the United States Government.

BY proper selection of kinds and varieties, a succession of fine fresh fruits may be harvested from the home garden throughout most of the summer. The average property can accommodate a few tree fruits as well as several small fruits.

UNLIKE the usual incandescent lamp, fluorescent lamps have no filament which glows continuously to give light. The inside of the tube is filled with mercury vapor which is heated by special filaments at the tube end.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The collapse of massive resistance in Virginia is widely regarded in Southern states as a turning point for the whole South in the struggle to maintain segregated schools.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A takin, an elusive creature found in the mountain snows of Burma's Kachin State, is being shipped to the Bronx Zoo in New York.

WE are likely to think of New England, in its essential aspects, at least, as unchanging. In the debate over intelligence estimates of Soviet military strength relative to that of the United States, particularly in rockets and missiles, Congress and the public must choose between the optimists and the pessimists.

TRYING to keep up with the intricate financial maneuverings of the movie world is like trying to run with the Joneses. But it is more important because the amount of money that has to be invested versus profit expectation determines, to a large extent, the quality and quantity of film entertainment.

TRENTON, Jan. 31 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will deliver his budget message Monday. The budget is expected to be a record, exceeding $400,000,000 in comparison with the $388,627,000 being spent this fiscal year.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 31 -- Last Thursday night a cross was burned surreptitiously before the doorway of Norview High School which on Monday will receive seven Negro pupils into its student body of some 1,600 whites.

HYDERABAD, India, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- The West Indies cricket team passed Hyderabad's first-innings total of 232 runs for the loss of two wickets today but its last seven batsmen were dismissed for the addition of only 83 runs.
New York Harbor's 4,000 tug-boat and oil-craft workers will vote this afternoon on the "last and best" contract offer of their employers.

When Texas legislators in Congress modestly refer to Westward themselves these days as coming from the nation's second largest state they are recognizing only one of a series of changes that have come about with the entrance of Alaska into the Union.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 31 -- There were nineteen women and six children among those aboard the Hedtoft. Many were officials, technicians and workmen employed by the Greenland Department and their relatives.
The nation's utilities appear to be doing their part in stepping up construction budgets that may pave the way for a record national economy in 1959.

The increasing importance of education for adults has prompted Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, to inaugurate a study of current programs in New York. He has appointed a special Advisory Council on Adult Education to assess the role and future development of adult education.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 31 -- Some 700 youngsters attending fourth to sixth grades responded enthusiastically today to the first of two concerts presented especially for them by the Norwalk Youth Symphony in the Norwalk High School Auditorium.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 31 -- The Virginia General Assembly completed action today on the emergency program of Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. designed to soften the impact of school integration.

Thousands of persons in Times Square watched a spectacular five-alarm fire last night that rivaled any of the dramatic attractions in near-by theatres. Dense smoke and swiftly climbing sparks rose to a height of twenty stories as a four-story brick building at Broadway and Forty-sixth Street was swept by flames.
CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- A plan is afoot to place parking meters along Cairo's main thoroughfares. One aim is to make a few piasters for the municipality. Another is to eliminate the car watcher.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- The second Conference of Governors on Civil Rights called upon President Eisenhower today to take the lead in creating a "positive climate of public opinion" on civil rights problems.

REVIEWING my biography, "Winston Churchill," A. L. Rowse complained that I had missed "two main points." One of them is that "Churchill does not have the temperament of the politician -- unlike so many politicians he is magnanimous * * * loyal to a fault (witness his devotion to Edward VIII), self-willed, careless of consequence to himself."

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- Australia virtually regained from England the Ashes -- mythical symbol of cricket superiority -- today as it ran its first-innings score to 403 runs for six wickets in the fourth test match.

IT'S over the ocean again for S. Hurok. The veteran shopper in the world's cultural markets is headed for Paris where, on Feb. 7, he is to be at the Palais-Royal. At the Palais-Royal, if you have not already heard, the Jen-Luis Barrault-Madeleine Renaud acting company is enjoying one of its greatest successes, a revival of "La Vie Parisienne."

When Dr. Arthur Purdy Stout became president of the New York Cancer Committee last Wednesday, he reinforced an already well established reputation as one of the busiest retired professors in the country.
A truck brake safety development using air suspension on two new General Motors tractors was announced last week by the corporation's Truck and Coach Division.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Florida people don't seem to have much time to go fishing in the winter but Northern people catch some fish here once in a while to keep the sporting legend alive. Nobody calls them Yankees: this state is not in the business of low-rating visitors.

BECAUSE everyone except the most myopic apologist agrees that American schools suffer from grave deficiencies, and because many earnest citizens are groping for solutions, uncritical readers of Admiral H. G. Rickover's book are likely to applaud both its objections to and corrections for public education.

BACH'S B minor Mass is not what one would ordinarily consider a road-show attraction. Yet next season Robert Shaw is taking it on tour and so many places have asked for it that Columbia Concerts has had no difficulty booking it six nights a week for almost two months.

The Eisenhower Administration is finding it difficult to devise a satisfactory oil import plan. With the present voluntary restriction program breaking at the seams, it has become clear that a different approach must be made if effective curbs are to result.

CHILDREN of all ages have enjoyed C. W. Anderson's horse stories and illustrations for many years. His newest, "Pony for Three," will be appreciated primarily by the picture book age, although the vocabulary can be mastered by second graders.

HONG KONG, Jan. 31 -- Industrialization of communes throughout China has begun on a large scale, according to official Chinese Communist sources. Industry will soon have a "new look as a result," it was predicted.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 31 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes said this week that "several" intermediares were attempting to reconcile Mexico and Guatemala in their month-old shrimp dispute.

MIAMI BEACH -- The best authority on south Florida weather, namely the Miami Weather Bureau, reports, in that cautious, restrained way that weather bureaus have, that February here will be "near normal."

HAVANA, Sunday, Feb. 1 -- Capt. Pedro Morejon, second "war criminal" of the Batista regime condemned to death in Havana, was reported to have been executed by a firing squad in La Cabana fortress at 11:10 last night.

TORONTO, Jan. 31 -- The New York Rangers, led by Andy Bathgate's twenty-sixth and twenty-seventh goals of the season, crushed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5-2; tonight. A crowd of 13,463 saw the National Hockey League game.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 31 -- For long hours each day, and often far into the night, a group of students and European refugees sits quietly in a brightly lighted room and pores diligently over the voluminous pages of the Soviet Mathematical Review Journal.

SPADE, fork, trowel, hoe and flit gun -- these plus lawn mower and sickle were all the gardening tools needed in the old days. The horticultural life then was simple -- but toilsome. Today, thanks to the boom in the garden-supply business, home gardening has become easier and more enjoyable, too.
The city may send an incomplete 1959-60 fiscal program to Albany if Mayor Wagner's committee on off-track betting does not submit a favorable report before Feb. 9.
There is no reason or excuse to put off statehood for Hawaii. The fact that Alaska has become a state is a contributing argument for Hawaiian statehood, but it is only one among many.
PROVIDENCE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Rudy LaRusso scored 28 points and controlled the backboards tonight in leading Dartmouth to a 71-59 Ivy League basketball triumph over Brown.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31 -- Dr. Albert Beecher Crawford, director of the Office of Counseling, Placement and Research at Yale University, announced today he would retire June 30 after forty years with the university.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 24 -- The Communist party solemnly admitted Prince Alexander Cuza, founder of the Rumanian state, and his princely forerunners to the pantheon of this country's national heroes, today.
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- The Allied plan to delay the break-up of the Krupp industrial empire was regarded as an indication that it might never be broken up. For times have changed.
