A BIOGRAPHY is always an intrusion into somebody's privacy. The biographer's inner motivations move somehow between loving admiration and hidden resentment. Most writers reveal in their biographies more about themselves than about the characters they set out to describe.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan bitterly accused United States officials today of using "cold war thinking" about trade with the Soviet Union. The Soviet First Deputy Premier, in a report to the Soviet Communist party's twenty-first congress on his recent visit to the United States, accused the Americans of using discriminatory measures against the Soviet Union in the field of trade.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The British Foreign Office declined to comment tonight on its action in association with the United States and France in agreeing to set up a special commission to review the Allied order ordering the break-up of Krupp industrial properties.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 31 -- President Mohammed Ayub Khan, Pakistan's reluctant revolutionary, is getting full credit here for determined action to break the political power of big landlords.
Major crimes in the city last year increased 5.2 per cent over 1957 and misdemeanors were up 3.4 per cent.
"The Mistress," a Japanesemade drama, which will arrive at the Guild Theatre, Fiftieth Street west of Fifth Avenue, today is the week's sole film newcomer.

SIX fashion reporters were tempted to stowaway last week, but the ship sailed without them. They had boarded the Santa Rosa to see both Elizabeth Arden's new beauty salon and a showing of her resort-cruise collection for 1959.
Bread rolls and pastry may be in short supply today in some sections of the city and the suburbs.

HISSING the villains (parents) and groaning in sympathy for the heroes (teen-agers), a class at Jamaica High School recently previewed an educational film concerning the making of family decisions that effect adolescent members.

Former President Daniel Fignole of Haiti said here yesterday that he had twice formally asked for the right to return from exile after President Francois Duvalier's recent promise to restore democratic rule.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration's upcoming examination of national transportation problems and policy is already pointing to the possible coordination of all of the Government's transportation activities in one agency.

ROME, Feb. 1 -- Italy's weekold government crisis was overshadowed today by the leadership crisis in the Christian Democratic party. Many Italians were worried over what they regarded as an impending crisis of the parliamentary regime.

This morning, if all goes as planned, four Negro children will peaceably join 1,700 white students in the Stratford Junior High School of Arlington, Va., and seventeen Negro youngsters will be distributed among the 10,000 white boys and girls who attend six high schools in Norfolk.

The legion of those who are fighting to modernize the structure of our courts has now an objective on which all their efforts should focus: passage of the measure introduced in the State Assembly by Robert Walmsley, Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee. It is in the form of a proposed constitutional amendment embodying the proposals of the Judicial Conference, whose members include the highest ranking judges of the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Government is ordering the nation's largest food merchants to help determine whether too few hands hold too much power over the housewife's food dollar.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 1 -- The guilder continues strong. This is particularly reflected in the dollar quotation, which in terms of guilders has reached the level of 3.7 guilders. This is the Netherlands Bank's official lowest margin price.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York is negotiating a loan of $30,000,000 with New York banks to help finance immigration from Eastern Europe to Israel.
Baptists here and over the world observed yesterday as "Baptist World Alliance Sunday."
FONTANA, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Kaiser Steel Corporation dedicated $240,000,000 worth of expansion today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- James B. Carey resigned from the Board of Trustees of Howard University today as a protest against what he called the school's anti-union policies.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- The Burmese Army has begun a vigorous counter-offensive in its propaganda war with former Premier U Nu, who hopes to win back political power from Gen. Ne Win's interim Government after a general election.
A small ray of hope developed early this morning in the search for survivors of the Danish ship Hans Hedtoft, which disappeared Friday after hitting an iceberg off the southern tip of Greenland.
The New York Rangers gave one of their finest hockey exhibitions of the home season before a crowd of 15,168 at Madison Square Garden last night. They defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 4.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Wendy Hanson of Wilton, Conn., who won the Maclay Trophy national horsemanship championship at Madison Square Garden in November, qualified for another national equitation final at the Secor Farms Riding Club horse show today.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. moved yesterday to obtain legislation that would reduce the fire hazard of Times Square's huge billboards.

STONY POINT, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Not even Soviet competition is enough to spur Western nations to give the help essential to underdeveloped countries, the World Council of Churches' representative at the United Nations said here today.
Sol Hurok, the impresario, suggested yesterday that the government subsidize repertory theatre, ballet and opera companies.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Marty Furgol, who hadn't won a golf tournament since 1954, today rallied for victory in the $20,000 San Diego open. The 41-year-old pro from Lemont, Ill., shot a 3-under-par 69 for a 72-hole total of 274 to win the $2,800 first prize.
ARLINGTON, Va., Feb. 1 -Arlington County officials expect quiet acceptance tomorrow of Virginia's first school integration.

Striking tugboat workers voted by the narrow margin of 1,100 to 916 yesterday to continue a walkout that had begun at midnight. Mayor Wagner immediately called the disputants to City Hall in an effort to end the strike.

OLEGNA FUSCHI pianist, gave a debut recital at Town Hall last night as winner of the Concert Artists Guild Award. She was to have been heard Dec. 11, but a cut hand that required several stitches forced postponement.

One of the most interesting and illuminating developments in economic-statistical research in recent years -- and particularly over the past decade -- has been the increasing emphasis on the technique of "sampling" in this area.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Performing before a record-breaking throng of 32,000, Arthur Tokle of the Odin (N. J.) Ski Club today captured the Telemark Ski Club Class A jumping honors at this resort's 50-meter hill.

WHEN the original script was completed for the annual Baseball Writers' Show, it was as bulky a bundle as Eugene O'Neill's "Mourning Becomes Electra." Unfortunately, though, it didn't hit with the same dramatic impact. All it had was length. Although the O'Neill classic ran for six hours without losing its gripping intensity, the diamond wooing of the muses merely ran.
MADRID, Feb. 1 -- A group of liberal and Rightist Spaniards announced today the formation of a political party opposed to the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
The Bronx Community College will open today for 125 students and a faculty of sixteen. It will be in temporary quarters at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, at Sixty-ninth Street.

While your editorial of Jan. 28 is thought provoking, this writer is unable to agree with your basic approach -- that the Berlin impasse must be solved within the context of a general settlement with the Soviets on Germany or even on Europe.

Joseph Hayes has been signed by Irene Selznick to adapt a recent London success, "Any Other Business," for the Broadway stage next season. The drama, with elements of mystery and suspense, deals with a struggle for power within a British industrial concern.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 11 -The need for strengthening zoning regulations in the North Stamford area was stressed today by speakers at a mass meeting.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 1 -- Norfolk is awaiting with an air of studied casualness the first integration of its public schools tomorrow.
Russell Sherman, young New York pianist, tackled a bruiser of a piano concerto in his first appearance with the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

Domestic cotton price changes last week were mixed. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from 30 points ($1.50 a bale) up to 48 points ($2.40 a bale) down. The two nearest deliveries showed gains for the week, while all later months were off.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. charged today that Attorney General William P. Rogers was trying to "amend the Constitution by writing memorandums."
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 1 -Nearly 450,000 persons demonstrated in front of the Presidential Palace today in support of President Adolfo Lopez Mateos' recent break of diplomatic relations with Guatemala.

Last week's developments at the Soviet Communist party congress appear to provide the first official confirmation of rumors that the "anti-party group" commanded a majority in the party Presidium when it tried to oust Nikita S. Khrushehev from his post as First Secretary of the party in June 1957.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The political awakening of Africa, as demonstrated by recent riots in the Belgian Congo, has stimulated the State Department's search for meaningful African policies.

Your paper of Jan. 28, like many others, talks about forgiveness of the 1958 income tax. It is unclear why anybody uses such a misleading word. There has been no question of forgiving a year's tax. We paid income tax last year and we are going to pay one this year.

Majority Leader Joseph F. Carlino of the State Assembly apparently exploded yesterday any hope of the Wagner Administration that legalized off-track betting might rescue the city from its financial dilemma.
GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- Swiss men refused today to give women the right to vote in national elections.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis won his thirteenth national outdoor speed-skating title today with a finishing kick that routed his younger rivals.
The Army Reserve in the eight-state First Army area will assume the new pentomic shape effective May 1.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 -- Hank Greenberg, the former baseball star, was reported here tonight to have been divorced by his wife, the former Caral Gimbel of the New York department store family.
The American Federation of Musicians and three broadcasting networks agreed yesterday on terms for a new contract that runs until March 1, 1964.

Robert Degnan, 47 years old, assistant public relations director for the City Welfare Department, was killed in Queens about 9 o'clock last night when his auto smashed into a pillar on Grand Central Parkway at the Forty-fourth Street overpass. Apparently Mr. Degnan's eastbound car apparently swerved out of control, the police reported.
A new medical advisory committee on research consisting of fourteen top American scientists has been named to guide the National Foundation's expanded scientific program.
Bank holding companies have increased competition for banks but they have not prevented their growth, two New York University professors reported yesterday.

The Chinese, who are old hands at buildhlg gigantic walls, are applying the traditional skill to erecting the 50S-foot Shihmen Dam in Northern Taiwan. The dam, keystone of an $80,000,000 hydroelectlSc and water supply system, will be one of the highest in the Far East.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens slammed in two third-period goals tonight to salvage their third straight tie with the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 3. The National Hockey League game drew 16,896 fans, the Hawks' biggest home crowd in ten years.
The Welfare Department has recovered $24,363,939 in the last nine years from persons who improperly received the money in relief payments, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 (UPI) -President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina said today that he hoped his twelve-day visit to the United States would mark an end of Argentina's traditional neutralism in favor of greater cooperation with this country.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Except for South African gold mining shares, the stock markets were quiet last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Twenty-two prominent scientists, clergymen, editors and business and labor leaders called on the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain today to ban tests of nuclear weapons even if there was a risk of cheating.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The Legislature was bracing itself tonight against the expected shock of receiving tomorrow the largest budget and tax program in the state's history.

OTTAWA, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- A Transport Ministry spokesman said today that the Canadian and United States Governments had reached "common ground" on St. Lawrence Seaway tolls. He said detailed tariffs would be published within two weeks.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- The St. George Curling Club rink of Montreal, skipped by W. E. (Ted) Thompson, won the Ardsley Medal as the fourday Cuthbertson Bonspiel ended at the St. Andrew's Golf Club today.
Zachary Davis Wheat, a renowned outfielder for Brooklyn's Trolley Dodgers, yesterday was elected unanimously to baseball's Hall of Fame by the Old-Timers' Committee.

The appointments of Warren H. Burding and Henry M. Schachte as executive vice presidents of the Lever Brothers Company have been announced by Milton C. Mumford, newly elected president and chief executive officer. The company makes soaps, detregents, toilet articles and margarine.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 1 -Diplomats and officials here expressed the view tonight that Secretary of State Dulles would seek on his European trip this week to patch up Western differences over how to proceed on the German question.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 1 -- Indonesia's Communist party appears to have taken a stand at variance with the position of some of the nation's top leaders on a key aspect of President Sukarno's "guided democracy" concept.

KERRVILLE, Tex., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- An Air Force C-47 transport with twenty-eight men aboard crashed and burned near here tonight after running low on fuel. It had attempted to make an emergency landing in a freezing rain with jammed gear and ice forming on its wings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- One of the basic axioms of modern genetics -- the "individuality" of the gene -- has been challenged in research sponsored by the National Science Foundation.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Industrial and banking circles are waiting until March to decide whether the Government's financial and economic plan has been a success.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -Abraham A. Redelheim, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asked for funds today to meet the emergency created by the recent emigration of Rumanian Jews to Israel. He called this "the most urgent task before American Jewry."

Reports from the United Nations indicate that the newly created "Special Fund" for economic help to underdeveloped countries is getting off to a flying start. Under the vigorous leadership of Paul G. Hoffman, it has evoked a warm response from several countries that are in need and that welcome this means of obtaining help.
Providing housing without discrimination is essential in insuring equal protection of the law, a member of the Civil Rights Commission said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Republicans stepped up their defense of President Eisenhower's $77,000,000,000 balanced budget today as Democrats concentrated criticism on its military and public-welfare provisions.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 1 -- Stock exchange dealing was brisk last week, but volumes in general were not as large as usual and price movements were very erratic.
"THE SECOND AGONY OF ATLANTA," which was seen last night over the National Broadcasting Company's network, is certain to prove a highly controversial hour.

The city's Department of Air Pollution Control achieved statistical progress in enforcement last year. Dr. Leonard Greenburg, the Commissioner, announced yesterday that 1958 had produced more summonses, violation notices and office hearings than in any year since the department was organized in November, 1952.

SOUTHOLD, L. I., Feb. 1 -This picturesque village's blacksmith, 82-year-old Spencer W. Petty Sr., will turn over his tongs, hammer and title to a son here tomorrow. The son, Wilbur S. Petty, is as familiar a sight at the white-hot forge as is the father.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- The current trend in Western diplomatic circles here -- with notable exceptions in the cases of France and West Germany -- is to put security arrangements ahead of political settlements in any resolution of the Berlin crisis and the German problem.
The admission of general partners in three major investment firms were announced in month-end changes over the week-end.
Philip Morris, Inc., achieved record sales last year and increased its earnings 8.4 per cent over those of 1957, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president, reported in the annual statement released today.
Writing an advertisement can be relatively simple. So can writing a letter. But the creation of an ad containing a letter in an envelope is another matter.
HAVANA, Feb. 1 -- Two women and a man were killed and fifty persons were wounded early today when a hand grenade was thrown into a religious procession just outside Santiago de Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A joint congressional committee recommended today that this city pay less attention to its monuments and more to its suburbs.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Garret G. Ackerson Jr., United States Charge d' Affaires, returned here today to await official notice from the Hungarian Government about the restrictions it intends to impose on his legation.
I have made my last contribution to any single health organization, and, when I complete a solicitation which I promised to make, I shall have made my last solicitation for any such organization.
The New York City Transit Authority is to be congratulated for the many improvements in the facilities and service on the subways, particularly the West Side IRT line, which it has brought about.

John J. McCloy, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, sees no reason to think that the present bank merger trend is indicative of "a tendency toward monopolization of credit in the commercial banking field." "I don't believe," said he, "that banks generally have ever been subject to as much outside competition as at present from other financial institutions, such as insurance companies, savings and loan associations and savings banks."

Adlai E. Stevenson and Sherman Adams will have books published by Harper. Mr. Stevenson's "Friends and Enemies" is an account of his recent 7,000-mile trip in the Soviet Union. His book has been subtitled "What I Learned in Russia."
PONTREMOLI, Italy, Feb. 1 (AP) -The North Italian village of San Rocco di Gravagna has just decided again that its children will do without school as a matter of geography.
THE collection of personal income tax through withholding will be new to New York State but it is old stuff to Joseph Hawley Murphy, new State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.
Concertgoers whose memories go back to 1943 will remember Ethel Drehmann as the blonde young usherette on the east aisle at Carnegie Hall who sang the National Anthem with special fervor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Hearings on Federal school aid will begin on both sides of the Capitol this week with no Administration proposal as yet announced.
The New York Metropolitan Council of the American Jewish Congress charged yesterday that racial discrimination existed in the city's public schools.

IN Paris on the slope of Montmartre lives a novelist named Marcel Ayme who, if there were such a thing as absolute literary justice, would be at least as famous and as widely read as Albert Camus and Jean Paul Sartre. Underlying much of M. Ayme's work is a pessimism about human nature and the lot of man as despairing as that of those two thoughtful gentlemen.
The Transit Authority is seeking a separate lane for buses on two Brooklyn streets that are to become one-way thoroughfares.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 1 -Tioga, a 39-foot sloop sailed by Bradley P. Noyes of Marblehead, Mass., last night won the Lipton Cup "drifting match," a thirty-one-mile race that lasted more than eleven hours.
The temperature dropped sharply early today to 9 degrees, the lowest reading of the winter.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Sam Spiegel, producer, is close to concluding an agreement with Joseph L. Mankiewicz to direct his film version of the Tennessee Williams play, "Suddenly Last Summer," to star Elizabeth Taylor.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- The Paris spring fashion collections drifted to a pleasant close, at least for the press, with the Saturday showing of Jean Desses. Like most other designers, he had handsome wide-shouldered suits and beautiful ball gowns.
The head of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, called on Congress last night to enact legislation to ban the distribution of hate literature.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -Bullish influences were scarce and of limited force in futures trading last week as prices of all grains except wheat went into a succession of declines on the Board of Trade.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 1 -- Demands for military action if violence breaks out again on the Syrian border were made today by a number of Israeli newspapers.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell told a congregation of 1,800 persons yesterday that when religious liberty is destroyed political freedom quickly disappears. He spoke in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

One of mankind's great blessings is the ability to forget. They say, for example, that a woman does not long remember the acute discomfort of childbirth. And it is certain that man does not long remember clearly that gray misery that is a cold in the head.

FOUNTAIN INN, S. C., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- A four-place plane crashed near here last night killed Lieut. George W. Walker, 22 years old of 1103 East Thirtyfourth Street, Brooklyn, and injuring two other Army officers.
How high is up?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that one of the purpose of his trip to Europe this week would be to discuss with Allied governments the "possibility" of talks with the Soviet Union on Germany.
The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read urged Christians yesterday to be "the blessed third."
Jimmy Curran, the fantastic Scotsman who has done an outstanding job as track coach at Mercersburg (Pa.) Academy for forty-nine years, came to New York last Saturday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- An American Roman Catholic priest prayed in Moscow today for the conversion of Russia. The Rev. Louis F. Dion of Worcester, Mass., said low mass in a temporary chapel in the library of the French Embassy.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Four more of forty-eight men and women from the United States arrested in gambling raids here last week, posted bail today. Twenty-two, including two women, remained in jail.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Feb. 1 -Pigeons that suffer naturally from atherosclerosis are being used here to study the nature of heart disease.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- A perky little wire-haired fox terrier who will be 5 years old next month twinkle-toed off with the bestin-show title tonight in the forty-sixth event of the Eastern Dog Club show in the Commonwealth Armory.

Mrs. Robert Leighton Crawford of 1130 Park Avenue will give a cocktail party in her home today for her fellow committee heads for the eleventh annual Spring Frolic of the Humane Society of New York. Mrs. Crawford heads the patrons committee for the tea dance that will be held in the Plaza on April 1.

Joe Lapchick yesterday angrily criticized his St. John's basketball team for playing "lazy, stupid and horrible ball." Lapchick expressed his views in a telephone interview from his room in the Morris Inn on the Notre Dame campus at South Bend, Ind.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -Senate Democrats will set out this week to capture what Lyndon B. Johnson, majority leader, refers to as "Scalp No. 1."
The New York State Publishers Association will join with the New York Associated Dailies and the State Society of Newspaper Editors in a two-day convention starting today at the Plaza Hotel.
A mobilization of community forces will begin today to war on juvenile delinquency in a vast section of the lower East Side.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, called today for full investigation of the proposed merger of the Manufacturers Trust Company and Bankers Trust Company of New York.
They used to say that mutual funds were for the little man, the unsophisticated investor.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, won her third consecutive national figureskating crown today with a superb display of free figures.

ORANGES, unquestionably the most attractive of fresh fruits at this season, are likely to decline in price soon. This good news comes from Florida, where the citrus crop, although late in maturing, is bigger than last year's.
Volume dropped sharply last week in the steamship charter market. Rates clung to previous low levels.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 -- The volume of steel orders continued to soar last week and additional increases are expected this week. When all the sales figures are in they will show a much stronger January in the steel industry than had been expected by most sales people less than forty days ago.
MONTE CARLO, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- A former aide of Gen. Charles de Gaulle arrived today to help Prince Rainier run Monaco.
Union newspaper deliverers will vote in secret ballot today on new contracts with wholesale concerns that deliver papers in this city and the suburbs.

WILMINGTON, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Tom Lefebvre of Lake Placid won the New York State championship slalom today at the Whiteface Mountain Ski Center. Lefebvre, 23, ran the tight, forty-five-gate course on the Wilderness run in 46 seconds.

LITTLE ROCK, Feb. 1 -- In a record turnout, residents of the northeast Arkansas town of Hoxie voted yesterday not to remove from office two school board members who were on the board when integration came to Hoxie in 1955.

Passage of Mayor Wagner's bill to set up a nine-member charter revision commission was urged upon the City Council and the Board of Estimate yesterday in a report made public by the city affairs committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce.
Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce was named the recipient of the 1958 Catholic Institute of the Press award at a communion breakfast of the Institute at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Navy has adopted a high-priortiy, ten-year program designed to provide the United States with a fleet of modern oceanographic research vessels.

Considering the remarkable variety of languages heard in recent New York song recitals it would hardly have seemed possible for a singer to come up with an extensive literature in still another tongue. But Armen Guirag did just that in his recital of Armenian songs Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Guy Gendron scored three goals tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 6 -- 4 victory over the lastplace Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at the Garden.
The City Housing Authority has proposed three new public housing developments to the City Planning Commission, William Reid, chairman of the authority, announced yesterday.
The Knickerbockers again extended their hospitality to the cellar-dwelling Philadelphia Warriors at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
Asse Nordmo-Loevberg, Norwegian soprano, and Karl Liebl, German tenor, will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts on Wednesday, Feb. 11, in Wagner's "Lohengrin."

The National Association of Investment Companies announced over the week-end that 3,630,096 investors owned $13,242,388,000 of mutual funds at the end of 1958. These were both new highs and compared with 3,110,392 holders and $8,714,143,000 assets at the end of 1957.
Three hundred policemen stood in silent ranks outside a Brooklyn mosque yesterday while Moslems inside chanted Arabic prayers over the coffin of Patrolman Michael Talkowsky.

Maj. Gen. Roger James Browne, United States Air Force, retired, will take office as a Deputy City Administrator today. His appointment to the $20,000-a-year post was announced yesterday by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.

IN Faenza, Italy, when Giuseppi Baggi, the brickmaker's son, was a lad of 10 thirty-five years ago Maestro Pezzi, the schoolmaster, drove him from the classroom. At the schoolhouse door he said: "Baggi, please stay home.
One of the greatest proofs of God's love for mankind was the creation of the world, the Rev. Edward Hoffman of the Holy Cross Fathers, said here yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of Robert MacCrate of Port Washington, L. I., as an associate counsel at a salary of $17,800 a year.
The Social Security Administration of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare will move its lower Manhattan district office from 42 Broadway to 100 Church Street.

The nine-story building at 73-75 Cliff Street, on the northwest corner of Ferry Street just east of City Hall Park, has been sold by Charles F. Noyes and Morris Moskowitz. It is 50 by 118 feet and is in a district that was once dominated by the leather industry.
A state legislative committee said yesterday that New York State, with 43 per cent of the nation's narcotic addicts, was doing far less than other states to cope with the problem.
The art exhibitions scheduled for Thursday, Friday and Saturday were ommitted from the list of displays for the week published Sunday in The New York Times. They are:
"MOVE the pictures about on the walls so as to see them in a new light."

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- Pravda gave new details today in the Kremlin's campaign against its so-called anti-party opponents. The Communist party newspaper said they had planned to take over the Soviet Government on June 18, 1957.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Willie Hoppe, a legend in the billiards world, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. He was 71 years old.
The Broad Street Investing Corporation reported yesterday a new high in net assets for 1958.
THE SELECTION OF RETAIL LOCATIONS. By Richard Lawrence Nelson. 422 pp. F. W. Dodge Corporation, New York. $9.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Not long after Stalin's death General de Gaulle, then by his own choice an exile in France's political wasteland, was heard to observe "the age of giants is over." He reasoned that the world situation was no longer so critical that it required great men at the helm.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Art Tyler of Weston, Mass., and Tom Butler of Vista, Calif., won the two-man bobsled derby today while two other Americans narrowly escaped injury when a broken bolt sent them hurtling out of control down the mile-long course.
Casey Stengel, master of double talk, thought for a few moments last night that he was seeing double, too.

Title to two four-story buildings at 342 East Sixty-third Street and 1147 First Avenue, a T-shaped property surrounding the southwest corner, has been taken by the Walt Whitman School. This is a private elementary school now at 340 East Forty-third Street. The two structures were bought from Fred H. Hill through Robert R. Rainey of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 1 -- The merged labor federation is likely to take a long -- but sympathetic -- look at the bid for reaffiliation it has received from the outcast International Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Sixteen years after the following words made history they seem to express no startling national attitude:

CINCINNATI, Feb. 2 -- Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of the Hebrew Union College - Jewish Institute of Religion, said today that the "death of Jonah B. Wise bringht to an end a brilliant chapter in the renaissance of modern Judaism."

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 2 -- Joseph B. Lynch, 22 years old, of Fort Lee was held without bail today on charges of assault with a deadly weapon in the shooting Thursday of two policemen in Englewood. He was arraigned in Englewood before Magistrate Henry J. Bendheim.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Post Office Department acknowledged today that the strength of the French franc, not its weakness, had caught it short by nearly $3,000.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- A sudden show of generosity by the Treasury has assured the British arts a bright financial future for the years just ahead.
SALEM, Ore., Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Oregon State Senate ratified unanimously today the fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. This guarantees the right to vote regardless of race.

IN the capacity of author of "The Saintliness of Margery Kempe," which was acted at the York Playhouse last evening, John Wulp has set his mind on the main point: Margery Kempe was a pain in the neck.

Philip Vetter, whose mother put one of his hands over a gas burner when he was 9 years old to punish him for stealing, was described yesterday in Federal Court as a "punk who never grew up." His brother, Frank, received a handshake and a suspended sentence from Judge Archie O. Dawson.
Nat Holman was a quiet man yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Metropolitan Basektball Writers' Association at Leone's.

TOKYO, Feb. 2 -- A public opinion poll has seemed to confirm that the Emperor still has a strong hold on the affection of the Japanese people, at least in the capital. But few Japanese, it appears, want him to be a personal ruler.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 2 -- Turkey was back on speaking terms today with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

Canal-Randolph Corporation, Chicago real estate and development concern, has announced plans to acquire control of United Stockyards Corporation. The latter owns twelve public stockyards in Midwestern and Western states. In addition, it holds other real estate.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Don McDermott, a two-time Olympian from Englewood Cliffs, N. J., covered the 500 meters in 0:42.6 today and led an eight-man team into United States Olympic speed-skating berths.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The defense at the Tobyhanna conspiracy trial brought an admission from a Government witness today that one of the defendants had challenged the extent of another's request for more Federal funds.
Commissioner Moses said last night that the decision was "indefinite, contradictory and inconclusive." He accused the members of producing "official gobbledygook."

A financial foundation was established yesterday for the Massachusetts Port Authority -- a new state agency charged with administration of the Mystic River Bridge, Logan Airport, Hanscom Field, and the general cargo handling facilities of the Port of Boston.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- A long-range privately financed program for development of San Francisco's waterfront was unveiled today by the Port Authority.
CAIRO, Feb. 2 -- Three hundred and fifty Asians and Africans ranging in age from early twenties to mid-forties met today in the auditorium of Cairo University in the first Asian-African conference.
Net income of the Ford Motor Company plummeted to $95,700,000 in 1958 from $282,754,541 in 1957. Sales fell off by 28 per cent, to $4,130,300,000, from $5,771,300,000 in 1957.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 2 -- President Francois Duvalier announced today that he had relinquished his dictatorial powers to rule by decree. The authority, given to him by Congress July 31 for six months, expired automatically last Friday.

WHITE JLAINS, Feb. 2 -- The Democratic minority leader asked the Westchester Board of Supervisors today to ask the county's Albany legislators to oppose the state budget and a taxing set-up under which "a man would have to have seven children to get a fair deal."

The development of a new technique by Israeli scientists for diagnosing coronary thrombosis was reported here yesterday. It includes the use of radioactive iodine and a Geiger counter to locate the clots.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator William Proxmire protested today against Southern domination of Senate committees and urged adoption of a new rule to end it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Democratic Advisory Council depicted the Eisenhower Administration today as incapable of strong Government and freightened by new ideas.
Ray Felix, the Knickerbocker center, is 6 feet 11 inches tall and lives in a world contrived for people 5-8.
Bowling for the physically handicapped has been growing for the past few years. With the help of volunteers, paraplegics have joined the big army of enthusiastic bowling buffs.

A succession of witnesses before the Civil Rights Commission proposed yesterday that the Federal Government ban discrimination in all public housing and in private housing built anywhere in this country with any form of Government aid.

A pamphlet outlining the energy-saving features of the Department of Agriculture's kitchen-workroom at Beltsville, Md., has just been issued. The booklet outlines in text, sketches and photographs every nook and corner of the kitchen-workroom and explains now step-saving measures are best achieved in this room.

PALM BEACH, Fla. Feb. 2 -- Local statisticians are now playing happily with the figures from the Sailfish Derby that ended Saturday, and many a fine toy house can they build with their little blocks. But some simple results are evident that not even a staistician can do much with.
A new thirty-four-story office building in the financial district will be constructed as a jacket around an existing building in an effort not to disturb an active communications center inside.
A rise in the city retail sales tax from 3 to 4 per cent appeared yesterday virtually certain to replace the rapidly fading proposed levy on off-track betting on horse races.

MANY career girls who must rush home from work to prepare dinner for guests have ingenious ways of coping with the situation. One New Yorker tackles the problem forthrightly. She plans not one but two dinner parties for successive evenings.

Between 1945, when the Red Army occupied Budapest, and 1956, when Ede Pfeiffer, then 20 years old, escaped from Hungary after the uprising, he had been brought up to be a citizen of a Communist state. In "Child of Communism," which Crowell will publish next Monday, he describes his childhood and education and tells of the atmosphere in the schools of a Communist country.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 2 (Reuters) -- Facing Australian total of 476 and likely loss of the cricket series, England made another poor start on the third day of the fourth test match today, losing both opening batsmen for 11 runs.
PROVIDENCE, Feb. 2 -- Kelley said he quit as Brown football coach today to accept a similar post at Colgate because he needed "a new challenge."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Administration outlined today a long-range national program to explore the infinite reaches of space -- from the turbulent atmosphere of earth to the fiery coronas of distant stars.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- In his budget message today Governor Rockefeller recommended changes in taxes on personal income, inheritances and tobacco.

An unemployed junior druggist was arrested yesterday and accused of trying to collect rents for office space he did not own. His intended victims, the police said, are tenants of eight buildings operated by a leading real estate company.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- A modicum of relief for New Jersey and Connecticut residents subject to New York State income taxes is proposed in Governor Rockefeller's fiscal program.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture's announcement of last Friday that it had reduced the 1959 soybean parity 8 cents a bushel set off rather broad liquidation of September and November contracts today on the Board of Trade.

Operators of unlicensed bingo games in the city are now subject to court summonses rather than warnings. They had been allowed thirty days to apply for licenses after bingo became legal here on Jan. 2. The grace period ended yesterday.
The Avco Manufacturing Company has added a star football coach to its management team.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 2 -- United States officials said today that there appeared to be a good chance that a settlement would be reached soon of long-standing financial differences with Prague.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Tuesday, Feb. 3 -- Soviet guards at the border between West and East Germany were holding up a United States Army convoy of four trucks today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The American Retail Federation attacked the Kennedy labor control bill today, implying it would be worse than no legislation at all.
A mass resignation of teachers closed two evening high schools last night and sharply curtailed activities at the remaining fourteen.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb 2 -- When Indira Gandhi was a child, living alone much of the time in her grandfather's big house at Allahabad, she loved to climb on a table and deliver thunderous political speeches to the servants. Sometimes the lonely girl would march her dolls in a procession demanding independence for India. At the crucial moment she had the marchers rounded up by other dolls representing the police.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower and Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, leader of his opposition in the Senate, agreed today that more basic research was needed in the fight on heart disease.
Kings County Judge Hyman Barshay directed a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday to inquire into charges of graft and corruption in the Brooklyn office of the New York City Department of Buildings.

Since there isn't room behind home plate for more than one catcher at a time and since the Yankees have two top-flight receivers -- Yogi Berra and Elston Howard -- one is going to have to move to another position. Howard, who yesterday signed is 1958 contract for an estimated salary of $25,000, said it would be all right with him if Berra shifted to the outfield.

Approval of an $11,710,000 cooperative housing project in Woodside, Queens, was announced yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa. The 697-apartment development is to be sponsored by New York Typographical Union No. 6.
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Differences between the Western Allies on German questions are limited to matters of tactics and timing rather than substance, a French spokesman said today.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 2 -- Strikes were called in three schools here today in protest against the appointment last week of Senora Julia Quinonez Ydigoras as Minister of Education.
The "big three" copper producers raised the price of refined metal 1 cent a pound yesterday to 30 cents, the highest level since mid-June of 1957.

Lovers of classical music may be aware of the fact that 150 years ago today the composer of such great and romantic works as the Elijah Oratorio, the incidental music to Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," the beautiful violin concerto in E, the symphonies subtitled the Scotch, the Italian and the Reformation, was born in Hamburg, Germany.

Stocks sagged yesterday after a strong start. Heavier steel production and a rise of 1 cent a pound in copper prices started the day with a good gain. Later January automobile production figures looked good only for American Motors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The Senate voted today to spend $3,522,000 for investigations in 1959, but the total did not cover all the inquiries planned for this year.
Sales of tile eight major department stores in the New York area last month showed a gain of 2.2 per cent over those of January, 1958.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- Pravda today branded as "outrageous" the decision of the International Basketball Federation to disqualify the undefeated Soviet team from the world championship finals in Santiago, Chile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, Chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, urged the Federal Trade Commission today to investigate "white coat" advertising by drug manufacturers.
An increase in the New York City 3 per cent sales tax could reduce sales by $750,000,000 and bring in less revenue than expected, according to a new study by a New York University economist.

A desperate flicker of hope for the survival of at least some of the ninety-four passengers or crew members of the Danish ship that struck an iceberg last Friday faded in the thin air where it originated yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2 -- Small business was warned today it would lose further ground in its fight against big business monopoly unless it stood firm against pricing abuses and the demands of large buying syndicates.
TRENTON, Feb. 2 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner presented a record but balanced budget to a joint session of the Legislature today.
The chaotic game of musical chairs has begun for the thousands of high school students who have applied for admission to college next autumn, with or without scholarships.
A strike by 4,000 New York harbor workers enters its third day today with no settlement in sight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Treasury bill rate dropped sharply this week, the Treasury reported tonight. The average interest rate on $1,400,000,000 of ninety-one day bills was 2.721 per cent compared with 2.975 per cent last week, and the rate on $400,000,000 of 182-day bills was 3.107 per cent this week compared with 3.337 per cent last week.
The British Government opened a campaign here yesterday for support in a sharpening dispute with the United States over rival air-navigation systems.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- A United States Communist told his Soviet comrades today that his party "would not allow the imperialist death merchants to plunge the United States into a war."
DETROIT, Feb. 2 -- The General Motors Corporation gave the State of Michigan a helping hand today.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 2 -- Public school integration came peacefully to Norfolk today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, introduced an education aid bill today carrying $3,800,000,000 for a five-year program of school construction and teacher salary increases.
A shipload of oil from behind the Iron Curtain that may be the first of a series of shipments to this country is expected in New York this month.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- An unofficial computation put the net cost of Governor Rockefeller's recommended tax increases today at about $42 a year for a typical family earning $4,500 to $7,000 a year. This amounts to an increase of nearly 50 per cent.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- The Havana police announced today they were holding Alan Robert Nye, 31-year-old Chicagoan, on charges of coming to Cuba to kill Fidel Castro. Another plot to kill Dr. Castro was reported to have been discovered in Santiago.

The Hungarian puppet regime of Janos Kadar has warned this country to establish "normal" diplomatic relations with it or suffer the consequences of refusal. When the American Government returned the Hungarian note as "offensive" and "insulting" the Kadar regime imposed immediate reprisals by "limiting" the activities of the American Legation in Budapest, with the threat of a complete break of diplomatic relations in the background.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington accused the Eisenhower Administration tonight of false economy in not budgeting funds for flood control and water resources development.
The formation of a new unit to conduct advanced research on super rocket fuels was announced yesterday by the Esso Research and Engineering Company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Terry Brennan, deposed as football coach at Notre Dame, tonight said he would join a Chicago investment banking firm in April instead of accepting any of six head coaching offers he had received.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The head of one of Britain's largest steel companies plunged headlong today into a political tempest that was blowing up over a market research survey on nationalization.
After singing her intensely emotional farewell at the end of Act II of Verdi's "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera last night, Antonietta Stella fainted dead away.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Tuscarora Indians won a major and perhaps decisive victory over New York State today.

In your issue of Jan. 23 Professor Emeritus Alvin H. Hansen of Harvard seems to argue that because wholesale prices have been rising for a good many decades there is nothing warranting anxiety in the present continuing inflation. Professor Hansen is to be thanked for putting the problem in historical perspective.

Directors of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., proposed yesterday a three-for-one common stock split, subject to stockholder approval at the annual meeting on April 15. The two additional shares would be issued about May 15.
Milwaukee County, Wis., sold three blocks of various purpose bonds yesterday to three syndicates. The total was $14,029,000.
John T. Clancy, Borough President of Queens, announced yesterday that he was dismissing Vincent T. McCarthy from his $20,000-a-year position as Commissioner of Borough Works.

On the American Stock Exchange, Providence Gas Company, Pepperell Manufacturing Company (sheets and pillow cases) and Reliance Insurance Company have something in common.. All have paid dividends for more than one hundred consecutive years -- 110, 107 and 101 years, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- The International Monetary Fund today announced endorsement of a plan to raise its capital by more than five billion dollars to cope more effectively with the free world's financial problems.
American Airlines announced yesterday that it would convert ten of its DC-7B passenger planes to cargo aircraft.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- A suggestion that the Maltese might resort to violence in pursuit of their national ambitions was raised in Parliament today.
Union deliverers voted yesterday to ratify a new two-year contract with wholesale companies that distribute newspapers in the city and suburbs.

ROME, Feb. 2 -- A quadrum-virate was appointed today to make the top political decisions for the Christian Democratic party in place of Amintore Fanfani. Two of its members immediately consulted President Giovanni Gronchi, who is still pondering how to solve the Cabinet crisis brought about by Signor Fanfani's resignation as Premier a week ago.
New York's picturesque and often troubled Lower East Side was designated yesterday as a "great natural laboratory" to study prevention and control of juvenile delinquency.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Saratoga will continue to hold its monopoly over thoroughbred horse racing in New York State during August.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 2 -- The West German Government committed itself today in favor of a Big Four foreign ministers' conference.
PARlS, Feb. 2 -- The spring fashion shows in Paris came to an end today and, from all reports, the finale was a disappointing one.

Steel production increased moderately last week, following a setback attributed to floods in the Midwest the week before. The industry turned out 2,178,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.

NEW YORK University has not as yet much to be proud of in the way it has run Town Hall. In fact, its chief effect on its new property has been to keep it much emptier than usual by too high a rent scale.
TRENTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Some 300 striking convicts in shops at the State Prison here went back to work today after getting a 5-cent-a-day rise.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Where is the money coming from?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Six million dollars in Federal funds for student loans was allocated today to 1,227 colleges and universities.
Soviet successes in weapons development have placed a new condition on our foreign-policy decisions, Joseph E. Johnson, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- The East German Communists are getting ready to sign a separate peace treaty with the Soviet Union and other East bloc countries, informed diplomatic sources in East Berlin said today.

AN exhibition of 220 French drawings assembled from public and private collections in America will open to the public today at the Metropolitan Museum. It compares very favorably with the big although somewhat smaller show from French museums and other European collections seen six years ago at the Metropolitan.

ERNIE KOVACS appeared last night in a comedy entitled "Symbol of Authority," which had a gentle warmth in its intent but hardly any credibility in its execution. He was seen on the "Desilu Playhouse" over Channel 2.
Fundamental Investors, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of 40 per cent, or more than $180,000,000, in net assets during 1958.

THE legend of Don Juan turns up in many literatures, though it is most at home in Spain. It has carried some of Mozart's finest music and Byron's raciest cantos. Not to mention the ideas and measures of so diverse a lot as Moliere and Goldoni, Gluck and Corneille and George Bernard Shaw.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Oklahoma Natural Gas Company moved today to withdraw a major gas case from the Supreme Court. The case raises the question whether the Federal Power Commission may approve a new pipeline project without first passing on the price to be paid for the supply of gas.
World sugar futures fell to new lows for the life of the contracts, and most domestic sugar positions dropped to the lows yesterday. Cocoa futures also declined to new lows for the move.

In his first exhibition at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery, 24 East Sixty-seventh Street, Ralph Humphrey shows a group of paintings, each of which is keyed to a single dominant color. He is a romantic painter searching for a transcendant expression.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 2 -- Virginia's peaceful integration today won the approval of the Governor and resulted in the quick recessing of the Legislature.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to approve a record rise of $277,000,000 in state taxes to finance a $2,041,000,000 state budget for the fiscal year 1959-60. It is the first budget in history to pass the $2,000,000,000 mark.

Some diabetic children from the Greater New York area will receive four-week scholarships at Camp Nyda in Burlingham, N. Y., as a result of the evening performance of "Redhead" at the Forty-Sixth Street Theatre on Feb. 25.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff cautioned today against signing a nuclear weapons test-ban agreement with the Soviet Union without providing adequate control safeguards.
The City Department of Correction's annual report for 1957, released yesterday, shows 124 per cent growth in inmate population in the twelve-year period from 1945 through 1957.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Audrey Hepburn, who suffered injuries to her back on a film location in Mexico last week, arrived at Los Angeles International Airport this afternoon in a private ambulance plane for further medical treatment. She was taken by ambulance to her home in Beverly Hills.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's daughter won unanimous election today as president of his ruling Congress party. Mrs. Indira Gandhi is the third generation of her family and the third woman to serve in the post.
A second dispute has arisen here over the hiring of a Hollywood director for a local film production.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller's tax proposals would affect nearly every class of taxpayers in the state. Most people's taxes would go up. Some would go down. A few would remain the same.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 2 -- What was described as a major step toward the formation of the United Church of Christ was taken here today. The step was announcement of plans for the overseas misson program of the United Church, a merger of the Evangelical and Reformed Church and the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches.
Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's recorded talk broadcast over a state-wide television network last evening as recorded by The New York Times:
A state mediator reported no progress yesterday toward ending the strike of 9,200 bakers employed by a variety of shops producing bread, cakes, rolls and pastry.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 2 -- The United Automobile Workers went on strike today at eight plants of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company.
Following a three-month search for a new agency, the Magnavox Company has awarded its advertising account to the Marschalk Pratt division of McCann-Erickson, Inc.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 2 -- Indonesia has asked Washington to sell her about $10,000,000 in small arms and related gear to equip twenty new battalions, a senior army officer said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Administration has run into a serious Congressional roadblock in its effort to get an emergency $225,000,000 appropriation for the Development Loan Fund.
Richard Dahl, the European high-jumping champion, arrived from Sweden yesterday, eager to test himself against this nation's seven-foot jumpers, John Thomas and Charley Dumas.
A MONTH-LONG sale of products made by the blind opens today at Hammacher Schlemmer. The sale is being held in conjunction with the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- New York University played a possession game for the final five minutes tonight, preserving a 55-54 basketball victory over Boston University. Al Barden of the Violets and Jackie Leaman of the Terriers scored 17 points each.

Governor Rockefeller's first budget message to the New York Legislature proposes state expenditures of $2,041,000,000, an increase of $240,000,000, and asks for $277,000,000 in tax increases. The budget relies, for "balancing," on $100,000,000 in bond issue borrowing, and on withdrawal of $47,000,000 from Capital Construction Fund reserves.

Charles Abrams, the outgoing State Commissioner Against Discrimination, yesterday urged reconsideration of an appeal on the Arabian American Oil Company's discrimination against Jews in its employment practices.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The withholding system for state income taxes proposed by Governor Rockefeller today would be used to catch tax dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- This city, as usual, is dominating the national debate over the Presidential nominees of 1960. It is providing most of the candidates and most of the political headlines, but in the last analysis it will probably not be this capital but the state capitals that will pick the nominees.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- Who rules the Soviet Communist party, and how?
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller sent the names of three new members he proposed for the State Banking Board to the Senate tonight for confirmation.
Record net earnings of $31,223,008 were attained last year by the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, despite a 2.5 per cent drop in sales, according to the annual report of Benjamin F. Few, president.
DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company asked the Michigan Supreme Court today for a rehearing of an unemployment compensation case involving a strike in Ohio.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Republican legislators greeted Governor Rockefeller's tax increase program today like small boys faced with a giant spoonful of nasty medicine.
The mercury dropped to the lowest point of the season in the metropolitan area yesterday, and clear skies promised six weeks more of winter to those who hold by Ground-Hog Day.

The measles and chicken pox season, now in full swing, brings with it problems for both the parent and child alike. A variety of quiet pastimes will keep young patients cheerful and busy. They can make soap sculpture, collages, paper bag puppets or scrap books.

TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Various stock purchases and sales made by and on behalf of Dave Beck were described by Fred Loomis, Seattle investment counselor in the former teamster president's income tax evasion trial today.
Senator Lyndon B. Johnson proposed last night that the United States set up an advisory committee of business men to formulate policies to defeat a world economic challenge by the Soviet Union.
TRENTON, Feb. 2 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed today a bill that would permit Camden County to build a new stadium in its bid to entice the Philadelphia Phillies to settle in the Jersey pines.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 11,672 pints of blood in January.
President Eisenhower and Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion of Israel emphasized in messages last night that cultural exchange between nations was an important force for world peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Senate Banking Committee approved today an omnibus housing bill containing about $1,000,000,000 more than President Eisenhower wanted in spending authority for the present and next fiscal years.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 -- Twenty-two United States citizens sat in a Mexican jail today in a burgeoning international cause celebre.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller chatted for half an hour today with 200 Protestants, members of the New York State Council of Churches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House Insular Affairs Committee added to the Hawaiian Bill today a provision designed to make certain that a majority of the island voters wanted statehood as soon as possible.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The continued presence of Fulgencio Batista is "repugnant and unpleasant" to the Dominican Republic, the Government radio says, backing a suggestion that he get out.

ROME, Feb. 2 -- Pope John XXIII has cited the belief in the Trinity and the cult of the Virgin Mary as a doctrinal platform on which Roman Catholics and the separated Christians of the East might meet.

The bull market in stocks in the United States is spreading into European shares as the result of two dissimilar buying forces. One force is speculation springing from the idea that stock values abroad are trailing the price heights of the New York market and for that reason are a "good buy." Whether this is true or false would stump many an accountant.

BALBOA, C. Z., Feb. 2 -- Ocean-going commercial ships transiting the Panama Canal set a record during January when 826 moved from ocean to ocean. The figure was thirteen higher than the previous record, set in October, 1957.
The Navy's mightiest new mailed fist, the super attack aircraft carrier Independence, put to sea for the first time yesterday -- but it wasn't easy.

MADRID, Feb. 2 -- Dionisio Ridruejo, the most outspoken opponent in Spain of the Franco dictatorship, was convicted in the Supreme Court here today on two charges of defaming Generalissimo Francisco Franco and carrying on "illegal propaganda." But he was set free.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Following are excerpts from the budget submitted to the Legislature today by Governor Rockefeller:
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- British Government securities and South African gold mining shares continued to improve in the stock market here today, but industrials remained irregular.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 -- President Arturo Frondizi returned today from an official visit to the United States. En route he stopped in Santiago, Chile, for conferences with President Jorge Alessandri of Chile. Dr. Frondizi was welcomed by several thousand people at Municipal Airport.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 -- President Arturo Frondizi returned today from an official visit to the United States. En route he stopped in Santiago, Chile, for conferences with President Jorge Alessandri of Chile. Dr. Frondizi was welcomed by several thousand people at Municipal Airport.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller's plan for the forgiveness of 1958 state income taxes would really pay off only when a person died.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Senate Investigations subcommittee called today for a new Federal law to check a confidence racket that it says may net as much as $50,000,000 a year.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Alva Kelley, Brown University football coach, was appointed head coach at Colgate today.

BRAZIL graciously saved the United States from deeper embarrassment during the world amateur basketball championships in Chile last week by outscoring out inept and maladroit heroes in their farewell game. Otherwise the North Americans would have taken the title from the Soviet Union by default. And that would have magnified our utter disgrace.

NEWARK, Feb. 2 -- An 18-year-old youth and a 15-year-old companion were charged, today with breaking and entering and the needless killing of an animal in the burglarizing of a camera shop last Friday. A 16-year-old accomplice is still being sought.
A Fire Department lieutenant was dismissed yesterday for neglect of duty.
AMESBURY, Mass., Feb. 2-- The parking lots around the plant of the Merrimac Hat Company, Inc., began filling up today with the cars of the company's new part owners, the union members.

Concerned because "many peoples dislike Americans," Cardinal Spellman has increased the Archdiocese of New York's share in the Catholic Bishops Relief Fund for foreign aid by 10 per cent. The contribution this year will be about $440,000.
The Board of Education will begin its first assessment of the value of the Board of Regents television programs today.

It will be a while before there is a more ferocious fist fight at the St. Nicholas Arena than the one waged there last night between Harold Carter and Bob Woodall, heavyweights with power in both hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The United States National Committee for the International Geophysical Year announced today the completion of a 1,629-mile scientific study expedition from Little America to McMurdo Sound, Antarctica.

Data purportedly showing the need for even higher automobile liability insurance rates than those sought since the fall of 1957 have been submitted to the State Insurance Department by the insurance industry.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley has been indirectly quoted in The Times recently as making, some extremely broad statements in praise of one-way avenue traffic. These statements are so hard to believe that I should like to see the Commissioner cite his evidence or else dig up other support for this wishful cure-all to his headache.
MIAMI, Feb. 2 -- Twenty-eight tautly tuned yachts, including many first-time starters on the Southern ocean racing circuit, will sail at noon Tuesday in the twenty-first annual Miami-to-Nassau race.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 2 -- Tom Hawkins led Notre Dame to a 72 -- 70 upset victory over St. John's tonight with 30 points -- 22 of them in the second half.
Your "'Hate' Literature" editorial of Jan. 25 focuses public attention on a problem which today is a source of growing anxiety to our society.
GENEVA, Feb. 2 -- The United States and Britain rejected today Soviet proposals for veto rights on the policing of a nuclear weapons test ban.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Italian teams took first and second places in the St. Moritz two-man bobsled championship today. The top American team of Arthur Tyler and Lieut. Tom Butler finished third in the final tune-up event before the world championships.
Dr. James R. Killian Jr. urged engineers yesterday to help end public confusion over the role of the engineer.
The situation in Haiti today is about as difficult to weigh and judge as any in the sphere of American foreign relations.
In the five-alarm fire in Times Square Saturday evening the huge metal advertising signs that encased the upper floors of the burning buildings hampered the firemen.

ALTHOUGH Walter Carringer, tenor from Columbia University, has sung fifteen times in Town Hall and three times at Carnegie Hall, it has invariably been as one of several soloists with orchestra or chorus.
Quidnuncs were predicting yesterday that John Gielgud might return to New York next season to act in "Much Ado About Nothing," which would be staged by him.

Protests against a Chet Huntley editorial on school integration resulted yesterday in the National Broadcasting Company scheduling a special television program to present "different points of view on the segregation issue."

The Union Carbide Corporation has sold its six-building complex at Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street to the Tishman Realty and Construction Company. The L-shaped parcel includes the entire west blockfront on Madison Avenue and frontage on Forty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that Secretary of State Dulles was "considering very seriously" countering Soviet proposals with new Western ideas for a solution of the German problem.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Italian teams took first and second places in the St. Moritz two-man bobsled championship today. The top American team of Arthur Tyler and Lieut. Tom Butler finished third in the final tune-up event before the world championships.
Dr. James R. Killian Jr. urged engineers yesterday to help end public confusion over the role of the engineer.
The situation in Haiti today is about as difficult to weigh and judge as any in the sphere of American foreign relations.
HIGH-STEPPING shoes at down-to-earth prices are the pride of Gimbels' new street-floor "Boot-ique."
The Board of Education last night ordered all but one of the city's sixteen evening high schools closed for the rest of the week. The schools normally have an enrollment of 30,000.

Broadway producers and theatre owners, normally an anarchic lot, took concerted action yesterday on earlier midweek matinees which begin on March 18. From then on, curtains for Wednesday and Thursday afternoon performances will rise at 2 o'clock, one-half hour earlier than usual.
MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- Marshal Rodion L. Malinovsky, Minister of Defense, told the Communist party congress today that Soviet missiles armed with hydrogen warheads could strike "precisely any point."
The long-delayed merger of the New York City councils of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has been accomplished.
A Pan American jet clipper scheduled to arrive here last night from Paris took a sudden dive of 30,000 feet, then leveled out and landed safely at Gander, Newfoundland. It carried 114 passengers.
More than 200 service empoyes began a sitdown strike last night in the Equitable Building in the financial district at 120 Broadway.
HAVANA, Feb. 3 -- Fidel Castro said last night that Cuba would be transformed within five years.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 3 (Reuters) -- Australia gained a first-innings lead of 236 runs over England on the fourth day of the fourth test today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The counsel for the Senate rackets committee charged today that Teamster Union funds were financing at least part of both sides of a lawsuit in United States Circuit Court of Appeals here.

Cries pierced the fog on the East River early this morning as survivors from the American Airlines plane tried to swim to shore. Many from the turbo-prop that crashed in the river were lost in the swift current.

SOMETIMES the course of a painter's work is the course of a river: moving in a single flow for a time, it then branches off, is interrupted or slackened in pace, but eventually becomes one again, catching up its past and rushing toward the open seas.

WHEN Zach Wheat first reported to the Brooklyn Dodgers at the tag-end of the 1909 season, he received a much friendlier greeting than the hard-bitten old-timers of that era normally gave to a rookie. A long, dispiriting campaign had robbed them of their zing and usual chip-onthe-shoulder bellicosity.
Stores throughout the country are going to the admired and imitated older brother in deciding what to stock for the younger brother.

SOME of the world's greatest chefs have been Frenchmen. But French women are among the best restaurateurs. One of the more successful of these distaff restaurant operators is Mme. Simone Prunier, now here en route to New Orleans for the Mardi Gras.
Los Angeles, Calif., raised $14,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the expansion of the city's recreational and park facilities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States told Congress today that the Kennedy-Ervin bill was wholly, inadequate to deal with dishonest, tyrannical labor leaders.

Ralph T. Reed, president of American Express Company, announced yesterday that John W. Houser would join the world-wide travel company as vice president in charge of domestic and foreign travel. The appointment is effective the first of next month.
The rising importance of Asia and Africa was emphasized last night by Dr. Sidney Hook, chairman of New York University's philosophy department, at the thirty-fourth Queens College commencement.
PARIS, Feb. 3 -- President Charles de Gaulle and twelve premiers from Africa sat down today in the Elysee Palace to organize the French Community.
Army's new head football coach was Navy-bound seventeen years ago until intercepted at the instigation of the man who named him to his present post.

Something new and refreshing is emerging from the squeeze on transit fares. The New York Times editorial of Jan. 27 takes due note of it. The Times deserves thanks for calling attention to the factors that help establish a fair measure of transit costs and the Transit Authority deserves the community's thanks for its willingness to consider practical measures of efficiency and economy.
All 225,000 officials and employes of New York City would be held to rigid standards of conduct under a new code of ethics proposed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- At President Eisenhower's direction, the Administration is preparing a grass-roots campaign to combat spending legislation beyond his budget.
NORFOLK, VA., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Navy Icebreaker Edisto has arrived in the Waddell Sea in Antarctica after a nonstop cruise from Norfolk, naval spokesmen reported today.

VALLETTA, Malta, Feb. 3 -- Malta harbor was brought virtually to a standstill today. Port workers stayed away from work for the "day of mourning" called by the Labor party leader, former Prime Minister Dom Mintoff, to protest Britain's revoking of the island's constitution.
GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- The fifty women teachers at the Basel girls' high school held a one-day strike today to protest against the defeat of women's suffrage in a nation-wide referendum Sunday.
The American Can Company last year set a new record in sales and increased its earnings by 10.1 per cent over those of 1957, according to the preliminary annual report of William C. Stolk, president.
ROME, Feb. 3 -- The Vatican acknowledged today that its idea of Christian unity was different from that of Protestants.
Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, yesterday established an endowment fund for expansion and emergency needs in Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Speakers at the annual convention of the Coalition of American Patriotic Societies said today it might be too late to save the American heritage.
MASON CITY, Iowa, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Three rock 'n' roll singers whose records and appearances have stirred millions of teen-agers were killed early today in a plane crash near here.
A gentle Arabian gazelle, about knee-high, has become the playful greeter of the animal nursery at the Bronx Zoo.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The Fifth French Republic comes of age this week when General de Gaulle's special powers end. On Thursday what is termed here a "parliamentary regime" begins. France will have an opportunity to judge the new Constitution's efficacy in terms of protecting the inherent democratic rights of Frenchmen.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Pressure was mounting today to ease the impact of Governor Rockefeller's proposed income-tax increases on married taxpayers.

WHEN Mark Twain died, in 1910, he was 74 years old, rich and world famous, but a sad, pessimistic and frequently bitter old man. His rich stream of humor, which had bubbled forth so spontaneously in his youth, had been drying up for a long time. Twain's opinions about human nature and the lot of man had grown bleaker and bleaker.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- A major victory by the Government in its campaign to end restrictive trade practices has restored free price competition in the Lancashire cotton yarn industry after a lapse of more than twenty years.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The British White Paper on the proposed European free-trade area, published Saturday, throws additional light on the split in Western Europe that resulted from the plan. This split is not likely to be overcome soon.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 3 (UPI) -- A B-47 Stratojet bomber crashed into a swampy, wooded area about twenty-five miles northeast of here tonight. Little Rock Air Force base officials said the three crewmen aboard were killed.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Senate today booted home a bill that would add five days of flat track racing to the state's present calendar.
BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company intends to compete on an all-out basis for more of the farm implement business, two of its top executives said today.
The Screen Directors International Guild yesterday placed pickets outside the Fox-Movie-tone Studios, Tenth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.
New York's city and state administrations joined forces yesterday at a City Hall conference designed to bring the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight title fight to New York.
