HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- A new attempt will be made to clear up the two-year mystery of Robert Rich -- the writer who failed to materialize after being voted an Academy Award for "The Brave One."
A memory-jogging show depicting New York theatres of days gone by opens today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Administration's ideas on civil rights legislation were presented today to Republican leaders of Congress.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Six of the eighteen western Aden protectorate states have agreed on a Constitution for a proposed federation, the Colonial Office announced today.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 -- A survey of problems hampering the garment trades was presented here today by members of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

January was a good dividend month for stockholders, with the recovery in corporate profits reflected in more liberal cash payments. In fact, Standard Poor's Corporation, which makes a business of such research, said January was the "most rewarding" month for shareholders in two years, taking seasonal factors into consideration.

The twenty-story and penthouse apartment building at 205 East Seventy-eighth Street, northeast corner of Third Avenue, has been sold by Rose Schwartz after an ownership of fifteen years. Herbert Geller and J. M. Crawford of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- A visit to Moscow by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan seemed probable tonight on the eve of Secretary of State Dulles' visit to Britain.

Management in the shipping industry must achieve the unity of action recently developed by maritime labor unions. Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A group of economists told the Congressional Joint Economic Committee today that there were lots of things the Government could do to curb price increases without breaking up big business and labor.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Government securities section was again the most active and buoyant in the stock market here today. Elsewhere, the demand was fairly selective and movements small and irregular.

PIANO-PLAYING in the great tradition was the order of business at Carnegie Hall last night, where Louis Kentner was soloist with Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra in the Brahms B flat concerto.

With Richie Guerin netting the final 6 points, including the deciding basket twenty-three seconds before the buzzer, the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Syracuse Nationals, 115 -- 114, at Madison Square Garden last night.

The American premiere of "Aparajito" on Feb. 15, at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, will be for the benefit of the Prime Minister of India's Relief Fund, it was announced yesterday. The imported drama, an Edward Harrison release, is the second film of Satyajit Ray's trilogy on Indian family life.
Search planes and ships continued to search the icy waters south of Greenland yesterday for the little Danish ship Hans Hedtoft and her ninety-five passengers and crew.

Renfield Importers, Ltd., liquor importing concern of Newark, has acquired the Medley Distilling Company of Owensboro, Ky., for more than $10,000,000 in cash.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- A United Nations mission to West Africa has recommended that the world body agree to end its trusteeship over the French Cameroons so the territory can attain its independence next Jan. 1.

World sugar futures continued to fall to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by prospects of ample supplies for the coming season. A lower spot price also contributed to the weakness.
Contract bridge made its bid for entry into the electronic age last night.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 3 -- President Syngman Rhee reiterated today his pledge that the controversial National Security Law would not be used to curtail freedom of the press and other democratic rights.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Led by a former two-time Olympic member, four more speed-skaters qualified for the sixteen-man 1960 United States Olympic squad by their performances in the 1,500 meters today.

Self supporting, tax paying railroads are unfairly handicapped by having to meet competition that is tax-supported, Anthony J. Winkler said yesterday. Mr. Winkler is chairman of the Trunk Line Central Passenger Committee of the Eastern Railroads.
Cotton figures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 6 points off on old July, the only decline, to 5 to 18 points up on other months. A point is 5 cents a bale.

The city moved yesterday to dispose of lands that are part of its old Long Island water supply system.
The Transit Authority has asked Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley to reconsider his refusal to permit a separate bus lane on two Brooklyn one-way streets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower made new appointments today to the twelve places on the International Development Advisory Board of the International Cooperation Administration.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 3 -- The eventual reunion of all Christendom seemed extremely remote here today at a meeting of leading Lutheran clergymen.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) --Betty Kerby, a 28-year-old Akron golfer, won medalist honors in the forty-first annual Palm Beach women's amateur tournament today with a 2-over-par 72.
The election of Thomas J. McHugh and Leo V. Bodine as directors of the Diamond Gardner Corporation, manufacturer of forest products, was announced yesterday by Robert G. Fairburn, president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture will announce within the next few days a new export subsidy program designed to recapture for the United States its share of the world cotton market, an informed source said today.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, Feb. 3 -- Five United States Army enlisted men bedded down in barricaded trucks at this border checkpoint tonight to await the outcome of a new quarrel with the Soviet Union over free access to Berlin.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Feb. 3 -- A one-day-a-week market, where the wares are used cars and only carefully investigated auto dealers may buy and sell, is housed here in a butterfly-roof structure in the New Jersey Meadows.

Vincent Astor, millionaire real estate owner and head of the American branch of the famous family, died yesterday in his apartment at 120 East End Avenue. Mr. Astor, who was 67 years old, succumbed to a heart attack at 1 A. M.
MIAMI, Feb. 3 -- The return of Hartack -- first name of Bill or Willie, depending on how one wants to stand in his favor -- is the major item on the racing agenda for tomorrow at Hialeah.

An American Airlines Electra turbo-prop plane crashed in the East River after it overshot a landing in the fog at La Guardia Airport late last night. At least twenty-two persons were killed and thirty-nine other persons were still missing at 5 A. M. today.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Treasury announced today another substantial gain in the gold and convertible currency reserves held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area.
MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- Mikhail G. Pervukhin confessed his "mistake" to the Soviet Communist party congress today.
TRENTON, Feb. 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called today for stricter enforcement of traffic laws, more adequate training of municipal policemen and continuing public education to cut traffic deaths.
The state's newspaper editors heard strong criticism of Governor Rockefeller's press relations yesterday. They decided to send a committee to seek improvements.
The City Council called upon the Legislature yesterday to permit amendment of New York's City Charter and Administrative Code to provide for a new Department of Real Estate.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Federal District Judge James C. Connell denied to the Department of Justice today subpoenas to bring labor leaders and their records before a Federal grand jury for investigation of the vending machine and Juke 'box business.

Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society will leave New York on Feb. 22 for an eight-week tour of the Far East. The visit will be under the sponsorship of the President's Special International Program for Cultural Presentations, administered by the American National Theatre and Academy.

Plans have been completed for this year's sessions of the Thursday Afternoon Lenten Sewing Class of the Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies Hospital, which has held meetings for almost sixty consecutive years.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The long general price decline in the grain futures market came to a halt today on the Board of Trade. All contracts finished with moderate to good gains.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- James A. Lundy, sworn in here today as chairman of the Public Service Commission, immediately aligned himself with Governor Rockefeller's direct, or wade-right - in - up - to-the-hips, approach to state problems.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was reported tonight to have offered support for a plan to unify Germany through free elections if West Germany consented to negotiate the arrangements with the East German Communist regime.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The designers of London do not want to set the fashion world on fire; they just want to make clothes that women will want to wear and wear.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Pimlico owners confirmed today that they had decided not to close the 89-year-old track. They outlined plans to give a new look to the track.
Middle South Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported new highs yesterday in nearly all 1958 operations.

Thirteen employes of the Department of Buildings' Brooklyn office yesterday balked at signing waivers of immunity when called before a grand jury. The jury is investigating possible graft and corruption in the department.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Legislature today elected J. Carlton Corwith of Water Mill, L. I., to succeed Dr. T. Norman Hurd as a member of the state Board of Regents. Dr. Hurd recently resigned to become the Director of the Budget under Governor Rockefeller.

Early next week, the Fact-Finding Committee, an over-all body representing New York's various entertainment unions, will consider a proposal calling for a concerted appeal to the city for support of a free theatre program.
The Russian Orthodox Theological Fund will benefit from the first American concert of the Kedroff Vocal Quartet, which will take place at Town Hall on March 9.

200 Hours Awake Peter Tripp's exploit of staying awake for more than 200 hours is something to be applauded, of course, for it not only added to the sum total of scientific knowledge but also aided the March of Dimes, certainly a worthwhile charity.

The proposals put forward in the President's economic report for setting up additional machinery within the Administration for dealing with the problem of price inflation were completed over the week-end when Vice President Nixon was named to head a new Cabinet body to be known as the Cabinet Committee on Price Stability for Economic Growth.

The philanthropic work of the Dixie Club of New York, Inc., will benefit from a card party to be held in the Terrace Room of the Plaza on Feb. 26. Mrs. Philip E. Frank and Mrs. Richard A. Garfield are chairman and vice chairman of the benefit committee.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 3 -- The second shanty fire here in a week took the life of man early this morning. It was the fourth shanty-fire death; three tiny children died in a converted chicken coop last Thursday.

A leading Cuban businessman said here yesterday that without Fidel Castro's summary justice for "war criminals" widespread disorder and 4,000 to 5,000 deaths could have been expected after the fall of President Fulgencio Batista.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3 -Easily read road signs, similar to those on the New York Thruway, are being installed on Westchester's 149 miles of county roads.

ROME, Feb. 3 -- President Giovanni Gronchi rejected today the resignation of Premier Amintore Fanfani's Government. He instructed Signor Fanfani to present himself to Parliament and ask for a formal vote of confidence.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 3 -- Jack Frye, one of the founders of Trans World Airlines, was killed in an automobile accident here tonight. He was 54 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The long-rumored resignation of Thomas S. Gates Jr. as Secretary of the Navy was announced today at the White House.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 3 -- The chief charm of inlet fishing at Stuart is that an angler may use about any kind of tackle he likes and never knows just what he will bring up. Right now it might be bluefish, mackerel, pompano, weakfish or ladyfish, but it might also be one of a dozen other fish.

Henry Banks, new competitions director, and Thomas Binford, president of the United States Auto Club, were in New York last week-end conferring with various persons interested in furthering the club's expanded program.
NORFOLK, Feb. 3 -- The first full day of integrated public school classes in Norfolk took seventeen Negro students safely over a delicate moment today in six previously all-white secondary schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Air Force has coined a new word, "Aerospace," to cover both the earth's atmosphere and outer space.

BRIDGETON, N. J., Feb. 3 -- A plan to have a Soviet official lecture to the combined history classes at Bridgeton High School today fell through because he had failed to ask the State Department for clearance.

Shipments of finished steel products from steel mills amounted to 59,914,433 net tons last year, compared with some 79,900,000 net tons delivered in the previous year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Eleven manufacturers have joined in a program to spur sales of electric ranges. The theme of the campaign, which also will urge utilities to support the program with advertising in local markets, is "the big change is to the electric range."

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3. (UPI) -- Negotiations are nearly complete in New York for a large loan from private banks to Pemex, the Mexican Government's oil enterprise, to finance an expansion program, a top Pemex spokesman said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Governor Rockefeller and Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Republican of Buffalo and Senate majority leader, went on record separately today in favor of revising the state's banking law at the present session of the Legislature.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 3 (UPI) -Aviation sources reported here today that national airlines of five European countries were discussing closer cooperation to compete on better terms with United States and British carriers.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 3 -- Opposition to an amendment that would restrict the operation of children's summer day camps was expressed at a zoning board hearing here.

George H. Wagner, a convicted gambler, and Philip Newman Associates, Inc., a brokerage concern he headed, were enjoined yesterday from future dealings in securities in the state. They were charged with high-pressure selling practices that defrauded individuals of "several hundred thousand dollars."

The General Tire and Rubber Company attained the highest quarterly sales in its history during the last three months of 1958 and raised the total for last year to a record $469,782,099. This was 11.5 per cent or $48,616,952 more than the volume for 1957.

TORONTO, Feb. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., had consolidated net income in 1958 of $21,062,315, equal to $12.70 a share of Class A and B stock. This compared with $17,332,654, or $10.44 a share, in 1957.
A managing agent who had pleaded guilty to 130 maintenance violations in four tenements he operated won a reversal of his thrity-day jail sentence yesterday.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 3 -- A Federal judge refused today to permit the Little Rock School Board to reopen temporarily its four high schools on a segregated basis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Orders for the construction of "Project Turnkey,'' the nation's first fully mechanized Post Office, were given today by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The United States warned the Soviet Union today that its insistence on "illusory control machinery" threatened to make "a shambles" of the project for a ban on testing nuclear weapons.

Stuart Mitchner, a 20-year-old Junior at the Indiana University, was named winner of the Thomas Y. Crowell Company Student Novel Contest yesterday. He will receive a prize of $2,500 and royalties from the publication of a novel he has written.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Secretary of Defense vigorously denied today that secret intelligence estimates of Soviet strength had been "tailored" to fit the defense budget.

Governor Rockefeller has announced his intention to raise state salaries by twenty million dollars. This is but a partial solution to the problem of low state wages. More than triple the Governor's figure is needed before our necessary state services can be carried out by adequate staffs of equitably paid workers.

A southern segregationist and an official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will appear on a television program Sunday from 6:30 to 7 P. M. to discuss the issue of school integration in the South.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Two brothers pleaded no defense to second-degree murder today in the 1956 slaying of James Quackenbush, a 60-year-old watchman. A codefendant was granted a mistrial.

Shipbuilding issues and a few of the specialty steels made strong gains in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The rest of the list was irregular but the market averages managed some small gains.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -American movies are taking on an international flavor that is wooing world-wide audiences, the Government said today.
MIAMI, Feb. 3 -- Erivale, a needle -slim British - designed sloop skippered by Allan Carlise of Miami, held the lead this afternoon after the first hour of the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau yacht race.
Last year was one of the most unprofitable the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has experienced since the late Nineteen Thirties, when it operated in bank ruptcy under court protection.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Volume predictions in the sales of reinforced plastics for 1959, have been sharply revsed upward as a result of a surge in January business, the Reinforced Plastics division of the Society of the Plastics Industry reported today.

Rikers Island, which is near the scene where the American Airlines Electra sank, into the East River last night, is the site of the crash of a Northeast Airlines plane on Feb. 1, 1957, two years and three days ago.
IN happy times now long gone by -- when the twentieth century was young -- heads of local traction systems owned private cars on trolley, subway and elevated lines. They used them for gay excursions.
VIENNA, Feb. 1 -- Communist governments in Eastern Europe have instructed their courts to crack down hard aginst the special kind of crime that plagues the whole area: theft of state property.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Feb. 3 -- The rioting has ceased in this steaming city dominated by the Congo River, but the burned shells of European shops in the African quarter remain as symbols of the turmoil and bloodshed that broke out a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, today introduced a sweeping sports antitrust bill that would set a limit of eighty on the number of major and minor league players any baseball team could control.

Nobody who wants to be fair and realistic can expect the cost of city government, in times of population growth and inflation, to go in any direction but up. This city's expense budget for 1959-60 will require an estimated $145,000,000 in new revenues beyond the "normal" increases in state aid and yield of present taxes.

Following are the essential portions of a proposed amendment to Section 886 of the New York City Charter defining conflicts of interest for city officers and employes. Also, the complete texts of three local laws that would establish a code of ethics for all city employes, set up a Board of Ethics and restrict the appearances before city agencies of former employes. All were made public yesterday:

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Eugenio Monti and Renzo Alvera of Italy, the defending champions in the two-man world bobsled championship next week-end, posted the fastest time today when official training runs began on the one-mile Olympic run.

Frank (Machine Gun) Campbell, ex-convict and waterfront thug, is scheduled to appear for questioning at the Waterfront Commission this morning. On Monday, Campbell walked into the bi-state agency's headquarters at 15 Park Row with his lawyer and accepted service of a subpoena.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Karol Divin, a 22-year-old language student from Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, today retained his European men's figure-skating title. He defeated the runner-up, Alain Giletti of France, by a clear margin.
Bargaining talks broke off yesterday in the four-day-old strike of 4,000 New York harbor workers. The walkout has halted movements of 400 tugboats and oil craft.
The Civil Rights Commission ended two days of public hearings yesterday with a voluminous record of testimony on widespread discrimination in housing against Jews, Negroes and Puerto Ricans here.
Merger discussions that would have created a fourth New York bank with resources in excess of $5,000,000,000 have been called off by the Manufacturers Trust Company and Bankers Trust Company.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Governor Rockefeller's first budget will give Ne wYork City the smallest ratio of state aid it has received in at least thirty years.
BALBOA, C. Z., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Merritt-Chapman Scott of New York City entered the low bid of $7,363,675 for widening the Panama Canal's Gaillard Cut, the Panama Canal Company announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Accidents took the lives of 91,000 persons in this country during 1958, the National Safety Council reported today.
A bakery industry spokesman predicted yesterday that there would be no settlement of the three-day-old bakery strike before next week.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 3 -- There are signs that Bonn is beginning to come closer to Washington's thinking on the German question even before Secretary of State Dulles arrives here this week.
A drive to organize employes of voluntary hospitals has brought 6,000 new members into Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union in one month, the union's president said yesterday.
A three-alarm fire in a jewelry mart at Canal Street and the Bowery slowed Brooklyn-bound vehicular traffic at the approaches to the Manhattan Bridge during yesterday's late afternoon rush period.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 4 -- A budget of $630,216 for mission education and promotion was adopted here today at the closing session of the midwinter meeting of the Congregational Christian Churches.

HESKETH PEARSON'S "Johnson and Boswell" is probably the most entertaining joint biography of those wits we shall ever have. Here we see what fame can do for men when they soar by way of anecdotage into immortality.

The ardor and enthusiasm of Governor Rockefeller's supporters seem to have cooled perceptibly in the wake of his proposed program for sharply increased taxation. Furthermore, there appears to be a rising tide of protest, as evidenced by the rather hostile mail pouring into the offices of State Legislature leaders.

The title of Stuart Mitchner's prize-winning novel was given incorrectly in this space yesterday. It is called "Let Me Be Awake," a story that gives more than a glancing blow at the "beat generation." The manuscript won the Thomas Y. Crowell Company Student Novel Contest with an award of $2,500.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 4 (AP) -Two 17-year-old schoolmates from a Chicago suburb and a former Olympian gained berths on the 1960 United States Olympic speed skating squad today.
SINCE "An Enemy of the People" is a rabble-rousing drama, a rabble-rousing performance is logical.

A tugboat captain who cast f off two barges he was towing and churned his boat into the mud near Rikers Island shortly after midnight yesterday rescued the only survivors of the airliner that crashed into the fog-shrouded East River.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Legislature was urged today to help preserve thousands of acres of Long Island "wetland" for conservation and recreation projects.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 4 -- Political tension is rising again in Haiti. Exiled opposition leaders are renewing their attacks on the sixteen-month-old Government of Dr. Francois Duvalier as the nation faces new economic difficulties.
MIAMI, Feb. 4 -- While most of the "sharp observers" were watching two other horses, Bayard Sharp's Troilus performed smoothly to win the seven-furlong Bahamas Stakes at Hialeah Park today.
This city is providing its children with some of the best education in the nation, in the opinion of three teachers who have spent a total of 116 years in the public school system here.
THERE will be no "sunken marble pools in the bathrooms" at the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Senator John F. Kennedy and Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell met head-on today in a duel over the merits of Democratic and Republican labor-reform bills.

A $12,173,000,000 program under which private capital and all levels of government would cooperate to give the city 730,000 new housing units within the next seventeen years was made public by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Jan. 28:

BHILAI, India, Feb. 4 -- Elaborate ceremonies marked the official opening here today of the first blast furnace of a steel plant the Soviet Union is building for the Indian Government. This was in sharp contrast to the simple inauguration yesterday of a West German-built steel plant at Rourkela.

Fire Commissioner Cavanagh's recent order to Fire Department officers that they relinquish all outside employment by June 1 is in keeping with the general reaction of industry and labor to the growing practice of individuals to hold down more than one job at a time.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- George Romney, a leading exponent of the compact car concept, told 170 stockholders of the American Motors Corporation today that the company must be prepared to expand to meet the full potential of the small car market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Eisenhower will send his civil rights message to Congress tomorrow, apparently unchanged from the content that was reported after yesterday's White House meeting with Republican Congressional leaders.

New York's City Council has done a pioneering job in writing a proposed code of ethics for its own members and the thousands of other city officials and employes. A special committee on standards and ethics, headed by Councilman Morris J. Stein of Brooklyn, has been at work on the job for two years, after some conflict-of-interest investigations had shown the need.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The United States demanded today that the Soviet Union take measures to prevent a repetition of the "unwarranted and inadmissible" attempt by Soviet authorities to inspect the military convoy.
A five-year program to assist local organizations in rebuilding American cities was announced yesterday by the American Council to Improve Our Neighborhoods.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A good demand slowly developed again today for rye and old-crop wheat in an otherwise dull market on the Board of Trade.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Del Flanagan of St. Paul exploited a six-pound weight advantage to gain a split decision over Ralph Dupas in a ten-round welterweight bout tonight. Flanagan weighed 148, Dupas 142.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Justice Department has ordered a broad grand jury investigation of the General Motors Corporation with a view toward possible criminal action against the giant company under the antitrust laws.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- In an atmosphere of complete agreement on policy toward Germany, Secretary of State Dulles and Prime Minister Macmillan discussed tonight the British leader's projected visit to Moscow.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 4 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike said today his Government would take every measure to thwart certain parties that were planning revolution and certain persons who were trying to cause trouble in Ceylon.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Feb. 4 -The Malayan Government said today that Communist bloc countries considerably increased their direct purchases of Malayan rubber last year. The official statement added that steady buying throughout most of the year had helped to maintain the price of rubber in the face of the American industrial recession.

ONE of the virtues of tradition emerges in two exhibitions of modern European prints at the Martin Widdifield Gallery, 818 Madison Avenue, and the Peter Deitsch Gallery, 51 East Seventy-third Street. It is the virtue of superb craftsmanship.

With all hope gone for any more survivors, officials yesterday sought to recover bodies and sufficient wreckage to determine the cause of the crash of the airliner that plunged into the East River Tuesday night.

CAIRO, Feb. 4 -- A communiqu from United Nations Emergency Force Headquarters in the Gaza Strip accused four armed Israelis tonight of a raid across the border last night. A woman and child were killed and another woman was wounded in the raid.
ALEXANDRA, Va., Feb. 4 -- A third Virginia community was ordered today to make an immediate start on desegregation of its public schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Government announced today a new regulation designed to aid small businesses in getting Federal contracts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to levy about $240,000,000 in additional taxes on the insurance industry's 1958 earnings.

An investor has purchased the eight-story apartment house on plot 62 by 80 feet at 315 West End Avenue at Seventy-fifth Street. The seller was a client of William Rosan, attorney. The building, which was constructed in 1948, contains twenty-four apartments of four to six rooms.
MADRID, Feb. 4 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has dashed the hopes of monarchists who have tried to persuade him to prepare public opinion for the restoration of Don Juan to the Spanish throne.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 4 -- President-elect Romulo Betancourt will name two or three members of each of the three principal parties to his Cabinet. His party, Democratic Action, will have the same number in the Cabinet as the Christian Socialist party and the Democratic Republican Union.
New terms for purchase of the city's subway power plants for a new total price of $125,690,000 have been offered by the Consolidated Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)--The National Education Association today endorsed as "necessary and reasonable" a Democratic-sponsored bill to provide Federal aid for school construction and increased teachers' pay.

Following a vigorous protest directly to Moscow, announced yesterday by President Eisenhower himself, the Soviets have released the American Army truck convoy from Berlin detained by them over local protests for more than two days. This settles the immediate incident with a vindication for the American argument that the Western forces have not only the right to stay in Berlin but also the right of free access to it.
A new time period for the Steve Allen show and cancellation of the George Gobel show were among several television program developments announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Democratic majorities in both houses of Congress rode roughshod over President Eisenhower's "hold-the-line" housing program today.
Five special centers will be opened Monday night by the Board of Education to provide instruction for some students affected by the shutdown of regular evening high schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Hopes for a solution of the Cyprus problem rose today with word that the two Premiers were to meet.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The inaugural meeting of the Executive Council of France's Overseas Community ended today. It brought together for the first time the French Government and the Premiers of twelve new republics in Africa and Madagascar.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Ski-conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- The United Automobile Workers announced today that monthly dues of members would be raised by $1 in March. The increase, the union said, will restore the U. A. W's strike fund to the constitutional minimum of $25,000,000.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Atlas No. 20 made a successful flight today in the Air Force's stepped-up campaign to develop the intercontinental-range ballistic missile.
The virtually indestructible Enos (Country) Slaughter yesterday became the eighth Yankee to sign his 1959 contract.
The White Sox have come up with a plan to help satisfy baseball-hungry fans in Chicago.

The City Planning Commission found unsuitable yesterday one of two plans submitted by the same builder as alternative substitutes for a Coney Island housing venture originally proposed by the United Housing Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A Democratic "liberal," but unique in the species, is coming to Washington this week in a period when many of his fellow "liberals" are proving how truly unique he is. The visitor is Governor Meyner of New Jersey, who has just presented to the State Legislature a balanced budget for fiscal 1960 and extolled the economic virtue of the same.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Soviet Union has reduced substantially its production of submarines, according to the latest military intelligence estimates.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 4 (Reuters)--Iran promised today to remain a loyal member of the Baghdad Pact.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 4 -With a fantastic performance to windward -- the point of sailing where races are won or lost -- the 42-foot yawl Callooh tonight emerged as the unofficial winner of the twenty-first annual Miami - to - Nassau yacht race.

ACCORDING to the honorable 4,657-year-old Chinese calendar, the Chinese New Year -the Year of the Pig--begins next Sunday. Locally, the celebration will be marked, as it has for many years, by lion dances in Chinatown and feasts in Chinese restaurants throughout the city and suburbs.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Iraq's Military Supreme Court sentenced three key figures of the ousted regime today to be hanged. The three are Said Qazzaz, former Interior Minister, Abdul Jabbar Fehmi, former Governor of Baghdad, and Bahjat Attiyah, the nation's former security chief.
On Jan. 6 The Times printed a letter from Harry R. Stern, written shortly after he returned from a three-month vacation in Europe.

CAIRO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Arab league secretary, Gen. Abdel Khalek Hassouna denied today that the league had recommended cancelling the concession of the American-owned Trans-Arabian Pipeline Company (Tapline).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senate rackets investigators charged today that an oil company with union connections had received a $19,834 pay-off on sales to Merritt-Chapman Scott, New York contracting concern.
A passenger on the Pan American jet clipper that pulled out of a 29,000-foot dive over the Atlantic on Tuesday paid tribute yesterday to "excellent handling and an excellent ship."

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 4 -- The women's coat and suit industry today was invited to join the over-all drive for promotion of women's apparel to be undertaker by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today presented the National Geographic Society's Hubbard Medal to Sir Vivian Fuchs, the British explorer who led a Commonwealth expedition that made the first overland crossing of Antarctica.
The lull in account activity that has existed along Madison Avenue for several weeks was broken yesterday by developments involving three companies. Two have appointed new agencies.

The nation's stocks of gasoline increased 4,628,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 197,511,000 barrels, compared with 192,883,000 a week earlier and 204,559,000 a year ago.

A twentieth-century musical landmark, but one more talked about than played, was the major point of interest in last evening's second Music in Our Time series at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 4 -- The West German Government said today that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union had introduced "no new element" into the German situation during his two-hour talk Monday with Dr. Hans Kroll, Bonn's Ambassador in Moscow.
An arbitrator has ruled that the owners of the defunct Brooklyn Eagle had a contractual obligation to pay about $1,000,000 in severance, vacation and other back pay to 315 of its former employes.
The Community Service Society ended its annual appeal yesterday with more contributions collected from more donors by more volunteers than ever before in its 110-year history.

Last week-end in Boston, George F. Foley, the professional superintendent, received a special engraved badge from the Eastern Dog Club as a tribute for running its show for forty years. Next Monday and Tuesday in Madison Square Garden, Foley will be superi ntendent of the Westminster show for the thirty-second time.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4, (UPI) -- The Government announced today a relaxation of stringent import regulations decreed more than a month ago. The regulations had been under fire from many business sectors here.
CHICAGO,. Feb. 4 (AP) -- The report of today' s livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 4 -- Religion has achieved new status on the college campus, a Lutheran leader declared here tonight.
An interpretation of "full operational command" has been prepared by the Joint Chiefs of Staff for the Secretary of Defense and the President.

Investigators sought to determine yesterday why one of the nation's newest airliners -- an American Airlines turbo-prop -- crashed while trying to land at La Guardia Airport just before midnight Tuesday.
Despite a soft intonation that easily could be drowned out in Stillman's Gym by the "holler guys," William P. Rosensohn has succeeded in making his voice heard in international boxing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Justice Department is ready to broaden an investigation into "undue concentration" in the automobile and steel industries.

The midwinter conference of Hadassah closed yesterday with a session honoring the twenty-fifth anniversary of Youth Aliyah, the agency that has rescued and rehabilitated 90,000 young refugees to Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Chief of Naval Research and Development urged today that all space research be placed under one civilian agency.
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Twenty-three daring drivers from seven nations will race down the icy Cresta run tomorrow in the one-man skeleton event of the world sledding championships.
CAIRO, Feb. 4 -- The divisions in the world continued to be reflected in the African-Asian youth conference today as it attempted to formulate a program of guidance for the two continents.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Feb. 4 -- Maurice van Hemelrijck, Belgian Minister for the Congo, has run into the first trouble of his tour of the territory. It arose not from Africans but from white settlers.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- It was Maksim Z. Saburov's turn today to confess his "mistake" and "political instability" at the time of the so-called anti-party plot.

Money for long-term investments totaling $23,700,000,000 will be available this year but demand for long - term funds will reach $24,700,000,000, according to Salomon Bros. Hutzler. The large investment banking concern, which makes an annual survey, says that interest rates will tend to rise, "at least during the first half of the year," because demand will exceed supply.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, Feb. 4 -- Four United States Army trucks, detained for fifty-four hours, crossed into West Germany from East Germany at 7:07 o'clock tonight without submitting to Soviet inspection.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers rallied from a 13-point deficit in the fourth period to defeat Boston. 129 -- 126, and snap the Celtics' six-game National Basketball Association winning streak tonight before a crowd of 3,270 at the Garden. Richie Guerin sparked the Knicks with 39 points.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 4 (UPI) -- A Government witness testified today that a contract clause had prompted him to speak to Representative William J. Green, Democrat of Pennsylvania, about the Representative's acting as a bond broker for a concern working on a Government job.

Fewer but more profitable pictures and economies at its studio and exchange centers enabled Warner Bros. Pictures. Inc., to operate in the black in the three months ended Nov. 29. In the same period of 1957 the company showed a loss.

The Aluminum Company of America showed a substantial improvement in sales and earnings in the last half of 1958 over the first six months of the year. Results for all of 1958, however, were sharply lower than for 1957.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- The twenty-first ecumenical council of the Roman Catholic Church will be held in Rome in 1961. It will be known as either the Vatican or the Lateran Council, depending on which of two Roman basilicas is the scene of plenary meetings.
Your editorials seem to be supporting Governor Rockefeller's tax proposals and you applaud him for the courage of his convictions.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Legislature has recalled for revision a bill to add five days to the flat track horse racing season. The bill is being rewritten to conform to Governor Rockefeller's desire to add ten days to the raci. calendar.
A $72,500,000 new issue of common stock in Universal Oil Processes, Inc., is being offered today by Lehman Brothers, Smith, Barney Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and associates.

Your important editorial of Jan. 28 rightly stresses the seriousness of the international situation as a result of the challenge or ultimatum of the Soviet Union. At stake is not only Berlin, Germany, Europe and peace, but also the survival of the free world.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee called today for import quotas and nine other measures to protect the ailing United States textile industry from foreign competition.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 4 -- John Hulsen, Republican leader of Huntington Township, was acquitted today of charges of coertion and extortion.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Alice O'Neal Dye, a six-time champion of Indiana's women golfers, upset the medalist, Betty Kerby of Akron, today in the first round of the Palm Beach women's amateur championship. The match went twenty holes.
BOSTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following reports on ski conditions along with the weather forecast:
GENEVA, Feb. 4 -- The Soviet Union offered today to review its plan for full national staffing of posts for controlling a ban on the tests of nuclear weapons.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Sir Winston Churchill believes that a war of "mutual extermination" may be indefinitely postponed if the non-Communist world preserves its unity and the Soviet Union achieves the gains of "peace and plenty."
The Southern Company, public utility holding company raised $45,279,000 in equity capital yesterday by the sale of 1,300,000 new shares of common stock at public sealed bidding.
A chubby 8-year-old boy told yesterday in Flushing Hospital of the death plunge of an airliner into the East River, but the tragedy was worse than he knew.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- England today was fighting desperately to avoid an innings defeat in the final day of the fourth test cricket match against Australia.

HALIFAX, N. S., Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Royal Canadian Air Force rescue planes, guided ships today to a red and white barrel believed to be from the Danish passenger-cargo vessel Hans Hedtoft, which hit an iceberg last Friday and disappeared with ninety-five persons aboard.

Four parcels at 619, 629 and 631 Kappock Street and 630 West 227th Street in the Riverdale area of the Bronx have been sold by Thorwald E. Jotten, Dr. Hiland L. Flowers, Ronsan Homes, Inc., and Carl E. Alder.
The Cleveland Orchestra, one of the best-disciplined musical groups in the country, staged an insurrection yesterday morning when it was penned in three subway cars for publicity.

The American Metal Products Company announced yesterday it had acquired the Davis Engineering Corporation of Elizabeth, N. J. The purchase was made for an undisclosed amount of cash. Andrew M. Mras, president of American Metal, said the acquisition of the maker of heat exchangers, evaporators and liquid oil coolers was another step in his company's program "to diversify its metal-Working activities into fields other than automotive supply."
The State of Louisiana borrowed $20,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway construction.
The vigorous upswing that characterized the last part of 1958 has continued into 1959, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said in its Monthly Review issued today.

SKI SKETCH: When Earle (Ole) Murphy joined the Swedish Ski Club seven years ago he found that he was the only member without a Scandinavian background. His fun - loving club-mates gave him his nick-name within two weeks.

The Pembroke College Club of New York will hold its annual theatre benefit Off Broadway this year. The Feb. 13 performance of Brendan Behan's "The Quare Fellow" at the Circle in the Square has been taken over by the club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A group of about two dozen men and women today filed at the House clerk's office a petition to impeach the United States Supreme Court.
THE Cleveland Orchestra behaves as if it intends to make a firm place for itself on the New York scene.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The Treasury took another step toward easier credit today when it announced that it was relaxing its control of borrowing and the raising of money through the issue of shares and other securities.

Manhattan College and New York University, undefeated in their last three starts, will meet in the second game of the collegiate basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. St. John's faces the University of Richmond in the 7:15 P. M. opener.

The ghastly midnight tragedy that overtook an airliner, plunging more than threescore passengers and crew members to their death in the East River, combined the horrors of air and sea disaster. The new turboprop airplane, so near to safe landing at La Guardia Airport and yet so far, went down without a word of impending trouble.
New York University will increase its tuition rates to $35 a point next September, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, the president, announced yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 4 -- As far as his boss is concerned, Capt. Samuel Nickerson is a hero.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- "The Henry Armstrong Story," a biography of the former featherweight-lightweight-welterweight boxing champion who became a Baptist minister, is to be filmed by William F. Broidy, producer, in association with Joseph Walleston.
The two new steel mills opened in India this week are part of that country's effort to raise its steel production to 6,000,000 tons by 1961. Last year steel output in India was 2,000,000 tons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman has sidestepped a suggestion that he run for a vacant seat in the House of Representatives, a Congressman said today.
Senator Lister Hill's "Health for Peace" bill has been introduced again in the Senate and this time it has no less than fifty-eight co-sponsors. Its adoption should be assured.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 4 -Dr. Charles Malik sought today to correct two "mistaken" conceptions of the United Nations: that it was a super-government capable of solving every world problem, or that it was a mere debating society.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Two Republican legislators from Manhattan proposed today that the Legislature make a year-long study of threatened and actual strikes by public employes.
A settlement of the strike of service employes at the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, was reached yesterday. The 400 employes involved agreed to return to work at 12:01 A. M. today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- The Soviet Union's new state security chief said today that his organization was continuing the fight against "agents smuggled into our country by the imperialist states."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee approved statehood for the Territory of Hawaii today by a vote of 25 to 4.
A leading Communist party official has been appointed head of the Soviet Union's foreign trade agency in this country.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Even Florida, which still has vast areas of open hunting land, is seeing the beginning of the commercial hunting preserve, and the chances are that preserves will sprout on all sides.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 20 points ($1) off to 6 points (30 cents) up today.
Stocks went through a relatively aimless session yesterday. Volume fell to 3,170,000 shares from 3,220,000 on Tuesday, and the market averages fell slightly.

TORONTO, Feb. 4 (Canadian Press) -Canada's newsprint industry faces an "ever present threat" of losing export markets if domestic costs are allowed to get out of line, according to Vernon E. Johnson of Montreal, president of the Canadian International Paper Company.

Fuel costs for four large-scale nuclear power plants due to begin operations in 1960 will "probably be less than half" the first core fuel cost for the Shippingport, Pa., plant that went into operation late in 1957.
Three years ago, at the Twentieth Soviet Communist party Congress in Moscow, Khrushchev claimed "Now our party is united as never before."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Legislation to require establishment of a Federal Narcotics hospital in New York State was introduced today in the House and Senate.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 4--A .22-caliber pistol reportedly used in the wounding of two policemen in Englewood, N. J., last Thursday night was found today.

The much-worn French expression to the effect that the more things change the more they remain the same does not apply to Africa. The new French Community, whose Executive Council held its first meeting in Paris Tuesday and yesterday, signalizes something decidedly new under the French sun.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- New building activity declined normally last month to $3,700,000,000 but nevertheless was 10 per cent above the previous January record set last year.
The Urban League of Greater New York called on the Board of Education yesterday to reconsider its decision to appeal a court ruling that some of the city's schools were inferior.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- John Cavanagh is an Irish designer who makes his home in London, but his clothes would be enthusiastically received in any of the world's fashion capitals. His collection today put plenty of snap and punch into the second day of showings by members of the Incorporated Society of London Designers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -President Eisenhower said today that the United States was maintaining "a very splendid posture" in "the whole security field."
BUFFALO, Feb. 4 (AP) -Several past or present City Councilmen said today a grand jury investigating paving contracts had questioned them about $2,000,000 in extra appropriations for street paving.

The Gulf and Western Corporation, automotive parts manufacturer and distributor, is expanding into the electrical appliance and television distribution field through the acquisition of J. A. Walsh Co. of Houston, Tex.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- A commission to revise and simplify the State Constitution was back in business today with a new chairman, David W. Peck, and five other new members.
ALAMEDA, Calif., Feb. 4 -- The Matson Navigation Company showed the public today a twenty-five-ton dock crane for loading huge aluminum containers on cargo ships.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 4 -- The Premiers of Turkey and Greece will meet in Zurich Friday to iron out their countries' differences over Cyprus. The Foreign Ministry announced tonight that Premier Adnan Menderes and Foreign Minister Fatin Rustu Zorlu would leave for Switzerland by plane tomorrow.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Benefit entertainments sponsored by the New Canaan Women's Republican Club this year will open with a bridge party on Monday afternoon. On March 24 there will be a meeting, lecture and reception at the Country Club of New Canaan for all groups affiliated with the Fairfield County Women's Republican Club.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 4 -- There's a suspicion that most Long Islanders sooner or later become pleasure boat skippers and also that early in life they learn to handle sports fishing gear well enough to bring in fifty-pound striped bass.
PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The Government issued tonight decrees affecting almost every domain of public administration and the national economy in France and Algeria.

About one hundred of 4,000 engineers here for the seventy-fifth anniversary meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers attended a major symposium on the nation's scientific status yesterday.
The Sportsmanship Brotherhood has chosen Stan Musial, the great Cardinal baseball player, for its 1958 citation, it was announced yesterday by Dan Chase, the brotherhood's executive director.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Normal service on the New Haven Railroad between here and New York will be restored Monday or Tuesday, the line said today. The service was disrupted by a freight-train wreck at Stamford on Jan. 10.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The English-bred Tempest II scored his first stakes victory in the United States today Willie Shoemaker rode him to a wire-to-wire triumph in the $27,800 San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita.
PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The proposed visit by Prime Minister Harold Mcmillan of Britain to Moscow was viewed without enthusiasm in French official circles today.
Three large new ferryboats planned by the city for the Staten Island run will stress the demand for vehicle rather than passenger space.

MOST New York stores have one department that consistently sells goodwill. This is the Bridal Department, which stands out as the one place where a customer can get service with a capital S at not a penny more.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 4 -A sudden rain squall forced President Eisenhower's special plane, Columbine III, to make an instrument landing today near Valdosta, Ga.
JOSEPH ODILON FLUET has "gone into a cloud" over the disastrous East River crash about midnight yesterday.
HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- The Federation of Havana University Students seized control of Havana University today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -United States exports amounted to $17,860,000,000 last year, which was 14 per cent less than the record set in 1957, according to preliminary estimates published today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) --ne Department of Agricul-I /ture, moving to regain lost for-] eign markets, announced todayl a substantial increase in theI Isubsidy it will pay on United] States cotton shipped abroad I beginning Aug. 1.
Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless.

Jamaica, the largest of the islands in the West Indies Federation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday a registration statement covering a proposed public sale of $12,500,000 of bonds in the United States.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Britain signed an agreement with the six-nation European Atomic Energy Community today for cooperation in the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller's Budget Director took State Controller Arthur Levitt to task today for charging that revenues from proposed income tax changes were being underestimated by $70,000,000 to $100,000,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 4 -American churches will contribute $140,000 to the cost of bringing 9,000 White Russians living on the China mainland out of that country through Hong Kong to homes in Australia, Latin America and other parts of the world.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 4 -- The Bergen County Free-holders heard a complaint today that the County Park Commission knew nothing about horses.

THE telegraph keys clattered with jarring stridency. Few ever had heard telegraph keys in Madison Square Garden before. But this was not an ordinary occasion. A 17-year-old boy had cast such a spell over 15,000 persons that they were frozen into immobility and bewitched into silence.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 4 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes said today that his new Minister of Education, Sefiora Julia Quinonez Ydigoras, would resign. The President, in a breakfast table interview, said he would appoint another woman to the ministerial post, but he did not identify his choice.
An Air Force plane with twelve men aboard was reported missing yesterday halfway between New York and Bermuda.
The runway the American Airlines Electra was using on its ill-fated approach to La Guardia Airport Tuesday night is the "back door" to the field's instrument strip.
Committees have been chosen to plan the annual Kips Bay dinner dance, which will take place in the ballroom of the Plaza on April 16.

The creators of the ingratiating "My Fair Lady" -- Alan Jay Lerner (book and lyrics) and Frederick Loewe (score) -- were discussing their next show yesterday. Like their current international entertainment, the source of which was the Galatea that George Bernard Shawmodeled into "Pygmalion," the new one bears a close kinship with mythology.

THE New York chapter of the American Institute of Decorators presented its Elsie de Wolfe Memorial Award to Cecil Beaton last night. Mrs. Frances Heard, home furnishings editor of House Beautiful magazine, also received a special citation for "her constant and loyal support of the decorating profession."
Mayor Wagner intervened yesterday in the five-day-old strike by 4,000 harbor workers. The walkout has immobilized 400 tugs, barges and oil craft.

"Holiday in Brussels," a feature-length film about last year's Brussels World's Fair, will begin an engagement as a companion film to "The Last Blitzkrieg" at the Mayfair Theatre tomorrow. The dramatized documentary was produced by Dick Randall, written by Jack Balch and directed by Frank VVarren. George Jessel is among the narrators.
TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- A $15-a-week increase in maximum unemployment benefits and extension of the payment period to thirty weeks were advocated today by the State Employment Security Council.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- George F. Kennan put his controversial argument for a sweeping revision of the United States policy on Germany before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.
Frank (Machine-Gun) Campbell, ex-convict and waterfront hoodlum, appeared yesterday before the Waterfront Commission but gave the agency no answers.
LINDEN, N. J., Feb. 4 -- A 13-cent drop in the tax rate here was forecast today as the City Council introduced the new municipal budget. A hearing was scheduled for March 3.
I was appalled to read your Feb. 4 editorial "Mexico and Guatemala," which shows a biased and unfair interpretation of the fishing-boat incident in Guatemalan territorial waters on Dec. 31, 1958.

Sign of the times: the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company, a leading advertiser, has appointed the Co-Ordinated Marketing Company to handle its merchandising. Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., continues as the advertising agency.

India passed an important milestone in the last few days when it opened two major new steel plants. The 2,000,000-ton capacity of these two plants together is about equal to India's entire steel production last year, and if one adds in the additional 1,000,000 tons of steel capacity completed by the Tata company late last year it becomes clear that India has more than doubled its steel production capacity within the past few months.
Several ski operators reporting conditions in the northlands yesterday seemed to be contradicting themselves as they prepared to welcome another large invasion of snow runners for the week-end.
Roswell Magill, president of the Tax Foundation, Inc., yesterday defended President Eisenhower's proposed budget for 1960 as "a step in the right direction."
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were; filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:
THOUGH there are ghosts onstage and off, the Metropolitan Opera's new "Macbeth" is not haunted. It is indeed a handsome, moving production of the finest of Verdi's early operas.

The chances are that "Lute Song," recorded in the Burns Mantle compendium as one of the ten best offerings of the 1945-46 season, will receive its first local revival at the City Center. If so, the Sidney Howard-Will Irwin "love story with music," for which Raymond Scott did the score and Bernard Hanighen the lyrics, will be seen March 11-22.

Sales of Burlington Industries, Inc., in the current March quarter are running about 10 per cent ahead of a year ago, J. Spencer Love, president and chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Wilmington yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Nine ships and seven planes made a fruitless search in the mid-Atlantic today for a United States Air Force weather plane missing with twelve men. The B-50 hurricane hunter left Bermuda's Kindley Air Base early Wednesday on a flight over the North Atlantic to collect weather data.
HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- The Cuban police said today that Alan Robert Nye of Whiting, Ind., had confessed that he had been employed by the Batista regime to kill Fidel Castro.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Economic planning in Yugoslavia over the last few years has brought "impressive progress," the Economic Commission for Europe reports in its latest quarterly bulletin.
The Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday slight gains in operating revenues and net income for 1958.

"THERE has been much talk about the return to elegance, but where is it?" So observed Benjamin De Setto, president of the Urban Furniture Company, who decided to promote the trend by producing a group of furniture that combines classic elegance with modern design.

Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, who announced his temporary retirement from television a year and a half ago, will resume a series of spiritual talks next month. The program will be recorded on video tape and distributed to stations by National Telefilm Associates, Inc.

ANY persistent reader of current fiction who was once an adolescent himself must sometimes feel that the experience, while moderately interesting in a private sort of way, is not necessarily so painful and generally soul-shattering as it is frequently portrayed in autobiographical novels.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the United Nations had made constant efforts toward "thawing the 'cold war'." In his view he added, it has achieved some success.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- Crusty old gentlemen yanked at their mustaches and gazed moodily into fireplaces at their clubs today; dowagers added a bitter pinch of lemon to their tea; a hush fell over London pubs, and pedestrians stared mournfully at the black headlines -- England had lost The Ashes.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- When town and city governments come to Albany for money and advice, they must walk through many doors. Governor Rockefeller wants a brand new door built just for them. On it would be:
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 5 -Iraq is on the verge of giving the Soviet Union and its satellites a major role in her forthcoming five-year economic program, informed observers here believe.

The protest by top American educators -- including Dr. Griswold of Yale, Dr. Goheen of Princeton and Dr. Pusey of Harvard -- against inclusion of the loyalty oath provision in the National Defense Education Act (as reported in the Jan. 25 New York Times) is hard to understand.

The special textile subcommittee of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, which has just completed a detailed report on the problems of the textile industry in this country, was commended yesterday by William I. Kent, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- A total of $2,000,000 in cash and property was left outright by Vincent Astor to his widow under terms of his will filed for probate here today. Mr. Astor died of a heart attack Tuesday.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -Australia today regained The Ashes, symbol of Anglo-Australian cricket supremacy, when it defeated England in the fourth test match.
A bill to give the city the authority to condemn property in business and commercial districts for off-street truck-loading facilities will be introduced in the Legislature Monday night.
Glenn E. Massnick has been elected vice president in charge of real estate for S. H. Kress Co. Mr. Massnick formerly was real estate manager for Montgomery Ward Co.
PARIS, Feb. 5 (UPI) -The Government lowered the 4 1/2 per cent rediscount rate by one quarter of 1 per cent today in a new move aimed at stimulating investment in France's expanding industry.
A new system that can put a live studio television show into a setting as big as all outdoors was demonstrated yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
For the second time in two years Puerto Rican migration to the continental United States has declined sharply, a Puerto Rican Department of Labor division reported here yesterday.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The Journey," a drama filmed in Europe with Yul Brynner, Deborah Kerr and Jason Robards Jr., has been scheduled to open on Feb. 19 at the Radio City Music Hall. Anatole Litvak directed and produced, from a screen play by George Tabori. Among the featured players are Robert Morley, E. G. Marshall and Kurt Kasznar.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Maurice Gendrom, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Paul Zukofsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Nicanor Zabaleta, harpist, Towr Hall, 8:30; Suzanne Bloch, music for lute and virginals, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -- A leader of the United Jewish Appeal said here today that the appeal was confronted with a "critical need for vast funds" to aid Jews now leaving Eastern European countries, particularly Rumania, for Israel.
TOKYO, Feb. 3 -- Japan's major department stores are planning to expand their businesses to overseas markets this year.

Assets of the 233 savings and loan associations in New York State rose $364,719,174, or 10.3 per cent, to $3,898,057,706 last year. This was a new record, the Savings Association League of New York State reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Carlo Ponti and Marcello Girosi, independent producers associated with Paramount, announced plans today for a program of six pictures they propose to complete by the end of 1961.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Stock market prices made another general advance here today, although the best levels were not always held.
Any court reforms approved by the Legislature this year would be an important gain, Harrison Tweed, former chairman of the Temporary Commission on the Courts, asserted yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Cornelia Harrington of Wayne, N. J., won the final women's berth on the 1960 United States Olympic speedskating squad as the four-day trials ended today.

Cardinal Spellman was honored last night at a dinner given by the Lotos Club and was called a man who has been "in the forefront of every religious, cultural and charitable endeavor in the last forty years."

Dean Witter Co., a stock brokerage concern, has signed a long-term lease for 32,000 square feet of space in the new thirty-story office building at 2 Broadway. Occupancy is planned for May 1. The building, constructed by Uris Brothers, contains 1,300,000 square feet of space.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A limited rally in the final few minutes of trading wiped out a number of small losses on the Board of Trade today and left the market steady to firm in except rye contracts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate passed tonight a many-sided housing bill carrying about $1,000,000,000 more in spending authority than asked by President Eisenhower. The vote was 60 to 28, with 47 Democrats and 13 Republicans for the bill and 18 Republicans and 10 Democrats against it.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 5 -- The Turkish and Greek Premiers will seek broad planes of agreement during their talks on Cyprus this week-end in Zurich.

ONE of the most extensive exhibitions ever held in New York of Kurt Schwitters' collages, at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, compels reflection on the role of Dada in contemporary art.
Conditions in some nursing homes were described yesterday as "shocking" by a witness before an investigating group of the Legislature.

ON Wednesday and Friday nights, in a small studio at 225 West Forty-sixth Street, there is a mass meeting attended by a group of mildly depressed gagwriters who say they are supremely talented, endlessly productive, frightfully clever -- and out of work.
ROME, Feb. 5 -- Rome celebrated its Giovedi Grasso, the Fat Thursday before Lent, with public mummery and carousing and did not listen to the prophets of political gloom.

The High School Teachers Association accused the Board of Education yesterday of using "labor-baiting" tactics in an attempt to operate an evening high school program after a resignation of instructors.
KARACHI, Pakistani, Feb. 3 -The benevolent dictatorship that rules Pakistan is beginning to seek the voluntary support of the people and to use its wide coercive powers more sparingly.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today that Western policies on Germany and European security would be based largely on the results of his forthcoming visit to Moscow.

The New York Philharmonic, conducted by Leonard Bernstein, gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall, and the players were dressed in white ties and tails. But the memory of the recently discarded rehearsal uniforms lingers on.
Macy's found itself embarrassed yesterday because a Russian was accused of taking too seriously the store's appeal to thrifty shopping.
The New York Heart Association disbursed $1,715,203 in the fiscal year ended last June 30, its annual report showed yesterday.

CHARLES CO., which has been catering to the city's taste for delicacies since 1848, opened a second store here yesterday. The new shop -- it is at 683 Madison Avenue, between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets -- is a handsome establishment that offers more than 7,000 different fancy foods.
THE Michel del Castillo novel, "Child of Our Time," was translated last night into a play of searing poignancy on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2.

HURST PARK, England, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji, one of the greatest American steeplechase horses ever sent to Europe, finished third today in the Morden Handicap and indicated he might be a tough competitor in the Cheltenham Gold Cup.
The city's fiscal program for 1959-60 calls for an $11,000,000 subsidy to preserve the 15-cent fare on the municipal subway and bus lines for at least one more year.
Net operating profit before taxes of the Royal-Globe Insurance Group in 1958 was $10,405,550, an increase of $9,639,767 over 1957, it was announced yesterday.

An inquiry into the American Airlines accident that cost sixty-five lives here Tuesday night was officially described yesterday as progressing, but still with no indication of what caused the accident.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -People who live in plastic houses, a Monsanto Chemical Company executive says, will be numerous in a few years.

LEONARD WARREN, who sang the title role in "Macbeth" when the 112-year-old Verdi opera received its first Metropolitan Opera performance last night, is what is known in the profession as a "slow study."
The Sperry Rand Corporation achieved record sales of $697,472,448 in the nine months ended Dec. 31. This compared with $648,571,966 for the prior year's period.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 5 -The City Planning Commission last night approved a capital projects budget of $2,980,300 for the current fiscal year, ending Aug. 31. A tax rise of 2.5 mills is indicated.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The State Public Works Department received today low bids totaling nearly $10,000,000 on three major highway projects.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Feb. 5 -- A visit today to one of the transit camps established by the authorities for Africans being rounded up in Leopoldville suggested that those being moved from the capital were submitting docilely to the transfer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senator Clifford P. Case called on the White House tonight to give the American people the facts concerning the nation's defense capabilities and military potential.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 5 (AP) -- United States bobsled racers finished far back in the world one-man bobsled championships today and made disappointing performances in practice for the two-man event.
STUART, Fla., Feb 5 -- This snook fishing with fly rods is everything they say it is, when things are halfway right. They were halfway right today.
Harris County, Tex., received bids yesterday on $8,000,000 of bonds in two issues.

Thanks largely to a stellar quartet from this area, the University of Illinois seems headed toward a tenth consecutive Big Ten gymnastics title. The Illini also appear to be a good bet to take sole possession of the National Collegiate crown, which they shared last year with Michigan State.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Several important Republican legislators have asked the Tax Department for an estimate of the cost of giving married taxpayers a double credit -- $20 instead of $10 -- in the pending income-tax bill.
Sixteen persons were injured last night when a bus collided with a trailer truck at Eighth Avenue and Twentieth Street.
TOKYO, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- Japan announced today she was withdrawing conditionally from the International VVhaling Convention, which regulates whale catching in Antarctic waters.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- In the midst of a scathing attack on United States leaders and foreign policy, Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev invited President Eisenhower today to visit the Soviet Union.

As part of the preparation for a united Western response to the Soviet challenge on Berlin Prime Minister Macmillan and Foreign Secretary Lloyd propose to fly to Moscow later this month for conferences with Premier Khrushchev. Mr. Macmillan gave formal assurance in the House of Commons yesterday that they are not going to conduct any negotiations "on behalf of the West" on issues confronting all the NATO allies.

John A. Herrmann, who died in the crash of the American Airlines plane Tuesday night, was chairman of the board of Herrmann-Herzman, Inc., handkerchief manufacturers, 10 East Thirty-eighth Street. He was 52 years old and lived at 955 Park Avenue.

Some new songs by the American composer Ben Weber and some European "punkt-musik" made up the bulk of last night's concert by the Parrenin String Quartet at the Rothschild Foundation, 316 East Sixty-third Street.
GENEVA, N. Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- The general counsel of the Lehigh Valley Railroad said today that the road was moving rapidly toward bankruptcy because of losses due to passenger service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Claude J. Jasper, Republican State Chairman for Wisconsin, was named today to head the party's new effort to enlist 2,000,000 more precinct workers for the 1960 Presidential campaign.

"ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Arthur Levitt, State Controller, announced today plans to sell $60,000,000 of state serial bonds publicly on Feb. 18. The bonds will be dated March 15. Of the $60,000,000, $24,000,000 is for highway construction and will mature in equal annual installments over twenty years; $18,000,000 for higher education institutions and will mature similarly over twenty years, and $18,000,000 for mental hospital construction will mature in equal installments over fifteen years."

Sales and production by the paper industry should reach record highs this year but the outlook for earnings is "mixed," according to a review of industry conditions issued this week by the American Paper and Pulp Association.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points (30 cents) off to 35 points up yesterday. New-crop months were strongest.
GENEVA, Feb. 5 -- A United States denunciation of the Soviet demand for a veto was placed today into the record of the conference on ending nuclear weapons tests.
HONG KONG, Feb. 5 -- The Chinese Communist party gave unequivocal acknowledgment today to the ideological leadership of the Soviet party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a secret, two-year investigation by its staff had developed information tending to show that Reynolds Co., a leading New York stock brokerage concern, had engaged in fraud in selling the securities of six mining companies.
BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- A withholding system for collecting personal income taxes was voted today by the Massachusetts Legislature.
JAY THORPE: This store has an international staff that is equipped to deal with weddings that encompass the earth.
AFTER the curtain has been up on "Redhead" for about fifteen minutes Gwen Verdon appears in man's attire, with a cane and a hard hat, and breaks down into a Chaplinesque serenade.
Stocks made a general retreat yesterday. Although there were occasional exceptions, every major group moved lower.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -Freight traffic of the nation's railroads showed a better year-to-year gain in the week ended last Saturday than in any week since August, 1957. Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 31 aggregated 582,636 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 5 -- President Eisenhower went hunting for quail today and, according to the White House press office, was successful. His vacation headquarters also confirmed that he has been hunting Democratic support in Congress for his legislative program.

A new controversy over school integration erupted in Brooklyn yesterday. A group of fifty white and Negro parents from the Crown Heights section accused the Board of Education of using rezoning to make Public School 138 an all-Negro School.

Crown Fabrics Corporation, New York, announced yesterday it had sold its entire merchandise inventory, furniture, fixtures, lease hold improvements, the lease on premises, good will and all registered trademarks and names to a newly formed company to be called Crown Fabrics Limited.

The nation's two leading maritime unions began a campaign yesterday to win Congressional support in their drive to organize approximately 8,000,000 tons of United States-owned shipping flying foreign flags.
