The six-story apartment house at 1420 Ocean Parkway at Rider Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Selig Charney, Inc., to Oceandale, Inc. The structure contains sixty apartments and stands on a plot 150 by 100 feet. It was sold subject to mortgages of $350,000.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $58,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The decline compared with one of $18,000,000 in the week a year ago.

The development of new cellulosic fibers by three leading rayon producers, announced recently, represents a major advance into the textile field dominated by cotton, J. B. Goldberg, consultant to the textile and allied industries, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A West Coast Teamsters official testified today that he had waived an election victory after pressure by a close friend of James R. Hoffa.
MIL WAUKEE, Feb. 5 -- Protestants were cautioned here tonght against "begrudging" the Roman Catholic Church what was described as its growing influence in American society.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -The Secretary of the Treasury resisted today an onslaught by Congressional Democrats and one Republican challenging the Administrations posi tion on the inflation danger and the need for a balanced budget. Congressional Economic Committee's hearings on President Eisenhower's fiscal program.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev scoffed today at a report that he had said anything derogatory about the Chinese Communists in his eight-hour interview with Senator Hubert H. Humphrey last fall.

TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- New Jersey legislative leaders today reached virtual accord on proposals to solve the commuter transportation problem and to provide a $66,800,000 bond issue for college construction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Following is a comparative analysis of provisions of the three principal civil rights proposals before Congress. They are the Administration plan submitted today, a bill introduced by the Senate majority leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, and a measure sponsored by Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, and sixteen other Senate liberals.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Feb. 5 -- A British trawler arrived at Seydisfjoerdur on the east coast of Iceland today under arrest on a charge of fishing within four miles of Iceland.

The shake-up in the office of the Borough President of Queens continued yesterday with the disclosure of two resignations to take effect Feb. 15. Both are being submitted at the request of Borough President John T. Clancy.
New developments in the lighting field should make it possible for the public soon to obtain long-life bulbs not generally available heretofore.

Despite all the talk about the Soviet bloc's expanding steel industry, the free world has added substantially more to capacity since 1955 than the Soviet Union and its satellites. The American Iron and Steel Institute published yesterday what it called a "rare comparison" -- unusual because few foreign nations make regular estimates of steel capacity.

TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner chided the Eisenhower Administration today for seeking to decrease its participation in local urban redevelopment projects at a time when it was "most needed."
When word of a major disaster reaches it, the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington anticipates a call from local authorities for assistance in identifying the dead.

UNION, N. J., Feb. 5 -- One of Union's oldest houses resounds these days with the cries of children at play. The house, part of which may be pre-Revolutionary, is now occupied by the Playtime Cooperative Nursery School.

At a time when everyone is concerned with increased international tensions at one point or another it is gratifying to get some good news from Thailand and Cambodia. With the help of a mediator from the United Nations, Baron Beck Friis of Sweden, the two countries now seem to be about to resume normal diplomatic relations and to take their problem of disputed borders into the field of friendly discussion.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 -- Donald Fleming, Minister of Finance, indicated the highest level of Government spending in Canada's history when he presented to Parliament today the estimates on which budgets are based.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The Basrah Petroleum Company, Ltd., announced today a 25,000,000 ($70,000,000) program for expanding the export of oil from Iraq.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- Five United States service men who had strayed into East Germany were released today after negotiations between the American and East German Red Cross. The group included Continued From Page 1, Col. 7 the Soviet authorities had released a United States Army convoy that had been detained for fifty-five hours at the Marienborn checkpoint on the autobahn from Berlin to West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The State Department made public today a tape recording of voices purported to be those of Russian fighter pilots transcribed while they were shooting down an unarmed Air Force transport over Armenia five months ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers, spurred by the third-period shooting of Ken Sears, defeated the Syracuse Nationals for the ninth straight time this season, posting a 111-98 victory tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 5 -- This shoreline town was advised today that the growth of pleasure boating required a new municipal department headed by a director at an annual salary of $12,000 to $15,000.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Secretary of State Dulles arrived in Paris this evening for the second{ stage of a voyage designed 'to! insure alignment of WesternI views in dealing with the Soviet threat to Berlin and with broader German and . security, questions.

Russell Porter's article of Jan. 25 covers many important angles of the court reorganization problem. I believe, however, that he has omitted one aspect which could very well change the attitude of many who now object to the reorganization plans because of the apparently increased cost to the taxpayer.

Directors of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 15 cents a common share, "in view of improved earnings in the final quarter of 1958 and estimated earnings for the 1959 first quarter."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senate Democrats said today that the Administration labor reform bill would favor unscrupulous employers and hinder legitimate unions. James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, making his second appearance before the Labor subcommittee, disagreed.
A tentative agreement was reached last night for a settlement in the city's six-day-old tugboat strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- In his news conference yesterday President Eisenhower left the impression that the paramount question in his mind was inflation, that this issue was simply one between those, like himself, who were for fiscal responsibility and those who were not, and that, in large part, this was a partisan issue.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 5 -- President Eisenhower congratulated the Boy Scouts of America today on the fortyninth anniversary of the Scout movement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- When President Eisenhower and his advisers changed their original plan to include in his current legislation that section (Title III) of the Civil Rights Act of 1957 that the Senate rejected, the effect was to sustain the deliberate rate of gradualism in Southern public school integration the Supreme Court approved in affirming a lower court ruling that the Alabama Pupil Placement Law is constitutional.

The decline in unemployment since the recession hit bottom has been very similar to that after the recessions of 1949 and 1954, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York said in its monthly survey published today.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, Feb. 5 (AP) -The drivers of the United States Army convoy held by the Soviet guards for more than fifty hours said today they got the impression that Soviet officials had deliberately set up the incident in advance.
"BERKELEY SQUARE," a fragile drama that once won acclaim on stage and screen, was re-created last night on television.
The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation has set a price of $37.50 a share on its 280,000-share offering of common stock to holders.
City departmental hearings on the 1959-60 budget closed yesterday with 128 agencies asking for $2,208,056,673. The amount, if granted, would be $212,630,636 above the current budget.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -The House of Representatives voted, 381 to 20 today to continue the draft for four years. The extension will start July 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, urged the National Advisory Committee on Farm Labor tonight to advocate a Federal minimum wage for migrant farm workers.
EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Directors of the American Photocopy Equipment Company recommended today a three-forone common stock split and an increase in the dividend rate.
Most cocoa, potato and world and sugar positions fell to new lows or equaled the lows on the New York exchanges yesterday. The three commodities were influenced by heavy production.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Two Curtis Cup team members reached the semi-finals of the forty-first annual women's golf championship of Palm Beach today.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A Democratic plan to reorganize the state's court system was submitted to the Legislature today. It follows the lines recommended by the Judicial Conference, a panel of high state judges.
MANILA, Feb. 5 -- Demands intensified today in Congressional circles for payment of $800,000,000 to $900,000,000 in claims against the United States.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The dignified and luxurious Ritz Hotel on the Place Vendome was the bizarre stage today for another scene in the sensational case known as "I'Affaire Lacaze."

A FIVE-FOOT BLONDE from California is on her way to gaining more admirers at Bonwit Teller. She is Edith Small, a designer whose clothes are created especially for petite women. For the first time Bonwit Teller is carrying an extensive collection of her resort and summer fashions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -Chief Justice Earl Warren may have saved tax-payers $8,000,000 today. That is almost five times as such as the cost of operating the Supreme Court this year.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Representative Lee Metcalf opened hearings on Federal aid to schools today with a plea for action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Administration sent a broad civil rights program to Congress today. It included a declaration of support for the Supreme Court's 1954 decision holding public school segregation unconstitutional.
A 47-year-old Bronx man, who described himself as a bookmaker, was accused yesterday of using stolen bankbooks to withdraw $27,350 of other people's money from banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Following are the principal documents, made public today by the State Department, on the disappearance of United States transport plane over the Soviet Union Sept. 2, 1958, together with .excerpts from a taperecorded radio conversation among Soviet fighter pilots who attacked the plane:
A 9-year-old boy who fell through the ice on a pond and the man who tried to rescue him drowned yesterday in GreenWood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

Mr. Khrushchev's report to the Soviet Communist party Congress to the effect that close to 30,000,000 less gallons of vodka were consumed in Russia in 1958 than in 1957 certainly is testimony to the vise in which its leaders can hold a people in a Communist state.

MIAMI, Feb. 5 -- Ingenuity showed today that she can win on a fast track as well as on a sloppy one. The filly owned by Ogden Phipps won today's feature event by three lengths over the favored Wayward Miss of the Cain Hoy Stable in a six-furlong race for 3-year-old fillies.
WARSAW, Feb. 5 -- Poland's Communist party has decided to make the Polish Union of Writers pay a price for its defiant attack on the Government's censorship policies.

Ray Milland will be the star of a filmed drama series to be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Saturdays from 10:30 to 11 P. M. beginning April 25. The actor will portray a lawyer in the series, which is titled "Crisis." It will be sponsored by the Schlitz Brewing Company.

It is encouraging that this week's Police Department report on crime in New York City last year -- which shows an alarming increase in juvenile delinquency -- should be paralleled by the publication of a plan for a coordinated drive on juvenile delinquency in the Lower East Side.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 2 -- One of the major projects of the present Guatemalan Administration is to bring British Honduras, the neighboring British colonial possession, under political and economic control.
The final contract was awarded yesterday in the construction of the Port Authority's new Pier 3, in the Fulton Terminal area of the agency's Brooklyn piers.
Privately owned ocean tank ship tonnage under the United States flag increased in 1958 for the first time in five years, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

WALDWICK, N. J., Feb. 5 -- The Board of Education will investigate the punishment of a 12-year-old boy who collapsed Monday at his home ten hours after walking up and down a flight of eight steps ten times for violating a rule.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones today announced a plan that would save $4,000,000 a year for New Jerseyans working in New York and at the same time add an undetermined number of tax-payers to the New York rolls.
The Anti-4 Per Cent Sales Tax Committee rallied yesterday to the pledge of its chairman, Walter Hoving, "We're going to win this fight!"
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -Democratic leaders of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy called on the Administration today to authorize construction of a nuclearpowered airplane.
In a sorry second-half exhibition, New York University's quintet blew a 14-point lead and bowed to Manhattan College, 63 -- 58, before 5,176 persons at Madison Square Garden last night.

In 1950 Peter Krott, an Austrian naturalist, went to Scandinavia to trap and study the habits of the wolverine, regarded as "the devil incarnate." He established a wildlife preserve outside Helsinki and there he learned about this odd animal, which moves at a clumsy gallop and{s not helped by particularly keen senses of sight; smell or hearing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -The Soviet Union has made a third bid to buy $2,500,000 worth of steel pipe for oil lines from United States producers.

It is curious that many people will freely and voluntarily spend every dollar they can afford and sometimes more on individual purchases of goods and services and at the same time complain bitterly about their taxes. The common attitude seems to be that private spending is beneficial to the community, while money paid in taxes is "poured down the drain" and does nobody any good.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Red Sullivan scored his sixteenth and seventeenth goals of the season tonight and led the New York Rangers to a 5-0 victory over the disorganized Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.
George A. Brenner, former Westchester surrogate and county judge who has been indicted for the larceny of $318,000, was accused again yesterday.

Alex Olmedo, the young Peruvian who led the United States Davis Cup team to victory over Australia in December, is planning to compete for the national indoor championship here. The tournament will be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, Feb. 19 to 23.
In an unusual job of casting, two well-known English actors will attend a costume ball here as legendary New Yorkers.
GENEVA, Feb. 5 -- The Turkish and Greek Premiers and Foreign Ministers had their first contacts today in Zurich prior to talks for a solution of the Cyprus problem.
Title to thirteen apartment houses, valued at $3,000,000, changed hands twice yesterday during four hours of intensive negotiations involving more than seventy persons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today on civil rights: To the Congress of the United States:

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 5 -The winner of the twenty-first annual Miami-to-Nassau yacht race was not Callooh after all. Instead, first place went to Rhubarb, a 40-foot yawl, skippered by Benjamin B. duPont of Pine Orchard, Conn.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The spring fashion collections of the Incorporated Society of London Designers came to an end today with the showings of Victor Stiebel, who is often compared to New York's Mainbocher, and of another of London's transplanted Irishmen, Michael, who is often referred to as "absolute tops here." Both presented collections that were designed, like all those in London, with the specific clients of the house in mind.

ESTES KEFAUVER, the resident surgeon at the legislative cure-all hospital in Washington, is operating on his sports patients with all the finesse of a physician who uses a meat-axe instead of a scalpel. Even though the operations are successful, the patients surely will die. The surgery is far too radical and has been prescribed without any true understanding of the backgrounds of those about to be carved.

Many persons entertained last evening in connection with the second annual Neighborhood Dinner Dance for the benefit of Lenox Hill Hospital. The event took place in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- Sales of new cars in January were 12.6 per cent greater than a year earlier, when sales had begun to lag badly. But last month's total was well below that for January, 1957.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that Nikita S. Khrushchev had betrayed "a high degree of insecurity" in the Moscow-Peiping axis by denying that he had called the Chinese communes "reactionary."

"MRS. BRIDGE,"* by Evan S. Connell Jr., is a searching and memorable portrait of a lost lady. The time and setting and characters may remind you of Booth Tarkington's midland America. But neither the style nor the point of view is Tarkingtonian.
OTTAWA, Feb. 6 -- There is every indication that East-West talks about the Berlin crisis and the future status of Germany will take place this spring, Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said today.

Lieut. Thomas J. Murtha, a fireman for fifteen years, has been suspended for thirty days and given an eleven-month leave of absence from his duties. The suspension and leave were imposed following a finding that he had been guilty on four charges of neglect of duty.

Four women, including a former substitute junior high school teacher in the city's schools, were arrested early yesterday morning in a vice raid on a $350-a-month apartment at 405 East Sixty-third Street.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad looks for a 4 per cent rise in its freight carloadings this year and expects gross revenues to reach $300,000,000, according to R. L. Dearmont, president. Last year gross revenues were $291,800,000.
PROVIDENCE, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Brown University tonight named John J. McLaughry of Amherst College as its thirteenth head football coach.
The investigation into the cause of Tuesday's crash of an American Airlines plane was hampered yesterday by the difficulty of raising the wreckage in the swift currents of the East River.
An improved West Side IRT subway service began operating yesterday and Mayor Wagner and transit officials expressed satisfaction with the modernization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company had withdrawn an application of last October for a Government guarantee on a proposed loan of $450,000.

FIFTY painters are showing a picture apiece in the February exhibition at the City Center Gallery, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street. The fact that this month's jury is made up of two conservatives, Leon Kroll and Sidney-Laufman, and one advance guard impresario and artist, Betty Parsons, guarantees a wide variety of styles.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The State Investigation Commission charged today that Joseph Barbara, host to the Apalachin gangland convention in 1957, was playing a game of "You catch me."
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 6 -- Former President Laureano Gomez was accused tonight of having been an "accomplice" in the assassination of Dr. Jorge Eliecer Gaitan, Liberal party leader, in 1948.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 28 -- The earnest young man from Tanganyika faced the calm Chicagoan and argued:
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Miss Pauline Weiss was held in $5,000 bail for court today charged with solicitation to commit murder and attempt to commit murder.

Your Jan. 25 editorial "Hate Literature" commented on the American Jewish Committee's suggestions for "constructive community action to meet the menace" as not going far enough. You quite properly pointed out that when "hate" literature can be "tied up to overt action such as bombing of public buildings or organized lynchings it becomes a problem in the preservation of public order * * * and thus touches the law itself."
BONN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- Two former concentration camp officers who confessed to multiple murders at the Sachsenhausen camp twenty years ago were sentenced today to life imprisonment at hard labor.

The Twenty-first Congress of the Soviet Communist party has now passed into history. Some caution in judging its significance is suggested by the recollection that three years ago the most important event at the Twentieth Congress -- Khrushchev's speech on Stalin, which is still unpublished in the Soviet Union -- did not become known to the outside world until weeks after the meeting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A special House subcommittee was named today to investigate Tuesday night's airliner crash and the over-all safety problems of transition to the jet and turbo-prop era.

An American developer will undertake to build a new city of 5,000 homes in Venezuela. It will have an industrial park, a shopping center, recreational facilities, and a center for exhibiting building products and services sold internationally.
ADVICE to a struggling artist: Put art on cloth instead of on canvas. It may make your fortune.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 6 -- American Jewish leaders were urged here today to make an intensive effort in the next thirty days of informing Jewish communities of their "gigantic responsibilties" in helping Israel to absorb some 100,000 immigrants this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A House subcommittee approved today a housing bill substantially more generous than the one proposed by President Eisenhower or the one approved by the Senate last night.
Cotton futures of the New York Cotton Exchange Friday closed 9 points (45 cents a bale) higher to 5 points (25 cents) lower than on Thursday.

TORONTO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, gained a commanding lead today in her bid for her second straight North American figure skating championship. Another American, Tim Brown of Colorado Springs, led at the halfway mark of the men's senior competition.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has not approved the revised policy West German representatives are presenting in Washington.

The election of David A. Stretch, president of the Atlas Corporation, as chairman of Northeast Airlines, was announced yesterday at Boston, following a regular meeting of the directors. Mr. Stretch succeeds George E. Gardner, who retired as chairman but will remain on the board and become a vice president of Atlas, the airline's majority stockholder.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 (Reuters) -- A second-wicket stand of 137 by N. J. Contractor and P. Umrigar gave India a good start in the fifth and last cricket test match against the West Indies today.
A guard at the City Prison in the Bronx was arrested yesterday on charges of accepting a $100 bribe to smuggle narcotics to an inmate.

The Tidewater Oil Company reported yesterday that it cleared $2,600,000 in 1958. In the quarter ended on Sept. 30, the company had a net loss of $607,000 and in the nine months to that date had a net loss of $328,00.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Federal Judge Edward J. Devitt signed a temporary restraining order today heading off a system-wide strike called by conductors and brakemen of the Great Northern Railway.

By adopting a plan to institute a 2 P. M. curtain time for midweek matinees starting March 18 Broadway Showmen have taken an encouraging step toward helping ease midtown rush-hour jams, insuring domestic tranquillity and luring more patrons to the local legitimate playhouses.

In your edition of Feb. 4 there is an editorial entitled "Mexico and Guatemala" wherein you express the opinion that "there would seem to be only one way out, and one wonders why it has not been used. Any third interested party in the Organization of American States can propose mediation or offer to mediate."
Directors of P. Lorillard Company yesterday voted to split the tobacco company's common stock on a two-for-one basis. It produces Kent, Old Gold and Newport cigarettes.

The gravity of Spain's economic crisis has been obvious for a long time despite Generalissimo Franco's complacency on the subject. However, so long as the United States has its valuable air and naval bases in Spain and keeps pouring economic aid into the country there will probably be no collapse. Perhaps the Caudillo has a right to some complacency on that score.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent to 119.2 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Dr. Walter W. Heller, University of Minnesota economist, told the House General Education subcommittee today that this nation had ample economic resources to finance any educational effort it wished to undertake.
Several hundred spectators watched the contract bridge champions of Italy, Argentina and the United States play a warm-up session last night for the 1959 official team-of-four world championship.
Proposed legislation to improve housing conditions in the state was discussed yesterday at a conference conducted by the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.
A new dial telephone intercom system has been developed to ensure security in government and business operations. It is now in operation at the Israeli Consulate here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Treasury Department has postponed the lifting of the countervailing penalty on Uraguayan wool top imports, pending a Senate committee hearing.
The Navy's newest colossus, the supercarrier Independence, returned from her maiden voyage yesterday and received only a pallid harbor reception because of the tugboat strike.
Harbor traffic, which has been severely curtailed for six and a half days by the absence of 400 strikebound tugboats, barges and oil craft, may start returning to normal this afternoon.

The two five-story apartment buildings at 305 East Eleventh Street and 310 East Twelfth Street have been sold by the Highmount Realty Corporation, representing a group of Swiss investors. The properties were purchased by Highmount Realty Associates, who are investing clients of Alan Brothers, attorney.

NEWARK, Feb. 6 (AP) -The Essex Drug Company, a distributor from the Bronx, filed an antitrust suit in United States District Court yesterday against the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company of Morris Plains. Essex asked treble damages totaling $150,000.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 6 -- The Danish Government announced tonight that all hope had been given up for the Danish ship Hans Hedtoft, which disappeared off Greenland with ninety five passengers and crew after having hit an Iceberg last Friday.

Directors of H. L. Green Company, Inc., and of Variety Stores, Inc., have reached a preliminary agreement whereby Green would purchase Variety's equity ownership in the United Stores Corporation. Maurice E. Olen, president of Green, in announcing the proposed merger, said "further details must await the drafting of a purchase agreement by counsel for each party."

The legalization and taxation of off-track betting on horse races have been recommended by a 4-to-2 vote of the committee named by Mayor Wagner last October to study the proposal. One of the seven committee members was unable to vote because of illness.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Sputnik III is expected to make visible passes directly over New York City and Boston this week-end.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 6 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that if he ever visited the Soviet Union, as Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev suggested yesterday, it would not be in response to "an off-hand invitation extended in a political speech."
A new attempt to settle a teachers' salary dispute that has closed the city's sixteen evening high schools will be made today.
A second major denomination announced yesterday the appropriation of funds to aid churches that may suffer financially if racial integration causes parishioners to withdraw.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The Thruway Authority wants to sell twenty-nine small parcels of land in Westchester County that it has found it does not need. Most parcels are less than an acre each. The largest parcel is twelve acres.
Commodity futures prices closed mostly lower on the New York exchanges yesterday. Trading was dull and featureless. Evening of positions before the week-end accounted for most of the volume.
An elixir of youth, which keeps insects at an early stage of development and prolongs their lives, has been found in human beings.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 -- Fifteen years ago Elliott and Ruth Handler were a suburban couple doing spare-time tinkering with handicrafts in their garage.
Talent is a wonderful gift but, especially when it reveals itself early, it must be developed carefully. The prodigy who never grows up is a sad and familiar story.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 6 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Albert V. Bryan rejected today a request to delay the enrollment Tuesday of nine Negroes in three previously all-white Alexandria public schools.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- Alan Robert Nye, a 30-year-old United States citizen being detained here, said today that he had "not signed any confession" that he had been hired by the Batista regime for $100,000 to kill Fidel Castro.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Mrs. Mildred Fairchild Woodbury of the National Child Labor Committee today urged that children be given the same protection from exploitation on commercial farms as in industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A method of causing oil wells to flow by the use of sound waves was patented this week. Powerful acoustic vibrations set up a resonance and actually fracture oil-bearing rock, much as an opera singer is said to be able to break a glass with certain tones.

MIAMI, Feb. 6 -- Bardstown of the Calumet Farm will be the strong choice to take tomorrow's $50,000 added McLennan Handicap. This 7-year-old campaigner will concede from eight to sixteen pounds to eight rivals in the test of a mile and an eighth and yet is expected to be even money or perhaps less.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Secretary of Defense testified today that circumstances might arise to warrant reversal of the Administration's policy of limited production of intercontinental ballastic missiles.

Murrow's recent radio broadcast on "The Business of Sex."

"THE PHIL HARRIS SHOW" meandered along unevenly last night on Channel 4, soaring from rickety dialogue to some pleasant musical interludes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Secret Service announced today the arrest of two Salt Lake City men accused of taking part in a conspiracy to steal gold from the Kennecott Copper Company and sell it on black market.

Lent, the forty days of fasting before the festival of Easter, begins in the Western church next week with Ash Wednesday, a day of penitence.

A. Angelica is not rhubarb,! !but a herb that grows in Lap-; iland, Iceland, the Scandinavian1 countries and in the Alps. It was a favorite English garden plant in the sixteenth century, and Mary of Scotland planted it at Holyrood and again in the garden at Chatsworth House during her imprisonment there.
TOKYO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Bank of Japan confirmed today the purchase of $50,000,000 worth of gold from the United States.

IN 1953, during the Broadway opening of a show called "Can-Can," an unknown, red-haired dancer was changing in her dressing room after having completed the second of her two featured numbers.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 6 -- Middlebury College skiers today threatened Dartmouth's long reign in its own winter carnival.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate passed tonight a bill calling for $465,000,000 to help states and communities develop airports in a four-year period starting next July 1. The roll-call vote was 63-22.

IT is always a problem to select the one best chocolate in a box. But, according to many hostesses, no such difficulty is encountered when there are brownies on a plate of assorted cookies. Served with tea, coffee or dessert, the rich chocolate confection is a general favorite and the first to be chosen.

A cooperative program that provides leadership and services of proved value to meet the baffling and complex special needs of our ever-changing city is offered by the Protestant Council of the City of New York, 71 West Twenty-third Street, New York 10. The festivity that precedes Fat Tuesday (that is Mardi Gras, for which New Orleans is famous) came to Broadway last night and it was a gay, colorful, though compressed version of its Southern sister.

Steel capacity in the Chicago area registered a net gain of 2,300,000 ingot tons during 1958, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry has reported. WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Department of Agriculture figures show that Federal farm price supports would be cut sharply under Administration recommendations for major revision of farm law.

ONE of the most obvious attractions of the historical Archive Production series issued by the German Grammophon Gesellschaft and distributed in this country by Decca records is the care with which the old instruments, or their modern counterparts, are selected to re-create the original sonorities of each work.

DOLLS and story-telling and maneuvers with toy trucks may still have their prized place during play periods in first-grade classrooms across the nation -- but not at Cocoa Beach, Fla., near Cape Canaveral. There, when it comes time to choose a game, the choice often is, "Launch a satellite!" Then things move toward "T" -- time for firing.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 7 -Emil (Bus) Mosbacher today sailed the 42-foot yawl Callooh, owned by Jack M. Brown, to victory in the thirty-mile Nassau Cup race.

IN the first line of "Fighting Bulls," Angus Macnab acknowledges that Hemingway's "Death in the Afternoon" remains the standard work of literature in the English language on bullfighting, but he then points out that it dealt chiefly with pre-1930 events "and its outlook is that of before 1928," two crucial dates in Spanish bullfighting.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 7 -Princeton's sophomore tailback, Hugh Scott, proved his worth on the ice today, scoring three goals to lead the Tigers to a 6-1 Ivy League victory over the Cornell hockey team. He had one assist.

WHEN he was in Coon Hill High School, Monte Linkletter -- who almost certainly is the Cricket Smith of this delightful boyhood memoir -- made a wonderful discovery: Midwestern farmers seldom their homes on the banks of the rivers that meander through their lands.

PRAYER, has been defined as "talking with God," and some of the finest writers in the language have given us examples of this special kind of talk, both in prose and poetry. The English writer, Elfrida Vipont, has here made an unusually varied and rewarding selection of brief prayers that will have meaning and beauty for young readers.

A disarmingly simple suit is the front-page fashion story this spring. In brief, it is nothing more than an open-faced jacket and a straight skirt, often with its own blouse. Designed on all price levels, the easy-going suit has stolen the hearts of American women because it stresses the stylish yet casual look for which they are already famous.

Two assignments were handed to the New York Knickerbockers last night. They were asked to beat the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden and to catch an 11:15 train to Syracuse. They carried out one of the assignments.

The seven or eight thousand persons in Brooklyn who will soon have no choice but to move out and make way for the Narrows bridge are expressive types of our times. Small consolation, no doubt, but they have a vast companionship.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7 -The resignation of Labor Minister Alfredo Allende was attributed today to discord within the Administration because of President Arturo. Frondizi's heavy reliance on the armed forces for political support.
French period furniture, paintings, old porcelains and Oriental rugs will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison avenue.

IT was a lucky day that brought together Deborah, a 10-year-old Cockney waif, and Gil, a boy who had come to London from Texas for a crucial eye operation. She persuaded him not to be scared of being permanently blind, lured him outdoors for a picnic in a park, where they rescued a stolen puppy and made friends with a young thief who "'ad a way with dawgs."

The elemental unit, or "atom," of heredity is the gene. The cells of all living things contain thousands of them, each for a specific hereditary characteristic. They are the agents used by nature to transmit hereditary traits from parent to offspring in the entire realm of life, from bacteria to higher animals, including man.

MR. SEAGLE accuses me of being "nonsensical or libelous." As an attorney, he well knows that the latter charge is groundless and I will write it off to injured pride. The hard fact remains that, in his own words, Mr. Seagle considers most of the constitutional protections available to a criminal defendant to be "meaningless techniques."

THREE new chrysanthemums have won top honors as All-America Mum Selections for 1959. Two of them -- Crimson Lady and Flair (a lavender) -- are cushion 'mums. The third, Girl Friend (pink), is a tall decorative type.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Joe W. Brown's Tenacious snapped out of his losing habits today and won the $11,875 Louisiana Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 30 -- The world knows cricket as the typical English sport. It has taken root nearly everywhere English empirebuilders have been. It is played under the same rules in Africa and Australia, India and the Caribbean, but not the carefree Polynesians of the South Pacific.

THE Abraham Lincoln born in Kentucky one hundred and fifty years ago looms colossal in American history or in world annals. Mystery attaches to him -- all that may lurk in "Democracy" or "The American Dream." Many believe this mystery is there in him more than in any other one man of the past. Other leaders had it greatly but somehow or other Lincoln is closer to the people and always he's close to storm.

The junco, the chickadee, the small woodpeckers, all those lively feathered ones who are so active through the winter days -- how do they make out?

SATURDAY will mark the hundredth anniversary of Oregon's statehood. For the past twelve months the second oldest of the West Coast states (the oldest is California) has occupied itself busily in planning frontier-style celebrations to honor the occasion.

A NEW Pacific cruise service will be introduced this April when the Orient and Pacific Lines' Himalaya steams from the West Coast to the Far East. The line, the largest operating in Pacific waters and a part of Britain's formidable Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, has been serving the Pacific for some time but the Himalaya will be its first Ship calling at Japan on a new Pacific route.

Madison Square Garden will be filled with 2,544 dogs tomorrow and Tuesday. Many will be the finest of their kinds.

A good deal of the zip went out of the stock market last week. Prices moved hesitantly in a narrow range. By the close on Friday, The New York Times combined average of fifty representative listed issues had lost 4.87 points.

One of the nation's ten mostwanted criminals was told to "get out of here" when he tried to hold up a Broadway restaurant cashier late Friday night. The man fle empty-handed and was captured in a few moments.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7 -- The United Jewish Appeal opened here tonight a two-fold campaign for 1959 to meet Jewish needs the world over. The emphasis in the program is being put on the new immigration emergency confronting Israel.

BEN HECHT'S original television drama, "The Third Commandment," performed yesterday afternoon, was an excoriating indictment of false evangelism and faith healing performed for profit. It was a work of power, controversy and vigor, with a commanding performance by Arthur Kennedy as the gag writer who commercialized revivalism.

Khrushchev of the Soviet Union and Chou Enlai of Communist China.

A Bronx interracial congregation held its first service in a new church yesterday. The edifice is a $200,000 structure belonging to the Sound View Presbyterian Church at Sound View and Lafayette Avenues.
