Widespread opposition in upstate New York to curbing discriminatory practices against Negroes and Puerto Ricans was reported yesterday by Charles Abrams.
The second of the season's three Music Forgotten and Remembered concerts took plane Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Museum.

Despite mounting opposition, Mayor Wagner was confident yesterday that the Republican-controlled Legislature would give the city the power to impose most, if not all, of its proposed new or increased special taxes.
The Democratic Minority Leader in the State Senate defended Carmine G. De Sapio yesterday as "a liberal leader."

Speaking as a long-time commuter on the Long Island Rail Roa I don't think that such letters a that from Nathan M. Klein, president of the North Shore Commuter Association, do anything to solve the commuter problem.
"Our Town," Thornton Wilder's drama that captured the Pulitzer Prize for the 1937-38 Broadway season, will be the next production at the Circle in the Square.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Archaeologists have discovered a thousand - year - old platform mound of Mexican design in southwestern Arizona.
On Saturday night the New York Knickerbockers had to hustle out of Madison Square Garden to catch an 11:15 train to Syracuse, where they played yesterday.

The Town Hall Annex, a five-story office building at 125 West Forty-third Street, has been sold by the National Board of Presbyterian Missions. It adjoins Town Hall and was purchased by Nation Wide Investors, Inc ., Eugene A. Hegy, president. O'Gara Co. were the brokers.

Last week's piece here was devoted to a discussion of the comparatively recent development of spot-checking to ascertain, on the basis of very small samples, the attitudes, intentions and behavior of the American consumer population.
Andre Kostelanetz conducted the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall last night with Leonard Pennario as soloist in Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 2 in C minor.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals beat the New York Knickerbockers 113 -- 104 in a nationally televised basketball game today. The Knicks had won all nine previous clashes between the Eastern Division National Basketball Association clubs this season.

The loss of Meyer Berger to The New York Times and to our whole community is an unusual one. We have lost an individual who defied any sort of routine classification. And we have all of us lost a warm, gentle and perceptive friend.

IT IS unfortunate that restaurants, unlike Broadway shows, never open out of town. A pre-Manhattan stint in New Haven might give the waiters an opportunity to coordinate their activities, the bartender a chance to improve his drinks and the chef ample time to expedite food to the patron's table so that it will arrive piping hot.

High praise, including a prediction for all-out success at the Westminster Kennel Club show, was showered on the winner of the best-in-breed award at the annual specialty of the Bulldog Club of America yesterday.
Ch. Merry brooks Fair Reward, the tan-and-white wirehaired fox terrier who won best to show at the big Eastern Dog Club event in Boston a week ago, scored again yesterday.
Ch. Hollee's Top Preview, a 3-year-old fawn-colored dog, was selected best of breed at the sixteenth annual American Boxer Club's specialty show last night at the 102nd Engineers Armory.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) -- Bronco Horvath scored three times, leading the Boston Bruins to a 4 -- 1 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers at the Garden tonight.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Neither the Soviet press nor domestic broadcasts told the Russian people today about the Moscow radio's denunciation of a United States tape recording of radio messages between Soviet fighter pilots said to have shot down an American plane.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 8 -- (AP) -- Gene Sandvig of Minneapolis and Keith Meyer of Glen Ellyn, Ill., members of the 1960 United States Olympic team, tied for the senior men's title today in the North American speed skating championships. A third Olympic skater, Los Angeles' Dick Hunt, finished third, a point behind.

THE New Century Players, who gave their first concert a year ago, gave their second one last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The flute and piccolo playing of Claude Monteux, the leader of the group, was consistently good, but the rest of the playing was uneven.

The United States bridge team yesterday afternoon took a three-point lead over Italy in the three-team contest between the United States. Italy, and Argentina for the 1959 team-off-four world championship.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 8 -- With apparent progress in the Zurich negotiations, a mood of guarded optimism increased in Cyprus during the week-end. It is qualified only by slight misgivings among Greek Cypriotes that a settlement is being "fixed" between Greece, Turkey and Britain without direct Cypriote participation.
The sponsor of the "Arthur Murray Party" has decided to decline a National Broadcasting Company invitation to switch the program to Sunday evening in the 8:30 to 9 o'clock time period.

THE notion that children should be seen and not heard still prevails to a large extent in South America, according to the observations of two recent visitors. The results, they believe, vary from desirable to highly questionable.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Karl Schranz of Austria today became the first to win three consecutive men's Alpine combined titles in the Arlberg-Kandahar ski meet.
The Rev. Pierre Delattre, a young Congregational minister who went to work among the rebels of San Francisco's Beat Generation, is conducting a rebellion of his own.
The Rev. Joseph D. Huntley called on Christians yesterday to "expose the shallow thinking" of persons who regard the death penalty as a deterrent to crime.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt renewed today his contention that the lowering of state income tax exemptions was unnecessary.

Coal and grain rates slipped again last week, driving the steamship charter market index to its lowest point in more than four mouths. Volume was up sharply, however, both in the dry-cargo and tanker trades.

The blues received some varied goings-over in the course of a jazz concert at Carnegie Hall at midnight Saturday. The performers were Jame: Moody and his band. Ray Charles and his band and Dinah Washington, singer.
ROME, Feb. 8 -- A new split today among Italy's Socialists added to the troubles besetting Premier-designate Antonio Segni and increased the chances of a swing to the Right in the country's politics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Maj. Gen. William J. (Wild Bill) Donovan, lawyer, soldier, diplomat and director of the Office of Strategic Services in World War II, died today at Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 76 years old.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday he had "no high hope" for the success of the ecumenical council to be held in Rome in 1961.
ALGIERS, Feb. 8 -- Premier Michel Debre declared upon his arrival here tonight that Algeria, just like the French mainland, would remain under French sovereignty.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Grain futures prices worked slowly and steadily up most of last week on the Board of Trade without the benefit of any new commercial influences.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 8 -- Bill Rigney, the 41-year-old manager of the San Francisco Giants, and his wife Paula were seriously injured when their car crashed into a power pole here early today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A new attack on court congestion will begin tomorrow in Brooklyn's Federal Court, which has the worst record of delay and congestion in the Federal judicial system.
CAIRO, Feb. 8 -- The first Asian-African youth conference closed this morning with about 400 delegates standing holding hands in a show of harmony. The week's events had not been quite so harmonious.

An entertaining horticultural chamber-opera by Vivian Fine, "A Guide to the Life Expectancy of a Rose," dominated the Saturday evening Composers Forum concert at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifty-third Street. Some of its appeal came as a result of a colorful and imaginative staging, previously unannounced, by Martha Graham and others.
Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey charged last night that Jews were being persecuted systematically in the Soviet Union and Communist satellite nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended Feb. 7.
LONG known as THE home furnishings store catering to the "carriage trade," W J Sloane is about to give that slogan a new meaning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House late today from a five-day holiday at the plantation in Thomasville, Ga., of George M. Humphrey, former Secretary of the Treasury.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The stock market showed strength last week, with industrial, British Government and gold issues participating in the gains.

The American Committee for Flags of Necessity criticized the leaders of two maritime unions yesterday for attacks on "runaway" ships. These ships register under foreign flags for tax benefits and lower wage minimums.

Seven years ago Scout Troop 88, sponsored by Congregation Beth Elohim in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, had languished almost to the point of extinction. There was talk of turning in its charter.

The team investigating last Tuesday's airliner crash in the East River began their study yesterday of the Lockheed Electra's instrument panel. They have high hopes that it will enable them to determine the cause of the accident.
Wine again is in the affairs of Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., and Compton Advertising, Inc., has made new gains in its liquor business.
The use of both curb lanes for buses on Fifth and Madison Avenues after the avenues are converted this summer to one-way operation is being explored by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.
Abba Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, said last night that his young nation could absorb the rising tide of Jewish immigration from Europe.

The plan to take the Navy hospital ship Consolation out of mothballs and send her on a year's visit to Southeast Asia is most imaginative and at the same time relatively simple. The vessel will be a combination hospital and medical school. She will carry a complement of about 200 doctors and an equal number of nurses.

The release of large numbers of Jews from East European countries will mean more than 100,000 immigrants to Israel, Mayor Gershon Agron of Jerusalem said yesterday. He spoke at the midwinter meeting of the National Committee for Labor Israel in the Commodore Hotel.
HOMEMAKERS contemplating spring decorating may be interested in Gene McDonald's new line of hand-screened fabrics. They are available through decorators at the McDonald Showroom, 509 Madison Avenue.
In your editorial of Feb. 2 you urge support of a court reform bill, introduced in the State Assembly by Robert Walmsley, based on the proposals of the Judicial Conference.

Dr. Bernard Schwartz, former House investigator, said here yesterday that he believed there should be a formal Congressional inquiry into contacts between the White House press secretary and the Federal Communications Commission.
The LaSalle String Quartet played the complete works of Anton Webern for string quartet Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. They took less than twenty minutes.

William Zeckendorf announced plans yesterday to build a forty-eight-story hotel in the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets. The site is on the east side of the avenue just north of the Radio City Music Hall.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 8 -- Greece and Turkey were believed today to have agreed that Cyprus should be independent, but with guarantees that Cypriote policies would not endanger Turkey's security.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced meritorious service awards yesterday to 483 members of the department.
SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Roger Dion, a Paul Smiths College freshman, accounted for the East's major ski jumping surprise of the season today by capturing the Connecticut State championship.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- Sixteen over-age skiers flexed their muscles today in the fourth renewal of the Old-Timers jumping tournament and slalom race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The International Cooperation Administration announced today the sale to two American corporations of $72,000,000 worth of investment guaranty contracts. The aim is to protect proposed investments by the companies in the huge bauxite mining and refining project in Guinea, West Africa.

Thurgood Marshall, chief counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that progress was being made in integration in the South. The only question, he added, is whether the progress is fast enough.
New York is not the only state government that faces the choice between tax increases and reduced spending in 1959.

The Kroger Company reported over the week-end a net income of $21,629,930 for 1958, or $1.76 each on the 12,319,317 shares outstanding after a three-for-one stock split approved last Dec. 10. Earnings equal 1.2 cents on each dollar of sales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Two newly found telegrams in Mary Todd Lincoln's hand tend to bear out the contention of many scholars that Lincoln's wife played a disturbed and disturbing role in his official life.

MADRID, Feb. 8 -- The United States policy that brought about what Franco considers a Spanish-American "alliance" was not an invention of the Eisenhower Administration. It was conceived by Democrats in 1950.

Three Haitian opposition political parties signed an agreement here yesterday to seek the dismissal from office of the regime of President Francois Duvalier in favor of "a democratic provisional government." They withheld comment on how they proposed to achieve this aim.
Ideally, man's economic life graph would show a steep mountain climb followed by a long, gradual descent.
A MAN who was Gen. Charles De Gaulle's pilot and who has explored 16,000 miles of Africa under the flag of the Museum of Natural History has recently completed another and different mission.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 8 -- There was no repetition of last year's charges of discrimination as Princeton University's social and dining clubs ended their election of members early this morning.

Thomas K. Finletter, one of the leaders in a movement to revamp the leadership of the Democratic party, greeted with disbelief last night a report that former Gov. Averell Harriman opposes the movement and regards it as doomed.

AVON, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Three years ago Frank Efinger went to the Avon Old Farms School to teach English. Efinger is a track enthusiast from 'way back. As an 8-year-old he raced around the streets in the Parkchester section of the Bronx.
An intricate peace move was under way last night to prevent secession of the giant United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners from the merged labor federation.
Nathan Milstein played his only New York violin recital of the season at Hunter College on Saturday evening. It was the ninth event of the Hunter College 1958-59 subscription series.
Four films are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
Work has been started on the new $965,000 cargo shed the city will erect at Twenty-ninth Street, in the Gowanus Bay area of Brooklyn.
The annual specialty show of the Pug Dog Club of America, held yesterday at the Hotel Sheraton-McAlpin with an entry of fifty-nine dogs, had a repeat winner.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 -- Steel orders were pouring into mills last week and there was no indication of slowing in the flow this week. Meanwhile production was expected to continue climbing. More furnaces are to be lighted to take care of rapidly increasing backlogs.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- In one respect Governor Rockefeller has made political history since he moved into the Capitol six weeks ago.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- When a man is the top banana in the track and field bunch, like Ron Delany, his influence tends to pervade the whole scene.
Roman Catholics were urged yesterday to regard sacrifice and penance as part of their "duty" during the Lenten season, which begins on Wednesday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 4 -- At the level of its international civil service assembled here the European Economic Community, or common market, is busy organizing itself economically. At the level of its higher officials and of the six member Governments it is in quest of a common foreign policy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The senate has established a subcommittee "to make a full and complete study and investigation" of administrative practices in Government departments and agencies.

A producing firm has been organized by Michael McAloney and Don Mankiewicz. Their initial entry, scheduled for next season after an experimental tour of the straw-hat circuit, is "The Better Man," described as "a higa comedy," set in London's swanky Mayfair section.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Sputnik III is continuing to orbit over the United States in the evening twilight.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 9 -- The top political and military leaders of this neutralist nation welcomed today the newly announced United States arms deal with Indonesia.
Net income of Standard Brands, Inc., last year increased 6.2 per cent to $14,690,214 from the $13,837,524 cleared in 1957, Joel S. Mitchell, president, reported yesterday.
Life on a modern farm was described by seven farm youths yesterday at a luncheon attended by 175 business men, farmers and educators. The luncheon was held at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Following is the text of a letter today from Senator J. William Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, to Secretary of State John Foster Dulles on ambassadorial appointments:

There are hundreds of things that could be said about Gen. William J. Donovan. He was a tradition as "Wild Bill." He commanded the "Fighting Sixty-ninth." He organized O. S. S. He was our Ambassador to Thailand at a time when Southeast Asia was an exceptionally "sensitive" area. He was a recognized public servant of the highest caliber. All that he was asked to do he did well.
BY the ingenuity of his playwriting, Reginald Lawrence has made the case of Lizzie Borden uninteresting.
TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- The Assembly approved and rushed to the Senate today a bill that would create a bi-state agency to devise a long-term solution to the critical commuter railroad problem.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Feb. 7 -- Lovanium University is not too little. But there is a question it might be too late.

Mayor Wagner's letter to Albany presenting New York City's fiscal program persists in the assumption that legalization and taxation of offtrack gambling remain within the realm of possibility. This would appear to be unrealistic in spite of the Republican strategy reported to be under consideration at Albany. But the Mayor's real reliance, and it always has been, is on a rise in the retail sales tax from 3 per cent to 4 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 (AP) -Stan (The Man) Musial, relaxed and confident, signed his second straight $100,000 contract with the St. Louis Cardinals today.
Applications for higher automobile liability insurance rates that would have cost the state's motorists and truckers $245,000,000 were rejected yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prices drifted lower today in quiet stock market trading. Selling was light but demand was restrained by Friday's setback on Wall Street and the customary balancing at the end of the bookkeeping account.
Burke Dowling Adams, Inc., and St. Georges Keyes, Inc., may be parties to Madison Avenue's next major merger. Total billings would be an estimated total of $20,000,000.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 9 -- A morning and an afternoon showing of the motion picture, "Knock on Wood," starring Danny Kaye, will be given exclusively for school children by the Darien-New Canaan Smith College Club on Feb. 24 at the Darien Playhouse.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers, behind for only two minutes, clung to second place in the National Basketball Association's Western Division tonight by defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 128 -- 122.
BAGHDAD, Iraq., Feb. 9 -For the first time Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq faces a united and increasingly bitter opposition of Arab nationalists.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 9 -- The Premiers of Greece and Turkey reached the threshold of a Cyprus solution in a three-and-a-half-hour talk here today.
PARIS, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Sixteen leading world airlines opened negotiations today on the thorny topic of jetliner fares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Senate Democratic leader who has been frequently mentioned as a possible presidential candidate, is now attending meetings of the Senate's Western Regional Conference.

Office buildings, a department store, a hotel, a motel and an apartment house are among the proposed structures to be built by the Diesel Construction Company this year. According to Carl A. Morse, president of Diesel, this program will set a record for any one year in the company's history.

WASHINGTON Feb. 9 -- The treasury bill rate rose a little this week, the treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,400,000,000 of 90-day bills was 2.810 per cent compared with 2.721 per cent last week, and the average rate on $400,000,000 of 181-day bills was 3.326 per cent compared with 3.107 per cent last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Administration announced a plan today to spur the construction of school and college classrooms through Federal aid toward retirement of bond issues.

For sheer, persistent success, none of the other dogs among the 2,544 entered in the Westminster Kennel Club show that began yesterday in Madison Square Garden equaled a bateared French bulldog from Livonia, Mich., named Champion Bouquet Nouvelle Ami.
ATLANTA, Feb. 9 -- The outlook for the nation's cotton growers is good, despite a sharp decline last year in consumption, according to the chief economist of the National Cotton Council.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Senate sent to the House today a bill to permit the use for the next two years of a coal tar coloring for oranges.
A program to speed up justice in Federal Court in Brooklyn, where cases filed nearly four years ago have not yet come to trial, was begun yesterday to mixed praise and criticism.
Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev appears to have introduced some important new elements into Communist theory in his major speech at the twenty-first Communist party congress, which ended last week.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., in a preliminary report yesterday put earnings for 1958 at "approximately'' $7,000,000, or $2.31 a share, compared with $9,378,000, or $3.21 a share, in 1957. Last year's profit showing was due entirely to a change effected by the company in its accounting procedures.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The No. 1 United States team, guided by Art Tyler, took the lead today in the St. Moritz four-man open bobsled championship, but the United States Air Force sled caused more excitement when it "took off."
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9 -- A team of United States military instructors is expected here soon to work with the Argentine Army on problems of curbing Communist subversion, according to Army sources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- A New York advertising executive today urged Madison Avenue to promote a twenty-four-hour-a-day educational television effort beamed at every "farm, tenement and garret."

In the most auspicious start by an amateur in years in challenging for the world open court tennis championship, Northrup Knox of Buffalo and Aiken, S. C., defeated Albert (Jack) Johnson, 3 sets to 1, yesterday in the first part of their match at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller rejected summarily today Democratic demands that he withdraw his recommendation for the lowering of income tax exemptions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Two things are worrying officials here about Secretary of State Dulles' illness, one personal and the other organizational. The personal problems is not primarily the necessity for a hernia operation but the fact that last year's attack of diverticulitis (inflammation of the colon) has not cleared up.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Thousands of children with low I. Q. ratings are being deprived of their right to free public education because local school systems will not take them in, the Joint Legislative Committee on Mental Retardation was told today.
I wish to refer to the letter from the Consul General of Guatemala published on Feb. 6 in connection with your editorial of Feb. 4 "Mexico and Guatemala."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved current standards on free baggage aboard airliners today.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Feb. 9 -- Government forces have recaptured the small garrison city of Santa Barbara after the outbreak of a revolt in northwest Honduras.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 9 -- The presence of thirteen Dominicans in political asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy here has strained the already bad relations between the Dominican Republic and Venezuela.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Following is the text of a special message Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature tonight urging a two-year extension of state residential rent controls:
Weakness in the metal markets sent commodity futures irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull and featureless in most markets.

Although both sides caution against premature optimism, the Greek-Turkish negotiations on Cyprus have made so much progress that a solution of this dangerous problem appears at last to be in sight. Some issues must still be resolved, but there is agreement on fundamentals to the point that the Greek and Turkish Foreign Ministers are drafting a new Constitution for the island.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 AP) -Wheat futures, both old and new crops, were the leading gainers today in a generally steady to strong market on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Rural electric cooperatives were told today to start looking for private funds because they did not have a "lifetime guarantee of Federal financing."

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 9 -- The best laugh during yesterday's two-man world bobsled championships here was provided by Gerard Pradeau's and Andre Donnet's French sled. The two riders lost control at the start and were bounced out into the snow.
State Controller Arthur Levitt asserted yesterday that population was no longer adequate as the sole criterion for state aid to communities. He advocated "a complete re-evaluation."
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 1 -- A white flag hoisted over an old, gray, gabled building here recently marked a major triumph in Czechoslovakia's fight against alcoholism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States arms deal with Indonesia announced yesterday results from a reassessment here of Indonesian neutralism.
DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP) -The auto industry, which built 545,760 cars last month, is scheduling 500,000 units for assembly this month.
Frank W. Thober's letter appearing in your Feb. 6 issue, defending taxes, missed the point why people bitterly complain about them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee today approved a bill to require sixty-day notice to the Federal Government of certain proposed corporate mergers.
GENEVA, Feb. 9 -- The tiny Alpine village of Herbriggen was threatened today with obliteration.
Mark Van Doren, poet, author, critic and educator, said yesterday that he would retire in June from his teaching post at Columbia University.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- President Francois Duvalier appealed today for United States economic assistance to "push the country's progress."

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Mayor Wagner of New York has come out in support of a bill to permit public welfare officials to place children in foster homes outside of the state. Such placements are now limited to families within the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare called today for a "militant majority" to prevail over the "militant minority" blocking water fluoridation in many cities.
ROME, Feb. 9 -- Pope John XXIII revealed today the draft of a stern speech that Pope Pius XI had planned to deliver twenty years ago next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency called today for an orderly tapering off of the Government's airport grant program. President Eisenhower has recommended such a curtailment.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 9 -- A new liberal front in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, to be known as the Central Africa party, was formed today.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- In a special message to the Legislature tonight, Governor Rockefeller asked for a two-year extension of state residential rent controls. They are now scheduled to expire on June 30.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 9 -- Tengku (Prince) Abdul Rahman, first Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, resigned today. He announced his decision at a meeting of his party, the United Malay National Organization, in Kuala Lumpur.
NEWARK, Feb. 9 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission opened the final phase of a hearing today on an application by the Lehigh Valley Railroad to abandon its passenger service on May 12.
A new attempt by city mediators failed yesterday to end a dispute over teachers' salaries that has closed the city's sixteen evening high schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Senator J. William Fulbright notified the Administration today that the Senate would henceforth insist on the appointment of "first-rate Ambassadors in every post."
Mayor Wagner lined up squarely with Carmine G. De Sapio yesterday in the controversy within the Democratic party over Mr. De Sapio's leadership.

The "Handbook of Information" of the Lincoln Sesquicentennial Commission to celebrate officially the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's birth on Feb. 12 of this year is a curious mixture of fact and fable.
NASHUA, N. H., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Maurice Gagnon, Rhode Island man who built a one-man cellar operation into a large plastics business, was found slain in his Cadillac here today.
A New York City banker predicted yesterday that legislation providing equitable tax treatment for self-employed pensioners would be passed before the present Congress adjourns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The Subversive Activities Control Board reaffirmed today its finding that the United States Communist party was Moscow-dominated and should register with the Department of Justice.
Sales and earnings last year of the Maytag Company, home laundry appliance maker, far exceeded those for 1957. The company reported record results in the fourth quarter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States and its allies have reaffirmed their intention to hold their positions in West Berlin by force if necessary. Secretary of State Dulles announced the Western determination on his return today from Europe, where he met with leaders of the British, French and West German Governments.

Nassau and Suffolk County, L. I., financial institutions complained yesterday that Governor Rockefeller had declined to hear their case for keeping branches of the large New York City banks out of their territory.
New York City bankers suggested yesterday that Mayor Wagner's proposed 2-cent-a-check tax might produce substantially less revenue than the $12,000,000 a year he has estimated.
I have read with interest your Feb. 2 editorial concerning the Haitian situation.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Britain firmly endorsed today the United States-West German formula of "no concessions without counter-concessions" for negotiating a settlement of the German issue with the Soviet Union.

DEATH was the occasion that inspired a great deal of primitive and ancient art. The elaborate rituals accompanying death in both preColumbian and Egyptian art are symbolized in an exhibition of unusual mummy masks at the Delacorte Gallery, 822 Madison Avenue.

I can sympathize with the enormous problems that Governor Rockefeller is confronted with as he seeks to put New York State on a pay-as-you-go basis, and admire his courage in speaking forthrightly for what he believes must be done to help reach this end.
RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 9 -Gov. Luther H. Hodges presented the General Assembly tonight proposals for a biennial budget balanced without tax increases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -Walter P. Reuther told Congress today that the nation could solve most of its problems by achieving a 5 per cent annual growth in the economy. The recent growth has been about 2 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 -The president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States declared today that a "drift toward Federal statism" would not be stopped until leaders in business and management became politically active.
James R. Dyer was reelected yesterday to his fourth consecutive term as chairman of the board of governors of the American Stock Exchange.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29 -- The two Communist Capitals with the most in common are the two with the most interesting contrasts -- Belgrade and Warsaw.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- More emphasis on science and mathematics in schools might lead to a spread of juvenile delinquency, an authority in the field declared today.
Once a person is inside a bowling establishment it's up to the proprietor to have the proper equipment, provide comfort and show the newcomer how to enjoy the game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, took an indefinite leave of absence today. He will undergo surgery for a hernia condition and receive further treatment for an intestinal disorder.
Churchgoers will observe Ash Wednesday tomorrow, the beginning of the penitential season of Lent.

IN its second season the Harpischord Music Society is presenting three forums and two concerts. Last night it gave the first of those concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall before a fashionable audience that included a liberal sprinkling of literary celebrities.

Directors of libraries, curators, scholars and students thronged the great hall of the Duke mansion last night. It was the first time in twenty years that the classic building at Fifth Avenue and Seventyeighth Street had been opened to a large group.
In its second season of nerican operas this spring, the New York City Center will present eight works nev to its repertory.

Four large blocks of common stocks worth a total of more than $5,000,000 were offered yesterday to investors in secondary distributions. Such sales do not represent company financing, but are a way of distributing a large holding.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- As Under Secretary of State, Christian Archibald Herter has for the last two years had the misfortune of being Number Two man in a one-man State Department.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The president of the American Medical Association suggested today that physicians be forced to keep pace with medical progress.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is considering an offer to present commercial messages on television for a manufacturer of oleomargarine. Three commercials already have been recorded on film for study purposes, although they are not yet committeed for use on television.

The first annual awards supper dance of the American National Theatre and Academy (ANTA) will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor next Tuesday. The event, an ANTA benefit, will inaugurate an annual award expressing recognition of and paying tribute to important young talent of the American stage.

SOME of the prettiest and most delicate new lingerie is of man-made fibers. The fabrics are as soft as silk and as filmy as chiffon. They have fast-drying qualities and a penchant for being washed without ironing.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 9 -The Air Force School of Aviation Medicine at near-by Randolph Air Force base celebrated its tenth anniversary today. It prepared for its expected role as the trainer of space travelers, both animal and human.

THE best commercial marmalades are those made from Seville oranges, a variety not obtainable in most markets. Each year, if the fruit is available, John R. Buchanan obtains a shipment for the customers of his food specialty shop in Grand Central Terminal.
The Owens-Illinois Glass Company and its consolidated subsidiaries cleared a record total of $37,772,005 last year on sales of $508,459,930, second highest in its history.

SR WINSTON CHURCHILL once said that those who ask what we are fighting for would soon find out if we stopped. We may well bear the idea in mind as we read Arthur Larson's new book, "What We Are For,"* a rousing challenge to our time's stylish moods of defeatism and despair.

A sharp rally in lumber production in the last four months of 1958 brought output for the year to 33,275,000,000 board feet, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. This was only 1 per cent below the 1957 figure.

ROME, Feb. 9 -- Premier-designate Antonio Segni applied himself today to the task of trying to reconstitute the fourparty Center coalition that gave Italy stable and efficient governments most of the time from 1947 to the middle of 1958.

CARTERET, N. J., Feb. 9 -The Mayor of this Middlesex County borough began a personal inquiry today into the forty-member police force. The investigation was prompted by the arrest of twelve men last week for allegedly running a $1,500,000-a-year numbers racket.

SAGINAW, Mich. Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The Chairman of the Senate Republican Campaign Committee said tonight that Michigan was declining industrially because United Automobile Workers leaders had it in a "stranglehold."
New restraints on teen-age drivers are being considered in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.
Vincent Astor's individual ownership of the St. Regis Hotel created a problem that required quick action after his death last Tuesday, it was made known yesterday.

A Long Island business man who has been linked by the Government to a $400,000 bank swindle, was accused yesterday in the Federal Court in Brooklyn of having participated in a $10,000 Federal Housing Administration fraud.
The snow that started falling on the city yesterday morning gave way later to a freezing drizzle that pocked the highways with hazardous patches of ice.

A letter arrived the other day from Eugene S. Wilson, Dean of Admission of Amherst College. He is trying hard to prevent high school athletes from accepting the wrong college scholarship. Wilson referred to an article that appeared in this space last week dealing with the problems of athletes besieged with scholarship offers.

St. John's, with a 13-4 wonlost record, and Villanova (14-4) yesterday became the first quintets to accept bids to the National Invitation college basketball tournament. The twenty-second annual competition will be staged at Madison Square Garden March 12 through March 21.

ALGIERS, Feb. 9 -- Michel Debre, Premier of France, reaffirmed in the name of President Charles de Gaulle today that "there will be no political negotiations" with Algerian nationalist leaders abroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- The Senate rackets committee will open its juke box investigation tomorrow with testimony about a company that a committee member once served as vice president.

The New York Regional Red Cross blood program received on Friday 647 pints of blood, including 352 at the United States Military Academy, West Point, N. Y. Also included were 152 pints given at the America Fore Insurance Companies, 80 Maiden Lane.

HARD-HEADED men will be wearing soft hats in 1959. This confident prediction comes from Harry Rolnick, president of Byer-Rolnick, the third largest manufacturer of men's hats in the nation. His concern turns out Resistol, Kevin McAndrew and Churchill hats.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (AP) -Clevite Corporation of Cleveland announced today that it had completed negotiations for acquisition of Walco Products, Inc., East Orange, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Senate Democratic Leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, said today Congress "has not been the spender but the saver" in dealing with the Federal budget.

GENEVA, Feb. 9 -- The United States and Britain said today that a Soviet Foreign Ministry statement Saturday grossly misrepresented their position at the three-power conference on a treaty for a cessation of tests of nuclear weapons.
Animal research suggesting that X-ray treatment of the heart may be beneficial for some heart disease cases has been reported by surgeons at Mount Sinai Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee brushed aside Treasury objections today and voted overwhelmingly to grant special tax relief to self-employed persons trying to save for their old age.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission handed down its final word in the Arvida case today, saying that it had put the securities industry on "unmistakable notice" about its limited right to publicize upcoming securities offerings.
Managements of the Pittsburgh Steel Company and of the Sharon Steel Corporation announced yesterday that discussions for merging the two concerns were being terminated.

The Federal Aviation Agency has imposed stringent new restrictions on bad-weather landings by the Lockheed Electra -the type of turbo-prop airliner that crashed into the East River last Tuesday with a loss of sixty-five lives.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller hinted today that he might force Mayor Wagner to choose between increasing the New York City sales tax to 4 per cent and legalizing offtrack betting on horse races for tax purposes.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Stockholders of Reynolds Metals Company today authorized the issuance of an additional 2,000,000 shares of stock, 1,000,000 of a new, second preferred and 1,000,000 of common.

The Grolier Society, a book publisher occupying five floors in the new building at 575 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fifty-first Street, has leased an additional floor. It now uses 57,000 square feet there.
THE comedy on last night's "Lucille Ball-Desi Arnaz Show" over Channel 2 ranged from pantomime to pratfall. Most of it was daffy and thoroughly enjoyable.

Transportation these days is in a jam -- economically and physically, on the rails as well as on the roads. The human passenger hears that he is a fiscal drain on the railroads, while the steer and the pig are not.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 9 (AP) -A film of ice covered electrical magnets in the starting gate at Bowie race track today and caused the first false start in twelve years at a Maryland track.

CHET HUNTLEY'S editorial criticism of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has now been confused further by a bewildering statement of policy by the National Broadcasting Company.

The Government security market -- which speaks with authority because it speaks with the public's money -- repeated for the benefit of Congress at the close of last week what the President, his Secretary of the Treasury and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board have been constantly emphasizing in their recent public statements.

WHEN Napoleon Lajoie was 40 years old, he still moved about a ball field with the grace of a big cat. One day that season he stood at the plate, the stylist supreme. With relaxed nonchalance he watched the pitcher try to tempt him with two teasers outside the strike zone. Lajoie didn't bite. He waited. The next pitch would have to be on the beam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Two Army generals testified today that Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy had rejected their urgent plea to put in production a missile that could shoot down Soviet intercontinental rockets.

The United States late last night led Italy by one international match point with onethird of the nine-day, team-offour world championship completed here at the Statler Hilton Hotel. Three teams, including Argentina, are participating.
The quest for materials that will function dependably in rocket and missile controls at high temperatures has given new stature to a rare tough, silvery metal named rhenium.

Storm warnings were posted for the New York Rangers yesterday, and the man who hoisted the danger signal was Coach Phil Watson. Pulling no punches, Watson warned his men that if they didn't show improvement in their play there would be no European trip for the club in late April.
The William Waldorf Astor estate has extended its holdings on Eighth Avenue to include the entire west blockfront between Forty-first and Fortysecond Streets.
A $250,000 breach-of-contract suit charging major league baseball with killing a minor league club through radio and television broadcasts went to trial yesterday in Federal court.
Lieut. Bill Dellinger of the Air Force decided yesterday to stay in the mile run, rather than switch to the two-mile event, in the New York Athletic Club's games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller rejected today any plan for adopting a flat $20 fee for all motor vehicle license plates.
All Brooklyn will be served by a single gas company soon.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 9 to 14 points up on old-crop months and 10 to 14 points off on new-crop months from Friday's close. A point is 5 cents a bale.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Bankruptcy trustees of the Boston Post Publishing Company seek to recover $1,217,485 they declare was improperly turned over to the North Penn Gas Company of Port Allegany.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Plans for the constitutional development of British Somaliland that would give its people "executive responsibility" in the Government by the end of 1960 were announced by the Colonial Office today.

The leaders of both the Soviet Union and Communist China have been at some pains recently to persuade the world that their alliance stands firm and unmarred by discord. Premier Khrushchev and other speakers at the last party congress spoke often and warmly of the Chinese Communists, while denouncing the Yugoslavs for daring to spread suggestions that all is not sweetness and light between Moscow and Peiping.
Foreign tourists are outnumbering business men 6 to 1 in visits to the United States, an American Express travel survey reported yesterday.

Steel production rose last week to the highest level since mid-April of 1957 as the industry sought to cope with growing backlogs of unfilled orders. Output was expected to continue increasing this week.

An account of the United States Postal Inspection Service, told in terms of the dramatic cases the inspectors have successfully handled, will be published April 27 by Dutton. Called "The Silent Investigators," it has been written by John N. Makris, a former newspaper reporter and feature writer.
Mario Sereni, Mattiwilda Dobbs and Belen Amparan appeared in new Metropolitan roles in last night's performance of Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera."
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 9 (Reuters) -- Two United States freighters collided tonight in dense fog in the new waterway, Rotterdam's outlet to the sea.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- This is a painful story to tell, and it will be distressing to many a strong, hardy outdoorsman who has been trying for twenty years to hit things with a shotgun. Yet in the interests of pure science it must be told.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The State Department challenged Moscow today to tell the Soviet people abolt a United States tape recording that has been cited as proof that Soviet pilots shot down an unarmed American plane last September.

FOR the last three months, Miss Katherine Alexeieff of St. John's University has been a photoelectronic image to hundreds of students. This afternoon, this instructor in the Russian language will appear in person, complete with samovar and pirozhki, before 300 of her television disciples.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- Producers of motion pictures in Hollywood spend approxi mately $300,000,000 annually in the community, Y. Frank Freeman told a luncheon meeting of the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce today.

Fair Dinkum, Mr. Sports Editor, you are a real Bonza Bloke for having gone to so much trouble to report the main features of the cricket test match series between Australia and England. We Australians have won back the Ashes which we lost for the first time in nearly thirty years to the mother country back in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Old Kent Bank and Trust Company asked the United States District Court today to rule that the Federal Reserve board has no authority to bar it from operating branches stemming from a merger.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Envin D. Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor, said today American education placed too much emphasis on preparing young people for jobs, professions and careers.
A hold-up man shot and killed a customer who joshed him last night as he was robbing a Brooklyn luggage shop.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The competitive maneuvers of Senator Kennedy and Secretary Mitchell over 1959 labor legislation are affected with a public interest beyond that implicit in the immediate subjectmatter. This extra element is contributed by the fact that the Senator is the front-runner among those Democrats who seek the 1960 Presidential nomination of their party, and the Secretary aspires to the Republican nomination for Vice President.

GENEVA, Feb. 9 -- The Executive Committee of the World Council of Churches began a four-day meeting here tonight. The Rev. Dr. Franklin Clark Fry, president of the United Lutheran Church of America, is chairman.

Robert Whitehead received the annual Barter Theatre of Virginia Award last night for "the most distinguished contribution to the American theatre during the current season." Mr. Whitehead's productions this season include "A Touch of the Poet," "The Cold Wind and the Warm" and "Goldilocks."
A dispute between the United States and Britain over competing air navigation systems is expected to dominate a meeting of twenty-five nations that begins today in Montreal.

Stefan Redl extended his winning streak at St. Nicholas Arena to thirteen last night by scoring a unanimous decision over Ernie (Sonny Boy) Williams of Washington in a tenround bout. A crowd of 1,145 paid $2,424.17.

The Continental Can Company increased net sales last year 3.3 per cent to a record $1,080,393,000 from the previous peak of $1,046,267,000 set in 1957, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, U. S. A. ret., board chairman, reported in a preliminary statement released today.
It is difficult to see how a tax plan such as Governor Rockefeller offers, which will hurt so many people, can be expected to do any good.
A three-alarm fire caused thirty explosions yesterday in the Chemistry Annex on the Bronx campus of Fordham University. The flames reached heights of sixty feet. Damage was estimated at $500,000.

The State of California announced yesterday that it would receive bids March 11 on an issue of $100,000,000 of bonds to finance public construction and loans to war veterans for the purchase of homes and farms.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 9 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus announced today that he would propose a law to give state funds to students who do not wish to attend integrated schools.
Heavy orders were placed yesterday at the eighth annual Trade Show of the House-toHouse industry in the New Yorker Hotel.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 -- A school budget of $16,193,312 was approved tonight by the Board of School Estimate here after a two-hour public hearing. It is expected to increase the city's tax rate by $6 on each $1,000 of assessed property valuation.
Market values of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange declined about $3,800,000,000 yesterday.

Mike Wallace and National Telefilm Associates are close to completing an agreement whereby he will conduct a nightly news program over Channel 13 and also do an interview program for syndication to stations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The justice Department has published for the first time an official statement of its legal advice to President Eisenhower in the use of Federal troops in Little Rock, Ark.
New capital issues of local government debt securities were absorbed in volume by the bond market yesterday.

"Le Roi est mort; vive le Roi!" was the ritualistic announcement made upon the death of the French king. Arthur Krock in his column of Jan. 29 seems to have revived it for America. For him the cry is, "Calhoun is dead; long live Calhounism!"

HAS anyone seen Frank Loesser ? The Fank Loesser who composed the music and lyrics for Where's Charle?" and "Guys and Dolls" and then not only created the music and lyrics, but also the libretto for "The Most Happy Fella."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 25 -- Taiwan's economy has attained its most stable level since 1952, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs. However, the Chinese Nationalist Government remains heavily dependent on United States support for huge military expenditures and a modest program of industrial expansion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Dr. Frank J. Welch will have to decide, possibly this week, whether he will stay on as a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority without White House assurances that he will be appointed to a full term next year.
FOR all his digging into the past, Newell Jenkins found his most interesting pieces for last night's Clarion Concerts program at Town Hall in the twentieth century.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Eisenhower expressed the suspicion today that false radio signals sometimes lured United States pilots off course and into Communist territory.
Tax reductions to encourage increased private investment abroad must be regarded as part of national security measures, Representative Hale Boggs declared yesterday.
One of the largest of the postwar crop of office buildings here will be erected on Third Avenue between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets.

The tri-state Governors' conference yesterday on commuter railroad problems confirmed the certainty that finding a solution will challenge the best we have in governmental leadership. One hopeful development of the meeting was the apparent agreement among Governors Rockefeller, Meyner and Ribicoff that initiative and responsibility must originate at the local or state, rather than Federal, level.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the winter wheat crop remained dormant in central and northern parts of the country on Feb. 1 because of cold weather.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 10 -- Four members of the United States House of Representatives conferred today with Judge Helge Klaestad, President of the International Court of Justice, about possible measures to strengthen the tribunal's position.
ELLA and The Duke had a ball last night. And it would seem prudent to assume that so did the viewers who were watching them over Channel 4.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
The advisory board of the counselor to Jewish students at Columbia University accepted the resignation of Arthur Hays Sulzberger yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Retail sales in January totaled $16,340,000,000, more than $1,000,000,000 above the volume for the same month last year.

FOR the second of its three New York concerts last night in Carnegie Hall, the Cleveland Orchestra under the direction of George Szell played an orthodox program. Rudolf Firkusny was soloist in Mozart's Piano Concerto in E flat (K. 271), and the purely orchestral pieces were the Berlioz "Benvenuto Cellini" Overture, Schumann's First Symphony and Strauss' "Death and Transfiguration."

Prof. Hanson Blatz, a radiation hazards expert, was appointed yesterday as the first director of radiation control in the City Department of Health. For ten years he served as chief of the Atomic Energy Commission's Radiation Branch, Health and Safety Laboratories.

A new book by C. L. Sulzberger, author of "The Big Thaw," will be published March 11 by Harcourt, Brace. Called "What's Wrong With U. S. Foreign Policy," the book is an extension of six articles published in Mr. Sulzberger's "Foreign Affairs" column in The New York Times.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- French-Tunisian relations, notably improved since Gen. Charles de Gaulle's return to power, took a sharp turn for the worse today.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Feb. 10 -- President Ramon Villeda Morales said today that an uprising against his Government would be quashed within the next few days.

ALGIERS, Feb. 10 -- Premier Michel Debre of France presided today over the first meeting of the forty-six-member commission set up to work out details of an economic development plan for Algeria. The project was announced by Gen. Charles de Gaulle last autumn.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 -- A tornado struck here without warning shortly after 2 A. M., Central standard time, today. Within three minutes it had left behind twenty-one known dead and more than 300 injured.

ROME, Feb. 10 -- After two days of consultations with the leaders of his own and other parties, Antonio Segni, Christian Democratic Premier-designate, saw little chance this evening of solving the Italian Cabinet crisis by forming a Center government.

While the textile industry's case for government assistance on imports has been strengthened by the report of a Senate sub-committee, the road ahead is still bumpy, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants, warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -A freshman member of Congress shook the experienced chairman of the House Agriculture Committee today.
Net income of the American Cyanamid Company and subsidiaries fell more than 14 per cent last year to $43,841,042, the company reported yesterday.
The construction of the second garage in the city's off-street parking program began yesterday on Eighth Avenue between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets.
Fog and rain disrupted air travel here yesterday and forced motorists to use extra caution on the highways.
HOUSTO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Joe Brown, the busiest of the boxing champions, will put his world lightweight title on the line for the sixth time in two years tomorrow night when he meets Johnny Busso.
"MY prime Olympic objective next year," said Ron Delany in his lilting fashion, "is the 800 meters."

In the midst of the controversy about the political future of Netherlands New Guinea, the Dutch have gone ahead with an interesting plan. They propose to hold popular elections in the Schouten Islands group to choose a "representative council" of twenty Papuans. This council, in turn, will work toward the establishment of village units in which representative government can be introduced.

IS Madison Avenue fretting over its television image? It would seem so in the wake of several suggestions by officials of advertising agencies that the time has come to think beyond their 15 per cent commission and give fresh consideration to education and culture on the home medium.

Broadway stage directors and choreographers met late Monday night and formally declared the establishment of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers. The new organization, it was determined, will be a membership corporation, operating under the laws of the State of New York.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet press charged today that the Western Allies still were clinging to "their old cold war line" on the questions of Germany and West Berlin.

Futures prices closed irregularly lower in generally dull and featureless trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, the world sugar months, wool, hides, rubber and burlap declined; copper, lead and potatoes rose, and price movements for coffee, domestic sugar, cottonseed oil and zinc were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee awarded four contracts to private research organizations today in its $300,000 study of the nation's foreign policy.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 10 -- The Premiers of Greece and Turkey decided to try again tomorrow for a Cyprus settlement after having fallen short of one during a ninety-minute conversation tonight.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 10 -- The General Electric Company said today that it would protest the award last Friday by the Tennessee Valley Authority of a contract for a 500,000-kilowatt turbogenerator to an English company, C. A. Parsons Co., Ltd., of Newcastle.

Cal MacCracken of the Princeton Club gained the final round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A singles championship yesterday by checking Vic Elmaleh of North Shore, 15 -12, 15 -12, 15 -9, at the University Club.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Teams headed by Art Tyler and Stan Benham today qualified to represent the United States in the world four-man bobsled championships and a German crew became the favorite for the week-end competition.

Officials of the Denver United States National Bank in Denver announced yesterday that they had obtained a sixty-day option to buy Denver's Mile-High Center from Webb Knapp, Inc. The option, they said, is "subject to satisfactory financing."

Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, accused evening high school teachers yesterday of "setting up picket lines to intimidate and threaten people who are willing to fulfill their professional responsibilities."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Eisenhower said today that there would be no delay in possible negotiations with the Soviet Union on the future of Germany as a result of the illness of John Foster Dulles.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., last year had the highest sales and earnings in its 110-year history.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The grain futures market overcame early moderate profit taking today in most contracts on the Board of Trade and closed steady to firm in a late rally.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Juke boxes, which thrive on those odd dimes and quarters, probably pay off to the tune of at least $300,000,000 a year.
The 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's birth will be observed here tomorrow at meetings and ceremonies held under the auspices of political, patriotic and civic organizations.

MADRID, Feb. 10 -- Although the United States and Spain are partners in what is tantamount to a military alliance, the only political tenet we share is mutual dislike of communism. It is therefore with particular interest that we regard Franco's efforts to combat that ideology.
The Kings County District Attorney's office yesterday asked that a longtime city employe be adjudged in contempt because of his refusal to fill out a financial questionnaire.

Educators recently have gone on record with the obvious notation that our new advances in space exploration will familiarize later generations with the layout of the solar system as thoroughly as we have been with the geography of the forty-eight states.

ON the license plate of the official car used by President Ramon Villeda Morales, whose forces seem to, be overcoming a revolt in northwest Honduras, is this legend: "Constitutional President of the Republic."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -President Eisenhower made a comment today that illustrates the change that has gradually developed in the selection of top foreign policy officials of the Government.

The Thrift Shop Committee of the Windham Children's Service is planning a bridge and canasta party and tea for the benefit of the agency. The fete will take place in the headquarters of the National Society of Colonial Dames at 215 East Seventy-first Street on the afternoon of Feb. 24.
Mayor Wagner estimated yesterday that the impecunious city treasury might expect an annual tax yield of $100,000,000 from legalized off-track betting on horse races.

MANHASSET, L. I., Feb. 10 -- A resolution for the construction of a controversial North Hempstead Town incinerator on Hempstead Harbor, near Roslyn, was adopted unanimously here today by the Town Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today endorsed as "a wonderful thing" a privately sponsored project to send the Navy hospital ship Consolation on a goodwill mission to Southeast Asia.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- How do you spot a potential juvenile delinquent before he causes trouble?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The number of unemployed rose in January to 4,724,000, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A measure that would require motion-picture theatre operators to be licensed by the Motion Picture Division of the State Department of Education is about to be submitted to the Legislature.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 10 -- The first of three local flood- control projects was initiated last night.
Proposals are being proffered to increase postages, gasoline tax and dues to obtain a few hundred millions of increased revenues.

Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, testified yesterday that he could do nothing to solve the problem of major league radio and television invasion of minor league territory for fear of causing antitrust action against baseball.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today that the committee in charge of patronage for the House had no authority to permit a Chicago Negro boy who is not a page to enter the Capitol page school.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank (Eximbank) is studying a report on a projected $74,000,000 steel producing plant for the Philippines. The report was submitted yesterday by officials of Koppers, Inc., a Pittsburgh concern that had made an engineering survey for the Philippines Government.

Screen Gems, Inc., has taken an option on the services of Sid Caesar for a proposed series of television films. If the option is exercised, Mr. Caesar will star in twenty-six half-hour situation comedy programs. Hal Janis, executive producer of the Shellrick Corporation, the comedian's company, said that no pilot film would be made.
ALMA, Ga., Feb. 10 -- Three men killed about a hundred quail on Gerard Jones' shooting preserve today and thereby drove another nail in the coffin of public hunting in the South.

FOR more years than I like to think I have been defending the proposition that we are living in a literary period that can truly be called the golden age of the historical novel -- and this in spite of the floods of mechanical and sensational trash that debase and disgrace that honorable subdivision of fiction.

A five-story building containing thirty-three apartments and occupying a plot 81 by 100 feet at 1277 Shakespeare Avenue in the Bronx was sold by Fred Indig. An investing client of Milton Tunick bought the property through the Philip Fogel Company, broker. The terms were cash over mortgages amounting to $95,000.
TOKYO, Feb. 10 -- Japan's Cabinet began today a formal study of an official proposal to repatriate Koreans residing here to Communist North Korea, if they wish to go there.

Changing plans overnight after consulting with his superior officer, Lieut. Bill Dellinger of the Air Force decided yesterday to switch from the Baxter Mile to the Toussaint Two Mile in Saturday's New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden.
A 38-year-old Filipino physician accused of slaying his Brooklyn woman friend pleaded guilty yesterday to first-degree manslaughter before Judge Nathan R. Sobel in Kings County Court.

Frustrated by the Tuscarora Indians, Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, announced yesterday that the authority would go ahead with plans for a smaller reservoir, not using Indian lands, for the Niagara power project, even though this meant less power at higher cost.

After twenty years at 521 Fifth Avenue, Eisner Lubin, certified public accountants, will move to the office building under construction next door at 529 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-fourth Street. They leased a floor in the new structure from Ivor B. Clark and Erwin S. Wolfson, builders and owners. Elk Realty, Inc., was the broker.

The local spiked-shoe set is getting soft. Just because it was cold, dark and drizzly and a few patches of ice decorated the board jumping runways at Ohio Field yesterday, the outdoor field events of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track championships were put off until today.
MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The meeting killed a British motion that long-range navigation systems be kept in mind when the short-range systems were discussed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 -- A week's postponement, until next Tuesday, was granted today by a Securities and Exchange Commission examiner in a hearing on fraud charges brought by the commission against Reynolds Co., a New York brokerage concern.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Feb. 10 -- The visit of a group of American financiers headed by David Rockefeller has focused new attention on the Belgian Congo's Inga project, potentially one of the greatest hydroelectric developments in the world.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A three-day strike by announcers, newsmen and disk jockeys ended tonight at KYW radio and television stations.
In the wake of Mayor Wagner's defense of Carmine G. De Sapio, Thomas K. Finletter declared yesterday that if the Mayor was opposed to the "democratization" of the Democratic party he should say so.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Pentagon sent Congress today its annual new construction program. It would cost $1,356,290,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- A claim by Rouben Mamoulian that he was entitled to screen credit on "Porgy and Bess" on the basis of his prefilming contributions to the production has been denied by the Screen Directors Guild. The organization's board of directors reviewed last night findings by the Guild's Credits Investigation Committee and "unanimously decided" that sole directorial credit belongs to Otto Preminger.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 10 -- The carnival came to a noisy end tonight and Argentines turned to the reality of austerity and social unrest.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday a reduction ranging from 5 cents to 15 cents a barrel in the selling prices of Venezuelan crude oil. This action followed a similar reduction made by the Shell Oil Company, another leading producer in Venezuela.

HONG KONG, Feb. 10 -- The courts last year operated as an integral part of Communist China's high-pressure production drive. They were also powerful instruments in enforcing acceptance of the country's new system of communes.
ROME, Feb. 10 -- Pope John XXIII urged the clergy today to administer "wisdom, simplicity and charity" from the pulpit rather than concern themselves with consummate showmanship.
Roy E. Larsen, president of Time, Inc., urged the advertising and communications industries yesterday to help sell ideas and promote higher national tastes and standards.

The Federal Aviation Agency announced yesterday that Lockheed Electra turbo-prop airliners could resume normal flying operations if they returned to older instruments for measuring altitude instead of a new type.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Following is a transscript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 10 -- Negro children entered another white school system in Virginia today, and again without trouble.

TOKYO, Feb. 10 -- Eric Johnston urged a program of "regional loan funds" today to buttress Asian, Middle Eastern and African countries in the non-Communist world. He suggested that Japan should be "one of the principal architects" of such a plan for Asia, under United States sponsorship.

Cooke and agreed to recommend a "package" measure to the 1959 legislature.

Unemployment increased by 616,000 in January, according to the combined monthly figures of the Departments of Commerce and Labor, reaching 4,724,000. January marks the third consecutive month in which the figure has risen. At its low point of October it stood at 3,805,000 hence, the ground lost in this recovery-resistant area over three months has aggregated 919,000.
