As had been anticipated, Fordham had a minimum of trouble defeating City College in the annual basketball game between the metropolitan schools last night in the Fordham Gymnasium. Breaking open the contest with a 9-point spurt late in the first half.
GENEVA, Feb. 11 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the East and West be evenly balanced in the proposed control commission for policing a ban on testing nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Fol lowing are President Eisenhower's remarks today before the annual meeting of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association at the National Guard Armory here;

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Dr. Bruno Pittermann, Vice Chancellor of Austria, ended his visit to Washington today with calls on Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Allen W. Dulles, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- The Government of Laos renounced today the Geneva agreements that ended the Indochina war in 1954.
A card party to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on March 6 will benefit the Scholarship Fund of the Texas Club of New York.
The Children's Blood Foundation at the New York Hospital will benefit from the Feb. 26 performance of "Redhead," the musical starring Gwen Verdon, at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre.
LILLE, France, Feb. 11 -- The gray and foggy industrial north is still Gaullist, but it is starting to waver a little.

A crew of sixteen expert check handlers at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York completed yesterday drying and processing of some 50,000 checks valued at about $21,000,000 recovered from the American Airlines plane that crashed last week into the East River.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- The Whirlpool Corporation announced this week that it would display a "Kitchen of the Future" and a "Kitchen of Today" in Moscow. The occasion will be the American National Exhibition in Sokolniki Park.
The nation's steel-makers turned out more ingots and steel for castings last month than in any other month since June, 1957, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11 (UPI) -Workers toiled in below-freezing temperatures today to clear away rubble left by a tornado that hit the heart of this city. Twenty-two persons were killed yesterday by the twister and more than 350 were injured.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -President Eisenhower borrowed from the political philosophy of Abraham Lincoln today to advise Congress that the FederalGovernment should not borrow money to spend on improvements.

The six-story building containing fifty-five apartments at 155 West Seventy-first Street has been purchased by Seymour Candee, realty operator, who resold his contract to an investing client of A. Michael Katz.

Jean Casadesus was the pianist in last night's Young Artists series at the Metropolitan Museum. Pie played pieces by Bach and Mozart, Schumann's rarely heard Intermezzi, Op. 4, the first book of Debussy's "Images" and Prokofieff's Sonata Iqo. 2 in D mino.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Representative Dale Alford, Democrat of Arkansas, accused the Department of Justice today of having ordered a "politically inspired" investigation into his election last Nov. 4.

NYACK, N. Y., Feb. 11 -Three villages in Rockland, most rural of the counties that ring New York City, hope to save 50 per cent of their projected costs in cleaning out slums and blighted business districts.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Warren C. Giles, the president of the National League, said today he had proposed that changes be made in two baseball rules before the 1959 season opens.
The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday that 8,000 ground crew and flight employes at Pan American World Airways had authorized a strike "on or before March 1."
PARIS, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- A deadlock over trans-Atlantic jet fares threatened tonight to break up a conference of sixteen major international airlines.
ALGIERS, Feb. 11 -- Premier Michel Debre appealed tonight to Frenchmen here to understand that the lot of the Algerian Moslems must be improved if Algeria was to remain French.
The High School Teachers Association called upon Mayor Wagner yesterday to intervene in the salary dispute that has closed the city's sixteen evening high schools.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 5 -- Brussels, like New York, has a tendency to pull down old buildings and erect in their places ultra-modern structures with lots of glass, chromium and steel furniture.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Britain's trade position improved last month, with exports rising and imports falling, the Board of Trade disclosed today.

Philip Carmel, realty investor, has purchased the former I. J. Fox Building, an eight-story structure on lot 41 by 111 feet at 393 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets. The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, the seller, acquired the structure six years ago and remodeled it into an office building containing 35,000 square feet of space, exclusive of the store and mezzanine areas.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Feb. 11 -- More than fifteen notices of zoning law violations have been sent to occupants of residences here in the last ten days. Edward P. Larkin, presiding supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, said tonight that most of the occupants were professional men who live elsewhere, but maintain offices in sections that were zoned for residences.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Although no outbreaks of influenza have been reported in this country, the Public Health Service warned state health officers today of increasing reports of flu outbreaks in Europe.

Two rather obscure facts about Abraham Lincoln were made known yesterday: Lincoln had an honorary degree from Columbia University, and he was probably the only individual to receive such a degree in shirt sleeves.

Title to the blockfront on the north side of Wilshire Boulevard, from Flower to Lebanon Streets, in Los Angeles, has been taken by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, which plans a twenty-story office building, the tallest in the city.
The American Legion of New York County will celebrate Lincoln's Birthday tonight at 8 o'clock in the auditorium of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.
Bingo may yield about $70,000,000 a year in revenue for nonprofit organizations by 1961 or 1962, and still more after that, the chairman of the State Lottery Control Commission predicted yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Mayor Wagner made his annual pilgrimage up the Hudson today in search of more money for New York City.

Twenty more building inspectors balked yesterday when asked to fill out financial questionnaires prior to their appearances before a Brooklyn Grand Jury investigating graft in the Department of Buildings.
TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- Brendan T. Byrne, executive secretary to Gov. Robert B. Meyner, will become Acting Prosecutor of Essex County on Monday.

The Janmit Corporation, of which Jan Mitchell, owner of Luchow's Restaurant, is president, has acquired control of Longchamps, which owns and operates ten restaurants in New York and one each in Philadelphia and Washington.

A report on the mentally ill in America is given by John Bartlow Martin in his new book, "The Pane of Glass." Using the Columbus State Hospital in Ohio as representative of the country's vast state hospital system, Mr. Martin takes the reader on a resident physician's daily round, showing what the shortage of psychiatrists means in terms of prolonged suffering for the mentally ill. The book will be published next Wednesday by Harper.

The Bach Aria Group presented the third and final concert of its 1958-59 subscription series at Town Hall last night. Frank Brieff conducted the group's orchestra and the Columbus Boys' Choir of Princeton, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Secretary of State Dulles' recent discussions with West European leaders "completely fulfilled" his expectations, the House Foreign Affairs Committee was told today.
Occupants of three Harlem tenements were forced to leave their apartments yesterday after the city had ordered the electricity cut off in the crumbling, unheated buildings.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 11 -Virginia started today to map a long-range program to minimize the effects of public school integration.

OTTAWA, Feb. 11 -- The latest attempt by United States transportation interests to gain concessions from the Canadian Government in connection with new immigration regulations has met with little success.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 -David Blejer took over as Labor Minister today with instructions from President Arturo Frondizi to yin labor's support or tolerance for the national economic stabilization plan.

The Securities and Exchange Commission took action on several fronts yesterday against the F. L. Jacobs Company and its chairman and president, Alex L. Guterma, for alleged violations of Federal securities laws.

TOKYO, Feb. 11 -- The Government approved today the construction of twelve highspeed freighters for the Philippines as the nucleus of a Philippine merchant fleet. The contracts had been opposed by Japanese shipowners, who are fearful of Philippine competition on trans-Pacific cargo routes.
After seventy-three years of doing business on the West Side the Department of Marine and Aviation crossed to the East Side yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization began today a study of draft Western notes to the Soviet Union holding out the possibility of a four-power foreign ministers' meeting on German questions.
Four Harlem mothers who were found guilty of violating the compulsory education law will not be punished if they return their children to school under an agreement with the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- A Navy legal expert said today that Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover and other Government officials could copyright speeches, provided they were not delivered under official orders or as part of their official duties.
Every public opinion poll taken in the New York City area in the last decade on offtrack betting on horse races has shown two-thirds of those questioned favoring the idea.
Floodwaters were rapidly rising at least one Indiana city lake yesterday, while crisp winter weather seemed to offer a respite to parts of flood-weary Ohio, The Associated Press reported.

Pending a clearer picture of what is happening in Honduras one can only express the hope that the hard-won and precarious democracy of the country is not in jeopardy. Honduras had a long history of military dictatorships and political instability, and it was, in effect, a "banana republic."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Representatives of the nation's airlines and the unions they deal with have rejected proposals for compulsory arbitration of airline labor disputes.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- With Mayor Wagner's help, Governor Rockefeller won assurances today of Democratic support for all but one phase of his budget and tax program.
A determined Italian contract bridge team yesterday afternoon defeated the United States and recaptured the lead in the team-of-four world championships at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

Jerry Whyte's know-how as production supervisor over many years here and abroad in behalf of the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d entertainments will be put to the test next October. If negotiations are successfully concluded, Mr. Whyte's first independent presentation will be "Hot Summer Night."
Plans are being made for a gala Bal Masque to be held at the Metropolitan Club at 1 East Sixtieth Street on Feb. 21.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -President Eisenhower carried his campaign to "live within your means" to rural electric cooperatives today. He told them their achievements could be torpedoed and the free-enterprise system destroyed by continued reliance on Federal subsidies they and other groups receive.

Net income of the United States Rubber Company fell nearly 24 per cent last year, to $22,670,772, equal to $3.05 a common share after preferred dividends, H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, reported yesterday. But earnings for the fourth quarter were sharply above those for the like 1957 period.
ON a chilly September day in 1915, when he was 19 years old, Robert Whittle Dowling dived into the Hudson River and swam around Manhattan Island.

ATLANTA, Feb. 11 -- Senator Richard B. Russell strongly implied tonight that he would filibuster if necessary to block Congressional endorsement of the Supreme Court's desegregation decision as advocated by President Eisenhower.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Former State Senator Arthur H. Wicks denied from the witness stand today that he had any knowledge of alleged kickbacks involving the late Frank Buckley, an equipment dealer at Troy, N. Y.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 3 -- Czechoslovak school children, like their Soviet counterparts, are going to have to work part-time.

MANILA, Feb. 11 -- A new tax proposal submitted to Congress yesterday by President Carlos P. Garcia in his budget for the coming year appeared certain today to create more controversy between the Philippines and the United States.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- The Premiers of Greece and Turkey agreed today on a settlement of their countries' long quarrel over Cyprus.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Lewis L. Strauss, Secretary of Commerce, today urged business men to "help defend our economy" by resisting "unwarranted" wage demands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Macmillan, President Celal Bayar of Turkey and President Mohammed Ayub Khan of Pakistan have sent messages to the Shah of Iran urging him to stand firm with his Western allies.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Long Island bankers appealed to the Legislature today to keep New York City banks out of their territory.

Federal Judge F. Dickinson Letts deserves applause for having taken a long step forward in the purge of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. He has now signed an order giving the monitors he appointed full power to compel compliance with their orders. So far Provisional President Hoffa and his colleagues have largely obstructed the monitors' directives on the ground that they were purely advisory.
A citizens' committee to further public understanding of the United States' work in international health has been formed.

MIAMI, Feb. 12 -- Kingmaker of the Happy Hill Farm scored with ease in the feature race at Hialeah today. There was good reason why he should have scored with ease.
BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 3 -- Friction between the Roman Catholic Church in Catalonia and civil authorities is growing. The issue, a seemingly trivial one, is control of 3,000 Catholic Boy Scouts.

President Eisenhower called upon Congress yesterday to implement the recent proposals of the governors of the two Bretton Woods institutions by voting them additional dollar-lending authority -- a 50 per cent increase in the case of the International Monetary Fund and 100 per cent in the case of the World Bank. The original American subscription to the Fund was $2,750 million and that to the Bank $3,175 million.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 12 -- The Young Democratic Club of Greenwich charged today that this town's planning policies had kept moderate-income families from building homes here.

An 800-ton hydraulic shear able to cut through a two-inch-thick metal plate or a five-inch metal billet with ease has been installed in the scrap metal processing yard of S. Blumberg Sons Company in Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Included in a military promotion list that went to the Senate today were these Air Force officers: Cols. James M. Stewart, John B. Montgomery and Barry M. Goldwater.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12 -- Yugoslav sources suggested cautiously today that the Greek-Turkish accord on Cyprus could lead to a rebirth of the Balkan Pact linking the three nations.

As a registered Republican I am indignant that, according to recent reports, the appointment of Henry R. Labouisse as head of the International Cooperation Administration has been vetoed by Meade Alcorn, chairman of the Republican National Committee, on the grounds that Mr. Labouisse is not a Republican.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today it was preparing a formal memorandum in support of its plan to seek recovery of $20,000,000 from Boeing Aircraft Company, for alleged excessive profits on 1952 defense contracts.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -Grain futures moved irregularly in generally small changes today on the Board of Trade. Old-crop bread grains attracted demand. Soybeans were steady to firm on a late rally.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The Government's hasty re-investigation of the national security threat posed by oil imports has drawn written comments from thirty-odd companies and associations, only two of whom take a clear stand against any restriction.
Municipal Radio Station WNYC opened its twentieth annual American Music Festival yesterday afternoon at Town Hall with a program of music for strings.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Two Connecticut legislators today charged a "gradual deterioration" of service at the gasoline stations on the Merritt and Wilbur Cross Parkways.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Linmold, a 13-1 shot, scored the first stakes victory of his career in the $88,870 California Breeders' Championship at Santa Anita today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A leading Senate Democrat urged today that Berlin be unified through direct negotiations between East and West Germany.
MIAMI, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Alvin Dark won the medal today in the national baseball players' golf tournament. The Chicago Cubs' infielder, a three-time winner of this event, scored a three-over-par 73.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor; Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Glenn Gould, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8; Concordia Choir of Moorhead, Minn., Town Hall, 8:30; Inga Lind, poetry reader and Maxim Schur, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 11 -- The first space travelers to orbit the world in a United States vehicle will probably be four black mice, carrying instrument packs no heavier than a penny.
Gravediggers warned yesterday of a "probable" strike tomorrow or Monday against Roman Catholic, Jewish, Protestant and nonsectarian cemeteries in the New York area.

Most of the occupants of three Harlem tenements ordered vacated by the city this week were still there yesterday, although their electricity and gas had been cut off. The crumbling, unheated buildings are at 108, 114 and 128 West 134th Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Senator Richard L. Neuberger returned to the Senate today after a long and apparently successful fight with cancer. The Oregon Democrat told colleagues he was now dedicated to increased Federal aid for medical research.
Business was very good in the department stores in the city and suburban areas yesterday, but merchants were reluctant to compare sales with those of Lincoln's Birthday in 1958.
STIRLING, N. J., Feb. 12 -- A former lawyer-teacher-engineer observed today the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the Roman Catholic priesthood.

Pickands Mather Co., Cleveland iron ore concern sharing in the development of the Wabush Lake iron ore deposits of western Laborador, said yesterday that a statement by Newfoundland's Premier Joseph R. Smallwood concerning the project "needed clarification."
The 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's birth was observed yesterday with two wreath-laying ceremonies at his statue in Union Square.
TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Government rested its case today in the tax-evasion trial of Dave Beck, former head of the Teamsters Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The poet moved to the rostrum where Presidents and other statesmen before him had looked down upon the assembled leaders of the Republic and began to speak in vibrant, whispered cadences.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -The St. Louis Hawks wiped out a 27-point New York lead with a second-half drive and beat the Knicks, 106 -- 105, tonight on Al Ferrari's steal of the ball and Bob Pettit's winning jump shot with twenty-six seconds left.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- An Air Force Snark missile failed today to make a scheduled round-trip flight down the Atlantic firing range in a demonstration for fifteen members of the House Select Committee on Astronautics and Space Exploration.

Carmine Lombardozzi, who was spared from a gangland execution has been in Civil Prison at 434 West Thirty-seventh Street since Aug. 21. He was jailed for refusing to answer questions about the meeting of underworld leaders at Apalachin, N. Y., before the State Investigation Commission.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The State Budget Director estimated today that proposed income tax changes would yield at least $50,000,000 more in the second year they were in effect than in the first.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- The trend toward curtailment of personnel and expenditure for the promotion of motion pictures that is taking place in the movie industry is "the most disgraceful thing that has happened in this business." Max E. Youngstein, vice president of United Artists, declared today.
Sidney M. Barton, specialist in lease-back operations, yester announced the acquisition of several properties with a total value of $10,000,000.
PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Feb. 12 -- The fifth victim of an explosion yesterday at the Ingersoll-Rand Company plant here died today. Thirty persons were injured.

There was more trading in Greek Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday than in all the other thirty-two foreign obligations that figured in the day's business. Word that high-ranking Greek and Turkish officials had agreed on a settlement to the Cyprus question caused gains of as much as 5 3/4 points on the two issues of Greek debt listed on the Big Board.

OWENSBORO, Ky., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Federal Judge Henry L. Brooks issued a temporary order today restraining four unions from calling a strike against the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. It had been scheduled for noon tomorrow.

A PUNGENT, sweetish aroma surrounds the four-story brick factory at 80 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn. The odor is unmistakably mustard. Inside the building, complicated machinery of the Old Dutch Mustard Company mills the seeds into a flour or mixes them with vinegar and spices to make prepared mustard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Underworld chieftains, meeting in Apalachin, N. Y., commuted a gangland death sentence against a racketeer and fined him $10,000 for stepping out of line, Senate investigators were told today.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 12 -The West German Government does not intend to step up its contacts with the East German authorities, a spokesman said today.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy demoted a deputy chief inspector, two inspectors and a deputy inspector yesterday as two gambling scandals shook the department. He issued strong orders to the police to be severe with gamblers.

The Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East has reported to the United Nations that the spice-producing areas of south and southeast Asia have not made an adequate effort to restore their position in the spice market.
MIDDLE RIVER, Md., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- A Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train, on its way from Washington to New York, hit a damaged rail at eighty miles an hour today, derailing six rear cars.

When Yale and Columbia meet in wrestling at the Light Blue's Morningside Heights gymnasium tomorrow, Andy Fitch, Yale's captain, will have a highly interested but somewhat apprehensive private rooting section.

Kim Stanley and Jason Robards Jr., both of whom are starred in Broadway stage productions, have been named winners of the American National Theatre and Academy Awards for "outstanding contributions to the art of the living theatre."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -Representative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana, today asked Defense Secretary Neil H. McElroy to lay down a uniform policy for participation of the Army, Navy and Air Force Academy football teams in post-season Bowl games.
Attorney General William P. Rogers Jr. said last night that President Eisenhower's "solemn determination" to balance the Federal budget merited the support of all thoughtful Americans.

OTTAWA, Feb. 12 (AP) -The Senate Transport Committee today proposed that United States pilots be authorized to navigate in Canadian water of the Great Lakes only if the United States granted the same navigation rights to Canadian pilots in its waters.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 4 -- Youth work brigades, a characteristic of East European communism in the first years after the war, have reappeared in Czechoslovakia.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI) -Jack McIntyre, off balance and falling to the ice, caged a 15-foot shot in the third period tonight that lifted the Detroit Red Wings to a 1-0 decision over the New York Rangers.
Alex Olmedo, the Peruvian who led the United States Davis Cup team to victory over Australia, was placed at the top of the draw last night for the national indoor tennis championships.

Bob Carroll of St. John's broke a 17-years-old pole vault record and Manhattan College wrapped up its tenth straight team title in the concluding phase of the Metropolitan Inter-collegiate indoor track and field championships yesterday.

I am writing with respect to the increased New York State income taxes proposed by Governor Rockefeller. My remarks are not concerned with the need for taxes, because that is a matter that must be decided jointly by the Governor and the Legislature.

There were snickers earlier in the week when Lou Rossini, the New York University basketball coach, called his six-time-beaten quintet a "good team that is getting better." However, last night at Madison Square Garden the Violets upheld their coach's judgment by upsetting the Mountaineers of West Virginia, 72 -- 70, in a dramatic overtime encounter.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Britain, Greece and Turkey appeared tonight to be moving steadily toward a tripartite conference that could end their dispute over Cyprus.
The New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn has completed a major transplanting job on the carrier Valley Forge.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Rail carloadings in the week ended last Saturday totaled 565,397 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The blockfront on the east side of Fifth Avenue from East 106th to 107th Streets has been sold by the Philadelphia Real Estate Bank to clients of Walter Scott Co., brokers. Now vacant, the property fronts 200 feet on the avenue and 100 feet on each of the side streets.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 12 -- This community's second annual Winter Carnival, sponsored by the Parent-Teachers Association, will be held in the gymnasium of the Veterans Park School on Saturday. The proceeds will augment the association's fund for assistance to Ridgefield High School students of outstanding ability whose goal is a college education.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The South Korean Cabinet discussed the crisis with Japan at a three-hour session today and Foreign Minister Cho Chung Whan said a "momentous decision" was made.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 -Willy Brandt, the Mayor of West Berlin, expressed surprise today at a proposal by Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana that East and West Germany settle between them the problem of unification.

Directors of Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., operators of a chain of women's accessory stores, have declared a quarterly dividend of 45 cents on the common stock, payable March 12. In previous quarters the company ;paid 40 cents.

Back in 1956 Frankie Ryff of New York and Robert (Cisco) Andrade of Whittier, Calif., were considered among the foremost lightweight boxers of the world. They were flashy, colorful, fast-punching; they fought in the classic style.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved up 2 to 7 points (10 to 35 cents a bale) yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today urging an increase in this country's financial back-lag of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 12 -- A policy of coexistence, cessation of nuclear tests and organized international economic assistance without strings attached were among the topics discussed by Marshal Tito and Emperor Haile Selassie during the Yugoslav President's ten-day visit to Ethiopia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Following is the text of Carl Sandburg's address before a joint session of Congress today:

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- East German sources suggested today that the Soviet Union might be willing to provide its "good offices" for the settlement of any disputes arising over East German control of the Western Allies' access to Berlin.
GENEVA, Feb. 12 (UPI) -The World Council of Churches said today it was interested in the call by Pope John XXIII for a conclave on Christian unity only "on the basis of mutual respect."

Surging floodwaters of the Wabash River bore down on West Terre Haute, Ind., Thursday and National Guardsmen joined a sandbagging battle to reinforce a 300-foot break in the town's levee, The Associated Press reported.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 12 -The entire city police force was called out for "emergency action" and armed forces were asked to stand by tonight after a disturbance in Parliament. Twelve members of the Trotskylist Opposition were forcibly ejected.
THE ever - agreeable child, reared in a home in which hardly an angry word is spoken, may well develop an emotional problem in common with his opposite number.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Leland (Duke) Gibson of Kansas City carded three birdies in the stretch today to win the Professional Golfers Association quarter-century tournament with a thirty-six-hole total of 139.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Britain is consulting other Governments in the hope of establishing a free-trade area of eleven countries outside the already-functioning six-nation European Economic Community, or common market.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Alabama Supreme Court refused today to be bound by a United States Supreme Court decision setting aside a $100,000 fine against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
A commission was named yesterday by Mayor Wagner to recommend immediate measures for cutting costs and improving care in the city's hospitals.

The Roach company produced the film, which was directed by John Cromwell, whose return to the cinema was marked by his direction of Paddy Chayefsky's "The Goddess" last year.

NEWARK, Feb. 12 -- A witness before the Interstate Commerce Commission today charged officials of the Lehigh Valley Railroad with a "bad managerial guess" in utilizing its reserves to repurchase the road's outstanding bonds.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Bear Mountain's new twenty-meter hill got its first official workout today as Lake Placid Ski Club members won six of the nine top prizes in the New York State and United States Amateur Ski Association junior jumping championships.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- The Syrian press reported today that the newly appointed Iraqi Mnister of National Guidance, Hussein Jamil, had resigned after "violent friction" with Premier Kassim.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 12 (UPI)--Marty Furgol narrowly missed short putts on the last two holes and with them the El Rio Country Club course record today, but his eight-under-par 62 was still good enough to head the field in the opening round of the $15,000 Tucson open.

A report by John Sack on his two-year trip around the world, visiting thirteen of its smallest and least-known countries, will be published March 4 by Harper. It will be called "Report From Practically Nowhere." The means by which Mr. Sack traveled included thirty-five planes, twenty-three boats and fourteen trains besides buses, automobiles, jeeps, tractors, paddle-wheelers, dhows, mules, pedicabs and tongas.
Leonard Bernstein paid an oral and musical tribute to one of his teachers, Walter Piston, at last night's Philharmonic preview concert at Carnegie Hall.

THE growing interest in drawings, evident this season in several gallery exhibitions, is an encouraging sign of more serious interest in the intimate sources of art. The most recent addition is an exhibition of charcoal and chalk sketches by Mercedes Matter, at the Tanager Gallery, 90 East Tenth Street.

GENEVA, Feb. 12 -- The three-power conference heard today reports on the technical problems in staffing control posts for policing a ban on testing nuclear weapons. There was no change in positions, Western sources reported.

BP Trading, Ltd., an affiliate of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., announced yesterday a reduction of 18 cents a barrel, or about 10 per cent in its prices for all Middle East crude oils. At the same time, the company adjusted its product prices in cargo lots at the Abadan, Iran, refinery to reflect the lower crude oil prices.

The Turnau Opera Players, who have been giving operas for the last four summers at Woodstock, N. Y., brought two of their productions to New York yesterday. They presented the double bill in matinee and evening performances at Carnegie Recital Hall.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- The Soviet Union marked Abraham Lincoln's 150th birthday today with long accounts of his fight against slavery and charges that his ideals were being "trampled upon" in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -President W. Eisenhower urged Congress in a special message today to increase the United States contribution to the "outstandingly successful" International Monetary Fund and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Fordham Prep won the team honors yesterday in a relay carnival for Catholic High Schools on the outdoor board track of Fordham University. Twenty-seven schools participated.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 12 (AP) -The Secretary of Labor announced today that he would not balk at the Democrats' two-package approach to labor legislation provided it included the full Eisenhower program at this session.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 12 -- News that the United States had agreed to send Indonesia small arms for twenty battalions has stirred criticism here in recent days. One member of Parliament, expressing the sentiment of many, said: "This is a stab in the back of a loyal ally."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Chuckling, President Eisenhower parked seven small orphans atop his White House desk today and gave each a silver dollar "so you'll never be dollar "so you'll never be broke."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Robert W. Sarnoff, board chairman of the National Broadcasting Company television network, said yesterday that parents should not allow their children to look at video shows the parents find objectionable.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, asked Congress today for authority to sell the Government-owned Alaskan communications system, valued at $158,000,000.

Two more bodies and additional wreckage was recovered yesterday from the bottom of the East River as salvage operations continued at the site of the Feb. 3 crash of an American Airlines turbo-prop Electra.
Weaknesses in Soviet engineering education were discussed frankly here yesterday by visiting Russians.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 13 -Premier Nobusuke Kishi's Cabinet endorsed today a plan to repatriate Koreans resident in Japan who wish to go to Communist North Korea.

A good snowfall last Tuesday and Wednesday through most of the north country has caused renewed enthusiasm among area operators, winter carnival promoters, innkeepers, restaurateurs -- and, of course, skiers. All expect busy week-ends.

Parke, Davis 3, Co. achieved record high sales and earnings in 1958, the pharmaceuticals concern reported yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The French Cabinet discussed today the mounting tension between France and Tunisia following the arrest of French technicians on charges of espionage.

If things jell, Peter Ustinov will have two plays of his authorship on view here next season. "No Sign of the Dove" has been nominated as his latest entry. MIAMI, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A dispute over porters' jobs at Pan American World Airways ended late today and 3,000 workers who had walked out agreed to return to their jobs.
A group of hot-water heating concerns in the New York metropolitan area have begun a campaign to interest consumers in properly engineered and installed heating systems.
Secretary of the Interior Fred A. Seaton urged Republicans last night to rally public support for a balanced budget and against Democratic spending proposals in Congress.

A theatre party at "Juno" on March 10 will benefit the New York Botanical Garden. The musical version of Sean O'Casey's "Juno and the Pay-cock," starring Shirley Booth and Melvyn Douglas, is scheduled to open at the Winter Garden on March 5.

Potatoes, cottonseed oil and platinum closed higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices movements for wool were mixed.

The Bethlehem Steel Company, the nation's second largest steel producer, is terminating its eighteen-year relationship with Jones, Brakeley Rockwell, Inc.
American Airline passengers have accepted the Boeing 707 jetliner almost 100 per cent, the company said yesterday.

James Lees Sons Company announced yesterday that it planned to increase prices of all its carpets to dealers about 3 1/2 per cent on March 14. Increased costs of materials and other manufacturing items necessitated the increase, the company said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Press Wireless, Inc., which supplies overseas communications service for newspapers and magazines, experienced an interim defeat today in an effort to expand the kind of messages it carries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Feb. 12 -- Symptomatic of postwar trends in the Orient, a wide range of new industries has burgeoned there, the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East has reported.

POTATOES, like rice and bread, may be called the staff of life. Of all the vegetables our markets offer, potatoes are the favorite. Enough are purchased every week to supply each man, woman and child in the country with five to six of medium size.

Variable annuities, a controversial subject in insurance and investment fields for several years, were in the limelight again last week. Three bills were passed by the New Jersey Assembly that would permit their sale by insurance companies in the state.

The women who attend the "Bal Baroque Italien," a benefit for an Italian orphanage to be held at the Plaza on April 21, have been asked to wear headdresses with a baroque motif in keeping with the theme.

The elcction of James E. Faulkner and k. (]. Lund as vice presidents of the Firestone Plantations Company was announced yesterday. The company, a subsidiary of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, operates rubber plantations in Liberia, Brazi!, Guatemala and the Philippines.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 12 (AP) -A draft bill submitted to the Dutch Parliament today proposes two Government loans, totaling 22,000,000 guilders for the construction and promotion of Hilton Hotels in Amsterdam and Rotterdam. One guilder equals about 26 cents.
The United States contract bridge team climbed to within four international match points of Italy last night in the team-of-four world championship held at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Sgt. Mallory Walker is a credit to any man's army -- and any city's opera company.
A major overhaul of the administrative duties and operations of the Board of Education was recommended yesterday by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.

ONE day a man "whose father could not sign his name" propped up his typewriter on a wooden crate in an attic and began to write a book about a man "whose mother could not sign her name." And this, concluded the author of the celebrated, six-volume Pulitzer-prize-winning life of Abraham Lincoln, could happen only in America.

The City Administrator's report to Mayor Wagner on various aspects of the management of New York's public schools prescribes some strong medicine. It has the merit of having gone far beyond the limits of original assignment to take up some fundamental issues.

The fifteenth annual Philadelphia Inquirer Games tonight touch off the busiest week-end of the 1959 campaign for the athletes of the indoor track and field circuit. The scene will shift tomorrow to Madison Square Garden for the ninety-first New York Athletic Club meet.

Investors Diversified Services, Inc., has reported that assets of the five mutual funds it manages topped $2,000,000,000 at the end of 1958. The five funds reported gains totaling $634,063,100 during the year, raising the year-end total to $2,024,500,879.

WILLIE GOGGIN was 12 years of age when he won his first golf tournament, the San Francisco junior championship. He shot a rather stunning 78. Just a fortnight ago he achieved his most recent victory when he averaged a sub-par 71 for four rounds to succeed the legendary Gene Sarazen as the United States senior champion.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- A major Protestant organization urged legislators today to oppose any "fringe" grants of state money to parochial schools.

It is high time for some external agency to step into the acute situation caused by the rapidly deteriorating relationships between the Republic of Korea and Japan. WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Air Force announced a contract today for the development of a new world - wide communications system able to work with weapons systems as far ahead as 1970.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- A statement of Britain's views and intentions regarding the European common market, made in the House of Commons yesterday, is a prelude to the resumption of negotiations broken off in November in an atmosphere of much bitterness.

THE art of book illustration, except in a few deluxe editions and children's books, has pretty well vanished from American publishing.

TUNIS, Feb. 13 -- President Habib Bourguiba appeared today to be intent on easing the tension in French-Tunisian relations. The situation has worsened in the last week with the announcement that a French spy ring had been discovered here.

TITUSVILLE, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) -- The marriage of Mary Lesly Stockard of Palm Beach to Frederick M. Alger 3d of Grosse Pointe, Mich., has been set aside because of religious differences. Circuit Court records disclosed today.

GREEN peas are a favorite vegetable, both with the average family and the most critical connoisseur. Whether freshly shelled, canned or frozen, their green appearance adds a cheery note to hearty winter casseroles, rice and spaghetti dishes, soups and stews, and their delicate flavor harmonizes with a host of other foods.

SUNDSVALL, Sweden, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Police with whirling clubs had to break up a fight between the United States national team and a Swedish provisional hockey combination tonight. The Americans won, 7 -- 2.

Teacher organizations in the city, in a rare display of unanimity, have agreed to support the Mitchell-McMullen pension bill which would permit teachers to retire at the age of 55 after twenty-five years of service.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady unchanged to 11 points, 55 cents a bale above Thursday's close. Old crop months showed the most strength.

The inauguration of Romulo Betancourt in Caracas yesterday is still another in a great series of landmarks in contemporary Latin-American history. Leithauser. The story begins with the harnessing of new sources of power in the age of steam and ends with a discussion of automation and electronic brains, "pointing the ways in which future generations will live."

The metamorphosis of certain insects from a caterpillar to a pupa and then to a multi-colored, winged moth is one of the most fascinating phenomena of living nature, holding the key to some important secrets in the processes of life. Two tiny glands in the brains of metamorphosing insects secrete, during the larval, or caterpillar stage, a specific hormone, which appears to be essential for that particular stage of development.

Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, warned the Republican leadership last night that it would not win elections unless "it demonstrates greater faith in the future of America than it has been doing in some places lately.

DURING nine April days in 1865, Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia disintegrated and finally ceased to exist. By April 1 the Federals, victorious at Five Forks, threatened to encircle Richmond and cut its last railroad connection with what remained of the Confederacy.

AN electric-eye still camera using 127 film for twelve 1 5/8 x 1 5/8-inch (superslide) pictures is being placed on the market by the Revere Camera Company of Chicago. The Revere EE-127 Electric Eye-Matic, like its popular predecessor in the 8mm movie field, automatically sets the lens for the correct exposure in the prevailing light.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- If present trends continue, the world's population will increase to nearly 6,300,000,000 by the year 2000.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Feb. 9 -- At night the main thoroughfare of this sweltering colonial capital, the Boulevard Albert I, is lit up like New York's Third Avenue by garish fluorescent units that project sideways and provide a purplish-white glow.

A bi-monthly survey of employment in Cuyahoga and Lake Counties made by the Cleveland office of the Ohio State Employment Service has disclosed that employment in the two-county area had dropped to 660,900 as of Jan. 31.

UNLIKE the Dodgers, the Giants seemed to escape the particularly violent emotional, psychological and standing-ofthe-teams dislocations last season that brought such grief to their ancient playmates from Brooklyn. The refugees from the Polo Grounds made their gold-prospecting trip across the Rockies gracefully and successfully.

The drug industry is far from drugged. In fact, it is probably the fastest growing of all industries. Gains last year -- in sales and on the stock market -- were striking and another spurt is likely in 1959.

"The Horse's Mouth," "Gigi," "The Big Country," "Separate Tables," "The Reluctant Debutante" and the most-praised British picture for a long time, "Room a the Top," are all showing simultaneously and with notable success.

JALPA, Mexico, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A political quarrel in the village of Juchipila erupted into a riot yesterday in which at least five persons were killed. The dead included the Mayor and the police chief, according to reports reaching here today.

Assuring compliance with safety regulations is an aroundthe-clock job of the New York office of the Interstate Commerce Commission's Bureau of Motor Carriers.

IT is easier to love humanity as a whole than to love one's neighbor. There may even be a certain antagonism between love of humanity and love of neighbor: a low capacity for getting along with those near us often goes hand in hand with a high receptivity to the idea of the brotherhood of men.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP) -Two Chinese Nationalist jet fighters buzzed a British Comet Airliner near Taiwan two weeks ago, the British Overseas Airways said today.

The Italian contract bridge champions of Europe increased their lead yesterday afternoon to a formidable thirty International Match Points over the United States in the team-offour World Championship.
When a hockey player at Madison Square Garden is caught kicking, biting, strangling, belting or otherwise abusing the honor of his opponents, he is sent to a glass-rimmed, policed penalty box.
Some 125 species of plants are being tested by the Air Force in its quest for one that can provide oxygen for the lungs of future space travelers.

TWENTY-FOUR years ago an alluring vision was added to the American Dream. It was the vision of happy, carefree retirement for the working masses. Aided by oldage payments under the Social Security Act of 1935 and by corporate pension plans newly added to work contracts, the average employe could look ahead to years free from want and tension.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The University of Minnesota regents tossed cold water today on this city's hopes of landing the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight title bout next summer. Its regents reaffirmed their position against using university facilities for professional sports.
BOXWOOD can be propagated easily by the home gardener. Although it can be grown from seed, it roots so readily that this is the most popular method.
NEW HAVEN. Conn., Feb. 14 -- Yale's varsity broke Harvard's Big Three track reign, outscoring the Crimson, 72 1/3 to 55 2/3, today. Princeton finished with 9 points.

Resident offices report that heavy reorders for suits and sportswear indicate an excellent spring season at retail. Many stores may be unable to capitalize on the Easter buying, since production lags are curtailing deliveries.
MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- Benjamin B. du Pont's 40-foot yawl, Rhubarb, is leading the 1959 Southern Ocean Racing Conference after three races.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -Dickie Moore's twenty-ninth goal of the season with Boston shorthanded midway in the last period enabled the Montreal Canadiens to gain a rough and tumble 2-1 National Hockey League victory today.

LOUIS COXE'S third book of poems, "The Wilderness," defines the range and the depth of his talent as spare but not austere, sober but energetic and exact. If the poems are sometimes uncompromising in their intellectual and moral strictness, they are seldom sententious.

IT isn't easy, nowadays, to get an idea for an anthology that hasn't been done before. Charles Van Doren has achieved the improbable by choosing a category so large that it has been overlooked. Nine youths were held yesterday in $5,000 bail each on charges of malicious mischief after they had terrorized about forty passengers on a Brooklyn-Staten Island ferryboat by splintering seats with fire axes.

Pennsylvania is now believed to have the highest unemployment rate in the nation. So says the Economic and Taxation Council of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia. As of last month, 508,000 persons were lnemployed in the state.

Members and friends of the Vassar Club of New York were hosts at dinner parties last night at Sherry's in the Metropolitan Opera House, preceding a benefit performance of "Madama Butterfly." Proceeds from this annual event sponsored by the club will augment its scholarship fund.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Representative Charles Porter, Democrat of Oregon, says that Gen. Fulgencio Batista, the ousted Cuban dictator, gave $1,000,000 to Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo, the Dominican strong man, after having taken refuge in the Dominican Republic.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -The Daily Mail said today it was satisfied that it did not betray the trust of Boris Pasternak by publishing a new poem by the Soviet Nobel Prize-winning poet-novelist.
Miss Helen Hall, for the last twenty-five years director of the Henry Street Settlement, is about to have another honor added to her long list.

Mount St. Michael edged Fordham Prep by one point to capture the team title yesterday in the first annual Iona College Spiked Shoe Club relay carnival. The meet, held on the Mounties' outdoor board track, drew entries from twenty-seven schools.

A Russian educator, one of a group who spent three weeks in this country visiting various schools, said yesterday that American engineering students were not adequately prepared when they entered engineering universities.

The news of Bill Donovan's death is a profound shock to all of his associates, friends and acquaintances. It hardly seems possible that this ageless man, this almost elemental force of nature, has been removed from our immediate contact.

Building permits for residential units issued by Chicago's Department of Buildings during January recorded substantial gains over the same month last year. For weeks the Masai tribe of Kenya, formerly great warriors but now cattle breeders, had suffered from lack of rain. Then came Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, on a visit to Nairobi. Speaking to a tribal gathering, she said: "I hope you will be blessed with good rains." Half an hour later came thunderclaps followed by a downpour that turned arid ditches into swiftmoving streams.

Nearly 400 technical and economic papers on mineral and oil industries will be presented at the five-day national convention of the American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers. It opens today in San Francisco.
More records and rousing competition are in prospect as track and field's most exciting indoor season in years enters the championship phase.
The Italian bridge champions of Europe early today soundly defeated a United States team to capture the team-of-four world contract bridge championship by fifty points.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics and the police in the metropolitan area, joining in more than a dozen raids over the week-end, smashed what was described as one of the country's major heroin rings.

Gian Carlo Menotti's two-act opera, "The Medium," was presented in three acts on yesterday's "Omnibus" program over the National Broadcasting Company television network between 5 and 6 P. M. The so-called "third" act was invented so plugs for wine, bacon and another television show could be wedged into the second half of the opera.

The General Public Utilities Corporation reported over the week-end that domestic subsidiaries sold about 3 per cent more electricity in 1958 than they did a year earlier to more than 1,000,000 customers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The Philippine Islands subsidiary, Manila Electric Company, raised its electricity sales by 16 per cent.
A four-day Assembly, called by the American National Theatre and Academy, opened yesterday afternoon in the Astor. The 250 persons registered are representing 100 chapters throughout the country.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that 66,555 cases had been transferred from relief rolls last year to other means of support. Many, he said, had been rehabilitated by his department.

Two well-known Norwegian steamship lines have joined forces to operate in the Great Lakes-Scandinavian trade. They are the Fjell Line, which pioneered Great Lakes to Europe service twenty-five years ago, and the Norwegian America Line.

A history of American politics from the election of Andrew Jackson to twenty years later will be published Wednesday by Harper, entitled "The Jacksonian Era." Written by Glyndon Van Deusen, chairman of the History Department at Rochester University, it traces the shifting balance of power between the Whigs and the Democrats, describing the internal party strife, the impact of personalities and the violent controversies that lent color and character to the period.

We are pleased this morning to print elsewhere in this paper the names of the boys and girls from the city and the suburbs who have distinguished themselves by winning New York State scholarships. Forty-one years ago today the little ancient nation of Lithuania proclaimed her independence of Russia. Her neighbors, Estonia and Latvia, also announced their freedom, Estonia on Feb. 24, 1918, Latvia in November. In 1940 all three were again subjugated by Russian troops and compelled to become "Soviet Socialist Republics." They have had, therefore, twenty-two years of freedom and nineteen years of servitude.

The sanity of Mary Todd Lincoln has been the subject of controversy for many years. In May, 1875, she was adjudged insane and committed to an institution. The following fall she was allowed to leave the hospital and go to the home of her sister Mrs. Ninian Edwards. In June, 1876, after a second sanity hearing, she was declared sane and able to manage her own property.
