The country's steel mills are coming closer to the previous output record.

Coffee prices were strong yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on the largest volume since Sept. 2, 1958. The M months rose 43 to 81 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 41,000 bags and the B futures advanced 26 to 45 points on 68,250 bags.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that Republicans must convince the nation's voters that their party's basic conservatism stands for progress and not just "stand-pat-ism."

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- The Soviet Government said tonight that none of the eleven United States airmen missing since their transport was downed in Armenia more than five months ago was in the Soviet Union.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- There once was a time when any man could win a bobsled race. All he needed was courage and an iron grip on the steering wheel. But time marches on and in bobsledding today the skill and nerve of the driver do not count nearly so much as the aerodynamic qualities of his sled.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Industrial production rose another point in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- An internationally known mining engineering consultant today urged United States risk capital to concentrate on developing rich ores south of the border instead of trying to keep "second class" domestic mines alive.

Harold Clurman, Broadway director, former actor and occasional critic baiter, unleashed another shaft at the local drama critics yesterday. Only last November, Mr. Clurman was in the middle of a contretemps involving the question of whether a critic's judgment was influenced by his dining habits.

The Ford Foundation yesterday announced grants of $10,000 each to ten stage directors from various parts of the country "to help stimulate their creative development." One Broadway director, Alan Schneider, was among the recipients.

HUNTING dogs used in exhibition soon develop a hambone quality that strongly resembles the same attributes in a television commercial jollyboy. But there is a difference: the dogs are not encouraged to be hambones.
J. Albert Woods, president and a director of Commercial Solvents Corporation, has resigned. He will serve the company as consultant through 1962.
Mayor Wagner's bill for legalizing and taxing off-track betting on horse races went to Albany last night and encountered a rising tide of opposition.
Cary Grant and Elizabeth Taylor have been chosen as the most popular film stars of 1958 in the twenty-second annual poll conducted by Boxoffice magazine, motion picture industry trade publication.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The Senate passed tonight a bill that would permit doctors and other self-employed residents to buy group life insurance through their professional societies. The bill now goes to the Assembly for action.
Plans have been completed for Bing Crosby's next television show over the American Broadcasting Company network on Monday, March 2, from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M.
PARIS, Feb. 16 -- The successful treatment of five Yugoslav atomic scientists exposed to radiation has encouraged French doctors seeking ways of treating other blood diseases, particularly leukemia.

Amid our grandiose plans for the conquest of space it may come as a rude shock to most of us that the oceans, which constitute threequarters of the earth's surface, still remain largely unexplored. Even more startling is the revelation by a committee on oceanography of the National Academy of Sciences that "we know less about many regions of the ocean today than we know about the lunar surface."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A reporter who joined the faculty of a New York junior high school to write news stories about how young hoodlums had cowed the school staff was named winner today of the American Newspaper Guild's top award.
A relatively simple and brief test to enable physicians to assay the mysterious "intrinsic factor" in stomach juices has been developed at Mount Sinai Hospital.

It should be noted by all voters who helped to elect Senators Javits and Keating that both Senators voted with the Democrats in support of the housing bill just passed by the Senate and against the recommendations of the President.
The trial against Alfried Krupp, to which former Congresswoman Helen Gahagan Douglas refers in her letter published Feb. 8, was no credit to our judicial system.

Earnings of the Springfield Fire and Marine Insurance Company and the Monarch Life Insurance Company were $4,614,120, before taxes. This was reported yesterday in the first consolidated statement since acquisition of Monarch Life by Springfield Fire last July 1.
Dr. George N. Shuster will resign next year as president of Hunter College.

Former Judge Learned Hand has written a letter to President Eisenhower endorsing Henry J. Friendly, vice president and general counsel of Pan American World Airways, for the vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
TRENTON, Feb. 16 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today a Newark ordinance that requires all employes of that municipality to reside within the city limits.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Following is a statement issued today by the Soviet press agency Tass in its English-language service, repudiating State Department charges that Soviet fighters shot down an unarmed United States transport:

There is a possibility that Joshua Logan and David Merrick, now associated with "The World of Suzie Wong," are getting together on "Bang the Drum Slowly." Both of them would figure as producers and Mr. Logan also would handle the direction. As of last night, Mr. Merrick denied that anything was definite regarding the reported affiliation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Robert B. Choate, publisher of The Boston Herald-Traveler, testified today that he had never talked to any Federal Communications Commissioner about the merits of his television-channel application while the case was pending before the F. C. C.
More than 200 city employes attended a Brotherhood Week conference yesterday in City Hall. They represented thirty-six religious and fraternal organizations within various city departments.
ON entering the midtown office of Hensleigh C. Wedgwood, the rumble of frenzied traffic outside fades against the patient ticking of an eighteenth-century clock.

George Brenner, former Westchester surrogate and county judge, was wheeled into General Sessions Court yesterday on a stretcher for arrignment. He pleaded not guilty to two indictments charging forgery, grand larceny and conspiracy.

Still bristling, but once again in a talkative mood, Phil Watson, the New York Rangers coach, told his seventeen players yesterday that he wanted a "100 per cent effort" from them in the homestretch drive for a berth in the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs.
MIAMI, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Copalan Stable's Joe's Master won the $6,000 Boca Raton Purse before 20,295 spectators today at Hialeah race course.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb 16 -- Arthur M. Weiss, the Democratic leader of Riverhead township for seventeen years, was appointed to the $10,000-a-year post as Suffolk County Elections Commissioner here today in a surprise move by the Board of Supervisors.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Bowing to pressures as old as the Magna Charta, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan announced today that a tribunal of inquiry would investigate the case of John Waters.
WARRENSBURG, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Elihu Root Geraghty, former counsel of the Hudson River Regulating Board, was killed here last night by an automobile, according to the police.
HOBART, Australia, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Australia's Dawn Fraser is fighting back from ill health to prove that she still is the best of the world's women sprint swimmers.
The proposed new zoning resolution for this city was endorsed in principle yesterday by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
Stocks rose during the first two hours of trading yesterday and then fell for the rest of the day. As a result, market averages were about unchanged.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Feb. 16 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court jury tonight found Edwin W. Ashby, prominent Kingston Republican, guilty of lying to a grand jury investigating corruption charges.

Lower sales volume and higher operating costs reduced operating earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. last year to $4.71 a common share from $5.93 a share in 1957, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 -- A special committee on higher education has warned against a tendency by Indian universities to drop English hastily as a medium of instruction.
CAIRO, Feb. 16 -- A united protest by all Arab states is being organized against any mass migration of Jews from Eastern Europe to Israel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A Republican Senator told the Republican Secretary of Agriculture today that he had so confused farmers that the Republican party had failed to get a majority of the farm vote in any state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A bill designed to wrest control of certain unions from "mobsters and power-mad demagogues" was introduced today by Representative Graham A. Barden, chairman of the House Labor Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- United Artists now has the largest assemblage of independent movie-makers in its history and plans to invest from $65,000,000 to $70,000,000 in the production of films in 1960. The announcement was made today by Max E. Youngstein, vice president, at the company's fortieth anniversary sales convention, which began yesterday at the Ambassador Hotel.

People with short memories may not recall just how cold January was, but the oil men have statistics to prove it. Yesterday the Independent Petroleum Association of America reported that the cold weather last month sent domestic and export demand for crude oil above 11,000,000 barrels a day, highest ever for that month except for January, 1957, when demand soared because of the Suez troubles.
A FEW minutes before 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon the game of "Haggis Baggis" on the National Broadcasting Company television network was interrupted for a commercial announcement. Its text follows:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in 1958 had the highest earnings in its 60-year-history despite a 3.8 per cent sales decrease, E. J. Thomas, board chairman, reported yesterday.
Two robbers forced their way into the hotel suite of Alexander L. Guterma last night and reportedly fled with $60,000 worth of jewelry after tying up the financier's wife and eldest daughter.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 16 -- Frederick M. Raubinger, New Jersey State Commissioner of Education, charged today that American schools were moving toward a national system of examinations, administered by the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Administration will present to Congress tomorrow an expanded program of atomic power development designed to bring nuclear electricity at competitive rates to some areas of the country within a decade.

As a first step toward averting the threatening crisis over Berlin and as a test of Soviet intentions the United States, Britain, France and West Germany have joined forces to propose to Soviet Russia an East-West foreign ministers' conference, with East and West Germany advisers present, to deal with the whole German problem.
The new Hi-Speed local service on the IRT Broadway line suffered its first jolt yesterday morning.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A mood of unconcealed optimism prevailed tonight as the five parties to the Cyprus dispute prepared their positions for a round-table conference here tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 16 -- The Western powers must be prepared for a long and wearisome diplomatic struggle in the negotiations they propose to hold with the Soviet Union on Germany, Chancellor Adenauer said today.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 16 -- Key union leaders warned tonight that any move to "whitewash" Maurice A. Hutcheson, indicted president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, would touch off a major revolt in the A. F. L.-C. I. O. high command.

Edwin Dale's column on Treasury refunding problems in The Times of Feb. 7 lives up to his standard of consistently illuminating economic reports. But it does not quite draw the evident conclusion as to the basic difficulty.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Louis Rittner's Optiquest dropped back into familiar company and romped to a length-and-a-half victory in the Red Cross Purse at the Fair Grounds today.
IN "A Majority of One," which opened at the Sam S. Shubert last evening, the central question is this: Is Gertrude Berg more sensible than the Department of State?
PADU, Italy, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- A Court of Appeals ruled tonight that artificial insemination without the husband's consent amounted to adultery.
A three-alarm fire on the Queens waterfront that could be seen from Manhattan's East Side destroyed a two-story frame factory building yesterday at 45-36 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City.

Although the premiere of Roosevelt Raceway's $50,000 The International for trotters is more than five months away, already there is a "horse to beat." That distinction belongs to Jamin, a 6-year-old French horse that won the recent Prix d'Amerique and the Grand Prix of France.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 16 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk received here tonight an illuminated plaque from President Eisenhower. He was honored as the physician who had made an outstanding contribution during the last year to the national program to widen job opportunities for physically impaired workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- United States District Judge Richmond B. Keech took under advisement today a defense motion for the acquittal of James G. Cross, 46 years old, president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The Government's long antitrust suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. focused today on the fate of the thousands of stockholders whose interests are involved.
Hal Roach Jr., who has assumed control of the F. L. Jacobs Company from Alexander L. Guterma, inspected the Jacobs books with independent auditors yesterday.
HONG KONG, Feb. 16 -- The policies and views of the Soviet Communist party under Nikita S. Khrushchev were given fresh endorsement today in Peiping.
Dr. Bruno Pittermann, Vice Chancellor of Austria, was officially welcomed yesterday by Mayor Wagner at City Hall.
AMONG the American Friends of Europe contingent, Macy's should be counted as a charter member.
Leopold Stokowski led the Symphony of the Air yesterday afternoon in a Carnegie Hall concert, which inaugurated the United Jewish Appeal's 1959 fund campaign.
At a happy reunion at Leone's restaurant yesterday, three Hungarians started to plot ways of relieving an Irish footracer of the American indoor mile title.
A leading Soviet economist has predicted that in the next few years the ruble will become an international currency and begin supplanting the dollar in international trade.

"LES BALLETS AFRICAINS" of Keita Fodeba opened at the Martin Beck Theatre last night under the auspices of Luben Vichy, after a long series of European successes. It should certainly repeat the story here, for it is a wonderful show and as chic as all get out.

The Board of Education made another attempt last night to operate four central evening high schools. The city's sixteen regular evening high schools have been closed since Feb. 4 because of the mass resignation of teachers in a salary dispute.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 16 (AP) -- A squabble involving East Germany today plagued Olympic officials making ready for the North American ski championships.
The city's Department of Public Works presented a program yesterday for $175,726,658 worth of construction this year.

The relief fund of the Association of Officers of the Former Imperial Russian Cavalry and Horse Artillery will benefit from the Mi-Careme Ball, to be held in the Ballroom of the Sheraton-East on March 13.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 16 -- Officially, and on the surface, every one in Ankara is happy over the prospects of a Cyprus settlement.
The city's anti-jaywalk campaign was reported yesterday to have helped save the lives of thirteen New Yorkers last year and to have helped 705 pedestrians avoid injury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee looked across the table today at a friend and winked. "We'll get a solution this time," he promised with a grin, as his committee questioned the Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson.

With unexpected flippancy for so established an institution, the Long Island Rail Road is reminding its commuters that it is celebrating its 125th birthday. As an eyeopener for those riders who do not awaken until their train plunges into the darkness of the East River tunnel, the railroad is offering a small, four-page brochure that depicts a rather elderly lady leaping for joy and clicking her heels.
City policemen will be used to track down and serve summonses on slum landlords or their agents who have made a practice of evading Building Department summonses for maintenance violations.
The city bade a fond farewell yesterday to Sirdar Jagjit Singh, India's "unofficial ambassador," who has been supporting the cause of his homeland in New York for the last thirty-three years.

Boosters are bowlers who rarely grab headlines or get high scores but serve as the proprietors' bread - and - butter patrons. For several years they have earned considerable prize money in tournaments designed for them.

THE most readable contribution to oil's centennial in America, 1859-1959, is undoubtedly Hildegarde Dolson's "The Great Oildorado."* Miss Dolson concentrates jauntily on this illuminating subject's wild early decades. But she has gathered enough good stories about the Pennsylvania oil rush, or gush, to characterize a restless and eventful century.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The advisability of replacing John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State was receiving serious consideration today from both friends and foes of the Administration.
GENEVA, Feb. 16 -- The United States warned the Soviet Union today that there could be no restricting of on-site inspection of possible violations of a ban on testing nuclear weapons.
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., reported yesterday new highs in gas sales, gross revenues and net income for 1958.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The Senate voted tonight to authorize the creation of an Office of Transportation in the state's executive branch. The Assembly postponed action on the bill until tomorrow, but is expected to pass it then.
HAVANA, Feb. 16 -- The luxury casinos in Cuba will be permitted to reopen next Friday, a reliable source said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note, almost identical with those of Britain, France and West Germany, delivered to the Soviet Union today, calling for a foreign ministers' meeting on Germany with East and West German advisers present:

Boris Pasternak's ordeal continues. The depth of that ordeal is suggested by the poem which became known last week, in which he compares himself with "a beast in an enclosure" and finds consolation only in the thought, "I am near my grave." These are shattering words to be written by any human being, let alone by one of the greatest and purest writers of our era.

Oklahoma City University yesterday became the third basketball team to accept a bid to the National Invitation Tournament scheduled to start at Madison Square Garden March 12. The Chiefs, St. John's and Villanova will be joined by nine others in the annual N. I. T.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Len Matthews battered Ray Lancaster helpless tonight to win by a technical knockout in 2:35 of the second round of Matthews' self-proclaimed revenge fight.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Feb. 16 (UPI) -- This area lost today a last-ditch effort to stave off integration and prepared to admit twenty-two Negroes Wednesday to the high school here.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 7 -- Future generations of German school children may be in luck. A determined effort is under way to simplify spelling.
The installation of brilliant runway threshold lights was completed on two La Guardia Airport runways three days after the crash of an American Airlines Electra on Feb. 3.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Feb. 16 -- The final section of a comprehensive zoning plan for the Town of Oyster Bay will be available for public inspection the first week of March.

TRENTON, Feb. 16 -- The Legislature gave its final approval today to bills that set up a state Division of Railroad Transportation and approve the establishment of a transit district in the metropolitan area.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 16 -- The chairman of the court-appointed monitors in charge of cleaning up the International Brotherhood of Teamsters disclosed here tonight the collapse of secret negotiations with James R. Hoffa to speed the reform effort.
The Coast Guard ruled yesterday that the Swedish freighter Nebraska had been the "principal cause" of the fiery crash between it and the harbor tanker Empress Bay last June.

Following are the texts of Mayor Wagner's summary of his bill for the legalization of off-track betting on horse races, and of a letter opposing such betting from two of the three minority members of the Mayor's Citizens Committee on Off-Track Betting:
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Striking employes of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company voted today to accept a memorandum of agreement and end a 134-day walkout at nine plants.

The New York City Housing Authority will take bids on Feb. 24 for $16,350,000 of temporary loan notes for the development of St. Mary's Park Houses, a Bronx project not aided by cash subsidy. The notes will be dated March 11 and will come due on Oct. 14.
TACOMA, Wash, Feb. 16 -- Dave Beck's counsel rested in the labor leader's income tax trial today after calling only one witness. His client did not take the stand.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Britain announced today that she would not draw the $250,000,000 loan made available to her on a "stand-by" basis by the United States Export-Import Bank, nor would she ask that the period of its availability be extended.

Bridge experts were doing careful post-mortems on Italy's victory early yesterday morning over the United States, a victory that gained Italy the team-of-four world championship for the third successive year.

MANILA, Feb. 16 -- Government sources said today plans had been made to open formal discussions on the Philippines' long-standing financial claims against the United States as soon as possible after the return of Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen next week.

Ships' officers may soon find themselves relieved of the tedious chore of plotting their positions at sea at short intervals or every time their vessels change course. A mechanical computer can take over the job.

I notice where Edward J. Schoenbrod writes in your paper of Jan. 30 about me cheapening the language in the subway poster he has reference to Mr. Schoenbrod sent a very nice letter, don't get me wrong. And well written.

Senator John F. Kennedy came out strongly yesterday in favor of the complete separation of church and state. He declared his opposition also to sending an Ambassador to the Vatican and to the use of Federal funds for the support of parochial or private schools.
ROME, Feb. 16 -- Premier Antonio Segni's new one-party Government was sworn in today by President Giovanni Gronchi.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Archbishop James of Melitis (Malta), 48-year-old representative of the Greek Orthodox Church to the World Council of Churches, has been elected to the disputed post of Archbishop of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Republicans and Democrats clashed in a jungle of budgetary confusion on the Senate floor today about whether the Republican White House or the Democratic Congress was to blame for high Government spending.
The Bell System -- American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal subsidiaries -- reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for 1958.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A report on social security programs throughout the world was issued today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Vanguard satellite, as the first weather eye in space, ushers in a new era of global forecasting of the earth's weather.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 17 -- The Common Council cleared the way last night for the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency to proceed with a major redevelopment project in the South Norwalk area.
Harry Hlavac, who has left his mark on at least a million dollars worth of gold and silver, took his loupe from his eye yesterday and retired as engraver at Tiffany's.
A "new diplomacy" in which goverments use radio appeal to get directly into homes in foreign countries is here to stay, according to George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency.
Japan re-entered the international bond market in the role of a borrower yesterday after a lapse of twenty-eight years.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- This city was assured today of a $5,223,771 Federal contribution toward redevelopment of a sixty-seven-acre substandard section near the heart of its business district.

TUNIS, Feb. 17 -- President Habib Bourguiba warned today that Tunisia might demand the liquidation of the remaining French military base in Tunisia if peace in Algeria was not in sight within four months.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The top price for butcher hogs slipped to another two-year low today with the market weak to 25 cents a hundred weight lower.
A major aspect of the Chinese scene that cannot escape one is that the whole nation is at work, hard at work, twenty-four hours a day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- James G. Cross, president of the Bakery and Confectioner Workers Union, was acquitted today of a charge that he lied to the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- Former Premier Nu told his supporters today to begin passive resistance against "oppression" by the followers of Gen. Ne Win, who resigned as Premier last week.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Legislation to require counties to levy a sales tax for school purposes upon demand was introduced here today.

An organizing drive recently begun by the nation's two leading seamen's unions can add $400,000,000 to $500,000,000 to the American taxpayers' annual subsidy bill, William C. White, president of Alcoa Steamship Company, declared last night.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The British Aluminium Company announced today the resignation of Viscount Portal, its chairman, and Geoffrey Cunliffe deputy chairman.

The Government's suit to block the repurchase by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad of 131,385 shares of its $5 preferred stock from New York and Chicago banking investment companies at $75 a share, more than $50 a share above the stock's present value, was thrown out yesterday by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey.
A new finish for woven pile fabric with a shrinkage of less than 2 per cent in normal machine or hand washing, has been developed by E. F. Timme Son, Inc., textile manufacturer.
The Yankees will have an Australian cricket player in uniform at their St. Petersburg (Fla.) training camp next month.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The Rockefeller Administration is calling in union lawyers to help rewrite the Republican labor rackets bill the party was so proud of last year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 17 -- In a "most energetic protest," the Yugoslav Government accused neighboring Albania today of organizing intensive spying and sabotage activities in Yugoslavia.

The critics of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's tax program seem to have one major characteristic in common: the inability to suggest any better method of raising the $277 million needed to balance the state's 1959-60 budget.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower went to Walter Reed Army Hospital today to check on the condition of his ailing Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles.
The new satellite will have the company of four earlier arrivals while orbiting the earth.

St. Bonaventure's basketball team, which has run up two long winning streaks this season, became the fourth squad to accept a bid to the National Invitation Tournament yesterday. St. John's, Villanova and Oklahoma City are the other teams that have agreed to play in the tourney, which will open at Madison Square Garden March 12.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 17 -- Bitterness inside labor's high command exploded today in an angry exchange involving three of the most powerful leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Dr. Bruno Pittermann, Vice Chancellor of Austria, told 100 members of the Overseas Press Club last night that Austrians are "immune to Communist infection."
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The cost of a civil marriage performed by New York's City Clerk may rise 50 per cent -- from $2 to $3 -- if Mayor Wagner and two legislators get their way.

HONG KONG, Feb. 17 -- Henry Kearns, United States Assistant Secretary of Commerce, left here today with no commitment from Hong Kong manufacturers to reduce shipments of textiles to the United States.
Despite good economic and corporation news, the stock market moved gently lower yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Trustees for the defunct German I. G. Farben combine decided today not to appeal an adverse Federal Court ruling in the complex General Aniline ease.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he would make a series of television appearances in an attempt to dispel the opposition to his tax and budget programs.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 17 -- A new family pattern bearing the strong imprint of Red China's communal way of life is to emerge in Bulgaria during the current industrial speed-up.
Blood will be given today at Hospital, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx.

IN the days of the prophet Elijah, the Tishbite, when Ahab was king in Israel and Jezebel was his queen, there lived in the city of Samaria one Dara, a maker of charms and amulets who came from Paphos on the island of Cyprus and worshiped Aphrodite and Adonis. And Queen Jezebel summoned Dara unto her in her palace and commanded him to make beautiful decorations for a new palace she was building.

SAN JUAN P. R., Feb. 17 -- The merged labor federation decided today to withdraw its support of the Kennedy-Ervin racket control bill if concessions to labor were eliminated from the bill. The concessions involve union-endorsed liberalizing amendments to the Taft-Hartley Act.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17--Vice President Richard M. Nixon, the leading prospect for the 1960 Republican Presidential nomination, made an evaluation tonight of the Democratic leaders in the race.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The National Steel Corporation announced today it would build a major new steel finishing mill in northern Indiana. The cost of the plant is included in a $300,000,000 construction program that also provides for expansion of facilities at National's plant in Detroit, Mich., and Steubenville, Ohio.
Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year first mortgage bonds at an interest cost of about 4.39 per cent.

The City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it had sent to the City Planning Commission proposals for three new public housing developments with a total of 1,335 units. Two would be on the lower West Side and one in the Crotona section of the Bronx:
BONN, Germany, Feb. 17 -- The Western Allies' preparations for negotiations with the Soviet Union on Germany have advanced sufficiently to provide a clear idea of both the procedure and the goals.

" The Helen Hall Settlement Papers," ranging from case studies of unemployment published in 1931 to a plan to fight juvenile delinquency last November, were placed yesterday in the library of the New York School of Social Work.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today :
Eleven-year-old James Bell plunged seventeen floors from a window of his apartment yesterday and hours later he was still alive although in critical condition.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Any tax relief for New York's commuter railroads will be based on individual situations rather than on a general rule, Governor Rockefeller indicated today.

A select field of leading contract bridge experts from the United States, Canada, South America and Europe yesterday afternoon played the first of two sessions in the Cavendish Club invitational fair championship.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A joint decision by President Eisenhower and President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexico on building a dam across the Rio Grande shaped up today as the probable outcome of their forthcoming meeting here.

Plans for the construction of a Protestant chapel at New York International Airport were announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the general assembly of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

A selective compilation of nearly 600 of Theodore Dreiser's letters written between 1897 and 1945 will be published by the University of Pennsylvania Press on March 3 in a three-volume edition. Called "Letters of Theodore Dreiser," it has been edited with a preface and notes by Robert H. Elias.

HARTFORD. Feb. 17 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff presented a record $462,200,000 balanced general fund budget for the next biennium to the Connecticut Legislature today. He said it would require neither new taxes nor increases in current levies.
ROME, Feb. 17 -- Plainclothes men posed as playgoers and uniformed policemen stood guard near by tonight to prevent a neo-Fascist victory in the theatre.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 17 -- Belgium called on the European Coal and Steel Community today for aid in solving her mine crisis. Miners have been on strike and a "march on Brussels" has been threatened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, suggested today that the raising of teachers' salaries be required before needy school districts could receive Federal-state aid under the Administration's school construction bill.

The Board of Education yesterday abandoned its attempt to operate its limited evening high school program in the current teachers' salary dispute. The board said that starting today all evening high schools would be closed.
Thanks to Alejandro Olmedo of Peru, the United States won back the Davis Cup from Australia in late December, its first victory in the challenge round since 1954.
IN his gay and breezy fashion Tim Mara had a pungently descriptive way of depicting the formation of his beloved New York Football Giants.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- The Trusteeship Council recommended today that the United Nations end its trusteeship over the French Cameroons Jan. 1, when the territory is due to emerge as a sovereign nation.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 17 -- Few Americans have known the world so well as John Foster Dulles and few have been so well known in the world. Nor has any other statesman traveled so feverishly while in office. Therefore, the news of his terrible illness produces singular shock.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -A brighter future for the operation of motion-picture theatres was forecast today by John A. Bertero, president of National Theatres, Inc., in a speech at the annual meeting here of the company's stockholders.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17 -- The Sheraton Ritz-Carlton, one of this resort's large Boardwalk hotels, has been sold for $4,000,000, it was announced here today.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- President Charles de Gaulle started back to Paris today from southwestern France, where he had given an impressive demonstration of his prestige.

A frustrated artist shot and killed two young women who were his fellow employes yesterday morning. He had been thrown into a rage by his discharge from the job by which he had supported his family of six and his art work.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17 -- School administrators disagreed strongly here today on a proposal that two-year junior colleges be made part of the public high school system.
GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- The West questioned the seriousness of Soviet intentions today at the three-power conference for ending nuclear weapons tests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The theory that a "lost tribe" of Israel exists in the mountain fastnesses of China was disputed by a former curator of the West China Union University Museum in a 114-page report published today by the Smithsonian Institution.
A man who received a one-year $200 full-tuition scholarship from Columbia University in 1898 remembered this in his will and has left the university more than $6,000,000.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- The District School Board here decided tonight to permit a foreign film festival sponsored by the Adult Education Committee to be presented at the high school. The board also ruled that children might attend. The first showing is scheduled for tomorrow night.

In giving a "farewell" luncheon for J. J. Singh, Mayor Wagner has recognized the distinguished part that this "unofficial envoy" from India has played in the life of our community. We hope that it is not "farewell" but merely "an revoir," and that J. J. -- as he is affectionately known to thousands of Americans -- will come back to visit soon and often.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Premier Adnan Menderes of Turkey was one of ten survivors in the crash of a Turkish turbo-prop airliner tonight that took the lives of twelve passengers and crew members. He suffered bruises and shock and possibly internal injuries.

Ralph E. Samuel, in a letter appearing in The Times on Feb. 7, undertakes to answer your editorial of Jan. 25 on "Hate Literature," and asserts with considerable positiveness that group libel legislation is "both undesirable and unconstitutional.

" La Traviata" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last night, with Mario Zanasi singing Giorgio Germont for the first time this season. Mr. Zanasi was in good voice and found the music congenial. He was cordially received by the audience.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- An eight - member syndicate, headed by the irrepressible Bill Veeck, today agreed to buy control of the Chicago White Sox. Veeck picked up an option to buy majority holdings within forty-five days.
The professional, community and academic branches of the theatre are unaware of what each is doing, according to a survey by the Ford Foundation in eighty-five communities outside of New York.
MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Nikolai S. Patolichev, Foreign Trade Minister, rejected today any suggestion that the Kremlin expected the United States to help finance the seven-year plan.

MIAMI, Feb. 17 -- First Landing will "go" again tomorrow. The 3-year-old colt, who runs for Christopher T. Chenery, will compete in the $25,000 added Everglades Stakes at Hialeah, and the race will mark his second start of the year.

Strength in short-term money market securities, firmness in long-term corporate bonds, and successful pricing of major new issues of local government securities marked business in the bond market yesterday.

The Empire State Music Festival will make its future home in Sterling Forest, a new scientific, educational and cultural community being developed near Tuxedo, N. Y. The festival's former home was in Ellenville N.Y.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 18 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that if the Western powers tried to shoot their way through to West Berlin, "this will mean the beginning of war." The Soviet leader also warned the Western Allies against trying to evade East German control of their military traffic to Berlin with an airlift.
BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- The Massachusetts Port Authority took over today operation of the Logan International and Hanscom airports, the Mystic River Bridge and Port of Boston facilities.

Carmine G. De Sapio, New York County Democratic leader, announced yesterday that he was pushing hard for a June primary this year as well as for the use of voting machines wherever contests developed.

MONTREAL, February 17--The International Federation of Airline Pilots' Associations has warned that the controversy between the United States and Britain over navigation aids may hurt the International Civil Aviation Organization.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The trend toward higher prices in the grain futures market appeared today to have come to an end.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to create a state office of atomic development within the Executive Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A second figure in the case of Boston television Channel 5 testified today that he had seen a number of high Government officials while it was under consideration and had asked them to keep politics out of the case.

Prospects of record shoe production this year induced active buying at the two-day Leather Show, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Forecasts of output in excess of 600,000,000 pairs has created a demand for leather and many manufacturers are seeking immediate delivery, according to Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America, sponsor of the event.

Princeton's nine-year string of victories is threatened in the defrosted Polar Bear track meet. Pennsylvania, building under Coach Boo Morcom, figures to take top honors in the once shivery, now steam-heated competition that also involves Columbia.
Taxicab owners concerned with a 50 per cent rise in the state gasoline tax next month are showing avid interest in Diesel-powered cabs.
I hope the visit of Prime Minister Macmillan to the Kremlin results in the opening of a door. I, for one, can see no objection to the initiative of the British Prime Minister.

ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- The Interior Ministry has ordered the deportation of seven men, all described as French subjects, on the ground that their presence in Ghana is "not conducive to the public good."

HOBART, Australia, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Sylvia Ruuska and Chris von Saltza, two teen-age Californians, won titles tonight at the Australian swimming championships by defeating some of this country's top stars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Still jubilant over the party's big victory in last November's Congressional election, House Democrats selected the same men today to supervise strategy for the 1960 campaign.

Wreckers are stripping the interiors of a group of buildings on the Lincoln Square site upon which the New York chapter of the American Red Cross will build a five-story headquarters of glass, aluminum and steel.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 17 -- The high command of merged labor took the first step today toward a possible end of the six-year exile of the International Longshoremen's Association.
Justice Joseph A. Gavagan reserved decision in Supreme Court yesterday on an action brought by a landlord to test the city's eleven-month-old law banning discrimination in private housing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Administration plans to make James W. Riddleberger, now United States Ambassador to Greece, the new director of the International Cooperation Administration.

THIS is the low period of the year when people sit in joints and discuss their relations with their favorite fishing or hunting guides. These conversations get pretty silly, because they have no relation to reality.

NEWARK, Feb, 17 -- A major part of one of Newark's oldest cemeteries will make way for a parking lot. Court approval was given today to convert the old First Presbyterian Church burial ground in the heart of the downtown section into a parking lot for 500 to 600 cars.
A crumple of cellophane in a big stainless steel washtub is being used at Bellevue Hospital to save lives that would have been lost a few years ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today it would take at least three years to develop a nuclear plane.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 17 -- The squawking loudspeakers were silent tonight and the stray cows had the darkened temple squares of this royal city to themselves.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The pot has been calling the kettle black on Capitol Hill during the last two days.

The heads of some Eastern railroads have been counting their carloadings unhappily. Although many factories have restored production to pre-recession levels, Eastern district carloadings just don't reflect the improvement.
HAVANA, Feb. 17 -- The revolutionary Government moved swiftly today to solve various problems during the first Cabinet meeting of Fidel Castro's tenure as Premier.
American Electric Power Company began its 1959 operations with record earnings, the company reported yesterday.

A 75-year-old inspector in the Department of Buildings was fined $250 and sentenced to thirty days for criminal contempt yesterday. He had refused to fill out a financial questionnaire requested by a Brooklyn grand jury.
PELHAM, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- The United States must take the lead in organizing a world federation to preserve a stable peace, Earl Attlee, former British Prime Minister, said here tonight.
The northwest corner of Second Avenue and Fortieth Street has been purchased by the 239 East Fortieth Street Property Corporation in a deal negotiated by Ackman Brothers, brokers.

The Ford Motor Company won't attempt to set up sales finance operations in any community where independent finance companies are willing to match the rates offered dealers by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, Edmund L. Grimes, chairman of Commercial Credit Company, Baltimore, said here yesterday.

The years since the end of the second World War have seen many changes in divers fields, but, according to a report in this newspaper the other day, one of the few industries that have made no major alterations is that of bell manufacturing.

The tangled affairs of Alexander L. Guterma took an odd turn yesterday when his counsel subpoenaed the regional administrator of the Securities land Exchange Commission to appear in Federal Court as a defense witness.

The body of George C. Carey, 30 years old, of 359 East Pine Street, Long Beach, L. I., was recovered Monday night from the waters off Rikers Island. It was the forty-fourth body found in the search for victims of the American Airlines crash Feb. 3.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- A French jurists' association has renewed charges that "inhumane methods" are being employed in continental France and in Algeria to put down the Algerian rebellion.

The Monroe County Water Authority, N. Y., sold $13,200,000 of serial bonds secured by service revenues yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., land Smith, Barney Co. at an interest cost of 4.069 per cent.

After the trials and setbacks that have plagued the Vanguard Project for more than a year yesterday's successful launching into orbit of the first full-sized Vanguard satellite is cheering news indeed. The success was, of course, particularly sweet for the many devoted scientists and engineers who have worked so long and hard on this effort, undeterred by past failures.

IT is not an old wives' tale. Van Cliburn does play other concertos besides the Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff that have been his constant companions in the flight to glory. He proved it last night at Carnegie Hall when he performed others by Mozart, Schumann and Prokofieff.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals vacated today the receivership of the brokerage firm of Arthur L. Wright Co., Inc. The court said a receivership was unnecessary.
Three advertising salesmen were arrested yesterday for selling $50,000 worth of advertising space in a newspaper that had few, if any, readers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A drive by conservatives to close what they call the Treasury's "back door" encountered the powerful opposition today of speaker Sam Rayburn.

Sales of new policies by the Home Life Insurance Company last year set a record at $251,854,000, according to William P. Worthington, president. Sales of individual insurance totaled $211,076,000, for a year to year increase of 6 per cent. Group sales of $40,778,000 were up 20 per cent.
Rafael Puyana, the Colombian harpsichordist who made his debut two years ago, returned to Town Hall last night for another recital.
An explosive noise of undetermined origin alarmed residents in uptown Manhattan last night.

HONG KONG, Feb. 17 -- Hongqi, Peiping's leading journal on Communist theory, has undertaken a sweeping refutation of all views about Communist China expressed in recent speeches by Secretary of State Dulles.
BETHPAGE, L. I., Feb. 17 -- A - high-speed vessel equipped with hydrofoils will be designed for the Maritime Administration by the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation here.

The Knickerbockers were not really in danger of losing to the St. Louis Hawks last night at Madison Square Garden. In the end, Coach Fuzzy Levane's team won, 112--93, and going away, but only after the National Basketball Association champions had cut a 27-point deficit to 10 points.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 17 -- Kenya's Government officially took notice today of the fact that although Jomo Kenyatta is in jail about 500 miles from the capital he has once again become a sensitive issue here.
Ten American painters and sculptors were named yesterday by the Ford Foundation to receive grants of $10,000 each to enable them to devote a maximum of time to creative work.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 17 -- A Hamburg court barred West Germany's most widely read illustrated magazine from the country's newsstands today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The United States launched into orbit today a scientific satellite that will serve as man's first weather observation station in space.
Arthur Godfrey will succeed Edward R. Murrow as the host of the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Person to Person" television program for the 1959-60 season.

A new plan to assist school integration here was proposed yesterday. It seeks to achieve a better ethnic balance in a new Brooklyn elementary school by drawing its pupils from beyond normal zoning lines.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan intends to warn Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the grave risks the Soviet Union runs in attempting to divide the West and hustle its forces out of Berlin, a highly placed source said today.
SOMEWHERE over the rainbow, the skies are blue and girdles are green. At the rainbow's end is Abraham Straus, which is all set to soar into a many-colored spring.
Leslie Stevens, one of the entertainment industry's most prolific writers, has taken on the task of adapting for the stage Robert Carson's film script, "Yankee Doodle Girl."
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's special message to the Legislature today asking for the creation of a state office of atomic energy:

The work of the Manhattan Society for Mental Health will be advanced as a result of a theatre party at the April 27 performance of "Destry Rides Again" at the Imperial Theatre. The new musical is scheduled to open on April 23.

American national and regional sports car rallies have developed, over the last three years, some exceptionally fine competitors. A few with the time, the money and the itch for something more challenging than the American-type rally, have ventured into the international field with marked success. Two recent international performances by Americans were outstanding.
The B. F. Goodrich Company reported yesterday a 9.9 per cent decline in earnings last year from the 1957 level and a 5.1 per cent drop in sales.

Somewhat obscured by the threatening Berlin crisis, a dramatic contest has just taken place between Soviet Russia and Iran in which the Soviets suffered a striking defeat but which still reveals their real attitudes, ambitions and methods.
Something new will be added soon to Manhattan's skyline -- an octagonal fifty-five-story office building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A happy accident of medical research has led to discovery that a fairly new drug shows great promise for treatment of gout. Gout is one of the rheumatic diseases that have plagued man for at least 4,000 years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A Securities and Exchange Commission hearing into charges against Reynolds Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage and investment firms, was told today that stipulations concerning facts of the charges were nearly completed.

Governor Rockefeller declared in Albany yesterday that he was not yet ready to accept Mayor Wagner's contention that New York City must have either a tax on off-track betting or a rise in the sales tax from 3 per cent to 4.
WILTON, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Growth has caught up with Wilton. Many in the town feel it no longer can operate without a charter.
WARSAW, Feb. 17 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Poland's Communist chief, returned to Warsaw tonight after a twenty-three-day visit to Moscow.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 17 -- Indonesia will pay compensation for nationalized Dutch-owned enterprises only after she and the Netherlands settle all their outstanding problems, including the controversy over Netherlands New Guinea, Foreign Ministry officials said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Important men of state drank a toast here this morning in an exotic beverage called milk.
Premiums written by the Travelers Insurance Companies last year totaled $1,068,604,000, or 7.7 per cent more than the $991,919,000 written in 1957, according to the group's annual report.
Two major industrial organizations announced yesterday distributions of stock to their shareholders.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- A motion calling for the establishment of a tribunal to inquire into the Waters case was approved by the House of Commons today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Administration is considering a plan to use private money -- handled through a Federal revolving fund -- for financing rural electric cooperatives.

The Joint Congressional Economic Committee will shortly launch its expected inquiry into inflation. It will address itself to the problem, however, as part of a larger, and highly controversial, problem that the new chairman of the joint committee, the able Senator Paul Douglas of Illinois, has summed up in this brief but comprehensive statement:
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 17 -- Lenten worshippers entered Asuncion's cool old churches early this week to find on benches white leaflets carrying a "Prayer for the Tortured."

The four winners of a citywide brotherhood poster contest among 400 children received their prizes yesterday at the Building for Brotherhood of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, 43 West Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- The total income of all Americans rose to a record last month, the Government reported today.

THE new Phantom Hostess, 323 East Fifty-eighth Street, is geared to provide all kinds of catering services. It will deliver a complete dinner for one, piping hot, on as little as an hour's notice. Or, with equal facility, it will take complete charge of a banquet for hundreds.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- Navy specialists meeting here today called the submarine threat the nation's most urgent defense problem.
CENTRAL air conditioning looms as one of the newest necessities for the home. This was indicated yesterday at a press seminar sponsored by the Carrier Corporation.

AS a pedestrian and user of bus transportation for the past twelve years in Manhattan I must express my astonishment that the planning of one-way, in place of the present two-way, bus routes on the East Side has apparently been agreed upon without the slightest effort to poll the views of the tens of thousands of people who will be the most severely affected by the change -- the non-car owners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A weeping Brooklyn man told Senate racket investigators today that he had been beaten mercilessly, while a juke box drowned his screams, until he agreed to give hoodlums a major part of his interest in a coin-machine business.

The shocking revelations of the slaughter of American flyers by the Soviet Union and the proved mendacity of Mikoyan and other high Communist officials in concealing this uncivilized act once more emphasize the futility of expecting the Soviet Union to live up to any accepted standards of conduct among nations.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Round Table galloped in impressive fashion today, brightening his chances of running in the $135,000 guaranteed Santa Anita Handicap Feb. 28.

THE National Academy of Design will open its annual exhibition -- the 134th in the long series -- with a preview reception this evening in the organization's galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Opening to the public tomorrow, the show will run through March 15.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The Department of Justice antitrust case against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. took a new turn today.
Four bakery union locals pledged their mutual support yesterday in the seventeen-day strike against five employers associations.
WILLIAM GRAHAM STROUD Jr., the scientist who directed development of the weather-observing satellite fired yesterday, is a young chief in a young man's business.
Branch Rickey, one of baseball's senior citizens, recommended a third major league yesterday, with New York as one of its key cities.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The final steps are under way for merging the First Western Bank of San Francisco and the California Bank of Los Angeles.

Bill Rosensohn, the promoter, and Cus D'Amato, the champion's manager, disclosed yesterday they favored home television for the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson world heavyweight title fight, regardless of where it is staged.
Gen. Lucius D. Clay praised Secretary of State Dulles last night as a champion of "all the peoples of the free world" and defended his foreign policy against demands for a new one.

The six sub-four-minute milers from abroad who will compete in the Amateur Athletic Union's national championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday will be divided evenly between the 1,000-yard and mile events.

The April 21 performance of "Sweet Bird of Youth" will benefit the Child Development Center. The Tennessee Williams play starring Paul Newman, Geraldine Page and Sidney Blackmer is scheduled to open at the Martin Beck Theatre on March 10.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, platinum, rubber and hides rose; cocoa, the domestic sugar positions, potatoes and copper declined, and price movements for the world sugar months, cotton-seed oil, wool, zinc and lead were mixed.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Trim as a new, freshly sharpened pencil, a Vanguard rocket rose straight up from this sand spit in the Atlantic today and shot into space.

Harold W. Cohn, Democratic-Liberal candidate for the Assembly in the Fourth Assembly District, Brooklyn, won election yesterday by a heavy majority over Victor A. Tirabasso Jr., the Republican candidate.

WARSAW, Feb. 17 -- The United States Embassy in Warsaw has been packed for the last week by Poles on the strength of a false rumor that the United States is seeking Polish workers to go to Alaska and other states.
Names made news on Madison Avenue yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission confirmed today that a sample of Minnesota wheat grown in 1957 carried an unusually high amount of radioactive strontium 90 from atomic fall-out.
A program to train teachers for the city's "600" schools -- special schools for pupils posing disciplinary problems -- has been established by the Graduate School of Education of Yeshiva University.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the day 2 to 13 points (10 to 65 cents a bale) below Monday's close.
LONDON, Feb. 17--The first session of the roundtable conference on Cyprus ended tonight in a spirit of harmony, hope and promise.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 18 -- Six of the eight members of the British Wolfe-Noel Cup team failed to reach the quarterfinals of the United States women's squash racquets championship today at the Merion Cricket Club.
A former Israeli official declared yesterday that Israel was capable of integrating a population of about 4,000,000 persons within her borders.

Turkish Premier Menderes is fortunately recovering rapidly from minor injuries suffered in a plane crash, but the London round-table conference on Cyprus which he came to attend has suddenly run into last-minute difficulties which prompted an emergency session last night to avert its collapse.
SOMERVILLE, N. J., Feb. 18 -- A 30,000,000-gallon reservoir on the Raritan River near here has been reduced to a shallow stream and the 123-year-old dam that held the water is crumbling.

The Securities and Exchange Commission asserted yesterday that "some $2,000,000 appears to have been siphoned" out of one company controlled by Alexander L. Guterma into another dominated by Mr. Guterma and an associate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Feb. 11:
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 18 (AP) -- An astronomer who photographed a strange object in the sky said today that it might have been the final collapse of a small or decaying star.

Alex Olmedo, the Peruvian youth who led the United States Davis Cup team to a stunning victory over Australia in December, will be seen here tonight in his first tournament appearance since his triumph Down Under.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Feb. 18 -- Penn's track and field team captured twelve of thirteen first places in winning the annual Polar Bear meet today. Despite the icy implications of the competition's name, the Quakers triumphed within the comfortable environs of Lawrenceville School's Lavino Field House.
Rumors of Russian commodity moves raised cocoa and platinum prices the daily limit yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in both commodities was heavy.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Widespread but not unanimous support for the court reorganization program recommended by the Judicial Conference was voiced today at a public hearing.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was "always open for suggestions on how to get funds needed to run the city." If "any of our citizens has any workable ideas, we are always glad to get them," he declared.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Objections by Archbishop Makarios threatened today to upset an agreement to make Cyprus independent.
The last decade is regarded the most fruitful period in man's modern war against ills of the heart, yet these diseases remain the nation's greatest health problem.

The country appears to have one set of bank merger standards for the West Coast and another for the East Coast, Morris A. Schapiro, bank analyst and president of the New York investment firm bearing his name, told a Boston audience yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 18 (Reuters) -- The Socialist Trade Union Federation called Belgiums 137,000 miners out on strike tonight as industrial unrest reached major proportions.
SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The New Mexico House of Representatives heatedly rejected today a message of congratulations from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman.
HAVANA, Feb. 18 -- Maj. Jesus Sosa Blanco, twice sentenced to death as a "war criminal," was executed by a firing squad this morning.
ALBANY, FEB. 18 (UPI) -Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
"The Gale Storm Show," a filmed comedy series, will switch from the Columbia Broadcasting System to the American Broadcasting Company television network early in April.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -President Eisenhower said today that if there was any shooting around Berlin, it would be the Communists who started it.

Mrs. Vera Owen Wilson, the 57-year-old woman accused of robbing two Manhattan banks, was permitted to plead guilty yesterday to robbery in the third degree before General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

I wish to thank you for the interest which you showed in my remarks in the Senate on Feb. 12. In your editorial of Feb. 14 you expressed the view that I was wrong on several points and that the sooner I rectified them "the better for the West and for peace."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -President Eisenhower reiterated today that he wanted John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State as long as Mr. Dulles believed he was able to carry on.

Barry Morell, the young American tenor who made his Metropolitan Opera debut in "Madama Butterfly" last Nov. 1, has been having a busy season of it. He went on from "Butterfly" to sing the leading tenor roles in "La Traviata," "Un Ballo in Maschera" and "La Boheme." Last night he added a fifth role, the Duke in "Rigoletto."

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The British Government continued intensive preparations today for the visit of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd to Moscow, undismayed by the threatening tone of Premier Khrushchev's latest speech.
The Sheltering Arms Children's Service announced yesterday a special campaign to raise $350,000 for building and expansion.

Governor Rockefeller is undergoing, at the very outset of his administration, a political ordeal which he has chosen to meet head-on as a matter of principle. It is a test on the question of demanding taxation equal to the cost of government. Constitutionally required to submit a "balanced budget," the Governor has decided that he wishes to return as soon as possible to the literal meaning of that often-misused term.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 18 (AP) -- E. H. Lane's unbeaten Espanto sped to a neck victory today in the $8,275 Duncan Kenner Stakes at the Fair-Grounds.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Governor Rockefeller set the stage today for a television campaign in favor of his tax and budget programs by calling for a realistic facing of the facts.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Mayor Wagner's administration asked the Legislature today for stiffer penalties for violators of the Multiple Dwelling Law. It also endorsed a proposal to make it easier to convert some one and two-family dwellings into apartment houses to relieve the housing shortage.
James Bell, the 11-year-old boy who survived a seventeen-story fall Tuesday afternoon, remained on the critical list yesterday at Beekman-Downtown Hospital.
NEWARK, Feb. 18 -- Fifteen independent bus operators, eleven of them serving the Newark-Elizabeth area, have been granted fare increases by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senators Johnson of Texas and Dirksen of Illinois, the majority and minority leaders, have just had a long argument over the sources of Federal spending and the partisan responsibility for it. But, while these leaders and other Senators discussed a basic cause of this spending that is bipartisan and inherent in CongressionalExecutive practice, they minimized its real weight as a factor in the inflated costs of Federal Government.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 18 -- The Indonesian Army leadership is lined up solidly behind President Sukarno in his tug-of-war with the major political parties on how to implement a guided democracy, the army's chief spokesman indicated today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (UPI) -- Phil Maloney scored his first two goals of the season tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 triumph over the New York Rangers. It was the Blues' sixth straight defeat.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- A pitcher, John Gray of the Philadelphia Phillies, won a three-way suddendeath play-off today for top honors in Tampa's annual baseball-golf tournament at the Palma Ceia golf course.

When Cyrus Tibbals 4th was 8 years old in 1955, he fell against a storm door at the home of a playmate near his home at 96 East Slope Road, Mahwah, N. J. The lower pane shattered and a glass sliver, nine inches long and shaped like a sword, pierced his right armpit, penetrating both lungs.
A former director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service yesterday blamed both management and labor for a "discouraging trend" in collective bargaining.
PARIS, Feb. 18 -- French and international diplomatic circles noted today the hard tone employed by Premier Khrushchev in discussing the problem of Berlin yesterday in the city of Tula.

HONG KONG, Feb. 18 -Marshal Chen Yi, Foreign Minister of Communist China, denounced the United States and the Government of Laos today over the recent renunciation by Laos of the Geneva agreements ending the Indochina war.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa renewed his criticism of the Board of Education's school construction program yesterday.

Consolidated net income of Associates Investment Company, South Bend, Ind., was $18,524,936 or $5.51 a share after preferred dividends in 1958. This compared with $20,531,453 or $6.11 a share after preferred dividends reported for 1957.

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Indiana Oil Purchasing Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) has dropped its price for Oklahoma and Kansas crude oil of 40 to 44.9-degree gravity from $3.08 to $3.05 a barrel. The change was effective yesterday.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Feb. 18 (AP) -- General of the Army George C. Marshall suffered another stroke last night. The first stroke, described as "mild," came at his winter home at near-by Pinehurst on Jan. 15. He was brought here to the Army hospital the same day.

WALTER PISTON is an American composer who gets his share of second and third performances as well as premieres. This is not a matter of politics or good luck. His music recommends itself to performers and audiences by its proportion, good taste and accessibility.
Boris Pasternak was quoted yesterday as having said he would not retract a single word of his best-selling novel, "Doctor Zhivago" and that he was "grateful in my heart that the world is reading it."
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18 (AP) -A three-day-old strike at the St. Louis Zoo was settled today. The fifty-five striking employes are to be back on the job tomorrow.
A subsidy for States Marine Lines for operation on worldwide routes has received tentative approval of the Federal Maritime Board.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson today set the minimum price support for 1959 crop corn at $1.12 a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The honeymoon between the Atomic Energy Commission and Congress ended abruptly today. Its termination was signaled when the commission chairman, John A. McCone, sharply berated Congressional Democrats for their criticism of his atomic power program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa threatened today to call a teamster strike against citrus groves at Lakeland, Fla., owned by the Carpenters Union.
BOSTON,Feb. 18 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller said today in response to questions, "I really don't know what steps the Republican party should take to prepare for 1960."

The women of the Hellenic Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity are sponsoring a dinner dance to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Feb. 27. The Children's Aid Society grants to achieve greater efficiency in its work in behalf of 58,000 boys and girls in this city. Morgan Dix Wheelock, the president, announced yesterday at the organization's 106th annual meeting.

Bob Pettit, the 6-foot 9-inch basketball star of the St. Louis Hawks, yesterday became the first qualifier for the tenth annual S. Rae Hickok "professional athlete of the year" award by leading the voting in the January poll of the nation's sports writers and broadcasters.

A fourth-quarter upturn in all divisions lifted the net income of Textron, Inc., in 1958 to a record of $10,753,865, equal to $2.51 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding. This represents an increase of 24 per cent over the $8,695,757, or $2.25 a common share, cleared the year before, according to the annual report of Royal Little, chairman, and R. C. Thompson Jr., president.

It is good news that Dr. Martin T. Catherwood, whom Governor Rockefeller recently appointed Industrial Commissioner, is going into action promptly on a bill to curb improper financial activities in labor unions. William Saroyan, the author and Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, said last night he was leaving on Saturday for Yugoslavia to do a movie and might stay abroad for the rest of his life.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18, (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee overwhelmingly rejected today President Eisenhower's proposal to impose a $200,000,000 ceiling on Federal aid for local airport construction over the next four years.

Two spring theatre parties have been announced for the benefit of The Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. One is scheduled for the April 1 performance of "Redhead," the musical starring Gwen Verdon at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, and the other for the Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse comedy, "Tall Story," with Hans Conried at the Belasco on April 30.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 18 -South Korea's Ambassador to Washington. You Chan Yang continued today the Seoul Government's attack on Japan's plan to repatriate Koreans to Communist North Korea if they wished to go there.

GIUSEPPE AJMONE, an Italian artist exhibiting for the first time in New York, at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, is an abstract painter whose references to nature are always ambiguous. All of his paintings are keyed to a soft mist that clings to landscapes, flowers and even storms with equal tenacity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -Real prices of major minerals have declined substantially since 1890, refuting alarmists concerned over the future of our "plundered planet," a leading minerals economist said today.
The resignation of John A. Roosevelt and three other leaders from both office and membership shook the Metropolitan Political Club yesterday.

The Ford Motor Company will market a small Ford to sell for less than $2,000 this fall. In addition, the company will put out a second, slightly larger compact car in 1960 under the Edsel name.

The proposal of the Greyhound Bus Corporation to build a $10,000,000 terminal on Thirty-fourth Street east of Eighth Avenue was unexpectedly revived by the City Planning Commission yesterday.

The first assembly conducted by the American National Theatre and Academy ended a four-day meeting here yesterday with the announcement that the event would be held annually.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 18 -- With the 1959 spring training campaign not even off the mark, Casey Stengel already finds himself spinning in orbit and tossing confusion into the ranks of friend and foe alike.

Not too many years ago, it took a week for a check deposited in a bank here to clear on the Pacific Coast. With the advent of air transport and faster handling, this time was cut. In 1951, the Federal Reserve system decided two days was the most that should be allowed for a check to clear anywhere in the country.
The Remington-Rand division of the Sperry-Rand Corporation is "seriously considering" moving its international advertising from Robert Otto Co., Inc., according to an informed source.

The nation's inventories of gasoline showed an increase of 1,212,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 200,120,000 barrels, compared with 198,908,000 a week earler and 210,560,000 a year ago.
MIAMI, Feb. 18 -- First Landing went into the mile-and-an-eighth Everglades Stakes at Hialeah today the nearest thing to a "sure thing" that anyone would ever want at a race track.
Four Negro mothers who had been found guilty of violating the Compulsory Education Law escaped punishment yesterday under a ruling by Justice Nathaniel Kaplan.

Electric power production last week dipped to 13,156,000,000 kilowatt hours from 13,292,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. Production in the comparable week of 1958 was 12,417,000,000 kilowatt hours.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday a 25 per cent drop in earnings for last year and a 13 per cent decline in sales. The results, however, were better than those for its two big competitors, the Ford Motor Company and Chrysler Corporation.
