Stocks had their first optimistic Thursday in weeks yesterday. The decline in the bill rate and the nature of the Treasury's financing problems appeared to have convinced the investing public that the Federal Reserve Banks were not likely to raise their lending (discount) rates.
CHOZLANIA, Syria, Feb. 19 -- Six smiling peasant farmers stood in a muddy field here today and gave a cheer for land reform and Gamal Abdel Nasser.

The Cuban peso is becoming a rare and unwanted currency in foreign exchange transactions. This results from the continuing effort of the Castro Government to thwart refugees of the ousted Batista regime from cashing in the money they took out of th ecountry.

The city's evening high school teachers, whose mass resignation has closed the night schools, were turned down yesterday in a plea for state aid. Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, said the dispute was purely local.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Debbie Reynolds divorced Eddie Fisher today. The actress charged that "another woman" had wrecked her marriage to the singer. She was referring to Elizabeth Taylor, actress, but did not mention her by name.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 19 -- Mrs. W. Pepper Constable, the defender from Princeton, N. J., gained the semi-final round today in the women's United States squash racquets championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 19 -- The relaxing of rules on competitive bidding for Defense Department contracts to favor concerns in distressed labor areas will be studied by a committee to be formed by the three Representatives in Congress from Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Many large dinner parties were given tonight at the Heart Ball held at the Bath and Tennis Club for the benefit of the American Heart Association. Of funds raised at the event, 60 per cent remain here to finance research and community service work in Palm Beach and Martin Counties.
Biting winds swept down from the northwest and sent the city's temperature down to 9 degrees above zero early this morning.
Burmeister Wain, the world's largest manufacturer of marine Diesel engines, has entered into a license agreement with the Soviet Union.
SOMERVILLE; N. J., Feb. 19 -- The question of who is going to foot the bill for about $60,000 in repairs for a dam on the Raritan River will be argued at a meeting here Feb. 27.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Senate rackets committee, Senator John L. McClellan, introduced his own labor-reform bill today aimed at "hoodums, gangsters and racketeers" in labor and management.

NORTH of Newport and southeast of Providence in the State of Rhode Island a peninsula shaped like a lobster's claw separates Mount Hope Bay from Narragansett Bay. On the larger part of the lobster's claw looking west across the harbor at the smaller part lies the old port of Bristol (population 10,335).
Executive changes by the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its principal manufacturing and marketing subsidiary were announced yesterday.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas (messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses):

A Kings County grand jury investigating lawlessness in the Brooklyn public schools commended George N. Allen yesterday for his series in The New York World-Telegram and Sun on the problems that teachers face in their classrooms.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The battle lines of a new war between states were drawn today following passage by the Nevada State Assembly of a bill to claim a 40,000-square-mile area of California for Nevada. California enjoyed the joke.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that a retail grocery chain could not escape commission jurisdiction by acquiring an "infinitesimal" interest in a recognized meat packing company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits reopened the Senate debate on the unification of Germany today with an attempt to counter sentiment for direct negotiations between the East and West German Governments.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 19 -- Miners in three of Belgium's coal regions struck today in answer to a call for a general mine strike, but in a fourth big district the workers ignored the appeal.

ROBERT RICCI, head of the suddenly famous house of Nina Ricci and vice president of the haute couture in Paris turned up in a new guise this week. He was an interested spectator at Bergdorf Goodman's "petite couture" showing of Virginie de Paris and Carven clothes.

The largest opening crowd within memory turned out at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night to see Alejandro Olmedo in his first tournament match since he led the United States Davis Cup team to victory in Australia.

Manhatan Borough President Hulan E. Jack said yesterday that he had enlisted the aid of Mayor Wagner and the police for tenants of two Harlem tenements that have been without central heating for nine days.

Samuel C. Waugh, president of the Export-Import Bank (Eximbank), urged yesterday that nations whose economies had been stabilized through aid provided by the United States join in giving similar assistance to lands that were still underdeveloped.

Net income of the General Electric Company last year fell 2 per cent below the record level of 1957 on a drop in sales of 5 per cent, according to Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman and chief executive officer of the world's biggest manufacturer of electrical devices.
A splinter union voted last night to strike the city's transit system unless it received prompt official recognition of its grievances.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Antitrust charges were filed today against the two largest newsstand chains and publishers and distributors of scores of the biggest magazines.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 20 -- President Luis A. Somoza Debayle said today that his Government was "as liberal as any in the Caribbean area."

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Feb. 19 -- President Eisenhower and his host, President Adolfo Lopez Mateos, renewed pledges of unwavering respect and friendship here today. Then, as the resort city on the Pacific put on its holiday mood, the two Presidents went for a cruise to talk about trade.
Hunter College conferred degrees on 460 graduating students at its 114th commencement last evening. About 2,200 persons attended the exercises in the college's Assembly Hall, 695 Park Avenue.
A neatly attired man, striking a Napoleonic pose, turned a 74,500 per cent profit in a midtown bank yesterday in something less than a minute.
Lincoln Square tenement dwellers paraded yesterday in protest against Fordham University's attempt to evict them from the site of its proposed midtown campus.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president emeritus of Brown University, questioned today the sincerity of former critics of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, who speak more kindly of his policies since his illness.
Cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange ended 5 to 25 points (25 cents to $1.10 a bale) below Wednesday's close. The near March contract showed the most weakness.

The British Government announced this week that it would not draw down the remaining $250 million available to it under the stand-by arrangement entered into with the United States Export-Import Bank in February, 1957. Nor would any extension be asked, according to Frederick J. Erroll, Economic Secretary to the Treasury, on the availability of the credit.

Harry Markson was named general manager of boxing at the first meeting of the Madison Square Garden Corporation's new board of directors yesterday. Markson had served as managing director of the New York half of the International Boxing Club, which is being dissolved by court order.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- One of the Administration's principal scientific advisers suggests that any inspection system for a ban on nuclear weapons tests should include satellites for the detection of nuclear explosions in space.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- A committee of the American Bar Association plans to propose "corrective legislation" to counteract recent United States Supreme Court decisions on Communists, association spokesmen said today.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The Governments of Britain, Greece and Turkey and the leaders of the Greek and Turkish Cypriotes agreed today to a plan for the future independence of Cyprus as a republic.

Religion must make itself "relevant" to the community before it can become an effective force for good, three speakers agreed yesterday at a Brotherhood Week luncheon at the Building for Brotherhood, 43 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst underwent major surgery today to speed his recovery from tuberculosis. His doctors repeated their belief that it was unlikely he could play this year, and they remained uncertain about 1960.
The city's proposed Code of Ethics was criticized at a City Hall public hearing yesterday as threatening to deprive the city of the services of valued unpaid officials.
FAR too many weddings are pretentiously out of keeping with the income of the bride's family.
HAVANA, Feb. 19 -- Hundreds of business and professional men and others have been arrested on charges of collaboration with the Batista Government and participation in its corruption.
Grant Advertising, Inc., which has had some recent ups and downs with its automobile advertising, received a jolt yesterday.

Two developments this week have driven labor reform legislation further than ever into the controversial arena. So far, in fact, has this happened that curbs on internal union abuses, which might have been enacted with relatively little infighting, may now be lost in the scuffle.
A three-and-one-half-acre tract in Sea Gate, Brooklyn, once the site of the Atlantic Yacht Club, has been purchased by builders for improvement with private homes.

EVERY exhibitor of standard products at the Outdoor Exposition in the Coliseum has something new or old that he likes to brag about more than he brags about other products. Here are a few of the brag items connected with hunting and fishing:

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Tossy Spivakovsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Claudio Arrau, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Paganini Quartet, Town Hall, 8:30.
The Queens police uncovered a heroin packaging plant early yesterday as a result of the chance discovery of a shipment of the narcotic at La Guardia Airport.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Former President Harry S. Truman informed Congress today that he had never thought well of the Twenty-second Amendment to the Constitution, which denies a third term to Presidents.
The Waterfront Commission postponed without explanation yesterday its scheduled questioning of Frank Campbell, an ex-convict and waterfront thug. Campbell was directed to return March 12.

The "golden era" of Greenwich Village, from 1912 to 1930, is the subject of a new book by Allen Churchill entitled "The Improper Bohemians." It portrays the famous New York neighborhood and the people who made it "the Left Bank of the United States."
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told the House of Commons tonight that he might visit Washington after his trip to Moscow.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Should persons coming into the state be forbidden to receive welfare money the first year?
MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Feb. 19 -- The vogue for engraved automobile hubcaps has spread to this community.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Pravda intensified today the Soviet quarrel with an influential Egyptian newspaper, accusing it of trying to disrupt relations between the United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union.
IN professional life Lonny Chapman is a sensitive, lucid actor, never better than in the touching revival of "The Glass Menagerie" in 1956.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Tentative plans for a forty-story office building in downtown Newark were announced today. The proposed skyscraper, at 526 Broad Street, would cost about $10,000,000 and would be New Jersey's tallest building.

With private investment houses unwilling to buy $7,000,000 of new Arkansas bridge bonds at an interest cost of 4 3/8 per cent or less, the Arkansas State Highway Commission borrowed the money yesterday from the Federal Housing and Home Financing Agency under the terms of a loan agreement reached before the sale.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- The new Daytona Beach International Speedway was a scene of feverish activity this morning.

Check transactions at the major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $24,322,734,000, according to the weekly report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was an increase of 8.8 per cent for the week, which included Lincoln's Birthday, over the $22,345,717,000 volume for the preceding full week. But the total was 3.8 per cent below the $25,275,842,000 of the 1958 week, which did not include the holiday.
A ninety-minute television drama presented last month on "Playhouse 90" will provide the basis for a weekly half-hour series to be offered by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator John F. Kennedy proposed today that only relatives of citizens and resident aliens of this country be admitted as immigrants.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru rejected today an Opposition plea for formation of a "national government," composed of all major political groups in the country, to carry out economic development programs.
Gene Fullmer and Wilfie Greaves will meet in the ten-round star bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight will be televised nationally by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator John F. Kennedy called today for a revitalized and sustained attack by the United States on the economic problems of the under-developed areas of the world.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States last month was 2.3 per cent above that for the corresponding month of last year, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 19 -- The merged labor federation made plans here today for establishment of a task force to seek Congressional approval of a Federal minimum wage of $1.25 an hour.
Following is the text of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's televised address last night on the tax situation, as recorded by The New York Times:

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The heaviest selling pressure in many months hit grain futures on the Board of Trade today on the announcement of several sharply reduced Government supports. Prices broke sharply before meeting any rallying strength.
RIO HATA, Panama, Feb. 19 -- An elite force of 1,330 paratroopers, fully equipped and ready for combat, flew 2,000 miles nonstop from the United States today and jumped here.
LONDON, Feb. 19 (Reuters) -- William S. Morrison, the Speaker of the House of Commons since 1951, announced today that he would retire from office at the end of the present Parliament.
The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in 1958 attained the highest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report of John C. Whitaker, board chairman, and Bowman Gray, president.

Stock-split action proposed by three companies came as no surprise yesterday. Another company, however, revised the formula of its original plan. The stocks affected by the various moves soared 1 1/2 to 3 1/2 points. Directors of the Thiokol Chemical Corporation voted to spit the stock three-for-one. Subject to approval of stockholders at the annual meeting on April 16, the authorized stock would be increased to 6,000,000 from 2,000,000 shares.

The Wagner administration has known for three months at least that it would need upward of $135,000,000 more in revenues, beyond the normal increase in tax and state-aid yield, to balance its 1959-60 expense budget. After various additions and subtractions that figure has gone up to $141,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Representative Graham A. Barden, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, promised resistance today "with every energy that is in me" to the repeal of the loyalty oath in the National Defense Education Act.
The Shell Petroleum Company, Ltd., a member of the Royal Dutch-Shell Group, reduced the price of gasoline and fuel oil yesterday at the Abadan, Iran, refinery.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19 -- Henry Ford 2d characterized the merged labor federation tonight as the "most aggressive ascendant force in American poltics."
Sometime today or tomorrow there is likely to be an announcement that New York University's basketball team has accepted a bid to play in the forthcoming National Invitation Tournament.

High blood pressure in itself seems to cause no degenerative changes such as arteriosclerosis in giraffes, although the long-necked animals have the world's highest blood pressure, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Government disclosed spending plans today for half a dozen rocket shots into outer space. It also plans to launch an inflatable communications satellite about 100 feet wide.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Some Democratic lawmakers were reported balking today at voting for an increase in New York City's sales tax if the Legislature refused to legalize off-track betting.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- The six nations of the European Economic Community have "seriously underestimated the harm they may do to the trade of other countries," according to eleven nations that export primary commodities.
BOOTY brought back from forays on the Paris Flea Market and from buying adventures in other parts of Europe and the United States will go on sale today at the Greenwich Village Antique Shop.
FRANCE as a country has never shown any particular feeling for Handel. Yet it was two Frenchmen who brought a note of distinction to the all-Handel program given last night at Town Hall.

AS green as the tropical verdure that surrounds baseball's spring training camps is the encyclopedic Green Book, a font of statistical information that Dave Grote of the National League compiles for the ink-stained wretches of the Fourth Estate. The latest volume arrived yesterday, just in time for a Florida-bound press-box tenant to pack it in his knapsack along with the sun-tan lotion. Want a peek?
The Cities Service Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a new plan for integrating the Arkansas Fuel Oil Corporation into the company.

The United States Army Band, Maj. Hugh Curry, director, and the United States Army Chorus, Capt. Samuel Loboda, director, gave a concert of American music late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall as part of the WNYC Twentieth American Music Festival.
The New York Centrail Railroad plans to discontinue passenger service to Albany and build a new station at Rensselaer, across the Hudson River from the state capital.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The Rockfeller Administration opened today an attack on the rooming houses and overcrowded converted apartments that are breeding slums in New York City.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Following are a translation of the text of the welcoming speech by President Lopez Mateos of Mexico to President Eisenhower on his arrival here today and the text of President Eisenhower's reply:
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 19 -- King Mohamed V and his two sons flew to Corsica today with a passenger whose identity was kept secret until after their departure.

"No encroachment on the territory of the German Democratic Republic -- in the middle of which Berlin is situated -- either by ground, air or water can be allowed. * * * It is common knowledge that there are Soviet troops in the German Democratic Republic and, mind you, they are not there to play skittles.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Boris L. Pasternak was reported today to have moved temporarily from his country home near Moscow, presumably to avoid calls from the dozens of newsmen arriving to cover the visit of Prime Minister Harold MacMillan.
LONDON, Feb.19 -- The industrials scored widespread minor gains on the stock market here today.
The Board of Estimate will hear arguments today on the sale of the city's subway power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company.
Platinum and cocoa rose the daily limit for the second day in succession yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was active in both markets.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 19 -- For the first time in 2,000 years, the people of Cyprus were assured tonight of their independence. But the agreement signed in London to make this possible caused no demonstrations here.
The General Telephone System reported yesterday new highs in 1958 revenues, net income, earnings a share, total assets and telephones in service.
TRENTON, Feb. 19 -- The number of unemployed in New Jersey rose last month to 221,000, the highest figure for any January since the World War II demobilization in 1946.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Americans should worry less about the role of stress in producing heart disease, an authority on problems of the circulatory system said here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The Metropolitan Regional Council proposed formally today the establishment of "a tri-state commuter railroad panel to deal exclusively with the pressing problem of saving existing suburban services."
HOBART, Australia, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Ilsa Konrads, 14 years old, lowered her world record to 10 minutes 11.4 seconds in winning the 880-yard free-style swim tonight in the Australian championship.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 19 -- The Long Island Symphony Society, the first completely professional symphony on Long Island, will sponsor a benefit dinner for its maintenance at the Garden City Hotel on April 4. The dinner will be preceeded by a cocktail party and reception in the hotel lounge.

After watching Penn State's Ed Moran perform at West Point last Saturday, Carleton Crowell, Army's track coach, wrote "I predict Moran will be the next American runner to break four minutes for the mile. I don't believe there's a college runner who can stay with him now at 1,000 yards or the mile."

The Norfolk and Western Railway Company and the Virginian Railway Company have reached a basis for merger. The announcement was made yesterday jointly by Stuart P. Saunders, president of the Norfolk and Western, and F. D. Beale, president of the Virginian.

JOSEPH J. CAPUTA may very well have been in the Governor's mind last month when Mr. Rockefeller wrote of the rent-control regulations that "it is essential [they] be made to operate as reasonably, as simply and as expeditiously as possible."

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 20 -- The Moscow radio said today that the West's reply to Soviet proposals on Germany "does not provide a reasonable basis for settlement of the German question." The broadcast said the Western notes delivered Monday "do not contain a single more or less constructive suggestion capable of facilitating settlement of questions either of Berlin or of Germany."

The five - story apartment building occupying an entire blockfront on Andrews Avenue between Tenney Place and University Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Harvey Sorkin Associates, realty investors, to clients of George Dines after a brief ownership.
The Securities and Exchange Commission asked yesterday for the appointment of a receiver for the F. L. Jacobs Company, until last Friday the key element in Alexander L. Guterma's financial empire.
Three off-duty policemen captured a 41-year-old man last night as he was trying to hold up an East Side night club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The old feud between organized labor and the Republican party is getting hot again.

The United States atomic energy industry last year reached maturity after a period of growing pains, according to Gordon R. Molesworth, president of Molesworth Associates and atomic energy consultant to Harris, Upham Co.

The report of the dissolving of the India League of America after twenty-two years of existence is poignant. The very existence of the league is a tribute not only to J. J. Singh, but also to America. The India League of the U. S. S. R. did not have to disband; it was never established.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service went into the atomic waste-disposal business yesterday.

FRONT ROYAL, Va., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Twenty-two Negro students started their first day of classes in integrated Warren County High School today with ten teachers in a building designed for 1,000 students. All white students again boycotted the school.

WILLOW, Alaska, Feb. 15 -- Exercise Caribou Creek, the Army's annual Alaska maneuver that ends on Thursday, has proved, ironically, that a modern Army has no place in the roadless wilds of the sub-arctic.

The women's Division of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will hold its eighth annual members luncheon and fashion show at the Waldorf-Astoria on April 7. Proceeds will go toward the support of the guild's programs for blind and visually handicapped persons of all ages, faiths and races.

Dr. Bruno Pittermann, Vice Chancellor of Austria, asserted yesterday that his country had recovered to the point where its credit was acceptable to American bankers. Thus, he added, there has been no need for him to request financial aid in Washington.

State Health Commissioner Herman E. Hilleboe called yesterday for re-examination of the entire concept of community health services. He was the keynote speaker at the third congress for nurses held at St. John's University.
PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Judicial investigators asked the police today to inquire into the circumstances of the death of Mrs. Margaret Thompson Biddle, June 8, 1956.
PENSIONS, deals and clashes behind the comfortable facade of big business were outlined in fascinating detail last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The General Assembly will meet tomorrow morning to pass judgment on plans to grant independence to two United Nations trust territories, the French Cameroons and the British Cameroons.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- Bill Hartack had a return engagement with Innishowen today, and Hartack won, easily. He had Ben Hatskin's 6-year-old horse under perfect control through the running of the mile-and-an-eighth turf event and guided him to a length triumph over W. Arnold Hanger's Washington, with the Lucky Day Farm's Toque third at Hialeah.
PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The widespread strikes in Belgium against closing uneconomic coal mines are a revolt against the economic integration of six nations through the European Coal and Steel Community.
Indications that nerve cells can alter the structure and function of muscles to which they are attached have just been adduced in Australian experiments on cats.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- The Assembly voted by 67-4 today to reject charges of a Chavez Ravine giveaway and approve the sale by the state of thirty-six acres in the ravine to the City of Los Angeles.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 19 -- The police today widened their investigation of a slumber party Friday night and Saturday morning that resulted in a 14-year-old Westport girl's being hospitalized. The police said they found fifteen girls, age 13 to 15, at the party, and that the majority had been drinking alcoholic beverages.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Feb. 19 -- The construction of five parking fields in the business district has been recommended by the Glen Cove Downtown Property Owners' Committee on Parking.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- The Justice Department today summoned ten more leading financial experts to testify in the present phase of the marathon antitrust suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

A Great Truth Little by little, women seem to be learning a great truth: that they can't have it both ways. Latest piece of evidence on this comes from Britain, where a proposed change in the matrimonial laws would allow for wives to pay alimony to their husbands when the circumstances made this desirable.

TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 19 -- Dave Beck was branded as a tax dodger by a Federal Court jury today. The pudgy, pink-cheeked, 64-year-old former labor leader, long a power in Seattle's business and civic community as well, was found guilty on all six counts of two indictments. They charged him with evading the payment of $240,000 of income taxes for the years 1950 to 1953.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Following is the text of a statement today to the Temporary Commission on Rents by Joseph J. Caputa, Rent Administrator, outlining the Rockefeller Administration's policy on residential rent controls:
The Reynolds Metals Company made a sharp recovery in the latter part of 1958, which enabled it to show the second highest sales and earnings in its forty-nine year history.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines registered yesterday a $17,000,000 issue of convertible subordinate debentures with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A measure to permit the start of harness racing in New York on March 25 instead of April 1 is reported to be gaining the backing of the Rockefeller Administration. There is also a strong possibility that the end of the season will be pushed back from Nov. 30 to Dec. 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The American Trucking Association reported today that intercity truckloadings last week were 12 per cent above those of the week a year ago in the thirty-four metropolitan areas surveyed.
The bond market continued strong yesterday.
ROME, Feb. 19 -- Jews and Christians joined today in condemning a version of the Bible in which a comic-book technique is used.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Titles of the five pictures nominated for the 1958 foreign-language film award to be made by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences April 6 were announced today by George Stevens, president.
The costumes in Les "Ballets Africains" have, come to the attention of License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 19 -- The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community wants to install an inspector in the Ruhr, in Germany, to stop what it considers monopolistic practices in coal marketing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Two juke box operators, one near tears, gave Senate racket investigators today a graphic picture of the mob-ridden coin-machine industry in the Chicago area.

A detailed analysis of the charges by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse that the city's school system is being operated under costly and archaic practices has been ordered by the Board of Education.

A new bill has been introduced into the New York State Senate and Assembly, the purpose of which is "to amend the education law, in relation to suspension of license or right to practice certain professions when practitioner has been received in a state hospital or private institution for care and treatment of mental illness, and termination of the suspension."

A conference of dairy industry officials was told yesterday that residues of insecticides and penicillin used to treat ailing cows had been found in some milk supplies, and constituted a potential health hazard.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens said yesterday that he was in favor of several of the proposed zoning changes made public this week by the City Planning Commission.
Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $30,000,000 to $565,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
General Motors and Chrysler were reportedly moving at an accelerated pace yesterday to produce a small car this fall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Ethiopian Government has complained to the United States, French and other diplomats in the Ethiopian capital that it suspects Britain of wishing to carve a new British Commonwealth out of the Somali territories of the horn of Africa.
The Madison Avenue Bridge over the Harlem River, connecting Manhattan and the Bronx at 138th Street, will be closed to traffic next Tuesday for a renovation job that will take about fifteen months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Congress, which frequently vies with the purveyors of Washington gossip as fact in making eminent citizens wish they had never undertaken Government service, is not used to their publicly expressed resentment. This is why John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, created a sensation at a hearing yesterday before the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The vice president of The Boston Globe testified today that the newspaper had protested to President Eisenhower and other high officials the award of television Channel 5 in Boston to a competitor, The Boston Herald-Traveler.
Washington's Birthday will be observed with appropriate entertainment and decorations this evening at the twentieth annual Colonial Ball at the Plaza.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- For the first time since taking office, Governor Rockefeller said tonight that former Gov. Averell Harriman's budget policies made tax increases necessary now.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The time has come for expansion of Western European economies, including consumption, according to the annual economic review of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, issued today.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 18 -- The people of this little buffer kingdom between India and Communist China taught political leaders a lesson in responsibility today.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens announced yesterday the appointment of Frank J. Livoti as Superintendent of Highways. Daniel A. Haggerty was named Sewer Commissioner.

The city has joined with leading charitable organizations, such as those benefiting from contributions to The Times Neediest Cases Fund, to work out a program of foster homes for the aging. The idea was conceived because existing institutions cannot be expanded fast enough to accommodate all who seek a place. Waiting lists grow daily.
FORT LEE, N. J., Feb. 19 -- A lost glove cost a Lodi policeman his life in an automobile accident here last night.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 19 -- There is something new popping up in baseball.

Profits in the chemical division of Armour Co. improved substantially in the fiscal quarter ended on last Jan. 31 while earnings of the food units were slightly above those of a year earlier, William Wood Prince, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.

This is the restless season, when the cook and housekeeper traditionally decides it is about time to take the youngest member of the family to Washington. Object a little for the sake of the record, but let her go.

TANGIER, Feb. 20 -- Now that the Cyprus argument appears at last to have been settled the Allied strategic position should improve significantly. NATO's eastern flank is re-established. The Balkan Pact, linking Yugoslavia to Greece and Turkey, can be revivified.
Wall Street took yesterday's announcement of the proposed cut in commission rates almost without a murmur.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb 20 -- With Panther skiers finishing one, two in both the downhill and cross-country races, Middlebury took a substantial lead today in the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association Championships. The competition was held in sub-zero weather.
DETROIT, Feb. 20 -- The General Motors Corporation has developed an experimental car equipped with a radar device that scans the highway and warns the driver of objects in his path.

After an ownership of thirty years, Max Abramson has sold the four-story apartment house for sixty families at 27-33 Lawrence Street, Flushing, Queens. The buyer was an investing client of George Rass. The property, 116 by 167 feet, was sold for cash in a deal negotiated by Ehrlich-Corso Inc., broker.

The plane that crashed in the East River recently carried with it a young man whose abilities were just becoming known to the genera public. To say that Herbert Greenwald was a speculative builder would be an accurate, but inadequate, statement. His work in Chicago, Detroit and, more recently, in the New York area has set new standards for urban development.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 20 (UPI) -- Army officials revealed belatedly today that a Nike-Hercules guided missile went awry, crashed and exploded at White Sands Missile Range, N. M., seventy-five yards from a ranch home yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 20 -- The Greenwich Taxpayers Association today disputed the contention of the Young Democratic Club of Greenwich that the town's planning policies prevent moderate-income families from building homes.
Leading officials of the Customs Service indicated yesterday that there was no plan to increase the enforcement staff on New York's waterfront.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Secretary of State Dulles underwent the first of a series of radiation treatments today. His physicians reported that his cancer was apparently confined to the abdomen.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20 -- The Yugoslav Government expressed its opposition today to any attempt to revive the military aspects of the moribund Balkan Pact. But it said it would continue efforts to cooperate with Greece and Turkey on the political, cultural and economic levels.
Pat Hingle, who plays the title role in the Broadway hit "J. B.," was critically injured yesterday morning when he fell thirty feet down an elevator shaft.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- Bela Kovacs, a leader of the Hungarian revolt, recanted today after two years of political silence.

Recent inquiries by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Senate rackets committee have uncovered areas of the credit business where interest rates on loans begin at 24 per cent and run as high as 198 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The index of average primary market prices was unchanged at 119.4 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs have declined for the second consecutive week, the Treasury reported tonight.

TO some New Yorkers, nothing would look or taste better right now than a loaf of old-fashioned Jewish pumpernickel or rye bread. Neither of these is easily available because of a strike of some bakery locals. But the city is far from deprived of its daily portion of the staff of life as a result of the strike, which started Feb. 1.

Property at 2600 Arlington Avenue, corner of Kappock Street, in the Riverdale district of the Bronx, has been purchased by Jack Resnick, builder, for improvement with a ten-story apartment building. The property, which contains a ten-room dwelling, was held at $120,000.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 20 -- European elected members of the Legislative Council said today they were determined to prevent the "achievements of the pioneers in Kenya" from being "undermined by irresponsible people to the detriment of all races and creeds."

HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro declared today that the United States had been "interferring in Cuban affairs for more than fifty years" and that now was the time for Cuba to "solve its own problems."
LONDON, Feb. 20 (UPI) -- British surgeons succeeded in keeping a 7-year-old girl's heart beating for eleven days with an electric battery, the medical journal The Lancet said today.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Capt. Rudy LaRusso and a reserve guard, Dave Gavitt, led Dartmouth to a 73-57 basketball victory over Pennsylvania tonight.

The fourteenth voyage of the American Banner liner Atlantic is not likely to be forgotten by Capt. Aime J. Gerber, his crew, or any of the 252 passengers who were aboard when the ship docked here yesterday.

Eastern European Communist sources have reported that Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, head of state of the Soviet Union, was a member of the "anti-party group" that almost removed Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev from power in June, 1957.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The inventor of an air-conditioning system for space ships has tackled two special problems -- hot, dead air inside the cabin and no air outside.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 20 (UPI) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of United States Naval Operations, said tonight that the United States "has the ability right now, in being, to destroy the Soviet Union in several ways and several times over."
A new product has been added to the list of Russian exports to this country. It is bleached sulphite wood pulp, used in making quality writing and printing papers.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 20 -- More than 1,000 Turkish Cypriote students demonstrated today in protest against the agreement making independence for Cyprus possible.
The administration of the New York post office, which has changed hands six times since 1952, is scheduled to be put under a permanent postmaster early this summer.
A procession of 1,600 Harlem school children marched out of an old schoolhouse yesterday and into their new Public School 123, to open what is now the city's largest elementary school.

MIAMI, Feb. 20 -- The attention of small-boat skippers focuses on Biscayne Bay tomorrow, when the One-of-a-Kind regatta offers sailors a chance to settle the timeworn argument as to which class is the fastest.

With starry fields in all fifteen title events, the stirring 1959 indoor track and field campaign should reach a peak of excitement tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's seventy-first national championships.
ACAPULCO, Mexico, Feb. 20 ( AP) -- The text of a joint statement issued tonight by President Eisenhower and President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexico follows:

Starters of new businesses have been busier than ever. Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reports that a record was set in January with new business incorporations reaching 18,773, compared with 13,080 a year earlier. That exceeded the previous high of 16,458 in December, 1958.

EVERETT SHINN, one of the original members of the "Eight," the group of realists who stirred up American art before 1914, turned his talents to many art fields, notably that of illustrating. The Davis Gallery, 231 East Sixtieth Street, is now showing some water-colors and drawings that he made for Dickens' "The Mystery of Edwin Drood."
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- On the eve of their departure for Moscow, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd discussed with Queen Elizabeth today their plans for the visit.

Governor Rockefeller was booed so intensively last night that it was only with considerable difficulty, patience and good humor that he was able to give a brief welcoming speech at the National Outdoor Exposition at the Coliseum.
New York's Consumer Price Index rose to a record in January, Herbert Bienstock, acting regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, announced yesterday.

CHAMBER music is almost a dead issue in Town Hall these days. Thus it may have been curiosity as much as anything else that drew a fair-sized audience (one that included about half the string players in New York, at a rough guess) there last night to hear the Paganini Quartet.
Two new films will open over the week-end.

TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Slightly rumpled but outwardly cheerful after twenty hours in jail, Dave Beck was released today to await sentencing next Friday for the evasion of $240,000 in Federal income taxes.

OTTAWA, Feb. 20 -- A gradual shift from manned interceptors to missiles with nuclear warheads for the defense of Canada and the North American continent was indicated today by Prime Minister John Diefenbaker.
A HUMOR magazine carried a cartoon recently of a moisty-eyed wife making a hesitant confession to her husband.
Alexander L. Guterma accused the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday of "fantastic irresponsibility" in making its latest charges against him.
PARIS, Feb. 20 -- The Constitutional Council, an important new institution of the Fifth Republic, was formed today with the designation of nine of its members for nine-year terms.
A wintry northwest wind whisked city temperatures down to 8 degrees at 6 A. M. yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor and Dick Garmaker scored 20 points each tonight as the Minneapolis Lakers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 116 to 106, in a National Basketball Association game.
FULTON, N. Y., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Three 17-year-old high school girls from middle-class homes were sentenced today to six months in jail for telephoning a series of bomb threats to their school.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- Government antitrust lawyers today brought the 1956 offering of Ford Motor Company stock into their argument for a judgment requiring sale of General Motors Corporation stock by E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., Inc.

Brief glimpses of the Mayor of Chicago on television newscasts entitle his rival in next week's mayoralty primaries to equal time on camera, according to a Federal Communications Commission ruling announced here yesterday.

The National Lead Company reported yesterday consolidated net earnings for 1958 of $44,721,398, equal to $3.65 a share on 11,652,777 common shares. This compared with $56,231,506 or $4.64 each on 11,648,602 common shares then outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency removed from his job today a control tower employe on duty when a Capital Airlines passenger plane had a near mid-air collision with an Air Force C-123 earlier in the day over Kentucky.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 15 -- The tin roof of the open-sided shelter in no man's land shook one morning recently from the voices of the hundred excited Arabs gathered beneath it.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren's resignation from the American Bar Association was accepted today by the association's Board of Governors.

Directors of the Frito Company proposed a two-for-one stock split and an increase in the authorized common shares from 1,000,000 to 2,000,000. Shareholders will be asked to approve the proposal at a special meeting March 16. If the split is approved it will be effective as of the date of the meeting.
Miss Edna (Micki) Wolter, a member of an insurgent Democratic club, was acquitted in Magistrate's Court yesterday of a charge of running a dance without a cabaret license.
The lawyer for major league baseball players argued in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday for the right to advise the players in the administration of their pension plan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the New York Stock Exchange had agreed to a roll-back of some of last year's increases in commissions.
Bond trading closed the week in a bullish mood that dominated all parts of the market -- Treasury and local government bonds and corporate obligations.
DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Passenger car output of United States factories this week will total 121,859 units, the highest in a month, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

TRENTON, Feb. 20 -- The State Commissioner of Labor and Industry said today that he saw no indication of any business or industrial recovery in New Jersey. He predicted that unemployment would continue at a high level at least until 1960.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- At least six of the eighty-two new House members were disclosed today to have put their wives on their office payrolls.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) -- Five members of the House of Representatives came up with a plan today to put Jimmy Johnson Jr. of Chicago in the Congressional page boy school.
NEW DELHI. India. Feb. 20 -- Mrs. Indira Gandhi, newly elected President of the ruling Congress party, has dropped her father, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, from the Executive Committee.
GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- The Soviet Union indicated today a possible slight modification of its demand for self-enforcement of a ban on testing nuclear weapons.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20 -- Two employes of a public relations concern were accused today of fraudulently obtaining money from business interests by representing themselves as New York state police officers.
" Goldilocks," the first musical of the season, will end its four-month run at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre next Saturday night.
ROME, Feb. 20 -- A gold-capped marble obelisk inscribed "Mussolini" caused an uproar in the city's Parliament today.
The Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs Championships, opening events of the Greater New York Championships, drew 182 contract bridge pairs yesterday in play at the Statler Hilton Hotel.
SIEMIATYCZE, Poland, Feb. 20 -- The six Communist officials sat around the table near the tile stove, trying to puzzle out how it was that the fever had come to Siemiatycze in eastern Poland.

MONS, Belgium, Feb. 20 -- Small mountains of coal here and there in a green countryside and throngs of glum men in the central squares of little towns: that is the way Belgium's coal crisis looks in the Borinage district south of this city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Among the communications reaching the State Department today were a letter from the congregation of a Methodist Church in a small Mississippi town and a telegram from a man in an upper New York village.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Two old friends were enjoying a happy reconciliation today after four years of painful estrangement.

Members of the Mount Holyoke College Club of New York have chosen the March 17 performance of "Rashomon" for their annual theatre party benefit.

PAGE, Ariz., Feb. 20 -- Truck and tourist traffic began rolling today across one of the world's highest steel arch spans, the spectacular new Glen Canyon Bridge anchored to sheer rock walls 700 feet above the Colorado River.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Louisiana's fiscal officials surveyed the largest mineral bonus in state history today with cautious optimism, bracing to fight off demands to spend it in a special legislative session.
Proceeds from the world professional championship tennis matches on April 15 and 16 at the White Plains County Center will go to the Family Service of Westchester.

In preparation for what he characterized as the "supreme test" of direct negotiations with the Soviets to avert a crisis over Berlin, Prime Minister Macmillan and a retinue of expert advisers, including Foreign Secretary Lloyd, fly to Moscow today to confer with Premier Khrushchev. The trip is accorded added importance because of Secretary Dulles' illness, which in European eyes transfers a greater degree of leadership and responsibility to the Prime Minister than he had before.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Feb. 20 -- President Eisenhower and President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexico have agreed on the desirability of going ahead with construction of the projected Diablo dam on the Rio Grande. The site is about 150 miles west of San Antonio, Tex.
OMAHA, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Richard E. Robinson ruled today in favor of a Nebraska farmer who challenged the wheat allotment system of the Department of Agriture.
Creditors of Sam Goody, owner of one of the biggest and busiest record discount houses here, are pressing for early payment of debts of more than $2,400,000.

People of lower socio-economic status seem to run a greater risk of mental illness, it was reported here yesterday.
A loan of $3,000,000 for the expansion of hydroelectric power facilities in El Salvador was made in Washington yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).
MONTREAL, Feb. 20 (UPI) Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, today lost ground because of a belated correction.

Sharp declines were registered in cocoa futures yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. After sharp gains earlier in the week, cocoa prices closed 70 to 83 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 753 lots.

Metropolitan James of Melita (Malta), newly elected Archbishop of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, will arrive in the United States late next month. A service of installation will be held here in April.

Net sales of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation for the nine months ended Jan. 31 increased to $258,529,472 from $249,062,288 in the period a year earlier. Net income, however, dipped to $17,979,055, or $2.11 a share, from $18,599,090 or $2.19 a share.

SIX radio sketches based on Proustian characters, broadcast by the B. B. C. during the last ten years, form the substance of this volume, in which entertainment is adroitly combined with criticism. Each script has an introductory note, and fascinating appendices refer to textual borrowings, discuss chronological problems and give the musical themes heard on the air which are so important throughout "Remembrance of Things Past."

The March 5 performance of "Look After Lulu" has been chosen by the Theodore Roosevelt Association as its annual theatre benefit. The Noel Coward comedy based on "Occupetoi D'Amelie" by Georges Feydeau is scheduled to open at Henry Miller's Theatre on March 3.

Easter business could prove satisfactory this year, according to retailers, if the weather would cooperate. Up to now, the performance of the elements has not been conducive to thoughts of spring apparel in most parts of the country.

Last night the losingest baskeaball team in Columbia University's history bowed for the nineteenth time this season. The Lions were beaten by Brown, 66 -- 64, when John Bellavance came through with a driving lay-up twelve seconds before the final buzzer.

CUSTOMS regulations make it difficult for the traveling gardener to bring home live plants as souvenirs. The rules are meant to bar entry of potential disease or insect-carrying plants. Most seed, however, can be brought in freely.

A student in a-Brooklyn-college, charged with being a narcotic supplier, and eight other youths described as narcotic users were arraigned yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court. They were arrested Friday night in raids on two Bronx apartments.

LA PAZ, Baja California -The long, ruggedly beautiful peninsula called Baja (or Lower) California came early into Western history but has stayed pretty persistently out of it ever since. Now, after more than four and a quarter centuries of stubborn resistance to everything called progress, it has begun to undergo what might be cautiously called the beginnings of a tourist boomlet.

The New York Chamber Soloists came up with another of their enterprising programs yesterday at the late afternoon hour in Carnegie Recital Hall. Five pieces were played, and all were unfamiliar. One of them was the American premiere of Vaughn Williams' "Ten Blake Songs," for tenor and oboe.
Educators have for the most part been working on the assumption that improving the schools is a matter of doing a better job within the existing framework.

THE heads of a dozen local unions New York City met recently to talk about calling a strike. Their discussion would have been equally perplexing to such divergent analysts of the free enterprise system as Karl Marx and Horatio Alger. For the strike that these leaders of the proletariat were weighing was a strike not of union men, but of union money.

Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Under Secretary for special political affairs in the United Nations and winner of the 1950 Nobel Peace Prize, received the thirteenth annual Brotherhood Award of the Men's Club of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun yesterday.

After what was described as a "fiery" closed meeting, representatives of the evening high school teachers agreed yesterday to submit proposals made by mediators to a full meeting of the 800 teachers next Tuesday.
Back in 1897, George Francis Myers applied in Washington for a patent on a helicopter he had designed. He was turned down. The flying machine, he was told, would not fly without the aid of a balloon.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 21 -- Brazil will begin negotiations in Washington next week for new financial aid. This request poses one of the tough problems for United States Latin-American diplomacy this year.
A group of five of the world's helicopter airlines, including New York Airways, have endorsed a navigation system of the Decca type.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A direct descendant of Alexander Hamilton said today that he was offering to the United States Treasury a letter written by Hamilton a month after he became the first Secretary of the Treasury for permanent display by an arm of that department -- the Coast Guard.

Roy Wilkins charged yesterday that Southern segregationists barred progress by suppressing honest discussion of the integration problem. He said they tried to divert attention by saying to the North: "You are guilty, too."
Rita Streich, German coloratura soprano, who made her local debut in Town Hall last season, returned there Saturday night for a song recital.
Unitarians were urged yesterday not to seek "reality" by turning their backs "on all its multiple forms and manifestations and seeking only some abstract, pure truth."

I wish to call attention to a new and obnoxious censorship campaign by the United States Post Office Department. During the past few weeks I have received a number of communications from the Post Office stating that certain literature containing "foreign political propaganda" has been addressed to me and is being held under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.
Mayor Wagner appealed to Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders yesterday to get behind three measures to curb abuses by slum landlords.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Wesley Ellis Jr. shot a 4-under-par 67 in the mud today and captured the $20,000 Texas open golf tournament by two strokes. He finished with a seventy-two-hole total of 276.
The Greater New York team-of-four bridge championship was won early today by two New Yorkers, Dr. William Lipton and Frank Nichols; a Bostonian, Lawrence Weiss, and Sidney Aronson of Washington.

ROME, Feb. 22 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader who recently returned from Moscow, attacked Premier Antonio Segni's new Government today -- just two days before it was to ask Parliament for a vote of confidence.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- This residential village, long-plagued by a public service problem that confronts many suburban communities, will put a new $500,000 sewerage system into operation Tuesday.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Warren Lutz of Bucyrus, Ohio, took the all-events lead in the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a 1,947 total.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Johnny Beauchamp, 35-year-old Harlan, Iowa, driver, thrilled a crowd of more than 60,000 with a victory by inches today in the first 500-mile stock race run on the new Daytona International Speedway.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 22 -- The Netherlands Bank will again consider applications for the introduction of foreign shares on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange. There has been a ban on such introductions since early in September, 1957.

The elected province of the National Bureau of Economic Research is such, some might suppose, as to insulate that institution completely from the mortal world around it -- the world that is characterized by the constant clash of economic opinion against economic opinion, economic theory against economic theory, and (what is at times almost indistinguishable from the latter) economic mythology against economic mythology.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Democrats on the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy are considering adding at least three large nuclear power plants to the atomic power program proposed by the Administration.
The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday his agency would take up this week President Eisenhower's request to consolidate all Pacific air route matters in a new proceeding.

The very sound of the name of the Association for Relief of Respectable, Aged, Indigent Females in the City of New York bespeaks its age. This is no catchy title brought up in an advertising-conscious era. When the association came into being the 92,000 inhabitants of New York County were living in fear of a British invasion.
The High School Teachers' Association has offered a counter-proposal to the Board of Education in the dispute that has closed the city's high schools.
At least three buying doors are open to the would-be mutual fund shareowner.

Ten Cuban revolutionaries--nine wearing beards--arrived here yesterday to pay a goodwill visit on Washington's Birthday. They were wildly cheered by 1,500 persons at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Their supporters shouted slogans for freedom and liberty.
The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that stories by James A. Michener, Pulitzer Prize-winning author, would provide the basis for a new film series, "Adventures in Paradise."

MARRAKECH, Morocco, Feb. 22 -- Morocco has been important to the United States longer than any other African country. In 1789, George Washington wrote the Sultan, with whom we already had friendly relations, asking him to intervene for us with hostile warlords in Tunis and Tripoli.

In the late summer of 1957 Santha Rama Rau, her husband, Faubion Bowers, their 4-year-old son and his nurse went to the Soviet Union for a three-month visit. Mr. Bowers' serviceable command of the Russian language made them independent of interpreters and they found the people of Leningrad, Moscow and Uzbekistan easy to meet and eager to talk about their everyday life.

ANOTHER Soviet musician, Igor Besrodni, violinist, was introduced to the United States at Carnegie Hall last night. He turned out to be an accomplished performer with a fine, reliable technique and a special gift for subtlety of color.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 22 -- Gamal Abdel Nasser and Marshal Tito arrived here today for a noisy climax of Syria's part in the celebration of the anniversary of the United Arab Republic.

Regret has often been expressed over the fact that it is difficult, sometimes impossible, to get accurate news about what is really happening in Red China. There has been much speculation, for example, about what life is really like in the new experimental communes, but only a little real testimony. We welcome, therefore, a break in the bamboo curtain.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 22 -- The Western Allies are now planning their strategy in the Berlin crisis on the assumption that the Soviet Union will transfer its controls over access to Berlin whether an East-West conference is under way by the end of May or not.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Herm Nickles, a boat builder from Lake Fenton, Mich., finished third today to take over-all honors in the twelfth annual Midwinter Lightning Regatta.

L. EUGENE HENDERSON, a multimillionaire by trade and a pathetic, swaggering clown by nature, reached an imaginary point of no return when he was 55 years old and felt that he had to go to Africa. His incessant follies, his alcoholism (he was often drunk before lunch) and his mordant discontent were more than he could bear.
SALISBURY, Feb 22 -- The Parliamentary Opposition in Southern Rhodesia plans to attack the Government this week for "totally inadequate measures" to rescue the stranded animals.

Max Goberman, the wiry little conductor with the pointed beard who leads "West Side Story" with such dynamic intensity, is what some of the rough-talking youngsters in the Broadway show might call a baroque buff.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A 41-year-old Congregational minister holds down one of the least publicized but most exacting posts on the White House staff of President Eisenhower.
Two new works were performed at last night's concert by the Composers Group of New York at Carl Fischer Concert Hall.
Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in 1958 were the highest in the company's history.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Joan Hannah, a Bennington (Vt.) College sophomore who is a member of one of the East's earliest skiing families, turned in the first surprise of the North American skiing championships today.
" THE GREAT CHALLENGE" made its seasonal return to television yesterday afternoon with a discussion of the need for better communications between the scientific community and society as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The American Friends of the Middle East is trying to find jobs for Middle Eastern students returning to their homes from the United States. It hopes thus to prevent them from turning against the United States.

There's nothing like having titles at stake to stir athletes to extra efforts. The stimulus of competing for national championships produced five world indoor records, with another tied, in a notable night of thrills, surprises and upsets at the Amateur Athletic Union track and field carnival last Saturday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Scores of manufacturing plants in India, it has been reported, will turn out in 1959 from 10 to 25 per cent more products than formerly, and of greatly improved quality. The acceleration will entail no expansion of plant or of staff, and in many instances will result in lower costs.
ROME, Feb. 22 -- Reviving a tradition of the Middle Ages, Pope John XXIII walked with many other Romans in a penitential Lenten procession at dusk tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -Their ministers may bicker occasionally, but Queen Elizabeth and President Eisenhower see eye-to-eye on at least one point. They like their gangplanks to slope gradually.
The new Stanley H. Miner Memorial Pavilion of Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn was dedicated yesterday by Frederick Buckley Newell, Bishop of the New York Area.

" If only someone would lose his temper and scream!" This was the reaction of a globe-trotting English woman after several weeks in the Stockholm area. She was talking about the "apparently placid, orally polite and quite formal Swedes."
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 22 (Reuters) -- Pakistan appeared set to clinch an easy victory over the West Indies today at the end of the third day's play in the five-day cricket test match.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Legislature's Fiscal Committee has decided to take a close look at appropriation increases recommended by Governor Rockefeller.

The airy look of filigree has been appearing in room dividers, portable screens, window shutters, sliding doors, drapery cornices and indirect lighting panels. The latest use of these lacy panels is at the head of the bed.
The power of the Securities and Exchange Commission to ask for court appointment of a receiver for a corporation has been challenged as a result of the Alexander L. Guterma case.

One of the most recalcitrant pieces of legislation ever nursed through Congress will become law next week as a part of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act. As an amendment to the basic food law, it will be the first provision covering the use of such things as flavorings, sweeteners, emulsifiers, preservatives, thickeners, anticaking agents, stabilizers and a host of other chemical agents known generally as "food additives."
The steamship charter market went through another "poor" period last week as volume dropped sharply and rates were off fractionally.

Governor Rockefeller's tax program has excited vast controversy. Some Liberals, as well as some Democrats, are opposing it. In this debate I think they are mistaken. Though I supported Harriman in the last campaign, I believe Rockefeller is right in this matter, and ought to get the substance of what he has asked.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- The African members of the United Nations have agreed to ask for new elections in the French Cameroons before that territory gains its independence Jan. 1.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 22 -- Bernie Dion, a 17-year-old schoolboy, today became the first Class B competitor in history to win the annual Brattleboro invitation ski jump. The meet was first held thirty-seven years ago.
The defeat of previously unbeaten Auburn was overshadowed on Saturday night by the upset of North Carolina, the nation's No. 1 college basketball team, by Maryland, 69 -- 51.

THE mutuel windows pay off for win, place and show but the cheers are only for the winner. The Eddie Arcaros and the Willie Hartacks are led into the winner's circle, returning conquerors to the cheering Romans, and the losers trudge back to the tack room.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 -- James R. Hoffa said today that this was not the time to push for a shorter work week. He asserted that higher real income for the workers should come first.

The chairman of the City Planning Commission has pledged the full eight years of his term, if necessary, to obtaining the passage of a new zoning resolution.

A store in the arcade of the Tishman Building, 666 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-second Street, has been leased by the Barricini Candy Shops.
Officials of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union will seek an appointment with Mayor Wagner today to discuss racketeer infiltration of the New York dress industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen T. Gardner, 51 years old, former wife of Trevor Gardner, was found dead today at her home in suburban McLean, Va., the police said. Mr. Gardner is a former Assistant Secretary of the Air Force.

The Rev. Dr. John Walter Houck preached his farewell sermon yesterday at the Pilgrim Church of New York (Congregational), Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx. Dr. Houck has been pastor of the church since 1925.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Geoffrey Atkins of New York advanced to the finals of the Tuxedo gold racquets tournament and the Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis event at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club today.
An appeal to Orthodox rabbis to participate more actively among Jewish trade unionists to advance Orthodox Judaism was made yesterday by a leader of the Rabbinical Alliance of America.

GEORGE POTTER LARRICK sat quietly in the back of the room and listened intently. The speaker described some headaches Mr. Larrick was likely to develop over the new food additives law he had fought so nard for.
The New York Philharmonic continued its series of Sunday afternoons with young American pianists yesterday at Carnegie Hall with a performance of the Schumann Piano Concerto by Jacob Lateiner.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -The strongest price-making factor of the year hit the grain futures market last week and jolted several contracts into their steepest slide in months.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22 -- The Soviet Ambassador to Teheran warned today that Iran "definitely will become our enemy" if she signs a planned mutual military aid pact with the United States.

No city hospital will admit an adult narcotics addict solely for treatment of his addiction. No city or state prison provides reduction treatment for an addict to enable him to withdraw painlessly from use of the drug.

Hale and hearty again and bent on a berth in the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs, the New York Rangers accomplished two important objectives last night at Madison Square Garden: They won a game and scored in the third period.
The Air Force's Air Research and Development Command reported yesterday that its scientists had accomplished the first successful measurement of gravity from an aircraft.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, Feb. 22 (Reuters) -Policemen and soldiers stood guard today as people returned to their homes in Brazzaville's African quarters, where more than 120 persons were killed in riots last week.
The birth of the first President of the United States 227 years ago today was hailed yesterday in churches over the city.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Joy Doniger, 15, of Rye in equitation; Margot Graham of Bedford Village with her pony, Dark Satin, and Carleton Saunders, Caldwell, N. J., with Teena, were double winners at the Sunnyfield Farm Horse Show today.
The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, asserted yesterday that Jesus was "the supreme and dominant character in history."
The secretary of the New York County Republican Committee, Daniel J. Riesner; is stepping down as president of the National Republican Club at the end of his sixth term in April.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 -- The Government was urged tonight to stimulate employment and economic growth by expanding its "socially valuable activities" in education, housing, welfare and recreation.
LEAVENWORTH, Wash., Feb. 22 (AP) -- A cutlery salesman from Iron Mountain, Mich., today became the new national ski-jumping champion.
An 18-year-old Bronx girl was found brutally beaten 300 feet from her home at 6:45 A. M. yesterday nearly six hours after she had left a dance.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 22 -- The volume of incoming steel orders soared to new heights last week, backlogs took a sharp upturn and mills rushed more steel-making equipment into production to expand shipments. The latter had been somewhat behind incoming business:
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 22 -- The merged labor federation called on unions throughout the free world today to undertake a major drive to end colonialism in Africa.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Ben Heckscher, a 23-year-old Army lieutenant from Fort Meade, Md., ended the Squash Racquets reign of Henri Salaun today. Heckscher downed Salaun in a tense five-game semi-final of the national amateur squash racquets tournament.
The election of Edwin C. McDonald and Maxwell W. Mackenzie as directors of the Celanese Corporation of America was announced over the week-end.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 22 -- A white hunter and his undermanned staff pushed ahead today with a "Noah's Ark" operation designed to save thousands of wild animals from drowning or starvation.
PREAKNESS, N. J., Feb. 22 -- A troop of nineteen well-insulated Boy Scouts tramped here from Fort Nonsense today to mark George Washington's birthday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey urged today that President Eisenhower appoint a successor to John Foster Dulles, the ailing Secretary of State.

MANY Southerners consider sweet potatoes one of the most versatile vegetables and use them in many interesting and delicious ways. Raw sticks and slices are nibbled with drinks, baked or raw slices are sauteed for service with any meat and cooked mashed sweet potatoes are used in any hot bread or in casseroles, puddings and pies.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would postpone his conclusions on New York City's tax requests until the Legislature had acted on his proposed state budget.
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 10 -- A rift on human rights is developing here between the Roman Catholic Church and the thirty-year - old dictatorial regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 22 -- High police officials from New York and thirty-eight other cities are on their way here at the invitation of the Commonwealth to seek a better understanding of Puerto Ricans.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22 -- Two streetcars carrying slogans acclaiming former President Camille Chamoun, clattered into a pro-Nasser neighborhood here tonight. They were immediately attacked and burned. Minister of Interior Raymond Edde said the incident amounted to "the acts of small children."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -- Although the Presidential election is twenty months off, Brazil's most discussed political topic is who will succeed President Juscelino Kubitschek.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 22 -- A scramble for stock in Italo-Suisse, Swiss holding company that plans to build a pipeline from Genoa, Italy, to Aigle, Switzerland, where the first oil refinery in Switzerland is to be built, again was the feature of stock exchange business here last week.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 22--The gates of detention camps in Cyprus were suddenly thrown open this afternoon and all political prisoners were set free.
CAIRO, Feb. 22 -- The 400-room Nile Hilton Hotel was formally opened today and had as two of its first guests Presidents Gamal Abdel Nasser and Tito.
LONDON, Monday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Pravda marked the fortyfirst anniversary of the Soviet Army and Navy today by warning the West not to bank on any surprise atomic attack to knock out the Soviet Union.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 22 (UPI) -- The Freedoms Foundation presented its principal annual awards today to Dr. Arthur A. Schuck, chief scout executive of the Boy Scouts of America, and Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States.

The Advertising Council, a nonprofit organization, reports that commercial television network programs last year gave the messages of its public service campaigns "more than 16 billion home impressions" and that, if the support donated by the networks and by more than 550 local stations is added, the figure would be at least double that amount.
Cotton futures prices closed firm in dull trading last week. Active contracts finished the week with gains of 5 cents to 65 cents a bale.

As I see the political picture, Congress represents groups of organized people, each one of which is seeking large handouts for the benefit of the members of its own group. The result is inflated expenditures beyond the ability of the taxpayers to pay for; thus usually a deficit.
The city is more likely to become a ghost town as a result of barring traffic than as a consequence of traffic congestion, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley said yesterday.
CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 22 -Two physicians from Dartmouth College, on a short trip by private plane, were missing today and feared down in the mountains of northern New Hampshire.

A builder represented by Morris A. Pomeranz, lawyer, has contracted to buy the blockfront on the north side of Kappock Street from Netherland to Arlington Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He will erect a six-story apartment house for 100 families from plans by Leo Stillman, architect.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 22 -- After three rounds of the North Jersey open chess championship at the Independent Chess Club, three of the forty-three contenders were tied for first place today with scores of 3 -- 0 each.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The stock markets were quiet but firm last week.
A special subcommittee of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries will begin public hearings on steamship conference practices on Wednesday.
Two youths were charged with grand larceny and four with juvenile delinqency yesterday after they returned three rifles that had been stolen from a booth at the Outdoor Exhibition in the Coliseum.

Acquisition of 78 per cent of the Bennett Mining Company by the Pittsburgh Steel Company was announced over the week-end by Allison R. Maxwell Jr., president of Pittsburgh Steel. He said the company had made the move to strengthen its iron ore supply.
NEWPORT, N. H., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Arthur Allen of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, drove his team of Siberian huskies over a frozen nineteen - mile road course today to win the New England sled dog championship.
MIAMI, Feb. 22 -- Eric Olsen of Essex, Conn., held his lead today in the One-of-a-Kind regatta.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Feb. 22 -- One African was killed and at least fifty were injured today in fresh clashes with policemen and troops here and in near-by Limbe.

A FAMILY discussion on how to evacuate a home or apartment in case of a fire is likely to preserve calm and minimize casualties in the event such a disaster should occur.

No player now in the National Basketball Association was in the league when Carl Braun joined the Knickerbockers in 1947. And no player has been held in greater esteem. This was particularly demonstrated yesterday by his teammates, friends and even foes on Carl Braun Day at Madison Square Garden.

As practically everyone has become aware, the weekday luncheon no longer is just a social function. Upon leaving the office at 1, the luncheoner immediately becomes a necessary business expense, and deductible.
