PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Direct and indirect state participation in French business amounts to more than a trillion francs ($2,024,300,000).

BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- Walter Ulbricht, East German Communist chief, has made it clear that the Soviet Union and its satellites will consider signing a separate peace treaty with East Germany if the West rejects Soviet overtures.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- An influential Republican lawmaker proposed today that the Legislature attach a condition to its approval of a $500,000,000 increase in New York City's borrowing power for school construction.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 (AP) -The American Newspaper Guild said today it would present a revised pension plan to striking members of the Globe-Democrat unit tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev met in the still, white peace of the Russian countryside today to confer for eight hours on the great issues of the East-West conflict.

TOPIARY trees of either the floral or fruit variety provide a fresh, spring touch to the winter home. Although they look as complicated as a Chinese puzzle to make, a reader has submitted simple, step-by-step instructions. Her topiary stands five feet tall, took twenty-four hours to make and cost about $10.

The National Advisory Committee on Farm Labor has done a signal service by calling public attention to the plight of farm employes in the United States through its recent conference in Washington. Those who attended were given a truly moving picture of how many such employes have to live -- especially the sharecroppers and the migratory workers.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Sweden completed a two-game sweep over the United States team headed for the world hockey championships with a 5-3 victory at the Ullevi outdoor rink tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Jack Lemmon will star in a second Billy Wilder production, "The Apartment," which the director -producer is writing in collaboration with I. A. L. Diamond. Filming is scheduled to start in September in association with the Mirisch Company.

THE Workbench's "cabinetmaker furniture," well known to residents of Greenwich Village, is now readily accessible to those who live uptown. On display at the new branch, which opens today at Second Avenue and Fifty-first Street, are oil-finished walnut chests, cabinets, tables, desks, hi-fidelity units, couches and chairs, all of which are surprisingly moderate in price.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 23 -Responsible Cypriotes said tonight that the independence agreement was workable provided the Greek and Turkish communities could be persuaded to put aside their enmity.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 23 -Iran has formally protested the intensive radio propaganda campaign waged by the Soviet Union in the last ten days.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23--Britain and the Soviet Union have indicated a willingness to discuss an expansion of trade and cultural relations.
LEXINGTON, N. C., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Seven Lexington furniture manufacturing plants today announced pay rises for their 4,000 workers.

MILLBURN, N. J., Feb. 23 -The Township Committee of Millburn has passed an ordinance to control the design of new architecture and remodeling in this Essex County community. A public hearing will be held next Monday.
The State Labor Department reported yesterday that it had enforced strictly last year the Unemployment Insurance Law.
THERE already are signs of spring on vegetable stands in certain parts of town. The first green spears of asparagus have arrived.

MAX POLLIKOFF always manages to come up with something interesting on his "Music in Our Time" series at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association and last night was no exception.
ALFRED WHITNEY GRISWOLD of Yale is a man who speaks his mind. The trenchancy of his remarks is all the sharper for the width that threads them.

The A. F. L.-C. I. O. has now joined several Latin-American spokesmen in calling upon the Organization of American States to expel the Dominican Republic. It did this in a resolution passed at its conference in Puerto Rico.
A former business executive celebrated his first mass yesterday, at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East Eightyninth Street.

Archbishop Molloy of Queens, the defending titleholder, defeated Sacred Heart of Yonkers, 77 -- 55, yesterday at the Fordham University gymnasium and moved into the semi-final round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball play-offs.

The Boston Celtics, who have won five straight games at Madison Square Garden against the Knickerbockers, will try to make it six in a row tonight when they meet the Knicks in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader.
School was out yesterday, and the stores were in.
ROME, Feb. 23 -- The Cabinet met this morning and approved the program speech with which Premier Antonio Segni will open the confidence debate in Parliament tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Growers in eighteen Eastern, Midwestern and Southern States will vote in four referenda tomorrow on Federal marketing quotas on the next three crops of four types of tobacco.
Alejandro Olmedo and Richard Savitt held a gallery of 3,500 enthralled at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday in one of the memorable tennis matches of all time.

Three prominent members of the real estate field -- William Zeckendorf, Lawrence A. Wien and Harry A. Yoars -- yesterday were named winners of awards for realty transactions "contributing most to the economic development of New York City."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -The United States won the Wolfe-Noel Cup from England today for the first time since 1952. The Americans scored a 3-2 victory in the thirteenth series of the international women's squash racquets competition on the new courts of the University of Pennsylvania.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- A high school principal who paddlled ten teen-age boys said today others "ought to get it" despite parental charges that the spankings had been brutal. John C. Barnes, Bartlett High School principal, said he had administered the paddlings because the youths had tried to organize a student strike as a "direct challenge to school authority."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Senator Herman E. Talmadge protested today against what he called the increasing tendency of the Supreme Court to act on lower court decisions without hearing oral arguments on the points at issue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Representative Thor C. Tollefson of Washington said today that too many Government workers traveling by plane at taxpayer expense were taking de luxe "champagne" flights rather than economy flights. He called for a Congressional investigation.

PERHAPS only in art can opposing principles be merged. Certainly Giorgio Cavallon, whose recent paintings are on view at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue, has effected a marriage of two seemingly incompatible esthetic views.

The recent agreement of all parties involved in the Cyprus dispute for the future of the island as outlined by the Zurich conferences has elicited varied responses throughout the diplomatic world. Your editorial of Feb. 20 hailed it as "a resounding success for enlightened statesmanship."

A film on censorship and a discussion led by Ephraim London, local lawyer who successfully presented "The Miracle" motion-picture case before the United States Supreme Court, will be presented at 7:30 o'clock tonight.
What more could boxing fans ask? Of the four fights at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, three ended in technical knockout and the fourth was a classy boxing match.

Stockholders of the InterCounty Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company will vote on a proposed 20-for-1 stock split at their annual meeting March 3. There are 7,014 shares outstanding with par value of $50. The stock was quoted in the over-the-counter market last week at a bid of $278 and asked price of $285, the company states.
The Kips Bay Boys Club will gain by a bridge party and tea on March 9. It will be held under the auspices of the Thrift Shop Committee in the home of Mrs. Anthony M. Del Balso at 740 Park Avenue.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Hakuchikara, the Japanese racing champion, scored an upset victory today in the $60,400 Washington's Birthday Handicap at Santa Anita. Round Table finished last and pulled up with a leg injury.
DETROIT, Feb. 23 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr. called today for more emphasis on basic research in the nation's laboratories.
The election of Gen. Mark W. Clark, U. S. A., retired, and Robert B. Jacob as directors of the Dayton Rubber Company was announced yesterday by C. M. Christie, president.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I.. Feb. 23 -- For two years the police here have suspected that a highly skilled burglary ring, perhaps nation-wide, was responsible for the theft of more than $50,000 worth of prize antiques from wealthy homes in this area.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- Coal miners decided today to continue a week-old strike that has affected 100,000 men and paralyzed mining.

Do not judge harshly the lady whose letter from Gaylord, Va., appears in your columns on Feb. 16. She thinks in the true Virginia tradition. True to Virginia tradition, her facts are a bit awry as to the adoption of the Constitution and Virginia's paramount patriotism.
Four men and a woman were killed yesterday when an automobile in which they were riding struck an abutment at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge in Manhattan.
The American approach to world communism is "too stringent, too emotional and too uncompromising," Sirdar J. J. Singh, president of the India League of America, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- There is a special obligation on the lawyers of the United States to review judicial decisions for themselves, and for laymen in language laymen will understand. If the duty is to be done with the required courage, as well as intelligently and fairly, it must at times be critical of the judiciary, not excluding the Supreme Court of the United States.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Tents, food and clothing were speeded today to unemployed and homeless migratory workers camped near a foul-smelling creek sixty-five miles northeast of this gambling resort.

There has been no relaxation of Soviet threats against neighbors to the south. Last week it was Pakistan, which was warned that it would have to "take the consequences" if any foreign military base were established on Pakistani soil as the result of the projected defense treaty with the United States. Now the hammer has swung back to Iran, already under propaganda fire.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams told the Senate today that two large farm operators had collected more than $2,500,000 in Government farm price supports in 1957.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Countries exporting raw materials and raw foodstuffs experienced a 10 per cent decline in the average export prices of these products between mid-1957 and mid-1958. Concurrently, average prices for manufactured goods entering international trade rose about 1 per cent.

A charge that Russia was selling wood pulp in world markets as a form of strategy in economic warfare was advanced yesterday by James L. Ritchie, executive director of the United States Pulp Producers Association, Inc.
WARSAW, Feb. 23 -- The Communist party is holding widely publicized conferences throughout the country to prepare the political ground for its first national congress in four years.

PARAMUS, N. J., Feb. 23 -Newly elected members of the Board of Education here will get a dose of their own medicine soon. They are going back to school to study law, finance, the philosophy of education and community education.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -The wealth of the Jim Norris- Arthur M. Wirtz business interests today was thrown behind the promotion of boxing under the name of National Boxing Enterprises, Inc.
JAMES M. TRENARY, a New York banker who gets fun from the administrative side of sailing, invited more trouble than a man should without pay at lunch the other day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The top price for butcher hogs hit a two-year low of $16 a hundredweight today for the second time within a week. Prices were steady to 25 cents lower with the high 25 cents under Friday's peak.
Immediate action on charges of waste and mismanagement in the Board of Education was demanded yesterday by Abe Stark, President of the City Council.
The nation is sending its best calculators abroad. Big electronic computers are entering the world market through foreign trade and as products of United States manufacturers' overseas subsidiaries.

Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy warned all members of the police force yesterday that the current discussion about legalizing off-track betting was no excuse for laxity in enforcing laws against gambling.
ROME, Feb. 23 -- The Vatican indicated today it had vetoed the proposed marriage of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran and an Italian princess less than half his age.
DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP) -The auto industry this week will build the 1,000,000th vehicle of 1959 -- approximately two weeks earlier than it reached that point last year.
The Brooklyn waterfront medical center at 283 Union Street reported yesterday that 7,107 longshoremen or their families had made 19,584 visits there in its first year.

Public understanding of the significance of the liberal United States trade policy is growing, according to a study report issued yesterday by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
The Carnegie Corporation said yesterday in its annual report that schools and colleges often had to swim upstream "against the interests of a public that thinks everything else more urgent."
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 (AP) -- James P. Mitchell called today for a reappraisal of programs under which foreign laborers were brought into the country to work on farms.

Governor Rockefeller continued yesterday his lonely fight for honest budget-making for New York State. His is mostly a voice in the wilderness. The leaders of his own party are largely conspicuous for their timid silence or half-hearted acquiescence. The Democrats are busy recklessly defending "the people" against just taxation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Tommy Leonetti, a singer, received permission today to give the Senate rackets committee his version of the story that had brought his name into hearings on the underworld.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 -The nation needs 2,000,000 additional homes a year for at least twenty years, delegates to the convention of the National Council of Jewish Women were told today.
PARIS, Feb. 23 -- The danger for the new French-West German partnership that may be entailed by East-West negotiations on Germany was emphasized by French commentators today.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Republican-controlled Legislature was rapidly approaching the showdown stage tonight in the controversy over Governor Rockefeller's tax and budget proposals.
Senator Kenneth B. Keating called last night for a strong United States stand in the Berlin crisis. He said "the whole future of freedom" was at stake.

At today's opening double-header of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball play-offs at Madison Square Garden, scouts representing colleges throughout the land will scrutinize every move of a tall, graceful sharpshooter who is expected to be the glamour boy of the tournament.
TAKAHIRO SONODA, Japanese pianist, made his New York debut last night at Town Hall. The pianist, who has been educated in the European tradition, played a traditional European program.
A five-year-old organization reported yesterday that it had really been cleaning up in its short corporate history.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Westchester County officials asked Governor Rockefeller today to relieve them of the pressing financial burden of most of their outmoded parkway system.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 23 -- Four persons, including two schoolboys, were killed when a private plane crashed and burned on a fog-shrouded hilltop shortly after taking off from the Danbury Municipal Airport early today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -Secretary of State Dulles's physicians announced today that he was getting longer and more extensive radiation treatments.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Republicans decided tonight to set Sept. 15 for this year's primary elections, thereby compounding the problems of Democrats in Manhattan and Queens.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Negative votes by five Senate Republicans blocked the passage tonight of a bill to allow children over 12 years of age to work four hours harvesting berries, fruit and vegetables on nonschool days.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- New York City's Budget Director, Abraham D. Beame, was questioned for more than two hours today on Mayor Wagner's assertion that the city needs $141,000,000 in additional revenue to balance its next budget.
GENEVA, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet Union attacked today a United States plan for exempting nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes from a proposed treaty banning nuclear weapon tests.
The 15-year-old son of the former Dodger catcher Roy Campanella and seventeen other youths were seized by the police in Queens yesterday during what was said to have been a prearranged gang fight.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- Brokers on London's 200-yearold Baltic Exchange, through which arrangements are made for ship charterings and commodity purchases around the world, are watching the St. Lawrence Seaway to see what effect it will have on shipping costs.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 23 -- The merged labor federation made its first break today in its fourteen-month-old policy of avoiding direct war with the outcast International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 23 (AP) -- A Federal judge acquitted three defendants today in the trial of seven accused of conspiring to defraud the Government in the construction of the $33.000.000 Tobyhanna Signal Corps Depot, in northeastern Pennsylvania.

" MARTIN'S FOLLY," last night's offering on the "Desilu Playhouse" over Channel 2, was not a profound drama. It was, however, an appealing story calculated to enliven the urge for escape and adventure that seizes most men occasionally.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 23 -A spokesman for the West German coal industry denounced as "an impudence" today the plan of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel community to inspect Ruhr marketing practices.

Shaking off the nightmare of four years of covert warfare, terror and sudden death, the people of Cyprus have begun to celebrate their independence and the return of peace. The enthusiasm displayed in these celebrations testifies that despite continued opposition by Communists and some Greek and Turkish diehards the bulk of the people of Cyprus accept independence as the final solution for their troubled island.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 23 -The voice of a prominent young West German publisher whose news magazine has wide readership and influence was raised today in favor of negotiations with and de facto recognition of East Germany.

Nine of Fidel Castro's Cuban revolutionary warriors, in town on a three-day goodwill visit, saw their first snow yesterday. Otherwise, it was largely a dismal, frustrating day for the long-haired, heavily bearded visitors.

The New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, in cooperation with the National Socity of Interior Designers, has arranged for its sixth annual House tour program. Tours will take place on April 7 and 14.

Irving Rosenberg and Fred Zimmerman, both of New York City, early today won the masters pairs championship in contract bridge, which was the final event of the Greater New York championships. A total of 113 high-ranked pairs were entered.

HONG KONG, Feb. 23 -Cambodian Army troops have taker control in Siemreap Province of western Cambodia and deposed the Governor, Gen. Chhuon Mochulpich, on a charge of treason. The Governor fled with followers before he could be arrested.

If the evening high school teachers vote tonight to return to their posts, the Board of Education will introduce expanded night sessions to make up for the class time lost.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -When the White House Press Secretary, James C. Hagerty, was asked today about calls by Senators Stuart Symington and Hubert H. Humphrey for the resignation of Secretary of State Dulles, he replied: "It is remarkable what people will say to get their names in the news papers." MIAMI, Feb. 23 -- Troilus did what Eurasia was expected to do in the feature race at Hialeah today. Running in the silks of Bayard Sharp, he went to the front at the start, stayed there all the way and beat Eurasia by almost five lengths. Quiz Star was third, three lengths in back of Eurasia.
THE sixth-floor boutique in Lord Taylor is looking forward to spring in a big way. Spilling over with bright accessories and wispy headgear, the boutique is as fresh as the first crocus.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- The lights of Moscow make the first and most vivid impression on a visitor returning after twelve years to this sprawling, clamorous capital.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- A State Senator, two Assemblymen and the 14-year-old son of one of the Assemblymen, all from Brooklyn, were injured this afternoon in a two-car collision on the New York Thruway.

MIAMI, Feb. 23 -- Eric Olsen of Essex, Conn., retained his championship today in the oneof-a-kind regatta off the Coral Reef Yacht Club.

CHAMONIX, France, Feb. 23 -- At 27, blond, 5-foot, 6-inch Anderl Molterer is the old pro of the Austrian national ski team. Toni Sailer is in Munich making movies. Josl Rieder has given up racing and Karl Schranz, injured Wednesday in practice, has been sent home.

Activity in the machine-tool industry, which was in a sharp upturn at the end of 1958 eased off a bit in January.

Providence College's basketball team, which has won sixteen games and lost three this season, was named as the seventh team to accept a bid to the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. Ken Norton, chairman of the N. I. T. selection committee, announced the addition of Providence at the weekly luncheon of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's Restaurant yesterday.

Tommy Bracken was known at The Times as the man who never knew when it was time to quit for the night and go home. On several occasions this loyalty to his newspaper, over and above the ordinary call of duty, enabled it to publish special editions covering important news that broke near dawn. It wasn't a function of his department to summon back offduty employes to get out a paper.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Supreme Court returns from its midterm recess tomorrow with much of the term's most important work still to be done.

The tag team of Antonino Rocca and Miguel Perez won as expected last night in the second wrestling show of the season at Madison Square Garden. Their victims were Mark Lewin and Don Curtis, who gave a polished performance before taking the cue to play dead.

Guaranty Trust Company has leased three additional floors in 30 West Broadway, a fourteen-story, 300,000-squarefoot office building being built in downtown Manhattan. The banking company had previously contracted to take six full floors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- A colorful musical and a stark drama tied today for number of Academy Award nominations in the thirty-first annual "Oscar" event. The films are the musical, "Gigi," and "The Defiant Ones," which captured nine nominations each.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- James R. Hoffa assailed all pending labor reform legislation today.

A bowler can usually mention one game or series in his career that stands out for any of a number of reasons -- failure, success or pressure. Junie McMahon, who has enjoyed mostly success in his bowling career, remembers and has talked many times of his final ten frames in the American Bowling Congress Angeles in 1947. Following four frames of that game, McMahon needed eight straight strikes to win the singles and all-events titles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Paolo Rosi won a ten-round split decision over Filipino Flash Elorde in a Cow Palace bout that finished in a fast-swinging final round this afternoon. Rosi weighed 135 pounds, Elorde 132.
The Police Benevolent Association of the New York State Police announced yesterday it was returning more than $20,000 it had received from advertisers for its fifteenth - anniversary book.
The Museum of Modern Art sent an emissary to Havana last month in the midst of the Cuban Revolution to bring back a valuable painting by Joan Miro, owned by Ernest Hemingway.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 23 (AP) -- The city's two daily newspapers charged today that answers to their cash-paying crossword puzzle contests were being obtained in advance. They called in the Federal Bureau of Investigation and discontinued the contests.

TUNIS, Feb. 23 -- The Algerian provisional government is bout to begin a major diplomatic offensive in Asia and the Middle East. Premier Ferhat Abbas is to carry a plea for moral and material support to governments in the two areas.

The rising importance of the real estate specialty of renting and managing New York's skyscrapers is underscored by the leasing of space for new quarters of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., in the Bankers Trust Company building under construction at 529 Fifth Avenue.

Three stars of Gallic descent have been corralled for "Caprice.'' They are Louis Jourdan, Jean Pierre Aumont and Claude Dauphin.

Surely those of us in the teaching profession wish Dr. George N. Shuster well in his decision to retire next year. The world of letters will profit from his writings as the world of education profited from his years of service as a great leader in a field which too often has been subject to unjust and unfounded criticism.

Events today: National Orchestral Association, John Barnett, conductor; Dame Myra Hess, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Carl Seemann, pianist, Town-Hall, 8:30; Patricia Neway, soprano, assisting artists: Valarie Lamoree, soprano, and Jerold Sein, baritone, Abba Bogin, conductor, music of Ned Rorem and William Flanagan, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

The relationship of organized crime in the United States to the Mafia is set forth by Frederic Sondern Jr. in "Brotherhood of Evil," which Farrar, Straus Cudahy will issue Friday. Beginning with an account of the meeting of the "Mafia's grand council" at Apalachin, N. Y., in November, 1957, the author describes the origin of the brotherhood in Sicily and its appearance in this country during the last century.
The 33,000 students who have been affected by the recent closing of the city's evening high schools are not at all happy about their enforced vacation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- John Sutherland Productions, Inc., has been commissioned by the Council for Financial Aid to Education to produce for theatrical and television exhibition a motion picture dealing with education shortages.
IN "Five Ideas That Change the World"* Barbara Ward presents a usefully luminous survey of man's unquiet past, present and future.

January mutual fund sales reached a new high of $223,516,000, according to the National Association of Investment Companies. The total for the month compared with $152,037,000 in December and $131,605,000 a year earlier.
BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Feb. 23 -- Four children, spending their last day in a house trailer prior to moving, were killed today when a kerosene stove blew up in it.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- Military leaders marking the forty-first anniversary of the Soviet Army and Navy reported today "radical changes" in the organization of the armed forces as a result of new weapons. They announced also that the Communist party organization in the armed forces now played a greater role.

BILOXI, Miss., Feb. 23 -- Gov. LeRoy Collins declared in an interview today that President Eisenhower had failed to take positive action in the school desegregation controversy and that failure could lead to a national catastrophe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Congress was asked today to settle in Wyoming's favor the battle between that state and the Federal Government over whether yellow or white is the best color for highway markings.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals denied today a motion asking it to reconsider its refusal last week to intervene in continued segregation at Memphis State University.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Britain will retain sovereignty over two sizable military enclaves in the projected independent Republic of Cyprus. Retention of the bases was provided in a complex formula for the island's future drafted Feb. 11 in Zurich, Switzerland, bythe Premiers of Greece and Turkey.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 23--Four representatives spoke from the British delegation's place today as the United Nations began to debate the future of the British and French Cameroons.

MADRID, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A general, six colonels, three majors and two captains were tried today by court-martial for administrative irregularities in the Quartermaster Department of the Madrid Military Region. " MARDI GRAS," a brief "pop opera" with text and music by Mildred Kayden, was performed at the Cricket Theatre last night.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 23 -- The experts have been saying that Bud Werner is America's No. 1 skiing hope in next year's winter Olympics.
Mayor Wagner promised the International Ladies Garment Workers Union yesterday that he would help it root out "evil influences" in the New York dress industry.
Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman held conferences in his chambers here yesterday on streamlining the Alexander L. Guterma securities case, and then put off hearings until March 18.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- The Southern Rhodesian National Guard was called out today as troops and planes were rushed to riot-torn Nyasaland.
PARIS, Feb. 23 -- France's first attempt at launching rockets into the upper atmosphere for scientific research will begin next month in the Sahara.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a foreign seaman injured on a foreign ship while in an American port is not covered by American maritime law.

Sales and operating revenues of Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation last year were little changed from those of 1957. Earnings, however, were drastically reduced by write-offs and unusual charges incurred mainly through its large expansion program, according to the annual report.
The preview of "Destry Rides Again" on April 21 has been chosen as a spring benefit for the Travelers Aid Society of New York. The musical will open April 23 at the Imperial Theatre.
Two actors, handcuffed together last night according to the plot of "She Shall Have Music," could not be separated on cue. So the show went on -- in a theatrical display of togetherness.

In January, 1946, Maj. Gen. Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation which preceded the New York City Transit Authority, notified Mayor William O'Dwyer that the power plants that generated electricity to operate subway trains were a money-losing proposition. This infuriated Michael J. Quill, then as now leader of the Transport Workers Union, who threatened a strike.
People today find science easier to take on faith than religion, a nuclear physicist who is also an ordained deacon of the Protestant Episcopal Church said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission opposed today special legislation aimed at preventing automobile manufacturers from financing or insuring automobiles sold at retail.

A proposal for the merger of Machlett Laboratories, Inc., into the Raytheon Manufacturing Company has been approved by directors of both organizations. This was announced jointly yesterday by Charles F. Adams and W. E. Stevenson, presidents of Raytheon and Machlett, respectively.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, who was expected to become West Germany's next Chancellor, will be the ruling Christian Democratic Union's candidate for the Presidency of the Federal Republic.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Farmers voted overwhelmingly today to continue Agriculture Department marketing quotas on the next three crops of burley and Virginia sun-cured types of tobacco.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Republican members of the House of Representatives formally agreed at a "pep" meeting today to support President Eisenhower's "hold-the-line" budget policy.
The paper industry is back in high gear, a trade association executive said yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 24 -- Leaders of the Teamsters union moved today to throw unlimited funds and additional organizers into Puerto Rico to meet the challenge posed there by the merged labor federation.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 24 -- A step toward abolition of the Westchester Parkway Authority was taken today by leaders of the County Board of Supervisors. The authority has been in occasional conflict with elected officials.
In two independent programs, both centered at a laboratory in Texas, submarines are being designed for operation at depths of three and four miles.
The decision of the Republican legislative leadership to set Sept. 15 as this year's primary date stirred a storm of protest yesterday in Democratic circles.
A new system of broadcasting stereophonic effects was demonstrated yesterday by the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Sylvia Ruuska of Berkeley, Calif., ended her Australian swimming tour tonight by setting world records for the women's 400-meter and 440-yard individual medleys in Melbourne's 55-yard Olympic pool.

A block of $10,000,000 Duquesne Light Company 4 1/4 per cent thirty-year first mortgage bonds are being offered today at par to yield 4.25 per cent by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., A. C. Allyn Co. and Ladenburg Thalmann Co. and associates.

Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, announced yesterday the commissioning of a $35,000 mural by Thomas Hart Benton. The painting will adorn the exhibition room of the Niagara Power Project near Niagara Falls.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- The American Bar Association approved today a series of recommendations calling upon Congress to modify the effect of recent decisions of the United States Supreme Court dealing with communism and internal security matters.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- This village on the shore of Long Island Sound, resplendent with yacht basins, big estates and luxury apartments, has so many slums that the state Division of Housing suggested remedies today.
Another revision of the State Banking Law is pending in the Legislature. It envisions statewide branch banking for commercial banks.
Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman has asserted that the Alexander L. Guterma securities case up to now seems to be "merely conjecture, suspicion, speculation, innuendo."
ROME, Feb. 24 -- Premier Antonio Segni, presenting the new Government to Parliament, said today that Western solidarity would be the foundation of his Government's policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The House Banking Committee approved today a sharp reduction in minimum down payments for higher-priced, Government-insured houses. It also voted a bigger slum-clearance program than President Eisenhower had proposed.
The new Thomas A. Edison Vocational High School, which opened Dec. 1, is being used on a split-shift basis because its shop facilities are not ready.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 -Three deposed officers of Local B of the Operating Engineers "Union were found guilty today of stealing union funds.

New York City has borrowed $55,000,000 on short-term tax anticipation notes at 2 per cent interest, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday. The notes will come due May 11 and are callable May 1. They were sold by allotment to twenty banks and trust companies as follows:
The Board of Education reported yesterday that it was making "very considerable progress" toward integration in the public schools.

Two years ago the Federal Government decided that the popularity of champions in every field of sport and creative endeavor might properly be extended to men whose prowess, courage and good works had helped to extend the cause of human liberty around the world.
One hundred and thirty-six probationary policemen received a stern welcome into the Police Department yesterday.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev rejected today the Western proposal for a foreign ministers' conference on Germany.
The United States Maritime Administration has agreed to insure the mortgage on a 106.500-ton tanker ordered in this country by the Stavros Niarchos Group, world-wide shipping operators.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad, which has applied for authority to quit the passenger business because of its inability to avoid deficit operations on the service, experienced a net loss of $949,247 last month. This was more than 70 per cent greater than the $538,022 loss sustained in January, 1957.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Representative Steven V. Carter said today he might cut his teen-age son's salary of $11,872 a year or take him off the Government payroll.
Medical scientists fear that there will be a rise in poliomyelitis this summer because millions of Americans have not been inoculated with the Salk vaccine.

In the midst of his talks with Prime Minister Macmillan, Premier Khrushchev has taken the extraordinary step of delivering a widely publicized speech in which he has notified his visitor, outside the framework of diplomatic courtesies and mutual compliments, that Soviet Russia stands pat on all its previous positions.
ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The University of Georgia Jazz Society has cancelled the appearance of the Dave Brubeck Quartet because it has a Negro player.

CARL SEEMANN, German pianist, is winding up his first American tour with several appearances in New York. He is another in a succession of visitors who have been booked in recent years across the country before being brought into a city where the critics are supposed to be voracious.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- Funds from abroad are pouring into the Italian stock market, attracted by comparatively high yields and hopes for capital gains. Sizable amounts of American money are believed to be behind Swiss and West German investment trusts that are buying Italian stocks, sending quotations to unparalleled heights.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Supreme Court, in two major constitutional decisions today, gave the states broad power to levy taxes on business. The court held that:

ALBION, Mich., Feb. 24 (AP) -One person was killed and three others injured today in an! explosion at an oil well three miles south of Albion. The man killed was Ronald Shuman, 431 years old, of Mount Pleasant. F Mich., one of a four-man cr2wl repairing the well. I

"STYLE," said Buffon, "is the man himself." (Le style c'est l'homme meme.) The style of Alejandro Olmedo has made him the man of the moment in tennis. Chief artisan of the United States Davis Cup team's stunning victory Down Under, he captivated Australians with the magic of his racquet in defeating their Ashley Cooper and Malcolm Anderson.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 24 -- Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, expressed agreement today with A. Whitney Griswold, Yale president, who described most college athletic scholarships yesterday as "one of the greatest educational swindles ever perpetrated on American youth."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Spending by dealers in alcoholic beverages to defeat proposed changes in state liquor laws cannot be deducted as a business expense under Federal tax statutes.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers said today it would ask for a 12 per cent increase in wage rates for more than 50,000 engineers. Notices will be served Monday on major railroads.

Revolutions, like the emotions, are untidy. The struggle that the new Government of Cuba is making to put all the hopes, dreams and ideals of the revolution into effect is meeting an unexpected number of obstacles with which the leaders are grappling earnestly.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Following is the text of recommendations adopted today by the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association calling on Congress for legislation to modify decisions of the United States Supreme Court dealing with internal security and communism:

Mahmoud Kerim of Egypt began the defense of his National Professional Squash Racquets Association title yesterday at the University Club. Kerim, an instructor at the Montreal Athletic Association, won a second-round encounter from Joe Krinock of Detroit.

Consolidated net earnings of Loew's, Inc., are expected to be about 50 cents a share for the second fiscal quarter ended March 12. Joseph R. Vogel, president, reported this to stockholders at a special meeting here yesterday.
CHIC Parisians are mistresses of the art of make-up. With patience and practice, American women can now achieve the same splendid effects.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will visit Moscow next month for talks with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and other Soviet leaders.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- A legislative investigation of welfare programs in the state was proposed today in a resolution introduced by Senator Henry A. Wise, Republican of Watertown.

NEWARK, Feb. 24 -- Federal taxes of the Prudential Insurance Company under the tax bill passed by the House of Representatives last week would be almost double those paid under the present method, Carroll M. Shanks, president, said here today.

In his letter of Feb. 19 Senator Mansfield disputes The New York Times editorial which found a similarity between some of the Senator's proposals on Germany and those of Khrushchev's Berlin ultimatum. The Senator claims his speech was misunderstood by your editorial.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Carol Heiss swept into a strong lead today toward her fourth straight women's title in the opening phase of the world figure-skating championships.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Feb. 24 -- Troops fired today on mobs in the market area of Lilongwe, capital of Nyasaland's Central Province.
NEWARK, Feb. 24 -- Suburban New Jersey areas face economic disaster unless railroads provide adequate passenger service, witnesses said today before the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

The Bal des Berceaux, an annual benefit for the Refuge des Petits at Hycres, France, will take place at the St. Regis Roof on April 3. It will be under the patronage of Herve Alphand, French Ambassador to the United States. The Committee of French - American Wives, of which Mrs. John S. Sandifer Jr. is president, is sponsoring the event.

Although his production schedule includes four musicals and five plays, David Merrick is taking on another venture. He is negotiating for the stage rights to a new novel that would serve as the basis for a musical.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A major scientific "breakthrough" in the development of Polaris and other solid fuel ballistic missiles has been achieved, the Navy said yesterday.
MIAMI, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Stewards at Hialeah today said that no official action would be taken against Bill Hartack for taking a horse to the post Saturday and then refusing to ride him.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Marge Burns of Greensboro, N. C., fired a par 72 today and led the qualifiers in the South Atlantic women's amateur golf tournament.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 24 -- Premier H. C. Hansen said today that Denmark had broken off negotiations with West Germany on the building of ammunition depots in Jutland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Senators Wayne Morse and Joseph S. Clark joined Senator William Proxmire today in objecting to the amount of control that Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas exercises over the Senate's Democratic legislative machinery.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 24 -- Gen. Wang Shuming, Chief of Staff of Nationalist China's armed forces, said today that there had been no reduction in the number of troops on the Chinese offshore islands since the Taiwan Strait crisis began last fall.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- Assemblyman Bernard Haber of Brooklyn continued in a critical condition here tonight. He sustained a skull fracture and other injuries in an accident yesterday on the New York State Thruway north of Tuxedo Park.

Missiles-Jets and Automation Fund, Inc., reported yesterday gains as of Jan. 31 of 13.5 per cent in net assets and 21 per cent in share values since the mutual fund began its operations on Oct. 1, 1958.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- If it does nothing else, the visit of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has given the world uncensored views from Moscow on world problems.
The Italian tanker Punta Spiga unloaded a cargo of Iron Curtain oil here yesterday under the watchful eyes of the Coast Guard.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -- Fred Astaire is the choice of William Perlberg and George Seaton for their film version of the current Broadway comedy "The Pleasure of His Company." Negotiations have been opened with the actor.
The 15-year-old son of Roy Campanella, the former Dodger catcher, was arrested yesterday on a charge of breaking into a Queens drug store and stealing money and cigarettes.
The steel industry inched closer last week to the output record of 2,525,000 tons achieved in the week of Dec. 17, 1956.
Prices were advanced yesterday for a number of nonferrous metals. Lead, an exception, was reduced.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 24 -- (Reuters) -- Pakistan was within 61 runs of victory with all of its second innings wickets standing after the fourth day's play in the first five-day cricket test against the West Indies today.
BOB BUGNAND, a couturier with an elegant salon at 117 East Sixty-second Street and a workshop in Paris, seems to have found a magical formula for selling made-to-order clothes to American women.
Having shown signs of revival with a 5-1 victory over Montreal Sunday night, the New York Rangers will face the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The old woman's life savings have not been tripled as she hoped, but the gypsy has disappeared instead of the cash.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A Cicero, Ill., man was charged today with being a front for successors of the old Al Capone gang in a plan to flood the Midwest with cut-rate counterfeits of popular phonograph records.
THE Old Vic's television version of "Hamlet" was presented on tape last night over Channel 2, a few hours after the London troupe had left for home upon completion of its American tour.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A private utility executive told Congress today there was no urgent need to develop nuclear power.

ONE of the Irish Republic's great triumphs in the last decade has been the rocket-like rise of a Dublin dress designer. She is Sybil Connolly, a handsome Irish woman who believes that clothes should look blown against the body and who, in her own words, "can go mad over a piece of cloth."

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The fantastic speed and safety records set by the elite of the stock-car racing fraternity here on the week-end seem to prove that the new Daytona International Speedway is the world's finest automobile racing plant.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Some modification of Governor Rockefeller's income tax increase proposal was reported "probable" tonight following a conference between legislative leaders and the Governor.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Londoners may soon be watching television out of doors.
The Board of Health announced yesterday it would press for the passage of measures pending before the Legislature to allow the city to crack down on slum landlords.

HONG KONG, Feb. 24 -Those in Communist China who work primarily with their brains recently began registering at factories, scattering far and wide in the wintry countryside to fulfill another year's assignment at physical labor.
A splendid team effort sparked by Richie Guerin's 37-point output carried the New York Knickerbockers to a 134-122 victory over the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A sudden broad rally in new-crop wheat futures during the final few minutes of trading today sent those contracts well ahead and made them the leaders in a fairly general recovery movement on the Board of Trade.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Britain and Denmark have agreed on a formula for coastal fishing off the Faeroe Islands that gives preferential rights to countries that traditionally have fished in the disputed offshore waters.
THE newest "built-in" for the American home is safety.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Eisenhower told Republican Congressional leaders today that he alone would decide when to replace John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State, if at all.

MILAN, Italy, Feb. 24 -- The 1959 Monza Speedway 500-mile race, the world's fastest auto competition, was canceled today because of the new international rule limiting the power of Europe's high-speed cars.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Government sources said a band of armed Paraguayan exiles was seized by Argentine policemen at the border today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that J. Ewetts Haley, a Texas farmer, must pay a $506.11 penalty for producing more wheat than he was permitted by Federal farm law.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 24 -- Game wardens operating in boats on the Southern Rhodesian side of the flooding Kariba Lake have started to rescue marooned zebra, kudu and other large animals.

VIENNA, Feb. 24 -- Msgr. Egon Turscanyi, former secretary to Josef Cardinal Mindszenty, Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary, died recently in a Hungarian prison, where he was serving a life sentence, The Austrian Catholic Press Service reported here.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 24 -New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad commuters won a favorable decision from an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today. However, there was little to indicate that their fares would be lower.

Cocoa prices were strong here yesterday. The spot month rose as much as 1 1/4 cents a pound on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Forty-four notices were issued and were well received. The volume was 748 lots, the seventh largest of the year.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has agreed to provide $12,000,000 for the financing of large-scale, long-range expansion of Cinerama, Inc. The latter concern holds the patents for the wide-screen film system of the same name.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Justice Department could proceed against a television station transaction on antitrust grounds even though the Federal Communications Commission had approved the transaction.

What difference is there between the Fidel Castro revolution in Cuba and the one led by Mao Tse-tung in China, asked Richard M. Leeds in the Feb. 9 Times. Isn't Castro as guilty as Mao of trying to shoot his way into the United Nations? Why do we recognize the one and not the other?
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- A few days before leaving for Moscow last Saturday, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said he was in favor of a nonaggression pact with Moscow if it would help reduce tension.
Earnings of the Borden Company in 1958 rose to a record high for the third consecutive year, Harold W. Comfort, president of the nation's second largest dairy producer, reported yesterday.
Movie theatre business on last Monday's holiday and the preceding week-end ranged from good to outstanding, according to reports from the various managements.
Poor business and poor equipment are rolling along together on some railroads, it seems.
In the days of silent movies, Pasquale Cacace (pronounced ka-casey), better known as Patsy, played first violin in a pit orchestra in a Loew's theatre and was well on his way toward a musical career.

A NEW development in recipe presentation is the Cookindex. Instead of presenting formulas between the covers of a book, they are printed on 4x6-inch cards and stacked into an ivory and chrome-finished styrene file box.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A detonation of high explosives killed two employes of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Joe Erskine, a former British Empire heavyweight champion, tonight outpointed favored Willie Pastrano of Miami Beach, in a ten-round bout at Wembley Stadium.

Except for yields on short-term bills of the United States Treasury, the market for bonds and other fixed-income investments was firm yesterday, but less active than during the succession of strong trading sessions of last week.

TUNIS, Feb. 24 -- The up-and-down relations between France and Tunisia took a sudden dip today with a threat by President Habib Bourguiba in a radio address to end the instruction in French in the Tunisian schools.
IF there is one thing that can be said about the average American hunter confidently, it is that he gets lost pretty easily.

SAN JUAN, P. R. Feb. 24 -- A compromise in the feud between George Meany and Walter P. Reuther resulted today in the calling of a "mass conference" in Washington to dramatize the plight of the country's 4,700,000 unemployed workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that civilian employes of the armed forces at overseas bases may not be court-martialed for non-capital crimes in peace time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The White House announced today the selection of four top United States artists to select examples of distinguished American art for this country's national exhibition in Moscow next summer.

Stephen A. Mitchell, former national chairman of the Democratic party, takes a look at the neighborhood political club movement in his book "Elm Street Politics." He points to the club, in its modern form, as the key to the survival of the two-party system through "watering the grass roots of American democracy."
BILOXI, Miss., Feb. 24 -- Gov. LeRoy Collins today abandoned his efforts to arrange a conference of White House representatives, Congressional leaders and Governors on school desegregation.
MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 24--A suit to test the constitutionality of morning prayer in the public schools started in State Supreme Court here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- India and Ceylon asked today for assurances that the French Cameroons, which is to become independent Jan. 1, will have completely independent status.

IN Its second concert of the season, last night in Carnegie Hall, the National Orchestral Association presented a Brahms symphony, a first New York parformance of a work by Aurelio de la Vega and wound up with the Schumann Piano Concerto played by Dame Myra Hess.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Democrats outvoted Republicans by a large margin in Chicago's primary election today, but they missed the big vote they had aimed for.

The American Tobacco Company increased its earnings to a new record in 1958 for the fourth successive year, Paul M. Hahn, president, reported yesterday. However, profit for the fourth quarter was below the 1957 level.

LEVITTOWN, Pa., Feb. 24 -- The Rev. Dr. Fred Manthey Jr., pastor of the Plymouth Congregational Church here, charged today that he was being forced to resign because of his efforts toward racial integration in his church.
Benton Bowles, Inc., and the Eversharp Pen Company have terminated their one-year relationship. No reason was given for the break, which is effective immediately.
MIAMI, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Easy Spur became a probable starter in Saturday's $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah by scoring an impressive victory in the feature race today.

Twenty-five more employes of the Department of Buildings declined yesterday to fill out financial questionnaires as ordered by a Kings County grand jury investigating graft and corruption in the department's Brooklyn office.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 24 -- The strike by 100,000 miners in three of Belgium's four coal basins was settled today. The Socialist trade unions accepted a mine owners' guarantee of a Government plan for resettling workers of uneconomic mines that will be closed in the second half of 1959.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Navy said today it would scrap forty-three aged warships, including five battleships, that have been out of use for eleven years or more.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- The Ministry of the Armed Forces cautioned the French and foreign press today against "premature or erroneous" stories on "military problems and, in particular, the operations in Algeria."

A building containing eighty-three apartments at 7022 Ridge Boulevard in the Bay Ridge district of Brooklyn has been sold by the 7022 Boulevard Company to investing clients of Jacob Schultz, attorney. The sale was negotiated by Aaron Poret, broker, in association with Murray Poret, for a price reported to have exceeded $500,000. Edward Segal was the attorney for the seller.

MOGADOR, Morocco, Feb. 24 -- Present-day Morocco is a strange contrast between superstition and science fiction. In a sense the clash between these antipodal forces affects our relations with this newly independent kingdom where vestiges of a long colonial heritage are everywhere to be seen.
Evening high school teachers, who resigned their jobs on Feb. 2 in a wage dispute, voted last night to go back to work.
Eight of Fidel Castro's Cuban revolutionary soldiers, heavily bewhiskered in their olive-drab uniforms, completed their three-day tour of New York city yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 24 -- The merged labor federation handled today for direct union representation on the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Board and of each of the twelve regional Federal Reserve banks.
Four alleged members of a Brooklyn gang were held without bail yesterday in the street slaying of a 17-year-old rival gang member. A hearing on a charge of homicide will be held tomorrow.

Good news from the steel industry gave the stock market an excellent start yesterday and it shot up to new highs in the first hour or so. Thereafter it thrashed about without much sense of direction and surrendered most of its gains.

MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- The British delegation, from Prime Minister Harold Macmillan to the lowliest stenographer, was surprised and stunned tonight by the timing, tone and content of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's speech earlier in the day.
The cotton futures closed 3 to 22 points (1 to $1.10 a bale) higher, with old March leading the advance.

Your recent editorial congratulating the druggists on their latest attempt to legalize their monopoly on the retail sale of home remedies comes as a surprise to a close observer of proprietary medicines legislation.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 24 -- The order exiling Archbishop Makarios from Cyprus was officially rescinded today.

The State Thruway Authority has obtained at least another year's extension of its $76,083,000 loan from the state. Albany also has become reconciled to waiting many years for fifteen other public authorities, set up to be self-supporting, to pay back advances that total $30,000,000.
WASHINGTON Feb. 24 -- Senator Estes Kefauver and the Justice Department fought an opening skirmish today over Senate confirmation of Lewis L. Strauss as Secretary of Commerce.
MUSIC for the voice by Ned Rorem and William Flanagan was performed before a capacity audience at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the New York Life Insurance Company, 51 Madison Avenue, and the Consolidated Edison Company, 380 Pearl Street, Brooklyn.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 24 -- Two more men have been arrested on charges of posing as state troopers to solicit funds for a police group.
The Rockefeller Foundation has announced a grant of $45,000 to help revive the 1,200-year-old Korean theatre, which was virtually snuffed out during the Korean conflict.
HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- Many school teachers, considered purely political appointees, were ordered dismissed by President Manuel Urrutia Lleo and the cabinet today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The president of the National Academy of Sciences testified today that his intimate association with the International Geophysical Year had convinced him that intensive international medical research would further world peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Counsel for Col. Rudolf I. Abel, master Soviet spy, contended before the Supreme Court today that illegal procedures had been followed in arresting him and searching his lodgings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court said today it would hear argument next fall in the dispute between the Federal Government and the five gulf states over ownership of submerged oil lands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United States called on the Soviet Union today to make a "reasoned reply" to the West's proposal for a Big Four foreign ministers' conference to settle the Berlin and German problems.
New York City's Civil Defense air-raid warning sirens were tested yesterday morning. Fourteen of the sirens failed to function, compared with nine in the last test, on Jan. 22.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 24 -- The Communist party, a strong advocate of the 1957 version of President Sukarno's guided democracy, was pictured today as not at all happy now that Indonesia was taking steps to introduce that form of government.
Election of Hubbard S. Caven and A. Nelson Myers as vice presidents of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, was announced yesterday by Fred M. Nelson, chairman.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Fairly soon Casey Stengel will indulge in his favorite spring pastime -- shuffling his players from one job to another.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 24 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi assured members of his Parliament today that Iran "definitely" would sign a defense agreement with the United States despite Soviet threats of retaliation.

Maurice Epstein has added the five-story building containing eight apartments and two stores at 203 East Sixty second Street to a plot he is assembling around the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Sixty-second Street.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 24 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and President Tito put off their scheduled departure for Cairo today ostensibly because a snowstorm had closed the Damascus airport

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A Baton Rouge couple has appealed to President Eisenhower to go behind the Iron Curtain to find out what happened to the crew of a United States plane shot down over Soviet Armenia.
PLOVDIV, Bulgaria, Feb. 23 -- Bulgaria's peasants were transformed into a proletariat this month with the introduction of a daily wage system on all collective farms.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Round Table today was declared out of Saturday's $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap because of a deep leg cut suffered in yesterday's Washington's Birthday Handicap.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller appointed Ronald B. Peterson of Schenectady today as Acting Commissioner of Commerce at $18,500 a year. Mr. Peterson, a career employe, has been with the Department of Commerce since 1940.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 24 -- (Reuters) -- A Communist campaign has brought more land under collective farming than before the retreats of 1952 and 1956.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- An air pollution control program covering the metropolitan New York and New Jersey areas moved halfway through the Legislature today.
DUBNA, U.S.S.R., Feb. 24 -- The Soviet Government did its best here today to impress Harold Macmillan with the achievements of its Joint Institute for Nuclear Research.
