The opening game of the fifty-sixth annual Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs yesterday provided an upset. Before a crowd of 10,000, Manual defeated Wingate by 67 -- 53 at Madison Square Garden.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Substantial agreement on a new omnibus banking bill was reported reached at a series of conferences here today.

The proposal, advanced by Assistant Secretary of Labor Newell Brown, that employes of non-profit agencies be brought under the Federal Unemployment Insurance Act will have repercussions far beyond its immediate objective. But it is high time the issue involved was faced -- not only by the Federal but by the state governments as well, and by those whom it affects.

The legal tide turned noticeably yesterday for American owners of foreign flag ships. In addition to a favorable Supreme Court decision in Washington, the "flag of convenience" operators won a major victory in the District Federal Court.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Fourth and fifth were added today to first and second as places in dispute at the wind-up of the 500-mile Daytona Beach international sweepstakes Sunday.
Tennessee Gas Transmission Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in 1958 operating revenues, net income and gas deliveries.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 24 -- Members of the Junior League of Stamford will act as models in "Fashion in Motion," a show that will be held at the Stamford Yacht Club on March 11.
The stage was set yesterday for a duel of words in Albany between Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa over the proposed $500,000,000 school construction bond issue.
A Federal grand jury will be summoned to investigate charges of juke box racketeering in New York City, an association of the music machine operators was advised here last night.
PARAMUS, N. J., Feb. 24 -- The chairman of the Middlesex County Board of Freeholders said today that he was glad Bergen County communities were moving ahead in the direction of regional thinking.
HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 24 -- Communism in Finland suffered a setback during the recent crisis in Soviet-Finnish relations.

FORT MYER, Va., Feb. 25 -- The Army revived a tradition today and held a sparkling horse-mounted review for a retiring cavalryman. It was more than twenty years since a similar performance was seen at this historic post across the Potomac River from Washington

TORONTO, Feb. 25 (UPI) -The Toronto Maple Leafs spotted the Montreal Canadiens two goals and then roared back to register a 3-2 victory to-] night to lift them into a tie forI fifth place with Detroit in the National Hockey League.

MICHIGAN, CITY, Ind., Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Indiana mother and wife of a missing airman have asked President Eisenhower to go to the Soviet Union personally to determine what happened to a United States plane that went down over Soviet Armenia Sept. 2.
Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., announced yesterday that it would close its store on the southwest corner of Thirty-sixth Street, which it has operated for nearly thirty-five years.

Washington, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Profits ranging as high as 38 per cent on airplane landing gear sold to the Air Force, resulted from failure to evaluate the reasonableness of profits, the General Accounting Office said today.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 25 -- A prompt appeal to test the authority of the court - appointed monitors of the Teamsters Union was agreed upon today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 25 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek intends to make a personal show of joint support with Dr. Arturo Frondizi, President of Argentina, for Latin-American economic development when representatives of twenty-one American chiefs of states meet in Buenos Aires.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Coal producers, the United Mine Workers, coal-carrying railroads and a number of related companies announced the formation of a united front today to advance and promote coal industry interests "on the broadest possible front."

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 7 points (5 to 35 cents a bale) yesterday, excepting the October option, which rose 1 point. The market fluctuated in a narrow range all day.
Jack Benny's television show may move to a new day and have a new sponsor next fall.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association continued its efforts yesterday to compel Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to set up impartial grievance procedures for the Police Department.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Frederick V. Follmer directed the acquital today of a fourth defendant in the Tobyhanna, Pa., Signal Corps depot conspiracy case. He refused, however, to free Representative William J. Green Jr., Democrat of Pennsylvania, and two others by bench orders.

In the closing session of their mid-winter meeting, at San Juan, P. R., delegates of the merged labor federation approved a proposal that would provide for union representation on the Federal Reserve Board and in the management of the twelve regional Federal Reserve Banks. The executive council of the combined labor groups charged that domination of the Reserve System by bankers and corporation directors had resulted in "misguided anti-inflation measures."
The Navy Ship's Store Office, nerve center of a world-wide chain of 175 exchange stores, turned over its entire accounting functions yesterday to an electronic processing system.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois joined other liberal Democrats today in calling for a broader representation of views in party councils.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Another general price advance in grain futures put $2 wheat back on the Board of Trade today.

A young woman, who assertedly sought to underwrite her trousseau for a September wedding with a threatening note to a bank teller, was arrested yesterday. The police in Brooklyn said she lost her nerve and fled after being stared down by her intended victim.

Can a business concern use the name Rockefeller when there is no Rockefeller in it? This question arose in Supreme Court yesterday when Rockefeller Williams Co., Inc., a brokerage concern at 149 Broadway, was ordered to show why it should not be enjoined from using the name Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has offered to meet Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq to straighten out differences between the two countries, diplomatic sources reported today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan warned Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today that the Soviet Union would bear the onus for important decisions the West must now take as a result of Soviet intransigence over Germany, British diplomats said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Following, as made available here today, are excerpts from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's speech, made to a group of his constituents in Moscow yesterday, in which he rejected Western proposals for a foreign ministers' conference on Germany:

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday upheld the validity of financial questionnaires given to employes of the Department of Buildings in a grand jury inquiry into charges of bribery and extortion.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- A change of name for Scott Radio Laboratories, Inc., to Electrovision Corporation and its planned expansion into the field of motion-picture exhibition were announced today with the election of Edwin F. Zabel as president and Robert L. Lippert Sr. as secretary-treasurer.

The Hercules Powder Company declared yesterday a 25-cent dividend on the common stock, payable March 25. Last year shareholders received 20 cents each in March, June and September and a year-end dividend of 50 cents in December.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- Pakistan today completed a resounding ten-wicket victory over the touring West Indies cricket team in their first test match.
Chicago borrowed $40,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance sewerage, airport, street lighting and other public improvements.
Retaining the fire they showed in whipping Montreal Sunday night, the New York Rangers spotted the Detroit Red Wings two goals and then proceeded to a 6-3 victory at Madison Square Garden last night.

VIENNA, Feb. 25 -- The Rumanian Government accused Israel and "imperialist circles" today of using the migration of Rumanian Jews to Israel to create bad blood between the Eastern bloc and the United Arab Republic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -The Government was accused today of using procedures like those of the Soviet police in obtaining evidence against Col. Rudolf I. Abel, the Russian who was convicted of espionage and sentenced to thirty years' imprisonment.

Pausing after four successive days of higher prices, the stock market yesterday staged an orderly retreat devoted largely to profit taking. Only the electronics and rubber issues moved upward with unanimity.
WITHIN the next few weeks, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to render an important decision regarding one of America's favorite flavors, vanilla.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- This city's latest attempt to solve a high school shortage problem was called an "educational tragedy" today by teachers and an "impractical plan" by a team of New York university experts.
ALTHOUGH "Say, Darling" retired from Broadway as recently as Jan. 17, it reappeared last evening at the City Center as one of the municipal classics.
HENDERSON, N. C., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Rocks and soda bottles were thrown today at cars carrying workers from this city's Henderson and Harriett Cotton Mills.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Consolidated Edison Company disclosed today that completion of its nuclear power plant at Indian Point, N. Y., would be delayed nearly a year by unexpected technical problems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Senate public hearings on admittance of the Territory of Hawaii as a state began and were completed today.
TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- A package of bills designed to circumvent a State Supreme Court ruling on assessments appeared tonight to be heading for drastic amendment before adoption.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 25 (UPI) -- The police continued to guard the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Rayfield in suburban Collins Park today after 300 persons demonstrated following the Negro family's arrival in this previously all-white community.
Production staffs for three operas to be performed by the New York City Opera Company during its spring season opening March 30 were announced yesterday by Julius Rudel, general director.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller and the State Tax Commissioner quickly discouraged today all suggestions that new business taxes could reduce the need for personal income tax increases.

While the Association of American Railroads has been gearing up its public relations division for a full-scale attack this summer and fall on ancient labor rules, the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway has been busy working out arrangements with labor that normally the brother-hoods would protest strenuously.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 18 -- Pakistan has embarked upon a radical program of economic rehabilitation charted by the men behind West Germany's remarkable post-war recovery.
Committee members have been announced for the Champagne Ball, to be given by the Junior Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary in the Terrace Room of the Roosevelt on March 20.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren and his Supreme Court colleagues were attacked and defended on the floor of the Assembly today during consideration of a loyalty oath issue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, announced from the White House today a forty-four-member committee to draft a long-range statement of party policy and objectives.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP) -- A Titan intercontinental ballistic missile made a highly successful test flight today, informed sources said.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Coach Don Kennedy of St. Peter's college insisted today that he did not pull his team off the court in last night's basketball game against Delaware State College and that the referees acted "hastily" in forfeiting the contest.

What more experienced Broadway managements have failed to do, the new producing team of Christopher B. Manos and Arnold Margolin has accomplished. It became known yesterday that they have signed Anton Walbrook to make his American stage debut as the star of "Masterpiece.

The New York Philharmonic, which this season advanced the starting time of its Thursday evening concerts from 8:45 to 8:30, is thinking of starting all of its evening concerts at 8 o'clock next season.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The White Motor Company announced today it would split its common stock. It said it would distribute to shareholders of record March 10 one additional share of common stock ofr each one held and increase the cash dividend to 87 1/2 cents.
BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- The Soviet Union is planning to conclude a peace treaty with East Germany within the next three months, informed sources in East Berlin said today.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- The United States asked the Soviet Union today whether yesterday's speech by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev heralded the collapse of negotiations for a controlled ban on nuclear weapon tests.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 -- India's Communist party has extended qualified support to the ruling Congress party's drastic land-reform program.
A Hollywood cosmetics company is negotiating to take over the Mutual Broadcasting System, which until two weeks ago was a major part of Alexander L. Guterma's financial empire.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Henry W. Harding, president of Laboratory for Electronics, Inc., of Boston, announced today that the company was considering a merger with Servomechanisms, Inc., of Los Angeles.
Another male stronghold in the world of big business has fallen.
NEWARK, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson predicted tonight that Government controls on wheat and "possibly" other major commodities would end this year.

Events tonight: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic, Pierre Monteux conducting, Rudolf Serkin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Mattiwilda Dobbs, soprano, chamber orchestra conducted by Carl Bamberger, Town Hall, 8:30.

"ELIZABETH THE GREAT,"* by Elizabeth Jenkins, is an unsparing yet admiring biography of the Virgin Queen. The primary aim of the book, Miss Jenkins tells us, "was to collect interesting personal information" about the monarch -and that aim has been achieved to an extraordinary degree.
A 9-year-old boy accidentally shot and killed himself yesterday afternoon while playing with a .22-caliber hunting rifle that his 15-year-old cousin had received from his parents as a Christmas gift.

ATHENS, Feb. 25 -- The Chamber of Deputies was in a turmoil tonight after Government supporters had heard the leader of the Opposition, Sophocles Venizelos, describe the London agreement on the Cyprus issue as "bloodless and cowardly."
Humans, with and without cameras, were outwitted yesterday by six spider monkeys at the Bronx Zoo.

Mayor Wagner has done well to pledge his help to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union in rooting out "evil influences" in the New York dress industry -- evidence of which, the union claims, was the beating of one of its officials by three unidentified thugs in Tenafly, N. J., last Friday night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Early action on bills to offset a number of controversial Supreme Court decisions is being sought in the House of Representatives with apparently good prospects of success.
Shipments of kraft paper, a key grade, are expected to approach a record high this year, an economist predicted yesterday.

Cross currents appeared in the bond market yesterday, carrying local government and long-term Treasury obligations to higher prices at the same time that high grade corporate bonds sold off by 1/4 to 1/2 a point.

The untiring traveler, who has savored the moods of many forms of transport, searches the mind for the right word to describe his first flight in the new Boeing 707 jetliner. But extravagance and misuse have dulled the edge of words that once were sharp with the arrow's truth.
In a letter published Feb. 18 H. U. S. Nesbit opposes one-way avenues and blames private cars for the traffic jams on Fifth, Madison, Lexington and Third Avenues.

A judgment of $179,732 was filed in the New York County Clerk's office yesterday against George A. Brenner, former Westchester surrogate. It is in favor of Arnold H. Kagan, president of the Republic Security Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The House Banking Committee approved today a three-year omnibus housing bill carrying $1,125,000,000 more than the amount asked by President Eisenhower. The vote was 19 -- 7.
The Board of Estimate will decide on March 11 whether to accept or reject an offer by the Consolidated Edison Company to buy the city's subway power plants.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Congress was told today that most high school science courses were "out of date" and that about half the science teachers were "not really qualified."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A drug manufacturer warned today against quick full-scale medical cooperation with the Soviet Union. He urged that under-developed countries get top priority in international medical research as a curb on what he called Soviet efforts at world domination.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- In a talk to a visiting group of Latin-American lawyers, Governor Rockefeller endorsed today the proposal for a Western Hemisphere "common market."

The work of The Speedwell Society, 1078 Madison Avenue, will be furthered as a result of a theatre party at the April 2 performance of "First Impressions.'' The musical, based on Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice," stars Hermione Gingold, Farley Granger, Polly Bergen and Hiram Sherman. It is scheduled to open at the Alvin Theatre on March 19.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission refused today to reconsider its opinion that a license it had issued for a Niagara Falls, N. Y., power plant would interfere with the Tuscarora Indian reservation.
The Dean of Columbia University's School of General Studies called for increased financial aid to part-time college students yesterday.
Criticism of a school building because it is attractively designed and well equipped can only do harm to the public school system, the Citizens Union declared yesterday.
The Governor's recent rent-control message to the Legislature was something of a disappointment.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- "At long last I am able to say a few words of my own. * * * I have found it impossible to carry the heavy burden of responsibility and to discharge my duties as King, as I would wish to do, without the help and support of the woman I love."

Some confident and even flashy violin playing was presented last night at the Metropolitan Museum by Charles Treger. Accompanied by Harry McClure, the young violinist played Tartini's "Didone Abandonato" Sonata, the Bach Chaconne, Mozart's B flat Sonata (K. 454), Schoenberg's Fantasy, Op. 47, and the Bartok-Szigeti Five Hungarian Folktunes. In addition there was the first performance of Kurt George Rogers' Sonata.

Protests are being made in Manila against the plan to spend $7,500,000 to erect an elaborate Corregidor-Bataan Memorial in honor of the Filipinos and Americans who died there together. It has been suggested that the actual memorial be much more modest and that part of the funds be used for permanent projects in the public interest.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A bill to permit the Conservation Commissioner to fix a special open season on wild deer, in addition to the regular season in areas where there are too many deer, drew heavy support today.
ROME, Feb. 25 -- Relations between Italy and Austria became noticeably strained today when Dr. Max Loewenthal-Chlumecky, Austrian Ambassador to Italy, left for Vienna by plane.
David Campanella, 15-year-old son of the former Dodger catcher, was released yesterday in $3,500 bail on charges of breaking into a Queens drugstore and stealing money and cigarettes.

An action challenging the constitutionality of a law governing the qualifications and activities of psychologists was filed in State Supreme Court here yesterday against the University of the State of New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

Grave disturbances in the British protectorate of Nyasaland have now followed the serious riots in the Belgian Congo and French Congo. There seems to be no direct connection between these troubles except the general atmosphere of ferment that is affecting the whole of central Africa.

NEW YORK can be a hospitable city except in one instance. The woman looking for a place to shower and rest for a few hours can rarely be accommodated. Suburbanites who spend the day shopping and plan to go out in the evening often long for a place where they can bathe and snooze.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Democrats won a crushing victory in yesterday's primary and tightened their command of city hall.

A MAN, not a silhouette, made the biggest news at the spring fashion collections in Paris. He is Jules Francois Crahay, 41-year-old Belgian-born designer for the house of Nina Ricci, and his collection won most of the applause and the bravos.
DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- Officials of six Great Lakes states and cities mobilized here today for a major battle against further diversion of Lake Michigan water by Chicago.

Robert W. Kerr is resigning as a vice president of American Machine Foundry Company to take charge of all manufacturing operations of Penn-Texas Corporation and an affiliate, Fairbanks, Morse Co., Inc., Penn-Texas announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Paul Arizin set the tempo as the Philadelphia Warriors defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 134 -- 123, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

An American edition of "T. E. Lawrence," a biographical study by Jean Beraud Villars, will be published March 16 by Duell, Sloan Pearce. The adventurer-soldier-writer, better known as Lawrence of Arabia, was the center of controversy and speculation in death as well as in life.

Members of the newly formed Manhattan Borough Committee of the New oYrk City Youth Board had an orientation meeting yesterday with the Commissioner of Youth Services, Ralph W. Whelan. They met in the Board's central office, 79 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Scott W. Lucas, former Senate Democratic leader, today urged that Congress force General Motors to divorce or liquidate its sales finance subsidiary, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

On several occasions the Russian rulers have hinted that they might consider the withdrawal of their forces from Continental Europe, but only on condition that the Western powers would do likewise and that the United States would relinquish its military bases on foreign territory.
The Board of Health proposed new rules yesterday that it said might open eight or ten new areas of supply, increase competition among dealers and cut milk costs to the city's consumers.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 -- Some of the biggest names in Nepalese politics are toppling in the Himalayan kingdom's first free election, news reports from Katmandu said today.
NEWARK, Feb. 25 -- The Atom Age has raised the issue of what is fair workmen's compensation for exposure to radiation .
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 -- The best news out of India today is that her leaders are finally aware of the menace of Communist China.

Several world and domestic sugar positions and zinc contracts fell to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume improved in most commodity futures markets with copper registering the fourth largest number of trades this year and zinc the best volume since Nov. 4.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 25 (AP) -- About 70,000 Mexican railway workers struck at noon today, paralyzing most of the Government's 14,000-mile rail system. But the management got some main trains running tonight.
The board of the Daitch Crystal Dairies, Inc. proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the stock, according to Herbert B. Daitch, board chairman of the food chain.
The Jamaica Government's $12,500,000 offering of bonds, its first payable in United States dollars, will reach the market today.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A group of citizens from various parts of the nation, feeling that obscene literature is endangering the morality of America's youth, has started a program to do something about it.
The city's evening academic high schools will reopen Monday after having been closed throughout the month by a teacher walkout.

ABOUT halfway through the first act of "The Golem," the green-skinned clay monster shuffled onto the open platform stage of the little St. Marks Playhouse and fixed his red eyes, with concentrated loathing, on a critic who happened to be in his line of view. The effect was chilling.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- One person was killed and fourteen, including four policemen and the district commissioner, were wounded in political rioting here today.
FASHION is on the move. After May 4, the Fashion Institute of Technology will be situated at 227 West Twenty-seventh Street. It is now at 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Feb. 25 -- Two men, a father and son, were killed early this morning and two others were critically injured when their car crashed into the rear of a tractor trailer truck at an intersection here.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- England's team of Mrs. Frances Marshall and Mrs. Dorothy Cooper reached the quarter-final round of the United States squash racquets doubles championship today. They defeated Diana Herman, another British player, and Mrs. John Bottger of Cynwyd, Pa., 15 -- 10, 15 -- 10, 16 -- 13, at Philadelphia Cricket Club.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 25 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard went off on a short winter vacation last week as arbiter of the West German economy, Vice Chancellor and second only to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer as the most powerful man in West Germany.
Once upon a time, about a half century ago, a stout-timbered ship of archaic design sailed up the Hudson River.
Thomas K. Finletter warned last night that setting a Sept. 15 primary date could "do injury to the healthy functioning of our two-party system, keystone of democracy in this country."

Mrs. Anthony B. Akers of 920 Fifth Avenue was hostess at a tea yesterday for the women interested in the success of the sixth annual May Festival Ball, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf on May 11.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Government lawyers in the antitrust case against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., made clear today that the Government was ready to modify its proposed decree to cut the link between du Pont and the General Motors Corporation.
HONG KONG, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists' establishment of people's communes has led to a drastic drop in remittances from overseas Chinese.

A dog show held every working day last week in the Manhattan Savings Bank on Madison Avenue could not have drawn much bigger crowds if the bank had been giving away money. Lunch-hour spectators sat and stood in the entrance lounge around a genuine dog show ring or paused to peer through the big windows.

Three sisters have given Barnard College $50,000 for a new language laboratory, Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, the president, announced last night. This becomes part of the $8,545,000 to be raised for the college's seventy - fifth anniversary in 1964.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 25 --- Three officials of a Newark bakery union local were called before the Hudson County grand jury today in an attempt to trace tax-exempt contributions by the C. F. Mueller Company to the union's welfare fund. The company makes macaroni and egg noodles.

TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- Superior Court Judge Frank J. Kingfield ruled valid today a referendum permitting the issuance by the state of $45,850,000 in bonds to finance new res-reservoirs. The proposal was approved by the voters last November.

MONTREAL, Feb. 25 (Canadian Press) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization adopted over British protest today an American-developed system as a navigation aid standard for the world's airlines until 1975.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- The National Council of Jewish Women went on record today as objecting to efforts to balance the budget at all costs. They said such an attempt was "a threat to the objectives of the United States."
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The Labor party Opposition denounced the Government's defense program today as ineffective, inconsistent and committed to a questionable policy of nuclear deterrence.
ROME, Feb. 25 -- The prospect that Frank Costello may be deported to his native Italy brought an angry protest today from a Right-Wing newspaper here.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 -- There is a strong possibility that within the year the Yankees will been seen in action in California, and their appearance is not wholly contingent upon their meeting either the Giants or the Dodgers in next October's world series.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 25 -- The newest member of the Ski Hall of Fame at Ishpeming, Mich., is Charley Proctor. He was named last Monday night at a dinner in near-by Crystal Bay, Nev., following the North American Alpine championships here.

Florida Power Corporation has reported new highs for virtually all phases of its 1958 operations. Sales of electricity rose by 5.7 per cent to 2,330,000,000 kilowatt hours, largely on increased residential and commercial sales.
A speeding sedan carrying six youths crashed through a barrier on an open drawbridge in Queens last night and plunged into a deep canal. Four of the boys got to shore safely but two were missing.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Leaders of the Air Force, science and industry announced today the development of a mechanical-brain language.

SPORTS figures down through the years have made highly individualistic contributions to the English language. None of these semantic embellishments will become Hall of Famers in the Dictionary League. Nonetheless, they have won acceptance through original pungency and continued usage.
CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Penny Pitou, a 20-year-old Gilford (N. H.) ski star, returned home today after a year of skiing in Europe.
A young policeman admitted yesterday that he took part in the fatal beating of a 60-yearold woman last Monday in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- John Foster Dulles' ability to continue discharging his full responsibilities as Secretary of State cannot be determined until the conclusion of his present course of radiation therapy, President Eisenhower said today.

SAN JUAN, P. R. Feb. 25 -The merged labor federation reported today that its unions had organized 1,000,000 nonunion workers in the last three years, but that the recession and automation had more than offset the gain.
IN the relentless total war between arms and ammunition manufacturers for victory in the production of new models, the Remington Arms Company recently has offered a number of new rifles and shotguns.

Consolidated net earnings of the Socony Mobil Oil Company for 1958 are estimated at $155,700,000, a drop of 29 per cent from $220,400,000 earned the year before, Albert L. Nickerson, president, reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 (AP) -The pilot of an American Airlines DC-6 passenger plane said today that three mysterious objects that looked like shining saucers appeared to accompany the plane for forty-five minutes last night on its nonstop flight from Newark, N. J., to Detroit.
PARIS, Feb. 25 -- President Charles de Gaulle and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will meet next Wednesday for the third time since last September and at a critical moment in East-West relations.
AT Betty Parsons' new Section Eleven Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, small drawings, paintings and sculptures by more than twenty artists make a lively impression.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -Senate rackets investigators warned today that unless mobster domination of some industries and unions could be halted it would create "great danger" to the country.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Mayor Wagner asked the Legislature today to give the police of New York City's Housing Authority more effective means of coping with vandalism and petty crime.
Directors of the Interchemical Corporation plan to split the common stock on a 2 1/2 for 1 basis at their next meeting scheduled early next month, H. B. Woodman, president, announced yesterday.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Village officials here reported today that they had sent to the Legislature a bill to set up a Mamaroneck housing authority.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Republican legislative leaders set the stage today for a head-on clash between Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa on New York City's need for additional school construction funds.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Feb. 25 -- (UPI) -- Otto Graham, professional football's most successful quarterback during ten seasons with the Cleveland Browns, today became head coach of the United States Coast Guard Academy. "It presents a real challenge -- a new type of life," Graham said of the job.
A NEW light bulb for household use has been developed by Westinghouse.
HONG KONG, Feb. 25 -- The military services in Communist China are becoming increasingly important as a work force in the country's campaign for economic development.
After a week in orbit and almost 100 circuits of the earth, Vanguard II, the world's first weather satellite, has produced a more steady flow of data than any previous American space vehicle.

CHARLES HARTING PERCY, a 39 - year - old business executive who accumulates corporate responsibilities and committee memberships with the zeal of a collector, has moved into the high councils of the Republican party.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower said today that he saw little use in a conference on Germany and Berlin as long as Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev rejected all Western proposals in advance.

THE city has its wonders for children, as well as for adults, but not every youngster is alert to the city's charms. How can city-minded parental "sell" the city to their young and still avoid the pangs of guilt that stab so sharply when boys and girls complain about urban living?
Importers expressed alarm yesterday over the Supreme Court's decision on Tuesday, upholding states' rights to taxi stored imports. They considered the ruling, potentially damaging to trade.
"THE average woman does not know how to dust. She just stirs up dirt and shakes it around the house."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Representative Leo E. Allen of Illinois, senior Republican member of the House Rules Committee and an important figure in his party's "Old Guard," announced today he would retire from Congress after his present term, which will expire on Jan. 3, 1961.
KIAMBU, Kenya, Feb. 22 -Kingangi Mbira has pierced ears, two wives, twelve children and twenty acres on which new coffee trees are pushing up through the terraced dark red earth.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Carmen Basilio, borrowing a line from his chief rival, Sugar Ray Robinson, today challenged Archie Moore to a light-heavyweight title defense.

LEONIE RYSANEK is the real thing as a singing actress. If anyone had doubts after her Metropolitan Opera debut as Lady Macbeth three weeks ago, they should have been resolved last night when she sang "Aida."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- France pledged herself today to propose the admission of the French Cameroons to the United Nations "in a short period of time" after the trust territory achieved independence next Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -President Eisenhower declared today that the United States could not agree to a suspension of nuclear weapons tests unless there was "untrammeled" right of inspection.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The New York State Council of Churches, a Protestant organization, asked the defeat today of two bills affecting bingo.
More than a dozen Haitian leaders have taken refuge in foreign embassies in Port-au-Prince since early this month, spokesmen for three Haitian Opposition parties declared here yesterday.
Three thousand dress workers demonstrated for forty-five minutes yesterday morning in the garment district as an aftermath of the assault on a union leader in New Jersey last Friday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- The United Nations delegates from Ghana, Liberia and Indonesia have asked Governor Rockefeller to help change the state law that subjects their homes in New Rochelle to taxation.
The Illinois Bell Telephone Company borrowed $50,000,000 on thirty-five year first mortgage bonds yesterday at an interest cost of 4.36 per cent.
Secretary of Commerce Lewis L. Strauss last night appeared to squelch any prospect of expanded trade with the Soviet Union.
Union negotiators in the twenty-five-day strike in the baking industry yesterday rejected employer wage offers for a three-year pact covering 4,000 bakers and clerks in 200 retail shops.
GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Feb. 25 -- Nearly 300 families here have reported they would consider moving if the railroads abandoned their passenger service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Feb. 18:

At last City Administrator Charles F. Preusse has submitted his report with the self-explanatory title "Board of Education: Organization and Management of School Planning and Construction." Its recommendations are intended to effect economical operation, to reduce the prevalence of juvenile delinquency, to elevate scholastic standards, to stop the exodus of students to sectarian and private schools, and to provide special facilities for the mentally retarded and the gifted.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- In his news conference today President Eisenhower was unusually gloomy about Berlin, but he avoided any overt effort to arouse the country to the dangers of the situation.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A Rockefeller administration proposal to establish a State Department of Motor Vehicles moved a step nearer fruition today. The Senate adopted a resolution in its favor.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Spider Webb scored a technical knockout over Bobby Boyd after 1:55 in the first round of their nationally televised middleweight fight at Chicago Stadium tonight. The contest was scheduled for ten rounds.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- A horse that, on form, had no business winning, captured the $27,350 Florida Breeders Stakes at Hialeah today over the "baby distance" of three furlongs. The horse was My Dear Girl. She triumphed over twenty-four other 2-year-olds, the largest field ever to run in Florida.

The nation's No. 1 and No. 2 railroads -- the Pennsylvania and the New York Central, respectively operated in the red last month. Both lines attributed their deficits to traffic losses and extraordinary expenses, resulting from storms and floods in their territories.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- A Pan American 707 Boeing airliner carrying five persons on a training flight dropped one of its four jet engines over France today shortly before a scheduled run to New York. The plane later landed safely in London.

HARTFORD, Feb. 25 -- The Christian church is morally and theologically obligated to speak its mind on major social issues no matter how controversial, a leading Protestant spokesman declared here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower said today that if people want economic growth and expansion they ought to favor above all "fiscal soundness." He meant by that a balanced budget now.

The Atlas Corporation disclosed yesterday that it planned to pay dividends on the common stock this year in stock rather than in cash. Directors reported that the company was working out a plan that would afford each stockholder the opportunity to sell up to fifteen shares of stock received as dividends without incurring sales expenses.

DAYTONA BEACH, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Lee Petty today was declared the winner of the 500-mile stock car sweepstakes Sunday. This took the victory away from John Beauchamp, who was named the winner after the race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 25 (UPI) -- An American Western all-star team upset the world champion Italian contract bridge team by twenty-nine international match points in play ended today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -Representative Peter Frelinghuysen Jr. of New Jersey said today he was considering asking the House Commerce Committee to make a study of the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut commuter transportation problem.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 25 -- The Puppeteers of the Junior League of Greenwich will give two performances of "The Clown," an original work by a member of the league, Mrs. Gilbert Shove, on Saturday and March 21 in Julian Curtiss School and in Riverside School.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 25 -- Chinese Nationalist Intelligence sources said today that the Chinese Communists had moved approximately 1,000 jet bombers within about 850 miles of Taiwan.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- The Southern Rhodesian Government intensified troop movements today in an attempt to quell labor unrest at home and political riots in neighboring Nyasaland.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The proposal by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in his Moscow speech yesterday that Britain and the Soviet Union sign a nonaggression pact has been given a chilly reception here.

THE new crop of California dates, now in abundant supply, is of particularly good quality, the Department of Agriculture reports. Signs of excellence are smooth skins, plumpness and a golden-brown lustrous hue.
Fort Greeley, at Big Delta in the heart of Alaska's Yukon Valley, is the nation's latest frontier post.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey told a group of Southern Democrats tonight that the Supreme Court's desegregation decision would not vanish "by open defiance, or by ignoring it, or by any other means."
In the Liberian hinterland of West Africa dowries are still paid in "soul" money by several tribes.

Every year The New York Times has helped us most successfully to secure fine volunteers for our City Hospital, Bird S. Coler, on Welfare Island. This hospital takes care of 1,900 chronically ill patients -- 1,000 of these are bedridden. Volunteers are needed for diversional therapy, reading, writing letters, feeding the bedridden -- and most of all for enthusiastic friendship.
Youthful vandals badly damaged yesterday the three-story synagogue of Congregation Beth Hamedrosh, 110 East 105th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues in East Harlem.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 26 -- A Japanese Right-wing leader attempted to assault Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama in Mr. Fujiyama's office yesterday after delivering a protest against the proposed repatriation of some Koreans in Japan to Communist North Korea.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The peak price of butcher hogs slipped to a new two-year i iow tOday. The market sagged a much as 50 cents a hunOredwelght on a continued poor shipping demand aJad a supply larger than expected.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, cut her usual precision designs in the ice today en route to an almost sure fourth consecutive world figure skating championship.

The 1959 "Festival of Two Worlds" will open in Spoleto, Italy, on June 11 with a performance of Donizetti's "The Duke of Alba." Gian Carlo Menotti, president of the festival, made the announcement yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Representative Steven V. Carter said today he would cut by nearly half the $11,872 Government salary being paid to his teen-age son.

Despite the fact that he is without two of his key men, the injured Bob Mealy and Don McGorty, Coach Ken Norton of Manhattan College figures his scrappy Jaspers will give the strong St. John's University basketball team a rugged tussle in the feature of the collegiate double-header tonight at Madison Square Garden.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A 16-year-old high school student urged the Legislature today to do something about poor discipline conditions in New York City schools.

Italy has a new Government under Premier Segni, who proposes to lead the country back to the middle-of-the-road policies of the late Premier De Gasperi that blossomed into Italy's post-war renaissance. The new Government, a "monocolor" regime of exclusively Christian Democrats, lacking its own majority in Parliament, must still win a vote of confidence.

The Rockefeller budget and tax program seems to be moving gradually toward enactment. Some compromise, probably not too serious, is indicated. We believe that, while there will still be lots of shouting, Governor Rockefeller will in the end win a substantial victory for the principle of an honestly balanced budget.
Sidney J. Ungar, lawyer, real estate dealer and one time Democratic candidate for Congress from Manhattan, denied yesterday that he was an "evasive landlord."
The once-reticent commercial banks will spend about $143,000,000 on advertising this year.

Manhattan's basketball team did its best last night to impress the National Invitation Tournament Selection Committee by winning in overtime before an excited gathering of 5,890 at Madison Square Garden. The Jaspers beat St. John's, already chosen for the N. I. T., 70 to 65.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Republican and Democratic Senators dismissed President Eisenhower's proposal to raise the Federal tax on gasoline today. They told Administration officials to devise other ways to obtain the money.

A recent series of articles in this newspaper has shown that the new law on food additives, which goes into effect next week, is not just an easy way out of a simple problem. Actually, the whole question is so complex that it has taken several years of legislative study to bring to enactment a measure that seemed to fit at least the majority of the facts in the case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Teamsters Union has won an election that provides its first major foothold in the missile industry. It also demonstrates an ironic twist of the no-raiding agreement among member unions of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
William Zeckendorf made public yesterday his plan to put up an office building on a two-block site across Ninth Avenue from the General Post Office that would dwarf the Pentagon.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 26 -- A Paterson lawyer today denied that any contributions had been made to the welfare fund of a bakery workers union in Newark by the C. F. Mueller Company.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 -- James R. Hoffa retorted to the Governor of Florida today that he ought to "stop talking about Hoffa and start worrying about the working people of Florida and their living standard."

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 26 -- The Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, Sir Edgar Whitehead, announced today a state of emergency in the territory and the detention of leaders of the African National Congress under emergency regulations.

MONTREAL, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization announced today that a new trans-Atlantic communications cable was to be laid in 1960-62 to improve air-traffic control along the Great Circle Route across the North Atlantic.
Sehenley Industries, Inc., has named Sidney G. Stricker Jr. director of advertising and George Balterman associate director of advertising, and advertising manager.
Fifty years ago this week a small town in Nova Scotia became the Kitty Hawk of Canada.
Morris High School of the Bronx suffered an unexpected double setback yesterday in the opening, game of a Public Schools Athletic League triple-header basketball play-off at Madison Square Garden.

The P. Lorillard Company recorded the highest sales and earnings in its nearly 200-year history last year. Increases were 63 per cent and 135 per cent, respectively, compared with the 1957 figures, Lewis Gruber, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today that schools all over the country were failing to get valuable science equipment from the Federal Government virtually free.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Representative William J. Green Jr. declined to testify on a conspiracy charge because no evidence was presented against him, his attorney asserted today.

I want to record my satisfaction with your editorials supporting the tax program of Governor Rockefeller. It is only too rarely that we have a man holding important public office who faces financial problems so directly and proposes remedies so completely free from political considerations.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Registered domestic and foreign vessels navigating the Hudson River may be required to take on a licensed pilot between Yonkers and Troy or pay an amount equivalent to his fee. A bill to require this has been reported out of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation here.

" It is senseless to consider further taking alternate lands," he stated, "as the time involved in hearings, litigation and appeals would result in a halt in construction, a breakdown of the entire project, unemployment on a tremendous scale on the frontier and in plants manufacturing our equipment, and suits by contractors running into colossal sums."
Jack Kramer, who holds a corner on most of the world's best tennis players, brought four of them into New York yesterday for a performance at Madison Square Garden Sunday afternoon.
General increases in trans-Atlantic air fares plus extra charges for jet travel were announced yesterday by the International Air Transport Association.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Pressmen went on strike against this city's three newspapers.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Legislature made public today the names and salaries of 973 of its employes, from those making $2,000 for the three-month session to one earning $23,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -Honduras and Nicaragua agreed today to prevent their territories from being used to mount rebellions against each other.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Clare Boothe Luce was named by President Eisenhower today to be Ambassador to Brazil. She is expected to win Senate confirmation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- African petitioners before the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today criticized plans before the United Nations for the future of French Cameroons.

Addressing a savings bond rally in Washington on Wednesday, President Eisenhower challenged the contention, stated or implied, of those who would have us believe that the economic growth of the nation depends directly on the amount of Government spending at any given time.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- In a pamphlet published recently outlining its policies, the Labor party said that the first contribution of a Labor Government to disarmament would be to suspend British nuclear tests at once, "whatever other powers might decide."

The State Power Authority announced last night that it was filing an immediate application for the right to build the reservoir for the Niagara power project on land off the Tuscarora Indian reservation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The United States and Poland will open talks here next week on a new sales and loan agreement, according to informed sources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A bronze statue of a woman medical scientist was placed in Statuary Hall at the Capitol today.
The New York Philharmonic, under Leonard Bernstein, will appear in Moscow for two weeks this summer in conjunction with the United States exhibition at Sokolniki Park.
Three major public health agencies here yesterday offered evidence of a nation-wide increase in venereal disease among teen-aged boys and girls in the last three years.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 26 -- Foreign Minister Subandrio, in a speech prepared for delivery before Parliament, warned today Indonesia could not remain idle if she had proof of Dutch intentions to used force in the dispute over Western New Guinea.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Janet Morgan and Mrs. Sheila Speight MacIntosh, the top-seeded British combination, scored two victories in reaching the semi-final round of the United States squash racquets doubles championship today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
Employes of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity will give blood today in the Municipal Building to the New York Red Cross Blood Program.
Helped by a firm tone in metals, prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- Eight Senators urged Congress today to initiate action to amend the Constitution to protect the status of the Supreme Court as final legal authority on Constitutional diction."

Maria Petrova, American soprano of Russian origin, gave her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. It featured the premiere of four songs by George Antheil, the American composer who died on Feb. 12.

The C. I. T. Financial Corporation, the nation's largest independent sales finance company, reported yesterday 1958 net income from operations of $41,025,291, or $4.31 a common share. This compared with $39,092,388, or $4.27 a share, in 1957.

HOLLISTER, N. C., Feb. 26 (UPI) -- Halifax County school authorities tried today to end a two-day boycott by 300 pupils at a Negro elementary school here backed by a pro-integrationist organization. The boycott here was aimed at supporting demands for construction of a new school for Negroes.
A continued increase in the nation's prosperity was predicted here yesterday by Secretary of Commerce Lewis L. Strauss.
A leading paper manufacturer said yesterday that the paper industry must step up its research efforts to remain competitive.
The Under Secretary of Labor warned here yesterday that a "real chasm" was beginning to develop between ownership and management on one hand and organized labor on the other.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Amerigo has worked himself into excellent condition, as attested by his fine performance in today's feature race at Hialeah. The 4-year-old son of Nearco was "liked" by the crowd of 17,313 in the seven-furlong race, and Amerigo was completely responsive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The nation's department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 24 per cent above the level of a year ago.

WHEN a soprano engages a flutist to assist her in a recital it is generally in the hope that she can demonstrate that she can beat the flute at its own game. Last night Mattiwilda Dobbs engaged three flutists, but clearly display was not her aim.
Advance gifts of $340,000 toward Irvington House Institute's goal of $1,000,000 were announced last night.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The section of the Waterfront Commission Act that bars felons as union dues collectors was upheld today by the Court of Appeals.

ON an afternoon in January, 1943, a telephone shrilled in a hotel suite in San Francisco. Clare Boothe Luce, working on a political speech she was to deliver that evening, let it ring, thinking her maid or secretary would answer it.
IN his farewell spring and summer collection for Elizabeth Arden, shown this week, Count Sarmi has swirled chiffon like a master. The full-length, lady-like chiffon dresses were enchanting.
The Board of Estimate turned down yesterday a bus company's plea to delay the conversion of Third Avenue to one-way operation.

A NEW JERSEY reader who describes himself as "one male person living alone" would like some advice on cooking for one. Like many others in similar circumstances, he often longs for a good, home-cooked meal.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 26 -- Committee members have been selected for the second annual contemporary art exhibition and sale sponsored by the Far Brook School of Short Hills. A reception for artists, patrons and sponsors on April 4 will open the event, which will be held at the West Orange Armory.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor declared today that it was "entirely possible to develop an anti-missile defense for the United States at an acceptable cost and in a reasonable time frame."

Charges of waste and mismanagement against the Board of Education must be cleared up before the city can prudently go on authorizing large appropriations for school construction, two city officials declared yesterday.

Interest rates in Canada are on the rise. Yesterday, the Bank of Canada's discount rate climbed to a near-record of 4.32 per cent, 0.29 point above last week's level and only 0.01 point below the record of 4.33 per cent set in August, 1957.
While the Union Pacific Railroad's income from transportation operations rose moderately last month, revenues from oil and gas properties on its line and from its investment portfolio declined.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Mark Twain's "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" will be the first picture to be produced by Samuel Goldwyn Jr. for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The studio had been contemplating filming the story as a musical since 1950 and it formerly was to have been produced by Arthur Freed.
Aircrafts, electronics, chemicals with missile connections and drugs acted as if they were in a bull market yesterday. Steels, rubbers, metals and oils behaved as if in some doubt of it.

Bills to tighten New York State's censorship of motion pictures drew more criticism than approval yesterday at a hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee to Study the Publication and Dissemination of Offensive and Obscene Material.

MESA, Ariz., Feb. 26 -- Spring training here in the Valley of the Sun, where fabled Superstition Mountain and picturesque Camelback Mountain present eye-filling backdrops, is like spring training anywhere the climate is warm. Players run, throw, hit, look interested and perspire.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Feb. 26 -- When the eighteenth Harriman Cup skiing races get under way tomorrow, the two Soviet Union Alpine racers, Stalina Korzukhina and Yevgeniya Sidorova, will be among the missing.

The man from Cunningham Walsh, Inc., will not be able to use cocktail-time market tests as an excuse for missing commuter trains, even though his agency was awarded a liquor account recently. The agency now has a watch account.
ROME, Feb. 26 -- The police battled thousands of students rampaging through Rome's streets in anti-Austrian demonstrations today.
Jack Benny and Lever Brothers Company were reported yesterday to be close to an agreement for the sponsorship of his television program next season.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- A Laborite resolution denouncing the Government's defense program was rejected tonight by a 297-to-230 vote. Later the House of Commons approved Britain's defense policy without a vote.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, easily won her fourth straight women's world figure skating championship tonight.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Pierre Monteux, conductor, Rudolph Serkin, pianist, 2:30; Henri Honegger, 'cellist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 6; "Don Giovanni." Metropolitan Opera, 8; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Maurice Gendron, 'cellist, and Philippe Entrement, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Kingston Trio and Josh White, folk singers, Town Hall, 8:30 and 11:15 P. M.
A continuing lively demand for the tax-exempt interest obligations of state and local governments held the center of attention in the bond market yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Court of Appeals today refused to release Joseph (Socks) Lanza from prison.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 26 -- Communist pamphlets are being distributed again in Syria despite official suppression of the Communist party.
Gambling has become the foundation of organized crime, both locally and nationally, a Brooklyn rackets grand jury declared yesterday.

" It went off passably well and gave me no trouble whatsoever." So Lincoln wrote to his wife after he had completed the Cooper Union address that brought him to national attention and helped considerably to win him the White House nomination.

Twenty-two public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $103,495,000 yesterday on bonds maturing over forty-one years. The average interest cost was 3.4087 per cent. The money will furnish permanent financing for low-rent projects administered by the local authorities.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said at a news conference today that he would not bring up the Berlin question during his visit to Moscow at the end of March.

HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- The revolutionary Government of Cuba today requested the Dominican Republic to arrest provisionally, pending extradition proceedings, a group of eight high officials of the former Batista regime now living there in exile.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- A Conservative member of the House of Commons has been rejected by Conservative voters in his constituency as their candidate in the next general election.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Johnny Pott, a Shreveport (La.) pro, carded a one-under-par 71 today to lead qualifiers in the $15,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament. Eight others matched par.

OTTAWA, Feb. 26 -- Canada aligned herself today with Britain, France and the United States in he defense of the West's rights in Berlin. At the same time Sidney E. Smith, Secretary of State for External Affairs, rejected arguments for immediate or early recognition of Communist China.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it planned to sell $30,000,000 of thirty-year consolidated bonds on March 5, 1959.

At this time of year, many New Yorkers are dreaming of and scheming to get a few days in Miami. Conversely, there's at least one population segment of Florida's resort capital that wants nothing more right now than a trip to New York.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- To clear the decks for presentation of New York City's alternative tax programs, Democratic leaders moved today for a showdown next week on off-track betting.
NO need to feel despondent about Irish drama. "God and Kate Murphy," which opened at the Fifty-fourth Street last evening, recovers some of the quality of the old-fashioned Irish theatre.
The enthusiasm for government control of private health insurance indicated in your editorial of Feb. 16 entitled "Canadian Hospital Insurance" leaves me a little breathless.
WHEN Horton Foote's "The Trip to Bountiful" was done on Broadway in 1953, it had the compensating virtues of Lillian Gish's and Jo Van Fleet's staunch acting in the two major roles.

SOMETIME in the autumn of 1939 a 16-year-old Irish boy landed in Liverpool with a suitcase full of bombs and fuses. His name was Brendan Behan and he was a great patriot, weaned on hatred of England and reared on heroic tales of the brave Fenlan men, his father and uncles not least among them, Who had asked nothing better than to suffer martyrdom for the holy cause of Irish freedom.
PEARL RIVER, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- With the help of a dozen chickens the high school here is trying to teach its students the facts of nutrition.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A battle flared on the Senate floor today over the choice of a floral emblem for the United States.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday he was considering the use of psychologists or psychiatrists to screen police candidates.
The Rockaway Chamber of Commerce charged yesterday that the city had favored two sites scheduled for development in setting property-assessment rates in the Rockaways.
Roy Campanella will go to Vero Beach, Fla., to work as a special coach with the Los Angeles Dodgers, but he will go to the baseball camp alone.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A handful of Senators, speaking in an almost empty Senate chamber, expressed alarm and concern today over the Berlin crisis.
MIAMI, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- A woman found beaten and shot to death in a riverside cove was identified today as Mrs. Louise Meslener, 24 years old, a National Airlines clerk formerly from New York City.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The full support of the American Legion was pledged today to the American Bar Association recommendation for tightening subversion laws.

Directors of the Republic Aviation Corporation cut the common stock dividend in half yesterday. The declaration of 25 cents a share for the quarter, payable March 23, compared with 50 cents distributed in previous quarters.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Ed Lubanski, who last night led the Pfeiffer team of Detroit to an American Bowling Congress record score, today smashed the A. B. C. all-events mark with a nine-game total of 2,116.

BULLETINS about great congregations of striped bass are flashing in from all directions. Upon them some wise old heads are basing forecasts of a great early season. If this be reason, make the most of it.

New York's neighbors up in Westchester County are having a warm debate over an issue, whether to sell away some park land, that is reminiscent of the Neponsit Beach controversy in mid-1955 which embroiled our city's Board of Estimate.
OXFORD, Ohio, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, called on thinking men and women today to base their decisions on fact, "not on fancy, fabrication or foolish fear."

Except for a final communique, the talks between Prime Minister Macmillan and Premier Khrushchev seem to have ended in an even colder stalemate than existed before they were begun. They were doomed to failure when Premier Khrushchev pulled the rug from under the British Prime Minister with a public speech in which he rejected all Western proposals and insisted on Western surrender to Soviet terms.
Eighteen-year-old Robert Reldan, nephew of the late Ferris Booth, investment counselor, was taken into custody yesterday by the police for the alleged theft of an automobile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Representative Oren Harris denied today that Dr. Bernard Schwartz had ever told House investigators that James C. Hagerty intervened in an Albany television case on political grounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Following are the texts of Navy announcements today on the boarding of a Soviet fishing trawler, together with sections of the 1884 submarine cable convention and the United States Law of 1888 relating to the right of search:
Radioactivity traced from a mechanic's glove to the engine of a jetliner back from a high-altitude trans-Atlantic flight has brought a new study by the Public Health Service.
VIENNA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A fist fight between American and Czech hockey players tonight marred a game in Prague in which the United States national team lost, 8 -- 3, the Prague radio said.
The economically and politically harried Haitian Government was reported yesterday to have received major aid from the United States Government as well as important private assistance.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 26 -- A revolt erupted in the parliamentary element of the Christian Democratic Union today against the party leaders' decision to nominate Dr. Ludwig Erhard for the Presidency of the West German Federal Republic.
Gene (Ace) Armstrong of Elizabeth, N. J., will put a sixteen-bout winning streak on the line in Madison Square Garden tonight when he meets Italo Scortichini, the Italian middle-weight champion.

New York University has, announced that Dr. G. RowI land Collins, dean of the Graduate School of Business ] Administration, plans to retire Aug. 31 after thirty-nine years' service. Dr. Joseph H. Taggart, now associate dean, will become dean Sept. 1.

Oil imports jumped sharply last week, rising to near record levels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. The increase came as the oil industry awaited announcement of the Government's new oil imports program, which is expected to impose mandatory, rather than voluntary, controls on imports.
Michael J. Murphy, executive director of the Waterfront Commission, resigned yesterday to resume his career in the Police Department.

Jack P. Schleifer, New York realty investor, has purchased the Eastern Airlines office building on Peachtree Street in Atlanta, Ga.., for about $800,000. The purchase included two adjacent parking lots used by employes of companies occupying the five-story structure.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 26 -- Abner (Longie) Zwillman, notorious as an underworld leader since he came into power and wealth in the Prohibition era committed suicide today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- This supposedly was the first big day of the 1959 training season for the world champion Yankees. It was reporting time for the infield and outfield regulars, and cameras clicked as such stalwarts as Hank Bauer, Gil McDougald, Bill Skowron, Jerry Lumpe, Norm Siebern and Enos Slaughter pranced on the field.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Senate Territories subcommittee approved the Hawaiian statehood bill today.
The newest apparel store in Queens -- Alexander's in Rego Park -- was opened yesterday with Borough President John T. Clancy and a helicopter cutting the ribbon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A question asked of the President at his news conference yesterday, and his reply, lifted the curtain only briefly on the next great inflationary threat to the domestic economy. This threat will be resolved or will materialize in the outcome of the oncoming wage negotiations in the steel industry.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 26 -- Bob Carpenter, president of the Philadelphia Phillies, met today for the first time with the Camden County Improvement Authority to discuss its proposals to move the club to South Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was told today that Eastern railroads were trying to eliminate the use of fuel oils in the New York area by reducing transportation charges on bituminous coal.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Controller Arthur Levitt attacked Governor Rockefeller's tax increase program tonight as "unfair and unnecessary," particularly as it deals with income taxes.

HARTFORD, Feb. 26 -- The cautious enthusiasm voiced a month ago by Protestant and Eastern Orthodox leaders over the announced intention of Pope John XXIII to convoke an ecumenical council has deteriorated rather sharply, it was apparent here today.
Net income of the Radio Corporation of America last year fell $7,607,000, compared with 1957 earnings, on a sales drop of $183,000.
All divisions of Loew's, Inc., are making money now, Joseph R. Vogel, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 26 -- The cost of building the proposed North Hempstead Town incinerator "will be well over $6,000,000," instead of the $3,600,000 estimated by the Town Board. a group of engineers said here today.

Loans to business, which had begun to show seasonal improvement at this time last year, declined at the larger New York City banks in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The decline of $6,000,000 compared with an increase of $42,000,000 in the week a year ago.
Cotton futures moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off 6 points (30 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The volume of trading was moderate.

If it remains difficult for foreigners to tell the difference between the Republican and Democratic parties this will not be because the Republican party is not trying to define itself.
