COPENHAGEN -- The Danes expect to welcome more than 110,000 American tourists this year. This is really a modest estimate, since last year's total was 109,000, while over the last decade the rate of American visits has steadily increased at a rate of 10 to 15 per cent a year.

SEBRING, Fla. -- Once a year this pleasant little south central Florida city basks in the limelight of a much-heralded international automobile racing event, the International Grand Prix of Endurance, which last year attracted more than 40,000 fans.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- The Junior League of Scarsdale is planning a country auction. It will be held in a tent on May 23 at the American Legion headquarters, Post 52, on Mamaroneck Road.

TOMORROW evening the Ballets Africains of Keita Fodeba will move over to the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre to continue their New York engagement, after a sold-out fortnight at the Martin Beck. The road tour, already booked, has been postponed to allow for the extension of the New York season, which is described as a "limited" one.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28 -- Bill Rigney took his first look at the 1959 San Francisco Giants today. He liked what he saw. The manager, who only three weeks ago was seriously hurt in an automobile smash-up, rejoined the club this morning and from a spot in the left-field stands watched his Giants go through their spring training chores.

MOST Americans don't know beans. This is a rather startling thought considering the fact that beans -- along with peas and lentils -- are among the oldest, most palatable and universally used foods. Early Egyptians and ancient Greeks doted on them. So did togaed Romans, who not only feasted on beans but also used them in an uncooked state as counters in games of chance.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- The one-party Government headed by Antonio Segni was given a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies Friday night by the largest majority that any Italian Government has had in the last seven years.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- During their frank and still cordial early meetings this week Premier Khrushchev confided to Prime Minister Macmillan that the Soviet Government was having its "difficulties" restricting the consumption of vodka.

ATHENS -- Greek tourist authorities have been struggling manfully during recent years to cope with the greatly increased, and still increasing, floods of visitors. The superb climate, the unique records of the classic past and the new possibilities for leisure and sight-seeing have brought more and more tourists here, and this has put quite a strain on the whole establishment.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 28 -- Navy's basketball team capped a successful program of competition with Army's athletic squads by posting a 69-52 victory over the cadets today before a record crowd of 4,553 in the Field House. The middies celebrated their triumph by accepting a bid to the National Collegiate basketball tournament as an at-large selection.

IF a ruler controls all the vast machinery of modern government and 75 per cent of the human spirit of his subjects, including almost all the youth, all the younger officers in the armed forces, and the high commands of the navy and air force, what can those few men do who regard him as an irresponsible, criminal, lunatic tyrant?
" Humor in Music" was the topic of Leonard Bernstein's nationally televised Young People's Concert yesterday afternoon.

AMERICA the Beautiful is relentlessly becoming America the Mess, and the reasons for this disgusting metamorphosis are clearly set forth by Wilfred Owen in a sane, terrifying and important new book, "Cities in the Motor Age."
The Government announced last week that a 106,500-ton tanker to be built for the Manhattan Tankers Company, Inc. was eligible for Federal mortgage insurance up to $20,925,000.

A citizens committee for urban renewal, believed to be the first of its kind in the country, has been invited by the Board of Education and the City Planning Commission to give its opinion on their plans in a pilot project on the West Side.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Bill Stead, one of last year's leading hydroplane pilots, suffered serious burns today when the boat Maverick exploded while traveling at 150 miles an hour on Lake Mead.

THE little girl obviously had something on her mind. She stood beside her mother's dressing table, studying with new interest every motion her mother made -- the carefully casual fluffing of her hair, the precise application of lipstick and eye-shadow, the dabs of perfume.

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- These islands, an archipelago playing touch and go with the Equator for 3,000 glittering miles, are a frustrating mixture of tourist attraction and tidak ads, which are two of the busiest words in the language.
The atom may be standing in the way of shipping progress.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 28 -- Uruguay hands over her executive power for the next four years tomorrow to an 86-year-old politician, an ambitious radio commentator and the candidate most thoroughly beaten in the last election.
Sigurd Stanton Larmon, white-haired elder statesman of the advertising industry, is slowly turning over the reins to his successor at Young Rubicam, Inc.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The College Women's Club of Montclair is once again "putting new life into old books" to raise money for college scholarships for girls.

Industrial expansion in the Chicago area started 1959 at a pace nearly double that of the year before, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry has reported. Announced expansion programs during January totaled $12,338,000 compared with $6,629,000 in the 1958 month. A major addition to the area's tinplate output was announced by Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Golden-brown autumn leaves will be fluttering to earth next month in this Southern Hemisphere land, one of the natural reminders of the beginning of the autumn-winter travel season.
WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 28 -- Dr. Nicholas T. Werthessen, a medical scientist, returned from Africa to visit his family here today. He was accompanied by thirty-one baboons.
Resident offices report that reorders are arriving in large volume as stores fill in their stocks for Easter.
HENRY JAMES once wrote that the theatre could "flourish" in barbarism but "develop" only in the air of civilization.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Maxwell Anderson, the playwright, died at 7:45 o'clock tonight at Stamford Hospital. Mr. Anderson suffered a stroke early Thursday at his home, 141 Downs Avenue. He was 70 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Forces within the Administration are strongly urging measures to deal with the human problem involved in the prospect of continued substantial unemployment.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 28 -- A contingent of the Tanganyika police crossed the border into Nyasaland today and occupied the Fort Hill airfield in the Northern Province of the British protectorate. The airfield, which had been held by African rioters for a week, was cleared.

LEONIA, N. J., Feb. 28 -- A commuter organization offered a plan this week to assure the continuation of railroad service. The program calls for a real estate tax in the nine northern counties of New Jersey, contributions by the state and the Port of New York Authority and a levy of 2 1/2 cents a ride on bus and rail commuters.

EVERY year it becomes easier for the American motorist to tour the Continent with his own car. This season for example, the American International Driving Permit will be accepted in almost every European country.
Until last Election Day, Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of New York's Tammany Hall, loomed as one of the most powerful political bosses in the country.

Outdoing themselves all along the line, Coach George Eastment's young men of Manhattan carried off the team honors last night in the championship meet of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.
The missile industry is rocketing -- in sales, earnings and on the stock market.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The continuing debate on the record of the Supreme Court in internal security questions was sharpened this week by some critical words from the American Bar Association.

The French have determined to grant complete independence to their African trust territory, the Cameroons, on Jan. 1 of next year. This is in accord with the expressed wish of the African peoples. Meanwhile, the United Nations is hearing a spirited debate on some details in the method by which this change is to be brought about. Some African groups wish still another popular election before the transfer of sovereignty is made.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 28 -- Wilkes College won its third straight team title and Harry Romig of Lycoming was voted the outstanding wrestler as the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic Conference wrestling championships came to a close tonight.

POET, novelist, teacher, Howard Nemerov also has a flair for writing short stories that belong to the school of chills. With a few exceptions, the fourteen tales included in "A Commodity of Dreams" feature someone who submits to a tiny, nagging impulse and then foolishly allows it to balloon into a monstrous compulsion.

BONN, West Germany -- "Any Time Is Travel Time in Germany" is the slogan for tourism here and it is not exaggerated. The infinite variety of landscape, legend, art, musical and literary associations, and the country's crowded history provide attractions during all seasons of the year.

IT used to be said about one of the most important among the last generation of American business men that he believed everything that was told to him in confidence. Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., is ex officio as well as in his own right one of the most important of the present generation of American business men.

THIS is the time of year when operators, innkeepers and others interested in the inclinations and behavior of skiers, wonder whether another skiing season has come and gone, to their way to thinking, ahead of schedule.
Patrolman Peter Booke aroused 100 tenants and rescued seven of them yesterday from a basement fire that started shortly after 5 A. M. in a six-story tenement at 72 West Eighty-ninth Street.
Two national Roman Catholic magazines joined a number of diocesan papers across the country yesterday in criticizing Senator John F. Kennedy for his recent stand on church-state relations.

The bond market is having a breathing spell from the impact of forces that threatened to push interest rates to new postwar highs. It is a 4 per cent market today, just as it was at the turn of the year. The intervening period has brought into play a number of noteworthy phases, most of which seem to be reaching a pause.

HOBART, Australia, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Mervyn Lincoln, who has broken four minutes for the mile on five occasions, finally won the Australian national mile championship today in 4:05.6 after four losses to John Landy and Herb Elliott.
HONG KONG, Feb. 27 -- Communist officials have announced plans to complete one of the largest combination hydroelectric and irrigation projects in the country this year on Hainan Island.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 28 -- Gov. Albert D. Rosellini's $2,000,000,000 spending program for the next biennium has stirred a taxpayer revolt that is deluging his office and legislators' desk with letters and petitions.
Holland - America Line's new 38,000-ton liner Rotterdam will arrive in New York in September, a month earlier than expected.

BRUSSELS -- Although the World Fair is over, some of its influences linger on here, notably the improvement in tourist conditions through increased hotel accommodations and lower prices induced by keener competition.

" The essential difference between the Unitarian Church and liberal Judaism is the wonderful tradition, culture and heritage of the Jewish religion," the Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring said yesterday morning at Temple Rodeph Sholom.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Strong protests were raised today by various associations of French journalists against a near blackout on news about criminal cases in France, scheduled to be applied starting Monday.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Influenza deaths in England and Wales continued to increase, according to figures published today by the Ministry of Health.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 28 -- This sun-swept island is so distraught over James R. Hoffa's plans to make Puerto Rico part of his teamsters union empire that it would not be surprising to learn that atomic cannon were being mounted in the ancient Spanish fortresses of El Morro and San Cristobal to repel the Hoffa invasion.

State Controller Arthur Levitt declared last night that the Rockefeller Administration must recognize that New York City has special problems and should not ask the city to assume the whole burden caused by them.
A year after they drew a record tennis crowd of 15,237 to Madison Square Garden, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, the world champion, and Lewis Hoad of Australia meet there again this afternoon.

The influence of weather on retail trade was sharply illustrated last week as Fifth District department store sales rose 30 per cent over those of the 1958 week, when snow paralyzed Baltimore. Stores in Baltimore noted an 82 per cent increase over a year ago, Washington sales gained 20 and Richmond 9 per cent.

WHAT Jerome Frank said in reviewing Judge Curtis Bok's prior book, "I too, Nicodemus," is justified again in "Star Wormwood" -- the author is a "profoundly wise judge who is also a sensitive soul and a gifted artist."

THIS is the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Academy of American Poets, an organization which is doing a great deal for the encouragement of poets in this country, and in speaking of what it has thus far accomplished, I should like to say a few things about the condition of poetry in the United States at the present time.

Barbara Ward's article is one of the most thought-provoking that I have read on the economic threat of the Soviet Union to the free world. Her call to action reminds one of Churchill's ceaseless efforts to try to stop Hitler before he became uncontrollable.
ELISABETHVILLE, Belgian Congo, Feb. 12 -- A massive house of worship, its orange-brown brick walls topped with a severe gray roof, dominates the flower-trimmed Avenue Tabora here.
The World O. R. T. Union (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) will observe the seventy-ninth anniversary of its founding next Wednesday over the country.

LONDON, Sunday, March 1 -- The Soviet Union said today that the action of the United States Navy in boarding a Soviet fishing vessel was a "premeditated provocation."

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 14 -- Speculation over the nation's future is growing here as Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, the Premier-dictator, nears his seventieth birthday.

MANILA, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- The Philippine Navy boarded five Soviet trawlers anchored a mile off the north coast of Luzon today and detained them for investigation.

President John Gardner of the Carnegie Corporation said in his annual report that the nation as a whole must first develop an "obsession" with the idea of individual moral and intellectual fulfillment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Back of the Democratic party's choice yesterday of Los Angeles as its 1960 convention city there were many months of investigation and finally decision of questions involving political hopes, financial considerations and creature-comfort calculations.

DURING the winter my kitchen becomes a greenhouse for starting seed and rooting cuttings. Gardening in the kitchen is a rather specialized branch of horticulture, though. Those with purists' views on seedlings' needs for temperature, light and soil may run into difficulties.
CANBERRA, Australia -- Australia is about 10,000 miles and nearly forty air hours from New York. This year Australia will still be 10,000 miles away, but it will be about twenty hours closer.

PRESCOTT, Ariz., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Five Navy crewmen were killed today when their Military Air Transport Service Super - Constellation crashed, exploded and burned at the edge of a busy highway. There were no survivors.
The last decade has seen "steady and marked improvement" in early cancer diagnosis in upstate New York, according to specialists of the State Health Department.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The notion that all the eels of Europe and North Africa make their way back across the Atlantic to breed in the deep, warm waters of the Sargasso Sea was challenged this week by a British zoologist.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- British aeronautical experts believe that many mid-air collisions between fast aircraft are due to a little-understood optical illusion known as autokinesis.

The final report on the 1958 appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is published today and shows $493,736.09 in gifts received. Thus, with the usual Feb. 28 closing of the books, the forty-seventh annual appeal is found to have set a record for all time, surpassing considerably the previous high of $477,756.73 given in 1956 and far exceeding the $449,286.11 in 1957, which till now was the second-best year.
HALIFAX, N. S., Feb. 28 -- An anti-discrimination bill has received a second reading in the Nova Scotia legislature.

But physical dimensions are only a partial measure of the Vienna-born performer, best known for such film roles as the sheriff (now an "Oscar" candidate) in "The Defiant Ones," and the psychiatrist in "I Want to Live."

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Clifford P. Case called on his Senate colleagues from New Jersey, New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania today to join him in seeking amendment of the Federal Transportation Act of 1958.

FOR THIS WEEK: Prune blueberries and grapevines . . . Prune and burn any suspicious looking woody twigs that show signs' of overwintering insects. Do not destroy the brown, foamy egg cases of the praying mantis. . . . Pick faded flowers from African violets regularly. . . . Use chickweed killer to control this weed that often appears in early March. . . .

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 28 -- While their friends and relatives clustered around the gate shouting Greek Cypriote slogans, eighty-three minor terrorists were released this afternoon from the Nicosia Central Prison.

ROME -- Many thousands come to Rome from abroad year after year for the sole, or at least principal, purpose of seeing the Pope and receiving his apostolic blessing. The Eternal City, scene of early Christian martyrdom and seat of the Papacy, attracted mass pilgrimages centuries before it became a major center of the modern tourist industry.

STOCKHOLM -- Swedish travel agents, having no European "Olympics" to advertise as they did last year, have decided to play up their perennial No. 1 attraction -- Sweden herself. And, as visitors of other years can testify, there is much to talk about -- from the tundra and mountains of the far north to the chateau country of the extreme south, with its ivy-covered castles evoking a martial past.

Factory employment in Pennsylvania edged downward to a level of 1,359,700 in mid-December, according to the Bureau of Employment Security of the State Department of Labor and Industry. The principal losses, seasonal in nature, were in the food products industry and the apparel and related products industry group, with employment drops of 2,600 and 2,300 respectively.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 -- A $50,000,000 cut in defense spending was announced today by India's Finance Minister Morarji Desai.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 28 -- The Civil Rights Commission will hold a forum here Thursday and Friday in an effort to determine what methods had proven most sucessful in achieving a smooth transition from segregated to desegregated classrooms.
Twelve editors of eastern newspapers and press services and six judges held a symposium yesterday on the uses of publicity in juvenile court cases.

Arrangements are being made for a theatre party to benefit the American Association for the United Nations. It will take place at the world premiere of George Stevens' Cinema Scope production of "The Diary of Anne Frank" at the Palace Theatre on the evening of March 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- The top-seeded American pair of Charles Wetzel and Mrs. Carter Simonin, both of this city, staged a thrilling comeback in a fifty-minute final of the women's United States squash racquets doubles championship today to defeat the top-seeded British squash racquets team of Janet Morgan and Mrs. Sheila Speight Mac-Intosh, 5 -- 15, 8 -- 15, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 11, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

PRAGUE -- Communist-ruled Czechoslovakia, a country of lovely towns and beautiful mountains, shares part of its borders with Austria and West Germany. The western-most wedge of the Soviet bloc in Europe, it affords the venturesome the easiest and most comfortable way to sample life behind the Iron Curtain.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 28 -- The Seoul District Prosecutor's office has charged a newspaper publisher and his editorial writer with instigation and propagation of a rebellion against the Government.

AS Oden Meeker remarks at the outset, a few years ago only a very few Americans had ever heard of the Kingdom of Laos. Now it is prominent in the news and information about it is timely. Mr. Meeker's book will be a valuable and pleasant introduction for those who wish to know more about this tiny state in Southeast Asia with whose freedom and whose future we are now concerned.

College freshmen commonly complain of the difficulty of accomplishing the kind and amount of work demanded in their new scholastic world. A test devised to help show Harvard University freshmen how to study more effectively has indicated that even students who read quickly and with understanding may not be aware of the principles of good studying.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senate Democratic leaders called on the country today to speak with a single voice on the Berlin crisis.

IN the world of steamship travel, there will be some bright new facets this year. From the standpoint of the shipping operator they will prove, if proof is necessary, that the ship can still hold its own against her high-flying competitor, the airliner.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 28 -- Missouri's new Representative from the Fourth Congressional District will be named in a special election next Tuesday. He will fill the unexpired term of George H. Christopher, Democrat, who died in Washington Jan. 23.
AFTER being closed for repairs for more than three months, the Washington Monument reopened last Monday, a day after the 227th birthday of the country's first President.
BATON ROUGE, Feb. 28 (AP) -- John McMullin faded to a one-over-par 73 today but still held a one-stroke lead at the midpoint of the $15,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Mickey Mantle, who has set four goals for himself in 1959 -- at least fifty homers, a batting average of .330 or better, action in 154 games and at least 100 runs batted in -- could be shooting for still another objective this year.

SOSTANJ, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16 -- A big new thermoelectric plant only a few miles from Yugoslavia's most complete hydroelectric system sounds like an anomaly. But it is essential because of the weather in this part of the world.

BELGRADE -- In Britain, the tourist attraction is the romance of history; in France, the gaiety of Paris and the Riviera; but in Yugoslavia it is the people. Friendly, talkative and easy to meet, the mercurial Yugoslavs outshine the country's scenery, even though this is among the most beautiful and varied in Europe.

EACH year, increasing hundreds of disabled Americans are finding that the rewards of international travel need not be denied them simply because of physical disabilities. They are finding, to their delight, that airline, steamship, railroad and bus companies do not consider the provision of the special help they need a problem or even an extraordinary procedure.
A PLEASANT summer retreat such as the one shown here is what many winter-weary city families are dreaming of now.

GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- The three-power conference on ending nuclear weapons testing begins its fifth month on Monday with every appearance of approaching its final agony. But none of the participants is yet prepared to concede that all hope is gone.

ATHENS, Feb. 20 -- In accordance with a contract just signed between the Greek National Tourist Organization and the French concern Son et Lumiere, the Acropolis here is to be the scene of "light and sound" performances, beginning May 15 and lasting until October, weather permitting.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- French authorities have released five Tunisian students whose arrest in Paris, Strasbourg and Nice a week ago caused strong protests by the Tunisian Government.

OSLO -- A great agricultural exhibition, perhaps the largest ever to be held in Europe, will take place here in June and early July on a 100-acre site just outside this capital. It is expected to attract farmers from all over Europe.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 Captain Tim Jecko set a Yale and Yale pool record in the 200-yard butterfly swim today as the Elis donwed Princeton, 69-17, for their 180th straight victory in dual meet competition.

It has happened thus ever since man began deforesting the hills and draining the swamps. And soon the perennial demand for better flood control will be heard again.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- Bayard Sharp's Troilus made things look easy as he took the thirtieth running of The Flamingo today at Hialeah. The son of Priam II scored by three lengths over the long-priced Open View of the Elkcam Stable.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb., 28 -- Society will turn out Thursday for the benefit showing at the Paramount Theatre of the film, "The Mating Game," starring Debbie Reynolds and Tony Randall.
HAVANA, Feb. 28 -- The Committee for Liberation of Haiti in Havana issued a call today to "all revolutionary sectors and the citizenry in general" to aid in the overthrow of the Haitian Government.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- Japanese postal officials are debating how to spend an expected profit of a billion yen ($2,778,000) from the sale of four special commemorative stamps to mark the wedding of Crown Prince Akihito and Miss Michiko Shoda.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 -- The Dalai Lama in Lhasa ceremonially passed the Gishe, a five-fold examination in classical Buddhist logic, canon law, philosophy and metaphysics last Sunday. Traditionally this has to be completed by every "incarnate Lama."

PERIODICALLY the world comes to the front door unadorned, without benefit of make-up or fancy allurements, like the commuter's sleepy wife driving her husband unembellished to the station to catch the 8:07. AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 28 -- An anti-atheism bill that would require faculty members in all state-supported colleges to sign affidavits declaring that they believed in a Supreme Being has stirred up strong criticism among educators and clergymen.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 28 -- The East-West struggle for Iran completed another round this week. The round went to the West with the signing in Ankara of a bilateral military agreement between Iran and the United States.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- A $3,500,000 six-story "modern but not modernistic" hotel is being built to replace the Bermudiana Hotel which was gutted by fire last September. The new hotel will be ready for occupancy by the middle of March, 1960.
GLEN ROCK, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Communities in Bergen County were urged this week to take a long and honest look at their future before they closed the door to industry.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 28 -- Dartmouth clinched the Ivy League hockey title with an easy 6-2 victory over Brown i University tonight. Freedom will be a strong stimulant to economic recovery and greater prosperity for Cuba, according to Luis A. Baralt, new Cuban Consul General in New York.
Representative W. R. Hull Jr., Democrat of Missouri, was sharply critical yesterday of the Administration's move to cut Federal aid on sewage-treatment construction. He called the move "incredible."

A COLDFRAME has many uses. It may serve as a propagating bed, an "early garden," a summer seedling bed or a winter storage area for questionably hardy plants.

THE success of a sports novel may, I suppose, be gauged by the extent to which the author manages to make a sport understandable and exciting to the reader who knows nothing whatsoever about it. In this respect, at least, Douglas Rutherford's ON THE TRACK OF DEATH (Abelard-Schuman, $2.95) is an unqualified triumph.

A GALLERY for the exhibition and sale of photographs is announced by Laurence Siegel, director of the gallery, Image, at 100 East Tenth Street. The first show, opening Sunday, March 15, will display photographs by Lou Bernstein and Fred Plaut.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 28 -- The United States tried to put a new satellite into orbit today as the first step in a new program of space research.

City Administrator Charles F. Preusse took issue yesterday with Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa on "waste and extravagance" in the city's schools. He called for an expanded building program.

The April 15 performance of Noel Coward's adaptation of Georges Feydeau's farce, "Look After Lulu," will benefit the Washington Square Home, 65 East Eighty-second Street. The comedy opens March 3 at Henry Miller's Theatre.
One day early last May, Roy Campanella lay flat on his back on a Stryker frame with his head held rigid and motionless in a neck brace.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 28 -- After midnight tonight the combined power of twelve nations will be used to see that enough fish remain in the sea to feed their people.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Eisenhower postponed the establishment of rigid oil import controls today to give himself time to study a report that the imports threatened national security.

ROME -- The coming travel season in Italy will be a dress rehearsal for the tourist rush that is expected in 1960 when the Seventeenth Olympic Games are held in Rome. This country is resolutely determined to achieve the number one position in the European travel business.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Tenacious scored a four-length victory today in the $62,500 New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 28 -- One day this week a British official was driving along a highway in southern Cyprus when he saw a Cypriote laborer waving for a ride.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Two African petitioners asked the United Nations today to end its trusteeship over the French Cameroons, without conditions, before Jan. 1. France has pledged the territory independence on that date.

IN his Sunday column, Bosley Crowther pointed out Mr. Disney's dilemma in inserting a goodly amount of fright into his "Sleeping Beauty" film. It seems to me that Disney has solved the dilemma by sacrificing the honest quality of his abilities for a bigger audience, e. g., a bigger "take."

IT is possible to have eight weeks of azalea bloom merely by selecting the right species and varieties. Kurume and Indian azaleas may make a big splurge of color in the South, but northern gardeners need not be envious.

MOST of the shades of painting from Nineteenth Century romantic realism to nonobjective were represented among the exhibitions opening last week. Without taking a theme or attempting to define a movement. World House Galleries has simply brought together pictures by artists from Daumier to Picasso on a basis of merit and intrinsic interest; and, while individual tastes may differ, the selection offers some outstanding work.

JERUSALEM, Israel -- This nation's young, eager tourist industry has laid out new plans and programs for the coming season with the hope of sustaining the worldwide attention the tiny country attracted last year during its tenth anniversary celebrations.

UNDOUBTEDLY the greatest single source of the standard foreign image of the United States is the caricaturist's figure of Uncle Sam -- the tall, spare, chin-whiskered personage in tall hat, striped trousers and star-decked vest so ingratiatingly presented on this side of the water, but so easily given ludicrous or sinister features abroad.

The theatre party for the benefit of the Brotherhood Scholarship Fund of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, originally planned for the March 11 preview performance of "First Impressions," has been rescheduled.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Princeton's varsity hockey squad tallied once in the first period and got two goals in the third as it defeated Cornell at Baker rink today, 3 -0.

AMONG the interesting specialty plant catalogues to arrive in the mail is one that lists honey plants exclusively. These are plants especially rich in nectar and favored by honeybees. Because many of the plants listed are decorative and thrive under poor conditions, they are ideal for planting in waste areas or a neglected corner.
OTTAWA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Shipping tolls for the St. Lawrence Seaway will be announced next Wednesday in Ottawa and Washington, it was reported last night.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Feb. 28 (AP) -- British authorities trying to sooth mounting unrest in the Central African Federation of Nyasaland and the Rhodesias were warned by the African nationalist leader in Nyasaland that jailing him would solve nothing.

AMBOISE, France -- The Valley of the Loire, called the Garden of France and also the Chateau Country, is practically an obligatory tour for anyone truly wanting to know the best of France. Here, French kings and nobles, over the centuries, spent fortunes to build magnificently, and the results are unique -- not to mention the lovely landscape and climate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The selection of Joseph M. McDonald, Colorado District judge, to be chief counsel for a Senate inquiry into the procedures of Federal agencies was announced today.

ONE of modern art's cornerstones, laid as long ago as the late Turner, is the increasingly dominant role played by the artist's materials and his handling of them in the image he presents. Ends and means drew closely together in Monet's waterlilies, closer still in Soutine's landscapes.

BY now, most of the main contenders for a 1960 Presidential nomination are on record as having denied that they are actively seeking it. Since this occurs only in a fixed season -- like the sight of birds flying south -- there is an obvious inference to be drawn.
The Long Island Boat and Sportsmen's show will open at the Jamaica 104th Field Artillery Armory Saturday. It will run through Mar. 15.

LEIPZIG, Germany, Feb. 28 -- The Leipzig Trade Fair, a showcase of Communist industrial achievements, was formally opened tonight with an official vision of world markets dominated by Socialist goods and rubles sounder than dollars.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 28 -- President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam, who is visiting Indonesia, put in a full day today making friends for his country.
TOKYO -- It is becoming, progressively easier for the foreign visitor to travel in Japan, since everyone concerned with tourism here has become conscious the vast dollar mine in this industry.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Dartmouth, battling to stay in the Ivy League basketball title picture, had to go all out tonight to defeat Penn, 69 -- 63, at the Palestra.

EDINBURGH -- Loch Ness's fabled thirty-foot sea serpent has shown itself early this year, giving an unmistakable hint that Scotland is well prepared to welcome its first spring tourists. And this year Scotland has come forward with a new inducement: conducted pony trekking through the Highlands.

SEAFORD, L. I., Feb. 28 -- Two children were killed today when an automobile was accidentally thrown into reverse and leaped seventy-two feet into the doorway of a crowded supermarket. The children's mother and another of her children were seriously injured. Five other persons also were hospitalized.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Feb 28 -- There was double-barreled action on the side of Ruud Mountain today. Speedsters in the men's and women's division of the Harriman Cup slalom raced down the slopes simultaneously and accounted for one of skiing's great spectaculars.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Army downed Navy on three fronts today, sweeping the home portion of the interservice winter athletic program with victories in swimming (48 -- 38), gymnastics (54 1/2 -- 41 1/2), and rifle shooting (1,435 -- 1,429). It was the second straight year the cadets had shut out visiting Navy teams.

AS Barbara Ward's latest book consists of lectures given at the University of Ghana, her audience naturally influenced her selection of the ideas that have been changing the world -- nationalism, industrialism, colonialism, communism, and internationalism.

SAN MARINO -- A bloodless civil war a year and a half ago has done for this tiny country what Princess Grace did for Monaco. The ouster here, with its comic opera overtones, of the only Communist-controlled government west of the Iron Curtain brought priceless publicity for San Marino's national industry, tourism.

SEED sowing time will start Tuesday when the five-session course, "Spring Planting Begins Indoors," opens at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. Students will start flower seed and summer-flowering plants in the greenhouses for their own gardens.

MOSCOW -- Being a tourist in the land of the proletarians is hard work. If one comes and does not work hard at seeing the glories of old Russia and the triumphs of the new communism, one's Soviet hosts will make no secret of their disappointment.

Since spring and song and dance go together, four of the shows will be musicals, ambitious and costly, deriving from the works of such diverse literary lights as Gypsy Rose Lee and Jane Austen.

IN the wake of the disclosure last week that Cinerama, Inc., creators of the wide-screen film system of that name, had obtained a $12,000,000 loan from the Prudential Insurance Company, came the news that Cinerama officials are in the midst of implementing an accelerated production program.

The work of the Kidney Disease Foundation of New York will be furthered by a percentage of the profits from the National Antiques Show, which will open at Madison Square Garden today and continue through next Sunday. Mrs. June Blossom is chairman of the benefit committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Pentagon is insisting on calm firmness rather than special precautions for a possible spring showdown with the Soviet Union over Berlin.
ROME, Feb. 28 -- This city is discussing the draft of a municipal code designed to save its historic center from being choked by traffic.

ANKARA, Turkey -- The moving of the Government tourist offices to new, expanded quarters here this month is a sign of the times and of better days for the traveler in Turkey. The offices, a branch of the Ministry of Press, Radio and Tourism, moved uptown from Ulus, or old Ankara, to a brand new building in Yenisehir, the new city.

The New York Times for Feb. 20 carried a report from Hollywood that five out of ten foreign films submitted have been chosen to compete for the 1958 Academy Award for the best foreign language film of the year.

SPRINGTIME and the American tourist will both soon be on the wing. They have each become about equally inevitable. At hand is the time of the bud, the nightingale and the migratory holiday exodus from New York.
KNOXVILLE, Feb. 28 -- The purchase of a turbo generator from an English company has been defended by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb 28 -- A scale model of the Globe Playhouse, the setting for Shakespeare's plays until it was destroyed by fire in 1613, will be displayed by Hofstra College beginning March 13 at its tenth annual Shakespeare Festival.

The stock market soared again last week to a historic high. By the end of the week, however, there had been an erosion of prices that drove The New York Times fifty-stock average down so that it finished off .07 on the week.

NEW DELHI -- "If you want to have an elephant ride accompanied by soft Indian music, go to the pink city of Jaipur; and there are many other exotic wonders to be found in India."

PARIS -- The spanking new -- the Fifth -- French Republic, dominated by the magisterial figure of President Charles de Gaulle, in spite of its domestic problems, has already done more than a little for the satisfaction of this year's tourists.

EFFORTS to introduce Soviet-made cameras and lenses to the American market are in the exploratory stage following the recent announcement of Russia's intention to compete with German and Japanese imports in this country.

On paper, the Republicans in the New York Legislature have a comfortable margin over the Democrats -- 92 to 57 in the 150-member Assembly (one seat is vacant) and 34 to 24 in the fifty-eight-member Senate. Passage of a bill requires an absolute majority -- seventy-six votes in the Assembly, thirty in the Senate.
WARSAW, Feb. 28 -- Polish trade inspectors wound up today an experiment in the shock technique -- an exhibition of the country's worst examples of consumer production.

FOR the past decade, the morale and the reputation of the New York Police Department have been shattered again and again, despite the efforts of a succession of Commissioners who talked tough, were honest and labored hard. Now, once again, the department is in a turmoil.

WINTER injury is showing up rather prominently on broadleaved and coniferous evergreens in gardens in the metropolitan area. It is caused by high winds and sudden changes in temperatures.

ANATOLE LITVAK's "The Journey," now at the Music Hall, is a bold and surprising screen drama for a number of reasons but mostly because it puts forth a poignant proposition that runs contrary to a concept that popularly prevails.

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- The proposed new division of railroad transportation to be charged with assuring the continuance of commuter service in New Jersey, will have adequate financial help, Senate President Wesley L. Lance said today.

The pineal gland in animals and in humans is a small, flattened cone-shaped body growing from the upper portion of the mid-brain area. Its role in man and animals has not been established. The seventeenth century French philosopher and mathematician, Rene Descartes, believed it was the "seat of the soul," and that the soul and body acted upon each other through the medium of the pineal gland.

IF I were given the nomination of two modern books which rise above their kind in the stark statement of man's central problem, the two would be "Ideological Differences and World Order," edited by F. S. C. Northrop, and this book by Percy Williams Bridgman, "The Way Things Are.
New York motorists will find a new sign on gasoline pumps if they drive in to "fil 'er up" this morning. It says "State Tax -- 6c."
MANY travelers who might at one time have been troubled about what to do with their pets while they were away, today are solving the problem simply by taking them along on their trips.

HONG KONG -- Britain's bustling and prosperous colony, perched here on the southeast edge of China, is still Asia's most popular tourist spot, perhaps because it offers so much enjoyment at so little cost in money or harassment.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild rejected today The St. Louis Globe-Democrat's latest offer to settle an eight-day-old strike.

LISBON -- The biggest dollar business in Portugal is now the American tourist, and the secret of last year's 27 per cent rise over 1957 in the number of American visitors, according to the tourists themselves, the easy-going atmosphere.
THE viburnums play many roles in home landscaping -- as screens, hedges, in the border, foundation plantings and as lawn specimens. These attractive shrubs are planted in early spring.

VIENNA -- Unless the Government of Austria changes its mind, which it has shown no signs of doing, visitors to Vienna this summer will have the opportunity of seeing and presumably talking to thousands of young people from Communist countries who will be gathered here for the World Youth Festival during the last week of July.
ATLANTA, Feb. 28 -- Leaders of regional higher education programs in the South, the West and New England will meet July 5 in White Sulphur Spring, W. Va., to review progress in this field.

One of the most interesting personalities in the industrial field in western canada is a slim, unassuming man who is both president of the-giant British Columbia Electric Company and Chancellor of the University of British Columbia here.

WILLIAM SAROYAN'S new play, "Ah, Sweet Mystery of Mrs. Murphy," was a warm and reassuring testament that life is worth living, a short work of only forty minutes that had its own touching faith in man's ability to rise above his omnipresent problems.
LENINGRAD, March 1 -- British-Soviet talks on international problems reopened unexpectedly here today in a slightly warmed atmosphere.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 1 -- The launching of a moon-probing rocket was postponed here tonight because of technical difficulties.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 1 -- Ted Williams, baseball's highest-paid performer and often its most controversial figure, reported for spring training with the Boston Red Sox today. Within an hour after he had donned his uniform with the familiar No. 9, Williams was doing what he does best -- swinging a bat.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Supreme Court, in a little-noticed action last week, gave evidence that it does respond to criticism.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Sporadic radio signals tend to indicate that the Discoverer rocket launched last night from the California coast has achieved orbit, the Air Force said tonight.

The National Bureau of Economic Research has for a number of years now devoted a considerable part of its efforts to the subject of national productivity. It is continuing to cultivate this significant area of economic inquiry in a number of separate, but related, studies -- some recently published in the press.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 1 -- The Foreign Minister of Iran said today his country awaited some sign from the Soviet Union of "goodwill and understanding." But All Asghar Hekmat added that he was pessimistic about receiving either from the Russians.

SYRACUSE, March 1 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals kept the New York Knickerbockers from clinching second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association today as they triumphed, 140 -- 115. It was their fifth straight home victory.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Sunbeam Corporation, Chicago, of paying discriminatory advertising allowances to favored customers.

There really seemed to be a serious risk in being assistant and general Man Friday to Sarah Benton, the celebrated roving photographer. Penn State yesterday protested Manhattan's victory in the track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletics of America at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Casey Stengel took time out today to take a brief inventory of the Yankee pitching resources.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., March 1 -- Gene Kotlarek, who has been pegged as a youngster who is going to put the United States on the ski-jumping map, just missed beating one of Finland's best today.

ST. LOUIS, March 1 (UPI) -- Free throws by Cliff Hagan and Si Green within the last 90 seconds of the game today gave the St. Louis Hawks a 104-102 victory over the Boston Celtics in a nationally televised National Basketball Association contest.

A cable ship finished splicing work yesterday on the trans-Atlantic telephone cable whose breaking resulted in the boarding of a Soviet trawler by the United States Navy.

With the advice of West German specialists who have played an important part in the economic recovery of their own country, Pakistan is making an important change in economic planning. " Every family in America has benefited in some way from the work of the Red Cross," President Eisenhower said recently. He went on to note that 79,500 disaster victims had been "sheltered, fed and restored to strength" in the last year.

Those who regard Prime Minister Macmillan's trip to Russia as a failure would do well to compare it with Prime Minister Chamberlain's visit to Munich in 1938. Mr. Chamberlain tried to keep the peace by selling the Sudetenland to Hitler. As a civilized man, Mr. Macmillan has shown an earnest desire to keep the peace but he has not sold to Mr. Khrushchev today's equivalent of the Sudetenland, the city of West Berlin.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Maurice Glick of Baltimore won the South Atlantic women's amateur golf crown today, 2 and 1, from the defending champion, Judy Bell of Wichita, Kan. The match was played on the Ellinor Village Country Club course.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 1 -- There was an unusual development in the eighty-third specialty of the Pekingese Club of America tonight when Mrs. Richard S. Quigley's Nia Bon Tia of Orchard Hill from Lock Haven, Pa., became the best-of-breed winner.

Prices of cotton futures turned reactionary last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close on Friday, small net changes were mixed at 70 cents a bale higher to 40 cents a bale lower than a week ago.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Department of Commerce has reported that world production of steel declined by a little more than 6 per cent last year, mostly because of the recession. It said that production now was "considerably ahead" of last year.
CHICAGO, March 1 -- (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks strengthened their hold on second place in the National Hockey League with a 3-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has been assured of "terrific support" if he enters the Democratic Presidential primary in New Hampshire next year.

A legislative hearing in Albany today will listen to opposing arguments on the question whether a constitutional amendment to exempt $500,000,000 in bond issue borrowing for school construction in New York City from the legal debt limit shall be submitted to the people in referendum. The proposal has already been approved by one Legislature; now the Legislature newly elected last November must act.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is planning to ask for a substantial increase in commutation fares. It did not say when it would seek the rise or how much it would ask for. George Alpert, the president of the road, disclosed its decision to raise fares again in the company's annual report mailed to stockholders over the week-end.
The American Export liner Constitution and the Norwegian oil tanker Jalanta collided in fog outside New York harbor shortly before 11 A. M. yesterday. No one was injured.

Six Barnard College faculty members have been promoted to the rank of professor, three to associate professor and three to assistant professor. In making the announcement yesterday Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, the president, said the promotions would take effect July 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 1 -- Ellen Bongard of Scarsdale qualified for the national final of the Alfred B. Maclay Trophy equitation championship today. She completed her eligibility at the Secor Farms Riding Club show by winning a Maclay class for the second time this season.
Three steamship lines and a maritime trade group have announced staff appointments and a shifting of executive personnel.

ROME, March 1 -- Pope John XXIII started the fifth month of his pontificate today by tackling a crowded schedule that included a visit to a workers' district.

HAVANA, March 1 -- Thousands of persons may be stripped of money and property under a new law authorizing the Cuban Government to confiscate all properties of former collaborators with the Batista regime.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 1 -- Political developments around Berlin caused a waiting attitude at the Stock Exchange last week. There were no signs of selling pressure, but there was little inclination to enter into fresh commitments.

Grosvenor Neighborhood House will benefit from the April 29 performance of "Destry Rides Again." The musical, starring Andy Griffith and Dolores Gray, will open April 23 at the Imperial Theatre.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., March 1 (AP) -- Finland's Juhani Jarvinen covered 1,500 meters over the Olympic speed skating oval today in 2 minutes 6.3 seconds, smashing the world record.

CAGNES-SUR-MER, France, March 1 -- Jamin is a 6-year-old French trotter with a taste for luxury. Transported about Europe in a handsome paneled van, he lives in plush stalls that are double-locked like safe deposit boxes. When his appetite lags, it is stimulated with his favorite food, artichokes.
The American Home Products Corporation and its subsidiaries increased its consolidated net earnings to $42,435,683 last year from $38,617,510 in 1957, the report disclosed today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- After ninety-three years of unbroken opposition, the Nationalist party assumed power today in a change of government that carried on Uruguay's democratic traditions.

Verdi's "Don Carlo" will return to the Metropolitan Opera after a year's absence on Saturday evening, March 14. On the Monday preceding, Lily Pons will return to the opera house to sing the title role in the season's final performance of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor."

Affiliated Fund, Inc., has reported net assets of $524,629,520, equal to $7.27 a share as of Jan. 31, end of its first fiscal quarter. This compared with $477,785,334, equal to $6.94 a share on Oct. 31, 1958, end of the fiscal year.

FOUR American educators participated yesterday in a televised exchange of views on the subject "Is America Anti-Intellectual?" The discussion, part of "The Great Challenge" series over Channel 2, was informal and sometimes amusing.

Clifford Curzon, now a Commander of the British Empire, gave his only New York recital on Saturday evening in Hunter College. His program consisted of Schubert's Sonata in A (Op. 120), Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (Op. 111), Schumann's "Scenes of Childhood" and three Brahms works -- the D minor Capriccio and E major Intermezzo, both from Op. 116, and the second book of "Paganini Variations."

The Beresford, an outstanding apartment house at 211 Central Park West with illuminated towers overlooking Central Park, has been sold by Max N. and Norbert Natanson, realty investors. It was bought by a client of Henry L. Connors, lawyer, through Joseph C. Lombardi, vice president of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked Congress for specific authority to seek receiverships in its anti-fraud cases. This despite an S. E. C. contention that the courts already can appoint such receivers under their "inherent powers."

HIS BEATITUDE MAKARIOS III, Greek Orthodox Archbishop and Ethnarch of Cyprus, is not a majestic figure. But he has a dynamic presence. His speech is quick and firm; his manner confident; his black eyes are bright with intelligence.

MOSCOW, March 1--Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was quoted today as having told a foreign Ambassador here that his strongly worded foreign policy speech in the Kremlin last Tuesday was "only an electioneering speech."
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that Mayor Wagner's defense of the political leadership of Carmine G. De Sapio had come to him as "a little surprise."

ERIC COSBY Esq. bristles at the mention of nylon bristles. The thought offends him. All brushes, in his opinion, should be made from real bristles. And real bristles come from a hog. An urbane Englishman who is chairman of the world's oldest brush company, Kent of London, Mr. Cosby is now here to visit the concern's New York offices.

The jazz musician who has composed a body of material of sufficient interest and variety to sustain a full concert is a rarity. Even rarer is the jazz-man-composer who is given the opportunity to perform a full-dress program of his works in New York.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 1 -- The doors to the Leipzig fairgrounds swung open at 10 A. M. today and immediately gears began to grind and wheels to turn.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., March 1 -- Two youths were killed here early today when their auto skidded off Montauk Highway and struck a tree. The 19-year-old driver was seriously injured.

THE city of New York has a bagful of problems -- taxes, traffic, housing, crime, politics, sin -- but it can find the energy to commemorate a musician. Like many places in Europe, it is observing the 200th anniversary of the death of Handel with a festival.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin charged today that the Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, had led his Senate colleagues in directions "directly contrary" to those spelled out in the party's platforms.

HONG KONG, March 1 -- Marshal Peng Teh-huai, Deputy Premier and Defense Minister of Communist China, warned tonight that Peiping would regard any "imperialist" assault on East Germany as an "attack on the whole Socialist camp."
Last night marked the official opening of the annual drive on behalf of the Red Cross. This is a cause to which all of us can and should give whole-hearted and warm-hearted support.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city might have to impose a payroll tax to balance its 1959-60 expense budget without curtailing essential services.
" Mozart and Kirchner" was the billing of yesterday afternoon's program at the New School for Social Research and, although Alexander Schneider had a major role in the concert, the title was apt.

The Judson Health Center at 34 Spring Street will be the beneficiary of the March 30 evening performance of "Redhead" at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. Tickets may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

PATERSON, N. J., March 1 (AP) -- Assemblyman Edward J. Crabiel, Democrat of Middlesex, said today he would introduce legislation to try to obtain aid from the Port of New York Authority to solve the transit problem.

PITTSBURGH, Mar. 1 -- Last week's steel activity started laying the groundwork for a new record in steelmaking for the first half. In 1956, slightly more than 62,500,000 tons of steel ingots were poured in the first six months.

LENINGRAD, March 1 -- In the spring of 1946 Leningrad was like a beautiful woman recovering from a long and wasting illness. The city that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan saw yesterday and today has been restored to all its former beauty.

Why do the British publish more new books than Americans who outproduce them in about everything else? Last year, according to a Publishers Weekly report, 11,012 new titles were brought out in the United States, against 16,172 in Britain.
The forces of evil are as active today against Christ and His Church as they were centuries ago, the Rev. Francis X. Cronin declared yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Richard Osiier, pianist, was presented at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon as an event of the Concert Artists of Pittsburgh New Friends of Music series.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Some 3,500 labor leaders will bring pressure on Congress this week to approve multibillion dollar housing, airport and school construction programs.
New York University had to fight off a hustling City College squad before going on to an 80166 victory at the Violets' gymnasium in the Bronx last night.

Though no official action was taken, Manhattan's narrow team victory over Penn State in last Saturday's Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America indoor track and field championships remained under hot challenge yesterday.

Many New Yorkers have long cherished a secret dream. Some day at high noon all traffic in the city will halt, choked in its own excess. Every street will be filled to the brim. Not a vehicle will be able to move.

Today's new film is "Stranger in My Arms," a romantic melodrama starring June Allyson and Jeff Chandler, at the Odeon Theatre, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street. The Universal-International release was directed by Helmut Kautner and produced by Ross Hunter.
VIENNA, March 2 -- Austria's coalition Government, which has given the country political stability for more than a decade, is displaying symptoms of disintegration.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Defense Department said today that if the Discoverer satellite was lost in space it was because of the failure of equipment and not the failure to notify Moonwatch observers.

Ben H. Willingham, president, of the General Shoe Corporation, reported yesterday that sales for the quarter ended Jan. 31 increased 14 per cent to $62,553,000 from the $54,929,000 volume for the similar three months a year ago earlier.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company cleared $5,886,566 in the final quarter of last year, more than double the $2,883,404 of the 1957 fourth quarter. This enabled the company to increase earnings for 1958 10 per cent above those of 1957, R. S. Stevenson, president, reported.

AN amateur statistician sitting alone in a joint can while away some happy hours, according to his capacity, with the Federal Government's latest figures on fishing and hunting. He can come to some lovely conclusions at about the time he is no longer able to see the figures.
The Coast Guard will start an investigation this morning into the collision between the liner Constitution and the Norwegian tanker Jalanta.
Patronessen have been announced for the second and Diamonds Ball of the Heart and Lung Foundation. The event will take place in the ballroom of the Plaza on April 7.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday record gross sales revenues for 1958.
HAMILTON, Ohio, March 2 (AP) -- A bank robber took $25,895 here today, drove to the airport, stole an airplane and flew away.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Republican majorities in the Legislature were reported close to an agreement tonight on modifications of Governor Rockefeller's budget and tax programs.
The bond market continued yesterday to register an unusual accompaniment of strength to the high-climbing stock market.

Leo Halliwell and his wife Jessie recently returned to this country after serving thirty years as Seventh-day Adventist medical missionaries in the Amazon jungle. When they first arrived on the Amazon, the native population was ravaged by malaria, leprosy, smallpox and malnutrition, and there wasn't a doctor in the whole area of 3,000,000 square miles.
Thirty-six Queens civic and business leaders discussed a plan yesterday to convert part of traffic-choked Jamaica Avenue into a pedestrian mall in the center of a "dream" shopping area.

WHITE PLAINS, March 2 -- Deer have become so numerous and bothersome in Westchester that the county Board of Supervisors unanimously asked the Legislature today to sanction the use of firearms to kill them in hunting seasons.
In his first legal move as a lawyer, Eugene J. Moran yesterday served papers on the District Attorney's office to show why his father, James J. Moran, should not be freed from prison.
Twenty-six members of the New York Police Department balked yesterday when asked to sign limited waivers of immunity before appearing before the Brooklyn grand jury investigating police corruption.

KATOWICE, Poland, March 2 (AP) -- Richard Meredith of Minneapolis was injured today in the opening minutes of a rough ice hockey game between the United States and Poland, won by the Americans, 5 -- 1.
Helicopter service to the Wall Street area, starting this summer, appeared assured yesterday.
GENEVA, March 2 -- The United States and Britain sought today to dispel Soviet fears of being automatically outvoted in the proposed organization for controlling a ban on testing nuclear weapons.

As heads of the Alumni Associations of City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges, representing 150,000 living alumni of the municipal college system, we ask you to help us increase public awareness that financial assistance from the state to these colleges is imperative.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The top award of a $7,500 scholarship in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search went tonight to John S. Letcher of Lexington, Va. He is a 17-year-old senior at The Baylor School in Chattanooga, Tenn.

LUXEMBOURG, March 2 -- The six-nation European Coal and Steel Community is moving toward a declaration of a "manifest crisis" in its coal industry. This would allow the imposition of mining and importing quotas.
DETROIT, March 2 (AP) -- A police slowdown strike continued today as authorities threatened suspension of patrolmen found neglectful of duty.

The Continental Oil Company has moved to expand its refining and marketing operations in the Middle West. It has offered to purchase the assets of International Refineries, Inc., and Western Oil and Fuel Company, both of Minneapolis, Minn.

The election of Howard E. Simpson, J. Theodore Wolfe and C. T. Crossfield as additional directors of the Commercial Credit Company was announced yesterday. The action increases the size of the board to nineteen members.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Congressional investigators called today for more meat and less fat on United States hogs.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Senator Frank Church urged the Administration today to ask the Soviet Union for a ban on testing nuclear weapons limited to explosions in the earth's atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Miss Diane Carroll, daughter of Senator John Carroll, may have to decide between her $12,000-a-year job as an aide to her father and a full schedule law course at Georgetown University Law School. Miss Carroll is 27 years old.

HAMBURGER HEAVEN is twenty years old. The chain of four quick lunch counters celebrated the occasion this week with the opening of a fifth establishment at 1044 Madison Avenue, corner of Seventy-ninth Street.

The deficit-ridden Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad yesterday was forced to liquidate one of its most valuable assets. It sold its holdings of 15 per cent of the voting shares of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad stock.

ROME. March 2 -- The Government has decreased the importance of Latin in Italian education by decreeing that henceforth 14-year-old boys and girls will not be required to show their proficiency in translating Italian into Latin to get their secondary school diplomas.
MOSCOW, March 2 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to a foreign ministers conference on Germany, but put forward conditions previously rejected by the West.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that consecutive sentences might be given a possessor of heroin for purchase of the narcotic from an unstamped package and for receiving it when knowing it had been illegally imported.
By disclosing that a second Federal grand jury was investigating the affairs of Alexander L. Guterma, the Government yesterday obtained a two-week delay in a criminal hearing for the financier.

LONDON, March 2 -- The Labor party leadership tonight asked John Stonehouse, one of its members of Parliament, to return from his controversial tour of the Central African Federation, which has resulted in his being declared a "prohibited immigrant" by the Federation Government.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March Although the United States is seeking to hurl a flying laboratory past the moon, it is not prepared to follow it during all of its flight past its target.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Mayor Wagner and City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa clashed publicly today over the need fo ra $500,000,000 school construction bond issue exempt from New York City's debt limit.
Samuel Wechsler, who operates a women's and children's apparel store in Passaic, N. H. J., took control yesterday of James McCutcheon Co., 104-year-old linen store here.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Margaret M. Henderson donned the eagles of a full colonel and assumed direction of all Women Marines in a ceremony today.

The importance of properly functioning radio equipment on artificial satellites has been vividly illustrated in the case of the Discoverer satellite. If the Discoverer has gone into orbit -- and random, erratic radio signals lead the Air Force to believe it has -- then it has been "lost," because no regularly scheduled signals are being received from it.

IN the stocky man with thick-lensed spectacles and a hearing aid, it is difficult to recognize the Oxford-educated descendant of a line of British diplomats. He appears at news conferences with neither tie nor jacket, his shirtfront flecked with shreds of tobacco from the pipe that is usually in his hand or mouth.
ALBANY, March 2 -- One of Governor Rockefeller's chief legislative aides announced today that he was supporting a program that the Governor opposed.

PARIS, March 2 -- The new Soviet note on German affairs was viewed here as "quite tough and disappointing" on substantive matters despite some concessions on procedures for a foreign ministers' meeting.

CLASSES C and D in minor league baseball are considerably more than a hoot and a holler from the major leagues. So the smart young man who plays in those lowly ranks either does well and moves up or sees the light and leaves for home.
In accepting a foreign minister's conference subject to its own conditions, the Soviet Union seemed yesterday almost to be repeating its performance of a year ago.

COLUMBIA, Mo., March 2 (AP) -- The opening session of the World Press Congress today developed a sharp floor debate on whether North American news media had reported accurately the background and development of Fidel Castro's successful Cuban revolution.

A young American consul from Massachusetts has managed to establish a six-club baseball league at Brazzaville in the new Congo Republic. The equipment is not quite standard. Since there are no gloves or masks, the ball is made of soft rubber. But the bats, turned out from a local wood, are splendid. And the boys on the Congo are just beginning to learn about baseball, but they love to bat.
